alone over their wine, in a well-furnished dining parlor, in\r\nthe town of P\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94, in Kentucky. There were no servants present, and the\r\ngentlemen, with chairs closely approaching, seemed to be discussing\r\nsome subject with great earnestness.\r\n\r\nFor convenience sake, we have said, hitherto, two _gentlemen_. One of\r\nthe parties, however, when critically examined, did not seem, strictly\r\nspeaking, to come under the species. He was a short, thick-set man,\r\nwith coarse, commonplace features, and that swaggering air of\r\npretension which marks a low man who is trying to elbow his way upward\r\nin the world. He was much over-dressed, in a gaudy vest of many colors,\r\na blue neckerchief, bedropped gayly with yellow spots, and arranged\r\nwith a flaunting tie, quite in keeping with the general air of the man.\r\nHis hands, large and coarse, were plentifully bedecked with rings; and\r\nhe wore a heavy gold watch-chain, with a bundle of seals of portentous\r\nsize, and a great variety of colors, attached to it,\xe2\x80\x94which, in the\r\nardor of conversation, he was in the habit of flourishing and jingling\r\nwith evident satisfaction. His conversation was in free and easy\r\ndefiance of Murray\xe2\x80\x99s Grammar,[1] and was garnished at convenient\r\nintervals with various profane expressions, which not even the desire\r\nto be graphic in our account shall induce us to transcribe.\r\n\r\n [1] English Grammar (1795), by Lindley Murray (1745-1826), the most\r\n authoritative American grammarian of his day.\r\n\r\n\r\nHis companion, Mr. Shelby, had the appearance of a gentleman; and the\r\narrangements of the house, and the general air of the housekeeping,\r\nindicated easy, and even opulent circumstances. As we before stated,\r\nthe two were in the midst of an earnest conversation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is the way I should arrange the matter,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Shelby.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t make trade that way\xe2\x80\x94I positively can\xe2\x80\x99t, Mr. Shelby,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nother, holding up a glass of wine between his eye and the light.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, the fact is, Haley, Tom is an uncommon fellow; he is certainly\r\nworth that sum anywhere,\xe2\x80\x94steady, honest, capable, manages my whole farm\r\nlike a clock.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou mean honest, as niggers go,\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley, helping himself to a\r\nglass of brandy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; I mean, really, Tom is a good, steady, sensible, pious fellow. He\r\ngot religion at a camp-meeting, four years ago; and I believe he really\r\n_did_ get it. I\xe2\x80\x99ve trusted him, since then, with everything I\r\nhave,\xe2\x80\x94money, house, horses,\xe2\x80\x94and let him come and go round the country;\r\nand I always found him true and square in everything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSome folks don\xe2\x80\x99t believe there is pious niggers Shelby,\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley,\r\nwith a candid flourish of his hand, \xe2\x80\x9cbut _I do_. I had a fellow, now,\r\nin this yer last lot I took to Orleans\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98t was as good as a meetin, now,\r\nreally, to hear that critter pray; and he was quite gentle and quiet\r\nlike. He fetched me a good sum, too, for I bought him cheap of a man\r\nthat was \xe2\x80\x99bliged to sell out; so I realized six hundred on him. Yes, I\r\nconsider religion a valeyable thing in a nigger, when it\xe2\x80\x99s the genuine\r\narticle, and no mistake.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Tom\xe2\x80\x99s got the real article, if ever a fellow had,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined the\r\nother. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy, last fall, I let him go to Cincinnati alone, to do\r\nbusiness for me, and bring home five hundred dollars. \xe2\x80\x98Tom,\xe2\x80\x99 says I to\r\nhim, \xe2\x80\x98I trust you, because I think you\xe2\x80\x99re a Christian\xe2\x80\x94I know you\r\nwouldn\xe2\x80\x99t cheat.\xe2\x80\x99 Tom comes back, sure enough; I knew he would. Some low\r\nfellows, they say, said to him\xe2\x80\x94Tom, why don\xe2\x80\x99t you make tracks for\r\nCanada?\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x99Ah, master trusted me, and I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94they told me about\r\nit. I am sorry to part with Tom, I must say. You ought to let him cover\r\nthe whole balance of the debt; and you would, Haley, if you had any\r\nconscience.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I\xe2\x80\x99ve got just as much conscience as any man in business can\r\nafford to keep,\xe2\x80\x94just a little, you know, to swear by, as \xe2\x80\x99t were,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nthe trader, jocularly; \xe2\x80\x9cand, then, I\xe2\x80\x99m ready to do anything in reason\r\nto \xe2\x80\x99blige friends; but this yer, you see, is a leetle too hard on a\r\nfellow\xe2\x80\x94a leetle too hard.\xe2\x80\x9d The trader sighed contemplatively, and\r\npoured out some more brandy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, Haley, how will you trade?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Shelby, after an\r\nuneasy interval of silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, haven\xe2\x80\x99t you a boy or gal that you could throw in with Tom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHum!\xe2\x80\x94none that I could well spare; to tell the truth, it\xe2\x80\x99s only hard\r\nnecessity makes me willing to sell at all. I don\xe2\x80\x99t like parting with\r\nany of my hands, that\xe2\x80\x99s a fact.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHere the door opened, and a small quadroon boy, between four and five\r\nyears of age, entered the room. There was something in his appearance\r\nremarkably beautiful and engaging. His black hair, fine as floss silk,\r\nhung in glossy curls about his round, dimpled face, while a pair of\r\nlarge dark eyes, full of fire and softness, looked out from beneath the\r\nrich, long lashes, as he peered curiously into the apartment. A gay\r\nrobe of scarlet and yellow plaid, carefully made and neatly fitted, set\r\noff to advantage the dark and rich style of his beauty; and a certain\r\ncomic air of assurance, blended with bashfulness, showed that he had\r\nbeen not unused to being petted and noticed by his master.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHulloa, Jim Crow!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Shelby, whistling, and snapping a bunch of\r\nraisins towards him, \xe2\x80\x9cpick that up, now!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe child scampered, with all his little strength, after the prize,\r\nwhile his master laughed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome here, Jim Crow,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. The child came up, and the master\r\npatted the curly head, and chucked him under the chin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, Jim, show this gentleman how you can dance and sing.\xe2\x80\x9d The boy\r\ncommenced one of those wild, grotesque songs common among the negroes,\r\nin a rich, clear voice, accompanying his singing with many comic\r\nevolutions of the hands, feet, and whole body, all in perfect time to\r\nthe music.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBravo!\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley, throwing him a quarter of an orange.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, Jim, walk like old Uncle Cudjoe, when he has the rheumatism,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid his master.\r\n\r\nInstantly the flexible limbs of the child assumed the appearance of\r\ndeformity and distortion, as, with his back humped up, and his master\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nstick in his hand, he hobbled about the room, his childish face drawn\r\ninto a doleful pucker, and spitting from right to left, in imitation of\r\nan old man.\r\n\r\nBoth gentlemen laughed uproariously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, Jim,\xe2\x80\x9d said his master, \xe2\x80\x9cshow us how old Elder Robbins leads the\r\npsalm.\xe2\x80\x9d The boy drew his chubby face down to a formidable length, and\r\ncommenced toning a psalm tune through his nose, with imperturbable\r\ngravity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHurrah! bravo! what a young \xe2\x80\x99un!\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley; \xe2\x80\x9cthat chap\xe2\x80\x99s a case,\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll promise. Tell you what,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, suddenly clapping his hand on\r\nMr. Shelby\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder, \xe2\x80\x9cfling in that chap, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll settle the\r\nbusiness\xe2\x80\x94I will. Come, now, if that ain\xe2\x80\x99t doing the thing up about the\r\nrightest!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this moment, the door was pushed gently open, and a young quadroon\r\nwoman, apparently about twenty-five, entered the room.\r\n\r\nThere needed only a glance from the child to her, to identify her as\r\nits mother. There was the same rich, full, dark eye, with its long\r\nlashes; the same ripples of silky black hair. The brown of her\r\ncomplexion gave way on the cheek to a perceptible flush, which deepened\r\nas she saw the gaze of the strange man fixed upon her in bold and\r\nundisguised admiration. Her dress was of the neatest possible fit, and\r\nset off to advantage her finely moulded shape;\xe2\x80\x94a delicately formed hand\r\nand a trim foot and ankle were items of appearance that did not escape\r\nthe quick eye of the trader, well used to run up at a glance the points\r\nof a fine female article.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Eliza?\xe2\x80\x9d said her master, as she stopped and looked hesitatingly\r\nat him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was looking for Harry, please, sir;\xe2\x80\x9d and the boy bounded toward her,\r\nshowing his spoils, which he had gathered in the skirt of his robe.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, take him away then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Shelby; and hastily she withdrew,\r\ncarrying the child on her arm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy Jupiter,\xe2\x80\x9d said the trader, turning to him in admiration, \xe2\x80\x9cthere\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nan article, now! You might make your fortune on that ar gal in Orleans,\r\nany day. I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen over a thousand, in my day, paid down for gals not a\r\nbit handsomer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want to make my fortune on her,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Shelby, dryly; and,\r\nseeking to turn the conversation, he uncorked a bottle of fresh wine,\r\nand asked his companion\xe2\x80\x99s opinion of it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCapital, sir,\xe2\x80\x94first chop!\xe2\x80\x9d said the trader; then turning, and slapping\r\nhis hand familiarly on Shelby\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder, he added\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, how will you trade about the gal?\xe2\x80\x94what shall I say for\r\nher\xe2\x80\x94what\xe2\x80\x99ll you take?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Haley, she is not to be sold,\xe2\x80\x9d said Shelby. \xe2\x80\x9cMy wife would not\r\npart with her for her weight in gold.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, ay! women always say such things, cause they ha\xe2\x80\x99nt no sort of\r\ncalculation. Just show \xe2\x80\x99em how many watches, feathers, and trinkets,\r\none\xe2\x80\x99s weight in gold would buy, and that alters the case, _I_ reckon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI tell you, Haley, this must not be spoken of; I say no, and I mean\r\nno,\xe2\x80\x9d said Shelby, decidedly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you\xe2\x80\x99ll let me have the boy, though,\xe2\x80\x9d said the trader; \xe2\x80\x9cyou must\r\nown I\xe2\x80\x99ve come down pretty handsomely for him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat on earth can you want with the child?\xe2\x80\x9d said Shelby.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, I\xe2\x80\x99ve got a friend that\xe2\x80\x99s going into this yer branch of the\r\nbusiness\xe2\x80\x94wants to buy up handsome boys to raise for the market. Fancy\r\narticles entirely\xe2\x80\x94sell for waiters, and so on, to rich \xe2\x80\x99uns, that can\r\npay for handsome \xe2\x80\x99uns. It sets off one of yer great places\xe2\x80\x94a real\r\nhandsome boy to open door, wait, and tend. They fetch a good sum; and\r\nthis little devil is such a comical, musical concern, he\xe2\x80\x99s just the\r\narticle!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would rather not sell him,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Shelby, thoughtfully; \xe2\x80\x9cthe fact\r\nis, sir, I\xe2\x80\x99m a humane man, and I hate to take the boy from his mother,\r\nsir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, you do?\xe2\x80\x94La! yes\xe2\x80\x94something of that ar natur. I understand,\r\nperfectly. It is mighty onpleasant getting on with women, sometimes, I\r\nal\xe2\x80\x99ays hates these yer screechin,\xe2\x80\x99 screamin\xe2\x80\x99 times. They are _mighty_\r\nonpleasant; but, as I manages business, I generally avoids \xe2\x80\x99em, sir.\r\nNow, what if you get the girl off for a day, or a week, or so; then the\r\nthing\xe2\x80\x99s done quietly,\xe2\x80\x94all over before she comes home. Your wife might\r\nget her some ear-rings, or a new gown, or some such truck, to make up\r\nwith her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m afraid not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLor bless ye, yes! These critters ain\xe2\x80\x99t like white folks, you know;\r\nthey gets over things, only manage right. Now, they say,\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley,\r\nassuming a candid and confidential air, \xe2\x80\x9cthat this kind o\xe2\x80\x99 trade is\r\nhardening to the feelings; but I never found it so. Fact is, I never\r\ncould do things up the way some fellers manage the business. I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen\r\n\xe2\x80\x99em as would pull a woman\xe2\x80\x99s child out of her arms, and set him up to\r\nsell, and she screechin\xe2\x80\x99 like mad all the time;\xe2\x80\x94very bad policy\xe2\x80\x94damages\r\nthe article\xe2\x80\x94makes \xe2\x80\x99em quite unfit for service sometimes. I knew a real\r\nhandsome gal once, in Orleans, as was entirely ruined by this sort o\xe2\x80\x99\r\nhandling. The fellow that was trading for her didn\xe2\x80\x99t want her baby; and\r\nshe was one of your real high sort, when her blood was up. I tell you,\r\nshe squeezed up her child in her arms, and talked, and went on real\r\nawful. It kinder makes my blood run cold to think of \xe2\x80\x99t; and when they\r\ncarried off the child, and locked her up, she jest went ravin\xe2\x80\x99 mad, and\r\ndied in a week. Clear waste, sir, of a thousand dollars, just for want\r\nof management,\xe2\x80\x94there\xe2\x80\x99s where \xe2\x80\x99t is. It\xe2\x80\x99s always best to do the humane\r\nthing, sir; that\xe2\x80\x99s been _my_ experience.\xe2\x80\x9d And the trader leaned back in\r\nhis chair, and folded his arm, with an air of virtuous decision,\r\napparently considering himself a second Wilberforce.\r\n\r\nThe subject appeared to interest the gentleman deeply; for while Mr.\r\nShelby was thoughtfully peeling an orange, Haley broke out afresh, with\r\nbecoming diffidence, but as if actually driven by the force of truth to\r\nsay a few words more.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt don\xe2\x80\x99t look well, now, for a feller to be praisin\xe2\x80\x99 himself; but I\r\nsay it jest because it\xe2\x80\x99s the truth. I believe I\xe2\x80\x99m reckoned to bring in\r\nabout the finest droves of niggers that is brought in,\xe2\x80\x94at least, I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nbeen told so; if I have once, I reckon I have a hundred times,\xe2\x80\x94all in\r\ngood case,\xe2\x80\x94fat and likely, and I lose as few as any man in the\r\nbusiness. And I lays it all to my management, sir; and humanity, sir, I\r\nmay say, is the great pillar of _my_ management.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Shelby did not know what to say, and so he said, \xe2\x80\x9cIndeed!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, I\xe2\x80\x99ve been laughed at for my notions, sir, and I\xe2\x80\x99ve been talked\r\nto. They an\xe2\x80\x99t pop\xe2\x80\x99lar, and they an\xe2\x80\x99t common; but I stuck to \xe2\x80\x99em, sir;\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ve stuck to \xe2\x80\x99em, and realized well on \xe2\x80\x99em; yes, sir, they have paid\r\ntheir passage, I may say,\xe2\x80\x9d and the trader laughed at his joke.\r\n\r\nThere was something so piquant and original in these elucidations of\r\nhumanity, that Mr. Shelby could not help laughing in company. Perhaps\r\nyou laugh too, dear reader; but you know humanity comes out in a\r\nvariety of strange forms now-a-days, and there is no end to the odd\r\nthings that humane people will say and do.\r\n\r\nMr. Shelby\xe2\x80\x99s laugh encouraged the trader to proceed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s strange, now, but I never could beat this into people\xe2\x80\x99s heads.\r\nNow, there was Tom Loker, my old partner, down in Natchez; he was a\r\nclever fellow, Tom was, only the very devil with niggers,\xe2\x80\x94on principle\r\n\xe2\x80\x99t was, you see, for a better hearted feller never broke bread; \xe2\x80\x99t was\r\nhis _system_, sir. I used to talk to Tom. \xe2\x80\x98Why, Tom,\xe2\x80\x99 I used to say,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98when your gals takes on and cry, what\xe2\x80\x99s the use o\xe2\x80\x99 crackin on\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x99em\r\nover the head, and knockin\xe2\x80\x99 on \xe2\x80\x99em round? It\xe2\x80\x99s ridiculous,\xe2\x80\x99 says I,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98and don\xe2\x80\x99t do no sort o\xe2\x80\x99 good. Why, I don\xe2\x80\x99t see no harm in their\r\ncryin\xe2\x80\x99,\xe2\x80\x99 says I; \xe2\x80\x99it\xe2\x80\x99s natur,\xe2\x80\x99 says I, \xe2\x80\x98and if natur can\xe2\x80\x99t blow off one\r\nway, it will another. Besides, Tom,\xe2\x80\x99 says I, \xe2\x80\x98it jest spiles your gals;\r\nthey get sickly, and down in the mouth; and sometimes they gets\r\nugly,\xe2\x80\x94particular yallow gals do,\xe2\x80\x94and it\xe2\x80\x99s the devil and all gettin\xe2\x80\x99 on\r\n\xe2\x80\x99em broke in. Now,\xe2\x80\x99 says I, \xe2\x80\x98why can\xe2\x80\x99t you kinder coax \xe2\x80\x99em up, and\r\nspeak \xe2\x80\x99em fair? Depend on it, Tom, a little humanity, thrown in along,\r\ngoes a heap further than all your jawin\xe2\x80\x99 and crackin\xe2\x80\x99; and it pays\r\nbetter,\xe2\x80\x99 says I, \xe2\x80\x98depend on \xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x99 But Tom couldn\xe2\x80\x99t get the hang on \xe2\x80\x99t;\r\nand he spiled so many for me, that I had to break off with him, though\r\nhe was a good-hearted fellow, and as fair a business hand as is goin\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd do you find your ways of managing do the business better than\r\nTom\xe2\x80\x99s?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Shelby.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, yes, sir, I may say so. You see, when I any ways can, I takes a\r\nleetle care about the onpleasant parts, like selling young uns and\r\nthat,\xe2\x80\x94get the gals out of the way\xe2\x80\x94out of sight, out of mind, you\r\nknow,\xe2\x80\x94and when it\xe2\x80\x99s clean done, and can\xe2\x80\x99t be helped, they naturally\r\ngets used to it. \xe2\x80\x99Tan\xe2\x80\x99t, you know, as if it was white folks, that\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbrought up in the way of \xe2\x80\x99spectin\xe2\x80\x99 to keep their children and wives,\r\nand all that. Niggers, you know, that\xe2\x80\x99s fetched up properly, ha\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99t no\r\nkind of \xe2\x80\x99spectations of no kind; so all these things comes easier.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m afraid mine are not properly brought up, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Shelby.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cS\xe2\x80\x99pose not; you Kentucky folks spile your niggers. You mean well by\r\n\xe2\x80\x99em, but \xe2\x80\x99tan\xe2\x80\x99t no real kindness, arter all. Now, a nigger, you see,\r\nwhat\xe2\x80\x99s got to be hacked and tumbled round the world, and sold to Tom,\r\nand Dick, and the Lord knows who, \xe2\x80\x99tan\xe2\x80\x99t no kindness to be givin\xe2\x80\x99 on\r\nhim notions and expectations, and bringin\xe2\x80\x99 on him up too well, for the\r\nrough and tumble comes all the harder on him arter. Now, I venture to\r\nsay, your niggers would be quite chop-fallen in a place where some of\r\nyour plantation niggers would be singing and whooping like all\r\npossessed. Every man, you know, Mr. Shelby, naturally thinks well of\r\nhis own ways; and I think I treat niggers just about as well as it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\never worth while to treat \xe2\x80\x99em.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a happy thing to be satisfied,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Shelby, with a slight\r\nshrug, and some perceptible feelings of a disagreeable nature.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley, after they had both silently picked their nuts for\r\na season, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat do you say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll think the matter over, and talk with my wife,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Shelby.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMeantime, Haley, if you want the matter carried on in the quiet way\r\nyou speak of, you\xe2\x80\x99d best not let your business in this neighborhood be\r\nknown. It will get out among my boys, and it will not be a particularly\r\nquiet business getting away any of my fellows, if they know it, I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\npromise you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO! certainly, by all means, mum! of course. But I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you. I\xe2\x80\x99m in\r\na devil of a hurry, and shall want to know, as soon as possible, what I\r\nmay depend on,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, rising and putting on his overcoat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, call up this evening, between six and seven, and you shall have\r\nmy answer,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Shelby, and the trader bowed himself out of the\r\napartment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d like to have been able to kick the fellow down the steps,\xe2\x80\x9d said he\r\nto himself, as he saw the door fairly closed, \xe2\x80\x9cwith his impudent\r\nassurance; but he knows how much he has me at advantage. If anybody had\r\never said to me that I should sell Tom down south to one of those\r\nrascally traders, I should have said, \xe2\x80\x99Is thy servant a dog, that he\r\nshould do this thing?\xe2\x80\x99 And now it must come, for aught I see. And\r\nEliza\xe2\x80\x99s child, too! I know that I shall have some fuss with wife about\r\nthat; and, for that matter, about Tom, too. So much for being in\r\ndebt,\xe2\x80\x94heigho! The fellow sees his advantage, and means to push it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPerhaps the mildest form of the system of slavery is to be seen in the\r\nState of Kentucky. The general prevalence of agricultural pursuits of a\r\nquiet and gradual nature, not requiring those periodic seasons of hurry\r\nand pressure that are called for in the business of more southern\r\ndistricts, makes the task of the negro a more healthful and reasonable\r\none; while the master, content with a more gradual style of\r\nacquisition, has not those temptations to hardheartedness which always\r\novercome frail human nature when the prospect of sudden and rapid gain\r\nis weighed in the balance, with no heavier counterpoise than the\r\ninterests of the helpless and unprotected.\r\n\r\nWhoever visits some estates there, and witnesses the good-humored\r\nindulgence of some masters and mistresses, and the affectionate loyalty\r\nof some slaves, might be tempted to dream the oft-fabled poetic legend\r\nof a patriarchal institution, and all that; but over and above the\r\nscene there broods a portentous shadow\xe2\x80\x94the shadow of _law_. So long as\r\nthe law considers all these human beings, with beating hearts and\r\nliving affections, only as so many _things_ belonging to a master,\xe2\x80\x94so\r\nlong as the failure, or misfortune, or imprudence, or death of the\r\nkindest owner, may cause them any day to exchange a life of kind\r\nprotection and indulgence for one of hopeless misery and toil,\xe2\x80\x94so long\r\nit is impossible to make anything beautiful or desirable in the best\r\nregulated administration of slavery.\r\n\r\nMr. Shelby was a fair average kind of man, good-natured and kindly, and\r\ndisposed to easy indulgence of those around him, and there had never\r\nbeen a lack of anything which might contribute to the physical comfort\r\nof the negroes on his estate. He had, however, speculated largely and\r\nquite loosely; had involved himself deeply, and his notes to a large\r\namount had come into the hands of Haley; and this small piece of\r\ninformation is the key to the preceding conversation.\r\n\r\nNow, it had so happened that, in approaching the door, Eliza had caught\r\nenough of the conversation to know that a trader was making offers to\r\nher master for somebody.\r\n\r\nShe would gladly have stopped at the door to listen, as she came out;\r\nbut her mistress just then calling, she was obliged to hasten away.\r\n\r\nStill she thought she heard the trader make an offer for her boy;\xe2\x80\x94could\r\nshe be mistaken? Her heart swelled and throbbed, and she involuntarily\r\nstrained him so tight that the little fellow looked up into her face in\r\nastonishment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEliza, girl, what ails you today?\xe2\x80\x9d said her mistress, when Eliza had\r\nupset the wash-pitcher, knocked down the workstand, and finally was\r\nabstractedly offering her mistress a long nightgown in place of the\r\nsilk dress she had ordered her to bring from the wardrobe.\r\n\r\nEliza started. \xe2\x80\x9cO, missis!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, raising her eyes; then, bursting\r\ninto tears, she sat down in a chair, and began sobbing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, Eliza child, what ails you?\xe2\x80\x9d said her mistress.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO! missis, missis,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eliza, \xe2\x80\x9cthere\xe2\x80\x99s been a trader talking with\r\nmaster in the parlor! I heard him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, silly child, suppose there has.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, missis, _do_ you suppose mas\xe2\x80\x99r would sell my Harry?\xe2\x80\x9d And the poor\r\ncreature threw herself into a chair, and sobbed convulsively.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSell him! No, you foolish girl! You know your master never deals with\r\nthose southern traders, and never means to sell any of his servants, as\r\nlong as they behave well. Why, you silly child, who do you think would\r\nwant to buy your Harry? Do you think all the world are set on him as\r\nyou are, you goosie? Come, cheer up, and hook my dress. There now, put\r\nmy back hair up in that pretty braid you learnt the other day, and\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t go listening at doors any more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, but, missis, _you_ never would give your consent\xe2\x80\x94to\xe2\x80\x94to\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNonsense, child! to be sure, I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t. What do you talk so for? I\r\nwould as soon have one of my own children sold. But really, Eliza, you\r\nare getting altogether too proud of that little fellow. A man can\xe2\x80\x99t put\r\nhis nose into the door, but you think he must be coming to buy him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nReassured by her mistress\xe2\x80\x99 confident tone, Eliza proceeded nimbly and\r\nadroitly with her toilet, laughing at her own fears, as she proceeded.\r\n\r\nMrs. Shelby was a woman of high class, both intellectually and morally.\r\nTo that natural magnanimity and generosity of mind which one often\r\nmarks as characteristic of the women of Kentucky, she added high moral\r\nand religious sensibility and principle, carried out with great energy\r\nand ability into practical results. Her husband, who made no\r\nprofessions to any particular religious character, nevertheless\r\nreverenced and respected the consistency of hers, and stood, perhaps, a\r\nlittle in awe of her opinion. Certain it was that he gave her unlimited\r\nscope in all her benevolent efforts for the comfort, instruction, and\r\nimprovement of her servants, though he never took any decided part in\r\nthem himself. In fact, if not exactly a believer in the doctrine of the\r\nefficiency of the extra good works of saints, he really seemed somehow\r\nor other to fancy that his wife had piety and benevolence enough for\r\ntwo\xe2\x80\x94to indulge a shadowy expectation of getting into heaven through her\r\nsuperabundance of qualities to which he made no particular pretension.\r\n\r\nThe heaviest load on his mind, after his conversation with the trader,\r\nlay in the foreseen necessity of breaking to his wife the arrangement\r\ncontemplated,\xe2\x80\x94meeting the importunities and opposition which he knew he\r\nshould have reason to encounter.\r\n\r\nMrs. Shelby, being entirely ignorant of her husband\xe2\x80\x99s embarrassments,\r\nand knowing only the general kindliness of his temper, had been quite\r\nsincere in the entire incredulity with which she had met Eliza\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsuspicions. In fact, she dismissed the matter from her mind, without a\r\nsecond thought; and being occupied in preparations for an evening\r\nvisit, it passed out of her thoughts entirely.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER II\r\nThe Mother\r\n\r\n\r\nEliza had been brought up by her mistress, from girlhood, as a petted\r\nand indulged favorite.\r\n\r\nThe traveller in the south must often have remarked that peculiar air\r\nof refinement, that softness of voice and manner, which seems in many\r\ncases to be a particular gift to the quadroon and mulatto women. These\r\nnatural graces in the quadroon are often united with beauty of the most\r\ndazzling kind, and in almost every case with a personal appearance\r\nprepossessing and agreeable. Eliza, such as we have described her, is\r\nnot a fancy sketch, but taken from remembrance, as we saw her, years\r\nago, in Kentucky. Safe under the protecting care of her mistress, Eliza\r\nhad reached maturity without those temptations which make beauty so\r\nfatal an inheritance to a slave. She had been married to a bright and\r\ntalented young mulatto man, who was a slave on a neighboring estate,\r\nand bore the name of George Harris.\r\n\r\nThis young man had been hired out by his master to work in a bagging\r\nfactory, where his adroitness and ingenuity caused him to be considered\r\nthe first hand in the place. He had invented a machine for the cleaning\r\nof the hemp, which, considering the education and circumstances of the\r\ninventor, displayed quite as much mechanical genius as Whitney\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncotton-gin.[1]\r\n\r\n [2] A machine of this description was really the invention of a young\r\n colored man in Kentucky. [Mrs. Stowe\xe2\x80\x99s note.]\r\n\r\n\r\nHe was possessed of a handsome person and pleasing manners, and was a\r\ngeneral favorite in the factory. Nevertheless, as this young man was in\r\nthe eye of the law not a man, but a thing, all these superior\r\nqualifications were subject to the control of a vulgar, narrow-minded,\r\ntyrannical master. This same gentleman, having heard of the fame of\r\nGeorge\xe2\x80\x99s invention, took a ride over to the factory, to see what this\r\nintelligent chattel had been about. He was received with great\r\nenthusiasm by the employer, who congratulated him on possessing so\r\nvaluable a slave.\r\n\r\nHe was waited upon over the factory, shown the machinery by George,\r\nwho, in high spirits, talked so fluently, held himself so erect, looked\r\nso handsome and manly, that his master began to feel an uneasy\r\nconsciousness of inferiority. What business had his slave to be\r\nmarching round the country, inventing machines, and holding up his head\r\namong gentlemen? He\xe2\x80\x99d soon put a stop to it. He\xe2\x80\x99d take him back, and\r\nput him to hoeing and digging, and \xe2\x80\x9csee if he\xe2\x80\x99d step about so smart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nAccordingly, the manufacturer and all hands concerned were astounded\r\nwhen he suddenly demanded George\xe2\x80\x99s wages, and announced his intention\r\nof taking him home.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, Mr. Harris,\xe2\x80\x9d remonstrated the manufacturer, \xe2\x80\x9cisn\xe2\x80\x99t this rather\r\nsudden?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat if it is?\xe2\x80\x94isn\xe2\x80\x99t the man _mine_?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe would be willing, sir, to increase the rate of compensation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo object at all, sir. I don\xe2\x80\x99t need to hire any of my hands out,\r\nunless I\xe2\x80\x99ve a mind to.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, sir, he seems peculiarly adapted to this business.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDare say he may be; never was much adapted to anything that I set him\r\nabout, I\xe2\x80\x99ll be bound.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut only think of his inventing this machine,\xe2\x80\x9d interposed one of the\r\nworkmen, rather unluckily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO yes! a machine for saving work, is it? He\xe2\x80\x99d invent that, I\xe2\x80\x99ll be\r\nbound; let a nigger alone for that, any time. They are all labor-saving\r\nmachines themselves, every one of \xe2\x80\x99em. No, he shall tramp!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGeorge had stood like one transfixed, at hearing his doom thus suddenly\r\npronounced by a power that he knew was irresistible. He folded his\r\narms, tightly pressed in his lips, but a whole volcano of bitter\r\nfeelings burned in his bosom, and sent streams of fire through his\r\nveins. He breathed short, and his large dark eyes flashed like live\r\ncoals; and he might have broken out into some dangerous ebullition, had\r\nnot the kindly manufacturer touched him on the arm, and said, in a low\r\ntone,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive way, George; go with him for the present. We\xe2\x80\x99ll try to help you,\r\nyet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe tyrant observed the whisper, and conjectured its import, though he\r\ncould not hear what was said; and he inwardly strengthened himself in\r\nhis determination to keep the power he possessed over his victim.\r\n\r\nGeorge was taken home, and put to the meanest drudgery of the farm. He\r\nhad been able to repress every disrespectful word; but the flashing\r\neye, the gloomy and troubled brow, were part of a natural language that\r\ncould not be repressed,\xe2\x80\x94indubitable signs, which showed too plainly\r\nthat the man could not become a thing.\r\n\r\nIt was during the happy period of his employment in the factory that\r\nGeorge had seen and married his wife. During that period,\xe2\x80\x94being much\r\ntrusted and favored by his employer,\xe2\x80\x94he had free liberty to come and go\r\nat discretion. The marriage was highly approved of by Mrs. Shelby, who,\r\nwith a little womanly complacency in match-making, felt pleased to\r\nunite her handsome favorite with one of her own class who seemed in\r\nevery way suited to her; and so they were married in her mistress\xe2\x80\x99\r\ngreat parlor, and her mistress herself adorned the bride\xe2\x80\x99s beautiful\r\nhair with orange-blossoms, and threw over it the bridal veil, which\r\ncertainly could scarce have rested on a fairer head; and there was no\r\nlack of white gloves, and cake and wine,\xe2\x80\x94of admiring guests to praise\r\nthe bride\xe2\x80\x99s beauty, and her mistress\xe2\x80\x99 indulgence and liberality. For a\r\nyear or two Eliza saw her husband frequently, and there was nothing to\r\ninterrupt their happiness, except the loss of two infant children, to\r\nwhom she was passionately attached, and whom she mourned with a grief\r\nso intense as to call for gentle remonstrance from her mistress, who\r\nsought, with maternal anxiety, to direct her naturally passionate\r\nfeelings within the bounds of reason and religion.\r\n\r\nAfter the birth of little Harry, however, she had gradually become\r\ntranquillized and settled; and every bleeding tie and throbbing nerve,\r\nonce more entwined with that little life, seemed to become sound and\r\nhealthful, and Eliza was a happy woman up to the time that her husband\r\nwas rudely torn from his kind employer, and brought under the iron sway\r\nof his legal owner.\r\n\r\nThe manufacturer, true to his word, visited Mr. Harris a week or two\r\nafter George had been taken away, when, as he hoped, the heat of the\r\noccasion had passed away, and tried every possible inducement to lead\r\nhim to restore him to his former employment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou needn\xe2\x80\x99t trouble yourself to talk any longer,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, doggedly;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know my own business, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI did not presume to interfere with it, sir. I only thought that you\r\nmight think it for your interest to let your man to us on the terms\r\nproposed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, I understand the matter well enough. I saw your winking and\r\nwhispering, the day I took him out of the factory; but you don\xe2\x80\x99t come\r\nit over me that way. It\xe2\x80\x99s a free country, sir; the man\xe2\x80\x99s _mine_, and I\r\ndo what I please with him,\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd so fell George\xe2\x80\x99s last hope;\xe2\x80\x94nothing before him but a life of toil\r\nand drudgery, rendered more bitter by every little smarting vexation\r\nand indignity which tyrannical ingenuity could devise.\r\n\r\nA very humane jurist once said, The worst use you can put a man to is\r\nto hang him. No; there is another use that a man can be put to that is\r\nWORSE!\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER III\r\nThe Husband and Father\r\n\r\n\r\nMrs. Shelby had gone on her visit, and Eliza stood in the verandah,\r\nrather dejectedly looking after the retreating carriage, when a hand\r\nwas laid on her shoulder. She turned, and a bright smile lighted up her\r\nfine eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGeorge, is it you? How you frightened me! Well; I am so glad you \xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncome! Missis is gone to spend the afternoon; so come into my little\r\nroom, and we\xe2\x80\x99ll have the time all to ourselves.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSaying this, she drew him into a neat little apartment opening on the\r\nverandah, where she generally sat at her sewing, within call of her\r\nmistress.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow glad I am!\xe2\x80\x94why don\xe2\x80\x99t you smile?\xe2\x80\x94and look at Harry\xe2\x80\x94how he grows.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nThe boy stood shyly regarding his father through his curls, holding\r\nclose to the skirts of his mother\xe2\x80\x99s dress. \xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t he beautiful?\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nEliza, lifting his long curls and kissing him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish he\xe2\x80\x99d never been born!\xe2\x80\x9d said George, bitterly. \xe2\x80\x9cI wish I\xe2\x80\x99d never\r\nbeen born myself!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSurprised and frightened, Eliza sat down, leaned her head on her\r\nhusband\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder, and burst into tears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere now, Eliza, it\xe2\x80\x99s too bad for me to make you feel so, poor girl!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid he, fondly; \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s too bad: O, how I wish you never had seen me\xe2\x80\x94you\r\nmight have been happy!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGeorge! George! how can you talk so? What dreadful thing has happened,\r\nor is going to happen? I\xe2\x80\x99m sure we\xe2\x80\x99ve been very happy, till lately.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo we have, dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said George. Then drawing his child on his knee, he\r\ngazed intently on his glorious dark eyes, and passed his hands through\r\nhis long curls.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust like you, Eliza; and you are the handsomest woman I ever saw, and\r\nthe best one I ever wish to see; but, oh, I wish I\xe2\x80\x99d never seen you,\r\nnor you me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, George, how can you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Eliza, it\xe2\x80\x99s all misery, misery, misery! My life is bitter as\r\nwormwood; the very life is burning out of me. I\xe2\x80\x99m a poor, miserable,\r\nforlorn drudge; I shall only drag you down with me, that\xe2\x80\x99s all. What\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nthe use of our trying to do anything, trying to know anything, trying\r\nto be anything? What\xe2\x80\x99s the use of living? I wish I was dead!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, now, dear George, that is really wicked! I know how you feel about\r\nlosing your place in the factory, and you have a hard master; but pray\r\nbe patient, and perhaps something\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPatient!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, interrupting her; \xe2\x80\x9chaven\xe2\x80\x99t I been patient? Did I\r\nsay a word when he came and took me away, for no earthly reason, from\r\nthe place where everybody was kind to me? I\xe2\x80\x99d paid him truly every cent\r\nof my earnings,\xe2\x80\x94and they all say I worked well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, it _is_ dreadful,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eliza; \xe2\x80\x9cbut, after all, he is your\r\nmaster, you know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy master! and who made him my master? That\xe2\x80\x99s what I think of\xe2\x80\x94what\r\nright has he to me? I\xe2\x80\x99m a man as much as he is. I\xe2\x80\x99m a better man than\r\nhe is. I know more about business than he does; I am a better manager\r\nthan he is; I can read better than he can; I can write a better\r\nhand,\xe2\x80\x94and I\xe2\x80\x99ve learned it all myself, and no thanks to him,\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nlearned it in spite of him; and now what right has he to make a\r\ndray-horse of me?\xe2\x80\x94to take me from things I can do, and do better than\r\nhe can, and put me to work that any horse can do? He tries to do it; he\r\nsays he\xe2\x80\x99ll bring me down and humble me, and he puts me to just the\r\nhardest, meanest and dirtiest work, on purpose!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, George! George! you frighten me! Why, I never heard you talk so;\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99m afraid you\xe2\x80\x99ll do something dreadful. I don\xe2\x80\x99t wonder at your\r\nfeelings, at all; but oh, do be careful\xe2\x80\x94do, do\xe2\x80\x94for my sake\xe2\x80\x94for\r\nHarry\xe2\x80\x99s!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have been careful, and I have been patient, but it\xe2\x80\x99s growing worse\r\nand worse; flesh and blood can\xe2\x80\x99t bear it any longer;\xe2\x80\x94every chance he\r\ncan get to insult and torment me, he takes. I thought I could do my\r\nwork well, and keep on quiet, and have some time to read and learn out\r\nof work hours; but the more he sees I can do, the more he loads on. He\r\nsays that though I don\xe2\x80\x99t say anything, he sees I\xe2\x80\x99ve got the devil in\r\nme, and he means to bring it out; and one of these days it will come\r\nout in a way that he won\xe2\x80\x99t like, or I\xe2\x80\x99m mistaken!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO dear! what shall we do?\xe2\x80\x9d said Eliza, mournfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was only yesterday,\xe2\x80\x9d said George, \xe2\x80\x9cas I was busy loading stones\r\ninto a cart, that young Mas\xe2\x80\x99r Tom stood there, slashing his whip so\r\nnear the horse that the creature was frightened. I asked him to stop,\r\nas pleasant as I could,\xe2\x80\x94he just kept right on. I begged him again, and\r\nthen he turned on me, and began striking me. I held his hand, and then\r\nhe screamed and kicked and ran to his father, and told him that I was\r\nfighting him. He came in a rage, and said he\xe2\x80\x99d teach me who was my\r\nmaster; and he tied me to a tree, and cut switches for young master,\r\nand told him that he might whip me till he was tired;\xe2\x80\x94and he did do it!\r\nIf I don\xe2\x80\x99t make him remember it, some time!\xe2\x80\x9d and the brow of the young\r\nman grew dark, and his eyes burned with an expression that made his\r\nyoung wife tremble. \xe2\x80\x9cWho made this man my master? That\xe2\x80\x99s what I want to\r\nknow!\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eliza, mournfully, \xe2\x80\x9cI always thought that I must obey my\r\nmaster and mistress, or I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t be a Christian.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is some sense in it, in your case; they have brought you up like\r\na child, fed you, clothed you, indulged you, and taught you, so that\r\nyou have a good education; that is some reason why they should claim\r\nyou. But I have been kicked and cuffed and sworn at, and at the best\r\nonly let alone; and what do I owe? I\xe2\x80\x99ve paid for all my keeping a\r\nhundred times over. I _won\xe2\x80\x99t_ bear it. No, I _won\xe2\x80\x99t_!\xe2\x80\x9d he said,\r\nclenching his hand with a fierce frown.\r\n\r\nEliza trembled, and was silent. She had never seen her husband in this\r\nmood before; and her gentle system of ethics seemed to bend like a reed\r\nin the surges of such passions.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know poor little Carlo, that you gave me,\xe2\x80\x9d added George; \xe2\x80\x9cthe\r\ncreature has been about all the comfort that I\xe2\x80\x99ve had. He has slept\r\nwith me nights, and followed me around days, and kind o\xe2\x80\x99 looked at me\r\nas if he understood how I felt. Well, the other day I was just feeding\r\nhim with a few old scraps I picked up by the kitchen door, and Mas\xe2\x80\x99r\r\ncame along, and said I was feeding him up at his expense, and that he\r\ncouldn\xe2\x80\x99t afford to have every nigger keeping his dog, and ordered me to\r\ntie a stone to his neck and throw him in the pond.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, George, you didn\xe2\x80\x99t do it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo it? not I!\xe2\x80\x94but he did. Mas\xe2\x80\x99r and Tom pelted the poor drowning\r\ncreature with stones. Poor thing! he looked at me so mournful, as if he\r\nwondered why I didn\xe2\x80\x99t save him. I had to take a flogging because I\r\nwouldn\xe2\x80\x99t do it myself. I don\xe2\x80\x99t care. Mas\xe2\x80\x99r will find out that I\xe2\x80\x99m one\r\nthat whipping won\xe2\x80\x99t tame. My day will come yet, if he don\xe2\x80\x99t look out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you going to do? O, George, don\xe2\x80\x99t do anything wicked; if you\r\nonly trust in God, and try to do right, he\xe2\x80\x99ll deliver you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI an\xe2\x80\x99t a Christian like you, Eliza; my heart\xe2\x80\x99s full of bitterness; I\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t trust in God. Why does he let things be so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, George, we must have faith. Mistress says that when all things go\r\nwrong to us, we must believe that God is doing the very best.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s easy to say for people that are sitting on their sofas and\r\nriding in their carriages; but let \xe2\x80\x99em be where I am, I guess it would\r\ncome some harder. I wish I could be good; but my heart burns, and can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nbe reconciled, anyhow. You couldn\xe2\x80\x99t in my place,\xe2\x80\x94you can\xe2\x80\x99t now, if I\r\ntell you all I\xe2\x80\x99ve got to say. You don\xe2\x80\x99t know the whole yet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat can be coming now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, lately Mas\xe2\x80\x99r has been saying that he was a fool to let me marry\r\noff the place; that he hates Mr. Shelby and all his tribe, because they\r\nare proud, and hold their heads up above him, and that I\xe2\x80\x99ve got proud\r\nnotions from you; and he says he won\xe2\x80\x99t let me come here any more, and\r\nthat I shall take a wife and settle down on his place. At first he only\r\nscolded and grumbled these things; but yesterday he told me that I\r\nshould take Mina for a wife, and settle down in a cabin with her, or he\r\nwould sell me down river.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy\xe2\x80\x94but you were married to _me_, by the minister, as much as if you\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nbeen a white man!\xe2\x80\x9d said Eliza, simply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you know a slave can\xe2\x80\x99t be married? There is no law in this\r\ncountry for that; I can\xe2\x80\x99t hold you for my wife, if he chooses to part\r\nus. That\xe2\x80\x99s why I wish I\xe2\x80\x99d never seen you,\xe2\x80\x94why I wish I\xe2\x80\x99d never been\r\nborn; it would have been better for us both,\xe2\x80\x94it would have been better\r\nfor this poor child if he had never been born. All this may happen to\r\nhim yet!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, but master is so kind!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but who knows?\xe2\x80\x94he may die\xe2\x80\x94and then he may be sold to nobody knows\r\nwho. What pleasure is it that he is handsome, and smart, and bright? I\r\ntell you, Eliza, that a sword will pierce through your soul for every\r\ngood and pleasant thing your child is or has; it will make him worth\r\ntoo much for you to keep.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe words smote heavily on Eliza\xe2\x80\x99s heart; the vision of the trader came\r\nbefore her eyes, and, as if some one had struck her a deadly blow, she\r\nturned pale and gasped for breath. She looked nervously out on the\r\nverandah, where the boy, tired of the grave conversation, had retired,\r\nand where he was riding triumphantly up and down on Mr. Shelby\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwalking-stick. She would have spoken to tell her husband her fears, but\r\nchecked herself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no,\xe2\x80\x94he has enough to bear, poor fellow!\xe2\x80\x9d she thought. \xe2\x80\x9cNo, I won\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ntell him; besides, it an\xe2\x80\x99t true; Missis never deceives us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo, Eliza, my girl,\xe2\x80\x9d said the husband, mournfully, \xe2\x80\x9cbear up, now; and\r\ngood-by, for I\xe2\x80\x99m going.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGoing, George! Going where?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo Canada,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, straightening himself up; \xe2\x80\x9cand when I\xe2\x80\x99m there,\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll buy you; that\xe2\x80\x99s all the hope that\xe2\x80\x99s left us. You have a kind\r\nmaster, that won\xe2\x80\x99t refuse to sell you. I\xe2\x80\x99ll buy you and the boy;\xe2\x80\x94God\r\nhelping me, I will!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, dreadful! if you should be taken?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI won\xe2\x80\x99t be taken, Eliza; I\xe2\x80\x99ll _die_ first! I\xe2\x80\x99ll be free, or I\xe2\x80\x99ll die!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou won\xe2\x80\x99t kill yourself!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo need of that. They will kill me, fast enough; they never will get\r\nme down the river alive!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, George, for my sake, do be careful! Don\xe2\x80\x99t do anything wicked; don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nlay hands on yourself, or anybody else! You are tempted too much\xe2\x80\x94too\r\nmuch; but don\xe2\x80\x99t\xe2\x80\x94go you must\xe2\x80\x94but go carefully, prudently; pray God to\r\nhelp you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, Eliza, hear my plan. Mas\xe2\x80\x99r took it into his head to send\r\nme right by here, with a note to Mr. Symmes, that lives a mile past. I\r\nbelieve he expected I should come here to tell you what I have. It\r\nwould please him, if he thought it would aggravate \xe2\x80\x99Shelby\xe2\x80\x99s folks,\xe2\x80\x99 as\r\nhe calls \xe2\x80\x99em. I\xe2\x80\x99m going home quite resigned, you understand, as if all\r\nwas over. I\xe2\x80\x99ve got some preparations made,\xe2\x80\x94and there are those that\r\nwill help me; and, in the course of a week or so, I shall be among the\r\nmissing, some day. Pray for me, Eliza; perhaps the good Lord will hear\r\n_you_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, pray yourself, George, and go trusting in him; then you won\xe2\x80\x99t do\r\nanything wicked.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now, _good-by_,\xe2\x80\x9d said George, holding Eliza\xe2\x80\x99s hands, and gazing\r\ninto her eyes, without moving. They stood silent; then there were last\r\nwords, and sobs, and bitter weeping,\xe2\x80\x94such parting as those may make\r\nwhose hope to meet again is as the spider\xe2\x80\x99s web,\xe2\x80\x94and the husband and\r\nwife were parted.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER IV\r\nAn Evening in Uncle Tom\xe2\x80\x99s Cabin\r\n\r\n\r\nThe cabin of Uncle Tom was a small log building, close adjoining to\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthe house,\xe2\x80\x9d as the negro _par excellence_ designates his master\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndwelling. In front it had a neat garden-patch, where, every summer,\r\nstrawberries, raspberries, and a variety of fruits and vegetables,\r\nflourished under careful tending. The whole front of it was covered by\r\na large scarlet bignonia and a native multiflora rose, which,\r\nentwisting and interlacing, left scarce a vestige of the rough logs to\r\nbe seen. Here, also, in summer, various brilliant annuals, such as\r\nmarigolds, petunias, four-o\xe2\x80\x99clocks, found an indulgent corner in which\r\nto unfold their splendors, and were the delight and pride of Aunt\r\nChloe\xe2\x80\x99s heart.\r\n\r\nLet us enter the dwelling. The evening meal at the house is over, and\r\nAunt Chloe, who presided over its preparation as head cook, has left to\r\ninferior officers in the kitchen the business of clearing away and\r\nwashing dishes, and come out into her own snug territories, to \xe2\x80\x9cget her\r\nole man\xe2\x80\x99s supper\xe2\x80\x9d; therefore, doubt not that it is her you see by the\r\nfire, presiding with anxious interest over certain frizzling items in a\r\nstew-pan, and anon with grave consideration lifting the cover of a\r\nbake-kettle, from whence steam forth indubitable intimations of\r\n\xe2\x80\x9csomething good.\xe2\x80\x9d A round, black, shining face is hers, so glossy as to\r\nsuggest the idea that she might have been washed over with white of\r\neggs, like one of her own tea rusks. Her whole plump countenance beams\r\nwith satisfaction and contentment from under her well-starched checked\r\nturban, bearing on it, however, if we must confess it, a little of that\r\ntinge of self-consciousness which becomes the first cook of the\r\nneighborhood, as Aunt Chloe was universally held and acknowledged to\r\nbe.\r\n\r\nA cook she certainly was, in the very bone and centre of her soul. Not\r\na chicken or turkey or duck in the barn-yard but looked grave when they\r\nsaw her approaching, and seemed evidently to be reflecting on their\r\nlatter end; and certain it was that she was always meditating on\r\ntrussing, stuffing and roasting, to a degree that was calculated to\r\ninspire terror in any reflecting fowl living. Her corn-cake, in all its\r\nvarieties of hoe-cake, dodgers, muffins, and other species too numerous\r\nto mention, was a sublime mystery to all less practised compounders;\r\nand she would shake her fat sides with honest pride and merriment, as\r\nshe would narrate the fruitless efforts that one and another of her\r\ncompeers had made to attain to her elevation.\r\n\r\nThe arrival of company at the house, the arranging of dinners and\r\nsuppers \xe2\x80\x9cin style,\xe2\x80\x9d awoke all the energies of her soul; and no sight\r\nwas more welcome to her than a pile of travelling trunks launched on\r\nthe verandah, for then she foresaw fresh efforts and fresh triumphs.\r\n\r\nJust at present, however, Aunt Chloe is looking into the bake-pan; in\r\nwhich congenial operation we shall leave her till we finish our picture\r\nof the cottage.\r\n\r\nIn one corner of it stood a bed, covered neatly with a snowy spread;\r\nand by the side of it was a piece of carpeting, of some considerable\r\nsize. On this piece of carpeting Aunt Chloe took her stand, as being\r\ndecidedly in the upper walks of life; and it and the bed by which it\r\nlay, and the whole corner, in fact, were treated with distinguished\r\nconsideration, and made, so far as possible, sacred from the marauding\r\ninroads and desecrations of little folks. In fact, that corner was the\r\n_drawing-room_ of the establishment. In the other corner was a bed of\r\nmuch humbler pretensions, and evidently designed for _use_. The wall\r\nover the fireplace was adorned with some very brilliant scriptural\r\nprints, and a portrait of General Washington, drawn and colored in a\r\nmanner which would certainly have astonished that hero, if ever he\r\nhappened to meet with its like.\r\n\r\nOn a rough bench in the corner, a couple of woolly-headed boys, with\r\nglistening black eyes and fat shining cheeks, were busy in\r\nsuperintending the first walking operations of the baby, which, as is\r\nusually the case, consisted in getting up on its feet, balancing a\r\nmoment, and then tumbling down,\xe2\x80\x94each successive failure being violently\r\ncheered, as something decidedly clever.\r\n\r\nA table, somewhat rheumatic in its limbs, was drawn out in front of the\r\nfire, and covered with a cloth, displaying cups and saucers of a\r\ndecidedly brilliant pattern, with other symptoms of an approaching\r\nmeal. At this table was seated Uncle Tom, Mr. Shelby\xe2\x80\x99s best hand, who,\r\nas he is to be the hero of our story, we must daguerreotype for our\r\nreaders. He was a large, broad-chested, powerfully-made man, of a full\r\nglossy black, and a face whose truly African features were\r\ncharacterized by an expression of grave and steady good sense, united\r\nwith much kindliness and benevolence. There was something about his\r\nwhole air self-respecting and dignified, yet united with a confiding\r\nand humble simplicity.\r\n\r\nHe was very busily intent at this moment on a slate lying before him,\r\non which he was carefully and slowly endeavoring to accomplish a copy\r\nof some letters, in which operation he was overlooked by young Mas\xe2\x80\x99r\r\nGeorge, a smart, bright boy of thirteen, who appeared fully to realize\r\nthe dignity of his position as instructor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot that way, Uncle Tom,\xe2\x80\x94not that way,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, briskly, as Uncle Tom\r\nlaboriously brought up the tail of his _g_ the wrong side out; \xe2\x80\x9cthat\r\nmakes a _q_, you see.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLa sakes, now, does it?\xe2\x80\x9d said Uncle Tom, looking with a respectful,\r\nadmiring air, as his young teacher flourishingly scrawled _q_\xe2\x80\x99s and\r\n_g_\xe2\x80\x99s innumerable for his edification; and then, taking the pencil in\r\nhis big, heavy fingers, he patiently recommenced.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow easy white folks al\xe2\x80\x99us does things!\xe2\x80\x9d said Aunt Chloe, pausing\r\nwhile she was greasing a griddle with a scrap of bacon on her fork, and\r\nregarding young Master George with pride. \xe2\x80\x9cThe way he can write, now!\r\nand read, too! and then to come out here evenings and read his lessons\r\nto us,\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s mighty interestin\xe2\x80\x99!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, Aunt Chloe, I\xe2\x80\x99m getting mighty hungry,\xe2\x80\x9d said George. \xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t that\r\ncake in the skillet almost done?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMose done, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r George,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aunt Chloe, lifting the lid and peeping\r\nin,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cbrowning beautiful\xe2\x80\x94a real lovely brown. Ah! let me alone for dat.\r\nMissis let Sally try to make some cake, t\xe2\x80\x99 other day, jes to _larn_\r\nher, she said. \xe2\x80\x98O, go way, Missis,\xe2\x80\x99 said I; \xe2\x80\x98it really hurts my\r\nfeelin\xe2\x80\x99s, now, to see good vittles spilt dat ar way! Cake ris all to\r\none side\xe2\x80\x94no shape at all; no more than my shoe; go way!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd with this final expression of contempt for Sally\xe2\x80\x99s greenness, Aunt\r\nChloe whipped the cover off the bake-kettle, and disclosed to view a\r\nneatly-baked pound-cake, of which no city confectioner need to have\r\nbeen ashamed. This being evidently the central point of the\r\nentertainment, Aunt Chloe began now to bustle about earnestly in the\r\nsupper department.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere you, Mose and Pete! get out de way, you niggers! Get away, Polly,\r\nhoney,\xe2\x80\x94mammy\xe2\x80\x99ll give her baby some fin, by and by. Now, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r George,\r\nyou jest take off dem books, and set down now with my old man, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\ntake up de sausages, and have de first griddle full of cakes on your\r\nplates in less dan no time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey wanted me to come to supper in the house,\xe2\x80\x9d said George; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I\r\nknew what was what too well for that, Aunt Chloe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo you did\xe2\x80\x94so you did, honey,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aunt Chloe, heaping the smoking\r\nbatter-cakes on his plate; \xe2\x80\x9cyou know\xe2\x80\x99d your old aunty\xe2\x80\x99d keep the best\r\nfor you. O, let you alone for dat! Go way!\xe2\x80\x9d And, with that, aunty gave\r\nGeorge a nudge with her finger, designed to be immensely facetious, and\r\nturned again to her griddle with great briskness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow for the cake,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mas\xe2\x80\x99r George, when the activity of the griddle\r\ndepartment had somewhat subsided; and, with that, the youngster\r\nflourished a large knife over the article in question.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLa bless you, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r George!\xe2\x80\x9d said Aunt Chloe, with earnestness,\r\ncatching his arm, \xe2\x80\x9cyou wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be for cuttin\xe2\x80\x99 it wid dat ar great\r\nheavy knife! Smash all down\xe2\x80\x94spile all de pretty rise of it. Here, I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\ngot a thin old knife, I keeps sharp a purpose. Dar now, see! comes\r\napart light as a feather! Now eat away\xe2\x80\x94you won\xe2\x80\x99t get anything to beat\r\ndat ar.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTom Lincon says,\xe2\x80\x9d said George, speaking with his mouth full, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\r\ntheir Jinny is a better cook than you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDem Lincons an\xe2\x80\x99t much count, no way!\xe2\x80\x9d said Aunt Chloe, contemptuously;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mean, set along side _our_ folks. Now, I went over thar when Miss Mary was gwine\r\nto be married, and Jinny she jest showed me de weddin\xe2\x80\x99 pies. Jinny and\r\nI is good friends, ye know.
