I\xe2\x80\x99ll boun\xe2\x80\x99 you pulled \xe2\x80\x99em out; some o\xe2\x80\x99 your shines,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nAunt Chloe.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, it\xe2\x80\x99ll stand, if it only keeps jam up agin de wall!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDen Uncle Peter mus\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99t sit in it, cause he al\xe2\x80\x99ays hitches when he\r\ngets a singing. He hitched pretty nigh across de room, t\xe2\x80\x99 other night,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Pete.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood Lor! get him in it, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mose, \xe2\x80\x9cand den he\xe2\x80\x99d begin, \xe2\x80\x98Come\r\nsaints\xe2\x80\x94and sinners, hear me tell,\xe2\x80\x99 and den down he\xe2\x80\x99d go,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and Mose\r\nimitated precisely the nasal tones of the old man, tumbling on the\r\nfloor, to illustrate the supposed catastrophe.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome now, be decent, can\xe2\x80\x99t ye?\xe2\x80\x9d said Aunt Chloe; \xe2\x80\x9can\xe2\x80\x99t yer shamed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMas\xe2\x80\x99r George, however, joined the offender in the laugh, and declared\r\ndecidedly that Mose was a \xe2\x80\x9cbuster.\xe2\x80\x9d So the maternal admonition seemed\r\nrather to fail of effect.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, ole man,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aunt Chloe, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99ll have to tote in them ar\r\nbar\xe2\x80\x99ls.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMother\xe2\x80\x99s bar\xe2\x80\x99ls is like dat ar widder\xe2\x80\x99s, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r George was reading\r\n\xe2\x80\x99bout, in de good book,\xe2\x80\x94dey never fails,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mose, aside to Peter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sure one on \xe2\x80\x99em caved in last week,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pete, \xe2\x80\x9cand let \xe2\x80\x99em all\r\ndown in de middle of de singin\xe2\x80\x99; dat ar was failin\xe2\x80\x99, warnt it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDuring this aside between Mose and Pete, two empty casks had been\r\nrolled into the cabin, and being secured from rolling, by stones on\r\neach side, boards were laid across them, which arrangement, together\r\nwith the turning down of certain tubs and pails, and the disposing of\r\nthe rickety chairs, at last completed the preparation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMas\xe2\x80\x99r George is such a beautiful reader, now, I know he\xe2\x80\x99ll stay to\r\nread for us,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aunt Chloe; \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98pears like \xe2\x80\x99t will be so much more\r\ninterestin\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGeorge very readily consented, for your boy is always ready for\r\nanything that makes him of importance.\r\n\r\nThe room was soon filled with a motley assemblage, from the old\r\ngray-headed patriarch of eighty, to the young girl and lad of fifteen.\r\nA little harmless gossip ensued on various themes, such as where old\r\nAunt Sally got her new red headkerchief, and how \xe2\x80\x9cMissis was a going to\r\ngive Lizzy that spotted muslin gown, when she\xe2\x80\x99d got her new berage made\r\nup;\xe2\x80\x9d and how Mas\xe2\x80\x99r Shelby was thinking of buying a new sorrel colt,\r\nthat was going to prove an addition to the glories of the place. A few\r\nof the worshippers belonged to families hard by, who had got permission\r\nto attend, and who brought in various choice scraps of information,\r\nabout the sayings and doings at the house and on the place, which\r\ncirculated as freely as the same sort of small change does in higher\r\ncircles.\r\n\r\nAfter a while the singing commenced, to the evident delight of all\r\npresent. Not even all the disadvantage of nasal intonation could\r\nprevent the effect of the naturally fine voices, in airs at once wild\r\nand spirited. The words were sometimes the well-known and common hymns\r\nsung in the churches about, and sometimes of a wilder, more indefinite\r\ncharacter, picked up at camp-meetings.\r\n\r\nThe chorus of one of them, which ran as follows, was sung with great\r\nenergy and unction:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDie on the field of battle,\r\nDie on the field of battle,\r\nGlory in my soul.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nAnother special favorite had oft repeated the words\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, I\xe2\x80\x99m going to glory,\xe2\x80\x94won\xe2\x80\x99t you come along with me?\r\nDon\xe2\x80\x99t you see the angels beck\xe2\x80\x99ning, and a calling me away?\r\nDon\xe2\x80\x99t you see the golden city and the everlasting day?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nThere were others, which made incessant mention of \xe2\x80\x9cJordan\xe2\x80\x99s banks,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nand \xe2\x80\x9cCanaan\xe2\x80\x99s fields,\xe2\x80\x9d and the \xe2\x80\x9cNew Jerusalem;\xe2\x80\x9d for the negro mind,\r\nimpassioned and imaginative, always attaches itself to hymns and\r\nexpressions of a vivid and pictorial nature; and, as they sung, some\r\nlaughed, and some cried, and some clapped hands, or shook hands\r\nrejoicingly with each other, as if they had fairly gained the other\r\nside of the river.\r\n\r\nVarious exhortations, or relations of experience, followed, and\r\nintermingled with the singing. One old gray-headed woman, long past\r\nwork, but much revered as a sort of chronicle of the past, rose, and\r\nleaning on her staff, said\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cWell, chil\xe2\x80\x99en! Well, I\xe2\x80\x99m mighty glad to\r\nhear ye all and see ye all once more, \xe2\x80\x99cause I don\xe2\x80\x99t know when I\xe2\x80\x99ll be\r\ngone to glory; but I\xe2\x80\x99ve done got ready, chil\xe2\x80\x99en; \xe2\x80\x99pears like I\xe2\x80\x99d got my\r\nlittle bundle all tied up, and my bonnet on, jest a waitin\xe2\x80\x99 for the\r\nstage to come along and take me home; sometimes, in the night, I think\r\nI hear the wheels a rattlin\xe2\x80\x99, and I\xe2\x80\x99m lookin\xe2\x80\x99 out all the time; now,\r\nyou jest be ready too, for I tell ye all, chil\xe2\x80\x99en,\xe2\x80\x9d she said striking\r\nher staff hard on the floor, \xe2\x80\x9cdat ar _glory_ is a mighty thing! It\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\nmighty thing, chil\xe2\x80\x99en,\xe2\x80\x94you don\xe2\x80\x99no nothing about it,\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s _wonderful_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nAnd the old creature sat down, with streaming tears, as wholly\r\novercome, while the whole circle struck up\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO Canaan, bright Canaan\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99m bound for the land of Canaan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nMas\xe2\x80\x99r George, by request, read the last chapters of Revelation, often\r\ninterrupted by such exclamations as \xe2\x80\x9cThe _sakes_ now!\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cOnly hear\r\nthat!\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cJest think on \xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cIs all that a comin\xe2\x80\x99 sure enough?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGeorge, who was a bright boy, and well trained in religious things by\r\nhis mother, finding himself an object of general admiration, threw in\r\nexpositions of his own, from time to time, with a commendable\r\nseriousness and gravity, for which he was admired by the young and\r\nblessed by the old; and it was agreed, on all hands, that \xe2\x80\x9ca minister\r\ncouldn\xe2\x80\x99t lay it off better than he did; that \xe2\x80\x99t was reely \xe2\x80\x99mazin\xe2\x80\x99!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nUncle Tom was a sort of patriarch in religious matters, in the\r\nneighborhood. Having, naturally, an organization in which the _morale_\r\nwas strongly predominant, together with a greater breadth and\r\ncultivation of mind than obtained among his companions, he was looked\r\nup to with great respect, as a sort of minister among them; and the\r\nsimple, hearty, sincere style of his exhortations might have edified\r\neven better educated persons. But it was in prayer that he especially\r\nexcelled. Nothing could exceed the touching simplicity, the childlike\r\nearnestness, of his prayer, enriched with the language of Scripture,\r\nwhich seemed so entirely to have wrought itself into his being, as to\r\nhave become a part of himself, and to drop from his lips unconsciously;\r\nin the language of a pious old negro, he \xe2\x80\x9cprayed right up.\xe2\x80\x9d And so much\r\ndid his prayer always work on the devotional feelings of his audiences,\r\nthat there seemed often a danger that it would be lost altogether in\r\nthe abundance of the responses which broke out everywhere around him.\r\n\r\n\r\nWhile this scene was passing in the cabin of the man, one quite\r\notherwise passed in the halls of the master.\r\n\r\nThe trader and Mr. Shelby were seated together in the dining room\r\nafore-named, at a table covered with papers and writing utensils.\r\n\r\nMr. Shelby was busy in counting some bundles of bills, which, as they\r\nwere counted, he pushed over to the trader, who counted them likewise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll fair,\xe2\x80\x9d said the trader; \xe2\x80\x9cand now for signing these yer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Shelby hastily drew the bills of sale towards him, and signed them,\r\nlike a man that hurries over some disagreeable business, and then\r\npushed them over with the money. Haley produced, from a well-worn\r\nvalise, a parchment, which, after looking over it a moment, he handed\r\nto Mr. Shelby, who took it with a gesture of suppressed eagerness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWal, now, the thing\xe2\x80\x99s _done_!\xe2\x80\x9d said the trader, getting up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s _done_!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Shelby, in a musing tone; and, fetching a long\r\nbreath, he repeated, _\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s done!\xe2\x80\x9d_\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYer don\xe2\x80\x99t seem to feel much pleased with it, \xe2\x80\x99pears to me,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\ntrader.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHaley,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Shelby, \xe2\x80\x9cI hope you\xe2\x80\x99ll remember that you promised, on\r\nyour honor, you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t sell Tom, without knowing what sort of hands\r\nhe\xe2\x80\x99s going into.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, you\xe2\x80\x99ve just done it sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the trader.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCircumstances, you well know, _obliged_ me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Shelby, haughtily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWal, you know, they may \xe2\x80\x99blige _me_, too,\xe2\x80\x9d said the trader.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHowsomever, I\xe2\x80\x99ll do the very best I can in gettin\xe2\x80\x99 Tom a good berth;\r\nas to my treatin\xe2\x80\x99 on him bad, you needn\xe2\x80\x99t be a grain afeard. If there\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nanything that I thank the Lord for, it is that I\xe2\x80\x99m never noways cruel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAfter the expositions which the trader had previously given of his\r\nhumane principles, Mr. Shelby did not feel particularly reassured by\r\nthese declarations; but, as they were the best comfort the case\r\nadmitted of, he allowed the trader to depart in silence, and betook\r\nhimself to a solitary cigar.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER V\r\nShowing the Feelings of Living Property on Changing Owners\r\n\r\n\r\nMr. and Mrs. Shelby had retired to their apartment for the night. He\r\nwas lounging in a large easy-chair, looking over some letters that had\r\ncome in the afternoon mail, and she was standing before her mirror,\r\nbrushing out the complicated braids and curls in which Eliza had\r\narranged her hair; for, noticing her pale cheeks and haggard eyes, she\r\nhad excused her attendance that night, and ordered her to bed. The\r\nemployment, naturally enough, suggested her conversation with the girl\r\nin the morning; and turning to her husband, she said, carelessly,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the by, Arthur, who was that low-bred fellow that you lugged in to\r\nour dinner-table today?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHaley is his name,\xe2\x80\x9d said Shelby, turning himself rather uneasily in\r\nhis chair, and continuing with his eyes fixed on a letter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHaley! Who is he, and what may be his business here, pray?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, he\xe2\x80\x99s a man that I transacted some business with, last time I was\r\nat Natchez,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Shelby.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd he presumed on it to make himself quite at home, and call and dine\r\nhere, ay?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, I invited him; I had some accounts with him,\xe2\x80\x9d said Shelby.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs he a negro-trader?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Shelby, noticing a certain\r\nembarrassment in her husband\xe2\x80\x99s manner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, my dear, what put that into your head?\xe2\x80\x9d said Shelby, looking up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing,\xe2\x80\x94only Eliza came in here, after dinner, in a great worry,\r\ncrying and taking on, and said you were talking with a trader, and that\r\nshe heard him make an offer for her boy\xe2\x80\x94the ridiculous little goose!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe did, hey?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Shelby, returning to his paper, which he\r\nseemed for a few moments quite intent upon, not perceiving that he was\r\nholding it bottom upwards.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt will have to come out,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, mentally; \xe2\x80\x9cas well now as ever.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI told Eliza,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Shelby, as she continued brushing her hair,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthat she was a little fool for her pains, and that you never had\r\nanything to do with that sort of persons. Of course, I knew you never\r\nmeant to sell any of our people,\xe2\x80\x94least of all, to such a fellow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Emily,\xe2\x80\x9d said her husband, \xe2\x80\x9cso I have always felt and said; but\r\nthe fact is that my business lies so that I cannot get on without. I\r\nshall have to sell some of my hands.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo that creature? Impossible! Mr. Shelby, you cannot be serious.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sorry to say that I am,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Shelby. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve agreed to sell\r\nTom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! our Tom?\xe2\x80\x94that good, faithful creature!\xe2\x80\x94been your faithful\r\nservant from a boy! O, Mr. Shelby!\xe2\x80\x94and you have promised him his\r\nfreedom, too,\xe2\x80\x94you and I have spoken to him a hundred times of it. Well,\r\nI can believe anything now,\xe2\x80\x94I can believe _now_ that you could sell\r\nlittle Harry, poor Eliza\xe2\x80\x99s only child!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Shelby, in a tone\r\nbetween grief and indignation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, since you must know all, it is so. I have agreed to sell Tom and\r\nHarry both; and I don\xe2\x80\x99t know why I am to be rated, as if I were a\r\nmonster, for doing what every one does every day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut why, of all others, choose these?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Shelby. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy sell\r\nthem, of all on the place, if you must sell at all?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause they will bring the highest sum of any,\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s why. I could\r\nchoose another, if you say so. The fellow made me a high bid on Eliza,\r\nif that would suit you any better,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Shelby.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe wretch!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Shelby, vehemently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t listen to it, a moment,\xe2\x80\x94out of regard to your feelings,\r\nI wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t;\xe2\x80\x94so give me some credit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Shelby, recollecting herself, \xe2\x80\x9cforgive me. I have\r\nbeen hasty. I was surprised, and entirely unprepared for this;\xe2\x80\x94but\r\nsurely you will allow me to intercede for these poor creatures. Tom is\r\na noble-hearted, faithful fellow, if he is black. I do believe, Mr.\r\nShelby, that if he were put to it, he would lay down his life for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know it,\xe2\x80\x94I dare say;\xe2\x80\x94but what\xe2\x80\x99s the use of all this?\xe2\x80\x94I can\xe2\x80\x99t help\r\nmyself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy not make a pecuniary sacrifice? I\xe2\x80\x99m willing to bear my part of the\r\ninconvenience. O, Mr. Shelby, I have tried\xe2\x80\x94tried most faithfully, as a\r\nChristian woman should\xe2\x80\x94to do my duty to these poor, simple, dependent\r\ncreatures. I have cared for them, instructed them, watched over them,\r\nand know all their little cares and joys, for years; and how can I ever\r\nhold up my head again among them, if, for the sake of a little paltry\r\ngain, we sell such a faithful, excellent, confiding creature as poor\r\nTom, and tear from him in a moment all we have taught him to love and\r\nvalue? I have taught them the duties of the family, of parent and\r\nchild, and husband and wife; and how can I bear to have this open\r\nacknowledgment that we care for no tie, no duty, no relation, however\r\nsacred, compared with money? I have talked with Eliza about her boy\xe2\x80\x94her\r\nduty to him as a Christian mother, to watch over him, pray for him, and\r\nbring him up in a Christian way; and now what can I say, if you tear\r\nhim away, and sell him, soul and body, to a profane, unprincipled man,\r\njust to save a little money? I have told her that one soul is worth\r\nmore than all the money in the world; and how will she believe me when\r\nshe sees us turn round and sell her child?\xe2\x80\x94sell him, perhaps, to\r\ncertain ruin of body and soul!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sorry you feel so about it,\xe2\x80\x94indeed I am,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Shelby; \xe2\x80\x9cand I\r\nrespect your feelings, too, though I don\xe2\x80\x99t pretend to share them to\r\ntheir full extent; but I tell you now, solemnly, it\xe2\x80\x99s of no use\xe2\x80\x94I can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nhelp myself. I didn\xe2\x80\x99t mean to tell you this Emily; but, in plain words,\r\nthere is no choice between selling these two and selling everything.\r\nEither they must go, or _all_ must. Haley has come into possession of a\r\nmortgage, which, if I don\xe2\x80\x99t clear off with him directly, will take\r\neverything before it. I\xe2\x80\x99ve raked, and scraped, and borrowed, and all\r\nbut begged,\xe2\x80\x94and the price of these two was needed to make up the\r\nbalance, and I had to give them up. Haley fancied the child; he agreed\r\nto settle the matter that way, and no other. I was in his power, and\r\n_had_ to do it. If you feel so to have them sold, would it be any\r\nbetter to have _all_ sold?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Shelby stood like one stricken. Finally, turning to her toilet,\r\nshe rested her face in her hands, and gave a sort of groan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is God\xe2\x80\x99s curse on slavery!\xe2\x80\x94a bitter, bitter, most accursed\r\nthing!\xe2\x80\x94a curse to the master and a curse to the slave! I was a fool to\r\nthink I could make anything good out of such a deadly evil. It is a sin\r\nto hold a slave under laws like ours,\xe2\x80\x94I always felt it was,\xe2\x80\x94I always\r\nthought so when I was a girl,\xe2\x80\x94I thought so still more after I joined\r\nthe church; but I thought I could gild it over,\xe2\x80\x94I thought, by kindness,\r\nand care, and instruction, I could make the condition of mine better\r\nthan freedom\xe2\x80\x94fool that I was!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, wife, you are getting to be an abolitionist, quite.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbolitionist! if they knew all I know about slavery, they _might_\r\ntalk! We don\xe2\x80\x99t need them to tell us; you know I never thought that\r\nslavery was right\xe2\x80\x94never felt willing to own slaves.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, therein you differ from many wise and pious men,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr.\r\nShelby. \xe2\x80\x9cYou remember Mr. B.\xe2\x80\x98s sermon, the other Sunday?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want to hear such sermons; I never wish to hear Mr. B. in our\r\nchurch again. Ministers can\xe2\x80\x99t help the evil, perhaps,\xe2\x80\x94can\xe2\x80\x99t cure it,\r\nany more than we can,\xe2\x80\x94but defend it!\xe2\x80\x94it always went against my common\r\nsense. And I think you didn\xe2\x80\x99t think much of that sermon, either.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Shelby, \xe2\x80\x9cI must say these ministers sometimes carry\r\nmatters further than we poor sinners would exactly dare to do. We men\r\nof the world must wink pretty hard at various things, and get used to a\r\ndeal that isn\xe2\x80\x99t the exact thing. But we don\xe2\x80\x99t quite fancy, when women\r\nand ministers come out broad and square, and go beyond us in matters of\r\neither modesty or morals, that\xe2\x80\x99s a fact. But now, my dear, I trust you\r\nsee the necessity of the thing, and you see that I have done the very\r\nbest that circumstances would allow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO yes, yes!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Shelby, hurriedly and abstractedly fingering\r\nher gold watch,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI haven\xe2\x80\x99t any jewelry of any amount,\xe2\x80\x9d she added,\r\nthoughtfully; \xe2\x80\x9cbut would not this watch do something?\xe2\x80\x94it was an\r\nexpensive one, when it was bought. If I could only at least save\r\nEliza\xe2\x80\x99s child, I would sacrifice anything I have.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sorry, very sorry, Emily,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Shelby, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sorry this takes\r\nhold of you so; but it will do no good. The fact is, Emily, the thing\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndone; the bills of sale are already signed, and in Haley\xe2\x80\x99s hands; and\r\nyou must be thankful it is no worse. That man has had it in his power\r\nto ruin us all,\xe2\x80\x94and now he is fairly off. If you knew the man as I do,\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99d think that we had had a narrow escape.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs he so hard, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, not a cruel man, exactly, but a man of leather,\xe2\x80\x94a man alive to\r\nnothing but trade and profit,\xe2\x80\x94cool, and unhesitating, and unrelenting,\r\nas death and the grave. He\xe2\x80\x99d sell his own mother at a good\r\npercentage\xe2\x80\x94not wishing the old woman any harm, either.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd this wretch owns that good, faithful Tom, and Eliza\xe2\x80\x99s child!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my dear, the fact is that this goes rather hard with me; it\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\nthing I hate to think of. Haley wants to drive matters, and take\r\npossession tomorrow. I\xe2\x80\x99m going to get out my horse bright and early,\r\nand be off. I can\xe2\x80\x99t see Tom, that\xe2\x80\x99s a fact; and you had better arrange\r\na drive somewhere, and carry Eliza off. Let the thing be done when she\r\nis out of sight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Shelby; \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll be in no sense accomplice or help in\r\nthis cruel business. I\xe2\x80\x99ll go and see poor old Tom, God help him, in his\r\ndistress! They shall see, at any rate, that their mistress can feel for\r\nand with them. As to Eliza, I dare not think about it. The Lord forgive\r\nus! What have we done, that this cruel necessity should come on us?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was one listener to this conversation whom Mr. and Mrs. Shelby\r\nlittle suspected.\r\n\r\nCommunicating with their apartment was a large closet, opening by a\r\ndoor into the outer passage. When Mrs. Shelby had dismissed Eliza for\r\nthe night, her feverish and excited mind had suggested the idea of this\r\ncloset; and she had hidden herself there, and, with her ear pressed\r\nclose against the crack of the door, had lost not a word of the\r\nconversation.\r\n\r\nWhen the voices died into silence, she rose and crept stealthily away.\r\nPale, shivering, with rigid features and compressed lips, she looked an\r\nentirely altered being from the soft and timid creature she had been\r\nhitherto. She moved cautiously along the entry, paused one moment at\r\nher mistress\xe2\x80\x99 door, and raised her hands in mute appeal to Heaven, and\r\nthen turned and glided into her own room. It was a quiet, neat\r\napartment, on the same floor with her mistress. There was a pleasant\r\nsunny window, where she had often sat singing at her sewing; there a\r\nlittle case of books, and various little fancy articles, ranged by\r\nthem, the gifts of Christmas holidays; there was her simple wardrobe in\r\nthe closet and in the drawers:\xe2\x80\x94here was, in short, her home; and, on\r\nthe whole, a happy one it had been to her. But there, on the bed, lay\r\nher slumbering boy, his long curls falling negligently around his\r\nunconscious face, his rosy mouth half open, his little fat hands thrown\r\nout over the bedclothes, and a smile spread like a sunbeam over his\r\nwhole face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor boy! poor fellow!\xe2\x80\x9d said Eliza; \xe2\x80\x9cthey have sold you! but your\r\nmother will save you yet!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNo tear dropped over that pillow; in such straits as these, the heart\r\nhas no tears to give,\xe2\x80\x94it drops only blood, bleeding itself away in\r\nsilence. She took a piece of paper and a pencil, and wrote, hastily,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Missis! dear Missis! don\xe2\x80\x99t think me ungrateful,\xe2\x80\x94don\xe2\x80\x99t think hard of\r\nme, any way,\xe2\x80\x94I heard all you and master said tonight. I am going to try\r\nto save my boy\xe2\x80\x94you will not blame me! God bless and reward you for all\r\nyour kindness!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHastily folding and directing this, she went to a drawer and made up a\r\nlittle package of clothing for her boy, which she tied with a\r\nhandkerchief firmly round her waist; and, so fond is a mother\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nremembrance, that, even in the terrors of that hour, she did not forget\r\nto put in the little package one or two of his favorite toys, reserving\r\na gayly painted parrot to amuse him, when she should be called on to\r\nawaken him. It was some trouble to arouse the little sleeper; but,\r\nafter some effort, he sat up, and was playing with his bird, while his\r\nmother was putting on her bonnet and shawl.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere are you going, mother?\xe2\x80\x9d said he, as she drew near the bed, with\r\nhis little coat and cap.\r\n\r\nHis mother drew near, and looked so earnestly into his eyes, that he at\r\nonce divined that something unusual was the matter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHush, Harry,\xe2\x80\x9d she said; \xe2\x80\x9cmustn\xe2\x80\x99t speak loud, or they will hear us. A\r\nwicked man was coming to take little Harry away from his mother, and\r\ncarry him \xe2\x80\x99way off in the dark; but mother won\xe2\x80\x99t let him\xe2\x80\x94she\xe2\x80\x99s going to\r\nput on her little boy\xe2\x80\x99s cap and coat, and run off with him, so the ugly\r\nman can\xe2\x80\x99t catch him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSaying these words, she had tied and buttoned on the child\xe2\x80\x99s simple\r\noutfit, and, taking him in her arms, she whispered to him to be very\r\nstill; and, opening a door in her room which led into the outer\r\nverandah, she glided noiselessly out.\r\n\r\nIt was a sparkling, frosty, starlight night, and the mother wrapped the\r\nshawl close round her child, as, perfectly quiet with vague terror, he\r\nclung round her neck.\r\n\r\nOld Bruno, a great Newfoundland, who slept at the end of the porch,\r\nrose, with a low growl, as she came near. She gently spoke his name,\r\nand the animal, an old pet and playmate of hers, instantly, wagging his\r\ntail, prepared to follow her, though apparently revolving much, in this\r\nsimple dog\xe2\x80\x99s head, what such an indiscreet midnight promenade might\r\nmean. Some dim ideas of imprudence or impropriety in the measure seemed\r\nto embarrass him considerably; for he often stopped, as Eliza glided\r\nforward, and looked wistfully, first at her and then at the house, and\r\nthen, as if reassured by reflection, he pattered along after her again.\r\nA few minutes brought them to the window of Uncle Tom\xe2\x80\x99s cottage, and\r\nEliza stopping, tapped lightly on the window-pane.\r\n\r\nThe prayer-meeting at Uncle Tom\xe2\x80\x99s had, in the order of hymn-singing,\r\nbeen protracted to a very late hour; and, as Uncle Tom had indulged\r\nhimself in a few lengthy solos afterwards, the consequence was, that,\r\nalthough it was now between twelve and one o\xe2\x80\x99clock, he and his worthy\r\nhelpmeet were not yet asleep.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood Lord! what\xe2\x80\x99s that?\xe2\x80\x9d said Aunt Chloe, starting up and hastily\r\ndrawing the curtain. \xe2\x80\x9cMy sakes alive, if it an\xe2\x80\x99t Lizy! Get on your\r\nclothes, old man, quick!\xe2\x80\x94there\xe2\x80\x99s old Bruno, too, a pawin round; what on\r\nairth! I\xe2\x80\x99m gwine to open the door.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd suiting the action to the word, the door flew open, and the light\r\nof the tallow candle, which Tom had hastily lighted, fell on the\r\nhaggard face and dark, wild eyes of the fugitive.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLord bless you!\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99m skeered to look at ye, Lizy! Are ye tuck sick, or\r\nwhat\xe2\x80\x99s come over ye?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m running away\xe2\x80\x94Uncle Tom and Aunt Chloe\xe2\x80\x94carrying off my child\xe2\x80\x94Master\r\nsold him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n[Illustration: Eliza comes to tell Uncle Tom that he is sold, and that\r\nshe is running away to save her child.]\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSold him?\xe2\x80\x9d echoed both, lifting up their hands in dismay.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sold him!\xe2\x80\x9d said Eliza, firmly; \xe2\x80\x9cI crept into the closet by\r\nMistress\xe2\x80\x99 door tonight, and I heard Master tell Missis that he had sold\r\nmy Harry, and you, Uncle Tom, both, to a trader; and that he was going\r\noff this morning on his horse, and that the man was to take possession\r\ntoday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom had stood, during this speech, with his hands raised, and his eyes\r\ndilated, like a man in a dream. Slowly and gradually, as its meaning\r\ncame over him, he collapsed, rather than seated himself, on his old\r\nchair, and sunk his head down upon his knees.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe good Lord have pity on us!\xe2\x80\x9d said Aunt Chloe. \xe2\x80\x9cO! it don\xe2\x80\x99t seem as\r\nif it was true! What has he done, that Mas\xe2\x80\x99r should sell _him_?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe hasn\xe2\x80\x99t done anything,\xe2\x80\x94it isn\xe2\x80\x99t for that. Master don\xe2\x80\x99t want to sell,\r\nand Missis she\xe2\x80\x99s always good. I heard her plead and beg for us; but he\r\ntold her \xe2\x80\x99t was no use; that he was in this man\xe2\x80\x99s debt, and that this\r\nman had got the power over him; and that if he didn\xe2\x80\x99t pay him off\r\nclear, it would end in his having to sell the place and all the people,\r\nand move off. Yes, I heard him say there was no choice between selling\r\nthese two and selling all, the man was driving him so hard. Master said\r\nhe was sorry; but oh, Missis\xe2\x80\x94you ought to have heard her talk! If she\r\nan\xe2\x80\x99t a Christian and an angel, there never was one. I\xe2\x80\x99m a wicked girl\r\nto leave her so; but, then, I can\xe2\x80\x99t help it. She said, herself, one\r\nsoul was worth more than the world; and this boy has a soul, and if I\r\nlet him be carried off, who knows what\xe2\x80\x99ll become of it? It must be\r\nright: but, if it an\xe2\x80\x99t right, the Lord forgive me, for I can\xe2\x80\x99t help\r\ndoing it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, old man!\xe2\x80\x9d said Aunt Chloe, \xe2\x80\x9cwhy don\xe2\x80\x99t you go, too? Will you wait\r\nto be toted down river, where they kill niggers with hard work and\r\nstarving? I\xe2\x80\x99d a heap rather die than go there, any day! There\xe2\x80\x99s time\r\nfor ye,\xe2\x80\x94be off with Lizy,\xe2\x80\x94you\xe2\x80\x99ve got a pass to come and go any time.\r\nCome, bustle up, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll get your things together.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom slowly raised his head, and looked sorrowfully but quietly around,\r\nand said,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no\xe2\x80\x94I an\xe2\x80\x99t going. Let Eliza go\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s her right! I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be the\r\none to say no\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98tan\xe2\x80\x99t in _natur_ for her to stay; but you heard what she\r\nsaid! If I must be sold, or all the people on the place, and everything\r\ngo to rack, why, let me be sold. I s\xe2\x80\x99pose I can bar it as well as any\r\non \xe2\x80\x99em,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, while something like a sob and a sigh shook his\r\nbroad, rough chest convulsively. \xe2\x80\x9cMas\xe2\x80\x99r always found me on the spot\xe2\x80\x94he\r\nalways will. I never have broke trust, nor used my pass no ways\r\ncontrary to my word, and I never will. It\xe2\x80\x99s better for me alone to go,\r\nthan to break up the place and sell all. Mas\xe2\x80\x99r an\xe2\x80\x99t to blame, Chloe,\r\nand he\xe2\x80\x99ll take care of you and the poor\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHere he turned to the rough trundle bed full of little woolly heads,\r\nand broke fairly down. He leaned over the back of the chair, and\r\ncovered his face with his large hands. Sobs, heavy, hoarse and loud,\r\nshook the chair, and great tears fell through his fingers on the floor;\r\njust such tears, sir, as you dropped into the coffin where lay your\r\nfirst-born son; such tears, woman, as you shed when you heard the cries\r\nof your dying babe. For, sir, he was a man,\xe2\x80\x94and you are but another\r\nman. And, woman, though dressed in silk and jewels, you are but a\r\nwoman, and, in life\xe2\x80\x99s great straits and mighty griefs, ye feel but one\r\nsorrow!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eliza, as she stood in the door, \xe2\x80\x9cI saw my husband only\r\nthis afternoon, and I little knew then what was to come. They have\r\npushed him to the very last standing place, and he told me, today, that\r\nhe was going to run away. Do try, if you can, to get word to him. Tell\r\nhim how I went, and why I went; and tell him I\xe2\x80\x99m going to try and find\r\nCanada. You must give my love to him, and tell him, if I never see him\r\nagain,\xe2\x80\x9d she turned away, and stood with her back to them for a moment,\r\nand then added, in a husky voice, \xe2\x80\x9ctell him to be as good as he can,\r\nand try and meet me in the kingdom of heaven.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCall Bruno in there,\xe2\x80\x9d she added. \xe2\x80\x9cShut the door on him, poor beast! He\r\nmustn\xe2\x80\x99t go with me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA few last words and tears, a few simple adieus and blessings, and\r\nclasping her wondering and affrighted child in her arms, she glided\r\nnoiselessly away.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VI\r\nDiscovery\r\n\r\n\r\nMr. and Mrs. Shelby, after their protracted discussion of the night\r\nbefore, did not readily sink to repose, and, in consequence, slept\r\nsomewhat later than usual, the ensuing morning.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wonder what keeps Eliza,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Shelby, after giving her bell\r\nrepeated pulls, to no purpose.\r\n\r\nMr. Shelby was standing before his dressing-glass, sharpening his\r\nrazor; and just then the door opened, and a colored boy entered, with\r\nhis shaving-water.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAndy,\xe2\x80\x9d said his mistress, \xe2\x80\x9cstep to Eliza\xe2\x80\x99s door, and tell her I have\r\nrung for her three times. Poor thing!\xe2\x80\x9d she added, to herself, with a\r\nsigh.\r\n\r\nAndy soon returned, with eyes very wide in astonishment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLor, Missis! Lizy\xe2\x80\x99s drawers is all open, and her things all lying\r\nevery which way; and I believe she\xe2\x80\x99s just done clared out!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe truth flashed upon Mr. Shelby and his wife at the same moment. He\r\nexclaimed,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen she suspected it, and she\xe2\x80\x99s off!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Lord be thanked!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Shelby. \xe2\x80\x9cI trust she is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWife, you talk like a fool! Really, it will be something pretty\r\nawkward for me, if she is. Haley saw that I hesitated about selling\r\nthis child, and he\xe2\x80\x99ll think I connived at it, to get him out of the\r\nway. It touches my honor!\xe2\x80\x9d And Mr. Shelby left the room hastily.\r\n\r\nThere was great running and ejaculating, and opening and shutting of\r\ndoors, and appearance of faces in all shades of color in different\r\nplaces, for about a quarter of an hour. One person only, who might have\r\nshed some light on the matter, was entirely silent, and that was the\r\nhead cook, Aunt Chloe. Silently, and with a heavy cloud settled down\r\nover her once joyous face, she proceeded making out her breakfast\r\nbiscuits, as if she heard and saw nothing of the excitement around her.\r\n\r\nVery soon, about a dozen young imps were roosting, like so many crows,\r\non the verandah railings, each one determined to be the first one to\r\napprize the strange Mas\xe2\x80\x99r of his ill luck.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99ll be rael mad, I\xe2\x80\x99ll be bound,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Won\xe2\x80\x99t_ he swar!\xe2\x80\x9d said little black Jake.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, for he _does_ swar,\xe2\x80\x9d said woolly-headed Mandy. \xe2\x80\x9cI hearn him\r\nyesterday, at dinner. I hearn all about it then, \xe2\x80\x99cause I got into the\r\ncloset where Missis keeps the great jugs, and I hearn every word.\xe2\x80\x9d And\r\nMandy, who had never in her life thought of the meaning of a word she\r\nhad heard, more than a black cat, now took airs of superior wisdom, and\r\nstrutted about, forgetting to state that, though actually coiled up\r\namong the jugs at the time specified, she had been fast asleep all the\r\ntime.\r\n\r\nWhen, at last, Haley appeared, booted and spurred, he was saluted with\r\nthe bad tidings on every hand. The young imps on the verandah were not\r\ndisappointed in their hope of hearing him \xe2\x80\x9cswar,\xe2\x80\x9d which he did with a\r\nfluency and fervency which delighted them all amazingly, as they ducked\r\nand dodged hither and thither, to be out of the reach of his\r\nriding-whip; and, all whooping off together, they tumbled, in a pile of\r\nimmeasurable giggle, on the withered turf under the verandah, where\r\nthey kicked up their heels and shouted to their full satisfaction.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I had the little devils!\xe2\x80\x9d muttered Haley, between his teeth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you ha\xe2\x80\x99nt got \xe2\x80\x99em, though!\xe2\x80\x9d said Andy, with a triumphant flourish,\r\nand making a string of indescribable mouths at the unfortunate trader\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nback, when he was fairly beyond hearing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say now, Shelby, this yer \xe2\x80\x99s a most extro\xe2\x80\x99rnary business!\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nHaley, as he abruptly entered the parlor. \xe2\x80\x9cIt seems that gal \xe2\x80\x99s off,\r\nwith her young un.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Haley, Mrs. Shelby is present,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Shelby.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg pardon, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley, bowing slightly, with a still\r\nlowering brow; \xe2\x80\x9cbut still I say, as I said before, this yer\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\nsing\xe2\x80\x99lar report. Is it true, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Shelby, \xe2\x80\x9cif you wish to communicate with me, you must\r\nobserve something of the decorum of a gentleman. Andy, take Mr. Haley\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhat and riding-whip. Take a seat, sir. Yes, sir; I regret to say that\r\nthe young woman, excited by overhearing, or having reported to her,\r\nsomething of this business, has taken her child in the night, and made\r\noff.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI did expect fair dealing in this matter, I confess,\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Shelby, turning sharply round upon him, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat am\r\nI to understand by that remark? If any man calls my honor in question,\r\nI have but one answer for him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe trader cowered at this, and in a somewhat lower tone said that \xe2\x80\x9cit\r\nwas plaguy hard on a fellow, that had made a fair bargain, to be gulled\r\nthat way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Haley,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Shelby, \xe2\x80\x9cif I did not think you had some cause\r\nfor disappointment, I should not have borne from you the rude and\r\nunceremonious style of your entrance into my parlor this morning. I say\r\nthus much, however, since appearances call for it, that I shall allow\r\nof no insinuations cast upon me, as if I were at all partner to any\r\nunfairness in this matter. Moreover, I shall feel bound to give you\r\nevery assistance, in the use of horses, servants, &c., in the recovery\r\nof your property. So, in short, Haley,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, suddenly dropping from\r\nthe tone of dignified coolness to his ordinary one of easy frankness,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthe best way for you is to keep good-natured and eat some breakfast,\r\nand we will then see what is to be done.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Shelby now rose, and said her engagements would prevent her being\r\nat the breakfast-table that morning; and, deputing a very respectable\r\nmulatto woman to attend to the gentlemen\xe2\x80\x99s coffee at the side-board,\r\nshe left the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOld lady don\xe2\x80\x99t like your humble servant, over and above,\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley,\r\nwith an uneasy effort to be very familiar.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not accustomed to hear my wife spoken of with such freedom,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nMr. Shelby, dryly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBeg pardon; of course, only a joke, you know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley, forcing a\r\nlaugh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSome jokes are less agreeable than others,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined Shelby.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDevilish free, now I\xe2\x80\x99ve signed those papers, cuss him!\xe2\x80\x9d muttered Haley\r\nto himself; \xe2\x80\x9cquite grand, since yesterday!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNever did fall of any prime minister at court occasion wider surges of\r\nsensation than the report of Tom\xe2\x80\x99s fate among his compeers on the\r\nplace. It was the topic in every mouth, everywhere; and nothing was\r\ndone in the house or in the field, but to discuss its probable results.\r\nEliza\xe2\x80\x99s flight\xe2\x80\x94an unprecedented event on the place\xe2\x80\x94was also a great\r\naccessory in stimulating the general excitement.\r\n\r\nBlack Sam, as he was commonly called, from his being about three shades\r\nblacker than any other son of ebony on the place, was revolving the\r\nmatter profoundly in all its phases and bearings, with a\r\ncomprehensiveness of vision and a strict lookout to his own personal\r\nwell-being, that would have done credit to any white patriot in\r\nWashington.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s an ill wind dat blow nowhar,\xe2\x80\x94dat ar a fact,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sam,\r\nsententiously, giving an additional hoist to his pantaloons, and\r\nadroitly substituting a long nail in place of a missing\r\nsuspender-button, with which effort of mechanical genius he seemed\r\nhighly delighted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, it\xe2\x80\x99s an ill wind blows nowhar,\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated. \xe2\x80\x9cNow, dar, Tom\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndown\xe2\x80\x94wal, course der\xe2\x80\x99s room for some nigger to be up\xe2\x80\x94and why not dis\r\nnigger?\xe2\x80\x94dat\xe2\x80\x99s de idee. Tom, a ridin\xe2\x80\x99 round de country\xe2\x80\x94boots\r\nblacked\xe2\x80\x94pass in his pocket\xe2\x80\x94all grand as Cuffee\xe2\x80\x94but who he? Now, why\r\nshouldn\xe2\x80\x99t Sam?\xe2\x80\x94dat\xe2\x80\x99s what I want to know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHalloo, Sam\xe2\x80\x94O Sam! Mas\xe2\x80\x99r wants you to cotch Bill and Jerry,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nAndy, cutting short Sam\xe2\x80\x99s soliloquy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHigh! what\xe2\x80\x99s afoot now, young un?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, you don\xe2\x80\x99t know, I s\xe2\x80\x99pose, that Lizy\xe2\x80\x99s cut stick, and clared out,\r\nwith her young un?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou teach your granny!\xe2\x80\x9d said Sam, with infinite contempt; \xe2\x80\x9cknowed it a\r\nheap sight sooner than you did; this nigger an\xe2\x80\x99t so green, now!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, anyhow, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r wants Bill and Jerry geared right up; and you and\r\nI \xe2\x80\x99s to go with Mas\xe2\x80\x99r Haley, to look arter her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood, now! dat\xe2\x80\x99s de time o\xe2\x80\x99 day!\xe2\x80\x9d said Sam. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s Sam dat\xe2\x80\x99s called for\r\nin dese yer times. He\xe2\x80\x99s de nigger. See if I don\xe2\x80\x99t cotch her, now;\r\nMas\xe2\x80\x99r\xe2\x80\x99ll see what Sam can do!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! but, Sam,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andy, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99d better think twice; for Missis don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nwant her cotched, and she\xe2\x80\x99ll be in yer wool.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHigh!\xe2\x80\x9d said Sam, opening his eyes. \xe2\x80\x9cHow you know dat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHeard her say so, my own self, dis blessed mornin\xe2\x80\x99, when I bring in\r\nMas\xe2\x80\x99r\xe2\x80\x99s shaving-water. She sent me to see why Lizy didn\xe2\x80\x99t come to dress\r\nher; and when I telled her she was off, she jest ris up, and ses she,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The Lord be praised;\xe2\x80\x99 and Mas\xe2\x80\x99r, he seemed rael mad, and ses he,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wife, you talk like a fool.\xe2\x80\x99 But Lor! she\xe2\x80\x99ll bring him to! I knows\r\nwell enough how that\xe2\x80\x99ll be,\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s allers best to stand Missis\xe2\x80\x99 side the\r\nfence, now I tell yer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBlack Sam, upon this, scratched his woolly pate, which, if it did not\r\ncontain very profound wisdom, still contained a great deal of a\r\nparticular species much in demand among politicians of all complexions\r\nand countries, and vulgarly denominated \xe2\x80\x9cknowing which side the bread\r\nis buttered;\xe2\x80\x9d so, stopping with grave consideration, he again gave a\r\nhitch to his pantaloons, which was his regularly organized method of\r\nassisting his mental perplexities.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDer an\xe2\x80\x99t no saying\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94never\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98bout no kind o\xe2\x80\x99 thing in _dis_ yer world,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nhe said, at last. Sam spoke like a philosopher, emphasizing _this_\xe2\x80\x94as\r\nif he had had a large experience in different sorts of worlds, and\r\ntherefore had come to his conclusions advisedly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, sartin I\xe2\x80\x99d a said that Missis would a scoured the varsal world\r\nafter Lizy,\xe2\x80\x9d added Sam, thoughtfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo she would,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andy; \xe2\x80\x9cbut can\xe2\x80\x99t ye see through a ladder, ye black\r\nnigger? Missis don\xe2\x80\x99t want dis yer Mas\xe2\x80\x99r Haley to get Lizy\xe2\x80\x99s boy; dat\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nde go!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHigh!\xe2\x80\x9d said Sam, with an indescribable intonation, known only to those\r\nwho have heard it among the negroes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell yer more \xe2\x80\x99n all,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andy; \xe2\x80\x9cI specs you\xe2\x80\x99d better be\r\nmaking tracks for dem hosses,\xe2\x80\x94mighty sudden, too,\xe2\x80\x94-for I hearn Missis\r\n\xe2\x80\x99quirin\xe2\x80\x99 arter yer,\xe2\x80\x94so you\xe2\x80\x99ve stood foolin\xe2\x80\x99 long enough.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSam, upon this, began to bestir himself in real earnest, and after a\r\nwhile appeared, bearing down gloriously towards the house, with Bill\r\nand Jerry in a full canter, and adroitly throwing himself off before\r\nthey had any idea of stopping, he brought them up alongside of the\r\nhorse-post like a tornado. Haley\xe2\x80\x99s horse, which was a skittish young\r\ncolt, winced, and bounced, and pulled hard at his halter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHo, ho!\xe2\x80\x9d said Sam, \xe2\x80\x9cskeery, ar ye?\xe2\x80\x9d and his black visage lighted up\r\nwith a curious, mischievous gleam. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll fix ye now!\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\nThere was a large beech-tree overshadowing the place, and the small,\r\nsharp, triangular beech-nuts lay scattered thickly on the ground. With\r\none of these in his fingers, Sam approached the colt, stroked and\r\npatted, and seemed apparently busy in soothing his agitation. On\r\npretence of adjusting the saddle, he adroitly slipped under it the\r\nsharp little nut, in such a manner that the least weight brought upon\r\nthe saddle would annoy the nervous sensibilities of the animal, without\r\nleaving any perceptible graze or wound.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDar!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, rolling his eyes with an approving grin; \xe2\x80\x9cme fix \xe2\x80\x99em!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this moment Mrs. Shelby appeared on the balcony, beckoning to him.\r\nSam approached with as good a determination to pay court as did ever\r\nsuitor after a vacant place at St. James\xe2\x80\x99 or Washington.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy have you been loitering so, Sam? I sent Andy to tell you to\r\nhurry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLord bless you, Missis!\xe2\x80\x9d said Sam, \xe2\x80\x9chorses won\xe2\x80\x99t be cotched all in a\r\nminit; they\xe2\x80\x99d done clared out way down to the south pasture, and the\r\nLord knows whar!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSam, how often must I tell you not to say \xe2\x80\x98Lord bless you, and the\r\nLord knows,\xe2\x80\x99 and such things? It\xe2\x80\x99s wicked.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Lord bless my soul! I done forgot, Missis! I won\xe2\x80\x99t say nothing of\r\nde sort no more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, Sam, you just _have_ said it again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid I? O, Lord! I mean\xe2\x80\x94I didn\xe2\x80\x99t go fur to say it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must be _careful_, Sam.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust let me get my breath, Missis, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll start fair. I\xe2\x80\x99ll be bery\r\ncareful.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Sam, you are to go with Mr. Haley, to show him the road, and\r\nhelp him. Be careful of the horses, Sam; you know Jerry was a little\r\nlame last week; _don\xe2\x80\x99t ride them too fast_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Shelby spoke the last words with a low voice, and strong emphasis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet dis child alone for dat!\xe2\x80\x9d said Sam, rolling up his eyes with a\r\nvolume of meaning. \xe2\x80\x9cLord knows! High! Didn\xe2\x80\x99t say dat!\xe2\x80\x9d said he,\r\nsuddenly catching his breath, with a ludicrous flourish of\r\napprehension, which made his mistress laugh, spite of herself. \xe2\x80\x9cYes,\r\nMissis, I\xe2\x80\x99ll look out for de hosses!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, Andy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sam, returning to his stand under the beech-trees,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cyou see I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be \xe2\x80\x99t all surprised if dat ar gen\xe2\x80\x99lman\xe2\x80\x99s crittur\r\nshould gib a fling, by and by, when he comes to be a gettin\xe2\x80\x99 up. You\r\nknow, Andy, critturs _will_ do such things;\xe2\x80\x9d and therewith Sam poked\r\nAndy in the side, in a highly suggestive manner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHigh!\xe2\x80\x9d said Andy, with an air of instant appreciation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, you see, Andy, Missis wants to make time,\xe2\x80\x94dat ar\xe2\x80\x99s clar to der\r\nmost or\xe2\x80\x99nary \xe2\x80\x99bserver. I jis make a little for her. Now, you see, get\r\nall dese yer hosses loose, caperin\xe2\x80\x99 permiscus round dis yer lot and\r\ndown to de wood dar, and I spec Mas\xe2\x80\x99r won\xe2\x80\x99t be off in a hurry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAndy grinned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYer see,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sam, \xe2\x80\x9cyer see, Andy, if any such thing should happen as\r\nthat Mas\xe2\x80\x99r Haley\xe2\x80\x99s horse _should_ begin to act contrary, and cut up,\r\nyou and I jist lets go of our\xe2\x80\x99n to help him, and _we\xe2\x80\x99ll help him_\xe2\x80\x94oh\r\nyes!\xe2\x80\x9d And Sam and Andy laid their heads back on their shoulders, and\r\nbroke into a low, immoderate laugh, snapping their fingers and\r\nflourishing their heels with exquisite delight.\r\n\r\nAt this instant, Haley appeared on the verandah. Somewhat mollified by\r\ncertain cups of very good coffee, he came out smiling and talking, in\r\ntolerably restored humor. Sam and Andy, clawing for certain fragmentary\r\npalm-leaves, which they were in the habit of considering as hats, flew\r\nto the horseposts, to be ready to \xe2\x80\x9chelp Mas\xe2\x80\x99r.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSam\xe2\x80\x99s palm-leaf had been ingeniously disentangled from all pretensions\r\nto braid, as respects its brim; and the slivers starting apart, and\r\nstanding upright, gave it a blazing air of freedom and defiance, quite\r\nequal to that of any Fejee chief; while the whole brim of Andy\xe2\x80\x99s being\r\ndeparted bodily, he rapped the crown on his head with a dexterous\r\nthump, and looked about well pleased, as if to say, \xe2\x80\x9cWho says I haven\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ngot a hat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, boys,\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley, \xe2\x80\x9clook alive now; we must lose no time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot a bit of him, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r!\xe2\x80\x9d said Sam, putting Haley\xe2\x80\x99s rein in his hand,\r\nand holding his stirrup, while Andy was untying the other two horses.\r\n\r\nThe instant Haley touched the saddle, the mettlesome creature bounded\r\nfrom the earth with a sudden spring, that threw his master sprawling,\r\nsome feet off, on the soft, dry turf. Sam, with frantic ejaculations,\r\nmade a dive at the reins, but only succeeded in brushing the blazing\r\npalm-leaf afore-named into the horse\xe2\x80\x99s eyes, which by no means tended\r\nto allay the confusion of his nerves. So, with great vehemence, he\r\noverturned Sam, and, giving two or three contemptuous snorts,\r\nflourished his heels vigorously in the air, and was soon prancing away\r\ntowards the lower end of the lawn, followed by Bill and Jerry, whom\r\nAndy had not failed to let loose, according to contract, speeding them\r\noff with various direful ejaculations. And now ensued a miscellaneous\r\nscene of confusion. Sam and Andy ran and shouted,\xe2\x80\x94dogs barked here and\r\nthere,\xe2\x80\x94and Mike, Mose, Mandy, Fanny, and all the smaller specimens on\r\nthe place, both male and female, raced, clapped hands, whooped, and\r\nshouted, with outrageous officiousness and untiring zeal.\r\n\r\nHaley\xe2\x80\x99s horse, which was a white one, and very fleet and spirited,\r\nappeared to enter into the spirit of the scene with great gusto; and\r\nhaving for his coursing ground a lawn of nearly half a mile in extent,\r\ngently sloping down on every side into indefinite woodland, he appeared\r\nto take infinite delight in seeing how near he could allow his pursuers\r\nto approach him, and then, when within a hand\xe2\x80\x99s breadth, whisk off with\r\na start and a snort, like a mischievous beast as he was and career far\r\ndown into some alley of the wood-lot. Nothing was further from Sam\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmind than to have any one of the troop taken until such season as\r\nshould seem to him most befitting,\xe2\x80\x94and the exertions that he made were\r\ncertainly most heroic. Like the sword of Coeur De Lion, which always\r\nblazed in the front and thickest of the battle, Sam\xe2\x80\x99s palm-leaf was to\r\nbe seen everywhere when there was the least danger that a horse could\r\nbe caught; there he would bear down full tilt, shouting, \xe2\x80\x9cNow for it!\r\ncotch him! cotch him!\xe2\x80\x9d in a way that would set everything to\r\nindiscriminate rout in a moment.\r\n\r\nHaley ran up and down, and cursed and swore and stamped\r\nmiscellaneously. Mr. Shelby in vain tried to shout directions from the\r\nbalcony, and Mrs. Shelby from her chamber window alternately laughed\r\nand wondered,\xe2\x80\x94not without some inkling of what lay at the bottom of all\r\nthis confusion.\r\n\r\nAt last, about twelve o\xe2\x80\x99clock, Sam appeared triumphant, mounted on\r\nJerry, with Haley\xe2\x80\x99s horse by his side, reeking with sweat, but with\r\nflashing eyes and dilated nostrils, showing that the spirit of freedom\r\nhad not yet entirely subsided.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s cotched!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed, triumphantly. \xe2\x80\x9cIf \xe2\x80\x99t hadn\xe2\x80\x99t been for me,\r\nthey might a bust themselves, all on \xe2\x80\x99em; but I cotched him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou!\xe2\x80\x9d growled Haley, in no amiable mood. \xe2\x80\x9cIf it hadn\xe2\x80\x99t been for you,\r\nthis never would have happened.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLord bless us, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sam, in a tone of the deepest concern,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cand me that has been racin\xe2\x80\x99 and chasin\xe2\x80\x99 till the sweat jest pours off\r\nme!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, well!\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99ve lost me near three hours, with your\r\ncursed nonsense. Now let\xe2\x80\x99s be off, and have no more fooling.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sam, in a deprecating tone, \xe2\x80\x9cI believe you mean to\r\nkill us all clar, horses and all. Here we are all just ready to drop\r\ndown, and the critters all in a reek of sweat. Why, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r won\xe2\x80\x99t think\r\nof startin\xe2\x80\x99 on now till arter dinner. Mas\xe2\x80\x99r\xe2\x80\x99s hoss wants rubben down;\r\nsee how he splashed hisself; and Jerry limps too; don\xe2\x80\x99t think Missis\r\nwould be willin\xe2\x80\x99 to have us start dis yer way, no how. Lord bless you,\r\nMas\xe2\x80\x99r, we can ketch up, if we do stop. Lizy never was no great of a\r\nwalker.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Shelby, who, greatly to her amusement, had overheard this\r\nconversation from the verandah, now resolved to do her part. She came\r\nforward, and, courteously expressing her concern for Haley\xe2\x80\x99s accident,\r\npressed him to stay to dinner, saying that the cook should bring it on\r\nthe table immediately.\r\n\r\nThus, all things considered, Haley, with rather an equivocal grace,\r\nproceeded to the parlor, while Sam, rolling his eyes after him with\r\nunutterable meaning, proceeded gravely with the horses to the\r\nstable-yard.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid yer see him, Andy? _did_ yer see him?\xe2\x80\x9d said Sam, when he had got\r\nfairly beyond the shelter of the barn, and fastened the horse to a\r\npost. \xe2\x80\x9cO, Lor, if it warn\xe2\x80\x99t as good as a meetin\xe2\x80\x99, now, to see him a\r\ndancin\xe2\x80\x99 and kickin\xe2\x80\x99 and swarin\xe2\x80\x99 at us. Didn\xe2\x80\x99t I hear him? Swar away,\r\nole fellow (says I to myself ); will yer have yer hoss now, or wait\r\ntill you cotch him? (says I). Lor, Andy, I think I can see him now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nAnd Sam and Andy leaned up against the barn and laughed to their\r\nhearts\xe2\x80\x99 content.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYer oughter seen how mad he looked, when I brought the hoss up. Lord,\r\nhe\xe2\x80\x99d a killed me, if he durs\xe2\x80\x99 to; and there I was a standin\xe2\x80\x99 as\r\ninnercent and as humble.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLor, I seed you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andy; \xe2\x80\x9can\xe2\x80\x99t you an old hoss, Sam?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRather specks I am,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sam; \xe2\x80\x9cdid yer see Missis up stars at the\r\nwinder? I seed her laughin\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sure, I was racin\xe2\x80\x99 so, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t see nothing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, yer see,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sam, proceeding gravely to wash down Haley\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npony, \xe2\x80\x9cI \xe2\x80\x99se \xe2\x80\x99quired what yer may call a habit _o\xe2\x80\x99 bobservation_, Andy.\r\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s a very \xe2\x80\x99portant habit, Andy; and I \xe2\x80\x99commend yer to be cultivatin\xe2\x80\x99\r\nit, now yer young. Hist up that hind foot, Andy. Yer see, Andy, it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n_bobservation_ makes all de difference in niggers. Didn\xe2\x80\x99t I see which\r\nway the wind blew dis yer mornin\xe2\x80\x99? Didn\xe2\x80\x99t I see what Missis wanted,\r\nthough she never let on? Dat ar\xe2\x80\x99s bobservation, Andy. I \xe2\x80\x99spects it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwhat you may call a faculty. Faculties is different in different\r\npeoples, but cultivation of \xe2\x80\x99em goes a great way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI guess if I hadn\xe2\x80\x99t helped your bobservation dis mornin\xe2\x80\x99, yer wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nhave seen your way so smart,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAndy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sam, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99s a promisin\xe2\x80\x99 child, der an\xe2\x80\x99t no manner o\xe2\x80\x99\r\ndoubt. I thinks lots of yer, Andy; and I don\xe2\x80\x99t feel no ways ashamed to\r\ntake idees from you. We oughtenter overlook nobody, Andy, cause the\r\nsmartest on us gets tripped up sometimes. And so, Andy, let\xe2\x80\x99s go up to\r\nthe house now. I\xe2\x80\x99ll be boun\xe2\x80\x99 Missis\xe2\x80\x99ll give us an uncommon good bite,\r\ndis yer time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VII\r\nThe Mother\xe2\x80\x99s Struggle\r\n\r\n\r\nIt is impossible to conceive of a human creature more wholly desolate\r\nand forlorn than Eliza, when she turned her footsteps from Uncle Tom\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncabin.\r\n\r\nHer husband\xe2\x80\x99s suffering and dangers, and the danger of her child, all\r\nblended in her mind, with a confused and stunning sense of the risk she\r\nwas running, in leaving the only home she had ever known, and cutting\r\nloose from the protection of a friend whom she loved and revered. Then\r\nthere was the parting from every familiar object,\xe2\x80\x94the place where she\r\nhad grown up, the trees under which she had played, the groves where\r\nshe had walked many an evening in happier days, by the side of her\r\nyoung husband,\xe2\x80\x94everything, as it lay in the clear, frosty starlight,\r\nseemed to speak reproachfully to her, and ask her whither could she go\r\nfrom a home like that?\r\n\r\nBut stronger than all was maternal love, wrought into a paroxysm of\r\nfrenzy by the near approach of a fearful danger. Her boy was old enough\r\nto have walked by her side, and, in an indifferent case, she would only\r\nhave led him by the hand; but now the bare thought of putting him out\r\nof her arms made her shudder, and she strained him to her bosom with a\r\nconvulsive grasp, as she went rapidly forward.\r\n\r\nThe frosty ground creaked beneath her feet, and she trembled at the\r\nsound; every quaking leaf and fluttering shadow sent the blood backward\r\nto her heart, and quickened her footsteps. She wondered within herself\r\nat the strength that seemed to be come upon her; for she felt the\r\nweight of her boy as if it had been a feather, and every flutter of\r\nfear seemed to increase the supernatural power that bore her on, while\r\nfrom her pale lips burst forth, in frequent ejaculations, the prayer to\r\na Friend above\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cLord, help! Lord, save me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIf it were _your_ Harry, mother, or your Willie, that were going to be\r\ntorn from you by a brutal trader, tomorrow morning,\xe2\x80\x94if you had seen the\r\nman, and heard that the papers were signed and delivered, and you had\r\nonly from twelve o\xe2\x80\x99clock till morning to make good your escape,\xe2\x80\x94how\r\nfast could _you_ walk? How many miles could you make in those few brief\r\nhours, with the darling at your bosom,\xe2\x80\x94the little sleepy head on your\r\nshoulder,\xe2\x80\x94the small, soft arms trustingly holding on to your neck?\r\n\r\nFor the child slept. At first, the novelty and alarm kept him waking;\r\nbut his mother so hurriedly repressed every breath or sound, and so\r\nassured him that if he were only still she would certainly save him,\r\nthat he clung quietly round her neck, only asking, as he found himself\r\nsinking to sleep,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMother, I don\xe2\x80\x99t need to keep awake, do I?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, my darling; sleep, if you want to.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, mother, if I do get asleep, you won\xe2\x80\x99t let him get me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo! so may God help me!\xe2\x80\x9d said his mother, with a paler cheek, and a\r\nbrighter light in her large dark eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re _sure_, an\xe2\x80\x99t you, mother?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, _sure_!\xe2\x80\x9d said the mother, in a voice that startled herself; for\r\nit seemed to her to come from a spirit within, that was no part of her;\r\nand the boy dropped his little weary head on her shoulder, and was soon\r\nasleep. How the touch of those warm arms, the gentle breathings that\r\ncame in her neck, seemed to add fire and spirit to her movements! It\r\nseemed to her as if strength poured into her in electric streams, from\r\nevery gentle touch and movement of the sleeping, confiding child.\r\nSublime is the dominion of the mind over the body, that, for a time,\r\ncan make flesh and nerve impregnable, and string the sinews like steel,\r\nso that the weak become so mighty.\r\n\r\nThe boundaries of the farm, the grove, the wood-lot, passed by her\r\ndizzily, as she walked on; and still she went, leaving one familiar\r\nobject after another, slacking not, pausing not, till reddening\r\ndaylight found her many a long mile from all traces of any familiar\r\nobjects upon the open highway.\r\n\r\nShe had often been, with her mistress, to visit some connections, in\r\nthe little village of T\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94, not far from the Ohio river, and knew the\r\nroad well. To go thither, to escape across the Ohio river, were the\r\nfirst hurried outlines of her plan of escape; beyond that, she could\r\nonly hope in God.\r\n\r\nWhen horses and vehicles began to move along the highway, with that\r\nalert perception peculiar to a state of excitement, and which seems to\r\nbe a sort of inspiration, she became aware that her headlong pace and\r\ndistracted air might bring on her remark and suspicion. She therefore\r\nput the boy on the ground, and, adjusting her dress and bonnet, she\r\nwalked on at as rapid a pace as she thought consistent with the\r\npreservation of appearances. In her little bundle she had provided a\r\nstore of cakes and apples, which she used as expedients for quickening\r\nthe speed of the child, rolling the apple some yards before them, when\r\nthe boy would run with all his might after it; and this ruse, often\r\nrepeated, carried them over many a half-mile.\r\n\r\nAfter a while, they came to a thick patch of woodland, through which\r\nmurmured a clear brook. As the child complained of hunger and thirst,\r\nshe climbed over the fence with him; and, sitting down behind a large\r\nrock which concealed them from the road, she gave him a breakfast out\r\nof her little package. The boy wondered and grieved that she could not\r\neat; and when, putting his arms round her neck, he tried to wedge some\r\nof his cake into her mouth, it seemed to her that the rising in her\r\nthroat would choke her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, Harry darling! mother can\xe2\x80\x99t eat till you are safe! We must go\r\non\xe2\x80\x94on\xe2\x80\x94till we come to the river!\xe2\x80\x9d And she hurried again into the road,\r\nand again constrained herself to walk regularly and composedly forward.\r\n\r\nShe was many miles past any neighborhood where she was personally\r\nknown. If she should chance to meet any who knew her, she reflected\r\nthat the well-known kindness of the family would be of itself a blind\r\nto suspicion, as making it an unlikely supposition that she could be a\r\nfugitive. As she was also so white as not to be known as of colored\r\nlineage, without a critical survey, and her child was white also, it\r\nwas much easier for her to pass on unsuspected.\r\n\r\nOn this presumption, she stopped at noon at a neat farmhouse, to rest\r\nherself, and buy some dinner for her child and self; for, as the danger\r\ndecreased with the distance, the supernatural tension of the nervous\r\nsystem lessened, and she found herself both weary and hungry.\r\n\r\nThe good woman, kindly and gossipping, seemed rather pleased than\r\notherwise with having somebody come in to talk with; and accepted,\r\nwithout examination, Eliza\xe2\x80\x99s statement, that she \xe2\x80\x9cwas going on a little\r\npiece, to spend a week with her friends,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94all which she hoped in her\r\nheart might prove strictly true.\r\n\r\nAn hour before sunset, she entered the village of T\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94, by the Ohio\r\nriver, weary and foot-sore, but still strong in heart. Her first glance\r\nwas at the river, which lay, like Jordan, between her and the Canaan of\r\nliberty on the other side.\r\n\r\nIt was now early spring, and the river was swollen and turbulent; great\r\ncakes of floating ice were swinging heavily to and fro in the turbid\r\nwaters. Owing to the peculiar form of the shore on the Kentucky side,\r\nthe land bending far out into the water, the ice had been lodged and\r\ndetained in great quantities, and the narrow channel which swept round\r\nthe bend was full of ice, piled one cake over another, thus forming a\r\ntemporary barrier to the descending ice, which lodged, and formed a\r\ngreat, undulating raft, filling up the whole river, and extending\r\nalmost to the Kentucky shore.\r\n\r\nEliza stood, for a moment, contemplating this unfavorable aspect of\r\nthings, which she saw at once must prevent the usual ferry-boat from\r\nrunning, and then turned into a small public house on the bank, to make\r\na few inquiries.\r\n\r\nThe hostess, who was busy in various fizzing and stewing operations\r\nover the fire, preparatory to the evening meal, stopped, with a fork in\r\nher hand, as Eliza\xe2\x80\x99s sweet and plaintive voice arrested her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t there any ferry or boat, that takes people over to B\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94, now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nshe said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, indeed!\xe2\x80\x9d said the woman; \xe2\x80\x9cthe boats has stopped running.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEliza\xe2\x80\x99s look of dismay and disappointment struck the woman, and she\r\nsaid, inquiringly,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay be you\xe2\x80\x99re wanting to get over?\xe2\x80\x94anybody sick? Ye seem mighty\r\nanxious?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve got a child that\xe2\x80\x99s very dangerous,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eliza. \xe2\x80\x9cI never heard of\r\nit till last night, and I\xe2\x80\x99ve walked quite a piece today, in hopes to\r\nget to the ferry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now, that\xe2\x80\x99s onlucky,\xe2\x80\x9d said the woman, whose motherly sympathies\r\nwere much aroused; \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m re\xe2\x80\x99lly consarned for ye. Solomon!\xe2\x80\x9d she called,\r\nfrom the window, towards a small back building. A man, in leather apron\r\nand very dirty hands, appeared at the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say, Sol,\xe2\x80\x9d said the woman, \xe2\x80\x9cis that ar man going to tote them bar\xe2\x80\x99ls\r\nover tonight?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe said he should try, if \xe2\x80\x99t was any way prudent,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s a man a piece down here, that\xe2\x80\x99s going over with some truck\r\nthis evening, if he durs\xe2\x80\x99 to; he\xe2\x80\x99ll be in here to supper tonight, so\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99d better set down and wait. That\xe2\x80\x99s a sweet little fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d added\r\nthe woman, offering him a cake.\r\n\r\nBut the child, wholly exhausted, cried with weariness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor fellow! he isn\xe2\x80\x99t used to walking, and I\xe2\x80\x99ve hurried him on so,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Eliza.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, take him into this room,\xe2\x80\x9d said the woman, opening into a small\r\nbed-room, where stood a comfortable bed. Eliza laid the weary boy upon\r\nit, and held his hands in hers till he was fast asleep. For her there\r\nwas no rest. As a fire in her bones, the thought of the pursuer urged\r\nher on; and she gazed with longing eyes on the sullen, surging waters\r\nthat lay between her and liberty.\r\n\r\nHere we must take our leave of her for the present, to follow the\r\ncourse of her pursuers.\r\n\r\n\r\nThough Mrs. Shelby had promised that the dinner should be hurried on\r\ntable, yet it was soon seen, as the thing has often been seen before,\r\nthat it required more than one to make a bargain. So, although the\r\norder was fairly given out in Haley\xe2\x80\x99s hearing, and carried to Aunt\r\nChloe by at least half a dozen juvenile messengers, that dignitary only\r\ngave certain very gruff snorts, and tosses of her head, and went on\r\nwith every operation in an unusually leisurely and circumstantial\r\nmanner.\r\n\r\nFor some singular reason, an impression seemed to reign among the\r\nservants generally that Missis would not be particularly disobliged by\r\ndelay; and it was wonderful what a number of counter accidents occurred\r\nconstantly, to retard the course of things. One luckless wight\r\ncontrived to upset the gravy; and then gravy had to be got up _de\r\nnovo_, with due care and formality, Aunt Chloe watching and stirring\r\nwith dogged precision, answering shortly, to all suggestions of haste,\r\nthat she \xe2\x80\x9cwarn\xe2\x80\x99t a going to have raw gravy on the table, to help\r\nnobody\xe2\x80\x99s catchings.\xe2\x80\x9d One tumbled down with the water, and had to go to\r\nthe spring for more; and another precipitated the butter into the path\r\nof events; and there was from time to time giggling news brought into\r\nthe kitchen that \xe2\x80\x9cMas\xe2\x80\x99r Haley was mighty oneasy, and that he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nsit in his cheer no ways, but was a walkin\xe2\x80\x99 and stalkin\xe2\x80\x99 to the winders\r\nand through the porch.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSarves him right!\xe2\x80\x9d said Aunt Chloe, indignantly. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99ll get wus nor\r\noneasy, one of these days, if he don\xe2\x80\x99t mend his ways. _His_ master\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nbe sending for him, and then see how he\xe2\x80\x99ll look!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99ll go to torment, and no mistake,\xe2\x80\x9d said little Jake.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe desarves it!\xe2\x80\x9d said Aunt Chloe, grimly; \xe2\x80\x9che\xe2\x80\x99s broke a many, many,\r\nmany hearts,\xe2\x80\x94I tell ye all!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, stopping, with a fork uplifted\r\nin her hands; \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s like what Mas\xe2\x80\x99r George reads in Ravelations,\xe2\x80\x94souls\r\na callin\xe2\x80\x99 under the altar! and a callin\xe2\x80\x99 on the Lord for vengeance on\r\nsich!\xe2\x80\x94and by and by the Lord he\xe2\x80\x99ll hear \xe2\x80\x99em\xe2\x80\x94so he will!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAunt Chloe, who was much revered in the kitchen, was listened to with\r\nopen mouth; and, the dinner being now fairly sent in, the whole kitchen\r\nwas at leisure to gossip with her, and to listen to her remarks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSich\xe2\x80\x99ll be burnt up forever, and no mistake; won\xe2\x80\x99t ther?\xe2\x80\x9d said Andy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d be glad to see it, I\xe2\x80\x99ll be boun\xe2\x80\x99,\xe2\x80\x9d said little Jake.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cChil\xe2\x80\x99en!\xe2\x80\x9d said a voice, that made them all start. It was Uncle Tom,\r\nwho had come in, and stood listening to the conversation at the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cChil\xe2\x80\x99en!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m afeard you don\xe2\x80\x99t know what ye\xe2\x80\x99re sayin\xe2\x80\x99.\r\nForever is a _dre\xe2\x80\x99ful_ word, chil\xe2\x80\x99en; it\xe2\x80\x99s awful to think on \xe2\x80\x99t. You\r\noughtenter wish that ar to any human crittur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t to anybody but the soul-drivers,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andy; \xe2\x80\x9cnobody can\r\nhelp wishing it to them, they \xe2\x80\x99s so awful wicked.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t natur herself kinder cry out on \xe2\x80\x99em?\xe2\x80\x9d said Aunt Chloe. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ndey tear der suckin\xe2\x80\x99 baby right off his mother\xe2\x80\x99s breast, and sell him,\r\nand der little children as is crying and holding on by her\r\nclothes,\xe2\x80\x94don\xe2\x80\x99t dey pull \xe2\x80\x99em off and sells \xe2\x80\x99em? Don\xe2\x80\x99t dey tear wife and\r\nhusband apart?\xe2\x80\x9d said Aunt Chloe, beginning to cry, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen it\xe2\x80\x99s jest\r\ntakin\xe2\x80\x99 the very life on \xe2\x80\x99em?\xe2\x80\x94and all the while does they feel one bit,\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t dey drink and smoke, and take it oncommon easy? Lor, if the devil\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t get them, what\xe2\x80\x99s he good for?\xe2\x80\x9d And Aunt Chloe covered her face\r\nwith her checked apron, and began to sob in good earnest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPray for them that \xe2\x80\x99spitefully use you, the good book says,\xe2\x80\x9d says Tom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPray for \xe2\x80\x99em!\xe2\x80\x9d said Aunt Chloe; \xe2\x80\x9cLor, it\xe2\x80\x99s too tough! I can\xe2\x80\x99t pray for\r\n\xe2\x80\x99em.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s natur, Chloe, and natur \xe2\x80\x99s strong,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, \xe2\x80\x9cbut the Lord\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ngrace is stronger; besides, you oughter think what an awful state a\r\npoor crittur\xe2\x80\x99s soul \xe2\x80\x99s in that\xe2\x80\x99ll do them ar things,\xe2\x80\x94you oughter thank\r\nGod that you an\xe2\x80\x99t _like_ him, Chloe. I\xe2\x80\x99m sure I\xe2\x80\x99d rather be sold, ten\r\nthousand times over, than to have all that ar poor crittur\xe2\x80\x99s got to\r\nanswer for.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo \xe2\x80\x99d I, a heap,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jake. \xe2\x80\x9cLor, _shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t_ we cotch it, Andy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAndy shrugged his shoulders, and gave an acquiescent whistle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m glad Mas\xe2\x80\x99r didn\xe2\x80\x99t go off this morning, as he looked to,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthat ar hurt me more than sellin\xe2\x80\x99, it did. Mebbe it might have been\r\nnatural for him, but \xe2\x80\x99t would have come desp\xe2\x80\x99t hard on me, as has known\r\nhim from a baby; but I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen Mas\xe2\x80\x99r, and I begin ter feel sort o\xe2\x80\x99\r\nreconciled to the Lord\xe2\x80\x99s will now. Mas\xe2\x80\x99r couldn\xe2\x80\x99t help hisself; he did\r\nright, but I\xe2\x80\x99m feared things will be kinder goin\xe2\x80\x99 to rack, when I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\ngone Mas\xe2\x80\x99r can\xe2\x80\x99t be spected to be a pryin\xe2\x80\x99 round everywhar, as I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\ndone, a keepin\xe2\x80\x99 up all the ends. The boys all means well, but they \xe2\x80\x99s\r\npowerful car\xe2\x80\x99less. That ar troubles me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe bell here rang, and Tom was summoned to the parlor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTom,\xe2\x80\x9d said his master, kindly, \xe2\x80\x9cI want you to notice that I give this\r\ngentleman bonds to forfeit a thousand dollars if you are not on the\r\nspot when he wants you; he\xe2\x80\x99s going today to look after his other\r\nbusiness, and you can have the day to yourself. Go anywhere you like,\r\nboy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd mind yourself,\xe2\x80\x9d said the trader, \xe2\x80\x9cand don\xe2\x80\x99t come it over your\r\nmaster with any o\xe2\x80\x99 yer nigger tricks; for I\xe2\x80\x99ll take every cent out of\r\nhim, if you an\xe2\x80\x99t thar.
