And now I jist ask you, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r, have I ever broke\r\nword to you, or gone contrary to you, \xe2\x80\x99specially since I was a\r\nChristian?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Shelby was fairly overcome, and the tears rose to his eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy good boy,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cthe Lord knows you say but the truth; and if I\r\nwas able to help it, all the world shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t buy you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd sure as I am a Christian woman,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Shelby, \xe2\x80\x9cyou shall be\r\nredeemed as soon as I can any way bring together means. Sir,\xe2\x80\x9d she said\r\nto Haley, \xe2\x80\x9ctake good account of who you sell him to, and let me know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLor, yes, for that matter,\xe2\x80\x9d said the trader, \xe2\x80\x9cI may bring him up in a\r\nyear, not much the wuss for wear, and trade him back.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll trade with you then, and make it for your advantage,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs.\r\nShelby.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course,\xe2\x80\x9d said the trader, \xe2\x80\x9call \xe2\x80\x99s equal with me; li\xe2\x80\x99ves trade \xe2\x80\x99em\r\nup as down, so I does a good business. All I want is a livin\xe2\x80\x99, you\r\nknow, ma\xe2\x80\x99am; that\xe2\x80\x99s all any on us wants, I, s\xe2\x80\x99pose.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. and Mrs. Shelby both felt annoyed and degraded by the familiar\r\nimpudence of the trader, and yet both saw the absolute necessity of\r\nputting a constraint on their feelings. The more hopelessly sordid and\r\ninsensible he appeared, the greater became Mrs. Shelby\xe2\x80\x99s dread of his\r\nsucceeding in recapturing Eliza and her child, and of course the\r\ngreater her motive for detaining him by every female artifice. She\r\ntherefore graciously smiled, assented, chatted familiarly, and did all\r\nshe could to make time pass imperceptibly.\r\n\r\nAt two o\xe2\x80\x99clock Sam and Andy brought the horses up to the posts,\r\napparently greatly refreshed and invigorated by the scamper of the\r\nmorning.\r\n\r\nSam was there new oiled from dinner, with an abundance of zealous and\r\nready officiousness. I spect they\xe2\x80\x99s the kind,\r\nthough they han\xe2\x80\x99t never had no practice. They \xe2\x80\x99s _far_ dogs, though, at\r\nmost anything, if you\xe2\x80\x99d get \xe2\x80\x99em started. Yer mustn\xe2\x80\x99t be a makin\xe2\x80\x99 game. This yer\r\nan\xe2\x80\x99t no way to help Mas\xe2\x80\x99r.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall take the straight road to the river,\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley, decidedly,\r\nafter they had come to the boundaries of the estate. \xe2\x80\x9cI know the way of\r\nall of \xe2\x80\x99em,\xe2\x80\x94they makes tracks for the underground.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSartin,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sam, \xe2\x80\x9cdat\xe2\x80\x99s de idee. Now, der\xe2\x80\x99s two roads to de river,\xe2\x80\x94de dirt road and der\r\npike,\xe2\x80\x94which Mas\xe2\x80\x99r mean to take?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAndy looked up innocently at Sam, surprised at hearing this new\r\ngeographical fact, but instantly confirmed what he said, by a vehement\r\nreiteration.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCause,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sam, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d rather be \xe2\x80\x99clined to \xe2\x80\x99magine that Lizy \xe2\x80\x99d take\r\nde dirt road, bein\xe2\x80\x99 it\xe2\x80\x99s the least travelled.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHaley, notwithstanding that he was a very old bird, and naturally\r\ninclined to be suspicious of chaff, was rather brought up by this view\r\nof the case.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf yer warn\xe2\x80\x99t both on yer such cussed liars, now!\xe2\x80\x9d he said,\r\ncontemplatively as he pondered a moment.\r\n\r\nThe pensive, reflective tone in which this was spoken appeared to amuse\r\nAndy prodigiously, and he drew a little behind, and shook so as\r\napparently to run a great risk of failing off his horse, while Sam\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nface was immovably composed into the most doleful gravity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCourse,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sam, \xe2\x80\x9cMas\xe2\x80\x99r can do as he\xe2\x80\x99d ruther, go de straight road,\r\nif Mas\xe2\x80\x99r thinks best,\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s all one to us. Gals is nat\xe2\x80\x99lly\r\nmade contrary; and so, if you thinks they\xe2\x80\x99ve gone one road, it is\r\nsartin you\xe2\x80\x99d better go t\xe2\x80\x99 other, and then you\xe2\x80\x99ll be sure to find \xe2\x80\x99em.\r\nNow, my private \xe2\x80\x99pinion is, Lizy took der road; so I think we\xe2\x80\x99d better\r\ntake de straight one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis profound generic view of the female sex did not seem to dispose\r\nHaley particularly to the straight road, and he announced decidedly\r\nthat he should go the other, and asked Sam when they should come to it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA little piece ahead,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sam, giving a wink to Andy with the eye\r\nwhich was on Andy\xe2\x80\x99s side of the head; and he added, gravely, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nstudded on de matter, and I\xe2\x80\x99m quite clar we ought not to go dat ar way.\r\nI nebber been over it no way. It\xe2\x80\x99s despit lonesome, and we might lose\r\nour way,\xe2\x80\x94whar we\xe2\x80\x99d come to, de Lord only knows.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNevertheless,\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley, \xe2\x80\x9cI shall go that way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow I think on \xe2\x80\x99t, I think I hearn \xe2\x80\x99em tell that dat ar road was all\r\nfenced up and down by der creek, and thar, an\xe2\x80\x99t it, Andy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAndy wasn\xe2\x80\x99t certain; he\xe2\x80\x99d only \xe2\x80\x9chearn tell\xe2\x80\x9d about that road, but never\r\nbeen over it. In short, he was strictly noncommittal.\r\n\r\nHaley, accustomed to strike the balance of probabilities between lies\r\nof greater or lesser magnitude, thought that it lay in favor of the\r\ndirt road aforesaid. The mention of the thing he thought he perceived\r\nwas involuntary on Sam\xe2\x80\x99s part at first, and his confused attempts to\r\ndissuade him he set down to a desperate lying on second thoughts, as\r\nbeing unwilling to implicate Liza.\r\n\r\nWhen, therefore, Sam indicated the road, Haley plunged briskly into it,\r\nfollowed by Sam and Andy.\r\n\r\nNow, the road, in fact, was an old one, that had formerly been a\r\nthoroughfare to the river, but abandoned for many years after the\r\nlaying of the new pike. It was open for about an hour\xe2\x80\x99s ride, and after\r\nthat it was cut across by various farms and fences. Sam knew this fact\r\nperfectly well,\xe2\x80\x94indeed, the road had been so long closed up, that Andy\r\nhad never heard of it. He therefore rode along with an air of dutiful\r\nsubmission, only groaning and vociferating occasionally that \xe2\x80\x99t was\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cdesp\xe2\x80\x99t rough, and bad for Jerry\xe2\x80\x99s foot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, I jest give yer warning,\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley, \xe2\x80\x9cI know yer; yer won\xe2\x80\x99t get\r\nme to turn off this road, with all yer fussin\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94so you shet up!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMas\xe2\x80\x99r will go his own way!\xe2\x80\x9d said Sam, with rueful submission, at the\r\nsame time winking most portentously to Andy, whose delight was now very\r\nnear the explosive point.\r\n\r\nSam was in wonderful spirits,\xe2\x80\x94professed to keep a very brisk\r\nlookout,\xe2\x80\x94at one time exclaiming that he saw \xe2\x80\x9ca gal\xe2\x80\x99s bonnet\xe2\x80\x9d on the top\r\nof some distant eminence, or calling to Andy \xe2\x80\x9cif that thar wasn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\n\xe2\x80\x99Lizy\xe2\x80\x99 down in the hollow;\xe2\x80\x9d always making these exclamations in some\r\nrough or craggy part of the road, where the sudden quickening of speed\r\nwas a special inconvenience to all parties concerned, and thus keeping\r\nHaley in a state of constant commotion.\r\n\r\nAfter riding about an hour in this way, the whole party made a\r\nprecipitate and tumultuous descent into a barn-yard belonging to a\r\nlarge farming establishment. Not a soul was in sight, all the hands\r\nbeing employed in the fields; but, as the barn stood conspicuously and\r\nplainly square across the road, it was evident that their journey in\r\nthat direction had reached a decided finale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWan\xe2\x80\x99t dat ar what I telled Mas\xe2\x80\x99r?\xe2\x80\x9d said Sam, with an air of injured\r\ninnocence. \xe2\x80\x9cHow does strange gentleman spect to know more about a\r\ncountry dan de natives born and raised?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou rascal!\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley, \xe2\x80\x9cyou knew all about this.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDidn\xe2\x80\x99t I tell yer I _knowd_, and yer wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t believe me? I telled\r\nMas\xe2\x80\x99r \xe2\x80\x99t was all shet up, and fenced up, and I didn\xe2\x80\x99t spect we could\r\nget through,\xe2\x80\x94Andy heard me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was all too true to be disputed, and the unlucky man had to pocket\r\nhis wrath with the best grace he was able, and all three faced to the\r\nright about, and took up their line of march for the highway.\r\n\r\nIn consequence of all the various delays, it was about three-quarters\r\nof an hour after Eliza had laid her child to sleep in the village\r\ntavern that the party came riding into the same place. Eliza was\r\nstanding by the window, looking out in another direction, when Sam\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nquick eye caught a glimpse of her. Haley and Andy were two yards\r\nbehind. At this crisis, Sam contrived to have his hat blown off, and\r\nuttered a loud and characteristic ejaculation, which startled her at\r\nonce; she drew suddenly back; the whole train swept by the window,\r\nround to the front door.\r\n\r\nA thousand lives seemed to be concentrated in that one moment to Eliza.\r\nHer room opened by a side door to the river. She caught her child, and\r\nsprang down the steps towards it. The trader caught a full glimpse of\r\nher just as she was disappearing down the bank; and throwing himself\r\nfrom his horse, and calling loudly on Sam and Andy, he was after her\r\nlike a hound after a deer. In that dizzy moment her feet to her scarce\r\nseemed to touch the ground, and a moment brought her to the water\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nedge. Right on behind they came; and, nerved with strength such as God\r\ngives only to the desperate, with one wild cry and flying leap, she\r\nvaulted sheer over the turbid current by the shore, on to the raft of\r\nice beyond. It was a desperate leap\xe2\x80\x94impossible to anything but madness\r\nand despair; and Haley, Sam, and Andy, instinctively cried out, and\r\nlifted up their hands, as she did it.\r\n\r\nThe huge green fragment of ice on which she alighted pitched and\r\ncreaked as her weight came on it, but she staid there not a moment.\r\nWith wild cries and desperate energy she leaped to another and still\r\nanother cake; stumbling\xe2\x80\x94leaping\xe2\x80\x94slipping\xe2\x80\x94springing upwards again! Her\r\nshoes are gone\xe2\x80\x94her stockings cut from her feet\xe2\x80\x94while blood marked every\r\nstep; but she saw nothing, felt nothing, till dimly, as in a dream, she\r\nsaw the Ohio side, and a man helping her up the bank.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYer a brave gal, now, whoever ye ar!\xe2\x80\x9d said the man, with an oath.\r\n\r\nEliza recognized the voice and face for a man who owned a farm not far\r\nfrom her old home.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Mr. Symmes!\xe2\x80\x94save me\xe2\x80\x94do save me\xe2\x80\x94do hide me!\xe2\x80\x9d said Elia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, what\xe2\x80\x99s this?\xe2\x80\x9d said the man. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy, if \xe2\x80\x99tan\xe2\x80\x99t Shelby\xe2\x80\x99s gal!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy child!\xe2\x80\x94this boy!\xe2\x80\x94he\xe2\x80\x99d sold him! The best I can do is to tell ye to go _thar_,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nhe, pointing to a large white house which stood by itself, off the main\r\nstreet of the village. \xe2\x80\x9cGo thar; they\xe2\x80\x99re kind folks. What do you take a feller for? In course not,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid the man. \xe2\x80\x9cCome, now, go along like a likely, sensible gal, as you\r\nare. You\xe2\x80\x99ve arnt your liberty, and you shall have it, for all me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe woman folded her child to her bosom, and walked firmly and swiftly\r\naway. The man stood and looked after her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShelby, now, mebbe won\xe2\x80\x99t think this yer the most neighborly thing in\r\nthe world; but what\xe2\x80\x99s a feller to do? Don\xe2\x80\x99t think I feel spry enough for dat ar, no way!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nand Sam gave a hoarse chuckle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_You_ laugh!\xe2\x80\x9d said the trader, with a growl.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLord bless you, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r, I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t help it now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sam, giving way\r\nto the long pent-up delight of his soul. \xe2\x80\x9cShe looked so curi\xe2\x80\x99s, a\r\nleapin\xe2\x80\x99 and springin\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94ice a crackin\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94and only to hear her,\xe2\x80\x94plump! ker\r\nchunk! ker splash! Spring! Lord! how she goes it!\xe2\x80\x9d and Sam and Andy\r\nlaughed till the tears rolled down their cheeks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll make ye laugh t\xe2\x80\x99 other side yer mouths!\xe2\x80\x9d said the trader, laying\r\nabout their heads with his riding-whip.\r\n\r\nBoth ducked, and ran shouting up the bank, and were on their horses\r\nbefore he was up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-evening, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r!\xe2\x80\x9d said Sam, with much gravity. \xe2\x80\x9cI berry much spect\r\nMissis be anxious \xe2\x80\x99bout Jerry. Mas\xe2\x80\x99r Haley won\xe2\x80\x99t want us no longer.\r\nMissis wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t hear of our ridin\xe2\x80\x99 the critters over Lizy\xe2\x80\x99s bridge\r\ntonight;\xe2\x80\x9d and, with a facetious poke into Andy\xe2\x80\x99s ribs, he started off,\r\nfollowed by the latter, at full speed,\xe2\x80\x94their shouts of laughter coming\r\nfaintly on the wind.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VIII\r\nEliza\xe2\x80\x99s Escape\r\n\r\n\r\nEliza made her desperate retreat across the river just in the dusk of\r\ntwilight. The gray mist of evening, rising slowly from the river,\r\nenveloped her as she disappeared up the bank, and the swollen current\r\nand floundering masses of ice presented a hopeless barrier between her\r\nand her pursuer. Haley therefore slowly and discontentedly returned to\r\nthe little tavern, to ponder further what was to be done. The woman\r\nopened to him the door of a little parlor, covered with a rag carpet,\r\nwhere stood a table with a very shining black oil-cloth, sundry lank,\r\nhigh-backed wood chairs, with some plaster images in resplendent colors\r\non the mantel-shelf, above a very dimly-smoking grate; a long hard-wood\r\nsettle extended its uneasy length by the chimney, and here Haley sat\r\nhim down to meditate on the instability of human hopes and happiness in\r\ngeneral.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat did I want with the little cuss, now,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to himself, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\r\nI should have got myself treed like a coon, as I am, this yer way?\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\nHaley relieved himself by repeating over a not very select litany of\r\nimprecations on himself, which, though there was the best possible\r\nreason to consider them as true, we shall, as a matter of taste, omit.\r\n\r\nHe was startled by the loud and dissonant voice of a man who was\r\napparently dismounting at the door. He hurried to the window.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the land! if this yer an\xe2\x80\x99t the nearest, now, to what I\xe2\x80\x99ve heard\r\nfolks call Providence,\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley. \xe2\x80\x9cI do b\xe2\x80\x99lieve that ar\xe2\x80\x99s Tom Loker.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHaley hastened out. Standing by the bar, in the corner of the room, was\r\na brawny, muscular man, full six feet in height, and broad in\r\nproportion. He was dressed in a coat of buffalo-skin, made with the\r\nhair outward, which gave him a shaggy and fierce appearance, perfectly\r\nin keeping with the whole air of his physiognomy. In the head and face\r\nevery organ and lineament expressive of brutal and unhesitating\r\nviolence was in a state of the highest possible development. Indeed,\r\ncould our readers fancy a bull-dog come unto man\xe2\x80\x99s estate, and walking\r\nabout in a hat and coat, they would have no unapt idea of the general\r\nstyle and effect of his physique. He was accompanied by a travelling\r\ncompanion, in many respects an exact contrast to himself. He was short\r\nand slender, lithe and catlike in his motions, and had a peering,\r\nmousing expression about his keen black eyes, with which every feature\r\nof his face seemed sharpened into sympathy; his thin, long nose, ran\r\nout as if it was eager to bore into the nature of things in general;\r\nhis sleek, thin, black hair was stuck eagerly forward, and all his\r\nmotions and evolutions expressed a dry, cautious acuteness. The great\r\nman poured out a big tumbler half full of raw spirits, and gulped it\r\ndown without a word. The little man stood tiptoe, and putting his head\r\nfirst to one side and then the other, and snuffing considerately in the\r\ndirections of the various bottles, ordered at last a mint julep, in a\r\nthin and quivering voice, and with an air of great circumspection. When\r\npoured out, he took it and looked at it with a sharp, complacent air,\r\nlike a man who thinks he has done about the right thing, and hit the\r\nnail on the head, and proceeded to dispose of it in short and\r\nwell-advised sips.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWal, now, who\xe2\x80\x99d a thought this yer luck \xe2\x80\x99ad come to me? Why, Loker,\r\nhow are ye?\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley, coming forward, and extending his hand to the\r\nbig man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe devil!\xe2\x80\x9d was the civil reply. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat brought you here, Haley?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe mousing man, who bore the name of Marks, instantly stopped his\r\nsipping, and, poking his head forward, looked shrewdly on the new\r\nacquaintance, as a cat sometimes looks at a moving dry leaf, or some\r\nother possible object of pursuit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say, Tom, this yer\xe2\x80\x99s the luckiest thing in the world. I\xe2\x80\x99m in a devil\r\nof a hobble, and you must help me out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUgh? aw! like enough!\xe2\x80\x9d grunted his complacent acquaintance. \xe2\x80\x9cA body\r\nmay be pretty sure of that, when _you\xe2\x80\x99re_ glad to see \xe2\x80\x99em; something to\r\nbe made off of \xe2\x80\x99em. What\xe2\x80\x99s the blow now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve got a friend here?\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley, looking doubtfully at Marks;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cpartner, perhaps?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I have. Here, Marks! here\xe2\x80\x99s that ar feller that I was in with in\r\nNatchez.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall be pleased with his acquaintance,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marks, thrusting out a\r\nlong, thin hand, like a raven\xe2\x80\x99s claw. \xe2\x80\x9cMr. Haley, I believe?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe same, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd now, gentlemen, seein\xe2\x80\x99 as we\xe2\x80\x99ve met\r\nso happily, I think I\xe2\x80\x99ll stand up to a small matter of a treat in this\r\nhere parlor. So, now, old coon,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to the man at the bar, \xe2\x80\x9cget us\r\nhot water, and sugar, and cigars, and plenty of the _real stuff_ and\r\nwe\xe2\x80\x99ll have a blow-out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBehold, then, the candles lighted, the fire stimulated to the burning\r\npoint in the grate, and our three worthies seated round a table, well\r\nspread with all the accessories to good fellowship enumerated before.\r\n\r\nHaley began a pathetic recital of his peculiar troubles. Loker shut up\r\nhis mouth, and listened to him with gruff and surly attention. Marks,\r\nwho was anxiously and with much fidgeting compounding a tumbler of\r\npunch to his own peculiar taste, occasionally looked up from his\r\nemployment, and, poking his sharp nose and chin almost into Haley\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nface, gave the most earnest heed to the whole narrative. The conclusion\r\nof it appeared to amuse him extremely, for he shook his shoulders and\r\nsides in silence, and perked up his thin lips with an air of great\r\ninternal enjoyment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo, then, ye\xe2\x80\x99r fairly sewed up, an\xe2\x80\x99t ye?\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9che! he! he! It\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nneatly done, too.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis yer young-un business makes lots of trouble in the trade,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nHaley, dolefully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf we could get a breed of gals that didn\xe2\x80\x99t care, now, for their young\r\nuns,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marks; \xe2\x80\x9ctell ye, I think \xe2\x80\x99t would be \xe2\x80\x99bout the greatest\r\nmod\xe2\x80\x99rn improvement I knows on,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and Marks patronized his joke by a\r\nquiet introductory sniggle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJes so,\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley; \xe2\x80\x9cI never couldn\xe2\x80\x99t see into it; young uns is heaps\r\nof trouble to \xe2\x80\x99em; one would think, now, they\xe2\x80\x99d be glad to get clar on\r\n\xe2\x80\x99em; but they arn\xe2\x80\x99t. And the more trouble a young un is, and the more\r\ngood for nothing, as a gen\xe2\x80\x99l thing, the tighter they sticks to \xe2\x80\x99em.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWal, Mr. Haley,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marks, \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98est pass the hot water. Now, I bought a gal once, when I\r\nwas in the trade,\xe2\x80\x94a tight, likely wench she was, too, and quite\r\nconsiderable smart,\xe2\x80\x94and she had a young un that was mis\xe2\x80\x99able sickly; it\r\nhad a crooked back, or something or other; and I jest gin \xe2\x80\x99t away to a\r\nman that thought he\xe2\x80\x99d take his chance raising on \xe2\x80\x99t, being it didn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ncost nothin\xe2\x80\x99;\xe2\x80\x94never thought, yer know, of the gal\xe2\x80\x99s takin\xe2\x80\x99 on about\r\nit,\xe2\x80\x94but, Lord, yer oughter seen how she went on. Fact\xe2\x80\x94he was stone blind. Wal, ye see, I thought there warn\xe2\x80\x99t no\r\nharm in my jest passing him along, and not sayin\xe2\x80\x99 nothin\xe2\x80\x99; and I\xe2\x80\x99d got\r\nhim nicely swapped off for a keg o\xe2\x80\x99 whiskey; but come to get him away\r\nfrom the gal, she was jest like a tiger. I\r\nwon\xe2\x80\x99t hear one word\xe2\x80\x94not the beginning of a word.\xe2\x80\x99 I says to \xe2\x80\x99em, \xe2\x80\x98This\r\nyer young un\xe2\x80\x99s mine, and not yourn, and you\xe2\x80\x99ve no kind o\xe2\x80\x99 business with\r\nit. Bob!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come, gentlemen, I say; this isn\xe2\x80\x99t business,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marks.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s different ways, you know, of looking at all subjects. After exchanging a few words of\r\nfurther arrangement, Haley, with visible reluctance, handed over the\r\nfifty dollars to Tom, and the worthy trio separated for the night.\r\n\r\nIf any of our refined and Christian readers object to the society into\r\nwhich this scene introduces them, let us beg them to begin and conquer\r\ntheir prejudices in time. The catching business, we beg to remind them,\r\nis rising to the dignity of a lawful and patriotic profession. If all\r\nthe broad land between the Mississippi and the Pacific becomes one\r\ngreat market for bodies and souls, and human property retains the\r\nlocomotive tendencies of this nineteenth century, the trader and\r\ncatcher may yet be among our aristocracy.\r\n\r\n\r\nWhile this scene was going on at the tavern, Sam and Andy, in a state\r\nof high felicitation, pursued their way home.\r\n\r\nSam was in the highest possible feather, and expressed his exultation\r\nby all sorts of supernatural howls and ejaculations, by divers odd\r\nmotions and contortions of his whole system. Sometimes he would sit\r\nbackward, with his face to the horse\xe2\x80\x99s tail and sides, and then, with a\r\nwhoop and a somerset, come right side up in his place again, and,\r\ndrawing on a grave face, begin to lecture Andy in high-sounding tones\r\nfor laughing and playing the fool. Anon, slapping his sides with his\r\narms, he would burst forth in peals of laughter, that made the old\r\nwoods ring as they passed. With all these evolutions, he contrived to\r\nkeep the horses up to the top of their speed, until, between ten and\r\neleven, their heels resounded on the gravel at the end of the balcony.\r\nMrs. Shelby flew to the railings.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs that you, Sam? And didn\xe2\x80\x99t I car Mas\xe2\x80\x99r Haley\r\nnight five miles out of de road, dis evening, or else he\xe2\x80\x99d a come up\r\nwith Lizy as easy as a dog arter a coon. These yer \xe2\x80\x99s all providences.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are a kind of providences that you\xe2\x80\x99ll have to be pretty sparing\r\nof, Master Sam. I allow no such practices with gentlemen on my place,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Mr. Shelby, with as much sternness as he could command, under the\r\ncircumstances.\r\n\r\nNow, there is no more use in making believe be angry with a negro than\r\nwith a child; both instinctively see the true state of the case,\r\nthrough all attempts to affect the contrary; and Sam was in no wise\r\ndisheartened by this rebuke, though he assumed an air of doleful\r\ngravity, and stood with the corners of his mouth lowered in most\r\npenitential style.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMas\xe2\x80\x99r quite right,\xe2\x80\x94quite; it was ugly on me,\xe2\x80\x94there\xe2\x80\x99s no disputin\xe2\x80\x99 that\r\nar; and of course Mas\xe2\x80\x99r and Missis wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t encourage no such works.\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99m sensible of dat ar; but a poor nigger like me \xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x99mazin\xe2\x80\x99 tempted to\r\nact ugly sometimes, when fellers will cut up such shines as dat ar\r\nMas\xe2\x80\x99r Haley; he an\xe2\x80\x99t no gen\xe2\x80\x99l\xe2\x80\x99man no way; anybody\xe2\x80\x99s been raised as I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nbeen can\xe2\x80\x99t help a seein\xe2\x80\x99 dat ar.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Sam,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Shelby, \xe2\x80\x9cas you appear to have a proper sense of\r\nyour errors, you may go now and tell Aunt Chloe she may get you some of\r\nthat cold ham that was left of dinner today. You and Andy must be\r\nhungry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMissis is a heap too good for us,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sam, making his bow with\r\nalacrity, and departing.\r\n\r\nIt will be perceived, as has been before intimated, that Master Sam had\r\na native talent that might, undoubtedly, have raised him to eminence in\r\npolitical life,\xe2\x80\x94a talent of making capital out of everything that\r\nturned up, to be invested for his own especial praise and glory; and\r\nhaving done up his piety and humility, as he trusted, to the\r\nsatisfaction of the parlor, he clapped his palm-leaf on his head, with\r\na sort of rakish, free-and-easy air, and proceeded to the dominions of\r\nAunt Chloe, with the intention of flourishing largely in the kitchen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll speechify these yer niggers,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sam to himself, \xe2\x80\x9cnow I\xe2\x80\x99ve got\r\na chance. Lord, I\xe2\x80\x99ll reel it off to make \xe2\x80\x99em stare!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt must be observed that one of Sam\xe2\x80\x99s especial delights had been to\r\nride in attendance on his master to all kinds of political gatherings,\r\nwhere, roosted on some rail fence, or perched aloft in some tree, he\r\nwould sit watching the orators, with the greatest apparent gusto, and\r\nthen, descending among the various brethren of his own color, assembled\r\non the same errand, he would edify and delight them with the most\r\nludicrous burlesques and imitations, all delivered with the most\r\nimperturbable earnestness and solemnity; and though the auditors\r\nimmediately about him were generally of his own color, it not\r\ninfrequently happened that they were fringed pretty deeply with those\r\nof a fairer complexion, who listened, laughing and winking, to Sam\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ngreat self-congratulation. In fact, Sam considered oratory as his\r\nvocation, and never let slip an opportunity of magnifying his office.\r\n\r\nNow, between Sam and Aunt Chloe there had existed, from ancient times,\r\na sort of chronic feud, or rather a decided coolness; but, as Sam was\r\nmeditating something in the provision department, as the necessary and\r\nobvious foundation of his operations, he determined, on the present\r\noccasion, to be eminently conciliatory; for he well knew that although\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMissis\xe2\x80\x99 orders\xe2\x80\x9d would undoubtedly be followed to the letter, yet he\r\nshould gain a considerable deal by enlisting the spirit also. He\r\ntherefore appeared before Aunt Chloe with a touchingly subdued,\r\nresigned expression, like one who has suffered immeasurable hardships\r\nin behalf of a persecuted fellow-creature,\xe2\x80\x94enlarged upon the fact that\r\nMissis had directed him to come to Aunt Chloe for whatever might be\r\nwanting to make up the balance in his solids and fluids,\xe2\x80\x94and thus\r\nunequivocally acknowledged her right and supremacy in the cooking\r\ndepartment, and all thereto pertaining.\r\n\r\nThe thing took accordingly. No poor, simple, virtuous body was ever\r\ncajoled by the attentions of an electioneering politician with more\r\nease than Aunt Chloe was won over by Master Sam\xe2\x80\x99s suavities; and if he\r\nhad been the prodigal son himself, he could not have been overwhelmed\r\nwith more maternal bountifulness; and he soon found himself seated,\r\nhappy and glorious, over a large tin pan, containing a sort of _olla\r\npodrida_ of all that had appeared on the table for two or three days\r\npast. Savory morsels of ham, golden blocks of corn-cake, fragments of\r\npie of every conceivable mathematical figure, chicken wings, gizzards,\r\nand drumsticks, all appeared in picturesque confusion; and Sam, as\r\nmonarch of all he surveyed, sat with his palm-leaf cocked rejoicingly\r\nto one side, and patronizing Andy at his right hand.\r\n\r\nThe kitchen was full of all his compeers, who had hurried and crowded\r\nin, from the various cabins, to hear the termination of the day\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nexploits. Now was Sam\xe2\x80\x99s hour of glory. The story of the day was\r\nrehearsed, with all kinds of ornament and varnishing which might be\r\nnecessary to heighten its effect; for Sam, like some of our fashionable\r\ndilettanti, never allowed a story to lose any of its gilding by passing\r\nthrough his hands. Roars of laughter attended the narration, and were\r\ntaken up and prolonged by all the smaller fry, who were lying, in any\r\nquantity, about on the floor, or perched in every corner. In the height\r\nof the uproar and laughter, Sam, however, preserved an immovable\r\ngravity, only from time to time rolling his eyes up, and giving his\r\nauditors divers inexpressibly droll glances, without departing from the\r\nsententious elevation of his oratory.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYer see, fellow-countrymen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sam, elevating a turkey\xe2\x80\x99s leg, with\r\nenergy, \xe2\x80\x9cyer see, now what dis yer chile \xe2\x80\x99s up ter, for fendin\xe2\x80\x99 yer\r\nall,\xe2\x80\x94yes, all on yer. For him as tries to get one o\xe2\x80\x99 our people is as\r\ngood as tryin\xe2\x80\x99 to get all; yer see the principle \xe2\x80\x99s de same,\xe2\x80\x94dat ar\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nclar. And any one o\xe2\x80\x99 these yer drivers that comes smelling round arter\r\nany our people, why, he\xe2\x80\x99s got _me_ in his way; _I\xe2\x80\x99m_ the feller he\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ngot to set in with,\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99m the feller for yer all to come to,\r\nbredren,\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99ll stand up for yer rights,\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99ll fend \xe2\x80\x99em to the last\r\nbreath!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, but Sam, yer telled me, only this mornin\xe2\x80\x99, that you\xe2\x80\x99d help this\r\nyer Mas\xe2\x80\x99r to cotch Lizy; seems to me yer talk don\xe2\x80\x99t hang together,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Andy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI tell you now, Andy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sam, with awful superiority, \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t yer be\r\na talkin\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x99bout what yer don\xe2\x80\x99t know nothin\xe2\x80\x99 on; boys like you, Andy,\r\nmeans well, but they can\xe2\x80\x99t be spected to collusitate the great\r\nprinciples of action.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAndy looked rebuked, particularly by the hard word collusitate, which\r\nmost of the youngerly members of the company seemed to consider as a\r\nsettler in the case, while Sam proceeded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDat ar was _conscience_, Andy; when I thought of gwine arter Lizy, I\r\nrailly spected Mas\xe2\x80\x99r was sot dat way. When I found Missis was sot the\r\ncontrar, dat ar was conscience _more yet_,\xe2\x80\x94cause fellers allers gets\r\nmore by stickin\xe2\x80\x99 to Missis\xe2\x80\x99 side,\xe2\x80\x94so yer see I \xe2\x80\x99s persistent either\r\nway, and sticks up to conscience, and holds on to principles. Yes,\r\n_principles_,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sam, giving an enthusiastic toss to a chicken\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nneck,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cwhat\xe2\x80\x99s principles good for, if we isn\xe2\x80\x99t persistent, I wanter\r\nknow? Thar, Andy, you may have dat ar bone,\xe2\x80\x94tan\xe2\x80\x99t picked quite clean.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSam\xe2\x80\x99s audience hanging on his words with open mouth, he could not but\r\nproceed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDis yer matter \xe2\x80\x99bout persistence, feller-niggers,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sam, with the\r\nair of one entering into an abstruse subject, \xe2\x80\x9cdis yer \xe2\x80\x99sistency \xe2\x80\x99s a\r\nthing what an\xe2\x80\x99t seed into very clar, by most anybody. Now, yer see,\r\nwhen a feller stands up for a thing one day and night, de contrar de\r\nnext, folks ses (and nat\xe2\x80\x99rally enough dey ses), why he an\xe2\x80\x99t\r\npersistent,\xe2\x80\x94hand me dat ar bit o\xe2\x80\x99 corn-cake, Andy. But let\xe2\x80\x99s look inter\r\nit. I hope the gen\xe2\x80\x99lmen and der fair sex will scuse my usin\xe2\x80\x99 an or\xe2\x80\x99nary\r\nsort o\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x99parison. Here! I\xe2\x80\x99m a trying to get top o\xe2\x80\x99 der hay. Wal, I puts\r\nup my larder dis yer side; \xe2\x80\x99tan\xe2\x80\x99t no go;\xe2\x80\x94den, cause I don\xe2\x80\x99t try dere no\r\nmore, but puts my larder right de contrar side, an\xe2\x80\x99t I persistent? I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\npersistent in wantin\xe2\x80\x99 to get up which ary side my larder is; don\xe2\x80\x99t you\r\nsee, all on yer?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s the only thing ye ever was persistent in, Lord knows!\xe2\x80\x9d muttered\r\nAunt Chloe, who was getting rather restive; the merriment of the\r\nevening being to her somewhat after the Scripture comparison,\xe2\x80\x94like\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cvinegar upon nitre.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, indeed!\xe2\x80\x9d said Sam, rising, full of supper and glory, for a\r\nclosing effort. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, my feller-citizens and ladies of de other sex in\r\ngeneral, I has principles,\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99m proud to \xe2\x80\x99oon \xe2\x80\x99em,\xe2\x80\x94they \xe2\x80\x99s perquisite to\r\ndese yer times, and ter _all_ times. I has principles, and I sticks to\r\n\xe2\x80\x99em like forty,\xe2\x80\x94jest anything that I thinks is principle, I goes in to\r\n\xe2\x80\x99t;\xe2\x80\x94I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t mind if dey burnt me \xe2\x80\x99live,\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99d walk right up to de\r\nstake, I would, and say, here I comes to shed my last blood fur my\r\nprinciples, fur my country, fur de gen\xe2\x80\x99l interests of society.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aunt Chloe, \xe2\x80\x9cone o\xe2\x80\x99 yer principles will have to be to get\r\nto bed some time tonight, and not be a keepin\xe2\x80\x99 everybody up till\r\nmornin\xe2\x80\x99; now, every one of you young uns that don\xe2\x80\x99t want to be cracked,\r\nhad better be scase, mighty sudden.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNiggers! all on yer,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sam, waving his palm-leaf with benignity,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI give yer my blessin\xe2\x80\x99; go to bed now, and be good boys.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd, with this pathetic benediction, the assembly dispersed.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER IX\r\nIn Which It Appears That a Senator Is But a Man\r\n\r\n\r\nThe light of the cheerful fire shone on the rug and carpet of a cosey\r\nparlor, and glittered on the sides of the tea-cups and well-brightened\r\ntea-pot, as Senator Bird was drawing off his boots, preparatory to\r\ninserting his feet in a pair of new handsome slippers, which his wife\r\nhad been working for him while away on his senatorial tour. Mrs. Bird,\r\nlooking the very picture of delight, was superintending the\r\narrangements of the table, ever and anon mingling admonitory remarks to\r\na number of frolicsome juveniles, who were effervescing in all those\r\nmodes of untold gambol and mischief that have astonished mothers ever\r\nsince the flood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTom, let the door-knob alone,\xe2\x80\x94there\xe2\x80\x99s a man! Mary! Mary! don\xe2\x80\x99t pull\r\nthe cat\xe2\x80\x99s tail,\xe2\x80\x94poor pussy! Jim, you mustn\xe2\x80\x99t climb on that table,\xe2\x80\x94no,\r\nno!\xe2\x80\x94You don\xe2\x80\x99t know, my dear, what a surprise it is to us all, to see\r\nyou here tonight!\xe2\x80\x9d said she, at last, when she found a space to say\r\nsomething to her husband.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, I thought I\xe2\x80\x99d just make a run down, spend the night, and\r\nhave a little comfort at home. I\xe2\x80\x99m tired to death, and my head aches!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Bird cast a glance at a camphor-bottle, which stood in the\r\nhalf-open closet, and appeared to meditate an approach to it, but her\r\nhusband interposed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, Mary, no doctoring! a cup of your good hot tea, and some of\r\nour good home living, is what I want. It\xe2\x80\x99s a tiresome business, this\r\nlegislating!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd the senator smiled, as if he rather liked the idea of considering\r\nhimself a sacrifice to his country.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said his wife, after the business of the tea-table was getting\r\nrather slack, \xe2\x80\x9cand what have they been doing in the Senate?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNow, it was a very unusual thing for gentle little Mrs. Bird ever to\r\ntrouble her head with what was going on in the house of the state, very\r\nwisely considering that she had enough to do to mind her own. Mr. Bird,\r\ntherefore, opened his eyes in surprise, and said,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot very much of importance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell; but is it true that they have been passing a law forbidding\r\npeople to give meat and drink to those poor colored folks that come\r\nalong? I heard they were talking of some such law, but I didn\xe2\x80\x99t think\r\nany Christian legislature would pass it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, Mary, you are getting to be a politician, all at once.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, nonsense! I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t give a fig for all your politics, generally,\r\nbut I think this is something downright cruel and unchristian. I hope,\r\nmy dear, no such law has been passed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere has been a law passed forbidding people to help off the slaves\r\nthat come over from Kentucky, my dear; so much of that thing has been\r\ndone by these reckless Abolitionists, that our brethren in Kentucky are\r\nvery strongly excited, and it seems necessary, and no more than\r\nChristian and kind, that something should be done by our state to quiet\r\nthe excitement.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what is the law? It don\xe2\x80\x99t forbid us to shelter those poor\r\ncreatures a night, does it, and to give \xe2\x80\x99em something comfortable to\r\neat, and a few old clothes, and send them quietly about their\r\nbusiness?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, yes, my dear; that would be aiding and abetting, you know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Bird was a timid, blushing little woman, of about four feet in\r\nheight, and with mild blue eyes, and a peach-blow complexion, and the\r\ngentlest, sweetest voice in the world;\xe2\x80\x94as for courage, a moderate-sized\r\ncock-turkey had been known to put her to rout at the very first gobble,\r\nand a stout house-dog, of moderate capacity, would bring her into\r\nsubjection merely by a show of his teeth. Her husband and children were\r\nher entire world, and in these she ruled more by entreaty and\r\npersuasion than by command or argument. There was only one thing that\r\nwas capable of arousing her, and that provocation came in on the side\r\nof her unusually gentle and sympathetic nature;\xe2\x80\x94anything in the shape\r\nof cruelty would throw her into a passion, which was the more alarming\r\nand inexplicable in proportion to the general softness of her nature.\r\nGenerally the most indulgent and easy to be entreated of all mothers,\r\nstill her boys had a very reverent remembrance of a most vehement\r\nchastisement she once bestowed on them, because she found them leagued\r\nwith several graceless boys of the neighborhood, stoning a defenceless\r\nkitten.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you what,\xe2\x80\x9d Master Bill used to say, \xe2\x80\x9cI was scared that time.\r\nMother came at me so that I thought she was crazy, and I was whipped\r\nand tumbled off to bed, without any supper, before I could get over\r\nwondering what had come about; and, after that, I heard mother crying\r\noutside the door, which made me feel worse than all the rest. I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell\r\nyou what,\xe2\x80\x9d he\xe2\x80\x99d say, \xe2\x80\x9cwe boys never stoned another kitten!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOn the present occasion, Mrs. Bird rose quickly, with very red cheeks,\r\nwhich quite improved her general appearance, and walked up to her\r\nhusband, with quite a resolute air, and said, in a determined tone,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, John, I want to know if you think such a law as that is right and\r\nChristian?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou won\xe2\x80\x99t shoot me, now, Mary, if I say I do!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never could have thought it of you, John; you didn\xe2\x80\x99t vote for it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEven so, my fair politician.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou ought to be ashamed, John! Poor, homeless, houseless creatures!\r\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s a shameful, wicked, abominable law, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll break it, for one,\r\nthe first time I get a chance; and I hope I _shall_ have a chance, I\r\ndo! Things have got to a pretty pass, if a woman can\xe2\x80\x99t give a warm\r\nsupper and a bed to poor, starving creatures, just because they are\r\nslaves, and have been abused and oppressed all their lives, poor\r\nthings!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, Mary, just listen to me. Your feelings are all quite right, dear,\r\nand interesting, and I love you for them; but, then, dear, we mustn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nsuffer our feelings to run away with our judgment; you must consider\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99s a matter of private feeling,\xe2\x80\x94there are great public interests\r\ninvolved,\xe2\x80\x94there is such a state of public agitation rising, that we\r\nmust put aside our private feelings.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, John, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know anything about politics, but I can read my\r\nBible; and there I see that I must feed the hungry, clothe the naked,\r\nand comfort the desolate; and that Bible I mean to follow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut in cases where your doing so would involve a great public evil\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cObeying God never brings on public evils. I know it can\xe2\x80\x99t. It\xe2\x80\x99s always\r\nsafest, all round, to _do as He_ bids us.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, listen to me, Mary, and I can state to you a very clear argument,\r\nto show\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, nonsense, John! you can talk all night, but you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t do it. I\r\nput it to you, John,\xe2\x80\x94would _you_ now turn away a poor, shivering,\r\nhungry creature from your door, because he was a runaway? _Would_ you,\r\nnow?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNow, if the truth must be told, our senator had the misfortune to be a\r\nman who had a particularly humane and accessible nature, and turning\r\naway anybody that was in trouble never had been his forte; and what was\r\nworse for him in this particular pinch of the argument was, that his\r\nwife knew it, and, of course was making an assault on rather an\r\nindefensible point. So he had recourse to the usual means of gaining\r\ntime for such cases made and provided; he said \xe2\x80\x9cahem,\xe2\x80\x9d and coughed\r\nseveral times, took out his pocket-handkerchief, and began to wipe his\r\nglasses. Mrs. Bird, seeing the defenceless condition of the enemy\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nterritory, had no more conscience than to push her advantage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should like to see you doing that, John\xe2\x80\x94I really should! Turning a\r\nwoman out of doors in a snowstorm, for instance; or may be you\xe2\x80\x99d take\r\nher up and put her in jail, wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t you? You would make a great hand\r\nat that!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course, it would be a very painful duty,\xe2\x80\x9d began Mr. Bird, in a\r\nmoderate tone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDuty, John! don\xe2\x80\x99t use that word! You know it isn\xe2\x80\x99t a duty\xe2\x80\x94it can\xe2\x80\x99t be\r\na duty! If folks want to keep their slaves from running away, let \xe2\x80\x99em\r\ntreat \xe2\x80\x99em well,\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s my doctrine. If I had slaves (as I hope I never\r\nshall have), I\xe2\x80\x99d risk their wanting to run away from me, or you either,\r\nJohn. I tell you folks don\xe2\x80\x99t run away when they are happy; and when\r\nthey do run, poor creatures! they suffer enough with cold and hunger\r\nand fear, without everybody\xe2\x80\x99s turning against them; and, law or no law,\r\nI never will, so help me God!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMary! Mary! My dear, let me reason with you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hate reasoning, John,\xe2\x80\x94especially reasoning on such subjects. There\xe2\x80\x99s\r\na way you political folks have of coming round and round a plain right\r\nthing; and you don\xe2\x80\x99t believe in it yourselves, when it comes to\r\npractice. I know _you_ well enough, John. You don\xe2\x80\x99t believe it\xe2\x80\x99s right\r\nany more than I do; and you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t do it any sooner than I.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this critical juncture, old Cudjoe, the black man-of-all-work, put\r\nhis head in at the door, and wished \xe2\x80\x9cMissis would come into the\r\nkitchen;\xe2\x80\x9d and our senator, tolerably relieved, looked after his little\r\nwife with a whimsical mixture of amusement and vexation, and, seating\r\nhimself in the arm-chair, began to read the papers.\r\n\r\nAfter a moment, his wife\xe2\x80\x99s voice was heard at the door, in a quick,\r\nearnest tone,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cJohn! John! I do wish you\xe2\x80\x99d come here, a moment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe laid down his paper, and went into the kitchen, and started, quite\r\namazed at the sight that presented itself:\xe2\x80\x94A young and slender woman,\r\nwith garments torn and frozen, with one shoe gone, and the stocking\r\ntorn away from the cut and bleeding foot, was laid back in a deadly\r\nswoon upon two chairs. There was the impress of the despised race on\r\nher face, yet none could help feeling its mournful and pathetic beauty,\r\nwhile its stony sharpness, its cold, fixed, deathly aspect, struck a\r\nsolemn chill over him. She\r\nwas tol\xe2\x80\x99able peart when she cum in, and asked if she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t warm\r\nherself here a spell; and I was just a-askin\xe2\x80\x99 her where she cum from,\r\nand she fainted right down. Never done much hard work, guess, by the\r\nlooks of her hands.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor creature!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Bird, compassionately, as the woman slowly\r\nunclosed her large, dark eyes, and looked vacantly at her. And oh! mother that reads this, has there never been in\r\nyour house a drawer, or a closet, the opening of which has been to you\r\nlike the opening again of a little grave? Ah! happy mother that you\r\nare, if it has not been so.\r\n\r\nMrs. Bird slowly opened the drawer. She\r\nsat down by the drawer, and, leaning her head on her hands over it,\r\nwept till the tears fell through her fingers into the drawer; then\r\nsuddenly raising her head, she began, with nervous haste, selecting the\r\nplainest and most substantial articles, and gathering them into a\r\nbundle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMamma,\xe2\x80\x9d said one of the boys, gently touching her arm, \xe2\x80\x9cyou going to\r\ngive away _those_ things?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear boys,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, softly and earnestly, \xe2\x80\x9cif our dear, loving\r\nlittle Henry looks down from heaven, he would be glad to have us do\r\nthis. I could not find it in my heart to give them away to any common\r\nperson\xe2\x80\x94to anybody that was happy; but I give them to a mother more\r\nheart-broken and sorrowful than I am; and I hope God will send his\r\nblessings with them!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere are in this world blessed souls, whose sorrows all spring up into\r\njoys for others; whose earthly hopes, laid in the grave with many\r\ntears, are the seed from which spring healing flowers and balm for the\r\ndesolate and the distressed. Among such was the delicate woman who sits\r\nthere by the lamp, dropping slow tears, while she prepares the\r\nmemorials of her own lost one for the outcast wanderer.\r\n\r\nAfter a while, Mrs. Bird opened a wardrobe, and, taking from thence a\r\nplain, serviceable dress or two, she sat down busily to her work-table,\r\nand, with needle, scissors, and thimble, at hand, quietly commenced the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cletting down\xe2\x80\x9d process which her husband had recommended, and continued\r\nbusily at it till the old clock in the corner struck twelve, and she\r\nheard the low rattling of wheels at the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMary,\xe2\x80\x9d said her husband, coming in, with his overcoat in his hand,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cyou must wake her up now; we must be off.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Bird hastily deposited the various articles she had collected in a\r\nsmall plain trunk, and locking it, desired her husband to see it in the\r\ncarriage, and then proceeded to call the woman. Soon, arrayed in a\r\ncloak, bonnet, and shawl, that had belonged to her benefactress, she\r\nappeared at the door with her child in her arms. Mr. Bird hurried her\r\ninto the carriage, and Mrs. Bird pressed on after her to the carriage\r\nsteps. Eliza leaned out of the carriage, and put out her hand,\xe2\x80\x94a hand\r\nas soft and beautiful as was given in return. She fixed her large, dark\r\neyes, full of earnest meaning, on Mrs. Bird\xe2\x80\x99s face, and seemed going to\r\nspeak. Her lips moved,\xe2\x80\x94she tried once or twice, but there was no\r\nsound,\xe2\x80\x94and pointing upward, with a look never to be forgotten, she fell\r\nback in the seat, and covered her face. The door was shut, and the\r\ncarriage drove on.\r\n\r\nWhat a situation, now, for a patriotic senator, that had been all the\r\nweek before spurring up the legislature of his native state to pass\r\nmore stringent resolutions against escaping fugitives, their harborers\r\nand abettors!\r\n\r\nOur good senator in his native state had not been exceeded by any of\r\nhis brethren at Washington, in the sort of eloquence which has won for\r\nthem immortal renown! How sublimely he had sat with his hands in his\r\npockets, and scouted all sentimental weakness of those who would put\r\nthe welfare of a few miserable fugitives before great state interests!\r\n\r\nHe was as bold as a lion about it, and \xe2\x80\x9cmightily convinced\xe2\x80\x9d not only\r\nhimself, but everybody that heard him;\xe2\x80\x94but then his idea of a fugitive\r\nwas only an idea of the letters that spell the word,\xe2\x80\x94or at the most,\r\nthe image of a little newspaper picture of a man with a stick and\r\nbundle with \xe2\x80\x9cRan away from the subscriber\xe2\x80\x9d under it. The magic of the\r\nreal presence of distress,\xe2\x80\x94the imploring human eye, the frail,\r\ntrembling human hand, the despairing appeal of helpless agony,\xe2\x80\x94these he\r\nhad never tried. He had never thought that a fugitive might be a\r\nhapless mother, a defenceless child,\xe2\x80\x94like that one which was now\r\nwearing his lost boy\xe2\x80\x99s little well-known cap; and so, as our poor\r\nsenator was not stone or steel,\xe2\x80\x94as he was a man, and a downright\r\nnoble-hearted one, too,\xe2\x80\x94he was, as everybody must see, in a sad case\r\nfor his patriotism. And you need not exult over him, good brother of\r\nthe Southern States; for we have some inklings that many of you, under\r\nsimilar circumstances, would not do much better. We have reason to\r\nknow, in Kentucky, as in Mississippi, are noble and generous hearts, to\r\nwhom never was tale of suffering told in vain. Ah, good brother! is it\r\nfair for you to expect of us services which your own brave, honorable\r\nheart would not allow you to render, were you in our place?\r\n\r\nBe that as it may, if our good senator was a political sinner, he was\r\nin a fair way to expiate it by his night\xe2\x80\x99s penance. There had been a\r\nlong continuous period of rainy weather, and the soft, rich earth of\r\nOhio, as every one knows, is admirably suited to the manufacture of\r\nmud\xe2\x80\x94and the road was an Ohio railroad of the good old times.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd pray, what sort of a road may that be?\xe2\x80\x9d says some eastern\r\ntraveller, who has been accustomed to connect no ideas with a railroad,\r\nbut those of smoothness or speed.\r\n\r\nKnow, then, innocent eastern friend, that in benighted regions of the\r\nwest, where the mud is of unfathomable and sublime depth, roads are\r\nmade of round rough logs, arranged transversely side by side, and\r\ncoated over in their pristine freshness with earth, turf, and\r\nwhatsoever may come to hand, and then the rejoicing native calleth it a\r\nroad, and straightway essayeth to ride thereupon. In process of time,\r\nthe rains wash off all the turf and grass aforesaid, move the logs\r\nhither and thither, in picturesque positions, up, down and crosswise,\r\nwith divers chasms and ruts of black mud intervening.\r\n\r\nOver such a road as this our senator went stumbling along, making moral\r\nreflections as continuously as under the circumstances could be\r\nexpected,\xe2\x80\x94the carriage proceeding along much as follows,\xe2\x80\x94bump! bump!\r\nbump! slush! down in the mud!\xe2\x80\x94the senator, woman and child, reversing\r\ntheir positions so suddenly as to come, without any very accurate\r\nadjustment, against the windows of the down-hill side. Carriage sticks\r\nfast, while Cudjoe on the outside is heard making a great muster among\r\nthe horses. After various ineffectual pullings and twitchings, just as\r\nthe senator is losing all patience, the carriage suddenly rights itself\r\nwith a bounce,\xe2\x80\x94two front wheels go down into another abyss, and\r\nsenator, woman, and child, all tumble promiscuously on to the front\r\nseat,\xe2\x80\x94senator\xe2\x80\x99s hat is jammed over his eyes and nose quite\r\nunceremoniously, and he considers himself fairly extinguished;\xe2\x80\x94child\r\ncries, and Cudjoe on the outside delivers animated addresses to the\r\nhorses, who are kicking, and floundering, and straining under repeated\r\ncracks of the whip. Carriage springs up, with another bounce,\xe2\x80\x94down go\r\nthe hind wheels,\xe2\x80\x94senator, woman, and child, fly over on to the back\r\nseat, his elbows encountering her bonnet, and both her feet being\r\njammed into his hat, which flies off in the concussion. After a few\r\nmoments the \xe2\x80\x9cslough\xe2\x80\x9d is passed, and the horses stop, panting;\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nsenator finds his hat, the woman straightens her bonnet and hushes her\r\nchild, and they brace themselves for what is yet to come.\r\n\r\nFor a while only the continuous bump! bump! intermingled, just by way\r\nof variety, with divers side plunges and compound shakes; and they\r\nbegin to flatter themselves that they are not so badly off, after all.\r\nAt last, with a square plunge, which puts all on to their feet and then\r\ndown into their seats with incredible quickness, the carriage\r\nstops,\xe2\x80\x94and, after much outside commotion, Cudjoe appears at the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlease, sir, it\xe2\x80\x99s powerful bad spot, this\xe2\x80\x99 yer. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know how we\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nto get clar out. I\xe2\x80\x99m a thinkin\xe2\x80\x99 we\xe2\x80\x99ll have to be a gettin\xe2\x80\x99 rails.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe senator despairingly steps out, picking gingerly for some firm\r\nfoothold; down goes one foot an immeasurable depth,\xe2\x80\x94he tries to pull it\r\nup, loses his balance, and tumbles over into the mud, and is fished\r\nout, in a very despairing condition, by Cudjoe.\r\n\r\nBut we forbear, out of sympathy to our readers\xe2\x80\x99 bones. Western\r\ntravellers, who have beguiled the midnight hour in the interesting\r\nprocess of pulling down rail fences, to pry their carriages out of mud\r\nholes, will have a respectful and mournful sympathy with our\r\nunfortunate hero. We beg them to drop a silent tear, and pass on.\r\n\r\nIt was full late in the night when the carriage emerged, dripping and\r\nbespattered, out of the creek, and stood at the door of a large\r\nfarmhouse.\r\n\r\nIt took no inconsiderable perseverance to arouse the inmates; but at\r\nlast the respectable proprietor appeared, and undid the door. He was a\r\ngreat, tall, bristling Orson of a fellow, full six feet and some inches\r\nin his stockings, and arrayed in a red flannel hunting-shirt. A very\r\nheavy mat of sandy hair, in a decidedly tousled condition, and a beard\r\nof some days\xe2\x80\x99 growth, gave the worthy man an appearance, to say the\r\nleast, not particularly prepossessing. He stood for a few minutes\r\nholding the candle aloft, and blinking on our travellers with a dismal\r\nand mystified expression that was truly ludicrous. It cost some effort\r\nof our senator to induce him to comprehend the case fully; and while he\r\nis doing his best at that, we shall give him a little introduction to\r\nour readers.\r\n\r\nHonest old John Van Trompe was once quite a considerable land-owner and\r\nslave-owner in the State of Kentucky. Having \xe2\x80\x9cnothing of the bear about\r\nhim but the skin,\xe2\x80\x9d and being gifted by nature with a great, honest,\r\njust heart, quite equal to his gigantic frame, he had been for some\r\nyears witnessing with repressed uneasiness the workings of a system\r\nequally bad for oppressor and oppressed. At last, one day, John\xe2\x80\x99s great\r\nheart had swelled altogether too big to wear his bonds any longer; so\r\nhe just took his pocket-book out of his desk, and went over into Ohio,\r\nand bought a quarter of a township of good, rich land, made out free\r\npapers for all his people,\xe2\x80\x94men, women, and children,\xe2\x80\x94packed them up in\r\nwagons, and sent them off to settle down; and then honest John turned\r\nhis face up the creek, and sat quietly down on a snug, retired farm, to\r\nenjoy his conscience and his reflections.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you the man that will shelter a poor woman and child from\r\nslave-catchers?\xe2\x80\x9d said the senator, explicitly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI rather think I am,\xe2\x80\x9d said honest John, with some considerable\r\nemphasis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought so,\xe2\x80\x9d said the senator.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf there\xe2\x80\x99s anybody comes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the good man, stretching his tall,\r\nmuscular form upward, \xe2\x80\x9cwhy here I\xe2\x80\x99m ready for him: and I\xe2\x80\x99ve got seven\r\nsons, each six foot high, and they\xe2\x80\x99ll be ready for \xe2\x80\x99em. Give our\r\nrespects to \xe2\x80\x99em,\xe2\x80\x9d said John; \xe2\x80\x9ctell \xe2\x80\x99em it\xe2\x80\x99s no matter how soon they\r\ncall,\xe2\x80\x94make no kinder difference to us,\xe2\x80\x9d said John, running his fingers\r\nthrough the shock of hair that thatched his head, and bursting out into\r\na great laugh.\r\n\r\nWeary, jaded, and spiritless, Eliza dragged herself up to the door,\r\nwith her child lying in a heavy sleep on her arm. The rough man held\r\nthe candle to her face, and uttering a kind of compassionate grunt,\r\nopened the door of a small bed-room adjoining to the large kitchen\r\nwhere they were standing, and motioned her to go in. He took down a\r\ncandle, and lighting it, set it upon the table, and then addressed\r\nhimself to Eliza.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, I say, gal, you needn\xe2\x80\x99t be a bit afeard, let who will come here.\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99m up to all that sort o\xe2\x80\x99 thing,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, pointing to two or three\r\ngoodly rifles over the mantel-piece; \xe2\x80\x9cand most people that know me know\r\nthat \xe2\x80\x99t wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be healthy to try to get anybody out o\xe2\x80\x99 my house when\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99m agin it. So _now_ you jist go to sleep now, as quiet as if yer\r\nmother was a rockin\xe2\x80\x99 ye,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, as he shut the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, this is an uncommon handsome un,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to the senator. \xe2\x80\x9cAh,\r\nwell; handsome uns has the greatest cause to run, sometimes, if they\r\nhas any kind o\xe2\x80\x99 feelin, such as decent women should. I know all about\r\nthat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe senator, in a few words, briefly explained Eliza\xe2\x80\x99s history.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO! ou! aw! now, I want to know?\xe2\x80\x9d said the good man, pitifully; \xe2\x80\x9csho!\r\nnow sho! That\xe2\x80\x99s natur now, poor crittur! hunted down now like a\r\ndeer,\xe2\x80\x94hunted down, jest for havin\xe2\x80\x99 natural feelin\xe2\x80\x99s, and doin\xe2\x80\x99 what no\r\nkind o\xe2\x80\x99 mother could help a doin\xe2\x80\x99! I tell ye what, these yer things\r\nmake me come the nighest to swearin\xe2\x80\x99, now, o\xe2\x80\x99 most anything,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nhonest John, as he wiped his eyes with the back of a great, freckled,\r\nyellow hand. \xe2\x80\x9cI tell yer what, stranger, it was years and years before\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99d jine the church, \xe2\x80\x99cause the ministers round in our parts used to\r\npreach that the Bible went in for these ere cuttings up,\xe2\x80\x94and I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nbe up to \xe2\x80\x99em with their Greek and Hebrew, and so I took up agin \xe2\x80\x99em,\r\nBible and all. I never jined the church till I found a minister that\r\nwas up to \xe2\x80\x99em all in Greek and all that, and he said right the\r\ncontrary; and then I took right hold, and jined the church,\xe2\x80\x94I did now,\r\nfact,\xe2\x80\x9d said John, who had been all this time uncorking some very frisky\r\nbottled cider, which at this juncture he presented.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYe\xe2\x80\x99d better jest put up here, now, till daylight,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, heartily,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cand I\xe2\x80\x99ll call up the old woman, and have a bed got ready for you in no\r\ntime.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, my good friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said the senator, \xe2\x80\x9cI must be along, to\r\ntake the night stage for Columbus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! well, then, if you must, I\xe2\x80\x99ll go a piece with you, and show you a\r\ncross road that will take you there better than the road you came on.\r\nThat road\xe2\x80\x99s mighty bad.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJohn equipped himself, and, with a lantern in hand, was soon seen\r\nguiding the senator\xe2\x80\x99s carriage towards a road that ran down in a\r\nhollow, back of his dwelling. When they parted, the senator put into\r\nhis hand a ten-dollar bill.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s for her,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, briefly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, ay,\xe2\x80\x9d said John, with equal conciseness.\r\n\r\nThey shook hands, and parted.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER X\r\nThe Property Is Carried Off\r\n\r\n\r\nThe February morning looked gray and drizzling through the window of\r\nUncle Tom\xe2\x80\x99s cabin. It looked on downcast faces, the images of mournful\r\nhearts. The little table stood out before the fire, covered with an\r\nironing-cloth; a coarse but clean shirt or two, fresh from the iron,\r\nhung on the back of a chair by the fire, and Aunt Chloe had another\r\nspread out before her on the table. Carefully she rubbed and ironed\r\nevery fold and every hem, with the most scrupulous exactness, every now\r\nand then raising her hand to her face to wipe off the tears that were\r\ncoursing down her cheeks.\r\n\r\nTom sat by, with his Testament open on his knee, and his head leaning\r\nupon his hand;\xe2\x80\x94but neither spoke. It was yet early, and the children\r\nlay all asleep together in their little rude trundle-bed.\r\n\r\nTom, who had, to the full, the gentle, domestic heart, which woe for\r\nthem! has been a peculiar characteristic of his unhappy race, got up\r\nand walked silently to look at his children.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s the last time,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nAunt Chloe did not answer, only rubbed away over and over on the coarse\r\nshirt, already as smooth as hands could make it; and finally setting\r\nher iron suddenly down with a despairing plunge, she sat down to the\r\ntable, and \xe2\x80\x9clifted up her voice and wept.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cS\xe2\x80\x99pose we must be resigned; but oh Lord! how ken I? If I know\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nanything whar you \xe2\x80\x99s goin\xe2\x80\x99, or how they\xe2\x80\x99d sarve you! Missis says she\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\ntry and \xe2\x80\x99deem ye, in a year or two; but Lor! nobody never comes up that\r\ngoes down thar! They kills \xe2\x80\x99em! I\xe2\x80\x99ve hearn \xe2\x80\x99em tell how dey works \xe2\x80\x99em\r\nup on dem ar plantations.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99ll be the same God there, Chloe, that there is here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aunt Chloe, \xe2\x80\x9cs\xe2\x80\x99pose dere will; but de Lord lets drefful\r\nthings happen, sometimes. I don\xe2\x80\x99t seem to get no comfort dat way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m in the Lord\xe2\x80\x99s hands,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom; \xe2\x80\x9cnothin\xe2\x80\x99 can go no furder than he\r\nlets it;\xe2\x80\x94and thar\xe2\x80\x99s _one_ thing I can thank him for. It\xe2\x80\x99s _me_ that\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsold and going down, and not you nur the chil\xe2\x80\x99en. Here you\xe2\x80\x99re\r\nsafe;\xe2\x80\x94what comes will come only on me; and the Lord, he\xe2\x80\x99ll help me,\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nknow he will.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAh, brave, manly heart,\xe2\x80\x94smothering thine own sorrow, to comfort thy\r\nbeloved ones! Mas\xe2\x80\x99r never ought ter left it so that ye\r\n_could_ be took for his debts. Ye\xe2\x80\x99ve arnt him all he gets for ye, twice\r\nover. He owed ye yer freedom, and ought ter gin \xe2\x80\x99t to yer years ago.\r\nMebbe he can\xe2\x80\x99t help himself now, but I feel it\xe2\x80\x99s wrong. Nothing can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nbeat that ar out o\xe2\x80\x99 me. Sich a faithful crittur as ye\xe2\x80\x99ve been,\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nallers sot his business \xe2\x80\x99fore yer own every way,\xe2\x80\x94and reckoned on him\r\nmore than yer own wife and chil\xe2\x80\x99en! Them as sells heart\xe2\x80\x99s love and\r\nheart\xe2\x80\x99s blood, to get out thar scrapes, de Lord\xe2\x80\x99ll be up to \xe2\x80\x99em!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cChloe! now, if ye love me, ye won\xe2\x80\x99t talk so, when perhaps jest the\r\nlast time we\xe2\x80\x99ll ever have together!
