Wan\xe2\x80\x99t he put in my arms a\r\nbaby?\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s natur I should think a heap of him. And he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t be\r\nspected to think so much of poor Tom. Mas\xe2\x80\x99rs is used to havin\xe2\x80\x99 all\r\nthese yer things done for \xe2\x80\x99em, and nat\xe2\x80\x99lly they don\xe2\x80\x99t think so much on\r\n\xe2\x80\x99t. They can\xe2\x80\x99t be spected to, no way. Set him \xe2\x80\x99longside of other\r\nMas\xe2\x80\x99rs\xe2\x80\x94who\xe2\x80\x99s had the treatment and livin\xe2\x80\x99 I\xe2\x80\x99ve had? And he never would\r\nhave let this yer come on me, if he could have seed it aforehand. I\r\nknow he wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWal, any way, thar\xe2\x80\x99s wrong about it _somewhar_,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aunt Chloe, in\r\nwhom a stubborn sense of justice was a predominant trait; \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t jest\r\nmake out whar \xe2\x80\x99t is, but thar\xe2\x80\x99s wrong somewhar, I\xe2\x80\x99m _clar_ o\xe2\x80\x99 that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYer ought ter look up to the Lord above\xe2\x80\x94he\xe2\x80\x99s above all\xe2\x80\x94thar don\xe2\x80\x99t a\r\nsparrow fall without him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt don\xe2\x80\x99t seem to comfort me, but I spect it orter,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aunt Chloe.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut dar\xe2\x80\x99s no use talkin\xe2\x80\x99; I\xe2\x80\x99ll jes wet up de corn-cake, and get ye one\r\ngood breakfast, \xe2\x80\x99cause nobody knows when you\xe2\x80\x99ll get another.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn order to appreciate the sufferings of the negroes sold south, it\r\nmust be remembered that all the instinctive affections of that race are\r\npeculiarly strong. Their local attachments are very abiding. They are\r\nnot naturally daring and enterprising, but home-loving and\r\naffectionate. Add to this all the terrors with which ignorance invests\r\nthe unknown, and add to this, again, that selling to the south is set\r\nbefore the negro from childhood as the last severity of punishment. The\r\nthreat that terrifies more than whipping or torture of any kind is the\r\nthreat of being sent down river. We have ourselves heard this feeling\r\nexpressed by them, and seen the unaffected horror with which they will\r\nsit in their gossipping hours, and tell frightful stories of that \xe2\x80\x9cdown\r\nriver,\xe2\x80\x9d which to them is\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat undiscovered country, from whose bourn\r\nNo traveller returns.\xe2\x80\x9d[1]\r\n\r\n\r\n [1] A slightly inaccurate quotation from _Hamlet_, Act III, scene I,\r\n lines 369-370.\r\n\r\n\r\nA missionary figure among the fugitives in Canada told us that many of\r\nthe fugitives confessed themselves to have escaped from comparatively\r\nkind masters, and that they were induced to brave the perils of escape,\r\nin almost every case, by the desperate horror with which they regarded\r\nbeing sold south,\xe2\x80\x94a doom which was hanging either over themselves or\r\ntheir husbands, their wives or children. This nerves the African,\r\nnaturally patient, timid and unenterprising, with heroic courage, and\r\nleads him to suffer hunger, cold, pain, the perils of the wilderness,\r\nand the more dread penalties of recapture.\r\n\r\nThe simple morning meal now smoked on the table, for Mrs. Shelby had\r\nexcused Aunt Chloe\xe2\x80\x99s attendance at the great house that morning. The\r\npoor soul had expended all her little energies on this farewell\r\nfeast,\xe2\x80\x94had killed and dressed her choicest chicken, and prepared her\r\ncorn-cake with scrupulous exactness, just to her husband\xe2\x80\x99s taste, and\r\nbrought out certain mysterious jars on the mantel-piece, some preserves\r\nthat were never produced except on extreme occasions.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLor, Pete,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mose, triumphantly, \xe2\x80\x9chan\xe2\x80\x99t we got a buster of a\r\nbreakfast!\xe2\x80\x9d at the same time catching at a fragment of the chicken.\r\n\r\nAunt Chloe gave him a sudden box on the ear. \xe2\x80\x9cThar now! crowing over\r\nthe last breakfast yer poor daddy\xe2\x80\x99s gwine to have to home!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Chloe!\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, gently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWal, I can\xe2\x80\x99t help it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aunt Chloe, hiding her face in her apron;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI \xe2\x80\x99s so tossed about it, it makes me act ugly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe boys stood quite still, looking first at their father and then at\r\ntheir mother, while the baby, climbing up her clothes, began an\r\nimperious, commanding cry.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThar!\xe2\x80\x9d said Aunt Chloe, wiping her eyes and taking up the baby; \xe2\x80\x9cnow\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99s done, I hope,\xe2\x80\x94now do eat something. This yer\xe2\x80\x99s my nicest chicken.\r\nThar, boys, ye shall have some, poor critturs! Yer mammy\xe2\x80\x99s been cross\r\nto yer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe boys needed no second invitation, and went in with great zeal for\r\nthe eatables; and it was well they did so, as otherwise there would\r\nhave been very little performed to any purpose by the party.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aunt Chloe, bustling about after breakfast, \xe2\x80\x9cI must put up\r\nyer clothes. Jest like as not, he\xe2\x80\x99ll take \xe2\x80\x99em all away. I know thar\r\nways\xe2\x80\x94mean as dirt, they is! Wal, now, yer flannels for rhumatis is in\r\nthis corner; so be careful, \xe2\x80\x99cause there won\xe2\x80\x99t nobody make ye no more.\r\nThen here\xe2\x80\x99s yer old shirts, and these yer is new ones. I toed off these\r\nyer stockings last night, and put de ball in \xe2\x80\x99em to mend with. But Lor!\r\nwho\xe2\x80\x99ll ever mend for ye?\xe2\x80\x9d and Aunt Chloe, again overcome, laid her head\r\non the box side, and sobbed. \xe2\x80\x9cTo think on \xe2\x80\x99t! no crittur to do for ye,\r\nsick or well! I don\xe2\x80\x99t railly think I ought ter be good now!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe boys, having eaten everything there was on the breakfast-table,\r\nbegan now to take some thought of the case; and, seeing their mother\r\ncrying, and their father looking very sad, began to whimper and put\r\ntheir hands to their eyes. Uncle Tom had the baby on his knee, and was\r\nletting her enjoy herself to the utmost extent, scratching his face and\r\npulling his hair, and occasionally breaking out into clamorous\r\nexplosions of delight, evidently arising out of her own internal\r\nreflections.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, crow away, poor crittur!\xe2\x80\x9d said Aunt Chloe; \xe2\x80\x9cye\xe2\x80\x99ll have to come to\r\nit, too! ye\xe2\x80\x99ll live to see yer husband sold, or mebbe be sold yerself;\r\nand these yer boys, they\xe2\x80\x99s to be sold, I s\xe2\x80\x99pose, too, jest like as not,\r\nwhen dey gets good for somethin\xe2\x80\x99; an\xe2\x80\x99t no use in niggers havin\xe2\x80\x99\r\nnothin\xe2\x80\x99!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHere one of the boys called out, \xe2\x80\x9cThar\xe2\x80\x99s Missis a-comin\xe2\x80\x99 in!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe can\xe2\x80\x99t do no good; what\xe2\x80\x99s she coming for?\xe2\x80\x9d said Aunt Chloe.\r\n\r\nMrs. Shelby entered. Aunt Chloe set a chair for her in a manner\r\ndecidedly gruff and crusty. She did not seem to notice either the\r\naction or the manner. She looked pale and anxious.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTom,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cI come to\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d and stopping suddenly, and regarding the\r\nsilent group, she sat down in the chair, and, covering her face with\r\nher handkerchief, began to sob.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLor, now, Missis, don\xe2\x80\x99t\xe2\x80\x94don\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x9d said Aunt Chloe, bursting out in her\r\nturn; and for a few moments they all wept in company. And in those\r\ntears they all shed together, the high and the lowly, melted away all\r\nthe heart-burnings and anger of the oppressed. O, ye who visit the\r\ndistressed, do ye know that everything your money can buy, given with a\r\ncold, averted face, is not worth one honest tear shed in real sympathy?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy good fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Shelby, \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t give you anything to do\r\nyou any good. If I give you money, it will only be taken from you. But\r\nI tell you solemnly, and before God, that I will keep trace of you, and\r\nbring you back as soon as I can command the money;\xe2\x80\x94and, till then,\r\ntrust in God!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHere the boys called out that Mas\xe2\x80\x99r Haley was coming, and then an\r\nunceremonious kick pushed open the door. Haley stood there in very ill\r\nhumor, having ridden hard the night before, and being not at all\r\npacified by his ill success in recapturing his prey.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cye nigger, ye\xe2\x80\x99r ready? Servant, ma\xe2\x80\x99am!\xe2\x80\x9d said he,\r\ntaking off his hat, as he saw Mrs. Shelby.\r\n\r\nAunt Chloe shut and corded the box, and, getting up, looked gruffly on\r\nthe trader, her tears seeming suddenly turned to sparks of fire.\r\n\r\nTom rose up meekly, to follow his new master, and raised up his heavy\r\nbox on his shoulder. His wife took the baby in her arms to go with him\r\nto the wagon, and the children, still crying, trailed on behind.\r\n\r\nMrs. Shelby, walking up to the trader, detained him for a few moments,\r\ntalking with him in an earnest manner; and while she was thus talking,\r\nthe whole family party proceeded to a wagon, that stood ready harnessed\r\nat the door. A crowd of all the old and young hands on the place stood\r\ngathered around it, to bid farewell to their old associate. Tom had\r\nbeen looked up to, both as a head servant and a Christian teacher, by\r\nall the place, and there was much honest sympathy and grief about him,\r\nparticularly among the women.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, Chloe, you bar it better \xe2\x80\x99n we do!\xe2\x80\x9d said one of the women, who\r\nhad been weeping freely, noticing the gloomy calmness with which Aunt\r\nChloe stood by the wagon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99s done _my_ tears!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, looking grimly at the trader, who was\r\ncoming up. \xe2\x80\x9cI does not feel to cry \xe2\x80\x99fore dat ar old limb, no how!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGet in!\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley to Tom, as he strode through the crowd of\r\nservants, who looked at him with lowering brows.\r\n\r\nTom got in, and Haley, drawing out from under the wagon seat a heavy\r\npair of shackles, made them fast around each ankle.\r\n\r\nA smothered groan of indignation ran through the whole circle, and Mrs.\r\nShelby spoke from the verandah,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Haley, I assure you that\r\nprecaution is entirely unnecessary.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99 know, ma\xe2\x80\x99am; I\xe2\x80\x99ve lost one five hundred dollars from this yer\r\nplace, and I can\xe2\x80\x99t afford to run no more risks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat else could she spect on him?\xe2\x80\x9d said Aunt Chloe, indignantly, while\r\nthe two boys, who now seemed to comprehend at once their father\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndestiny, clung to her gown, sobbing and groaning vehemently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sorry,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, \xe2\x80\x9cthat Mas\xe2\x80\x99r George happened to be away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGeorge had gone to spend two or three days with a companion on a\r\nneighboring estate, and having departed early in the morning, before\r\nTom\xe2\x80\x99s misfortune had been made public, had left without hearing of it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive my love to Mas\xe2\x80\x99r George,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, earnestly.\r\n\r\nHaley whipped up the horse, and, with a steady, mournful look, fixed to\r\nthe last on the old place, Tom was whirled away.\r\n\r\nMr. Shelby at this time was not at home. He had sold Tom under the spur\r\nof a driving necessity, to get out of the power of a man whom he\r\ndreaded,\xe2\x80\x94and his first feeling, after the consummation of the bargain,\r\nhad been that of relief. But his wife\xe2\x80\x99s expostulations awoke his\r\nhalf-slumbering regrets; and Tom\xe2\x80\x99s manly disinterestedness increased\r\nthe unpleasantness of his feelings. It was in vain that he said to\r\nhimself that he had a _right_ to do it,\xe2\x80\x94that everybody did it,\xe2\x80\x94and that\r\nsome did it without even the excuse of necessity;\xe2\x80\x94he could not satisfy\r\nhis own feelings; and that he might not witness the unpleasant scenes\r\nof the consummation, he had gone on a short business tour up the\r\ncountry, hoping that all would be over before he returned.\r\n\r\nTom and Haley rattled on along the dusty road, whirling past every old\r\nfamiliar spot, until the bounds of the estate were fairly passed, and\r\nthey found themselves out on the open pike. After they had ridden about\r\na mile, Haley suddenly drew up at the door of a blacksmith\xe2\x80\x99s shop,\r\nwhen, taking out with him a pair of handcuffs, he stepped into the\r\nshop, to have a little alteration in them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThese yer \xe2\x80\x99s a little too small for his build,\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley, showing\r\nthe fetters, and pointing out to Tom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLor! now, if thar an\xe2\x80\x99t Shelby\xe2\x80\x99s Tom. He han\xe2\x80\x99t sold him, now?\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nsmith.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, he has,\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, ye don\xe2\x80\x99t! well, reely,\xe2\x80\x9d said the smith, \xe2\x80\x9cwho\xe2\x80\x99d a thought it! Why,\r\nye needn\xe2\x80\x99t go to fetterin\xe2\x80\x99 him up this yer way. He\xe2\x80\x99s the faithfullest,\r\nbest crittur\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley; \xe2\x80\x9cbut your good fellers are just the critturs to\r\nwant ter run off. Them stupid ones, as doesn\xe2\x80\x99t care whar they go, and\r\nshifless, drunken ones, as don\xe2\x80\x99t care for nothin\xe2\x80\x99, they\xe2\x80\x99ll stick by,\r\nand like as not be rather pleased to be toted round; but these yer\r\nprime fellers, they hates it like sin. No way but to fetter \xe2\x80\x99em; got\r\nlegs,\xe2\x80\x94they\xe2\x80\x99ll use \xe2\x80\x99em,\xe2\x80\x94no mistake.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said the smith, feeling among his tools, \xe2\x80\x9cthem plantations down\r\nthar, stranger, an\xe2\x80\x99t jest the place a Kentuck nigger wants to go to;\r\nthey dies thar tol\xe2\x80\x99able fast, don\xe2\x80\x99t they?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWal, yes, tol\xe2\x80\x99able fast, ther dying is; what with the \xe2\x80\x99climating and\r\none thing and another, they dies so as to keep the market up pretty\r\nbrisk,\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWal, now, a feller can\xe2\x80\x99t help thinkin\xe2\x80\x99 it\xe2\x80\x99s a mighty pity to have a\r\nnice, quiet, likely feller, as good un as Tom is, go down to be fairly\r\nground up on one of them ar sugar plantations.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWal, he\xe2\x80\x99s got a fa\xe2\x80\x99r chance. I promised to do well by him. I\xe2\x80\x99ll get\r\nhim in house-servant in some good old family, and then, if he stands\r\nthe fever and \xe2\x80\x99climating, he\xe2\x80\x99ll have a berth good as any nigger ought\r\nter ask for.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe leaves his wife and chil\xe2\x80\x99en up here, s\xe2\x80\x99pose?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but he\xe2\x80\x99ll get another thar. Lord, thar\xe2\x80\x99s women enough everywhar,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Haley.\r\n\r\nTom was sitting very mournfully on the outside of the shop while this\r\nconversation was going on. Suddenly he heard the quick, short click of\r\na horse\xe2\x80\x99s hoof behind him; and, before he could fairly awake from his\r\nsurprise, young Master George sprang into the wagon, threw his arms\r\ntumultuously round his neck, and was sobbing and scolding with energy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI declare, it\xe2\x80\x99s real mean! So, now, you hold on to her, and grow up, and be a comfort\r\nto her, thar\xe2\x80\x99s my own good boy,\xe2\x80\x94you will now, won\xe2\x80\x99t ye?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I will, Uncle Tom,\xe2\x80\x9d said George seriously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd be careful of yer speaking, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r George. Young boys, when they\r\ncomes to your age, is wilful, sometimes\xe2\x80\x94it is natur they should be. But\r\nreal gentlemen, such as I hopes you\xe2\x80\x99ll be, never lets fall on words\r\nthat isn\xe2\x80\x99t \xe2\x80\x99spectful to thar parents. Ye an\xe2\x80\x99t \xe2\x80\x99fended, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r George?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, indeed, Uncle Tom; you always did give me good advice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99s older, ye know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, stroking the boy\xe2\x80\x99s fine, curly head\r\nwith his large, strong hand, but speaking in a voice as tender as a\r\nwoman\xe2\x80\x99s, \xe2\x80\x9cand I sees all that\xe2\x80\x99s bound up in you. O, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r George, you\r\nhas everything,\xe2\x80\x94l\xe2\x80\x99arnin\xe2\x80\x99, privileges, readin\xe2\x80\x99, writin\xe2\x80\x99,\xe2\x80\x94and you\xe2\x80\x99ll grow\r\nup to be a great, learned, good man and all the people on the place and\r\nyour mother and father\xe2\x80\x99ll be so proud on ye! Be a good Mas\xe2\x80\x99r, like yer\r\nfather; and be a Christian, like yer mother. \xe2\x80\x99Member yer Creator in the\r\ndays o\xe2\x80\x99 yer youth, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r George.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll be _real_ good, Uncle Tom, I tell you,\xe2\x80\x9d said George. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m going\r\nto be a _first-rater_; and don\xe2\x80\x99t you be discouraged. I\xe2\x80\x99ll have you back\r\nto the place, yet. As I told Aunt Chloe this morning, I\xe2\x80\x99ll build our\r\nhouse all over, and you shall have a room for a parlor with a carpet on\r\nit, when I\xe2\x80\x99m a man. O, you\xe2\x80\x99ll have good times yet!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHaley now came to the door, with the handcuffs in his hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook here, now, Mister,\xe2\x80\x9d said George, with an air of great\r\nsuperiority, as he got out, \xe2\x80\x9cI shall let father and mother know how you\r\ntreat Uncle Tom!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re welcome,\xe2\x80\x9d said the trader.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should think you\xe2\x80\x99d be ashamed to spend all your life buying men and\r\nwomen, and chaining them, like cattle! I should think you\xe2\x80\x99d feel mean!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid George.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo long as your grand folks wants to buy men and women, I\xe2\x80\x99m as good as\r\nthey is,\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley; \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98tan\xe2\x80\x99t any meaner sellin\xe2\x80\x99 on \xe2\x80\x99em, that \xe2\x80\x99t is\r\nbuyin\xe2\x80\x99!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll never do either, when I\xe2\x80\x99m a man,\xe2\x80\x9d said George; \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m ashamed, this\r\nday, that I\xe2\x80\x99m a Kentuckian. I always was proud of it before;\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\nGeorge sat very straight on his horse, and looked round with an air, as\r\nif he expected the state would be impressed with his opinion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, good-by, Uncle Tom; keep a stiff upper lip,\xe2\x80\x9d said George.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-by, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r George,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, looking fondly and admiringly at\r\nhim. \xe2\x80\x9cGod Almighty bless you! Ah! Kentucky han\xe2\x80\x99t got many like you!\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nsaid, in the fulness of his heart, as the frank, boyish face was lost\r\nto his view. Away he went, and Tom looked, till the clatter of his\r\nhorse\xe2\x80\x99s heels died away, the last sound or sight of his home. But over\r\nhis heart there seemed to be a warm spot, where those young hands had\r\nplaced that precious dollar. Tom put up his hand, and held it close to\r\nhis heart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, I tell ye what, Tom,\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley, as he came up to the wagon, and\r\nthrew in the handcuffs, \xe2\x80\x9cI mean to start fa\xe2\x80\x99r with ye, as I gen\xe2\x80\x99ally do\r\nwith my niggers; and I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell ye now, to begin with, you treat me\r\nfa\xe2\x80\x99r, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll treat you fa\xe2\x80\x99r; I an\xe2\x80\x99t never hard on my niggers.\r\nCalculates to do the best for \xe2\x80\x99em I can. Now, ye see, you\xe2\x80\x99d better jest\r\nsettle down comfortable, and not be tryin\xe2\x80\x99 no tricks; because nigger\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ntricks of all sorts I\xe2\x80\x99m up to, and it\xe2\x80\x99s no use. If niggers is quiet,\r\nand don\xe2\x80\x99t try to get off, they has good times with me; and if they\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t, why, it\xe2\x80\x99s thar fault, and not mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom assured Haley that he had no present intentions of running off. In\r\nfact, the exhortation seemed rather a superfluous one to a man with a\r\ngreat pair of iron fetters on his feet. But Mr. Haley had got in the\r\nhabit of commencing his relations with his stock with little\r\nexhortations of this nature, calculated, as he deemed, to inspire\r\ncheerfulness and confidence, and prevent the necessity of any\r\nunpleasant scenes.\r\n\r\nAnd here, for the present, we take our leave of Tom, to pursue the\r\nfortunes of other characters in our story.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XI\r\nIn Which Property Gets into an Improper State of Mind\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was late in a drizzly afternoon that a traveler alighted at the door\r\nof a small country hotel, in the village of N\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94, in Kentucky. In the\r\nbarroom he found assembled quite a miscellaneous company, whom stress\r\nof weather had driven to harbor, and the place presented the usual\r\nscenery of such reunions. Great, tall, raw-boned Kentuckians, attired\r\nin hunting-shirts, and trailing their loose joints over a vast extent\r\nof territory, with the easy lounge peculiar to the race,\xe2\x80\x94rifles stacked\r\naway in the corner, shot-pouches, game-bags, hunting-dogs, and little\r\nnegroes, all rolled together in the corners,\xe2\x80\x94were the characteristic\r\nfeatures in the picture. At each end of the fireplace sat a long-legged\r\ngentleman, with his chair tipped back, his hat on his head, and the\r\nheels of his muddy boots reposing sublimely on the mantel-piece,\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nposition, we will inform our readers, decidedly favorable to the turn\r\nof reflection incident to western taverns, where travellers exhibit a\r\ndecided preference for this particular mode of elevating their\r\nunderstandings.\r\n\r\nMine host, who stood behind the bar, like most of his country men, was\r\ngreat of stature, good-natured and loose-jointed, with an enormous\r\nshock of hair on his head, and a great tall hat on the top of that.\r\n\r\nIn fact, everybody in the room bore on his head this characteristic\r\nemblem of man\xe2\x80\x99s sovereignty; whether it were felt hat, palm-leaf,\r\ngreasy beaver, or fine new chapeau, there it reposed with true\r\nrepublican independence. In truth, it appeared to be the characteristic\r\nmark of every individual. Some wore them tipped rakishly to one\r\nside\xe2\x80\x94these were your men of humor, jolly, free-and-easy dogs; some had\r\nthem jammed independently down over their noses\xe2\x80\x94these were your hard\r\ncharacters, thorough men, who, when they wore their hats, _wanted_ to\r\nwear them, and to wear them just as they had a mind to; there were\r\nthose who had them set far over back\xe2\x80\x94wide-awake men, who wanted a clear\r\nprospect; while careless men, who did not know, or care, how their hats\r\nsat, had them shaking about in all directions. The various hats, in\r\nfact, were quite a Shakespearean study.\r\n\r\nDivers negroes, in very free-and-easy pantaloons, and with no\r\nredundancy in the shirt line, were scuttling about, hither and thither,\r\nwithout bringing to pass any very particular results, except expressing\r\na generic willingness to turn over everything in creation generally for\r\nthe benefit of Mas\xe2\x80\x99r and his guests. Add to this picture a jolly,\r\ncrackling, rollicking fire, going rejoicingly up a great wide\r\nchimney,\xe2\x80\x94the outer door and every window being set wide open, and the\r\ncalico window-curtain flopping and snapping in a good stiff breeze of\r\ndamp raw air,\xe2\x80\x94and you have an idea of the jollities of a Kentucky\r\ntavern.\r\n\r\nYour Kentuckian of the present day is a good illustration of the\r\ndoctrine of transmitted instincts and peculiarities. His fathers were\r\nmighty hunters,\xe2\x80\x94men who lived in the woods, and slept under the free,\r\nopen heavens, with the stars to hold their candles; and their\r\ndescendant to this day always acts as if the house were his camp,\xe2\x80\x94wears\r\nhis hat at all hours, tumbles himself about, and puts his heels on the\r\ntops of chairs or mantelpieces, just as his father rolled on the green\r\nsward, and put his upon trees and logs,\xe2\x80\x94keeps all the windows and doors\r\nopen, winter and summer, that he may get air enough for his great\r\nlungs,\xe2\x80\x94calls everybody \xe2\x80\x9cstranger,\xe2\x80\x9d with nonchalant _bonhommie_, and is\r\naltogether the frankest, easiest, most jovial creature living.\r\n\r\nInto such an assembly of the free and easy our traveller entered. He\r\nwas a short, thick-set man, carefully dressed, with a round,\r\ngood-natured countenance, and something rather fussy and particular in\r\nhis appearance. He was very careful of his valise and umbrella,\r\nbringing them in with his own hands, and resisting, pertinaciously, all\r\noffers from the various servants to relieve him of them. He looked\r\nround the barroom with rather an anxious air, and, retreating with his\r\nvaluables to the warmest corner, disposed them under his chair, sat\r\ndown, and looked rather apprehensively up at the worthy whose heels\r\nillustrated the end of the mantel-piece, who was spitting from right to\r\nleft, with a courage and energy rather alarming to gentlemen of weak\r\nnerves and particular habits.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say, stranger, how are ye?\xe2\x80\x9d said the aforesaid gentleman, firing an\r\nhonorary salute of tobacco-juice in the direction of the new arrival.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I reckon,\xe2\x80\x9d was the reply of the other, as he dodged, with some\r\nalarm, the threatening honor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAny news?\xe2\x80\x9d said the respondent, taking out a strip of tobacco and a\r\nlarge hunting-knife from his pocket.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot that I know of,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cChaw?\xe2\x80\x9d said the first speaker, handing the old gentleman a bit of his\r\ntobacco, with a decidedly brotherly air.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, thank ye\xe2\x80\x94it don\xe2\x80\x99t agree with me,\xe2\x80\x9d said the little man, edging off.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t, eh?\xe2\x80\x9d said the other, easily, and stowing away the morsel in his\r\nown mouth, in order to keep up the supply of tobacco-juice, for the\r\ngeneral benefit of society.\r\n\r\nThe old gentleman uniformly gave a little start whenever his long-sided\r\nbrother fired in his direction; and this being observed by his\r\ncompanion, he very good-naturedly turned his artillery to another\r\nquarter, and proceeded to storm one of the fire-irons with a degree of\r\nmilitary talent fully sufficient to take a city.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s that?\xe2\x80\x9d said the old gentleman, observing some of the company\r\nformed in a group around a large handbill.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNigger advertised!\xe2\x80\x9d said one of the company, briefly.\r\n\r\nMr. Wilson, for that was the old gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s name, rose up, and, after\r\ncarefully adjusting his valise and umbrella, proceeded deliberately to\r\ntake out his spectacles and fix them on his nose; and, this operation\r\nbeing performed, read as follows:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRan away from the subscriber, my mulatto boy, George. Said George six\r\nfeet in height, a very light mulatto, brown curly hair; is very\r\nintelligent, speaks handsomely, can read and write, will probably try\r\nto pass for a white man, is deeply scarred on his back and shoulders,\r\nhas been branded in his right hand with the letter H.\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cI will give four hundred dollars for him alive, and the same sum\r\n    for satisfactory proof that he has been _killed.\xe2\x80\x9d_\r\n\r\n\r\nThe old gentleman read this advertisement from end to end in a low\r\nvoice, as if he were studying it.\r\n\r\nThe long-legged veteran, who had been besieging the fire-iron, as\r\nbefore related, now took down his cumbrous length, and rearing aloft\r\nhis tall form, walked up to the advertisement and very deliberately\r\nspit a full discharge of tobacco-juice on it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s my mind upon that!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, briefly, and sat down again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, now, stranger, what\xe2\x80\x99s that for?\xe2\x80\x9d said mine host.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d do it all the same to the writer of that ar paper, if he was\r\nhere,\xe2\x80\x9d said the long man, coolly resuming his old employment of cutting\r\ntobacco. \xe2\x80\x9cAny man that owns a boy like that, and can\xe2\x80\x99t find any better\r\nway o\xe2\x80\x99 treating on him, _deserves_ to lose him. Such papers as these is\r\na shame to Kentucky; that\xe2\x80\x99s my mind right out, if anybody wants to\r\nknow!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now, that\xe2\x80\x99s a fact,\xe2\x80\x9d said mine host, as he made an entry in his\r\nbook.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve got a gang of boys, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the long man, resuming his attack\r\non the fire-irons, \xe2\x80\x9cand I jest tells \xe2\x80\x99em\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Boys,\xe2\x80\x99 says I,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98_run_ now!\r\ndig! put! jest when ye want to! I never shall come to look after you!\xe2\x80\x99\r\nThat\xe2\x80\x99s the way I keep mine. Let \xe2\x80\x99em know they are free to run any time,\r\nand it jest breaks up their wanting to. More \xe2\x80\x99n all, I\xe2\x80\x99ve got free\r\npapers for \xe2\x80\x99em all recorded, in case I gets keeled up any o\xe2\x80\x99 these\r\ntimes, and they know it; and I tell ye, stranger, there an\xe2\x80\x99t a fellow\r\nin our parts gets more out of his niggers than I do. Why, my boys have\r\nbeen to Cincinnati, with five hundred dollars\xe2\x80\x99 worth of colts, and\r\nbrought me back the money, all straight, time and agin. It stands to\r\nreason they should. Treat \xe2\x80\x99em like dogs, and you\xe2\x80\x99ll have dogs\xe2\x80\x99 works\r\nand dogs\xe2\x80\x99 actions. Treat \xe2\x80\x99em like men, and you\xe2\x80\x99ll have men\xe2\x80\x99s works.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nAnd the honest drover, in his warmth, endorsed this moral sentiment by\r\nfiring a perfect _feu de joi_ at the fireplace.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think you\xe2\x80\x99re altogether right, friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Wilson; \xe2\x80\x9cand this\r\nboy described here _is_ a fine fellow\xe2\x80\x94no mistake about that. He worked\r\nfor me some half-dozen years in my bagging factory, and he was my best\r\nhand, sir. He is an ingenious fellow, too: he invented a machine for\r\nthe cleaning of hemp\xe2\x80\x94a really valuable affair; it\xe2\x80\x99s gone into use in\r\nseveral factories. His master holds the patent of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll warrant ye,\xe2\x80\x9d said the drover, \xe2\x80\x9cholds it and makes money out of\r\nit, and then turns round and brands the boy in his right hand. If I had\r\na fair chance, I\xe2\x80\x99d mark him, I reckon so that he\xe2\x80\x99d carry it _one_\r\nwhile.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThese yer knowin\xe2\x80\x99 boys is allers aggravatin\xe2\x80\x99 and sarcy,\xe2\x80\x9d said a\r\ncoarse-looking fellow, from the other side of the room; \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s why\r\nthey gets cut up and marked so. If they behaved themselves, they\r\nwouldn\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is to say, the Lord made \xe2\x80\x99em men, and it\xe2\x80\x99s a hard squeeze gettin\r\n\xe2\x80\x99em down into beasts,\xe2\x80\x9d said the drover, dryly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBright niggers isn\xe2\x80\x99t no kind of \xe2\x80\x99vantage to their masters,\xe2\x80\x9d continued\r\nthe other, well entrenched, in a coarse, unconscious obtuseness, from\r\nthe contempt of his opponent; \xe2\x80\x9cwhat\xe2\x80\x99s the use o\xe2\x80\x99 talents and them\r\nthings, if you can\xe2\x80\x99t get the use on \xe2\x80\x99em yourself? Why, all the use they\r\nmake on \xe2\x80\x99t is to get round you. I\xe2\x80\x99ve had one or two of these fellers,\r\nand I jest sold \xe2\x80\x99em down river. I knew I\xe2\x80\x99d got to lose \xe2\x80\x99em, first or\r\nlast, if I didn\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBetter send orders up to the Lord, to make you a set, and leave out\r\ntheir souls entirely,\xe2\x80\x9d said the drover.\r\n\r\nHere the conversation was interrupted by the approach of a small\r\none-horse buggy to the inn. It had a genteel appearance, and a\r\nwell-dressed, gentlemanly man sat on the seat, with a colored servant\r\ndriving.\r\n\r\nThe whole party examined the new comer with the interest with which a\r\nset of loafers in a rainy day usually examine every newcomer. He was\r\nvery tall, with a dark, Spanish complexion, fine, expressive black\r\neyes, and close-curling hair, also of a glossy blackness. His\r\nwell-formed aquiline nose, straight thin lips, and the admirable\r\ncontour of his finely-formed limbs, impressed the whole company\r\ninstantly with the idea of something uncommon. He walked easily in\r\namong the company, and with a nod indicated to his waiter where to\r\nplace his trunk, bowed to the company, and, with his hat in his hand,\r\nwalked up leisurely to the bar, and gave in his name as Henry Butter,\r\nOaklands, Shelby County. Turning, with an indifferent air, he sauntered\r\nup to the advertisement, and read it over.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJim,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to his man, \xe2\x80\x9cseems to me we met a boy something like\r\nthis, up at Beman\xe2\x80\x99s, didn\xe2\x80\x99t we?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jim, \xe2\x80\x9conly I an\xe2\x80\x99t sure about the hand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t look, of course,\xe2\x80\x9d said the stranger with a careless\r\nyawn. Then walking up to the landlord, he desired him to furnish him\r\nwith a private apartment, as he had some writing to do immediately.\r\n\r\nThe landlord was all obsequious, and a relay of about seven negroes,\r\nold and young, male and female, little and big, were soon whizzing\r\nabout, like a covey of partridges, bustling, hurrying, treading on each\r\nother\xe2\x80\x99s toes, and tumbling over each other, in their zeal to get\r\nMas\xe2\x80\x99r\xe2\x80\x99s room ready, while he seated himself easily on a chair in the\r\nmiddle of the room, and entered into conversation with the man who sat\r\nnext to him.\r\n\r\nThe manufacturer, Mr. Wilson, from the time of the entrance of the\r\nstranger, had regarded him with an air of disturbed and uneasy\r\ncuriosity. He seemed to himself to have met and been acquainted with\r\nhim somewhere, but he could not recollect. Every few moments, when the\r\nman spoke, or moved, or smiled, he would start and fix his eyes on him,\r\nand then suddenly withdraw them, as the bright, dark eyes met his with\r\nsuch unconcerned coolness. At last, a sudden recollection seemed to\r\nflash upon him, for he stared at the stranger with such an air of blank\r\namazement and alarm, that he walked up to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Wilson, I think,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, in a tone of recognition, and extending\r\nhis hand. \xe2\x80\x9cI beg your pardon, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t recollect you before. I see you\r\nremember me,\xe2\x80\x94Mr. Butler, of Oaklands, Shelby County.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYe\xe2\x80\x94yes\xe2\x80\x94yes, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Wilson, like one speaking in a dream.\r\n\r\nJust then a negro boy entered, and announced that Mas\xe2\x80\x99r\xe2\x80\x99s room was\r\nready.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJim, see to the trunks,\xe2\x80\x9d said the gentleman, negligently; then\r\naddressing himself to Mr. Wilson, he added\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI should like to have a few\r\nmoments\xe2\x80\x99 conversation with you on business, in my room, if you please.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Wilson followed him, as one who walks in his sleep; and they\r\nproceeded to a large upper chamber, where a new-made fire was\r\ncrackling, and various servants flying about, putting finishing touches\r\nto the arrangements.\r\n\r\nWhen all was done, and the servants departed, the young man\r\ndeliberately locked the door, and putting the key in his pocket, faced\r\nabout, and folding his arms on his bosom, looked Mr. Wilson full in the\r\nface.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGeorge!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Wilson.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, George,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI couldn\xe2\x80\x99t have thought it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am pretty well disguised, I fancy,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man, with a\r\nsmile. \xe2\x80\x9cA little walnut bark has made my yellow skin a genteel brown,\r\nand I\xe2\x80\x99ve dyed my hair black; so you see I don\xe2\x80\x99t answer to the\r\nadvertisement at all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, George! but this is a dangerous game you are playing. I could not\r\nhave advised you to it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can do it on my own responsibility,\xe2\x80\x9d said George, with the same\r\nproud smile.\r\n\r\nWe remark, _en passant_, that George was, by his father\xe2\x80\x99s side, of\r\nwhite descent. His mother was one of those unfortunates of her race,\r\nmarked out by personal beauty to be the slave of the passions of her\r\npossessor, and the mother of children who may never know a father. From\r\none of the proudest families in Kentucky he had inherited a set of fine\r\nEuropean features, and a high, indomitable spirit. From his mother he\r\nhad received only a slight mulatto tinge, amply compensated by its\r\naccompanying rich, dark eye. A slight change in the tint of the skin\r\nand the color of his hair had metamorphosed him into the\r\nSpanish-looking fellow he then appeared; and as gracefulness of\r\nmovement and gentlemanly manners had always been perfectly natural to\r\nhim, he found no difficulty in playing the bold part he had\r\nadopted\xe2\x80\x94that of a gentleman travelling with his domestic.\r\n\r\nMr. Wilson, a good-natured but extremely fidgety and cautious old\r\ngentleman, ambled up and down the room, appearing, as John Bunyan hath\r\nit, \xe2\x80\x9cmuch tumbled up and down in his mind,\xe2\x80\x9d and divided between his\r\nwish to help George, and a certain confused notion of maintaining law\r\nand order: so, as he shambled about, he delivered himself as follows:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, George, I s\xe2\x80\x99pose you\xe2\x80\x99re running away\xe2\x80\x94leaving your lawful master,\r\nGeorge\xe2\x80\x94(I don\xe2\x80\x99t wonder at it)\xe2\x80\x94at the same time, I\xe2\x80\x99m sorry, George,\xe2\x80\x94yes,\r\ndecidedly\xe2\x80\x94I think I must say that, George\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s my duty to tell you so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy are you sorry, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d said George, calmly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, to see you, as it were, setting yourself in opposition to the\r\nlaws of your country.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_My_ country!\xe2\x80\x9d said George, with a strong and bitter emphasis; \xe2\x80\x9cwhat\r\ncountry have I, but the grave,\xe2\x80\x94and I wish to God that I was laid\r\nthere!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, George, no\xe2\x80\x94no\xe2\x80\x94it won\xe2\x80\x99t do; this way of talking is\r\nwicked\xe2\x80\x94unscriptural. George, you\xe2\x80\x99ve got a hard master\xe2\x80\x94in fact, he\r\nis\xe2\x80\x94well he conducts himself reprehensibly\xe2\x80\x94I can\xe2\x80\x99t pretend to defend\r\nhim. But you know how the angel commanded Hagar to return to her\r\nmistress, and submit herself under the hand;[1] and the apostle sent\r\nback Onesimus to his master.\xe2\x80\x9d[2]\r\n\r\n [1] Gen. 16. The angel bade the pregnant Hagar return to her mistress\r\n Sarai, even though Sarai had dealt harshly with her.\r\n\r\n\r\n [2] Phil. 1:10. Onesimus went back to his master to become no longer a\r\n servant but a \xe2\x80\x9cbrother beloved.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t quote Bible at me that way, Mr. Wilson,\xe2\x80\x9d said George, with a\r\nflashing eye, \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t! for my wife is a Christian, and I mean to be, if\r\never I get to where I can; but to quote Bible to a fellow in my\r\ncircumstances, is enough to make him give it up altogether. I appeal to\r\nGod Almighty;\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99m willing to go with the case to Him, and ask Him if I\r\ndo wrong to seek my freedom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThese feelings are quite natural, George,\xe2\x80\x9d said the good-natured man,\r\nblowing his nose. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, they\xe2\x80\x99re natural, but it is my duty not to\r\nencourage \xe2\x80\x99em in you. Yes, my boy, I\xe2\x80\x99m sorry for you, now; it\xe2\x80\x99s a bad\r\ncase\xe2\x80\x94very bad; but the apostle says, \xe2\x80\x98Let everyone abide in the\r\ncondition in which he is called.\xe2\x80\x99 We must all submit to the indications\r\nof Providence, George,\xe2\x80\x94don\xe2\x80\x99t you see?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGeorge stood with his head drawn back, his arms folded tightly over his\r\nbroad breast, and a bitter smile curling his lips.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wonder, Mr. Wilson, if the Indians should come and take you a\r\nprisoner away from your wife and children, and want to keep you all\r\nyour life hoeing corn for them, if you\xe2\x80\x99d think it your duty to abide in\r\nthe condition in which you were called. I rather think that you\xe2\x80\x99d think\r\nthe first stray horse you could find an indication of\r\nProvidence\xe2\x80\x94shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe little old gentleman stared with both eyes at this illustration of\r\nthe case; but, though not much of a reasoner, he had the sense in which\r\nsome logicians on this particular subject do not excel,\xe2\x80\x94that of saying\r\nnothing, where nothing could be said. So, as he stood carefully\r\nstroking his umbrella, and folding and patting down all the creases in\r\nit, he proceeded on with his exhortations in a general way.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see, George, you know, now, I always have stood your friend; and\r\nwhatever I\xe2\x80\x99ve said, I\xe2\x80\x99ve said for your good. If you\xe2\x80\x99re\r\ntaken, it will be worse with you than ever; they\xe2\x80\x99ll only abuse you, and\r\nhalf kill you, and sell you down the river.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Wilson, I know all this,\xe2\x80\x9d said George. \xe2\x80\x9cI _do_ run a risk, but\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nhe threw open his overcoat, and showed two pistols and a bowie-knife.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m ready for \xe2\x80\x99em! No!\r\nif it comes to that, I can earn myself at least six feet of free\r\nsoil,\xe2\x80\x94the first and last I shall ever own in Kentucky!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, George, this state of mind is awful; it\xe2\x80\x99s getting really\r\ndesperate George. We don\xe2\x80\x99t make them,\xe2\x80\x94we don\xe2\x80\x99t consent to them,\xe2\x80\x94we have\r\nnothing to do with them; all they do for us is to crush us, and keep us\r\ndown. Can\xe2\x80\x99t he put this and that together, and see what it comes to?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Wilson\xe2\x80\x99s mind was one of those that may not unaptly be represented\r\nby a bale of cotton,\xe2\x80\x94downy, soft, benevolently fuzzy and confused. He\r\nreally pitied George with all his heart, and had a sort of dim and\r\ncloudy perception of the style of feeling that agitated him; but he\r\ndeemed it his duty to go on talking _good_ to him, with infinite\r\npertinacity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGeorge, this is bad. I must tell you, you know, as a friend, you\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nbetter not be meddling with such notions; they are bad, George, very\r\nbad, for boys in your condition,\xe2\x80\x94very;\xe2\x80\x9d and Mr. Wilson sat down to a\r\ntable, and began nervously chewing the handle of his umbrella.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee here, now, Mr. Wilson,\xe2\x80\x9d said George, coming up and sitting himself\r\ndeterminately down in front of him; \xe2\x80\x9clook at me, now. Look at my\r\nface,\xe2\x80\x94look at my hands,\xe2\x80\x94look at my body,\xe2\x80\x9d and the young man drew\r\nhimself up proudly; \xe2\x80\x9cwhy am I _not_ a man, as much as anybody? Well,\r\nMr. Wilson, hear what I can tell you. I had a father\xe2\x80\x94one of your\r\nKentucky gentlemen\xe2\x80\x94who didn\xe2\x80\x99t think enough of me to keep me from being\r\nsold with his dogs and horses, to satisfy the estate, when he died. I\r\nsaw my mother put up at sheriff\xe2\x80\x99s sale, with her seven children. They\r\nwere sold before her eyes, one by one, all to different masters; and I\r\nwas the youngest. She came and kneeled down before old Mas\xe2\x80\x99r, and\r\nbegged him to buy her with me, that she might have at least one child\r\nwith her; and he kicked her away with his heavy boot. I saw him do it;\r\nand the last that I heard was her moans and screams, when I was tied to\r\nhis horse\xe2\x80\x99s neck, to be carried off to his place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy master traded with one of the men, and bought my oldest sister. She\r\nwas a pious, good girl,\xe2\x80\x94a member of the Baptist church,\xe2\x80\x94and as handsome\r\nas my poor mother had been. She was well brought up, and had good\r\nmanners. At first, I was glad she was bought, for I had one friend near\r\nme. I was soon sorry for it. Sir, I have stood at the door and heard\r\nher whipped, when it seemed as if every blow cut into my naked heart,\r\nand I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t do anything to help her; and she was whipped, sir, for\r\nwanting to live a decent Christian life, such as your laws give no\r\nslave girl a right to live; and at last I saw her chained with a\r\ntrader\xe2\x80\x99s gang, to be sent to market in Orleans,\xe2\x80\x94sent there for nothing\r\nelse but that,\xe2\x80\x94and that\xe2\x80\x99s the last I know of her. Well, I grew up,\xe2\x80\x94long\r\nyears and years,\xe2\x80\x94no father, no mother, no sister, not a living soul\r\nthat cared for me more than a dog; nothing but whipping, scolding,\r\nstarving. Why, sir, I\xe2\x80\x99ve been so hungry that I have been glad to take\r\nthe bones they threw to their dogs; and yet, when I was a little\r\nfellow, and laid awake whole nights and cried, it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the hunger, it\r\nwasn\xe2\x80\x99t the whipping, I cried for. No, sir, it was for _my mother_ and\r\n_my sisters_,\xe2\x80\x94it was because I hadn\xe2\x80\x99t a friend to love me on earth. I\r\nnever knew what peace or comfort was. I never had a kind word spoken to\r\nme till I came to work in your factory. Mr. Wilson, you treated me\r\nwell; you encouraged me to do well, and to learn to read and write, and\r\nto try to make something of myself; and God knows how grateful I am for\r\nit. Then, sir, I found my wife; you\xe2\x80\x99ve seen her,\xe2\x80\x94you know how beautiful\r\nshe is. When I found she loved me, when I married her, I scarcely could\r\nbelieve I was alive, I was so happy; and, sir, she is as good as she is\r\nbeautiful. But now what? Why, now comes my master, takes me right away\r\nfrom my work, and my friends, and all I like, and grinds me down into\r\nthe very dirt! And why? Because, he says, I forgot who I was; he says,\r\nto teach me that I am only a nigger! After all, and last of all, he\r\ncomes between me and my wife, and says I shall give her up, and live\r\nwith another woman. And all this your laws give him power to do, in\r\nspite of God or man. Mr. Wilson, look at it! There isn\xe2\x80\x99t _one_ of all\r\nthese things, that have broken the hearts of my mother and my sister,\r\nand my wife and myself, but your laws allow, and give every man power\r\nto do, in Kentucky, and none can say to him nay! I don\xe2\x80\x99t want anything of _your_\r\ncountry, except to be let alone,\xe2\x80\x94to go peaceably out of it; and when I\r\nget to Canada, where the laws will own me and protect me, _that_ shall\r\nbe my country, and its laws I will obey. But if any man tries to stop\r\nme, let him take care, for I am desperate. I\xe2\x80\x99ll fight for my liberty to\r\nthe last breath I breathe. You say your fathers did it; if it was right\r\nfor them, it is right for me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis speech, delivered partly while sitting at the table, and partly\r\nwalking up and down the room,\xe2\x80\x94delivered with tears, and flashing eyes,\r\nand despairing gestures,\xe2\x80\x94was altogether too much for the good-natured\r\nold body to whom it was addressed, who had pulled out a great yellow\r\nsilk pocket-handkerchief, and was mopping up his face with great\r\nenergy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBlast \xe2\x80\x99em all!\xe2\x80\x9d he suddenly broke out. \xe2\x80\x9cHaven\xe2\x80\x99t I always said so\xe2\x80\x94the\r\ninfernal old cusses! I\r\nshall travel by daylight, stop at the best hotels, go to the\r\ndinner-tables with the lords of the land. So, good-by, sir; if you hear\r\nthat I\xe2\x80\x99m taken, you may know that I\xe2\x80\x99m dead!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGeorge stood up like a rock, and put out his hand with the air of a\r\nprince. The friendly little old man shook it heartily, and after a\r\nlittle shower of caution, he took his umbrella, and fumbled his way out\r\nof the room.\r\n\r\nGeorge stood thoughtfully looking at the door, as the old man closed\r\nit. A thought seemed to flash across his mind. He hastily stepped to\r\nit, and opening it, said,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Wilson, one word more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe old gentleman entered again, and George, as before, locked the\r\ndoor, and then stood for a few moments looking on the floor,\r\nirresolutely. At last, raising his head with a sudden effort\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cMr.\r\nWilson, you have shown yourself a Christian in your treatment of me,\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nwant to ask one last deed of Christian kindness of you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, George.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, sir,\xe2\x80\x94what you said was true. I _am_ running a dreadful risk.\r\nThere isn\xe2\x80\x99t, on earth, a living soul to care if I die,\xe2\x80\x9d he added,\r\ndrawing his breath hard, and speaking with a great effort,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI shall be\r\nkicked out and buried like a dog, and nobody\xe2\x80\x99ll think of it a day\r\nafter,\xe2\x80\x94_only my poor wife!_ Poor soul! she\xe2\x80\x99ll mourn and grieve; and if\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99d only contrive, Mr. Wilson, to send this little pin to her. She\r\ngave it to me for a Christmas present, poor child! Give it to her, and\r\ntell her I loved her to the last. Will you? _Will_ you?\xe2\x80\x9d he added,\r\nearnestly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, certainly\xe2\x80\x94poor fellow!\xe2\x80\x9d said the old gentleman, taking the pin,\r\nwith watery eyes, and a melancholy quiver in his voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell her one thing,\xe2\x80\x9d said George; \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s my last wish, if she _can_ get\r\nto Canada, to go there. No matter how kind her mistress is,\xe2\x80\x94no matter\r\nhow much she loves her home; beg her not to go back,\xe2\x80\x94for slavery always\r\nends in misery. Tell her to bring up our boy a free man, and then he\r\nwon\xe2\x80\x99t suffer as I have. Tell her this, Mr. Wilson, will you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, George. I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell her; but I trust you won\xe2\x80\x99t die; take\r\nheart,\xe2\x80\x94you\xe2\x80\x99re a brave fellow. Trust in the Lord, George. I wish in my\r\nheart you were safe through, though,\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s what I do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Is_ there a God to trust in?\xe2\x80\x9d said George, in such a tone of bitter\r\ndespair as arrested the old gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s words. \xe2\x80\x9cO, I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen things all\r\nmy life that have made me feel that there can\xe2\x80\x99t be a God. You\r\nChristians don\xe2\x80\x99t know how these things look to us. There\xe2\x80\x99s a God for\r\nyou, but is there any for us?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, now, don\xe2\x80\x99t\xe2\x80\x94don\xe2\x80\x99t, my boy!\xe2\x80\x9d said the old man, almost sobbing as he\r\nspoke; \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t feel so! There is\xe2\x80\x94there is; clouds and darkness are\r\naround about him, but righteousness and judgment are the habitation of\r\nhis throne. There\xe2\x80\x99s a _God_, George,\xe2\x80\x94believe it; trust in Him, and I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nsure He\xe2\x80\x99ll help you. Everything will be set right,\xe2\x80\x94if not in this life,\r\nin another.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe real piety and benevolence of the simple old man invested him with\r\na temporary dignity and authority, as he spoke. George stopped his\r\ndistracted walk up and down the room, stood thoughtfully a moment, and\r\nthen said, quietly,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you for saying that, my good friend; I\xe2\x80\x99ll _think of that_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XII\r\nSelect Incident of Lawful Trade\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn Ramah there was a voice heard,\xe2\x80\x94weeping, and lamentation, and great\r\nmourning; Rachel weeping for her children, and would not be comforted.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nJer. 31:15.\r\n\r\n\r\nMr. Haley and Tom jogged onward in their wagon, each, for a time,\r\nabsorbed in his own reflections. Now, the reflections of two men\r\nsitting side by side are a curious thing,\xe2\x80\x94seated on the same seat,\r\nhaving the same eyes, ears, hands and organs of all sorts, and having\r\npass before their eyes the same objects,\xe2\x80\x94it is wonderful what a variety\r\nwe shall find in these same reflections!\r\n\r\nAs, for example, Mr. Haley: he thought first of Tom\xe2\x80\x99s length, and\r\nbreadth, and height, and what he would sell for, if he was kept fat and\r\nin good case till he got him into market. He thought of how he should\r\nmake out his gang; he thought of the respective market value of certain\r\nsupposititious men and women and children who were to compose it, and\r\nother kindred topics of the business; then he thought of himself, and\r\nhow humane he was, that whereas other men chained their \xe2\x80\x9cniggers\xe2\x80\x9d hand\r\nand foot both, he only put fetters on the feet, and left Tom the use of\r\nhis hands, as long as he behaved well; and he sighed to think how\r\nungrateful human nature was, so that there was even room to doubt\r\nwhether Tom appreciated his mercies. He had been taken in so by\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cniggers\xe2\x80\x9d whom he had favored; but still he was astonished to consider\r\nhow good-natured he yet remained!\r\n\r\nAs to Tom, he was thinking over some words of an unfashionable old\r\nbook, which kept running through his head, again and again, as follows:\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe have here no continuing city, but we seek one to come; wherefore\r\nGod himself is not ashamed to be called our God; for he hath prepared\r\nfor us a city.\xe2\x80\x9d These words of an ancient volume, got up principally by\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cignorant and unlearned men,\xe2\x80\x9d have, through all time, kept up, somehow,\r\na strange sort of power over the minds of poor, simple fellows, like\r\nTom. They stir up the soul from its depths, and rouse, as with trumpet\r\ncall, courage, energy, and enthusiasm, where before was only the\r\nblackness of despair.\r\n\r\nMr. Haley pulled out of his pocket sundry newspapers, and began looking\r\nover their advertisements, with absorbed interest. He was not a\r\nremarkably fluent reader, and was in the habit of reading in a sort of\r\nrecitative half-aloud, by way of calling in his ears to verify the\r\ndeductions of his eyes. In this tone he slowly recited the following\r\nparagraph:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEXECUTOR\xe2\x80\x99S SALE,\xe2\x80\x94NEGROES!\xe2\x80\x94Agreeably to order of court, will be sold,\r\non Tuesday, February 20, before the Court-house door, in the town of\r\nWashington, Kentucky, the following negroes: Hagar, aged 60; John, aged\r\n30; Ben, aged 21; Saul, aged 25; Albert, aged 14. Sold for the benefit\r\nof the creditors and heirs of the estate of Jesse Blutchford,\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSAMUEL MORRIS,\r\nTHOMAS FLINT,\r\n_Executors_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis yer I must look at,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to Tom, for want of somebody else to\r\ntalk to.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYe see, I\xe2\x80\x99m going to get up a prime gang to take down with ye, Tom;\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99ll make it sociable and pleasant like,\xe2\x80\x94good company will, ye know.\r\nWe must drive right to Washington first and foremost, and then I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nclap you into jail, while I does the business.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom received this agreeable intelligence quite meekly; simply\r\nwondering, in his own heart, how many of these doomed men had wives and\r\nchildren, and whether they would feel as he did about leaving them. It\r\nis to be confessed, too, that the naive, off-hand information that he\r\nwas to be thrown into jail by no means produced an agreeable impression\r\non a poor fellow who had always prided himself on a strictly honest and\r\nupright course of life. Yes, Tom, we must confess it, was rather proud\r\nof his honesty, poor fellow,\xe2\x80\x94not having very much else to be proud\r\nof;\xe2\x80\x94if he had belonged to some of the higher walks of society, he,\r\nperhaps, would never have been reduced to such straits. However, the\r\nday wore on, and the evening saw Haley and Tom comfortably accommodated\r\nin Washington,\xe2\x80\x94the one in a tavern, and the other in a jail.\r\n\r\nAbout eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock the next day, a mixed throng was gathered around\r\nthe court-house steps,\xe2\x80\x94smoking, chewing, spitting, swearing, and\r\nconversing, according to their respective tastes and turns,\xe2\x80\x94waiting for\r\nthe auction to commence. The men and women to be sold sat in a group\r\napart, talking in a low tone to each other. The woman who had been\r\nadvertised by the name of Hagar was a regular African in feature and\r\nfigure. She might have been sixty, but was older than that by hard work\r\nand disease, was partially blind, and somewhat crippled with\r\nrheumatism. By her side stood her only remaining son, Albert, a\r\nbright-looking little fellow of fourteen years. The boy was the only\r\nsurvivor of a large family, who had been successively sold away from\r\nher to a southern market. The mother held on to him with both her\r\nshaking hands, and eyed with intense trepidation every one who walked\r\nup to examine him.\r\n\r\n\r\n[Illustration: THE AUCTION SALE.]\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t be feard, Aunt Hagar,\xe2\x80\x9d said the oldest of the men, \xe2\x80\x9cI spoke to\r\nMas\xe2\x80\x99r Thomas \xe2\x80\x99bout it, and he thought he might manage to sell you in a\r\nlot both together.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDey needn\xe2\x80\x99t call me worn out yet,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, lifting her shaking\r\nhands. \xe2\x80\x9cI can cook yet, and scrub, and scour,\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99m wuth a buying, if I\r\ndo come cheap;\xe2\x80\x94tell em dat ar,\xe2\x80\x94you _tell_ em,\xe2\x80\x9d she added, earnestly.\r\n\r\nHaley here forced his way into the group, walked up to the old man,\r\npulled his mouth open and looked in, felt of his teeth, made him stand\r\nand straighten himself, bend his back, and perform various evolutions\r\nto show his muscles; and then passed on to the next, and put him\r\nthrough the same trial. Walking up last to the boy, he felt of his\r\narms, straightened his hands, and looked at his fingers, and made him\r\njump, to show his agility.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe an\xe2\x80\x99t gwine to be sold widout me!\xe2\x80\x9d said the old woman, with\r\npassionate eagerness; \xe2\x80\x9che and I goes in a lot together; I \xe2\x80\x99s rail\r\nstrong yet, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r and can do heaps o\xe2\x80\x99 work,\xe2\x80\x94heaps on it, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn plantation?\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley, with a contemptuous glance. \xe2\x80\x9cLikely\r\nstory!\xe2\x80\x9d and, as if satisfied with his examination, he walked out and\r\nlooked, and stood with his hands in his pocket, his cigar in his mouth,\r\nand his hat cocked on one side, ready for action.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat think of \xe2\x80\x99em?\xe2\x80\x9d said a man who had been following Haley\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nexamination, as if to make up his own mind from it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWal,\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley, spitting, \xe2\x80\x9cI shall put in, I think, for the\r\nyoungerly ones and the boy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey want to sell the boy and the old woman together,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFind it a tight pull;\xe2\x80\x94why, she\xe2\x80\x99s an old rack o\xe2\x80\x99 bones,\xe2\x80\x94not worth her\r\nsalt.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t then?\xe2\x80\x9d said the man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnybody \xe2\x80\x99d be a fool \xe2\x80\x99t would. She\xe2\x80\x99s half blind, crooked with\r\nrheumatis, and foolish to boot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSome buys up these yer old critturs, and ses there\xe2\x80\x99s a sight more wear\r\nin \xe2\x80\x99em than a body \xe2\x80\x99d think,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man, reflectively.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo go, \xe2\x80\x99t all,\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley; \xe2\x80\x9cwouldn\xe2\x80\x99t take her for a\r\npresent,\xe2\x80\x94fact,\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99ve _seen_, now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWal, \xe2\x80\x99t is kinder pity, now, not to buy her with her son,\xe2\x80\x94her heart\r\nseems so sot on him,\xe2\x80\x94s\xe2\x80\x99pose they fling her in cheap.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThem that\xe2\x80\x99s got money to spend that ar way, it\xe2\x80\x99s all well enough. I\r\nshall bid off on that ar boy for a plantation-hand;\xe2\x80\x94wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be\r\nbothered with her, no way, not if they\xe2\x80\x99d give her to me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99ll take on desp\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNat\xe2\x80\x99lly, she will,\xe2\x80\x9d said the trader, coolly.\r\n\r\nThe conversation was here interrupted by a busy hum in the audience;\r\nand the auctioneer, a short, bustling, important fellow, elbowed his\r\nway into the crowd. The old woman drew in her breath, and caught\r\ninstinctively at her son.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKeep close to yer mammy, Albert,\xe2\x80\x94close,\xe2\x80\x94dey\xe2\x80\x99ll put us up togedder,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nshe said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, mammy, I\xe2\x80\x99m feard they won\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said the boy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDey must, child; I can\xe2\x80\x99t live, no ways, if they don\xe2\x80\x99t\xe2\x80\x9d said the old\r\ncreature, vehemently.\r\n\r\nThe stentorian tones of the auctioneer, calling out to clear the way,\r\nnow announced that the sale was about to commence. A place was cleared,\r\nand the bidding began. The different men on the list were soon knocked\r\noff at prices which showed a pretty brisk demand in the market; two of\r\nthem fell to Haley.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, now, young un,\xe2\x80\x9d said the auctioneer, giving the boy a touch with\r\nhis hammer, \xe2\x80\x9cbe up and show your springs, now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPut us two up togedder, togedder,\xe2\x80\x94do please, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old\r\nwoman, holding fast to her boy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe off,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man, gruffly, pushing her hands away; \xe2\x80\x9cyou come\r\nlast. Now, darkey, spring;\xe2\x80\x9d and, with the word, he pushed the boy\r\ntoward the block, while a deep, heavy groan rose behind him. The boy\r\npaused, and looked back; but there was no time to stay, and, dashing\r\nthe tears from his large, bright eyes, he was up in a moment.\r\n\r\nHis fine figure, alert limbs, and bright face, raised an instant\r\ncompetition, and half a dozen bids simultaneously met the ear of the\r\nauctioneer. Anxious, half-frightened, he looked from side to side, as\r\nhe heard the clatter of contending bids,\xe2\x80\x94now here, now there,\xe2\x80\x94till the\r\nhammer fell. Haley had got him. He was pushed from the block toward his\r\nnew master, but stopped one moment, and looked back, when his poor old\r\nmother, trembling in every limb, held out her shaking hands toward him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBuy me too, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r, for de dear Lord\xe2\x80\x99s sake!\xe2\x80\x94buy me,\xe2\x80\x94I shall die if you\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll die if I do, that\xe2\x80\x99s the kink of it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cno!\xe2\x80\x9d And he\r\nturned on his heel.\r\n\r\nThe bidding for the poor old creature was summary. The man who had\r\naddressed Haley, and who seemed not destitute of compassion, bought her\r\nfor a trifle, and the spectators began to disperse.\r\n\r\nThe poor victims of the sale, who had been brought up in one place\r\ntogether for years, gathered round the despairing old mother, whose\r\nagony was pitiful to see.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCouldn\xe2\x80\x99t dey leave me one? Mas\xe2\x80\x99r allers said I should have one,\xe2\x80\x94he\r\ndid,\xe2\x80\x9d she repeated over and over, in heart-broken tones.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrust in the Lord, Aunt Hagar,\xe2\x80\x9d said the oldest of the men,\r\nsorrowfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat good will it do?\xe2\x80\x9d said she, sobbing passionately.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMother, mother,\xe2\x80\x94don\xe2\x80\x99t! don\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x9d said the boy. \xe2\x80\x9cThey say you \xe2\x80\x99s got a\r\ngood master.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t care,\xe2\x80\x94I don\xe2\x80\x99t care. O, Albert! oh, my boy! you \xe2\x80\x99s my last\r\nbaby. Lord, how ken I?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, take her off, can\xe2\x80\x99t some of ye?\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley, dryly; \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t do no\r\ngood for her to go on that ar way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe old men of the company, partly by persuasion and partly by force,\r\nloosed the poor creature\xe2\x80\x99s last despairing hold, and, as they led her\r\noff to her new master\xe2\x80\x99s wagon, strove to comfort her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow!\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley, pushing his three purchases together, and producing\r\na bundle of handcuffs, which he proceeded to put on their wrists; and\r\nfastening each handcuff to a long chain, he drove them before him to\r\nthe jail.\r\n\r\nA few days saw Haley, with his possessions, safely deposited on one of\r\nthe Ohio boats. It was the commencement of his gang, to be augmented,\r\nas the boat moved on, by various other merchandise of the same kind,\r\nwhich he, or his agent, had stored for him in various points along\r\nshore.\r\n\r\nThe La Belle Riviere, as brave and beautiful a boat as ever walked the\r\nwaters of her namesake river, was floating gayly down the stream, under\r\na brilliant sky, the stripes and stars of free America waving and\r\nfluttering over head; the guards crowded with well-dressed ladies and\r\ngentlemen walking and enjoying the delightful day. All was full of\r\nlife, buoyant and rejoicing;\xe2\x80\x94all but Haley\xe2\x80\x99s gang, who were stored,\r\nwith other freight, on the lower deck, and who, somehow, did not seem\r\nto appreciate their various privileges, as they sat in a knot, talking\r\nto each other in low tones.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBoys,\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley, coming up, briskly, \xe2\x80\x9cI hope you keep up good heart,\r\nand are cheerful. Now, no sulks, ye see; keep stiff upper lip, boys; do\r\nwell by me, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll do well by you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe boys addressed responded the invariable \xe2\x80\x9cYes, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r,\xe2\x80\x9d for ages the\r\nwatchword of poor Africa; but it\xe2\x80\x99s to be owned they did not look\r\nparticularly cheerful; they had their various little prejudices in\r\nfavor of wives, mothers, sisters, and children, seen for the last\r\ntime,\xe2\x80\x94and though \xe2\x80\x9cthey that wasted them required of them mirth,\xe2\x80\x9d it was\r\nnot instantly forthcoming.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve got a wife,\xe2\x80\x9d spoke out the article enumerated as \xe2\x80\x9cJohn, aged\r\nthirty,\xe2\x80\x9d and he laid his chained hand on Tom\xe2\x80\x99s knee,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cand she don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nknow a word about this, poor girl!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere does she live?\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn a tavern a piece down here,\xe2\x80\x9d said John; \xe2\x80\x9cI wish, now, I _could_ see\r\nher once more in this world,\xe2\x80\x9d he added.\r\n\r\nPoor John! It _was_ rather natural; and the tears that fell, as he\r\nspoke, came as naturally as if he had been a white man. Tom drew a long\r\nbreath from a sore heart, and tried, in his poor way, to comfort him.\r\n\r\nAnd over head, in the cabin, sat fathers and mothers, husbands and\r\nwives; and merry, dancing children moved round among them, like so many\r\nlittle butterflies, and everything was going on quite easy and\r\ncomfortable.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, mamma,\xe2\x80\x9d said a boy, who had just come up from below, \xe2\x80\x9cthere\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\nnegro trader on board, and he\xe2\x80\x99s brought four or five slaves down\r\nthere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor creatures!\xe2\x80\x9d said the mother, in a tone between grief and\r\nindignation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s that?\xe2\x80\x9d said another lady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSome poor slaves below,\xe2\x80\x9d said the mother.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd they\xe2\x80\x99ve got chains on,\xe2\x80\x9d said the boy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a shame to our country that such sights are to be seen!\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nanother lady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, there\xe2\x80\x99s a great deal to be said on both sides of the subject,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\na genteel woman, who sat at her state-room door sewing, while her\r\nlittle girl and boy were playing round her. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been south, and I\r\nmust say I think the negroes are better off than they would be to be\r\nfree.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn some respects, some of them are well off, I grant,\xe2\x80\x9d said the lady\r\nto whose remark she had answered. \xe2\x80\x9cThe most dreadful part of slavery,\r\nto my mind, is its outrages on the feelings and affections,\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nseparating of families, for example.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat _is_ a bad thing, certainly,\xe2\x80\x9d said the other lady, holding up a\r\nbaby\xe2\x80\x99s dress she had just completed, and looking intently on its\r\ntrimmings; It needs not to be told;\xe2\x80\x94every day is\r\ntelling it,\xe2\x80\x94telling it, too, in the ear of One who is not deaf, though\r\nhe be long silent.\r\n\r\nThe young man who had spoken for the cause of humanity and God before\r\nstood with folded arms, looking on this scene. He turned, and Haley was\r\nstanding at his side. \xe2\x80\x9cMy friend,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, speaking with thick\r\nutterance, \xe2\x80\x9chow can you, how dare you, carry on a trade like this? Men talked, and loafed, and read, and smoked. Women sewed, and\r\nchildren played, and the boat passed on her way.\r\n\r\nOne day, when she lay to for a while at a small town in Kentucky, Haley\r\nwent up into the place on a little matter of business.\r\n\r\nTom, whose fetters did not prevent his taking a moderate circuit, had\r\ndrawn near the side of the boat, and stood listlessly gazing over the\r\nrailing. After a time, he saw the trader returning, with an alert step,\r\nin company with a colored woman, bearing in her arms a young child. She\r\nwas dressed quite respectably, and a colored man followed her, bringing\r\nalong a small trunk. The woman came cheerfully onward, talking, as she\r\ncame, with the man who bore her trunk, and so passed up the plank into\r\nthe boat. The bell rung, the steamer whizzed, the engine groaned and\r\ncoughed, and away swept the boat down the river.\r\n\r\nThe woman walked forward among the boxes and bales of the lower deck,\r\nand, sitting down, busied herself with chirruping to her baby.\r\n\r\nHaley made a turn or two about the boat, and then, coming up, seated\r\nhimself near her, and began saying something to her in an indifferent\r\nundertone.\r\n\r\nTom soon noticed a heavy cloud passing over the woman\xe2\x80\x99s brow; and that\r\nshe answered rapidly, and with great vehemence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t believe it,\xe2\x80\x94I won\xe2\x80\x99t believe it!\xe2\x80\x9d he heard her say. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re\r\njist a foolin\xe2\x80\x99 with me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you won\xe2\x80\x99t believe it, look here!\xe2\x80\x9d said the man, drawing out a\r\npaper; \xe2\x80\x9cthis yer\xe2\x80\x99s the bill of sale, and there\xe2\x80\x99s your master\xe2\x80\x99s name to\r\nit; and I paid down good solid cash for it, too, I can tell you,\xe2\x80\x94so,\r\nnow!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t believe Mas\xe2\x80\x99r would cheat me so; it can\xe2\x80\x99t be true!\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nwoman, with increasing agitation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou can ask any of these men here, that can read writing. And she saw sunshine sparkling on the water, in golden ripples,\r\nand heard gay voices, full of ease and pleasure, talking around her\r\neverywhere; but her heart lay as if a great stone had fallen on it. Her\r\nbaby raised himself up against her, and stroked her cheeks with his\r\nlittle hands; and, springing up and down, crowing and chatting, seemed\r\ndetermined to arouse her. Sell well, either way;\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\nHaley resumed his cigar.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey won\xe2\x80\x99t want the young \xe2\x80\x99un on the plantation,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall sell him, first chance I find,\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley, lighting another\r\ncigar.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cS\xe2\x80\x99pose you\xe2\x80\x99d be selling him tol\xe2\x80\x99able cheap,\xe2\x80\x9d said the stranger,\r\nmounting the pile of boxes, and sitting down comfortably.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t know \xe2\x80\x99bout that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley; \xe2\x80\x9che\xe2\x80\x99s a pretty smart young \xe2\x80\x99un,\r\nstraight, fat, strong; flesh as hard as a brick!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery true, but then there\xe2\x80\x99s the bother and expense of raisin\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNonsense!\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley; \xe2\x80\x9cthey is raised as easy as any kind of critter\r\nthere is going; they an\xe2\x80\x99t a bit more trouble than pups. This yer chap\r\nwill be running all around, in a month.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve got a good place for raisin\xe2\x80\x99, and I thought of takin\xe2\x80\x99 in a little\r\nmore stock,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man. \xe2\x80\x9cOne cook lost a young \xe2\x80\x99un last week,\xe2\x80\x94got\r\ndrownded in a washtub, while she was a hangin\xe2\x80\x99 out the clothes,\xe2\x80\x94and I\r\nreckon it would be well enough to set her to raisin\xe2\x80\x99 this yer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHaley and the stranger smoked a while in silence, neither seeming\r\nwilling to broach the test question of the interview. At last the man\r\nresumed:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t think of wantin\xe2\x80\x99 more than ten dollars for that ar chap,\r\nseeing you _must_ get him off yer hand, any how?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHaley shook his head, and spit impressively.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat won\xe2\x80\x99t do, no ways,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, and began his smoking again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, stranger, what will you take?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley, \xe2\x80\x9cI _could_ raise that ar chap myself, or get\r\nhim raised; he\xe2\x80\x99s oncommon likely and healthy, and he\xe2\x80\x99d fetch a hundred\r\ndollars, six months hence; and, in a year or two, he\xe2\x80\x99d bring two\r\nhundred, if I had him in the right spot; I shan\xe2\x80\x99t take a cent less nor\r\nfifty for him now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, stranger! that\xe2\x80\x99s rediculous, altogether,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFact!\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley, with a decisive nod of his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll give thirty for him,\xe2\x80\x9d said the stranger, \xe2\x80\x9cbut not a cent more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell ye what I will do,\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley, spitting again, with\r\nrenewed decision. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll split the difference, and say forty-five; and\r\nthat\xe2\x80\x99s the most I will do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, agreed!\xe2\x80\x9d said the man, after an interval.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDone!\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere do you land?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt Louisville,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLouisville,\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley. \xe2\x80\x9cVery fair, we get there about dusk. Chap\r\nwill be asleep,\xe2\x80\x94all fair,\xe2\x80\x94get him off quietly, and no\r\nscreaming,\xe2\x80\x94happens beautiful,\xe2\x80\x94I like to do everything quietly,\xe2\x80\x94I hates\r\nall kind of agitation and fluster.\xe2\x80\x9d And so, after a transfer of certain\r\nbills had passed from the man\xe2\x80\x99s pocket-book to the trader\xe2\x80\x99s, he resumed\r\nhis cigar.\r\n\r\nIt was a bright, tranquil evening when the boat stopped at the wharf at\r\nLouisville. The woman had been sitting with her baby in her arms, now\r\nwrapped in a heavy sleep. When she heard the name of the place called\r\nout, she hastily laid the child down in a little cradle formed by the\r\nhollow among the boxes, first carefully spreading under it her cloak;\r\nand then she sprung to the side of the boat, in hopes that, among the\r\nvarious hotel-waiters who thronged the wharf, she might see her\r\nhusband. In this hope, she pressed forward to the front rails, and,\r\nstretching far over them, strained her eyes intently on the moving\r\nheads on the shore, and the crowd pressed in between her and the child.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow\xe2\x80\x99s your time,\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley, taking the sleeping child up, and\r\nhanding him to the stranger. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t wake him up, and set him to crying,\r\nnow; it would make a devil of a fuss with the gal.\xe2\x80\x9d The man took the\r\nbundle carefully, and was soon lost in the crowd that went up the\r\nwharf.\r\n\r\nWhen the boat, creaking, and groaning, and puffing, had loosed from the\r\nwharf, and was beginning slowly to strain herself along, the woman\r\nreturned to her old seat. The trader was sitting there,\xe2\x80\x94the child was\r\ngone!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, why,\xe2\x80\x94where?\xe2\x80\x9d she began, in bewildered surprise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLucy,\xe2\x80\x9d said the trader, \xe2\x80\x9cyour child\xe2\x80\x99s gone; you may as well know it\r\nfirst as last. You see, I know\xe2\x80\x99d you couldn\xe2\x80\x99t take him down south; and\r\nI got a chance to sell him to a first-rate family, that\xe2\x80\x99ll raise him\r\nbetter than you can.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe trader had arrived at that stage of Christian and political\r\nperfection which has been recommended by some preachers and politicians\r\nof the north, lately, in which he had completely overcome every humane\r\nweakness and prejudice.
