His heart was exactly where yours, sir, and\r\nmine could be brought, with proper effort and cultivation. The wild\r\nlook of anguish and utter despair that the woman cast on him might have\r\ndisturbed one less practised; but he was used to it. He had seen that\r\nsame look hundreds of times. You can get used to such things, too, my\r\nfriend; and it is the great object of recent efforts to make our whole\r\nnorthern community used to them, for the glory of the Union. So the\r\ntrader only regarded the mortal anguish which he saw working in those\r\ndark features, those clenched hands, and suffocating breathings, as\r\nnecessary incidents of the trade, and merely calculated whether she was\r\ngoing to scream, and get up a commotion on the boat; for, like other\r\nsupporters of our peculiar institution, he decidedly disliked\r\nagitation.\r\n\r\nBut the woman did not scream. The shot had passed too straight and\r\ndirect through the heart, for cry or tear.\r\n\r\nDizzily she sat down. Her slack hands fell lifeless by her side. Her\r\neyes looked straight forward, but she saw nothing. All the noise and\r\nhum of the boat, the groaning of the machinery, mingled dreamily to her\r\nbewildered ear; and the poor, dumb-stricken heart had neither cry not\r\ntear to show for its utter misery. She was quite calm.\r\n\r\nThe trader, who, considering his advantages, was almost as humane as\r\nsome of our politicians, seemed to feel called on to administer such\r\nconsolation as the case admitted of.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know this yer comes kinder hard, at first, Lucy,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cbut such\r\na smart, sensible gal as you are, won\xe2\x80\x99t give way to it. You see it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n_necessary_, and can\xe2\x80\x99t be helped!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO! don\xe2\x80\x99t, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r, don\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x9d said the woman, with a voice like one that is\r\nsmothering.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re a smart wench, Lucy,\xe2\x80\x9d he persisted; \xe2\x80\x9cI mean to do well by ye,\r\nand get ye a nice place down river; and you\xe2\x80\x99ll soon get another\r\nhusband,\xe2\x80\x94such a likely gal as you\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO! Mas\xe2\x80\x99r, if you _only_ won\xe2\x80\x99t talk to me now,\xe2\x80\x9d said the woman, in a\r\nvoice of such quick and living anguish that the trader felt that there\r\nwas something at present in the case beyond his style of operation. He\r\ngot up, and the woman turned away, and buried her head in her cloak.\r\n\r\nThe trader walked up and down for a time, and occasionally stopped and\r\nlooked at her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTakes it hard, rather,\xe2\x80\x9d he soliloquized, \xe2\x80\x9cbut quiet, tho\xe2\x80\x99;\xe2\x80\x94let her\r\nsweat a while; she\xe2\x80\x99ll come right, by and by!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom had watched the whole transaction from first to last, and had a\r\nperfect understanding of its results. To him, it looked like something\r\nunutterably horrible and cruel, because, poor, ignorant black soul! he\r\nhad not learned to generalize, and to take enlarged views. If he had\r\nonly been instructed by certain ministers of Christianity, he might\r\nhave thought better of it, and seen in it an every-day incident of a\r\nlawful trade; a trade which is the vital support of an institution\r\nwhich an American divine[2] tells us has _\xe2\x80\x9cno evils but such as are\r\ninseparable from any other relations in social and domestic life_.\xe2\x80\x9d But\r\nTom, as we see, being a poor, ignorant fellow, whose reading had been\r\nconfined entirely to the New Testament, could not comfort and solace\r\nhimself with views like these. His very soul bled within him for what\r\nseemed to him the _wrongs_ of the poor suffering thing that lay like a\r\ncrushed reed on the boxes; the feeling, living, bleeding, yet immortal\r\n_thing_, which American state law coolly classes with the bundles, and\r\nbales, and boxes, among which she is lying.\r\n\r\n [2] Dr. Joel Parker of Philadelphia. [Mrs. Stowe\xe2\x80\x99s note.] Presbyterian\r\n clergyman (1798-1873), a friend of the Beecher family. Mrs. Stowe\r\n attempted unsuccessfully to have this identifying note removed from\r\n the stereotype-plate of the first edition.\r\n\r\n\r\nTom drew near, and tried to say something; but she only groaned.\r\nHonestly, and with tears running down his own cheeks, he spoke of a\r\nheart of love in the skies, of a pitying Jesus, and an eternal home;\r\nbut the ear was deaf with anguish, and the palsied heart could not\r\nfeel.\r\n\r\nNight came on,\xe2\x80\x94night calm, unmoved, and glorious, shining down with her\r\ninnumerable and solemn angel eyes, twinkling, beautiful, but silent.\r\nThere was no speech nor language, no pitying voice or helping hand,\r\nfrom that distant sky. One after another, the voices of business or\r\npleasure died away; all on the boat were sleeping, and the ripples at\r\nthe prow were plainly heard. Tom stretched himself out on a box, and\r\nthere, as he lay, he heard, ever and anon, a smothered sob or cry from\r\nthe prostrate creature,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cO! what shall I do? O Lord! O good Lord, do\r\nhelp me!\xe2\x80\x9d and so, ever and anon, until the murmur died away in silence.\r\n\r\nAt midnight, Tom waked, with a sudden start. Something black passed\r\nquickly by him to the side of the boat, and he heard a splash in the\r\nwater. No one else saw or heard anything. He raised his head,\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nwoman\xe2\x80\x99s place was vacant! He got up, and sought about him in vain. The\r\npoor bleeding heart was still, at last, and the river rippled and\r\ndimpled just as brightly as if it had not closed above it.\r\n\r\nPatience! patience! ye whose hearts swell indignant at wrongs like\r\nthese. Not one throb of anguish, not one tear of the oppressed, is\r\nforgotten by the Man of Sorrows, the Lord of Glory. In his patient,\r\ngenerous bosom he bears the anguish of a world. Bear thou, like him, in\r\npatience, and labor in love; for sure as he is God, \xe2\x80\x9cthe year of his\r\nredeemed _shall_ come.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe trader waked up bright and early, and came out to see to his live\r\nstock. It was now his turn to look about in perplexity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere alive is that gal?\xe2\x80\x9d he said to Tom.\r\n\r\nTom, who had learned the wisdom of keeping counsel, did not feel called\r\nupon to state his observations and suspicions, but said he did not\r\nknow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe surely couldn\xe2\x80\x99t have got off in the night at any of the landings,\r\nfor I was awake, and on the lookout, whenever the boat stopped. I never\r\ntrust these yer things to other folks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis speech was addressed to Tom quite confidentially, as if it was\r\nsomething that would be specially interesting to him. Tom made no\r\nanswer.\r\n\r\nThe trader searched the boat from stem to stern, among boxes, bales and\r\nbarrels, around the machinery, by the chimneys, in vain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, I say, Tom, be fair about this yer,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, when, after a\r\nfruitless search, he came where Tom was standing. \xe2\x80\x9cYou know something\r\nabout it, now. Don\xe2\x80\x99t tell me,\xe2\x80\x94I know you do. I saw the gal stretched\r\nout here about ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock, and ag\xe2\x80\x99in at twelve, and ag\xe2\x80\x99in between one\r\nand two; and then at four she was gone, and you was a sleeping right\r\nthere all the time. Now, you know something,\xe2\x80\x94you can\xe2\x80\x99t help it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, \xe2\x80\x9ctowards morning something brushed by me, and\r\nI kinder half woke; and then I hearn a great splash, and then I clare\r\nwoke up, and the gal was gone. That\xe2\x80\x99s all I know on \xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe trader was not shocked nor amazed; because, as we said before, he\r\nwas used to a great many things that you are not used to. Even the\r\nawful presence of Death struck no solemn chill upon him. He had seen\r\nDeath many times,\xe2\x80\x94met him in the way of trade, and got acquainted with\r\nhim,\xe2\x80\x94and he only thought of him as a hard customer, that embarrassed\r\nhis property operations very unfairly; and so he only swore that the\r\ngal was a baggage, and that he was devilish unlucky, and that, if\r\nthings went on in this way, he should not make a cent on the trip. In\r\nshort, he seemed to consider himself an ill-used man, decidedly; but\r\nthere was no help for it, as the woman had escaped into a state which\r\n_never will_ give up a fugitive,\xe2\x80\x94not even at the demand of the whole\r\nglorious Union. The trader, therefore, sat discontentedly down, with\r\nhis little account-book, and put down the missing body and soul under\r\nthe head of _losses!_\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s a shocking creature, isn\xe2\x80\x99t he,\xe2\x80\x94this trader? so unfeeling! It\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndreadful, really!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, but nobody thinks anything of these traders! They are universally\r\ndespised,\xe2\x80\x94never received into any decent society.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut who, sir, makes the trader? Who is most to blame? The enlightened,\r\ncultivated, intelligent man, who supports the system of which the\r\ntrader is the inevitable result, or the poor trader himself? You make\r\nthe public statement that calls for his trade, that debauches and\r\ndepraves him, till he feels no shame in it; and in what are you better\r\nthan he?\r\n\r\nAre you educated and he ignorant, you high and he low, you refined and\r\nhe coarse, you talented and he simple?\r\n\r\nIn the day of a future judgment, these very considerations may make it\r\nmore tolerable for him than for you.\r\n\r\nIn concluding these little incidents of lawful trade, we must beg the\r\nworld not to think that American legislators are entirely destitute of\r\nhumanity, as might, perhaps, be unfairly inferred from the great\r\nefforts made in our national body to protect and perpetuate this\r\nspecies of traffic.\r\n\r\nWho does not know how our great men are outdoing themselves, in\r\ndeclaiming against the _foreign_ slave-trade. There are a perfect host\r\nof Clarksons and Wilberforces[3] risen up among us on that subject,\r\nmost edifying to hear and behold. Trading negroes from Africa, dear\r\nreader, is so horrid! It is not to be thought of! But trading them from\r\nKentucky,\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s quite another thing!\r\n\r\n [3] Thomas Clarkson (1760-1846) and William Wilberforce (1759- 1833),\r\n English philanthropists and anti-slavery agitators who helped to\r\n secure passage of the Emancipation Bill by Parliament in 1833.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XIII\r\nThe Quaker Settlement\r\n\r\n\r\nA quiet scene now rises before us. A large, roomy, neatly-painted\r\nkitchen, its yellow floor glossy and smooth, and without a particle of\r\ndust; a neat, well-blacked cooking-stove; rows of shining tin,\r\nsuggestive of unmentionable good things to the appetite; glossy green\r\nwood chairs, old and firm; a small flag-bottomed rocking-chair, with a\r\npatch-work cushion in it, neatly contrived out of small pieces of\r\ndifferent colored woollen goods, and a larger sized one, motherly and\r\nold, whose wide arms breathed hospitable invitation, seconded by the\r\nsolicitation of its feather cushions,\xe2\x80\x94a real comfortable, persuasive\r\nold chair, and worth, in the way of honest, homely enjoyment, a dozen\r\nof your plush or _brochetelle_ drawing-room gentry; and in the chair,\r\ngently swaying back and forward, her eyes bent on some fine sewing, sat\r\nour fine old friend Eliza. Yes, there she is, paler and thinner than in\r\nher Kentucky home, with a world of quiet sorrow lying under the shadow\r\nof her long eyelashes, and marking the outline of her gentle mouth! It\r\nwas plain to see how old and firm the girlish heart was grown under the\r\ndiscipline of heavy sorrow; and when, anon, her large dark eye was\r\nraised to follow the gambols of her little Harry, who was sporting,\r\nlike some tropical butterfly, hither and thither over the floor, she\r\nshowed a depth of firmness and steady resolve that was never there in\r\nher earlier and happier days.\r\n\r\nBy her side sat a woman with a bright tin pan in her lap, into which\r\nshe was carefully sorting some dried peaches. She might be fifty-five\r\nor sixty; but hers was one of those faces that time seems to touch only\r\nto brighten and adorn. The snowy lisse crape cap, made after the strait\r\nQuaker pattern,\xe2\x80\x94the plain white muslin handkerchief, lying in placid\r\nfolds across her bosom,\xe2\x80\x94the drab shawl and dress,\xe2\x80\x94showed at once the\r\ncommunity to which she belonged. Her face was round and rosy, with a\r\nhealthful downy softness, suggestive of a ripe peach. Her hair,\r\npartially silvered by age, was parted smoothly back from a high placid\r\nforehead, on which time had written no inscription, except peace on\r\nearth, good will to men, and beneath shone a large pair of clear,\r\nhonest, loving brown eyes; you only needed to look straight into them,\r\nto feel that you saw to the bottom of a heart as good and true as ever\r\nthrobbed in woman\xe2\x80\x99s bosom. So much has been said and sung of beautiful\r\nyoung girls, why don\xe2\x80\x99t somebody wake up to the beauty of old women? If\r\nany want to get up an inspiration under this head, we refer them to our\r\ngood friend Rachel Halliday, just as she sits there in her little\r\nrocking-chair. It had a turn for quacking and squeaking,\xe2\x80\x94that chair\r\nhad,\xe2\x80\x94either from having taken cold in early life, or from some\r\nasthmatic affection, or perhaps from nervous derangement; but, as she\r\ngently swung backward and forward, the chair kept up a kind of subdued\r\n\xe2\x80\x9ccreechy crawchy,\xe2\x80\x9d that would have been intolerable in any other chair.\r\nBut old Simeon Halliday often declared it was as good as any music to\r\nhim, and the children all avowed that they wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t miss of hearing\r\nmother\xe2\x80\x99s chair for anything in the world. For why? for twenty years or\r\nmore, nothing but loving words, and gentle moralities, and motherly\r\nloving kindness, had come from that chair;\xe2\x80\x94head-aches and heart-aches\r\ninnumerable had been cured there,\xe2\x80\x94difficulties spiritual and temporal\r\nsolved there,\xe2\x80\x94all by one good, loving woman, God bless her!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd so thee still thinks of going to Canada, Eliza?\xe2\x80\x9d she said, as she\r\nwas quietly looking over her peaches.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eliza, firmly. \xe2\x80\x9cI must go onward. I dare not stop.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what\xe2\x80\x99ll thee do, when thee gets there? Thee must think about that,\r\nmy daughter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy daughter\xe2\x80\x9d came naturally from the lips of Rachel Halliday; for hers\r\nwas just the face and form that made \xe2\x80\x9cmother\xe2\x80\x9d seem the most natural\r\nword in the world.\r\n\r\nEliza\xe2\x80\x99s hands trembled, and some tears fell on her fine work; but she\r\nanswered, firmly,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall do\xe2\x80\x94anything I can find. I hope I can find something.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThee knows thee can stay here, as long as thee pleases,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rachel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, thank you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eliza, \xe2\x80\x9cbut\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94she pointed to Harry\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t sleep\r\nnights; I can\xe2\x80\x99t rest. Last night I dreamed I saw that man coming into\r\nthe yard,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, shuddering.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor child!\xe2\x80\x9d said Rachel, wiping her eyes; \xe2\x80\x9cbut thee mustn\xe2\x80\x99t feel so.\r\nThe Lord hath ordered it so that never hath a fugitive been stolen from\r\nour village. I trust thine will not be the first.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe door here opened, and a little short, round, pin-cushiony woman\r\nstood at the door, with a cheery, blooming face, like a ripe apple. She\r\nwas dressed, like Rachel, in sober gray, with the muslin folded neatly\r\nacross her round, plump little chest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRuth Stedman,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rachel, coming joyfully forward; \xe2\x80\x9chow is thee,\r\nRuth? she said, heartily taking both her hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNicely,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ruth, taking off her little drab bonnet, and dusting it\r\nwith her handkerchief, displaying, as she did so, a round little head,\r\non which the Quaker cap sat with a sort of jaunty air, despite all the\r\nstroking and patting of the small fat hands, which were busily applied\r\nto arranging it. Certain stray locks of decidedly curly hair, too, had\r\nescaped here and there, and had to be coaxed and cajoled into their\r\nplace again; and then the new comer, who might have been\r\nfive-and-twenty, turned from the small looking-glass, before which she\r\nhad been making these arrangements, and looked well pleased,\xe2\x80\x94as most\r\npeople who looked at her might have been,\xe2\x80\x94for she was decidedly a\r\nwholesome, whole-hearted, chirruping little woman, as ever gladdened\r\nman\xe2\x80\x99s heart withal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRuth, this friend is Eliza Harris; and this is the little boy I told\r\nthee of.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am glad to see thee, Eliza,\xe2\x80\x94very,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ruth, shaking hands, as if\r\nEliza were an old friend she had long been expecting; \xe2\x80\x9cand this is thy\r\ndear boy,\xe2\x80\x94I brought a cake for him,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, holding out a little\r\nheart to the boy, who came up, gazing through his curls, and accepted\r\nit shyly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere\xe2\x80\x99s thy baby, Ruth?\xe2\x80\x9d said Rachel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, he\xe2\x80\x99s coming; but thy Mary caught him as I came in, and ran off with\r\nhim to the barn, to show him to the children.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this moment, the door opened, and Mary, an honest, rosy-looking\r\ngirl, with large brown eyes, like her mother\xe2\x80\x99s, came in with the baby.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! ha!\xe2\x80\x9d said Rachel, coming up, and taking the great, white, fat\r\nfellow in her arms, \xe2\x80\x9chow good he looks, and how he does grow!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be sure, he does,\xe2\x80\x9d said little bustling Ruth, as she took the\r\nchild, and began taking off a little blue silk hood, and various layers\r\nand wrappers of outer garments; and having given a twitch here, and a\r\npull there, and variously adjusted and arranged him, and kissed him\r\nheartily, she set him on the floor to collect his thoughts. Baby seemed\r\nquite used to this mode of proceeding, for he put his thumb in his\r\nmouth (as if it were quite a thing of course), and seemed soon absorbed\r\nin his own reflections, while the mother seated herself, and taking out\r\na long stocking of mixed blue and white yarn, began to knit with\r\nbriskness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMary, thee\xe2\x80\x99d better fill the kettle, hadn\xe2\x80\x99t thee?\xe2\x80\x9d gently suggested\r\nthe mother.\r\n\r\nMary took the kettle to the well, and soon reappearing, placed it over\r\nthe stove, where it was soon purring and steaming, a sort of censer of\r\nhospitality and good cheer. The peaches, moreover, in obedience to a\r\nfew gentle whispers from Rachel, were soon deposited, by the same hand,\r\nin a stew-pan over the fire.\r\n\r\nRachel now took down a snowy moulding-board, and, tying on an apron,\r\nproceeded quietly to making up some biscuits, first saying to\r\nMary,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cMary, hadn\xe2\x80\x99t thee better tell John to get a chicken ready?\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\nMary disappeared accordingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how is Abigail Peters?\xe2\x80\x9d said Rachel, as she went on with her\r\nbiscuits.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, she\xe2\x80\x99s better,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ruth; \xe2\x80\x9cI was in, this morning; made the bed,\r\ntidied up the house. Leah Hills went in, this afternoon, and baked\r\nbread and pies enough to last some days; and I engaged to go back to\r\nget her up, this evening.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will go in tomorrow, and do any cleaning there may be, and look over\r\nthe mending,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rachel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! that is well,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ruth. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve heard,\xe2\x80\x9d she added, \xe2\x80\x9cthat Hannah\r\nStanwood is sick. John was up there, last night,\xe2\x80\x94I must go there\r\ntomorrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJohn can come in here to his meals, if thee needs to stay all day,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsuggested Rachel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank thee, Rachel; will see, tomorrow; but, here comes Simeon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSimeon Halliday, a tall, straight, muscular man, in drab coat and\r\npantaloons, and broad-brimmed hat, now entered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow is thee, Ruth?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, warmly, as he spread his broad open hand\r\nfor her little fat palm; \xe2\x80\x9cand how is John?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO! John is well, and all the rest of our folks,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ruth, cheerily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAny news, father?\xe2\x80\x9d said Rachel, as she was putting her biscuits into\r\nthe oven.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeter Stebbins told me that they should be along tonight, with\r\n_friends_,\xe2\x80\x9d said Simeon, significantly, as he was washing his hands at\r\na neat sink, in a little back porch.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed!\xe2\x80\x9d said Rachel, looking thoughtfully, and glancing at Eliza.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid thee say thy name was Harris?\xe2\x80\x9d said Simeon to Eliza, as he\r\nreentered.\r\n\r\nRachel glanced quickly at her husband, as Eliza tremulously answered\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cyes;\xe2\x80\x9d her fears, ever uppermost, suggesting that possibly there might\r\nbe advertisements out for her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMother!\xe2\x80\x9d said Simeon, standing in the porch, and calling Rachel out.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat does thee want, father?\xe2\x80\x9d said Rachel, rubbing her floury hands,\r\nas she went into the porch.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis child\xe2\x80\x99s husband is in the settlement, and will be here tonight,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Simeon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, thee doesn\xe2\x80\x99t say that, father?\xe2\x80\x9d said Rachel, all her face radiant\r\nwith joy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s really true. Peter was down yesterday, with the wagon, to the\r\nother stand, and there he found an old woman and two men; and one said\r\nhis name was George Harris; and from what he told of his history, I am\r\ncertain who he is. He is a bright, likely fellow, too.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall we tell her now?\xe2\x80\x9d said Simeon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s tell Ruth,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rachel. \xe2\x80\x9cHere, Ruth,\xe2\x80\x94come here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nRuth laid down her knitting-work, and was in the back porch in a\r\nmoment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRuth, what does thee think?\xe2\x80\x9d said Rachel. \xe2\x80\x9cFather says Eliza\xe2\x80\x99s husband\r\nis in the last company, and will be here tonight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA burst of joy from the little Quakeress interrupted the speech. She\r\ngave such a bound from the floor, as she clapped her little hands, that\r\ntwo stray curls fell from under her Quaker cap, and lay brightly on her\r\nwhite neckerchief.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHush thee, dear!\xe2\x80\x9d said Rachel, gently; \xe2\x80\x9chush, Ruth! Tell us, shall we\r\ntell her now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow! to be sure,\xe2\x80\x94this very minute. Why, now, suppose \xe2\x80\x99t was my John,\r\nhow should I feel? Do tell her, right off.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThee uses thyself only to learn how to love thy neighbor, Ruth,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nSimeon, looking, with a beaming face, on Ruth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be sure. Isn\xe2\x80\x99t it what we are made for? If I didn\xe2\x80\x99t love John and\r\nthe baby, I should not know how to feel for her. Come, now do tell\r\nher,\xe2\x80\x94do!\xe2\x80\x9d and she laid her hands persuasively on Rachel\xe2\x80\x99s arm. \xe2\x80\x9cTake\r\nher into thy bed-room, there, and let me fry the chicken while thee\r\ndoes it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nRachel came out into the kitchen, where Eliza was sewing, and opening\r\nthe door of a small bed-room, said, gently, \xe2\x80\x9cCome in here with me, my\r\ndaughter; I have news to tell thee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe blood flushed in Eliza\xe2\x80\x99s pale face; she rose, trembling with\r\nnervous anxiety, and looked towards her boy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no,\xe2\x80\x9d said little Ruth, darting up, and seizing her hands. \xe2\x80\x9cNever\r\nthee fear; it\xe2\x80\x99s good news, Eliza,\xe2\x80\x94go in, go in!\xe2\x80\x9d And she gently pushed\r\nher to the door which closed after her; and then, turning round, she\r\ncaught little Harry in her arms, and began kissing him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThee\xe2\x80\x99ll see thy father, little one. Does thee know it? Thy father is\r\ncoming,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, over and over again, as the boy looked wonderingly\r\nat her.\r\n\r\nMeanwhile, within the door, another scene was going on. Rachel Halliday\r\ndrew Eliza toward her, and said, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Lord hath had mercy on thee,\r\ndaughter; thy husband hath escaped from the house of bondage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe blood flushed to Eliza\xe2\x80\x99s cheek in a sudden glow, and went back to\r\nher heart with as sudden a rush. She sat down, pale and faint.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave courage, child,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rachel, laying her hand on her head. \xe2\x80\x9cHe is\r\namong friends, who will bring him here tonight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTonight!\xe2\x80\x9d Eliza repeated, \xe2\x80\x9ctonight!\xe2\x80\x9d The words lost all meaning to\r\nher; her head was dreamy and confused; all was mist for a moment.\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen she awoke, she found herself snugly tucked up on the bed, with a\r\nblanket over her, and little Ruth rubbing her hands with camphor. She\r\nopened her eyes in a state of dreamy, delicious languor, such as one\r\nwho has long been bearing a heavy load, and now feels it gone, and\r\nwould rest. The tension of the nerves, which had never ceased a moment\r\nsince the first hour of her flight, had given way, and a strange\r\nfeeling of security and rest came over her; and as she lay, with her\r\nlarge, dark eyes open, she followed, as in a quiet dream, the motions\r\nof those about her. She saw the door open into the other room; saw the\r\nsupper-table, with its snowy cloth; heard the dreamy murmur of the\r\nsinging tea-kettle; saw Ruth tripping backward and forward, with plates\r\nof cake and saucers of preserves, and ever and anon stopping to put a\r\ncake into Harry\xe2\x80\x99s hand, or pat his head, or twine his long curls round\r\nher snowy fingers. She saw the ample, motherly form of Rachel, as she\r\never and anon came to the bedside, and smoothed and arranged something\r\nabout the bedclothes, and gave a tuck here and there, by way of\r\nexpressing her good-will; and was conscious of a kind of sunshine\r\nbeaming down upon her from her large, clear, brown eyes. She saw Ruth\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhusband come in,\xe2\x80\x94saw her fly up to him, and commence whispering very\r\nearnestly, ever and anon, with impressive gesture, pointing her little\r\nfinger toward the room. She saw her, with the baby in her arms, sitting\r\ndown to tea; she saw them all at table, and little Harry in a high\r\nchair, under the shadow of Rachel\xe2\x80\x99s ample wing; there were low murmurs\r\nof talk, gentle tinkling of tea-spoons, and musical clatter of cups and\r\nsaucers, and all mingled in a delightful dream of rest; and Eliza\r\nslept, as she had not slept before, since the fearful midnight hour\r\nwhen she had taken her child and fled through the frosty starlight.\r\n\r\nShe dreamed of a beautiful country,\xe2\x80\x94a land, it seemed to her, of\r\nrest,\xe2\x80\x94green shores, pleasant islands, and beautifully glittering water;\r\nand there, in a house which kind voices told her was a home, she saw\r\nher boy playing, free and happy child. She heard her husband\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfootsteps; she felt him coming nearer; his arms were around her, his\r\ntears falling on her face, and she awoke! It was no dream. The daylight\r\nhad long faded; her child lay calmly sleeping by her side; a candle was\r\nburning dimly on the stand, and her husband was sobbing by her pillow.\r\n\r\n\r\nThe next morning was a cheerful one at the Quaker house. \xe2\x80\x9cMother\xe2\x80\x9d was\r\nup betimes, and surrounded by busy girls and boys, whom we had scarce\r\ntime to introduce to our readers yesterday, and who all moved\r\nobediently to Rachel\xe2\x80\x99s gentle \xe2\x80\x9cThee had better,\xe2\x80\x9d or more gentle \xe2\x80\x9cHadn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nthee better?\xe2\x80\x9d in the work of getting breakfast; for a breakfast in the\r\nluxurious valleys of Indiana is a thing complicated and multiform, and,\r\nlike picking up the rose-leaves and trimming the bushes in Paradise,\r\nasking other hands than those of the original mother. While, therefore,\r\nJohn ran to the spring for fresh water, and Simeon the second sifted\r\nmeal for corn-cakes, and Mary ground coffee, Rachel moved gently, and\r\nquietly about, making biscuits, cutting up chicken, and diffusing a\r\nsort of sunny radiance over the whole proceeding generally. If there\r\nwas any danger of friction or collision from the ill-regulated zeal of\r\nso many young operators, her gentle \xe2\x80\x9cCome! come!\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cI wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t, now,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nwas quite sufficient to allay the difficulty. Bards have written of the\r\ncestus of Venus, that turned the heads of all the world in successive\r\ngenerations. We had rather, for our part, have the cestus of Rachel\r\nHalliday, that kept heads from being turned, and made everything go on\r\nharmoniously. We think it is more suited to our modern days, decidedly.\r\n\r\nWhile all other preparations were going on, Simeon the elder stood in\r\nhis shirt-sleeves before a little looking-glass in the corner, engaged\r\nin the anti-patriarchal operation of shaving. Everything went on so\r\nsociably, so quietly, so harmoniously, in the great kitchen,\xe2\x80\x94it seemed\r\nso pleasant to every one to do just what they were doing, there was\r\nsuch an atmosphere of mutual confidence and good fellowship\r\neverywhere,\xe2\x80\x94even the knives and forks had a social clatter as they went\r\non to the table; and the chicken and ham had a cheerful and joyous\r\nfizzle in the pan, as if they rather enjoyed being cooked than\r\notherwise;\xe2\x80\x94and when George and Eliza and little Harry came out, they\r\nmet such a hearty, rejoicing welcome, no wonder it seemed to them like\r\na dream.\r\n\r\nAt last, they were all seated at breakfast, while Mary stood at the\r\nstove, baking griddle-cakes, which, as they gained the true exact\r\ngolden-brown tint of perfection, were transferred quite handily to the\r\ntable.\r\n\r\nRachel never looked so truly and benignly happy as at the head of her\r\ntable. There was so much motherliness and full-heartedness even in the\r\nway she passed a plate of cakes or poured a cup of coffee, that it\r\nseemed to put a spirit into the food and drink she offered.\r\n\r\nIt was the first time that ever George had sat down on equal terms at\r\nany white man\xe2\x80\x99s table; and he sat down, at first, with some constraint\r\nand awkwardness; but they all exhaled and went off like fog, in the\r\ngenial morning rays of this simple, overflowing kindness.\r\n\r\nThis, indeed, was a home,\xe2\x80\x94_home_,\xe2\x80\x94a word that George had never yet\r\nknown a meaning for; and a belief in God, and trust in his providence,\r\nbegan to encircle his heart, as, with a golden cloud of protection and\r\nconfidence, dark, misanthropic, pining atheistic doubts, and fierce\r\ndespair, melted away before the light of a living Gospel, breathed in\r\nliving faces, preached by a thousand unconscious acts of love and good\r\nwill, which, like the cup of cold water given in the name of a\r\ndisciple, shall never lose their reward.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFather, what if thee should get found out again?\xe2\x80\x9d said Simeon second,\r\nas he buttered his cake.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should pay my fine,\xe2\x80\x9d said Simeon, quietly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what if they put thee in prison?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCouldn\xe2\x80\x99t thee and mother manage the farm?\xe2\x80\x9d said Simeon, smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMother can do almost everything,\xe2\x80\x9d said the boy. \xe2\x80\x9cBut isn\xe2\x80\x99t it a shame\r\nto make such laws?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThee mustn\xe2\x80\x99t speak evil of thy rulers, Simeon,\xe2\x80\x9d said his father,\r\ngravely. \xe2\x80\x9cThe Lord only gives us our worldly goods that we may do\r\njustice and mercy; if our rulers require a price of us for it, we must\r\ndeliver it up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I hate those old slaveholders!\xe2\x80\x9d said the boy, who felt as\r\nunchristian as became any modern reformer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am surprised at thee, son,\xe2\x80\x9d said Simeon; \xe2\x80\x9cthy mother never taught\r\nthee so. I would do even the same for the slaveholder as for the slave,\r\nif the Lord brought him to my door in affliction.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSimeon second blushed scarlet; but his mother only smiled, and said,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSimeon is my good boy; he will grow older, by and by, and then he will\r\nbe like his father.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope, my good sir, that you are not exposed to any difficulty on our\r\naccount,\xe2\x80\x9d said George, anxiously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFear nothing, George, for therefore are we sent into the world. If we\r\nwould not meet trouble for a good cause, we were not worthy of our\r\nname.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, for _me_,\xe2\x80\x9d said George, \xe2\x80\x9cI could not bear it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFear not, then, friend George; it is not for thee, but for God and\r\nman, we do it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Simeon. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd now thou must lie by quietly this\r\nday, and tonight, at ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock, Phineas Fletcher will carry thee\r\nonward to the next stand,\xe2\x80\x94thee and the rest of thy company. The\r\npursuers are hard after thee; we must not delay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf that is the case, why wait till evening?\xe2\x80\x9d said George.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou art safe here by daylight, for every one in the settlement is a\r\nFriend, and all are watching. It has been found safer to travel by\r\nnight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XIV\r\nEvangeline\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA young star! which shone\r\nO\xe2\x80\x99er life\xe2\x80\x94too sweet an image, for such glass!\r\nA lovely being, scarcely formed or moulded;\r\nA rose with all its sweetest leaves yet folded.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nThe Mississippi! How, as by an enchanted wand, have its scenes been\r\nchanged, since Chateaubriand wrote his prose-poetic description of\r\nit,[1] as a river of mighty, unbroken solitudes, rolling amid undreamed\r\nwonders of vegetable and animal existence.\r\n\r\n [1] _In Atala; or the Love and Constantcy of Two Savages in the\r\n Desert_ (1801) by Francois Auguste Rene, Vicomte de Chateaubriand\r\n (1768-1848).\r\n\r\n\r\nBut as in an hour, this river of dreams and wild romance has emerged to\r\na reality scarcely less visionary and splendid. What other river of the\r\nworld bears on its bosom to the ocean the wealth and enterprise of such\r\nanother country?\xe2\x80\x94a country whose products embrace all between the\r\ntropics and the poles! Those turbid waters, hurrying, foaming, tearing\r\nalong, an apt resemblance of that headlong tide of business which is\r\npoured along its wave by a race more vehement and energetic than any\r\nthe old world ever saw. Ah! would that they did not also bear along a\r\nmore fearful freight,\xe2\x80\x94the tears of the oppressed, the sighs of the\r\nhelpless, the bitter prayers of poor, ignorant hearts to an unknown\r\nGod\xe2\x80\x94unknown, unseen and silent, but who will yet \xe2\x80\x9ccome out of his place\r\nto save all the poor of the earth!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe slanting light of the setting sun quivers on the sea-like expanse\r\nof the river; the shivery canes, and the tall, dark cypress, hung with\r\nwreaths of dark, funereal moss, glow in the golden ray, as the\r\nheavily-laden steamboat marches onward.\r\n\r\nPiled with cotton-bales, from many a plantation, up over deck and\r\nsides, till she seems in the distance a square, massive block of gray,\r\nshe moves heavily onward to the nearing mart. We must look some time\r\namong its crowded decks before we shall find again our humble friend\r\nTom. High on the upper deck, in a little nook among the everywhere\r\npredominant cotton-bales, at last we may find him.\r\n\r\nPartly from confidence inspired by Mr. Shelby\xe2\x80\x99s representations, and\r\npartly from the remarkably inoffensive and quiet character of the man,\r\nTom had insensibly won his way far into the confidence even of such a\r\nman as Haley.\r\n\r\nAt first he had watched him narrowly through the day, and never allowed\r\nhim to sleep at night unfettered; but the uncomplaining patience and\r\napparent contentment of Tom\xe2\x80\x99s manner led him gradually to discontinue\r\nthese restraints, and for some time Tom had enjoyed a sort of parole of\r\nhonor, being permitted to come and go freely where he pleased on the\r\nboat.\r\n\r\nEver quiet and obliging, and more than ready to lend a hand in every\r\nemergency which occurred among the workmen below, he had won the good\r\nopinion of all the hands, and spent many hours in helping them with as\r\nhearty a good will as ever he worked on a Kentucky farm.\r\n\r\nWhen there seemed to be nothing for him to do, he would climb to a nook\r\namong the cotton-bales of the upper deck, and busy himself in studying\r\nover his Bible,\xe2\x80\x94and it is there we see him now.\r\n\r\nFor a hundred or more miles above New Orleans, the river is higher than\r\nthe surrounding country, and rolls its tremendous volume between\r\nmassive levees twenty feet in height. The traveller from the deck of\r\nthe steamer, as from some floating castle top, overlooks the whole\r\ncountry for miles and miles around. Tom, therefore, had spread out full\r\nbefore him, in plantation after plantation, a map of the life to which\r\nhe was approaching.\r\n\r\nHe saw the distant slaves at their toil; he saw afar their villages of\r\nhuts gleaming out in long rows on many a plantation, distant from the\r\nstately mansions and pleasure-grounds of the master;\xe2\x80\x94and as the moving\r\npicture passed on, his poor, foolish heart would be turning backward to\r\nthe Kentucky farm, with its old shadowy beeches,\xe2\x80\x94to the master\xe2\x80\x99s house,\r\nwith its wide, cool halls, and, near by, the little cabin overgrown\r\nwith the multiflora and bignonia. There he seemed to see familiar faces\r\nof comrades who had grown up with him from infancy; he saw his busy\r\nwife, bustling in her preparations for his evening meals; he heard the\r\nmerry laugh of his boys at their play, and the chirrup of the baby at\r\nhis knee; and then, with a start, all faded, and he saw again the\r\ncanebrakes and cypresses and gliding plantations, and heard again the\r\ncreaking and groaning of the machinery, all telling him too plainly\r\nthat all that phase of life had gone by forever.\r\n\r\nIn such a case, you write to your wife, and send messages to your\r\nchildren; but Tom could not write,\xe2\x80\x94the mail for him had no existence,\r\nand the gulf of separation was unbridged by even a friendly word or\r\nsignal.\r\n\r\nIs it strange, then, that some tears fall on the pages of his Bible, as\r\nhe lays it on the cotton-bale, and, with patient finger, threading his\r\nslow way from word to word, traces out its promises? Having learned\r\nlate in life, Tom was but a slow reader, and passed on laboriously from\r\nverse to verse. Fortunate for him was it that the book he was intent on\r\nwas one which slow reading cannot injure,\xe2\x80\x94nay, one whose words, like\r\ningots of gold, seem often to need to be weighed separately, that the\r\nmind may take in their priceless value. Let us follow him a moment, as,\r\npointing to each word, and pronouncing each half aloud, he reads,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x94not\xe2\x80\x94your\xe2\x80\x94heart\xe2\x80\x94be\xe2\x80\x94troubled.\r\nIn\xe2\x80\x94my\xe2\x80\x94Father\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x94house\xe2\x80\x94are\xe2\x80\x94many\xe2\x80\x94mansions.\r\nI\xe2\x80\x94go\xe2\x80\x94to\xe2\x80\x94prepare\xe2\x80\x94a\xe2\x80\x94place\xe2\x80\x94for\xe2\x80\x94you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCicero, when he buried his darling and only daughter, had a heart as\r\nfull of honest grief as poor Tom\xe2\x80\x99s,\xe2\x80\x94perhaps no fuller, for both were\r\nonly men;\xe2\x80\x94but Cicero could pause over no such sublime words of hope,\r\nand look to no such future reunion; and if he _had_ seen them, ten to\r\none he would not have believed,\xe2\x80\x94he must fill his head first with a\r\nthousand questions of authenticity of manuscript, and correctness of\r\ntranslation. But, to poor Tom, there it lay, just what he needed, so\r\nevidently true and divine that the possibility of a question never\r\nentered his simple head. It must be true; for, if not true, how could\r\nhe live?\r\n\r\nAs for Tom\xe2\x80\x99s Bible, though it had no annotations and helps in margin\r\nfrom learned commentators, still it had been embellished with certain\r\nway-marks and guide-boards of Tom\xe2\x80\x99s own invention, and which helped him\r\nmore than the most learned expositions could have done. It had been his\r\ncustom to get the Bible read to him by his master\xe2\x80\x99s children, in\r\nparticular by young Master George; and, as they read, he would\r\ndesignate, by bold, strong marks and dashes, with pen and ink, the\r\npassages which more particularly gratified his ear or affected his\r\nheart. His Bible was thus marked through, from one end to the other,\r\nwith a variety of styles and designations; so he could in a moment\r\nseize upon his favorite passages, without the labor of spelling out\r\nwhat lay between them;\xe2\x80\x94and while it lay there before him, every passage\r\nbreathing of some old home scene, and recalling some past enjoyment,\r\nhis Bible seemed to him all of this life that remained, as well as the\r\npromise of a future one.\r\n\r\nAmong the passengers on the boat was a young gentleman of fortune and\r\nfamily, resident in New Orleans, who bore the name of St. Clare. He had\r\nwith him a daughter between five and six years of age, together with a\r\nlady who seemed to claim relationship to both, and to have the little\r\none especially under her charge.\r\n\r\nTom had often caught glimpses of this little girl,\xe2\x80\x94for she was one of\r\nthose busy, tripping creatures, that can be no more contained in one\r\nplace than a sunbeam or a summer breeze,\xe2\x80\x94nor was she one that, once\r\nseen, could be easily forgotten.\r\n\r\nHer form was the perfection of childish beauty, without its usual\r\nchubbiness and squareness of outline. There was about it an undulating\r\nand aerial grace, such as one might dream of for some mythic and\r\nallegorical being. Her face was remarkable less for its perfect beauty\r\nof feature than for a singular and dreamy earnestness of expression,\r\nwhich made the ideal start when they looked at her, and by which the\r\ndullest and most literal were impressed, without exactly knowing why.\r\nThe shape of her head and the turn of her neck and bust was peculiarly\r\nnoble, and the long golden-brown hair that floated like a cloud around\r\nit, the deep spiritual gravity of her violet blue eyes, shaded by heavy\r\nfringes of golden brown,\xe2\x80\x94all marked her out from other children, and\r\nmade every one turn and look after her, as she glided hither and\r\nthither on the boat. Nevertheless, the little one was not what you\r\nwould have called either a grave child or a sad one. On the contrary,\r\nan airy and innocent playfulness seemed to flicker like the shadow of\r\nsummer leaves over her childish face, and around her buoyant figure.\r\nShe was always in motion, always with a half smile on her rosy mouth,\r\nflying hither and thither, with an undulating and cloud-like tread,\r\nsinging to herself as she moved as in a happy dream. Her father and\r\nfemale guardian were incessantly busy in pursuit of her,\xe2\x80\x94but, when\r\ncaught, she melted from them again like a summer cloud; and as no word\r\nof chiding or reproof ever fell on her ear for whatever she chose to\r\ndo, she pursued her own way all over the boat. Always dressed in white,\r\nshe seemed to move like a shadow through all sorts of places, without\r\ncontracting spot or stain; and there was not a corner or nook, above or\r\nbelow, where those fairy footsteps had not glided, and that visionary\r\ngolden head, with its deep blue eyes, fleeted along.\r\n\r\nThe fireman, as he looked up from his sweaty toil, sometimes found\r\nthose eyes looking wonderingly into the raging depths of the furnace,\r\nand fearfully and pityingly at him, as if she thought him in some\r\ndreadful danger. Anon the steersman at the wheel paused and smiled, as\r\nthe picture-like head gleamed through the window of the round house,\r\nand in a moment was gone again. A thousand times a day rough voices\r\nblessed her, and smiles of unwonted softness stole over hard faces, as\r\nshe passed; and when she tripped fearlessly over dangerous places,\r\nrough, sooty hands were stretched involuntarily out to save her, and\r\nsmooth her path.\r\n\r\nTom, who had the soft, impressible nature of his kindly race, ever\r\nyearning toward the simple and childlike, watched the little creature\r\nwith daily increasing interest. To him she seemed something almost\r\ndivine; and whenever her golden head and deep blue eyes peered out upon\r\nhim from behind some dusky cotton-bale, or looked down upon him over\r\nsome ridge of packages, he half believed that he saw one of the angels\r\nstepped out of his New Testament.\r\n\r\nOften and often she walked mournfully round the place where Haley\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ngang of men and women sat in their chains. She would glide in among\r\nthem, and look at them with an air of perplexed and sorrowful\r\nearnestness; and sometimes she would lift their chains with her slender\r\nhands, and then sigh wofully, as she glided away. Several times she\r\nappeared suddenly among them, with her hands full of candy, nuts, and\r\noranges, which she would distribute joyfully to them, and then be gone\r\nagain.\r\n\r\nTom watched the little lady a great deal, before he ventured on any\r\novertures towards acquaintanceship. He knew an abundance of simple acts\r\nto propitiate and invite the approaches of the little people, and he\r\nresolved to play his part right skilfully. He could cut cunning little\r\nbaskets out of cherry-stones, could make grotesque faces on\r\nhickory-nuts, or odd-jumping figures out of elder-pith, and he was a\r\nvery Pan in the manufacture of whistles of all sizes and sorts. His\r\npockets were full of miscellaneous articles of attraction, which he had\r\nhoarded in days of old for his master\xe2\x80\x99s children, and which he now\r\nproduced, with commendable prudence and economy, one by one, as\r\novertures for acquaintance and friendship.\r\n\r\nThe little one was shy, for all her busy interest in everything going\r\non, and it was not easy to tame her. For a while, she would perch like\r\na canary-bird on some box or package near Tom, while busy in the little\r\narts afore-named, and take from him, with a kind of grave bashfulness,\r\nthe little articles he offered. But at last they got on quite\r\nconfidential terms.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s little missy\xe2\x80\x99s name?\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, at last, when he thought\r\nmatters were ripe to push such an inquiry.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEvangeline St. Clare,\xe2\x80\x9d said the little one, \xe2\x80\x9cthough papa and everybody\r\nelse call me Eva. Now, what\xe2\x80\x99s your name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy name\xe2\x80\x99s Tom; the little chil\xe2\x80\x99en used to call me Uncle Tom, way back\r\nthar in Kentuck.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I mean to call you Uncle Tom, because, you see, I like you,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nEva. \xe2\x80\x9cSo, Uncle Tom, where are you going?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know, Miss Eva.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t know?\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I am going to be sold to somebody. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know who.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy papa can buy you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva, quickly; \xe2\x80\x9cand if he buys you, you will\r\nhave good times. I mean to ask him, this very day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, my little lady,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom.\r\n\r\nThe boat here stopped at a small landing to take in wood, and Eva,\r\nhearing her father\xe2\x80\x99s voice, bounded nimbly away. Tom rose up, and went\r\nforward to offer his service in wooding, and soon was busy among the\r\nhands.\r\n\r\nEva and her father were standing together by the railings to see the\r\nboat start from the landing-place, the wheel had made two or three\r\nrevolutions in the water, when, by some sudden movement, the little one\r\nsuddenly lost her balance and fell sheer over the side of the boat into\r\nthe water. Her father, scarce knowing what he did, was plunging in\r\nafter her, but was held back by some behind him, who saw that more\r\nefficient aid had followed his child.\r\n\r\nTom was standing just under her on the lower deck, as she fell. He saw\r\nher strike the water, and sink, and was after her in a moment. A\r\nbroad-chested, strong-armed fellow, it was nothing for him to keep\r\nafloat in the water, till, in a moment or two the child rose to the\r\nsurface, and he caught her in his arms, and, swimming with her to the\r\nboat-side, handed her up, all dripping, to the grasp of hundreds of\r\nhands, which, as if they had all belonged to one man, were stretched\r\neagerly out to receive her. A few moments more, and her father bore\r\nher, dripping and senseless, to the ladies\xe2\x80\x99 cabin, where, as is usual\r\nin cases of the kind, there ensued a very well-meaning and kind-hearted\r\nstrife among the female occupants generally, as to who should do the\r\nmost things to make a disturbance, and to hinder her recovery in every\r\nway possible.\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was a sultry, close day, the next day, as the steamer drew near to\r\nNew Orleans. A general bustle of expectation and preparation was spread\r\nthrough the boat; in the cabin, one and another were gathering their\r\nthings together, and arranging them, preparatory to going ashore. The\r\nsteward and chambermaid, and all, were busily engaged in cleaning,\r\nfurbishing, and arranging the splendid boat, preparatory to a grand\r\nentree.\r\n\r\nOn the lower deck sat our friend Tom, with his arms folded, and\r\nanxiously, from time to time, turning his eyes towards a group on the\r\nother side of the boat.\r\n\r\nThere stood the fair Evangeline, a little paler than the day before,\r\nbut otherwise exhibiting no traces of the accident which had befallen\r\nher. A graceful, elegantly-formed young man stood by her, carelessly\r\nleaning one elbow on a bale of cotton while a large pocket-book lay\r\nopen before him. It was quite evident, at a glance, that the gentleman\r\nwas Eva\xe2\x80\x99s father. There was the same noble cast of head, the same large\r\nblue eyes, the same golden-brown hair; yet the expression was wholly\r\ndifferent. In the large, clear blue eyes, though in form and color\r\nexactly similar, there was wanting that misty, dreamy depth of\r\nexpression; all was clear, bold, and bright, but with a light wholly of\r\nthis world: the beautifully cut mouth had a proud and somewhat\r\nsarcastic expression, while an air of free-and-easy superiority sat not\r\nungracefully in every turn and movement of his fine form. He was\r\nlistening, with a good-humored, negligent air, half comic, half\r\ncontemptuous, to Haley, who was very volubly expatiating on the quality\r\nof the article for which they were bargaining.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll the moral and Christian virtues bound in black Morocco, complete!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nhe said, when Haley had finished. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, now, my good fellow, what\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nthe damage, as they say in Kentucky; in short, what\xe2\x80\x99s to be paid out\r\nfor this business? How much are you going to cheat me, now? Out with\r\nit!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWal,\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley, \xe2\x80\x9cif I should say thirteen hundred dollars for that\r\nar fellow, I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t but just save myself; I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t, now, re\xe2\x80\x99ly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor fellow!\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man, fixing his keen, mocking blue eye on\r\nhim; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I suppose you\xe2\x80\x99d let me have him for that, out of a particular\r\nregard for me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, the young lady here seems to be sot on him, and nat\xe2\x80\x99lly enough.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO! certainly, there\xe2\x80\x99s a call on your benevolence, my friend. Now, as a\r\nmatter of Christian charity, how cheap could you afford to let him go,\r\nto oblige a young lady that\xe2\x80\x99s particular sot on him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWal, now, just think on \xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said the trader; \xe2\x80\x9cjust look at them\r\nlimbs,\xe2\x80\x94broad-chested, strong as a horse. Look at his head; them high\r\nforrads allays shows calculatin niggers, that\xe2\x80\x99ll do any kind o\xe2\x80\x99 thing.\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ve, marked that ar. Now, a nigger of that ar heft and build is worth\r\nconsiderable, just as you may say, for his body, supposin he\xe2\x80\x99s stupid;\r\nbut come to put in his calculatin faculties, and them which I can show\r\nhe has oncommon, why, of course, it makes him come higher. Why, that ar\r\nfellow managed his master\xe2\x80\x99s whole farm. He has a strornary talent for\r\nbusiness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBad, bad, very bad; knows altogether too much!\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man,\r\nwith the same mocking smile playing about his mouth. \xe2\x80\x9cNever will do, in\r\nthe world. Your smart fellows are always running off, stealing horses,\r\nand raising the devil generally. I think you\xe2\x80\x99ll have to take off a\r\ncouple of hundred for his smartness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWal, there might be something in that ar, if it warnt for his\r\ncharacter; but I can show recommends from his master and others, to\r\nprove he is one of your real pious,\xe2\x80\x94the most humble, prayin, pious\r\ncrittur ye ever did see. Why, he\xe2\x80\x99s been called a preacher in them parts\r\nhe came from.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I might use him for a family chaplain, possibly,\xe2\x80\x9d added the young\r\nman, dryly. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s quite an idea. Religion is a remarkably scarce\r\narticle at our house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re joking, now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do you know I am? Didn\xe2\x80\x99t you just warrant him for a preacher? Has\r\nhe been examined by any synod or council? Come, hand over your papers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIf the trader had not been sure, by a certain good-humored twinkle in\r\nthe large eye, that all this banter was sure, in the long run, to turn\r\nout a cash concern, he might have been somewhat out of patience; as it\r\nwas, he laid down a greasy pocket-book on the cotton-bales, and began\r\nanxiously studying over certain papers in it, the young man standing\r\nby, the while, looking down on him with an air of careless, easy\r\ndrollery.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPapa, do buy him! it\xe2\x80\x99s no matter what you pay,\xe2\x80\x9d whispered Eva, softly,\r\ngetting up on a package, and putting her arm around her father\xe2\x80\x99s neck.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have money enough, I know. I want him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat for, pussy? Are you going to use him for a rattle-box, or a\r\nrocking-horse, or what?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want to make him happy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAn original reason, certainly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHere the trader handed up a certificate, signed by Mr. Shelby, which\r\nthe young man took with the tips of his long fingers, and glanced over\r\ncarelessly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA gentlemanly hand,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cand well spelt, too. Well, now, but I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nnot sure, after all, about this religion,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, the old wicked\r\nexpression returning to his eye; \xe2\x80\x9cthe country is almost ruined with\r\npious white people; such pious politicians as we have just before\r\nelections,\xe2\x80\x94such pious goings on in all departments of church and state,\r\nthat a fellow does not know who\xe2\x80\x99ll cheat him next. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\r\neither, about religion\xe2\x80\x99s being up in the market, just now. I have not\r\nlooked in the papers lately, to see how it sells. How many hundred\r\ndollars, now, do you put on for this religion?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou like to be jokin, now,\xe2\x80\x9d said the trader; \xe2\x80\x9cbut, then, there\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n_sense_ under all that ar. I know there\xe2\x80\x99s differences in religion. Some\r\nkinds is mis\xe2\x80\x99rable: there\xe2\x80\x99s your meetin pious; there\xe2\x80\x99s your singin,\r\nroarin pious; them ar an\xe2\x80\x99t no account, in black or white;\xe2\x80\x94but these\r\nrayly is; and I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen it in niggers as often as any, your rail\r\nsoftly, quiet, stiddy, honest, pious, that the hull world couldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ntempt \xe2\x80\x99em to do nothing that they thinks is wrong; and ye see in this\r\nletter what Tom\xe2\x80\x99s old master says about him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man, stooping gravely over his book of bills, \xe2\x80\x9cif\r\nyou can assure me that I really can buy _this_ kind of pious, and that\r\nit will be set down to my account in the book up above, as something\r\nbelonging to me, I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t care if I did go a little extra for it. How\r\nd\xe2\x80\x99ye say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWal, raily, I can\xe2\x80\x99t do that,\xe2\x80\x9d said the trader. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m a thinkin that\r\nevery man\xe2\x80\x99ll have to hang on his own hook, in them ar quarters.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRather hard on a fellow that pays extra on religion, and can\xe2\x80\x99t trade\r\nwith it in the state where he wants it most, an\xe2\x80\x99t it, now?\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nyoung man, who had been making out a roll of bills while he was\r\nspeaking. \xe2\x80\x9cThere, count your money, old boy!\xe2\x80\x9d he added, as he handed\r\nthe roll to the trader.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Haley, his face beaming with delight; and pulling out\r\nan old inkhorn, he proceeded to fill out a bill of sale, which, in a\r\nfew moments, he handed to the young man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wonder, now, if I was divided up and inventoried,\xe2\x80\x9d said the latter\r\nas he ran over the paper, \xe2\x80\x9chow much I might bring. Say so much for the\r\nshape of my head, so much for a high forehead, so much for arms, and\r\nhands, and legs, and then so much for education, learning, talent,\r\nhonesty, religion! Bless me! there would be small charge on that last,\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99m thinking. But come, Eva,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; and taking the hand of his\r\ndaughter, he stepped across the boat, and carelessly putting the tip of\r\nhis finger under Tom\xe2\x80\x99s chin, said, good-humoredly, \xe2\x80\x9cLook-up, Tom, and\r\nsee how you like your new master.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom looked up. It was not in nature to look into that gay, young,\r\nhandsome face, without a feeling of pleasure; and Tom felt the tears\r\nstart in his eyes as he said, heartily, \xe2\x80\x9cGod bless you, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I hope he will. What\xe2\x80\x99s your name? Tom? Quite as likely to do it\r\nfor your asking as mine, from all accounts. Can you drive horses, Tom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been allays used to horses,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom. \xe2\x80\x9cMas\xe2\x80\x99r Shelby raised heaps\r\nof \xe2\x80\x99em.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I think I shall put you in coachy, on condition that you won\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nbe drunk more than once a week, unless in cases of emergency, Tom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom looked surprised, and rather hurt, and said, \xe2\x80\x9cI never drink,\r\nMas\xe2\x80\x99r.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve heard that story before, Tom; but then we\xe2\x80\x99ll see. It will be a\r\nspecial accommodation to all concerned, if you don\xe2\x80\x99t. Never mind, my\r\nboy,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, good-humoredly, seeing Tom still looked grave; \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ndoubt you mean to do well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI sartin do, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you shall have good times,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva. \xe2\x80\x9cPapa is very good to\r\neverybody, only he always will laugh at them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPapa is much obliged to you for his recommendation,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare,\r\nlaughing, as he turned on his heel and walked away.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XV\r\nOf Tom\xe2\x80\x99s New Master, and Various Other Matters\r\n\r\n\r\nSince the thread of our humble hero\xe2\x80\x99s life has now become interwoven\r\nwith that of higher ones, it is necessary to give some brief\r\nintroduction to them.\r\n\r\nAugustine St. Clare was the son of a wealthy planter of Louisiana. The\r\nfamily had its origin in Canada. Of two brothers, very similar in\r\ntemperament and character, one had settled on a flourishing farm in\r\nVermont, and the other became an opulent planter in Louisiana. The\r\nmother of Augustine was a Huguenot French lady, whose family had\r\nemigrated to Louisiana during the days of its early settlement.\r\nAugustine and another brother were the only children of their parents.\r\nHaving inherited from his mother an exceeding delicacy of constitution,\r\nhe was, at the instance of physicians, during many years of his\r\nboyhood, sent to the care of his uncle in Vermont, in order that his\r\nconstitution might be strengthened by the cold of a more bracing\r\nclimate.\r\n\r\nIn childhood, he was remarkable for an extreme and marked sensitiveness\r\nof character, more akin to the softness of woman than the ordinary\r\nhardness of his own sex. Time, however, overgrew this softness with the\r\nrough bark of manhood, and but few knew how living and fresh it still\r\nlay at the core. His talents were of the very first order, although his\r\nmind showed a preference always for the ideal and the \xc3\xa6sthetic, and\r\nthere was about him that repugnance to the actual business of life\r\nwhich is the common result of this balance of the faculties. Soon after\r\nthe completion of his college course, his whole nature was kindled into\r\none intense and passionate effervescence of romantic passion. His hour\r\ncame,\xe2\x80\x94the hour that comes only once; his star rose in the horizon,\xe2\x80\x94that\r\nstar that rises so often in vain, to be remembered only as a thing of\r\ndreams; and it rose for him in vain. To drop the figure,\xe2\x80\x94he saw and won\r\nthe love of a high-minded and beautiful woman, in one of the northern\r\nstates, and they were affianced. He returned south to make arrangements\r\nfor their marriage, when, most unexpectedly, his letters were returned\r\nto him by mail, with a short note from her guardian, stating to him\r\nthat ere this reached him the lady would be the wife of another. Stung\r\nto madness, he vainly hoped, as many another has done, to fling the\r\nwhole thing from his heart by one desperate effort. Too proud to\r\nsupplicate or seek explanation, he threw himself at once into a whirl\r\nof fashionable society, and in a fortnight from the time of the fatal\r\nletter was the accepted lover of the reigning belle of the season; and\r\nas soon as arrangements could be made, he became the husband of a fine\r\nfigure, a pair of bright dark eyes, and a hundred thousand dollars;\r\nand, of course, everybody thought him a happy fellow.\r\n\r\nThe married couple were enjoying their honeymoon, and entertaining a\r\nbrilliant circle of friends in their splendid villa, near Lake\r\nPontchartrain, when, one day, a letter was brought to him in _that_\r\nwell-remembered writing. It was handed to him while he was in full tide\r\nof gay and successful conversation, in a whole room-full of company. He\r\nturned deadly pale when he saw the writing, but still preserved his\r\ncomposure, and finished the playful warfare of badinage which he was at\r\nthe moment carrying on with a lady opposite; and, a short time after,\r\nwas missed from the circle. In his room, alone, he opened and read the\r\nletter, now worse than idle and useless to be read. It was from her,\r\ngiving a long account of a persecution to which she had been exposed by\r\nher guardian\xe2\x80\x99s family, to lead her to unite herself with their son: and\r\nshe related how, for a long time, his letters had ceased to arrive; how\r\nshe had written time and again, till she became weary and doubtful; how\r\nher health had failed under her anxieties, and how, at last, she had\r\ndiscovered the whole fraud which had been practised on them both. The\r\nletter ended with expressions of hope and thankfulness, and professions\r\nof undying affection, which were more bitter than death to the unhappy\r\nyoung man. He wrote to her immediately:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have received yours,\xe2\x80\x94but too late. I believed all I heard. I was\r\ndesperate. _I am married_, and all is over. Only forget,\xe2\x80\x94it is all that\r\nremains for either of us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd thus ended the whole romance and ideal of life for Augustine St.\r\nClare. But the _real_ remained,\xe2\x80\x94the _real_, like the flat, bare, oozy\r\ntide-mud, when the blue sparkling wave, with all its company of gliding\r\nboats and white-winged ships, its music of oars and chiming waters, has\r\ngone down, and there it lies, flat, slimy, bare,\xe2\x80\x94exceedingly real.\r\n\r\nOf course, in a novel, people\xe2\x80\x99s hearts break, and they die, and that is\r\nthe end of it; and in a story this is very convenient. But in real life\r\nwe do not die when all that makes life bright dies to us. There is a\r\nmost busy and important round of eating, drinking, dressing, walking,\r\nvisiting, buying, selling, talking, reading, and all that makes up what\r\nis commonly called _living_, yet to be gone through; and this yet\r\nremained to Augustine. Had his wife been a whole woman, she might yet\r\nhave done something\xe2\x80\x94as woman can\xe2\x80\x94to mend the broken threads of life,\r\nand weave again into a tissue of brightness. But Marie St. Clare could\r\nnot even see that they had been broken. As before stated, she consisted\r\nof a fine figure, a pair of splendid eyes, and a hundred thousand\r\ndollars; and none of these items were precisely the ones to minister to\r\na mind diseased.\r\n\r\nWhen Augustine, pale as death, was found lying on the sofa, and pleaded\r\nsudden sick-headache as the cause of his distress, she recommended to\r\nhim to smell of hartshorn; and when the paleness and headache came on\r\nweek after week, she only said that she never thought Mr. St. Clare was\r\nsickly; but it seems he was very liable to sick-headaches, and that it\r\nwas a very unfortunate thing for her, because he didn\xe2\x80\x99t enjoy going\r\ninto company with her, and it seemed odd to go so much alone, when they\r\nwere just married. Augustine was glad in his heart that he had married\r\nso undiscerning a woman; but as the glosses and civilities of the\r\nhoneymoon wore away, he discovered that a beautiful young woman, who\r\nhas lived all her life to be caressed and waited on, might prove quite\r\na hard mistress in domestic life. Marie never had possessed much\r\ncapability of affection, or much sensibility, and the little that she\r\nhad, had been merged into a most intense and unconscious selfishness; a\r\nselfishness the more hopeless, from its quiet obtuseness, its utter\r\nignorance of any claims but her own. From her infancy, she had been\r\nsurrounded with servants, who lived only to study her caprices; the\r\nidea that they had either feelings or rights had never dawned upon her,\r\neven in distant perspective. Her father, whose only child she had been,\r\nhad never denied her anything that lay within the compass of human\r\npossibility; and when she entered life, beautiful, accomplished, and an\r\nheiress, she had, of course, all the eligibles and non-eligibles of the\r\nother sex sighing at her feet, and she had no doubt that Augustine was\r\na most fortunate man in having obtained her. It is a great mistake to\r\nsuppose that a woman with no heart will be an easy creditor in the\r\nexchange of affection. There is not on earth a more merciless exactor\r\nof love from others than a thoroughly selfish woman; and the more\r\nunlovely she grows, the more jealously and scrupulously she exacts\r\nlove, to the uttermost farthing. When, therefore, St. Clare began to\r\ndrop off those gallantries and small attentions which flowed at first\r\nthrough the habitude of courtship, he found his sultana no way ready to\r\nresign her slave; there were abundance of tears, poutings, and small\r\ntempests, there were discontents, pinings, upbraidings. St. Clare was\r\ngood-natured and self-indulgent, and sought to buy off with presents\r\nand flatteries; and when Marie became mother to a beautiful daughter,\r\nhe really felt awakened, for a time, to something like tenderness.\r\n\r\nSt. Clare\xe2\x80\x99s mother had been a woman of uncommon elevation and purity of\r\ncharacter, and he gave to his child his mother\xe2\x80\x99s name, fondly fancying\r\nthat she would prove a reproduction of her image. The thing had been\r\nremarked with petulant jealousy by his wife, and she regarded her\r\nhusband\xe2\x80\x99s absorbing devotion to the child with suspicion and dislike;\r\nall that was given to her seemed so much taken from herself. From the\r\ntime of the birth of this child, her health gradually sunk. A life of\r\nconstant inaction, bodily and mental,\xe2\x80\x94the friction of ceaseless ennui\r\nand discontent, united to the ordinary weakness which attended the\r\nperiod of maternity,\xe2\x80\x94in course of a few years changed the blooming\r\nyoung belle into a yellow faded, sickly woman, whose time was divided\r\namong a variety of fanciful diseases, and who considered herself, in\r\nevery sense, the most ill-used and suffering person in existence.\r\n\r\nThere was no end of her various complaints; but her principal forte\r\nappeared to lie in sick-headache, which sometimes would confine her to\r\nher room three days out of six. As, of course, all family arrangements\r\nfell into the hands of servants, St. Clare found his menage anything\r\nbut comfortable. His only daughter was exceedingly delicate, and he\r\nfeared that, with no one to look after her and attend to her, her\r\nhealth and life might yet fall a sacrifice to her mother\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ninefficiency. He had taken her with him on a tour to Vermont, and had\r\npersuaded his cousin, Miss Ophelia St. Clare, to return with him to his\r\nsouthern residence; and they are now returning on this boat, where we\r\nhave introduced them to our readers.\r\n\r\nAnd now, while the distant domes and spires of New Orleans rise to our\r\nview, there is yet time for an introduction to Miss Ophelia.\r\n\r\nWhoever has travelled in the New England States will remember, in some\r\ncool village, the large farmhouse, with its clean-swept grassy yard,\r\nshaded by the dense and massive foliage of the sugar maple; and\r\nremember the air of order and stillness, of perpetuity and unchanging\r\nrepose, that seemed to breathe over the whole place. Nothing lost, or\r\nout of order; not a picket loose in the fence, not a particle of litter\r\nin the turfy yard, with its clumps of lilac bushes growing up under the\r\nwindows. Within, he will remember wide, clean rooms, where nothing ever\r\nseems to be doing or going to be done, where everything is once and\r\nforever rigidly in place, and where all household arrangements move\r\nwith the punctual exactness of the old clock in the corner. In the\r\nfamily \xe2\x80\x9ckeeping-room,\xe2\x80\x9d as it is termed, he will remember the staid,\r\nrespectable old book-case, with its glass doors, where Rollin\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nHistory,[1] Milton\xe2\x80\x99s Paradise Lost, Bunyan\xe2\x80\x99s Pilgrim\xe2\x80\x99s Progress, and\r\nScott\xe2\x80\x99s Family Bible,[2] stand side by side in decorous order, with\r\nmultitudes of other books, equally solemn and respectable. There are no\r\nservants in the house, but the lady in the snowy cap, with the\r\nspectacles, who sits sewing every afternoon among her daughters, as if\r\nnothing ever had been done, or were to be done,\xe2\x80\x94she and her girls, in\r\nsome long-forgotten fore part of the day, \xe2\x80\x9c_did up the work_,\xe2\x80\x9d and for\r\nthe rest of the time, probably, at all hours when you would see them,\r\nit is \xe2\x80\x9c_done up_.\xe2\x80\x9d The old kitchen floor never seems stained or\r\nspotted; the tables, the chairs, and the various cooking utensils,\r\nnever seem deranged or disordered; though three and sometimes four\r\nmeals a day are got there, though the family washing and ironing is\r\nthere performed, and though pounds of butter and cheese are in some\r\nsilent and mysterious manner there brought into existence.\r\n\r\n [1] _The Ancient History_, ten volumes (1730-1738), by the French\r\n historian Charles Rollin (1661-1741).\r\n\r\n\r\n [2] _Scott\xe2\x80\x99s Family Bible_ (1788-1792), edited with notes by the\r\n English Biblical commentator, Thomas Scott (1747-1821).\r\n\r\n\r\nOn such a farm, in such a house and family, Miss Ophelia had spent a\r\nquiet existence of some forty-five years, when her cousin invited her\r\nto visit his southern mansion. The eldest of a large family, she was\r\nstill considered by her father and mother as one of \xe2\x80\x9cthe children,\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\nthe proposal that she should go to _Orleans_ was a most momentous one\r\nto the family circle. The old gray-headed father took down Morse\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nAtlas[3] out of the book-case, and looked out the exact latitude and\r\nlongitude; and read Flint\xe2\x80\x99s Travels in the South and West,[4] to make\r\nup his own mind as to the nature of the country.\r\n\r\n [3] _The Cerographic Atlas of the United States_ (1842-1845), by\r\n Sidney Edwards Morse (1794-1871), son of the geographer, Jedidiah\r\n Morse, and brother of the painter-inventor, Samuel F. B. Morse.\r\n\r\n\r\n [4] _Recollections of the Last Ten Years_ (1826) by Timothy Flint\r\n (1780-1840), missionary of Presbyterianism to the trans-Allegheny\r\n West.\r\n\r\n\r\nThe good mother inquired, anxiously, \xe2\x80\x9cif Orleans wasn\xe2\x80\x99t an awful wicked\r\nplace,\xe2\x80\x9d saying, \xe2\x80\x9cthat it seemed to her most equal to going to the\r\nSandwich Islands, or anywhere among the heathen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was known at the minister\xe2\x80\x99s and at the doctor\xe2\x80\x99s, and at Miss\r\nPeabody\xe2\x80\x99s milliner shop, that Ophelia St. Clare was \xe2\x80\x9ctalking about\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ngoing away down to Orleans with her cousin; and of course the whole\r\nvillage could do no less than help this very important process of\r\n_talking about_ the matter. The minister, who inclined strongly to\r\nabolitionist views, was quite doubtful whether such a step might not\r\ntend somewhat to encourage the southerners in holding on to their\r\nslaves; while the doctor, who was a stanch colonizationist, inclined to\r\nthe opinion that Miss Ophelia ought to go, to show the Orleans people\r\nthat we don\xe2\x80\x99t think hardly of them, after all. He was of opinion, in\r\nfact, that southern people needed encouraging. When however, the fact\r\nthat she had resolved to go was fully before the public mind, she was\r\nsolemnly invited out to tea by all her friends and neighbors for the\r\nspace of a fortnight, and her prospects and plans duly canvassed and\r\ninquired into. Miss Moseley, who came into the house to help to do the\r\ndress-making, acquired daily accessions of importance from the\r\ndevelopments with regard to Miss Ophelia\xe2\x80\x99s wardrobe which she had been\r\nenabled to make. It was credibly ascertained that Squire Sinclare, as\r\nhis name was commonly contracted in the neighborhood, had counted out\r\nfifty dollars, and given them to Miss Ophelia, and told her to buy any\r\nclothes she thought best; and that two new silk dresses, and a bonnet,\r\nhad been sent for from Boston. As to the propriety of this\r\nextraordinary outlay, the public mind was divided,\xe2\x80\x94some affirming that\r\nit was well enough, all things considered, for once in one\xe2\x80\x99s life, and\r\nothers stoutly affirming that the money had better have been sent to\r\nthe missionaries; but all parties agreed that there had been no such\r\nparasol seen in those parts as had been sent on from New York, and that\r\nshe had one silk dress that might fairly be trusted to stand alone,\r\nwhatever might be said of its mistress. There were credible rumors,\r\nalso, of a hemstitched pocket-handkerchief; and report even went so far\r\nas to state that Miss Ophelia had one pocket-handkerchief with lace all\r\naround it,\xe2\x80\x94it was even added that it was worked in the corners; but\r\nthis latter point was never satisfactorily ascertained, and remains, in\r\nfact, unsettled to this day.\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia, as you now behold her, stands before you, in a very\r\nshining brown linen travelling-dress, tall, square-formed, and angular.\r\nHer face was thin, and rather sharp in its outlines; the lips\r\ncompressed, like those of a person who is in the habit of making up her\r\nmind definitely on all subjects; while the keen, dark eyes had a\r\npeculiarly searching, advised movement, and travelled over everything,\r\nas if they were looking for something to take care of.\r\n\r\nAll her movements were sharp, decided, and energetic; and, though she\r\nwas never much of a talker, her words were remarkably direct, and to\r\nthe purpose, when she did speak.\r\n\r\nIn her habits, she was a living impersonation of order, method, and\r\nexactness.
