In punctuality, she was as inevitable as a clock, and as\r\ninexorable as a railroad engine; and she held in most decided contempt\r\nand abomination anything of a contrary character.\r\n\r\nThe great sin of sins, in her eyes,\xe2\x80\x94the sum of all evils,\xe2\x80\x94was expressed\r\nby one very common and important word in her\r\nvocabulary\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cshiftlessness.\xe2\x80\x9d Her finale and ultimatum of contempt\r\nconsisted in a very emphatic pronunciation of the word \xe2\x80\x9cshiftless;\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\nby this she characterized all modes of procedure which had not a direct\r\nand inevitable relation to accomplishment of some purpose then\r\ndefinitely had in mind. People who did nothing, or who did not know\r\nexactly what they were going to do, or who did not take the most direct\r\nway to accomplish what they set their hands to, were objects of her\r\nentire contempt,\xe2\x80\x94a contempt shown less frequently by anything she said,\r\nthan by a kind of stony grimness, as if she scorned to say anything\r\nabout the matter.\r\n\r\nAs to mental cultivation,\xe2\x80\x94she had a clear, strong, active mind, was\r\nwell and thoroughly read in history and the older English classics, and\r\nthought with great strength within certain narrow limits. Her\r\ntheological tenets were all made up, labelled in most positive and\r\ndistinct forms, and put by, like the bundles in her patch trunk; there\r\nwere just so many of them, and there were never to be any more. So,\r\nalso, were her ideas with regard to most matters of practical\r\nlife,\xe2\x80\x94such as housekeeping in all its branches, and the various\r\npolitical relations of her native village. And, underlying all, deeper\r\nthan anything else, higher and broader, lay the strongest principle of\r\nher being\xe2\x80\x94conscientiousness. Nowhere is conscience so dominant and\r\nall-absorbing as with New England women. It is the granite formation,\r\nwhich lies deepest, and rises out, even to the tops of the highest\r\nmountains.\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia was the absolute bond-slave of the \xe2\x80\x9c_ought_.\xe2\x80\x9d Once make\r\nher certain that the \xe2\x80\x9cpath of duty,\xe2\x80\x9d as she commonly phrased it, lay in\r\nany given direction, and fire and water could not keep her from it. She\r\nwould walk straight down into a well, or up to a loaded cannon\xe2\x80\x99s mouth,\r\nif she were only quite sure that there the path lay. Her standard of\r\nright was so high, so all-embracing, so minute, and making so few\r\nconcessions to human frailty, that, though she strove with heroic ardor\r\nto reach it, she never actually did so, and of course was burdened with\r\na constant and often harassing sense of deficiency;\xe2\x80\x94this gave a severe\r\nand somewhat gloomy cast to her religious character.\r\n\r\nBut, how in the world can Miss Ophelia get along with Augustine St.\r\nClare,\xe2\x80\x94gay, easy, unpunctual, unpractical, sceptical,\xe2\x80\x94in short,\xe2\x80\x94walking\r\nwith impudent and nonchalant freedom over every one of her most\r\ncherished habits and opinions?\r\n\r\nTo tell the truth, then, Miss Ophelia loved him. When a boy, it had\r\nbeen hers to teach him his catechism, mend his clothes, comb his hair,\r\nand bring him up generally in the way he should go; and her heart\r\nhaving a warm side to it, Augustine had, as he usually did with most\r\npeople, monopolized a large share of it for himself, and therefore it\r\nwas that he succeeded very easily in persuading her that the \xe2\x80\x9cpath of\r\nduty\xe2\x80\x9d lay in the direction of New Orleans, and that she must go with\r\nhim to take care of Eva, and keep everything from going to wreck and\r\nruin during the frequent illnesses of his wife. The idea of a house\r\nwithout anybody to take care of it went to her heart; then she loved\r\nthe lovely little girl, as few could help doing; and though she\r\nregarded Augustine as very much of a heathen, yet she loved him,\r\nlaughed at his jokes, and forbore with his failings, to an extent which\r\nthose who knew him thought perfectly incredible. But what more or other\r\nis to be known of Miss Ophelia our reader must discover by a personal\r\nacquaintance.\r\n\r\nThere she is, sitting now in her state-room, surrounded by a mixed\r\nmultitude of little and big carpet-bags, boxes, baskets, each\r\ncontaining some separate responsibility which she is tying, binding up,\r\npacking, or fastening, with a face of great earnestness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, Eva, have you kept count of your things? Of course you\r\nhaven\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x94children never do: there\xe2\x80\x99s the spotted carpet-bag and the\r\nlittle blue band-box with your best bonnet,\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s two; then the India\r\nrubber satchel is three; and my tape and needle box is four; and my\r\nband-box, five; and my collar-box; and that little hair trunk, seven.\r\nWhat have you done with your sunshade? Give it to me, and let me put a\r\npaper round it, and tie it to my umbrella with my shade;\xe2\x80\x94there, now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, aunty, we are only going up home;\xe2\x80\x94what is the use?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo keep it nice, child; people must take care of their things, if they\r\never mean to have anything; and now, Eva, is your thimble put up?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally, aunty, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, never mind; I\xe2\x80\x99ll look your box over,\xe2\x80\x94thimble, wax, two spools,\r\nscissors, knife, tape-needle; all right,\xe2\x80\x94put it in here. What did you\r\never do, child, when you were coming on with only your papa. I should\r\nhave thought you\xe2\x80\x99d a lost everything you had.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, aunty, I did lose a great many; and then, when we stopped\r\nanywhere, papa would buy some more of whatever it was.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMercy on us, child,\xe2\x80\x94what a way!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was a very easy way, aunty,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a dreadful shiftless one,\xe2\x80\x9d said aunty.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, aunty, what\xe2\x80\x99ll you do now?\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva; \xe2\x80\x9cthat trunk is too full to\r\nbe shut down.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt _must_ shut down,\xe2\x80\x9d said aunty, with the air of a general, as she\r\nsqueezed the things in, and sprung upon the lid;\xe2\x80\x94still a little gap\r\nremained about the mouth of the trunk.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGet up here, Eva!\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, courageously; \xe2\x80\x9cwhat has been\r\ndone can be done again. This trunk has _got to be_ shut and\r\nlocked\xe2\x80\x94there are no two ways about it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd the trunk, intimidated, doubtless, by this resolute statement, gave\r\nin. The hasp snapped sharply in its hole, and Miss Ophelia turned the\r\nkey, and pocketed it in triumph.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow we\xe2\x80\x99re ready. Where\xe2\x80\x99s your papa? I think it time this baggage was\r\nset out. Do look out, Eva, and see if you see your papa.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, yes, he\xe2\x80\x99s down the other end of the gentlemen\xe2\x80\x99s cabin, eating an\r\norange.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe can\xe2\x80\x99t know how near we are coming,\xe2\x80\x9d said aunty; \xe2\x80\x9chadn\xe2\x80\x99t you better\r\nrun and speak to him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPapa never is in a hurry about anything,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva, \xe2\x80\x9cand we haven\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ncome to the landing. Do step on the guards, aunty. Look! there\xe2\x80\x99s our\r\nhouse, up that street!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe boat now began, with heavy groans, like some vast, tired monster,\r\nto prepare to push up among the multiplied steamers at the levee. Eva\r\njoyously pointed out the various spires, domes, and way-marks, by which\r\nshe recognized her native city.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, dear; very fine,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia. \xe2\x80\x9cBut mercy on us! the\r\nboat has stopped! where is your father?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd now ensued the usual turmoil of landing\xe2\x80\x94waiters running twenty ways\r\nat once\xe2\x80\x94men tugging trunks, carpet-bags, boxes\xe2\x80\x94women anxiously calling\r\nto their children, and everybody crowding in a dense mass to the plank\r\ntowards the landing.\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia seated herself resolutely on the lately vanquished trunk,\r\nand marshalling all her goods and chattels in fine military order,\r\nseemed resolved to defend them to the last.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall I take your trunk, ma\xe2\x80\x99am?\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cShall I take your baggage?\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cLet me\r\n\xe2\x80\x99tend to your baggage, Missis?\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cShan\xe2\x80\x99t I carry out these yer, Missis?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nrained down upon her unheeded. She sat with grim determination, upright\r\nas a darning-needle stuck in a board, holding on her bundle of umbrella\r\nand parasols, and replying with a determination that was enough to\r\nstrike dismay even into a hackman, wondering to Eva, in each interval,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwhat upon earth her papa could be thinking of; he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t have fallen\r\nover, now,\xe2\x80\x94but something must have happened;\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and just as she had begun\r\nto work herself into a real distress, he came up, with his usually\r\ncareless motion, and giving Eva a quarter of the orange he was eating,\r\nsaid,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Cousin Vermont, I suppose you are all ready.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been ready, waiting, nearly an hour,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia; \xe2\x80\x9cI began\r\nto be really concerned about you.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s a clever fellow, now,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, the carriage is waiting,\r\nand the crowd are now off, so that one can walk out in a decent and\r\nChristian manner, and not be pushed and shoved. Here,\xe2\x80\x9d he added to a\r\ndriver who stood behind him, \xe2\x80\x9ctake these things.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll go and see to his putting them in,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, pshaw, cousin, what\xe2\x80\x99s the use?\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, at any rate, I\xe2\x80\x99ll carry this, and this, and this,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss\r\nOphelia, singling out three boxes and a small carpet-bag.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Miss Vermont, positively you mustn\xe2\x80\x99t come the Green Mountains\r\nover us that way. You must adopt at least a piece of a southern\r\nprinciple, and not walk out under all that load. They\xe2\x80\x99ll take you for a\r\nwaiting-maid; give them to this fellow; he\xe2\x80\x99ll put them down as if they\r\nwere eggs, now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia looked despairingly as her cousin took all her treasures\r\nfrom her, and rejoiced to find herself once more in the carriage with\r\nthem, in a state of preservation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere\xe2\x80\x99s Tom?\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, he\xe2\x80\x99s on the outside, Pussy. I\xe2\x80\x99m going to take Tom up to mother for\r\na peace-offering, to make up for that drunken fellow that upset the\r\ncarriage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Tom will make a splendid driver, I know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva; \xe2\x80\x9che\xe2\x80\x99ll never\r\nget drunk.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe carriage stopped in front of an ancient mansion, built in that odd\r\nmixture of Spanish and French style, of which there are specimens in\r\nsome parts of New Orleans. It was built in the Moorish fashion,\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nsquare building enclosing a court-yard, into which the carriage drove\r\nthrough an arched gateway. The court, in the inside, had evidently been\r\narranged to gratify a picturesque and voluptuous ideality. Wide\r\ngalleries ran all around the four sides, whose Moorish arches, slender\r\npillars, and arabesque ornaments, carried the mind back, as in a dream,\r\nto the reign of oriental romance in Spain. In the middle of the court,\r\na fountain threw high its silvery water, falling in a never-ceasing\r\nspray into a marble basin, fringed with a deep border of fragrant\r\nviolets. The water in the fountain, pellucid as crystal, was alive with\r\nmyriads of gold and silver fishes, twinkling and darting through it\r\nlike so many living jewels. Around the fountain ran a walk, paved with\r\na mosaic of pebbles, laid in various fanciful patterns; and this,\r\nagain, was surrounded by turf, smooth as green velvet, while a\r\ncarriage-drive enclosed the whole. Two large orange-trees, now fragrant\r\nwith blossoms, threw a delicious shade; and, ranged in a circle round\r\nupon the turf, were marble vases of arabesque sculpture, containing the\r\nchoicest flowering plants of the tropics. Huge pomegranate trees, with\r\ntheir glossy leaves and flame-colored flowers, dark-leaved Arabian\r\njessamines, with their silvery stars, geraniums, luxuriant roses\r\nbending beneath their heavy abundance of flowers, golden jessamines,\r\nlemon-scented verbenum, all united their bloom and fragrance, while\r\nhere and there a mystic old aloe, with its strange, massive leaves, sat\r\nlooking like some old enchanter, sitting in weird grandeur among the\r\nmore perishable bloom and fragrance around it.\r\n\r\nThe galleries that surrounded the court were festooned with a curtain\r\nof some kind of Moorish stuff, and could be drawn down at pleasure, to\r\nexclude the beams of the sun. On the whole, the appearance of the place\r\nwas luxurious and romantic.\r\n\r\nAs the carriage drove in, Eva seemed like a bird ready to burst from a\r\ncage, with the wild eagerness of her delight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it beautiful, lovely! my own dear, darling home!\xe2\x80\x9d she said to\r\nMiss Ophelia. \xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t it beautiful?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x99T is a pretty place,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, as she alighted; \xe2\x80\x9cthough it\r\nlooks rather old and heathenish to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom got down from the carriage, and looked about with an air of calm,\r\nstill enjoyment. The negro, it must be remembered, is an exotic of the\r\nmost gorgeous and superb countries of the world, and he has, deep in\r\nhis heart, a passion for all that is splendid, rich, and fanciful; a\r\npassion which, rudely indulged by an untrained taste, draws on them the\r\nridicule of the colder and more correct white race.\r\n\r\nSt. Clare, who was in heart a poetical voluptuary, smiled as Miss\r\nOphelia made her remark on his premises, and, turning to Tom, who was\r\nstanding looking round, his beaming black face perfectly radiant with\r\nadmiration, he said,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTom, my boy, this seems to suit you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r, it looks about the right thing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom.\r\n\r\nAll this passed in a moment, while trunks were being hustled off,\r\nhackman paid, and while a crowd, of all ages and sizes,\xe2\x80\x94men, women, and\r\nchildren,\xe2\x80\x94came running through the galleries, both above and below to\r\nsee Mas\xe2\x80\x99r come in. Foremost among them was a highly-dressed young\r\nmulatto man, evidently a very _distingue_ personage, attired in the\r\nultra extreme of the mode, and gracefully waving a scented cambric\r\nhandkerchief in his hand.\r\n\r\nThis personage had been exerting himself, with great alacrity, in\r\ndriving all the flock of domestics to the other end of the verandah.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBack! all of you. I am ashamed of you,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, in a tone of\r\nauthority. \xe2\x80\x9cWould you intrude on Master\xe2\x80\x99s domestic relations, in the\r\nfirst hour of his return?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAll looked abashed at this elegant speech, delivered with quite an air,\r\nand stood huddled together at a respectful distance, except two stout\r\nporters, who came up and began conveying away the baggage.\r\n\r\nOwing to Mr. Adolph\xe2\x80\x99s systematic arrangements, when St. Clare turned\r\nround from paying the hackman, there was nobody in view but Mr. Adolph\r\nhimself, conspicuous in satin vest, gold guard-chain, and white pants,\r\nand bowing with inexpressible grace and suavity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, Adolph, is it you?\xe2\x80\x9d said his master, offering his hand to him;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9chow are you, boy?\xe2\x80\x9d while Adolph poured forth, with great fluency, an\r\nextemporary speech, which he had been preparing, with great care, for a\r\nfortnight before.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, well,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, passing on, with his usual air of\r\nnegligent drollery, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s very well got up, Adolph. See that the\r\nbaggage is well bestowed. I\xe2\x80\x99ll come to the people in a minute;\xe2\x80\x9d and, so\r\nsaying, he led Miss Ophelia to a large parlor that opened on the\r\nverandah.\r\n\r\nWhile this had been passing, Eva had flown like a bird, through the\r\nporch and parlor, to a little boudoir opening likewise on the verandah.\r\n\r\nA tall, dark-eyed, sallow woman, half rose from a couch on which she\r\nwas reclining.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMamma!\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva, in a sort of a rapture, throwing herself on her\r\nneck, and embracing her over and over again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99ll do,\xe2\x80\x94take care, child,\xe2\x80\x94don\xe2\x80\x99t, you make my head ache,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nmother, after she had languidly kissed her.\r\n\r\nSt. Clare came in, embraced his wife in true, orthodox, husbandly\r\nfashion, and then presented to her his cousin. Marie lifted her large\r\neyes on her cousin with an air of some curiosity, and received her with\r\nlanguid politeness. A crowd of servants now pressed to the entry door,\r\nand among them a middle-aged mulatto woman, of very respectable\r\nappearance, stood foremost, in a tremor of expectation and joy, at the\r\ndoor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, there\xe2\x80\x99s Mammy!\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva, as she flew across the room; and,\r\nthrowing herself into her arms, she kissed her repeatedly.\r\n\r\nThis woman did not tell her that she made her head ache, but, on the\r\ncontrary, she hugged her, and laughed, and cried, till her sanity was a\r\nthing to be doubted of; and when released from her, Eva flew from one\r\nto another, shaking hands and kissing, in a way that Miss Ophelia\r\nafterwards declared fairly turned her stomach.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell!\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, \xe2\x80\x9cyou southern children can do something that\r\n_I_ couldn\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, now, pray?\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I want to be kind to everybody, and I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have anything\r\nhurt; but as to kissing\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNiggers,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you\xe2\x80\x99re not up to,\xe2\x80\x94hey?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, that\xe2\x80\x99s it. How can she?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSt. Clare laughed, as he went into the passage. \xe2\x80\x9cHalloa, here, what\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nto pay out here? Here, you all\xe2\x80\x94Mammy, Jimmy, Polly, Sukey\xe2\x80\x94glad to see\r\nMas\xe2\x80\x99r?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, as he went shaking hands from one to another. \xe2\x80\x9cLook\r\nout for the babies!\xe2\x80\x9d he added, as he stumbled over a sooty little\r\nurchin, who was crawling upon all fours. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I step upon anybody, let\r\n\xe2\x80\x99em mention it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was an abundance of laughing and blessing Mas\xe2\x80\x99r, as St. Clare\r\ndistributed small pieces of change among them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, now, take yourselves off, like good boys and girls,\xe2\x80\x9d he said;\r\nand the whole assemblage, dark and light, disappeared through a door\r\ninto a large verandah, followed by Eva, who carried a large satchel,\r\nwhich she had been filling with apples, nuts, candy, ribbons, laces,\r\nand toys of every description, during her whole homeward journey.\r\n\r\nAs St. Clare turned to go back his eye fell upon Tom, who was standing\r\nuneasily, shifting from one foot to the other, while Adolph stood\r\nnegligently leaning against the banisters, examining Tom through an\r\nopera-glass, with an air that would have done credit to any dandy\r\nliving.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPuh! you puppy,\xe2\x80\x9d said his master, striking down the opera glass; \xe2\x80\x9cis\r\nthat the way you treat your company? Seems to me, Dolph,\xe2\x80\x9d he added,\r\nlaying his finger on the elegant figured satin vest that Adolph was\r\nsporting, \xe2\x80\x9cseems to me that\xe2\x80\x99s _my_ vest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO! Master, this vest all stained with wine; of course, a gentleman in\r\nMaster\xe2\x80\x99s standing never wears a vest like this. I understood I was to\r\ntake it. It does for a poor nigger-fellow, like me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd Adolph tossed his head, and passed his fingers through his scented\r\nhair, with a grace.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo, that\xe2\x80\x99s it, is it?\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, carelessly. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, here, I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\ngoing to show this Tom to his mistress, and then you take him to the\r\nkitchen; and mind you don\xe2\x80\x99t put on any of your airs to him. He\xe2\x80\x99s worth\r\ntwo such puppies as you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMaster always will have his joke,\xe2\x80\x9d said Adolph, laughing. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m\r\ndelighted to see Master in such spirits.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere, Tom,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, beckoning.\r\n\r\nTom entered the room. He looked wistfully on the velvet carpets, and\r\nthe before unimagined splendors of mirrors, pictures, statues, and\r\ncurtains, and, like the Queen of Sheba before Solomon, there was no\r\nmore spirit in him. He looked afraid even to set his feet down.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee here, Marie,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare to his wife, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve bought you a\r\ncoachman, at last, to order. I tell you, he\xe2\x80\x99s a regular hearse for\r\nblackness and sobriety, and will drive you like a funeral, if you want.\r\nOpen your eyes, now, and look at him. Now, don\xe2\x80\x99t say I never think\r\nabout you when I\xe2\x80\x99m gone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMarie opened her eyes, and fixed them on Tom, without rising.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know he\xe2\x80\x99ll get drunk,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, he\xe2\x80\x99s warranted a pious and sober article.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I hope he may turn out well,\xe2\x80\x9d said the lady; \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s more than I\r\nexpect, though.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDolph,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, \xe2\x80\x9cshow Tom down stairs; and, mind yourself,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nadded; \xe2\x80\x9cremember what I told you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAdolph tripped gracefully forward, and Tom, with lumbering tread, went\r\nafter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s a perfect behemoth!\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, now, Marie,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, seating himself on a stool beside\r\nher sofa, \xe2\x80\x9cbe gracious, and say something pretty to a fellow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve been gone a fortnight beyond the time,\xe2\x80\x9d said the lady, pouting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you know I wrote you the reason.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuch a short, cold letter!\xe2\x80\x9d said the lady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear me! the mail was just going, and it had to be that or nothing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s just the way, always,\xe2\x80\x9d said the lady; \xe2\x80\x9calways something to make\r\nyour journeys long, and letters short.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee here, now,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, drawing an elegant velvet case out of his\r\npocket, and opening it, \xe2\x80\x9chere\xe2\x80\x99s a present I got for you in New York.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was a daguerreotype, clear and soft as an engraving, representing\r\nEva and her father sitting hand in hand.\r\n\r\nMarie looked at it with a dissatisfied air.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat made you sit in such an awkward position?\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, the position may be a matter of opinion; but what do you think\r\nof the likeness?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you don\xe2\x80\x99t think anything of my opinion in one case, I suppose you\r\nwouldn\xe2\x80\x99t in another,\xe2\x80\x9d said the lady, shutting the daguerreotype.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHang the woman!\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, mentally; but aloud he added, \xe2\x80\x9cCome,\r\nnow, Marie, what do you think of the likeness? Don\xe2\x80\x99t be nonsensical,\r\nnow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s very inconsiderate of you, St. Clare,\xe2\x80\x9d said the lady, \xe2\x80\x9cto insist\r\non my talking and looking at things. You know I\xe2\x80\x99ve been lying all day\r\nwith the sick-headache; and there\xe2\x80\x99s been such a tumult made ever since\r\nyou came, I\xe2\x80\x99m half dead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re subject to the sick-headache, ma\xe2\x80\x99am!\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia,\r\nsuddenly rising from the depths of the large arm-chair, where she had\r\nsat quietly, taking an inventory of the furniture, and calculating its\r\nexpense.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I\xe2\x80\x99m a perfect martyr to it,\xe2\x80\x9d said the lady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJuniper-berry tea is good for sick-headache,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia; \xe2\x80\x9cat\r\nleast, Auguste, Deacon Abraham Perry\xe2\x80\x99s wife, used to say so; and she\r\nwas a great nurse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll have the first juniper-berries that get ripe in our garden by the\r\nlake brought in for that special purpose,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, gravely\r\npulling the bell as he did so; \xe2\x80\x9cmeanwhile, cousin, you must be wanting\r\nto retire to your apartment, and refresh yourself a little, after your\r\njourney. Dolph,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, \xe2\x80\x9ctell Mammy to come here.\xe2\x80\x9d The decent\r\nmulatto woman whom Eva had caressed so rapturously soon entered; she\r\nwas dressed neatly, with a high red and yellow turban on her head, the\r\nrecent gift of Eva, and which the child had been arranging on her head.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMammy,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, \xe2\x80\x9cI put this lady under your care; she is\r\ntired, and wants rest; take her to her chamber, and be sure she is made\r\ncomfortable,\xe2\x80\x9d and Miss Ophelia disappeared in the rear of Mammy.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XVI\r\nTom\xe2\x80\x99s Mistress and Her Opinions\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now, Marie,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, \xe2\x80\x9cyour golden days are dawning. Here\r\nis our practical, business-like New England cousin, who will take the\r\nwhole budget of cares off your shoulders, and give you time to refresh\r\nyourself, and grow young and handsome. The ceremony of delivering the\r\nkeys had better come off forthwith.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis remark was made at the breakfast-table, a few mornings after Miss\r\nOphelia had arrived.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sure she\xe2\x80\x99s welcome,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie, leaning her head languidly on her\r\nhand. \xe2\x80\x9cI think she\xe2\x80\x99ll find one thing, if she does, and that is, that\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99s we mistresses that are the slaves, down here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, certainly, she will discover that, and a world of wholesome truths\r\nbesides, no doubt,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTalk about our keeping slaves, as if we did it for our _convenience_,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Marie. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sure, if we consulted _that_, we might let them all go\r\nat once.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEvangeline fixed her large, serious eyes on her mother\xe2\x80\x99s face, with an\r\nearnest and perplexed expression, and said, simply, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you keep\r\nthem for, mamma?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure, except for a plague; they are the plague of my\r\nlife. I believe that more of my ill health is caused by them than by\r\nany one thing; and ours, I know, are the very worst that ever anybody\r\nwas plagued with.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, come, Marie, you\xe2\x80\x99ve got the blues, this morning,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know \xe2\x80\x99t isn\xe2\x80\x99t so. There\xe2\x80\x99s Mammy, the best creature living,\xe2\x80\x94what\r\ncould you do without her?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMammy is the best I ever knew,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie; \xe2\x80\x9cand yet Mammy, now, is\r\nselfish\xe2\x80\x94dreadfully selfish; it\xe2\x80\x99s the fault of the whole race.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSelfishness _is_ a dreadful fault,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, gravely.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now, there\xe2\x80\x99s Mammy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie, \xe2\x80\x9cI think it\xe2\x80\x99s selfish of her to\r\nsleep so sound nights; she knows I need little attentions almost every\r\nhour, when my worst turns are on, and yet she\xe2\x80\x99s so hard to wake. I\r\nabsolutely am worse, this very morning, for the efforts I had to make\r\nto wake her last night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHasn\xe2\x80\x99t she sat up with you a good many nights, lately, mamma?\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nEva.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow should you know that?\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie, sharply; \xe2\x80\x9cshe\xe2\x80\x99s been\r\ncomplaining, I suppose.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe didn\xe2\x80\x99t complain; she only told me what bad nights you\xe2\x80\x99d had,\xe2\x80\x94so\r\nmany in succession.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy don\xe2\x80\x99t you let Jane or Rosa take her place, a night or two,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nSt. Clare, \xe2\x80\x9cand let her rest?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow can you propose it?\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie. \xe2\x80\x9cSt. Clare, you really are\r\ninconsiderate. So nervous as I am, the least breath disturbs me; and a\r\nstrange hand about me would drive me absolutely frantic. If Mammy felt\r\nthe interest in me she ought to, she\xe2\x80\x99d wake easier,\xe2\x80\x94of course, she\r\nwould. I\xe2\x80\x99ve heard of people who had such devoted servants, but it never\r\nwas _my_ luck;\xe2\x80\x9d and Marie sighed.\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia had listened to this conversation with an air of shrewd,\r\nobservant gravity; and she still kept her lips tightly compressed, as\r\nif determined fully to ascertain her longitude and position, before she\r\ncommitted herself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, Mammy has a _sort_ of goodness,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie; \xe2\x80\x9cshe\xe2\x80\x99s smooth and\r\nrespectful, but she\xe2\x80\x99s selfish at heart. Now, she never will be done\r\nfidgeting and worrying about that husband of hers. You see, when I was\r\nmarried and came to live here, of course, I had to bring her with me,\r\nand her husband my father couldn\xe2\x80\x99t spare. He was a blacksmith, and, of\r\ncourse, very necessary; and I thought and said, at the time, that Mammy\r\nand he had better give each other up, as it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t likely to be\r\nconvenient for them ever to live together again. I wish, now, I\xe2\x80\x99d\r\ninsisted on it, and married Mammy to somebody else; but I was foolish\r\nand indulgent, and didn\xe2\x80\x99t want to insist. I told Mammy, at the time,\r\nthat she mustn\xe2\x80\x99t ever expect to see him more than once or twice in her\r\nlife again, for the air of father\xe2\x80\x99s place doesn\xe2\x80\x99t agree with my health,\r\nand I can\xe2\x80\x99t go there; and I advised her to take up with somebody else;\r\nbut no\xe2\x80\x94she wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t. I\xe2\x80\x99ve worked\r\nsometimes whole afternoons, trimming her caps, and getting her ready to\r\ngo to a party. As to abuse, she don\xe2\x80\x99t know what it is. She never was\r\nwhipped more than once or twice in her whole life. She has her strong\r\ncoffee or her tea every day, with white sugar in it. It\xe2\x80\x99s abominable,\r\nto be sure; but St. Clare will have high life below-stairs, and they\r\nevery one of them live just as they please. The fact is, our servants\r\nare over-indulged. I suppose it is partly our fault that they are\r\nselfish, and act like spoiled children; but I\xe2\x80\x99ve talked to St. Clare\r\ntill I am tired.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I, too,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, taking up the morning paper.\r\n\r\nEva, the beautiful Eva, had stood listening to her mother, with that\r\nexpression of deep and mystic earnestness which was peculiar to her.\r\nShe walked softly round to her mother\xe2\x80\x99s chair, and put her arms round\r\nher neck.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Eva, what now?\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMamma, couldn\xe2\x80\x99t I take care of you one night\xe2\x80\x94just one? I often lie awake\r\nnights, thinking\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, nonsense, child\xe2\x80\x94nonsense!\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie; \xe2\x80\x9cyou are such a strange\r\nchild!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut may I, mamma? Mammy is just like all the rest\r\nof them\xe2\x80\x94makes such a fuss about every little headache or finger-ache;\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99ll never do to encourage it\xe2\x80\x94never! I never complain myself\xe2\x80\x94nobody knows what I\r\nendure. I feel it a duty to bear it quietly, and I do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia\xe2\x80\x99s round eyes expressed an undisguised amazement at this\r\nperoration, which struck St. Clare as so supremely ludicrous, that he\r\nburst into a loud laugh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSt. Clare always laughs when I make the least allusion to my ill\r\nhealth,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie, with the voice of a suffering martyr. \xe2\x80\x9cI only hope\r\nthe day won\xe2\x80\x99t come when he\xe2\x80\x99ll remember it!\xe2\x80\x9d and Marie put her\r\nhandkerchief to her eyes.\r\n\r\nOf course, there was rather a foolish silence. Finally, St. Clare got\r\nup, looked at his watch, and said he had an engagement down street. Eva\r\ntripped away after him, and Miss Ophelia and Marie remained at the\r\ntable alone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, that\xe2\x80\x99s just like St. Clare!\xe2\x80\x9d said the latter, withdrawing her\r\nhandkerchief with somewhat of a spirited flourish when the criminal to\r\nbe affected by it was no longer in sight. \xe2\x80\x9cHe never realizes, never\r\ncan, never will, what I suffer, and have, for years. If I was one of\r\nthe complaining sort, or ever made any fuss about my ailments, there\r\nwould be some reason for it. Men do get tired, naturally, of a\r\ncomplaining wife. But I\xe2\x80\x99ve kept things to myself, and borne, and borne,\r\ntill St. Clare has got in the way of thinking I can bear anything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia did not exactly know what she was expected to answer to\r\nthis.\r\n\r\nWhile she was thinking what to say, Marie gradually wiped away her\r\ntears, and smoothed her plumage in a general sort of way, as a dove\r\nmight be supposed to make toilet after a shower, and began a\r\nhousewifely chat with Miss Ophelia, concerning cupboards, closets,\r\nlinen-presses, store-rooms, and other matters, of which the latter was,\r\nby common understanding, to assume the direction,\xe2\x80\x94giving her so many\r\ncautious directions and charges, that a head less systematic and\r\nbusiness-like than Miss Ophelia\xe2\x80\x99s would have been utterly dizzied and\r\nconfounded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie, \xe2\x80\x9cI believe I\xe2\x80\x99ve told you everything; so that,\r\nwhen my next sick turn comes on, you\xe2\x80\x99ll be able to go forward entirely,\r\nwithout consulting me;\xe2\x80\x94only about Eva,\xe2\x80\x94she requires watching.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe seems to be a good child, very,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia; \xe2\x80\x9cI never saw a\r\nbetter child.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEva\xe2\x80\x99s peculiar,\xe2\x80\x9d said her mother, \xe2\x80\x9cvery. Now, I always played with father\xe2\x80\x99s little\r\nnegroes\xe2\x80\x94it never did me any harm. But Eva somehow always seems to put\r\nherself on an equality with every creature that comes near her. It\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\nstrange thing about the child. I never have been able to break her of\r\nit. St. Clare, I believe, encourages her in it. The fact is, St. Clare\r\nindulges every creature under this roof but his own wife.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAgain Miss Ophelia sat in blank silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, there\xe2\x80\x99s no way with servants,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie, \xe2\x80\x9cbut to _put them\r\ndown_, and keep them down. It was always natural to me, from a child.\r\nEva is enough to spoil a whole house-full. What she will do when she\r\ncomes to keep house herself, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure I don\xe2\x80\x99t know. I hold to being\r\n_kind_ to servants\xe2\x80\x94I always am; but you must make \xe2\x80\x99em _know their\r\nplace_. Eva never does; there\xe2\x80\x99s no getting into the child\xe2\x80\x99s head the\r\nfirst beginning of an idea what a servant\xe2\x80\x99s place is! You heard her\r\noffering to take care of me nights, to let Mammy sleep! That\xe2\x80\x99s just a\r\nspecimen of the way the child would be doing all the time, if she was\r\nleft to herself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, bluntly, \xe2\x80\x9cI suppose you think your servants\r\nare human creatures, and ought to have some rest when they are tired.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly, of course. Mammy can make up her sleep, some time or\r\nother; there\xe2\x80\x99s no difficulty about that. She\xe2\x80\x99s the sleepiest concern\r\nthat ever I saw; sewing, standing, or sitting, that creature will go to\r\nsleep, and sleep anywhere and everywhere. No danger but Mammy gets\r\nsleep enough. But this treating servants as if they were exotic\r\nflowers, or china vases, is really ridiculous,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie, as she\r\nplunged languidly into the depths of a voluminous and pillowy lounge,\r\nand drew towards her an elegant cut-glass vinaigrette.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see,\xe2\x80\x9d she continued, in a faint and lady-like voice, like the last\r\ndying breath of an Arabian jessamine, or something equally ethereal,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cyou see, Cousin Ophelia, I don\xe2\x80\x99t often speak of myself. It isn\xe2\x80\x99t my\r\n_habit_; \xe2\x80\x99t isn\xe2\x80\x99t agreeable to me. In fact, I haven\xe2\x80\x99t strength to do\r\nit. But there are points where St. Clare and I differ. St. Clare never\r\nunderstood me, never appreciated me. I think it lies at the root of all\r\nmy ill health. St. Clare means well, I am bound to believe; but men are\r\nconstitutionally selfish and inconsiderate to woman. That, at least, is\r\nmy impression.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia, who had not a small share of the genuine New England\r\ncaution, and a very particular horror of being drawn into family\r\ndifficulties, now began to foresee something of this kind impending;\r\nso, composing her face into a grim neutrality, and drawing out of her\r\npocket about a yard and a quarter of stocking, which she kept as a\r\nspecific against what Dr. Watts asserts to be a personal habit of Satan\r\nwhen people have idle hands, she proceeded to knit most energetically,\r\nshutting her lips together in a way that said, as plain as words could,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou needn\xe2\x80\x99t try to make me speak. I don\xe2\x80\x99t want anything to do with\r\nyour affairs,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94in fact, she looked about as sympathizing as a stone\r\nlion. But Marie didn\xe2\x80\x99t care for that. She had got somebody to talk to,\r\nand she felt it her duty to talk, and that was enough; and reinforcing\r\nherself by smelling again at her vinaigrette, she went on.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see, I brought my own property and servants into the connection,\r\nwhen I married St. Clare, and I am legally entitled to manage them my\r\nown way. St. Clare had his fortune and his servants, and I\xe2\x80\x99m well\r\nenough content he should manage them his way; but St. Clare will be\r\ninterfering. He has wild, extravagant notions about things,\r\nparticularly about the treatment of servants. He really does act as if\r\nhe set his servants before me, and before himself, too; for he lets\r\nthem make him all sorts of trouble, and never lifts a finger. Now,\r\nabout some things, St. Clare is really frightful\xe2\x80\x94he frightens\r\nme\xe2\x80\x94good-natured as he looks, in general. Now, he has set down his foot\r\nthat, come what will, there shall not be a blow struck in this house,\r\nexcept what he or I strike; and he does it in a way that I really dare\r\nnot cross him. Well, you may see what that leads to; for St. Clare\r\nwouldn\xe2\x80\x99t raise his hand, if every one of them walked over him, and\r\nI\xe2\x80\x94you see how cruel it would be to require me to make the exertion.\r\nNow, you know these servants are nothing but grown-up children.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know anything about it, and I thank the Lord that I don\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Miss Ophelia, shortly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, but you will have to know something, and know it to your cost,\r\nif you stay here. You don\xe2\x80\x99t know what a provoking, stupid, careless,\r\nunreasonable, childish, ungrateful set of wretches they are.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMarie seemed wonderfully supported, always, when she got upon this\r\ntopic; and she now opened her eyes, and seemed quite to forget her\r\nlanguor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t know, and you can\xe2\x80\x99t, the daily, hourly trials that beset a\r\nhousekeeper from them, everywhere and every way. But it\xe2\x80\x99s no use to\r\ncomplain to St. Clare. He talks the strangest stuff. He says we have\r\nmade them what they are, and ought to bear with them. He says their\r\nfaults are all owing to us, and that it would be cruel to make the\r\nfault and punish it too. He says we shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t do any better, in their\r\nplace; just as if one could reason from them to us, you know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you believe that the Lord made them of one blood with us?\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nMiss Ophelia, shortly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, indeed not I! A pretty story, truly! They are a degraded race.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you think they\xe2\x80\x99ve got immortal souls?\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, with\r\nincreasing indignation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, well,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie, yawning, \xe2\x80\x9cthat, of course\xe2\x80\x94nobody doubts that.\r\nBut as to putting them on any sort of equality with us, you know, as if\r\nwe could be compared, why, it\xe2\x80\x99s impossible! Now, St. Clare really has\r\ntalked to me as if keeping Mammy from her husband was like keeping me\r\nfrom mine. There\xe2\x80\x99s no comparing in this way. Mammy couldn\xe2\x80\x99t have the\r\nfeelings that I should. It\xe2\x80\x99s a different thing altogether,\xe2\x80\x94of course,\r\nit is,\xe2\x80\x94and yet St. Clare pretends not to see it. And just as if Mammy\r\ncould love her little dirty babies as I love Eva! Yet St. Clare once\r\nreally and soberly tried to persuade me that it was my duty, with my\r\nweak health, and all I suffer, to let Mammy go back, and take somebody\r\nelse in her place. That was a little too much even for _me_ to bear. I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t often show my feelings, I make it a principle to endure\r\neverything in silence; it\xe2\x80\x99s a wife\xe2\x80\x99s hard lot, and I bear it. But I did\r\nbreak out, that time; so that he has never alluded to the subject\r\nsince. But I know by his looks, and little things that he says, that he\r\nthinks so as much as ever; and it\xe2\x80\x99s so trying, so provoking!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia looked very much as if she was afraid she should say\r\nsomething; but she rattled away with her needles in a way that had\r\nvolumes of meaning in it, if Marie could only have understood it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo, you just see,\xe2\x80\x9d she continued, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat you\xe2\x80\x99ve got to manage. A\r\nhousehold without any rule; where servants have it all their own way,\r\ndo what they please, and have what they please, except so far as I,\r\nwith my feeble health, have kept up government. I keep my cowhide\r\nabout, and sometimes I do lay it on; but the exertion is always too\r\nmuch for me. If St. Clare would only have this thing done as others\r\ndo\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how\xe2\x80\x99s that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, send them to the calaboose, or some of the other places to be\r\nflogged. That\xe2\x80\x99s the only way. If I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t such a poor, feeble piece, I\r\nbelieve I should manage with twice the energy that St. Clare does.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how does St. Clare contrive to manage?\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\r\nsay he never strikes a blow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, men have a more commanding way, you know; it is easier for them;\r\nbesides, if you ever looked full in his eye, it\xe2\x80\x99s peculiar,\xe2\x80\x94that\r\neye,\xe2\x80\x94and if he speaks decidedly, there\xe2\x80\x99s a kind of flash. I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid of\r\nit, myself; and the servants know they must mind. I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t do as much\r\nby a regular storm and scolding as St. Clare can by one turn of his\r\neye, if once he is in earnest. O, there\xe2\x80\x99s no trouble about St. Clare;\r\nthat\xe2\x80\x99s the reason he\xe2\x80\x99s no more feeling for me. But you\xe2\x80\x99ll find, when\r\nyou come to manage, that there\xe2\x80\x99s no getting along without\r\nseverity,\xe2\x80\x94they are so bad, so deceitful, so lazy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe old tune,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, sauntering in. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat an awful account\r\nthese wicked creatures will have to settle, at last, especially for\r\nbeing lazy! You see, cousin,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, as he stretched himself at full\r\nlength on a lounge opposite to Marie, \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s wholly inexcusable in them,\r\nin the light of the example that Marie and I set them,\xe2\x80\x94this laziness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, now, St. Clare, you are too bad!\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAm I, now? Why, I thought I was talking good, quite remarkably for me.\r\nI try to enforce your remarks, Marie, always.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know you meant no such thing, St. Clare,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, I must have been mistaken, then. Thank you, my dear, for setting me\r\nright.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do really try to be provoking,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, come, Marie, the day is growing warm, and I have just had a long\r\nquarrel with Dolph, which has fatigued me excessively; so, pray be\r\nagreeable, now, and let a fellow repose in the light of your smile.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter about Dolph?\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie. \xe2\x80\x9cThat fellow\xe2\x80\x99s impudence\r\nhas been growing to a point that is perfectly intolerable to me. I only\r\nwish I had the undisputed management of him a while. I\xe2\x80\x99d bring him\r\ndown!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat you say, my dear, is marked with your usual acuteness and good\r\nsense,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare. \xe2\x80\x9cAs to Dolph, the case is this: that he has so\r\nlong been engaged in imitating my graces and perfections, that he has,\r\nat last, really mistaken himself for his master; and I have been\r\nobliged to give him a little insight into his mistake.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow?\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, I was obliged to let him understand explicitly that I preferred\r\nto keep _some_ of my clothes for my own personal wearing; also, I put\r\nhis magnificence upon an allowance of cologne-water, and actually was\r\nso cruel as to restrict him to one dozen of my cambric handkerchiefs.\r\nDolph was particularly huffy about it, and I had to talk to him like a\r\nfather, to bring him round.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO! St. Clare, when will you learn how to treat your servants? It\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nabominable, the way you indulge them!\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, after all, what\xe2\x80\x99s the harm of the poor dog\xe2\x80\x99s wanting to be like\r\nhis master; and if I haven\xe2\x80\x99t brought him up any better than to find his\r\nchief good in cologne and cambric handkerchiefs, why shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t I give\r\nthem to him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd why haven\xe2\x80\x99t you brought him up better?\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, with\r\nblunt determination.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cToo much trouble,\xe2\x80\x94laziness, cousin, laziness,\xe2\x80\x94which ruins more souls\r\nthan you can shake a stick at. If it weren\xe2\x80\x99t for laziness, I should\r\nhave been a perfect angel, myself. I\xe2\x80\x99m inclined to think that laziness\r\nis what your old Dr. Botherem, up in Vermont, used to call the \xe2\x80\x98essence\r\nof moral evil.\xe2\x80\x99 It\xe2\x80\x99s an awful consideration, certainly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think you slaveholders have an awful responsibility upon you,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nMiss Ophelia. \xe2\x80\x9cI wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have it, for a thousand worlds. You ought to\r\neducate your slaves, and treat them like reasonable creatures,\xe2\x80\x94like\r\nimmortal creatures, that you\xe2\x80\x99ve got to stand before the bar of God\r\nwith. That\xe2\x80\x99s my mind,\xe2\x80\x9d said the good lady, breaking suddenly out with a\r\ntide of zeal that had been gaining strength in her mind all the\r\nmorning.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO! come, come,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, getting up quickly; \xe2\x80\x9cwhat do you know\r\nabout us?\xe2\x80\x9d And he sat down to the piano, and rattled a lively piece of\r\nmusic. St. Clare had a decided genius for music. His touch was\r\nbrilliant and firm, and his fingers flew over the keys with a rapid and\r\nbird-like motion, airy, and yet decided. He played piece after piece,\r\nlike a man who is trying to play himself into a good humor. After\r\npushing the music aside, he rose up, and said, gayly, \xe2\x80\x9cWell, now,\r\ncousin, you\xe2\x80\x99ve given us a good talk and done your duty; on the whole, I\r\nthink the better of you for it. I make no manner of doubt that you\r\nthrew a very diamond of truth at me, though you see it hit me so\r\ndirectly in the face that it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t exactly appreciated, at first.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor my part, I don\xe2\x80\x99t see any use in such sort of talk,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sure, if anybody does more for servants than we do, I\xe2\x80\x99d like to\r\nknow who; and it don\xe2\x80\x99t do \xe2\x80\x99em a bit good,\xe2\x80\x94not a particle,\xe2\x80\x94they get\r\nworse and worse. As to talking to them, or anything like that, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure\r\nI have talked till I was tired and hoarse, telling them their duty, and\r\nall that; and I\xe2\x80\x99m sure they can go to church when they like, though\r\nthey don\xe2\x80\x99t understand a word of the sermon, more than so many pigs,\xe2\x80\x94so\r\nit isn\xe2\x80\x99t of any great use for them to go, as I see; but they do go, and\r\nso they have every chance; but, as I said before, they are a degraded\r\nrace, and always will be, and there isn\xe2\x80\x99t any help for them; you can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nmake anything of them, if you try. You see, Cousin Ophelia, I\xe2\x80\x99ve tried,\r\nand you haven\xe2\x80\x99t; I was born and bred among them, and I know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia thought she had said enough, and therefore sat silent. St.\r\nClare whistled a tune.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSt. Clare, I wish you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t whistle,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie; \xe2\x80\x9cit makes my head\r\nworse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI won\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare. \xe2\x80\x9cIs there anything else you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t wish me\r\nto do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish you _would_ have some kind of sympathy for my trials; you never\r\nhave any feeling for me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear accusing angel!\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s provoking to be talked to in that way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, how will you be talked to? I\xe2\x80\x99ll talk to order,\xe2\x80\x94any way you\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nmention,\xe2\x80\x94only to give satisfaction.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA gay laugh from the court rang through the silken curtains of the\r\nverandah. St. Clare stepped out, and lifting up the curtain, laughed\r\ntoo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, coming to the railing.\r\n\r\nThere sat Tom, on a little mossy seat in the court, every one of his\r\nbutton-holes stuck full of cape jessamines, and Eva, gayly laughing,\r\nwas hanging a wreath of roses round his neck; and then she sat down on\r\nhis knee, like a chip-sparrow, still laughing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Tom, you look so funny!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom had a sober, benevolent smile, and seemed, in his quiet way, to be\r\nenjoying the fun quite as much as his little mistress. He lifted his\r\neyes, when he saw his master, with a half-deprecating, apologetic air.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow can you let her?\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy not?\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know, it seems so dreadful!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou would think no harm in a child\xe2\x80\x99s caressing a large dog, even if he\r\nwas black; but a creature that can think, and reason, and feel, and is\r\nimmortal, you shudder at; confess it, cousin. I know the feeling among\r\nsome of you northerners well enough. Not that there is a particle of\r\nvirtue in our not having it; but custom with us does what Christianity\r\nought to do,\xe2\x80\x94obliterates the feeling of personal prejudice. I have\r\noften noticed, in my travels north, how much stronger this was with you\r\nthan with us. You loathe them as you would a snake or a toad, yet you\r\nare indignant at their wrongs. You would not have them abused; but you\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t want to have anything to do with them yourselves. You would send\r\nthem to Africa, out of your sight and smell, and then send a missionary\r\nor two to do up all the self-denial of elevating them compendiously.\r\nIsn\xe2\x80\x99t that it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, cousin,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, thoughtfully, \xe2\x80\x9cthere may be some\r\ntruth in this.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat would the poor and lowly do, without children?\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare,\r\nleaning on the railing, and watching Eva, as she tripped off, leading\r\nTom with her. \xe2\x80\x9cYour little child is your only true democrat. Tom, now\r\nis a hero to Eva; his stories are wonders in her eyes, his songs and\r\nMethodist hymns are better than an opera, and the traps and little bits\r\nof trash in his pocket a mine of jewels, and he the most wonderful Tom\r\nthat ever wore a black skin. This is one of the roses of Eden that the\r\nLord has dropped down expressly for the poor and lowly, who get few\r\nenough of any other kind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s strange, cousin,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, \xe2\x80\x9cone might almost think you\r\nwere a _professor_, to hear you talk.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA professor?\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; a professor of religion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot at all; not a professor, as your town-folks have it; and, what is\r\nworse, I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid, not a _practiser_, either.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat makes you talk so, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing is easier than talking,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare. \xe2\x80\x9cI believe\r\nShakespeare makes somebody say, \xe2\x80\x99I could sooner show twenty what were\r\ngood to be done, than be one of the twenty to follow my own\r\nshowing.\xe2\x80\x98[1] Nothing like division of labor. My forte lies in talking,\r\nand yours, cousin, lies in doing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n [1] _The Merchant of Venice_, Act 1, scene 2, lines 17-18.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nIn Tom\xe2\x80\x99s external situation, at this time, there was, as the world\r\nsays, nothing to complain of Little Eva\xe2\x80\x99s fancy for him\xe2\x80\x94the instinctive\r\ngratitude and loveliness of a noble nature\xe2\x80\x94had led her to petition her\r\nfather that he might be her especial attendant, whenever she needed the\r\nescort of a servant, in her walks or rides; and Tom had general orders\r\nto let everything else go, and attend to Miss Eva whenever she wanted\r\nhim,\xe2\x80\x94orders which our readers may fancy were far from disagreeable to\r\nhim. He was kept well dressed, for St. Clare was fastidiously\r\nparticular on this point. His stable services were merely a sinecure,\r\nand consisted simply in a daily care and inspection, and directing an\r\nunder-servant in his duties; for Marie St. Clare declared that she\r\ncould not have any smell of the horses about him when he came near her,\r\nand that he must positively not be put to any service that would make\r\nhim unpleasant to her, as her nervous system was entirely inadequate to\r\nany trial of that nature; one snuff of anything disagreeable being,\r\naccording to her account, quite sufficient to close the scene, and put\r\nan end to all her earthly trials at once. Tom, therefore, in his\r\nwell-brushed broadcloth suit, smooth beaver, glossy boots, faultless\r\nwristbands and collar, with his grave, good-natured black face, looked\r\nrespectable enough to be a Bishop of Carthage, as men of his color\r\nwere, in other ages.\r\n\r\nThen, too, he was in a beautiful place, a consideration to which his\r\nsensitive race was never indifferent; and he did enjoy with a quiet joy\r\nthe birds, the flowers, the fountains, the perfume, and light and\r\nbeauty of the court, the silken hangings, and pictures, and lustres,\r\nand statuettes, and gilding, that made the parlors within a kind of\r\nAladdin\xe2\x80\x99s palace to him.\r\n\r\nIf ever Africa shall show an elevated and cultivated race,\xe2\x80\x94and come it\r\nmust, some time, her turn to figure in the great drama of human\r\nimprovement.\xe2\x80\x94life will awake there with a gorgeousness and splendor of\r\nwhich our cold western tribes faintly have conceived. In that far-off\r\nmystic land of gold, and gems, and spices, and waving palms, and\r\nwondrous flowers, and miraculous fertility, will awake new forms of\r\nart, new styles of splendor; and the negro race, no longer despised and\r\ntrodden down, will, perhaps, show forth some of the latest and most\r\nmagnificent revelations of human life. Certainly they will, in their\r\ngentleness, their lowly docility of heart, their aptitude to repose on\r\na superior mind and rest on a higher power, their childlike simplicity\r\nof affection, and facility of forgiveness. In all these they will\r\nexhibit the highest form of the peculiarly _Christian life_, and,\r\nperhaps, as God chasteneth whom he loveth, he hath chosen poor Africa\r\nin the furnace of affliction, to make her the highest and noblest in\r\nthat kingdom which he will set up, when every other kingdom has been\r\ntried, and failed; for the first shall be last, and the last first.\r\n\r\nWas this what Marie St. Clare was thinking of, as she stood, gorgeously\r\ndressed, on the verandah, on Sunday morning, clasping a diamond\r\nbracelet on her slender wrist? Most likely it was. Or, if it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nthat, it was something else; for Marie patronized good things, and she\r\nwas going now, in full force,\xe2\x80\x94diamonds, silk, and lace, and jewels, and\r\nall,\xe2\x80\x94to a fashionable church, to be very religious. Marie always made a\r\npoint to be very pious on Sundays. There she stood, so slender, so\r\nelegant, so airy and undulating in all her motions, her lace scarf\r\nenveloping her like a mist. She looked a graceful creature, and she\r\nfelt very good and very elegant indeed. Miss Ophelia stood at her side,\r\na perfect contrast. It was not that she had not as handsome a silk\r\ndress and shawl, and as fine a pocket-handkerchief; but stiffness and\r\nsquareness, and bolt-uprightness, enveloped her with as indefinite yet\r\nappreciable a presence as did grace her elegant neighbor; not the grace\r\nof God, however,\xe2\x80\x94that is quite another thing!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere\xe2\x80\x99s Eva?\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe child stopped on the stairs, to say something to Mammy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd what was Eva saying to Mammy on the stairs? Listen, reader, and you\r\nwill hear, though Marie does not.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear Mammy, I know your head is aching dreadfully.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLord bless you, Miss Eva! my head allers aches lately. You don\xe2\x80\x99t need\r\nto worry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I\xe2\x80\x99m glad you\xe2\x80\x99re going out; and here,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and the little girl threw\r\nher arms around her,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cMammy, you shall take my vinaigrette.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! your beautiful gold thing, thar, with them diamonds! Lor, Miss,\r\n\xe2\x80\x99t wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be proper, no ways.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy not? You need it, and I don\xe2\x80\x99t. Mamma always uses it for headache,\r\nand it\xe2\x80\x99ll make you feel better. No, you shall take it, to please me,\r\nnow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo hear the darlin talk!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mammy, as Eva thrust it into her bosom,\r\nand kissing her, ran down stairs to her mother.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat were you stopping for?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was just stopping to give Mammy my vinaigrette, to take to church\r\nwith her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEva\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie, stamping impatiently,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cyour gold vinaigrette to\r\n_Mammy!_ When will you learn what\xe2\x80\x99s _proper_? Go right and take it back\r\nthis moment!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEva looked downcast and aggrieved, and turned slowly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say, Marie, let the child alone; she shall do as she pleases,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nSt. Clare.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSt. Clare, how will she ever get along in the world?\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Lord knows,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, \xe2\x80\x9cbut she\xe2\x80\x99ll get along in heaven\r\nbetter than you or I.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, papa, don\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva, softly touching his elbow; \xe2\x80\x9cit troubles\r\nmother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, cousin, are you ready to go to meeting?\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia,\r\nturning square about on St. Clare.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not going, thank you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do wish St. Clare ever would go to church,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie; \xe2\x80\x9cbut he\r\nhasn\xe2\x80\x99t a particle of religion about him. It really isn\xe2\x80\x99t respectable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know it,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare. \xe2\x80\x9cYou ladies go to church to learn how to\r\nget along in the world, I suppose, and your piety sheds respectability\r\non us. If I did go at all, I would go where Mammy goes; there\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsomething to keep a fellow awake there, at least.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! those shouting Methodists? Horrible!\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnything but the dead sea of your respectable churches, Marie.\r\nPositively, it\xe2\x80\x99s too much to ask of a man. Eva, do you like to go?\r\nCome, stay at home and play with me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, papa; but I\xe2\x80\x99d rather go to church.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t it dreadful tiresome?\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think it is tiresome, some,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva, \xe2\x80\x9cand I am sleepy, too, but I\r\ntry to keep awake.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you go for, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, you know, papa,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, in a whisper, \xe2\x80\x9ccousin told me that God\r\nwants to have us; and he gives us everything, you know; and it isn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nmuch to do it, if he wants us to. It isn\xe2\x80\x99t so very tiresome after all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou sweet, little obliging soul!\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, kissing her; \xe2\x80\x9cgo\r\nalong, that\xe2\x80\x99s a good girl, and pray for me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly, I always do,\xe2\x80\x9d said the child, as she sprang after her\r\nmother into the carriage.\r\n\r\nSt. Clare stood on the steps and kissed his hand to her, as the\r\ncarriage drove away; large tears were in his eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Evangeline! rightly named,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9chath not God made thee an\r\nevangel to me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo he felt a moment; and then he smoked a cigar, and read the Picayune,\r\nand forgot his little gospel. Was he much unlike other folks?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see, Evangeline,\xe2\x80\x9d said her mother, \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s always right and proper\r\nto be kind to servants, but it isn\xe2\x80\x99t proper to treat them _just_ as we\r\nwould our relations, or people in our own class of life. Now, if Mammy\r\nwas sick, you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t want to put her in your own bed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should feel just like it, mamma,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva, \xe2\x80\x9cbecause then it would\r\nbe handier to take care of her, and because, you know, my bed is better\r\nthan hers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMarie was in utter despair at the entire want of moral perception\r\nevinced in this reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat can I do to make this child understand me?\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, significantly.\r\n\r\nEva looked sorry and disconcerted for a moment; but children, luckily,\r\ndo not keep to one impression long, and in a few moments she was\r\nmerrily laughing at various things which she saw from the\r\ncoach-windows, as it rattled along.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, ladies,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, as they were comfortably seated at the\r\ndinner-table, \xe2\x80\x9cand what was the bill of fare at church today?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Dr. G\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94 preached a splendid sermon,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie. \xe2\x80\x9cIt was just such\r\na sermon as you ought to hear; it expressed all my views exactly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt must have been very improving,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare. \xe2\x80\x9cThe subject must\r\nhave been an extensive one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I mean all my views about society, and such things,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe text was, \xe2\x80\x98He hath made everything beautiful in its season;\xe2\x80\x99 and\r\nhe showed how all the orders and distinctions in society came from God;\r\nand that it was so appropriate, you know, and beautiful, that some\r\nshould be high and some low, and that some were born to rule and some\r\nto serve, and all that, you know; and he applied it so well to all this\r\nridiculous fuss that is made about slavery, and he proved distinctly\r\nthat the Bible was on our side, and supported all our institutions so\r\nconvincingly. I only wish you\xe2\x80\x99d heard him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t need it,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare. \xe2\x80\x9cI can learn what does me as\r\nmuch good as that from the Picayune, any time, and smoke a cigar\r\nbesides; which I can\xe2\x80\x99t do, you know, in a church.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t you believe in these views?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho,\xe2\x80\x94I? You know I\xe2\x80\x99m such a graceless dog that these religious aspects\r\nof such subjects don\xe2\x80\x99t edify me much. If I was to say anything on this\r\nslavery matter, I would say out, fair and square, \xe2\x80\x98We\xe2\x80\x99re in for it;\r\nwe\xe2\x80\x99ve got \xe2\x80\x99em, and mean to keep \xe2\x80\x99em,\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s for our convenience and our\r\ninterest;\xe2\x80\x99 for that\xe2\x80\x99s the long and short of it,\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s just the whole\r\nof what all this sanctified stuff amounts to, after all; and I think\r\nthat it will be intelligible to everybody, everywhere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do think, Augustine, you are so irreverent!\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie. \xe2\x80\x9cI think\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99s shocking to hear you talk.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShocking! it\xe2\x80\x99s the truth. This religious talk on such matters,\xe2\x80\x94why\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t they carry it a little further, and show the beauty, in its\r\nseason, of a fellow\xe2\x80\x99s taking a glass too much, and sitting a little too\r\nlate over his cards, and various providential arrangements of that\r\nsort, which are pretty frequent among us young men;\xe2\x80\x94we\xe2\x80\x99d like to hear\r\nthat those are right and godly, too.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you think slavery right or wrong?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not going to have any of your horrid New England directness,\r\ncousin,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, gayly. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I answer that question, I know\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99ll be at me with half a dozen others, each one harder than the\r\nlast; and I\xe2\x80\x99m not a going to define my position. I am one of the sort\r\nthat lives by throwing stones at other people\xe2\x80\x99s glass houses, but I\r\nnever mean to put up one for them to stone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s just the way he\xe2\x80\x99s always talking,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie; \xe2\x80\x9cyou can\xe2\x80\x99t get\r\nany satisfaction out of him. I believe it\xe2\x80\x99s just because he don\xe2\x80\x99t like\r\nreligion, that he\xe2\x80\x99s always running out in this way he\xe2\x80\x99s been doing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReligion!\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, in a tone that made both ladies look at\r\nhim. \xe2\x80\x9cReligion! Is what you hear at church, religion? Is that which can\r\nbend and turn, and descend and ascend, to fit every crooked phase of\r\nselfish, worldly society, religion? Is that religion which is less\r\nscrupulous, less generous, less just, less considerate for man, than\r\neven my own ungodly, worldly, blinded nature? No! When I look for a\r\nreligion, I must look for something above me, and not something\r\nbeneath.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you don\xe2\x80\x99t believe that the Bible justifies slavery,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss\r\nOphelia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Bible was my _mother\xe2\x80\x99s_ book,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare. \xe2\x80\x9cBy it she lived\r\nand died, and I would be very sorry to think it did. I\xe2\x80\x99d as soon desire\r\nto have it proved that my mother could drink brandy, chew tobacco, and\r\nswear, by way of satisfying me that I did right in doing the same. It\r\nwouldn\xe2\x80\x99t make me at all more satisfied with these things in myself, and\r\nit would take from me the comfort of respecting her; and it really is a\r\ncomfort, in this world, to have anything one can respect. In short, you\r\nsee,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, suddenly resuming his gay tone, \xe2\x80\x9call I want is that\r\ndifferent things be kept in different boxes. The whole frame-work of\r\nsociety, both in Europe and America, is made up of various things which\r\nwill not stand the scrutiny of any very ideal standard of morality.\r\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s pretty generally understood that men don\xe2\x80\x99t aspire after the\r\nabsolute right, but only to do about as well as the rest of the world.\r\nNow, when any one speaks up, like a man, and says slavery is necessary\r\nto us, we can\xe2\x80\x99t get along without it, we should be beggared if we give\r\nit up, and, of course, we mean to hold on to it,\xe2\x80\x94this is strong, clear,\r\nwell-defined language; it has the respectability of truth to it; and,\r\nif we may judge by their practice, the majority of the world will bear\r\nus out in it. But when he begins to put on a long face, and snuffle,\r\nand quote Scripture, I incline to think he isn\xe2\x80\x99t much better than he\r\nshould be.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are very uncharitable,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, \xe2\x80\x9csuppose that something should bring down the\r\nprice of cotton once and forever, and make the whole slave property a\r\ndrug in the market, don\xe2\x80\x99t you think we should soon have another version\r\nof the Scripture doctrine? What a flood of light would pour into the\r\nchurch, all at once, and how immediately it would be discovered that\r\neverything in the Bible and reason went the other way!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, at any rate,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie, as she reclined herself on a lounge,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m thankful I\xe2\x80\x99m born where slavery exists; and I believe it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nright,\xe2\x80\x94indeed, I feel it must be; and, at any rate, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nget along without it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say, what do you think, Pussy?\xe2\x80\x9d said her father to Eva, who came in\r\nat this moment, with a flower in her hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat about, papa?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, which do you like the best,\xe2\x80\x94to live as they do at your uncle\xe2\x80\x99s,\r\nup in Vermont, or to have a house-full of servants, as we do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, of course, our way is the pleasantest,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy so?\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, stroking her head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, it makes so many more round you to love, you know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva,\r\nlooking up earnestly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, that\xe2\x80\x99s just like Eva,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie; \xe2\x80\x9cjust one of her odd\r\nspeeches.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it an odd speech, papa?\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva, whisperingly, as she got upon\r\nhis knee.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRather, as this world goes, Pussy,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare. \xe2\x80\x9cBut where has my\r\nlittle Eva been, all dinner-time?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, I\xe2\x80\x99ve been up in Tom\xe2\x80\x99s room, hearing him sing, and Aunt Dinah gave\r\nme my dinner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHearing Tom sing, hey?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, yes! he sings such beautiful things about the New Jerusalem, and\r\nbright angels, and the land of Canaan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI dare say; it\xe2\x80\x99s better than the opera, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and he\xe2\x80\x99s going to teach them to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSinging lessons, hey?\xe2\x80\x94you _are_ coming on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, he sings for me, and I read to him in my Bible; and he explains\r\nwhat it means, you know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn my word,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie, laughing, \xe2\x80\x9cthat is the latest joke of the\r\nseason.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTom isn\xe2\x80\x99t a bad hand, now, at explaining Scripture, I\xe2\x80\x99ll dare swear,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid St. Clare. \xe2\x80\x9cTom has a natural genius for religion. I wanted the\r\nhorses out early, this morning, and I stole up to Tom\xe2\x80\x99s cubiculum\r\nthere, over the stables, and there I heard him holding a meeting by\r\nhimself; and, in fact, I haven\xe2\x80\x99t heard anything quite so savory as\r\nTom\xe2\x80\x99s prayer, this some time. He put in for me, with a zeal that was\r\nquite apostolic.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps he guessed you were listening. I\xe2\x80\x99ve heard of that trick\r\nbefore.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf he did, he wasn\xe2\x80\x99t very polite; for he gave the Lord his opinion of\r\nme, pretty freely. Tom seemed to think there was decidedly room for\r\nimprovement in me, and seemed very earnest that I should be converted.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope you\xe2\x80\x99ll lay it to heart,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI suppose you are much of the same opinion,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, we\r\nshall see,\xe2\x80\x94shan\xe2\x80\x99t we, Eva?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XVII\r\nThe Freeman\xe2\x80\x99s Defence\r\n\r\n\r\nThere was a gentle bustle at the Quaker house, as the afternoon drew to\r\na close. Rachel Halliday moved quietly to and fro, collecting from her\r\nhousehold stores such needments as could be arranged in the smallest\r\ncompass, for the wanderers who were to go forth that night. The\r\nafternoon shadows stretched eastward, and the round red sun stood\r\nthoughtfully on the horizon, and his beams shone yellow and calm into\r\nthe little bed-room where George and his wife were sitting. He was\r\nsitting with his child on his knee, and his wife\xe2\x80\x99s hand in his. Both\r\nlooked thoughtful and serious and traces of tears were on their cheeks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Eliza,\xe2\x80\x9d said George, \xe2\x80\x9cI know all you say is true. You are a good\r\nchild,\xe2\x80\x94a great deal better than I am; and I will try to do as you say.\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll try to act worthy of a free man. I\xe2\x80\x99ll try to feel like a\r\nChristian. God Almighty knows that I\xe2\x80\x99ve meant to do well,\xe2\x80\x94tried hard to\r\ndo well,\xe2\x80\x94when everything has been against me; and now I\xe2\x80\x99ll forget all\r\nthe past, and put away every hard and bitter feeling, and read my\r\nBible, and learn to be a good man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd when we get to Canada,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eliza, \xe2\x80\x9cI can help you. I can do\r\ndress-making very well; and I understand fine washing and ironing; and\r\nbetween us we can find something to live on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Eliza, so long as we have each other and our boy. O! Eliza, if\r\nthese people only knew what a blessing it is for a man to feel that his\r\nwife and child belong to _him_! I\xe2\x80\x99ve often wondered to see men that\r\ncould call their wives and children _their own_ fretting and worrying\r\nabout anything else. Why, I feel rich and strong, though we have\r\nnothing but our bare hands. I feel as if I could scarcely ask God for\r\nany more. Yes, though I\xe2\x80\x99ve worked hard every day, till I am twenty-five\r\nyears old, and have not a cent of money, nor a roof to cover me, nor a\r\nspot of land to call my own, yet, if they will only let me alone now, I\r\nwill be satisfied,\xe2\x80\x94thankful; I will work, and send back the money for\r\nyou and my boy. As to my old master, he has been paid five times over\r\nfor all he ever spent for me. I don\xe2\x80\x99t owe him anything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut yet we are not quite out of danger,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eliza; \xe2\x80\x9cwe are not yet\r\nin Canada.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue,\xe2\x80\x9d said George, \xe2\x80\x9cbut it seems as if I smelt the free air, and it\r\nmakes me strong.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this moment, voices were heard in the outer apartment, in earnest\r\nconversation, and very soon a rap was heard on the door. Eliza started\r\nand opened it.\r\n\r\nSimeon Halliday was there, and with him a Quaker brother, whom he\r\nintroduced as Phineas Fletcher. Phineas was tall and lathy, red-haired,\r\nwith an expression of great acuteness and shrewdness in his face.
