He\r\nhad not the placid, quiet, unworldly air of Simeon Halliday; on the\r\ncontrary, a particularly wide-awake and _au fait_ appearance, like a\r\nman who rather prides himself on knowing what he is about, and keeping\r\na bright lookout ahead; peculiarities which sorted rather oddly with\r\nhis broad brim and formal phraseology.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOur friend Phineas hath discovered something of importance to the\r\ninterests of thee and thy party, George,\xe2\x80\x9d said Simeon; \xe2\x80\x9cit were well\r\nfor thee to hear it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat I have,\xe2\x80\x9d said Phineas, \xe2\x80\x9cand it shows the use of a man\xe2\x80\x99s always\r\nsleeping with one ear open, in certain places, as I\xe2\x80\x99ve always said.\r\nLast night I stopped at a little lone tavern, back on the road. Thee\r\nremembers the place, Simeon, where we sold some apples, last year, to\r\nthat fat woman, with the great ear-rings. Well, I was tired with hard\r\ndriving; and, after my supper I stretched myself down on a pile of bags\r\nin the corner, and pulled a buffalo over me, to wait till my bed was\r\nready; and what does I do, but get fast asleep.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith one ear open, Phineas?\xe2\x80\x9d said Simeon, quietly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; I slept, ears and all, for an hour or two, for I was pretty well\r\ntired; but when I came to myself a little, I found that there were some\r\nmen in the room, sitting round a table, drinking and talking; and I\r\nthought, before I made much muster, I\xe2\x80\x99d just see what they were up to,\r\nespecially as I heard them say something about the Quakers. \xe2\x80\x98So,\xe2\x80\x99 says\r\none, \xe2\x80\x98they are up in the Quaker settlement, no doubt,\xe2\x80\x99 says he. Then I\r\nlistened with both ears, and I found that they were talking about this\r\nvery party. So I lay and heard them lay off all their plans. This young\r\nman, they said, was to be sent back to Kentucky, to his master, who was\r\ngoing to make an example of him, to keep all niggers from running away;\r\nand his wife two of them were going to run down to New Orleans to sell,\r\non their own account, and they calculated to get sixteen or eighteen\r\nhundred dollars for her; and the child, they said, was going to a\r\ntrader, who had bought him; and then there was the boy, Jim, and his\r\nmother, they were to go back to their masters in Kentucky. They said\r\nthat there were two constables, in a town a little piece ahead, who\r\nwould go in with \xe2\x80\x99em to get \xe2\x80\x99em taken up, and the young woman was to be\r\ntaken before a judge; and one of the fellows, who is small and\r\nsmooth-spoken, was to swear to her for his property, and get her\r\ndelivered over to him to take south. They\xe2\x80\x99ve got a right notion of the\r\ntrack we are going tonight; and they\xe2\x80\x99ll be down after us, six or eight\r\nstrong. So now, what\xe2\x80\x99s to be done?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe group that stood in various attitudes, after this communication,\r\nwere worthy of a painter. Rachel Halliday, who had taken her hands out\r\nof a batch of biscuit, to hear the news, stood with them upraised and\r\nfloury, and with a face of the deepest concern. Simeon looked\r\nprofoundly thoughtful; Eliza had thrown her arms around her husband,\r\nand was looking up to him. George stood with clenched hands and glowing\r\neyes, and looking as any other man might look, whose wife was to be\r\nsold at auction, and son sent to a trader, all under the shelter of a\r\nChristian nation\xe2\x80\x99s laws.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat _shall_ we do, George?\xe2\x80\x9d said Eliza faintly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know what _I_ shall do,\xe2\x80\x9d said George, as he stepped into the little\r\nroom, and began examining pistols.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, ay,\xe2\x80\x9d said Phineas, nodding his head to Simeon; \xe2\x80\x9cthou seest,\r\nSimeon, how it will work.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see,\xe2\x80\x9d said Simeon, sighing; \xe2\x80\x9cI pray it come not to that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want to involve any one with or for me,\xe2\x80\x9d said George. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you\r\nwill lend me your vehicle and direct me, I will drive alone to the next\r\nstand. Jim is a giant in strength, and brave as death and despair, and\r\nso am I.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, well, friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said Phineas, \xe2\x80\x9cbut thee\xe2\x80\x99ll need a driver, for all\r\nthat. Thee\xe2\x80\x99s quite welcome to do all the fighting, thee knows; but I\r\nknow a thing or two about the road, that thee doesn\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to involve you,\xe2\x80\x9d said George.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cInvolve,\xe2\x80\x9d said Phineas, with a curious and keen expression of face,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen thee does involve me, please to let me know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPhineas is a wise and skilful man,\xe2\x80\x9d said Simeon. \xe2\x80\x9cThee does well,\r\nGeorge, to abide by his judgment; and,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, laying his hand\r\nkindly on George\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder, and pointing to the pistols, \xe2\x80\x9cbe not over\r\nhasty with these,\xe2\x80\x94young blood is hot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will attack no man,\xe2\x80\x9d said George. \xe2\x80\x9cAll I ask of this country is to\r\nbe let alone, and I will go out peaceably; but,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he paused, and his\r\nbrow darkened and his face worked,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve had a sister sold in that New\r\nOrleans market. I know what they are sold for; and am I going to stand\r\nby and see them take my wife and sell her, when God has given me a pair\r\nof strong arms to defend her? No; God help me! I\xe2\x80\x99ll fight to the last\r\nbreath, before they shall take my wife and son. Can you blame me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMortal man cannot blame thee, George. Flesh and blood could not do\r\notherwise,\xe2\x80\x9d said Simeon. \xe2\x80\x9cWoe unto the world because of offences, but\r\nwoe unto them through whom the offence cometh.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould not even you, sir, do the same, in my place?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI pray that I be not tried,\xe2\x80\x9d said Simeon; \xe2\x80\x9cthe flesh is weak.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think my flesh would be pretty tolerable strong, in such a case,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Phineas, stretching out a pair of arms like the sails of a\r\nwindmill. \xe2\x80\x9cI an\xe2\x80\x99t sure, friend George, that I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t hold a fellow\r\nfor thee, if thee had any accounts to settle with him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf man should _ever_ resist evil,\xe2\x80\x9d said Simeon, \xe2\x80\x9cthen George should\r\nfeel free to do it now: but the leaders of our people taught a more\r\nexcellent way; for the wrath of man worketh not the righteousness of\r\nGod; but it goes sorely against the corrupt will of man, and none can\r\nreceive it save they to whom it is given. Let us pray the Lord that we\r\nbe not tempted.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd so _I_ do,\xe2\x80\x9d said Phineas; \xe2\x80\x9cbut if we are tempted too much\xe2\x80\x94why, let\r\nthem look out, that\xe2\x80\x99s all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s quite plain thee wasn\xe2\x80\x99t born a Friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said Simeon, smiling.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe old nature hath its way in thee pretty strong as yet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTo tell the truth, Phineas had been a hearty, two-fisted backwoodsman,\r\na vigorous hunter, and a dead shot at a buck; but, having wooed a\r\npretty Quakeress, had been moved by the power of her charms to join the\r\nsociety in his neighborhood; and though he was an honest, sober, and\r\nefficient member, and nothing particular could be alleged against him,\r\nyet the more spiritual among them could not but discern an exceeding\r\nlack of savor in his developments.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFriend Phineas will ever have ways of his own,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rachel Halliday,\r\nsmiling; \xe2\x80\x9cbut we all think that his heart is in the right place, after\r\nall.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said George, \xe2\x80\x9cisn\xe2\x80\x99t it best that we hasten our flight?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI got up at four o\xe2\x80\x99clock, and came on with all speed, full two or\r\nthree hours ahead of them, if they start at the time they planned. It\r\nisn\xe2\x80\x99t safe to start till dark, at any rate; for there are some evil\r\npersons in the villages ahead, that might be disposed to meddle with\r\nus, if they saw our wagon, and that would delay us more than the\r\nwaiting; but in two hours I think we may venture. I will go over to\r\nMichael Cross, and engage him to come behind on his swift nag, and keep\r\na bright lookout on the road, and warn us if any company of men come\r\non. Michael keeps a horse that can soon get ahead of most other horses;\r\nand he could shoot ahead and let us know, if there were any danger. I\r\nam going out now to warn Jim and the old woman to be in readiness, and\r\nto see about the horse. We have a pretty fair start, and stand a good\r\nchance to get to the stand before they can come up with us. So, have\r\ngood courage, friend George; this isn\xe2\x80\x99t the first ugly scrape that I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nbeen in with thy people,\xe2\x80\x9d said Phineas, as he closed the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPhineas is pretty shrewd,\xe2\x80\x9d said Simeon. \xe2\x80\x9cHe will do the best that can\r\nbe done for thee, George.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll I am sorry for,\xe2\x80\x9d said George, \xe2\x80\x9cis the risk to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThee\xe2\x80\x99ll much oblige us, friend George, to say no more about that. What\r\nwe do we are conscience bound to do; we can do no other way. And now,\r\nmother,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, turning to Rachel, \xe2\x80\x9churry thy preparations for these\r\nfriends, for we must not send them away fasting.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd while Rachel and her children were busy making corn-cake, and\r\ncooking ham and chicken, and hurrying on the _et ceteras_ of the\r\nevening meal, George and his wife sat in their little room, with their\r\narms folded about each other, in such talk as husband and wife have\r\nwhen they know that a few hours may part them forever.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEliza,\xe2\x80\x9d said George, \xe2\x80\x9cpeople that have friends, and houses, and lands,\r\nand money, and all those things _can\xe2\x80\x99t_ love as we do, who have nothing\r\nbut each other. Till I knew you, Eliza, no creature had loved me, but\r\nmy poor, heart-broken mother and sister. I saw poor Emily that morning\r\nthe trader carried her off. She came to the corner where I was lying\r\nasleep, and said, \xe2\x80\x99Poor George, your last friend is going. What will\r\nbecome of you, poor boy?\xe2\x80\x99 And I got up and threw my arms round her, and\r\ncried and sobbed, and she cried too; and those were the last kind words\r\nI got for ten long years; and my heart all withered up, and felt as dry\r\nas ashes, till I met you. And your loving me,\xe2\x80\x94why, it was almost like\r\nraising one from the dead! I\xe2\x80\x99ve been a new man ever since! And now,\r\nEliza, I\xe2\x80\x99ll give my last drop of blood, but they _shall not_ take you\r\nfrom me. Whoever gets you must walk over my dead body.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Lord, have mercy!\xe2\x80\x9d said Eliza, sobbing. \xe2\x80\x9cIf he will only let us get\r\nout of this country together, that is all we ask.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs God on their side?\xe2\x80\x9d said George, speaking less to his wife than\r\npouring out his own bitter thoughts. \xe2\x80\x9cDoes he see all they do? Why does\r\nhe let such things happen? And they tell us that the Bible is on their\r\nside; certainly all the power is. They are rich, and healthy, and\r\nhappy; they are members of churches, expecting to go to heaven; and\r\nthey get along so easy in the world, and have it all their own way; and\r\npoor, honest, faithful Christians,\xe2\x80\x94Christians as good or better than\r\nthey,\xe2\x80\x94are lying in the very dust under their feet. They buy \xe2\x80\x99em and\r\nsell \xe2\x80\x99em, and make trade of their heart\xe2\x80\x99s blood, and groans and\r\ntears,\xe2\x80\x94and God _lets_ them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFriend George,\xe2\x80\x9d said Simeon, from the kitchen, \xe2\x80\x9clisten to this Psalm;\r\nit may do thee good.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGeorge drew his seat near the door, and Eliza, wiping her tears, came\r\nforward also to listen, while Simeon read as follows:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut as for me, my feet were almost gone; my steps had well-nigh\r\nslipped. For I was envious of the foolish, when I saw the prosperity of\r\nthe wicked. They are not in trouble like other men, neither are they\r\nplagued like other men. Therefore, pride compasseth them as a chain;\r\nviolence covereth them as a garment. Their eyes stand out with fatness;\r\nthey have more than heart could wish. They are corrupt, and speak\r\nwickedly concerning oppression; they speak loftily. Therefore his\r\npeople return, and the waters of a full cup are wrung out to them, and\r\nthey say, How doth God know? and is there knowledge in the Most High?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs not that the way thee feels, George?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is so indeed,\xe2\x80\x9d said George,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cas well as I could have written it\r\nmyself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, hear,\xe2\x80\x9d said Simeon: \xe2\x80\x9cWhen I thought to know this, it was too\r\npainful for me until I went unto the sanctuary of God. Then understood\r\nI their end. Surely thou didst set them in slippery places, thou\r\ncastedst them down to destruction. As a dream when one awaketh, so, oh\r\nLord, when thou awakest, thou shalt despise their image. Nevertheless I\r\nam continually with thee; thou hast holden me by my right hand. Thou\r\nshalt guide me by thy counsel, and afterwards receive me to glory. It\r\nis good for me to draw near unto God. I have put my trust in the Lord\r\nGod.\xe2\x80\x9d[1]\r\n\r\n [1] Ps. 73, \xe2\x80\x9cThe End of the Wicked contrasted with that of the\r\n Righteous.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nThe words of holy trust, breathed by the friendly old man, stole like\r\nsacred music over the harassed and chafed spirit of George; and after\r\nhe ceased, he sat with a gentle and subdued expression on his fine\r\nfeatures.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf this world were all, George,\xe2\x80\x9d said Simeon, \xe2\x80\x9cthee might, indeed, ask\r\nwhere is the Lord? But it is often those who have least of all in this\r\nlife whom he chooseth for the kingdom. Put thy trust in him and, no\r\nmatter what befalls thee here, he will make all right hereafter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIf these words had been spoken by some easy, self-indulgent exhorter,\r\nfrom whose mouth they might have come merely as pious and rhetorical\r\nflourish, proper to be used to people in distress, perhaps they might\r\nnot have had much effect; but coming from one who daily and calmly\r\nrisked fine and imprisonment for the cause of God and man, they had a\r\nweight that could not but be felt, and both the poor, desolate\r\nfugitives found calmness and strength breathing into them from it.\r\n\r\nAnd now Rachel took Eliza\xe2\x80\x99s hand kindly, and led the way to the\r\nsupper-table. As they were sitting down, a light tap sounded at the\r\ndoor, and Ruth entered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI just ran in,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cwith these little stockings for the\r\nboy,\xe2\x80\x94three pair, nice, warm woollen ones. It will be so cold, thee\r\nknows, in Canada. Does thee keep up good courage, Eliza?\xe2\x80\x9d she added,\r\ntripping round to Eliza\xe2\x80\x99s side of the table, and shaking her warmly by\r\nthe hand, and slipping a seed-cake into Harry\xe2\x80\x99s hand. \xe2\x80\x9cI brought a\r\nlittle parcel of these for him,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, tugging at her pocket to get\r\nout the package. \xe2\x80\x9cChildren, thee knows, will always be eating.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, thank you; you are too kind,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eliza.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, Ruth, sit down to supper,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rachel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI couldn\xe2\x80\x99t, any way. I left John with the baby, and some biscuits in\r\nthe oven; and I can\xe2\x80\x99t stay a moment, else John will burn up all the\r\nbiscuits, and give the baby all the sugar in the bowl. That\xe2\x80\x99s the way\r\nhe does,\xe2\x80\x9d said the little Quakeress, laughing. \xe2\x80\x9cSo, good-by, Eliza;\r\ngood-by, George; the Lord grant thee a safe journey;\xe2\x80\x9d and, with a few\r\ntripping steps, Ruth was out of the apartment.\r\n\r\nA little while after supper, a large covered-wagon drew up before the\r\ndoor; the night was clear starlight; and Phineas jumped briskly down\r\nfrom his seat to arrange his passengers. George walked out of the door,\r\nwith his child on one arm and his wife on the other. His step was firm,\r\nhis face settled and resolute. Rachel and Simeon came out after them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou get out, a moment,\xe2\x80\x9d said Phineas to those inside, \xe2\x80\x9cand let me fix\r\nthe back of the wagon, there, for the women-folks and the boy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere are the two buffaloes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rachel. \xe2\x80\x9cMake the seats as\r\ncomfortable as may be; it\xe2\x80\x99s hard riding all night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJim came out first, and carefully assisted out his old mother, who\r\nclung to his arm, and looked anxiously about, as if she expected the\r\npursuer every moment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJim, are your pistols all in order?\xe2\x80\x9d said George, in a low, firm\r\nvoice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, indeed,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you\xe2\x80\x99ve no doubt what you shall do, if they come?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI rather think I haven\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jim, throwing open his broad chest,\r\nand taking a deep breath. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you think I\xe2\x80\x99ll let them get mother\r\nagain?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDuring this brief colloquy, Eliza had been taking her leave of her kind\r\nfriend, Rachel, and was handed into the carriage by Simeon, and,\r\ncreeping into the back part with her boy, sat down among the\r\nbuffalo-skins. The old woman was next handed in and seated and George\r\nand Jim placed on a rough board seat front of them, and Phineas mounted\r\nin front.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFarewell, my friends,\xe2\x80\x9d said Simeon, from without.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod bless you!\xe2\x80\x9d answered all from within.\r\n\r\nAnd the wagon drove off, rattling and jolting over the frozen road.\r\n\r\nThere was no opportunity for conversation, on account of the roughness\r\nof the way and the noise of the wheels. The vehicle, therefore, rumbled\r\non, through long, dark stretches of woodland,\xe2\x80\x94over wide dreary\r\nplains,\xe2\x80\x94up hills, and down valleys,\xe2\x80\x94and on, on, on they jogged, hour\r\nafter hour. The child soon fell asleep, and lay heavily in his mother\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nlap. The poor, frightened old woman at last forgot her fears; and, even\r\nEliza, as the night waned, found all her anxieties insufficient to keep\r\nher eyes from closing. Phineas seemed, on the whole, the briskest of\r\nthe company, and beguiled his long drive with whistling certain very\r\nunquaker-like songs, as he went on.\r\n\r\nBut about three o\xe2\x80\x99clock George\xe2\x80\x99s ear caught the hasty and decided click\r\nof a horse\xe2\x80\x99s hoof coming behind them at some distance and jogged\r\nPhineas by the elbow. Phineas pulled up his horses, and listened.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat must be Michael,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cI think I know the sound of his\r\ngallop;\xe2\x80\x9d and he rose up and stretched his head anxiously back over the\r\nroad.\r\n\r\nA man riding in hot haste was now dimly descried at the top of a\r\ndistant hill.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere he is, I do believe!\xe2\x80\x9d said Phineas. George and Jim both sprang\r\nout of the wagon before they knew what they were doing. All stood\r\nintensely silent, with their faces turned towards the expected\r\nmessenger. On he came. Now he went down into a valley, where they could\r\nnot see him; but they heard the sharp, hasty tramp, rising nearer and\r\nnearer; at last they saw him emerge on the top of an eminence, within\r\nhail.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, that\xe2\x80\x99s Michael!\xe2\x80\x9d said Phineas; and, raising his voice, \xe2\x80\x9cHalloa,\r\nthere, Michael!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPhineas! is that thee?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; what news\xe2\x80\x94they coming?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRight on behind, eight or ten of them, hot with brandy, swearing and\r\nfoaming like so many wolves.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd, just as he spoke, a breeze brought the faint sound of galloping\r\nhorsemen towards them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn with you,\xe2\x80\x94quick, boys, _in!_\xe2\x80\x9d said Phineas. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you must fight,\r\nwait till I get you a piece ahead.\xe2\x80\x9d And, with the word, both jumped in,\r\nand Phineas lashed the horses to a run, the horseman keeping close\r\nbeside them. The wagon rattled, jumped, almost flew, over the frozen\r\nground; but plainer, and still plainer, came the noise of pursuing\r\nhorsemen behind. The women heard it, and, looking anxiously out, saw,\r\nfar in the rear, on the brow of a distant hill, a party of men looming\r\nup against the red-streaked sky of early dawn. Another hill, and their\r\npursuers had evidently caught sight of their wagon, whose white\r\ncloth-covered top made it conspicuous at some distance, and a loud yell\r\nof brutal triumph came forward on the wind. Eliza sickened, and\r\nstrained her child closer to her bosom; the old woman prayed and\r\ngroaned, and George and Jim clenched their pistols with the grasp of\r\ndespair. The pursuers gained on them fast; the carriage made a sudden\r\nturn, and brought them near a ledge of a steep overhanging rock, that\r\nrose in an isolated ridge or clump in a large lot, which was, all\r\naround it, quite clear and smooth. This isolated pile, or range of\r\nrocks, rose up black and heavy against the brightening sky, and seemed\r\nto promise shelter and concealment. It was a place well known to\r\nPhineas, who had been familiar with the spot in his hunting days; and\r\nit was to gain this point he had been racing his horses.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow for it!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, suddenly checking his horses, and springing from\r\nhis seat to the ground. \xe2\x80\x9cOut with you, in a twinkling, every one, and\r\nup into these rocks with me. Michael, thee tie thy horse to the wagon,\r\nand drive ahead to Amariah\xe2\x80\x99s and get him and his boys to come back and\r\ntalk to these fellows.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn a twinkling they were all out of the carriage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere,\xe2\x80\x9d said Phineas, catching up Harry, \xe2\x80\x9cyou, each of you, see to the\r\nwomen; and run, _now_ if you ever _did_ run!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey needed no exhortation. Quicker than we can say it, the whole party\r\nwere over the fence, making with all speed for the rocks, while\r\nMichael, throwing himself from his horse, and fastening the bridle to\r\nthe wagon, began driving it rapidly away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome ahead,\xe2\x80\x9d said Phineas, as they reached the rocks, and saw in the\r\nmingled starlight and dawn, the traces of a rude but plainly marked\r\nfoot-path leading up among them; \xe2\x80\x9cthis is one of our old hunting-dens.\r\nCome up!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPhineas went before, springing up the rocks like a goat, with the boy\r\nin his arms. Jim came second, bearing his trembling old mother over his\r\nshoulder, and George and Eliza brought up the rear. The party of\r\nhorsemen came up to the fence, and, with mingled shouts and oaths, were\r\ndismounting, to prepare to follow them. A few moments\xe2\x80\x99 scrambling\r\nbrought them to the top of the ledge; the path then passed between a\r\nnarrow defile, where only one could walk at a time, till suddenly they\r\ncame to a rift or chasm more than a yard in breadth, and beyond which\r\nlay a pile of rocks, separate from the rest of the ledge, standing full\r\nthirty feet high, with its sides steep and perpendicular as those of a\r\ncastle. Phineas easily leaped the chasm, and sat down the boy on a\r\nsmooth, flat platform of crisp white moss, that covered the top of the\r\nrock.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOver with you!\xe2\x80\x9d he called; \xe2\x80\x9cspring, now, once, for your lives!\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nhe, as one after another sprang across. Several fragments of loose\r\nstone formed a kind of breast-work, which sheltered their position from\r\nthe observation of those below.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, here we all are,\xe2\x80\x9d said Phineas, peeping over the stone\r\nbreast-work to watch the assailants, who were coming tumultuously up\r\nunder the rocks. \xe2\x80\x9cLet \xe2\x80\x99em get us, if they can. Whoever comes here has\r\nto walk single file between those two rocks, in fair range of your\r\npistols, boys, d\xe2\x80\x99ye see?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do see,\xe2\x80\x9d said George! \xe2\x80\x9cand now, as this matter is ours, let us take\r\nall the risk, and do all the fighting.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThee\xe2\x80\x99s quite welcome to do the fighting, George,\xe2\x80\x9d said Phineas,\r\nchewing some checkerberry-leaves as he spoke; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I may have the fun\r\nof looking on, I suppose. But see, these fellows are kinder debating\r\ndown there, and looking up, like hens when they are going to fly up on\r\nto the roost. Hadn\xe2\x80\x99t thee better give \xe2\x80\x99em a word of advice, before they\r\ncome up, just to tell \xe2\x80\x99em handsomely they\xe2\x80\x99ll be shot if they do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe party beneath, now more apparent in the light of the dawn,\r\nconsisted of our old acquaintances, Tom Loker and Marks, with two\r\nconstables, and a posse consisting of such rowdies at the last tavern\r\nas could be engaged by a little brandy to go and help the fun of\r\ntrapping a set of niggers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Tom, yer coons are farly treed,\xe2\x80\x9d said one.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I see \xe2\x80\x99em go up right here,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom; \xe2\x80\x9cand here\xe2\x80\x99s a path. I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nfor going right up. They can\xe2\x80\x99t jump down in a hurry, and it won\xe2\x80\x99t take\r\nlong to ferret \xe2\x80\x99em out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, Tom, they might fire at us from behind the rocks,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marks.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat would be ugly, you know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUgh!\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, with a sneer. \xe2\x80\x9cAlways for saving your skin, Marks! No\r\ndanger! niggers are too plaguy scared!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know why I _shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t_ save my skin,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marks. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\nbest I\xe2\x80\x99ve got; and niggers _do_ fight like the devil, sometimes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this moment, George appeared on the top of a rock above them, and,\r\nspeaking in a calm, clear voice, said,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen, who are you, down there, and what do you want?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe want a party of runaway niggers,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom Loker. \xe2\x80\x9cOne George\r\nHarris, and Eliza Harris, and their son, and Jim Selden, and an old\r\nwoman. We\xe2\x80\x99ve got the officers, here, and a warrant to take \xe2\x80\x99em; and\r\nwe\xe2\x80\x99re going to have \xe2\x80\x99em, too. D\xe2\x80\x99ye hear? An\xe2\x80\x99t you George Harris, that\r\nbelongs to Mr. Harris, of Shelby county, Kentucky?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am George Harris. A Mr. Harris, of Kentucky, did call me his\r\nproperty. But now I\xe2\x80\x99m a free man, standing on God\xe2\x80\x99s free soil; and my\r\nwife and my child I claim as mine. Jim and his mother are here. We have\r\narms to defend ourselves, and we mean to do it. You can come up, if you\r\nlike; but the first one of you that comes within the range of our\r\nbullets is a dead man, and the next, and the next; and so on till the\r\nlast.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, come! come!\xe2\x80\x9d said a short, puffy man, stepping forward, and blowing\r\nhis nose as he did so. \xe2\x80\x9cYoung man, this an\xe2\x80\x99t no kind of talk at all for\r\nyou. You see, we\xe2\x80\x99re officers of justice. We\xe2\x80\x99ve got the law on our side,\r\nand the power, and so forth; so you\xe2\x80\x99d better give up peaceably, you\r\nsee; for you\xe2\x80\x99ll certainly have to give up, at last.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know very well that you\xe2\x80\x99ve got the law on your side, and the power,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid George, bitterly. \xe2\x80\x9cYou mean to take my wife to sell in New\r\nOrleans, and put my boy like a calf in a trader\xe2\x80\x99s pen, and send Jim\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nold mother to the brute that whipped and abused her before, because he\r\ncouldn\xe2\x80\x99t abuse her son. You want to send Jim and me back to be whipped\r\nand tortured, and ground down under the heels of them that you call\r\nmasters; and your laws _will_ bear you out in it,\xe2\x80\x94more shame for you\r\nand them! But you haven\xe2\x80\x99t got us. We don\xe2\x80\x99t own your laws; we don\xe2\x80\x99t own\r\nyour country; we stand here as free, under God\xe2\x80\x99s sky, as you are; and,\r\nby the great God that made us, we\xe2\x80\x99ll fight for our liberty till we\r\ndie.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGeorge stood out in fair sight, on the top of the rock, as he made his\r\ndeclaration of independence; the glow of dawn gave a flush to his\r\nswarthy cheek, and bitter indignation and despair gave fire to his dark\r\neye; and, as if appealing from man to the justice of God, he raised his\r\nhand to heaven as he spoke.\r\n\r\nIf it had been only a Hungarian youth, now bravely defending in some\r\nmountain fastness the retreat of fugitives escaping from Austria into\r\nAmerica, this would have been sublime heroism; but as it was a youth of\r\nAfrican descent, defending the retreat of fugitives through America\r\ninto Canada, of course we are too well instructed and patriotic to see\r\nany heroism in it; and if any of our readers do, they must do it on\r\ntheir own private responsibility. When despairing Hungarian fugitives\r\nmake their way, against all the search-warrants and authorities of\r\ntheir lawful government, to America, press and political cabinet ring\r\nwith applause and welcome. When despairing African fugitives do the\r\nsame thing,\xe2\x80\x94it is\xe2\x80\x94what _is_ it?\r\n\r\nBe it as it may, it is certain that the attitude, eye, voice, manner,\r\nof the speaker for a moment struck the party below to silence. There is\r\nsomething in boldness and determination that for a time hushes even the\r\nrudest nature. Marks was the only one who remained wholly untouched. He\r\nwas deliberately cocking his pistol, and, in the momentary silence that\r\nfollowed George\xe2\x80\x99s speech, he fired at him.\r\n\r\n\r\n[Illustration: THE FREEMAN\xe2\x80\x99S DEFENCE.]\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYe see ye get jist as much for him dead as alive in Kentucky,\xe2\x80\x9d he said\r\ncoolly, as he wiped his pistol on his coat-sleeve.\r\n\r\nGeorge sprang backward,\xe2\x80\x94Eliza uttered a shriek,\xe2\x80\x94the ball had passed\r\nclose to his hair, had nearly grazed the cheek of his wife, and struck\r\nin the tree above.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s nothing, Eliza,\xe2\x80\x9d said George, quickly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThee\xe2\x80\x99d better keep out of sight, with thy speechifying,\xe2\x80\x9d said Phineas;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthey\xe2\x80\x99re mean scamps.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, Jim,\xe2\x80\x9d said George, \xe2\x80\x9clook that your pistols are all right, and\r\nwatch that pass with me. The first man that shows himself I fire at;\r\nyou take the second, and so on. It won\xe2\x80\x99t do, you know, to waste two\r\nshots on one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what if you don\xe2\x80\x99t hit?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI _shall_ hit,\xe2\x80\x9d said George, coolly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood! now, there\xe2\x80\x99s stuff in that fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d muttered Phineas, between\r\nhis teeth.\r\n\r\nThe party below, after Marks had fired, stood, for a moment, rather\r\nundecided.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think you must have hit some on \xe2\x80\x99em,\xe2\x80\x9d said one of the men. \xe2\x80\x9cI heard\r\na squeal!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m going right up for one,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom. \xe2\x80\x9cI never was afraid of niggers,\r\nand I an\xe2\x80\x99t going to be now. Who goes after?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, springing up the\r\nrocks.\r\n\r\nGeorge heard the words distinctly. He drew up his pistol, examined it,\r\npointed it towards that point in the defile where the first man would\r\nappear.\r\n\r\nOne of the most courageous of the party followed Tom, and, the way\r\nbeing thus made, the whole party began pushing up the rock,\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nhindermost pushing the front ones faster than they would have gone of\r\nthemselves. On they came, and in a moment the burly form of Tom\r\nappeared in sight, almost at the verge of the chasm.\r\n\r\nGeorge fired,\xe2\x80\x94the shot entered his side,\xe2\x80\x94but, though wounded, he would\r\nnot retreat, but, with a yell like that of a mad bull, he was leaping\r\nright across the chasm into the party.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFriend,\xe2\x80\x9d said Phineas, suddenly stepping to the front, and meeting him\r\nwith a push from his long arms, \xe2\x80\x9cthee isn\xe2\x80\x99t wanted here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDown he fell into the chasm, crackling down among trees, bushes, logs,\r\nloose stones, till he lay bruised and groaning thirty feet below. The\r\nfall might have killed him, had it not been broken and moderated by his\r\nclothes catching in the branches of a large tree; but he came down with\r\nsome force, however,\xe2\x80\x94more than was at all agreeable or convenient.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLord help us, they are perfect devils!\xe2\x80\x9d said Marks, heading the\r\nretreat down the rocks with much more of a will than he had joined the\r\nascent, while all the party came tumbling precipitately after him,\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nfat constable, in particular, blowing and puffing in a very energetic\r\nmanner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say, fellers,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marks, \xe2\x80\x9cyou jist go round and pick up Tom,\r\nthere, while I run and get on to my horse to go back for help,\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nyou;\xe2\x80\x9d and, without minding the hootings and jeers of his company, Marks\r\nwas as good as his word, and was soon seen galloping away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas ever such a sneaking varmint?\xe2\x80\x9d said one of the men; \xe2\x80\x9cto come on\r\nhis business, and he clear out and leave us this yer way!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, we must pick up that feller,\xe2\x80\x9d said another. \xe2\x80\x9cCuss me if I much\r\ncare whether he is dead or alive.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe men, led by the groans of Tom, scrambled and crackled through\r\nstumps, logs and bushes, to where that hero lay groaning and swearing\r\nwith alternate vehemence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYe keep it agoing pretty loud, Tom,\xe2\x80\x9d said one. \xe2\x80\x9cYe much hurt?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t know. Get me up, can\xe2\x80\x99t ye? Blast that infernal Quaker! If it\r\nhadn\xe2\x80\x99t been for him, I\xe2\x80\x99d a pitched some on \xe2\x80\x99em down here, to see how\r\nthey liked it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith much labor and groaning, the fallen hero was assisted to rise;\r\nand, with one holding him up under each shoulder, they got him as far\r\nas the horses.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you could only get me a mile back to that ar tavern. Give me a\r\nhandkerchief or something, to stuff into this place, and stop this\r\ninfernal bleeding.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGeorge looked over the rocks, and saw them trying to lift the burly\r\nform of Tom into the saddle. After two or three ineffectual attempts,\r\nhe reeled, and fell heavily to the ground.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, I hope he isn\xe2\x80\x99t killed!\xe2\x80\x9d said Eliza, who, with all the party, stood\r\nwatching the proceeding.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy not?\xe2\x80\x9d said Phineas; \xe2\x80\x9cserves him right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause after death comes the judgment,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eliza.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old woman, who had been groaning and praying, in her\r\nMethodist fashion, during all the encounter, \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s an awful case for\r\nthe poor crittur\xe2\x80\x99s soul.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn my word, they\xe2\x80\x99re leaving him, I do believe,\xe2\x80\x9d said Phineas.\r\n\r\nIt was true; for after some appearance of irresolution and\r\nconsultation, the whole party got on their horses and rode away. When\r\nthey were quite out of sight, Phineas began to bestir himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, we must go down and walk a piece,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI told Michael to\r\ngo forward and bring help, and be along back here with the wagon; but\r\nwe shall have to walk a piece along the road, I reckon, to meet them.\r\nThe Lord grant he be along soon! It\xe2\x80\x99s early in the day; there won\xe2\x80\x99t be\r\nmuch travel afoot yet a while; we an\xe2\x80\x99t much more than two miles from\r\nour stopping-place. If the road hadn\xe2\x80\x99t been so rough last night, we\r\ncould have outrun \xe2\x80\x99em entirely.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs the party neared the fence, they discovered in the distance, along\r\nthe road, their own wagon coming back, accompanied by some men on\r\nhorseback.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now, there\xe2\x80\x99s Michael, and Stephen and Amariah,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed\r\nPhineas, joyfully. \xe2\x80\x9cNow we _are_ made\xe2\x80\x94as safe as if we\xe2\x80\x99d got there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, do stop, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eliza, \xe2\x80\x9cand do something for that poor man;\r\nhe\xe2\x80\x99s groaning dreadfully.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt would be no more than Christian,\xe2\x80\x9d said George; \xe2\x80\x9clet\xe2\x80\x99s take him up\r\nand carry him on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd doctor him up among the Quakers!\xe2\x80\x9d said Phineas; \xe2\x80\x9cpretty well,\r\nthat! Well, I don\xe2\x80\x99t care if we do. Here, let\xe2\x80\x99s have a look at him;\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\nPhineas, who in the course of his hunting and backwoods life had\r\nacquired some rude experience of surgery, kneeled down by the wounded\r\nman, and began a careful examination of his condition.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMarks,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, feebly, \xe2\x80\x9cis that you, Marks?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; I reckon \xe2\x80\x99tan\xe2\x80\x99t friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said Phineas. \xe2\x80\x9cMuch Marks cares for thee,\r\nif his own skin\xe2\x80\x99s safe. He\xe2\x80\x99s off, long ago.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe I\xe2\x80\x99m done for,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom. \xe2\x80\x9cThe cussed sneaking dog, to leave\r\nme to die alone! My poor old mother always told me \xe2\x80\x99t would be so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLa sakes! jist hear the poor crittur. He\xe2\x80\x99s got a mammy, now,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nold negress. \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t help kinder pityin\xe2\x80\x99 on him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSoftly, softly; don\xe2\x80\x99t thee snap and snarl, friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said Phineas, as\r\nTom winced and pushed his hand away. \xe2\x80\x9cThee has no chance, unless I stop\r\nthe bleeding.\xe2\x80\x9d And Phineas busied himself with making some off-hand\r\nsurgical arrangements with his own pocket-handkerchief, and such as\r\ncould be mustered in the company.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou pushed me down there,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, faintly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell if I hadn\xe2\x80\x99t thee would have pushed us down, thee sees,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nPhineas, as he stooped to apply his bandage. \xe2\x80\x9cThere, there,\xe2\x80\x94let me fix\r\nthis bandage. We mean well to thee; we bear no malice. Thee shall be\r\ntaken to a house where they\xe2\x80\x99ll nurse thee first rate, well as thy own\r\nmother could.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom groaned, and shut his eyes. In men of his class, vigor and\r\nresolution are entirely a physical matter, and ooze out with the\r\nflowing of the blood; and the gigantic fellow really looked piteous in\r\nhis helplessness.\r\n\r\nThe other party now came up. The seats were taken out of the wagon. The\r\nbuffalo-skins, doubled in fours, were spread all along one side, and\r\nfour men, with great difficulty, lifted the heavy form of Tom into it.\r\nBefore he was gotten in, he fainted entirely. The old negress, in the\r\nabundance of her compassion, sat down on the bottom, and took his head\r\nin her lap. Eliza, George and Jim, bestowed themselves, as well as they\r\ncould, in the remaining space and the whole party set forward.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you think of him?\xe2\x80\x9d said George, who sat by Phineas in front.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell it\xe2\x80\x99s only a pretty deep flesh-wound; but, then, tumbling and\r\nscratching down that place didn\xe2\x80\x99t help him much. It has bled pretty\r\nfreely,\xe2\x80\x94pretty much drained him out, courage and all,\xe2\x80\x94but he\xe2\x80\x99ll get\r\nover it, and may be learn a thing or two by it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m glad to hear you say so,\xe2\x80\x9d said George. \xe2\x80\x9cIt would always be a heavy\r\nthought to me, if I\xe2\x80\x99d caused his death, even in a just cause.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Phineas, \xe2\x80\x9ckilling is an ugly operation, any way they\xe2\x80\x99ll fix\r\nit,\xe2\x80\x94man or beast. I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen a buck that was shot down and a dying, look\r\nthat way on a feller with his eye, that it reely most made a feller\r\nfeel wicked for killing on him; and human creatures is a more serious\r\nconsideration yet, bein\xe2\x80\x99, as thy wife says, that the judgment comes to\r\n\xe2\x80\x99em after death. So I don\xe2\x80\x99t know as our people\xe2\x80\x99s notions on these\r\nmatters is too strict; and, considerin\xe2\x80\x99 how I was raised, I fell in\r\nwith them pretty considerably.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat shall you do with this poor fellow?\xe2\x80\x9d said George.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, carry him along to Amariah\xe2\x80\x99s. There\xe2\x80\x99s old Grandmam Stephens\r\nthere,\xe2\x80\x94Dorcas, they call her,\xe2\x80\x94she\xe2\x80\x99s most an amazin\xe2\x80\x99 nurse. She takes to\r\nnursing real natural, and an\xe2\x80\x99t never better suited than when she gets a\r\nsick body to tend. We may reckon on turning him over to her for a\r\nfortnight or so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA ride of about an hour more brought the party to a neat farmhouse,\r\nwhere the weary travellers were received to an abundant breakfast. Tom\r\nLoker was soon carefully deposited in a much cleaner and softer bed\r\nthan he had ever been in the habit of occupying. His wound was\r\ncarefully dressed and bandaged, and he lay languidly opening and\r\nshutting his eyes on the white window-curtains and gently-gliding\r\nfigures of his sick room, like a weary child. And here, for the\r\npresent, we shall take our leave of one party.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XVIII\r\nMiss Ophelia\xe2\x80\x99s Experiences and Opinions\r\n\r\n\r\nOur friend Tom, in his own simple musings, often compared his more\r\nfortunate lot, in the bondage into which he was cast, with that of\r\nJoseph in Egypt; and, in fact, as time went on, and he developed more\r\nand more under the eye of his master, the strength of the parallel\r\nincreased.\r\n\r\nSt. Clare was indolent and careless of money. Hitherto the providing\r\nand marketing had been principally done by Adolph, who was, to the\r\nfull, as careless and extravagant as his master; and, between them\r\nboth, they had carried on the dispersing process with great alacrity.\r\nAccustomed, for many years, to regard his master\xe2\x80\x99s property as his own\r\ncare, Tom saw, with an uneasiness he could scarcely repress, the\r\nwasteful expenditure of the establishment; and, in the quiet, indirect\r\nway which his class often acquire, would sometimes make his own\r\nsuggestions.\r\n\r\nSt. Clare at first employed him occasionally; but, struck with his\r\nsoundness of mind and good business capacity, he confided in him more\r\nand more, till gradually all the marketing and providing for the family\r\nwere intrusted to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, Adolph,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, one day, as Adolph was deprecating the\r\npassing of power out of his hands; \xe2\x80\x9clet Tom alone. You only understand\r\nwhat you want; Tom understands cost and come to; and there may be some\r\nend to money, bye and bye if we don\xe2\x80\x99t let somebody do that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTrusted to an unlimited extent by a careless master, who handed him a\r\nbill without looking at it, and pocketed the change without counting\r\nit, Tom had every facility and temptation to dishonesty; and nothing\r\nbut an impregnable simplicity of nature, strengthened by Christian\r\nfaith, could have kept him from it. But, to that nature, the very\r\nunbounded trust reposed in him was bond and seal for the most\r\nscrupulous accuracy.\r\n\r\nWith Adolph the case had been different. Thoughtless and\r\nself-indulgent, and unrestrained by a master who found it easier to\r\nindulge than to regulate, he had fallen into an absolute confusion as\r\nto _meum tuum_ with regard to himself and his master, which sometimes\r\ntroubled even St. Clare. His own good sense taught him that such a\r\ntraining of his servants was unjust and dangerous. A sort of chronic\r\nremorse went with him everywhere, although not strong enough to make\r\nany decided change in his course; and this very remorse reacted again\r\ninto indulgence. He passed lightly over the most serious faults,\r\nbecause he told himself that, if he had done his part, his dependents\r\nhad not fallen into them.\r\n\r\nTom regarded his gay, airy, handsome young master with an odd mixture\r\nof fealty, reverence, and fatherly solicitude. That he never read the\r\nBible; never went to church; that he jested and made free with any and\r\nevery thing that came in the way of his wit; that he spent his Sunday\r\nevenings at the opera or theatre; that he went to wine parties, and\r\nclubs, and suppers, oftener than was at all expedient,\xe2\x80\x94were all things\r\nthat Tom could see as plainly as anybody, and on which he based a\r\nconviction that \xe2\x80\x9cMas\xe2\x80\x99r wasn\xe2\x80\x99t a Christian;\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94a conviction, however,\r\nwhich he would have been very slow to express to any one else, but on\r\nwhich he founded many prayers, in his own simple fashion, when he was\r\nby himself in his little dormitory. Not that Tom had not his own way of\r\nspeaking his mind occasionally, with something of the tact often\r\nobservable in his class; as, for example, the very day after the\r\nSabbath we have described, St. Clare was invited out to a convivial\r\nparty of choice spirits, and was helped home, between one and two\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock at night, in a condition when the physical had decidedly\r\nattained the upper hand of the intellectual. Tom and Adolph assisted to\r\nget him composed for the night, the latter in high spirits, evidently\r\nregarding the matter as a good joke, and laughing heartily at the\r\nrusticity of Tom\xe2\x80\x99s horror, who really was simple enough to lie awake\r\nmost of the rest of the night, praying for his young master.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Tom, what are you waiting for?\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, the next day, as\r\nhe sat in his library, in dressing-gown and slippers. St. Clare had\r\njust been entrusting Tom with some money, and various commissions.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t all right there, Tom?\xe2\x80\x9d he added, as Tom still stood waiting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m \xe2\x80\x99fraid not, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, with a grave face.\r\n\r\nSt. Clare laid down his paper, and set down his coffee-cup, and looked\r\nat Tom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy Tom, what\xe2\x80\x99s the case? You look as solemn as a coffin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI feel very bad, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r. I allays have thought that Mas\xe2\x80\x99r would be good\r\nto everybody.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Tom, haven\xe2\x80\x99t I been? Come, now, what do you want? There\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsomething you haven\xe2\x80\x99t got, I suppose, and this is the preface.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMas\xe2\x80\x99r allays been good to me. I haven\xe2\x80\x99t nothing to complain of on that\r\nhead. But there is one that Mas\xe2\x80\x99r isn\xe2\x80\x99t good to.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, Tom, what\xe2\x80\x99s got into you? Speak out; what do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLast night, between one and two, I thought so. I studied upon the\r\nmatter then. Mas\xe2\x80\x99r isn\xe2\x80\x99t good to _himself_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom said this with his back to his master, and his hand on the\r\ndoor-knob. St. Clare felt his face flush crimson, but he laughed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, that\xe2\x80\x99s all, is it?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, gayly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll!\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, turning suddenly round and falling on his knees. \xe2\x80\x9cO,\r\nmy dear young Mas\xe2\x80\x99r; I\xe2\x80\x99m \xe2\x80\x99fraid it will be _loss of all\xe2\x80\x94all_\xe2\x80\x94body and\r\nsoul. The good Book says, \xe2\x80\x99it biteth like a serpent and stingeth like\r\nan adder!\xe2\x80\x99 my dear Mas\xe2\x80\x99r!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom\xe2\x80\x99s voice choked, and the tears ran down his cheeks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou poor, silly fool!\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, with tears in his own eyes.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGet up, Tom. I\xe2\x80\x99m not worth crying over.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut Tom wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t rise, and looked imploring.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I won\xe2\x80\x99t go to any more of their cursed nonsense, Tom,\xe2\x80\x9d said St.\r\nClare; \xe2\x80\x9con my honor, I won\xe2\x80\x99t. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know why I haven\xe2\x80\x99t stopped long\r\nago. I\xe2\x80\x99ve always despised _it_, and myself for it,\xe2\x80\x94so now, Tom, wipe up\r\nyour eyes, and go about your errands. Come, come,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, \xe2\x80\x9cno\r\nblessings. I\xe2\x80\x99m not so wonderfully good, now,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, as he gently\r\npushed Tom to the door. \xe2\x80\x9cThere, I\xe2\x80\x99ll pledge my honor to you, Tom, you\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t see me so again,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; and Tom went off, wiping his eyes,\r\nwith great satisfaction.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll keep my faith with him, too,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, as he closed the\r\ndoor.\r\n\r\nAnd St. Clare did so,\xe2\x80\x94for gross sensualism, in any form, was not the\r\npeculiar temptation of his nature.\r\n\r\nBut, all this time, who shall detail the tribulations manifold of our\r\nfriend Miss Ophelia, who had begun the labors of a Southern\r\nhousekeeper?\r\n\r\nThere is all the difference in the world in the servants of Southern\r\nestablishments, according to the character and capacity of the\r\nmistresses who have brought them up.\r\n\r\nSouth as well as north, there are women who have an extraordinary\r\ntalent for command, and tact in educating. Such are enabled, with\r\napparent ease, and without severity, to subject to their will, and\r\nbring into harmonious and systematic order, the various members of\r\ntheir small estate,\xe2\x80\x94to regulate their peculiarities, and so balance and\r\ncompensate the deficiencies of one by the excess of another, as to\r\nproduce a harmonious and orderly system.\r\n\r\nSuch a housekeeper was Mrs. Shelby, whom we have already described; and\r\nsuch our readers may remember to have met with. If they are not common\r\nat the South, it is because they are not common in the world. They are\r\nto be found there as often as anywhere; and, when existing, find in\r\nthat peculiar state of society a brilliant opportunity to exhibit their\r\ndomestic talent.\r\n\r\nSuch a housekeeper Marie St. Clare was not, nor her mother before her.\r\nIndolent and childish, unsystematic and improvident, it was not to be\r\nexpected that servants trained under her care should not be so\r\nlikewise; and she had very justly described to Miss Ophelia the state\r\nof confusion she would find in the family, though she had not ascribed\r\nit to the proper cause.\r\n\r\nThe first morning of her regency, Miss Ophelia was up at four o\xe2\x80\x99clock;\r\nand having attended to all the adjustments of her own chamber, as she\r\nhad done ever since she came there, to the great amazement of the\r\nchambermaid, she prepared for a vigorous onslaught on the cupboards and\r\nclosets of the establishment of which she had the keys.\r\n\r\nThe store-room, the linen-presses, the china-closet, the kitchen and\r\ncellar, that day, all went under an awful review. Hidden things of\r\ndarkness were brought to light to an extent that alarmed all the\r\nprincipalities and powers of kitchen and chamber, and caused many\r\nwonderings and murmurings about \xe2\x80\x9cdese yer northern ladies\xe2\x80\x9d from the\r\ndomestic cabinet.\r\n\r\nOld Dinah, the head cook, and principal of all rule and authority in\r\nthe kitchen department, was filled with wrath at what she considered an\r\ninvasion of privilege. No feudal baron in _Magna Charta_ times could\r\nhave more thoroughly resented some incursion of the crown.\r\n\r\nDinah was a character in her own way, and it would be injustice to her\r\nmemory not to give the reader a little idea of her. She was a native\r\nand essential cook, as much as Aunt Chloe,\xe2\x80\x94cooking being an indigenous\r\ntalent of the African race; but Chloe was a trained and methodical one,\r\nwho moved in an orderly domestic harness, while Dinah was a self-taught\r\ngenius, and, like geniuses in general, was positive, opinionated and\r\nerratic, to the last degree.\r\n\r\nLike a certain class of modern philosophers, Dinah perfectly scorned\r\nlogic and reason in every shape, and always took refuge in intuitive\r\ncertainty; and here she was perfectly impregnable. No possible amount\r\nof talent, or authority, or explanation, could ever make her believe\r\nthat any other way was better than her own, or that the course she had\r\npursued in the smallest matter could be in the least modified. This had\r\nbeen a conceded point with her old mistress, Marie\xe2\x80\x99s mother; and \xe2\x80\x9cMiss\r\nMarie,\xe2\x80\x9d as Dinah always called her young mistress, even after her\r\nmarriage, found it easier to submit than contend; and so Dinah had\r\nruled supreme. This was the easier, in that she was perfect mistress of\r\nthat diplomatic art which unites the utmost subservience of manner with\r\nthe utmost inflexibility as to measure.\r\n\r\nDinah was mistress of the whole art and mystery of excuse-making, in\r\nall its branches. Indeed, it was an axiom with her that the cook can do\r\nno wrong; and a cook in a Southern kitchen finds abundance of heads and\r\nshoulders on which to lay off every sin and frailty, so as to maintain\r\nher own immaculateness entire. If any part of the dinner was a failure,\r\nthere were fifty indisputably good reasons for it; and it was the fault\r\nundeniably of fifty other people, whom Dinah berated with unsparing\r\nzeal.\r\n\r\nBut it was very seldom that there was any failure in Dinah\xe2\x80\x99s last\r\nresults. Though her mode of doing everything was peculiarly meandering\r\nand circuitous, and without any sort of calculation as to time and\r\nplace,\xe2\x80\x94though her kitchen generally looked as if it had been arranged\r\nby a hurricane blowing through it, and she had about as many places for\r\neach cooking utensil as there were days in the year,\xe2\x80\x94yet, if one would\r\nhave patience to wait her own good time, up would come her dinner in\r\nperfect order, and in a style of preparation with which an epicure\r\ncould find no fault.\r\n\r\nIt was now the season of incipient preparation for dinner. Dinah, who\r\nrequired large intervals of reflection and repose, and was studious of\r\nease in all her arrangements, was seated on the kitchen floor, smoking\r\na short, stumpy pipe, to which she was much addicted, and which she\r\nalways kindled up, as a sort of censer, whenever she felt the need of\r\nan inspiration in her arrangements. It was Dinah\xe2\x80\x99s mode of invoking the\r\ndomestic Muses.\r\n\r\nSeated around her were various members of that rising race with which a\r\nSouthern household abounds, engaged in shelling peas, peeling potatoes,\r\npicking pin-feathers out of fowls, and other preparatory\r\narrangements,\xe2\x80\x94Dinah every once in a while interrupting her meditations\r\nto give a poke, or a rap on the head, to some of the young operators,\r\nwith the pudding-stick that lay by her side. In fact, Dinah ruled over\r\nthe woolly heads of the younger members with a rod of iron, and seemed\r\nto consider them born for no earthly purpose but to \xe2\x80\x9csave her steps,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nas she phrased it. It was the spirit of the system under which she had\r\ngrown up, and she carried it out to its full extent.\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia, after passing on her reformatory tour through all the\r\nother parts of the establishment, now entered the kitchen. Dinah had\r\nheard, from various sources, what was going on, and resolved to stand\r\non defensive and conservative ground,\xe2\x80\x94mentally determined to oppose and\r\nignore every new measure, without any actual observable contest.\r\n\r\nThe kitchen was a large brick-floored apartment, with a great\r\nold-fashioned fireplace stretching along one side of it,\xe2\x80\x94an arrangement\r\nwhich St. Clare had vainly tried to persuade Dinah to exchange for the\r\nconvenience of a modern cook-stove. Not she. No Puseyite,[1] or\r\nconservative of any school, was ever more inflexibly attached to\r\ntime-honored inconveniences than Dinah.\r\n\r\n [1] Edward Bouverie Pusey (1800-1882), champion of the orthodoxy of\r\n revealed religion, defender of the Oxford movement, and Regius\r\n professor of Hebrew and Canon of Christ Church, Oxford.\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen St. Clare had first returned from the north, impressed with the\r\nsystem and order of his uncle\xe2\x80\x99s kitchen arrangements, he had largely\r\nprovided his own with an array of cupboards, drawers, and various\r\napparatus, to induce systematic regulation, under the sanguine illusion\r\nthat it would be of any possible assistance to Dinah in her\r\narrangements. He might as well have provided them for a squirrel or a\r\nmagpie. The more drawers and closets there were, the more hiding-holes\r\ncould Dinah make for the accommodation of old rags, hair-combs, old\r\nshoes, ribbons, cast-off artificial flowers, and other articles of\r\n_vertu_, wherein her soul delighted.\r\n\r\nWhen Miss Ophelia entered the kitchen Dinah did not rise, but smoked on\r\nin sublime tranquillity, regarding her movements obliquely out of the\r\ncorner of her eye, but apparently intent only on the operations around\r\nher.\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia commenced opening a set of drawers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is this drawer for, Dinah?\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s handy for most anything, Missis,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dinah. So it appeared to\r\nbe. From the variety it contained, Miss Ophelia pulled out first a fine\r\ndamask table-cloth stained with blood, having evidently been used to\r\nenvelop some raw meat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s this, Dinah? You don\xe2\x80\x99t wrap up meat in your mistress\xe2\x80\x99 best\r\ntable-cloths?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO Lor, Missis, no; the towels was all a missin\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94so I jest did it. I\r\nlaid out to wash that a,\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s why I put it thar.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShif\xe2\x80\x99less!\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia to herself, proceeding to tumble over\r\nthe drawer, where she found a nutmeg-grater and two or three nutmegs, a\r\nMethodist hymn-book, a couple of soiled Madras handkerchiefs, some yarn\r\nand knitting-work, a paper of tobacco and a pipe, a few crackers, one\r\nor two gilded china-saucers with some pomade in them, one or two thin\r\nold shoes, a piece of flannel carefully pinned up enclosing some small\r\nwhite onions, several damask table-napkins, some coarse crash towels,\r\nsome twine and darning-needles, and several broken papers, from which\r\nsundry sweet herbs were sifting into the drawer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere do you keep your nutmegs, Dinah?\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, with the\r\nair of one who prayed for patience.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMost anywhar, Missis; there\xe2\x80\x99s some in that cracked tea-cup, up there,\r\nand there\xe2\x80\x99s some over in that ar cupboard.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere are some in the grater,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, holding them up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLaws, yes, I put \xe2\x80\x99em there this morning,\xe2\x80\x94I likes to keep my things\r\nhandy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dinah. \xe2\x80\x9cYou, Jake! what are you stopping for! You\xe2\x80\x99ll cotch\r\nit! Be still, thar!\xe2\x80\x9d she added, with a dive of her stick at the\r\ncriminal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s this?\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, holding up the saucer of pomade.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLaws, it\xe2\x80\x99s my har _grease_;\xe2\x80\x94I put it thar to have it handy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you use your mistress\xe2\x80\x99 best saucers for that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLaw! it was cause I was driv, and in sich a hurry;\xe2\x80\x94I was gwine to\r\nchange it this very day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere are two damask table-napkins.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThem table-napkins I put thar, to get \xe2\x80\x99em washed out, some day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you have some place here on purpose for things to be washed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r St. Clare got dat ar chest, he said, for dat; but I likes\r\nto mix up biscuit and hev my things on it some days, and then it an\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nhandy a liftin\xe2\x80\x99 up the lid.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy don\xe2\x80\x99t you mix your biscuits on the pastry-table, there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLaw, Missis, it gets sot so full of dishes, and one thing and another,\r\nder an\xe2\x80\x99t no room, noway\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you should _wash_ your dishes, and clear them away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWash my dishes!\xe2\x80\x9d said Dinah, in a high key, as her wrath began to rise\r\nover her habitual respect of manner; \xe2\x80\x9cwhat does ladies know \xe2\x80\x99bout work,\r\nI want to know? When \xe2\x80\x99d Mas\xe2\x80\x99r ever get his dinner, if I vas to spend\r\nall my time a washin\xe2\x80\x99 and a puttin\xe2\x80\x99 up dishes? Miss Marie never telled\r\nme so, nohow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, here are these onions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLaws, yes!\xe2\x80\x9d said Dinah; \xe2\x80\x9cthar _is_ whar I put \xe2\x80\x99em, now. I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\n\xe2\x80\x99member. Them \xe2\x80\x99s particular onions I was a savin\xe2\x80\x99 for dis yer very\r\nstew. I\xe2\x80\x99d forgot they was in dat ar old flannel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia lifted out the sifting papers of sweet herbs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish Missis wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t touch dem ar. You, Sam, don\xe2\x80\x99t you gib the baby dat ar\r\nsugar-bowl! I\xe2\x80\x99ll crack ye over, if ye don\xe2\x80\x99t mind!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m going through the kitchen, and going to put everything in order,\r\n_once_, Dinah; and then I\xe2\x80\x99ll expect you to _keep_ it so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLor, now! Miss Phelia; dat ar an\xe2\x80\x99t no way for ladies to do. I never\r\ndid see ladies doin\xe2\x80\x99 no sich; my old Missis nor Miss Marie never did,\r\nand I don\xe2\x80\x99t see no kinder need on \xe2\x80\x99t;\xe2\x80\x9d and Dinah stalked indignantly\r\nabout, while Miss Ophelia piled and sorted dishes, emptied dozens of\r\nscattering bowls of sugar into one receptacle, sorted napkins,\r\ntable-cloths, and towels, for washing; washing, wiping, and arranging\r\nwith her own hands, and with a speed and alacrity which perfectly\r\namazed Dinah.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLor now! if dat ar de way dem northern ladies do, dey an\xe2\x80\x99t ladies,\r\nnohow,\xe2\x80\x9d she said to some of her satellites, when at a safe hearing\r\ndistance. \xe2\x80\x9cI has things as straight as anybody, when my clarin\xe2\x80\x99 up\r\ntimes comes; but I don\xe2\x80\x99t want ladies round, a henderin\xe2\x80\x99, and getting my\r\nthings all where I can\xe2\x80\x99t find \xe2\x80\x99em.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTo do Dinah justice, she had, at irregular periods, paroxyms of\r\nreformation and arrangement, which she called \xe2\x80\x9cclarin\xe2\x80\x99 up times,\xe2\x80\x9d when\r\nshe would begin with great zeal, and turn every drawer and closet wrong\r\nside outward, on to the floor or tables, and make the ordinary\r\nconfusion seven-fold more confounded. Then she would light her pipe,\r\nand leisurely go over her arrangements, looking things over, and\r\ndiscoursing upon them; making all the young fry scour most vigorously\r\non the tin things, and keeping up for several hours a most energetic\r\nstate of confusion, which she would explain to the satisfaction of all\r\ninquirers, by the remark that she was a \xe2\x80\x9cclarin\xe2\x80\x99 up.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cShe couldn\xe2\x80\x99t hev\r\nthings a gwine on so as they had been, and she was gwine to make these\r\nyer young ones keep better order;\xe2\x80\x9d for Dinah herself, somehow, indulged\r\nthe illusion that she, herself, was the soul of order, and it was only\r\nthe _young uns_, and the everybody else in the house, that were the\r\ncause of anything that fell short of perfection in this respect. When\r\nall the tins were scoured, and the tables scrubbed snowy white, and\r\neverything that could offend tucked out of sight in holes and corners,\r\nDinah would dress herself up in a smart dress, clean apron, and high,\r\nbrilliant Madras turban, and tell all marauding \xe2\x80\x9cyoung uns\xe2\x80\x9d to keep out\r\nof the kitchen, for she was gwine to have things kept nice. Indeed,\r\nthese periodic seasons were often an inconvenience to the whole\r\nhousehold; for Dinah would contract such an immoderate attachment to\r\nher scoured tin, as to insist upon it that it shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be used again\r\nfor any possible purpose,\xe2\x80\x94at least, till the ardor of the \xe2\x80\x9cclarin\xe2\x80\x99 up\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nperiod abated.\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia, in a few days, thoroughly reformed every department of\r\nthe house to a systematic pattern; but her labors in all departments\r\nthat depended on the cooperation of servants were like those of\r\nSisyphus or the Danaides. In despair, she one day appealed to St.\r\nClare.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is no such thing as getting anything like a system in this\r\nfamily!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be sure, there isn\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuch shiftless management, such waste, such confusion, I never saw!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI dare say you didn\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou would not take it so coolly, if you were housekeeper.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear cousin, you may as well understand, once for all, that we\r\nmasters are divided into two classes, oppressors and oppressed. We who\r\nare good-natured and hate severity make up our minds to a good deal of\r\ninconvenience. If we _will keep_ a shambling, loose, untaught set in\r\nthe community, for our convenience, why, we must take the consequence.\r\nSome rare cases I have seen, of persons, who, by a peculiar tact, can\r\nproduce order and system without severity; but I\xe2\x80\x99m not one of them,\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nso I made up my mind, long ago, to let things go just as they do. I\r\nwill not have the poor devils thrashed and cut to pieces, and they know\r\nit,\xe2\x80\x94and, of course, they know the staff is in their own hands.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut to have no time, no place, no order,\xe2\x80\x94all going on in this\r\nshiftless way!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Vermont, you natives up by the North Pole set an extravagant\r\nvalue on time! What on earth is the use of time to a fellow who has\r\ntwice as much of it as he knows what to do with? As to order and\r\nsystem, where there is nothing to be done but to lounge on the sofa and\r\nread, an hour sooner or later in breakfast or dinner isn\xe2\x80\x99t of much\r\naccount. Now, there\xe2\x80\x99s Dinah gets you a capital dinner,\xe2\x80\x94soup, ragout,\r\nroast fowl, dessert, ice-creams and all,\xe2\x80\x94and she creates it all out of\r\nchaos and old night down there, in that kitchen. I think it really\r\nsublime, the way she manages. But, Heaven bless us! if we are to go\r\ndown there, and view all the smoking and squatting about, and\r\nhurryscurryation of the preparatory process, we should never eat more!\r\nMy good cousin, absolve yourself from that! It\xe2\x80\x99s more than a Catholic\r\npenance, and does no more good. You\xe2\x80\x99ll only lose your own temper, and\r\nutterly confound Dinah. Let her go her own way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, Augustine, you don\xe2\x80\x99t know how I found things.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t I? Don\xe2\x80\x99t I know that the rolling-pin is under her bed, and the\r\nnutmeg-grater in her pocket with her tobacco,\xe2\x80\x94that there are sixty-five\r\ndifferent sugar-bowls, one in every hole in the house,\xe2\x80\x94that she washes\r\ndishes with a dinner-napkin one day, and with a fragment of an old\r\npetticoat the next? But the upshot is, she gets up glorious dinners,\r\nmakes superb coffee; and you must judge her as warriors and statesmen\r\nare judged, _by her success_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut the waste,\xe2\x80\x94the expense!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, well! Lock everything you can, and keep the key. Give out by\r\ndriblets, and never inquire for odds and ends,\xe2\x80\x94it isn\xe2\x80\x99t best.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat troubles me, Augustine. I can\xe2\x80\x99t help feeling as if these servants\r\nwere not _strictly honest_. Are you sure they can be relied on?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAugustine laughed immoderately at the grave and anxious face with which\r\nMiss Ophelia propounded the question.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, cousin, that\xe2\x80\x99s too good,\xe2\x80\x94_honest!_\xe2\x80\x94as if that\xe2\x80\x99s a thing to be\r\nexpected! Honest!\xe2\x80\x94why, of course, they arn\xe2\x80\x99t. Why should they be? What\r\nupon earth is to make them so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy don\xe2\x80\x99t you instruct?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cInstruct! O, fiddlestick! What instructing do you think I should do? I\r\nlook like it! As to Marie, she has spirit enough, to be sure, to kill\r\noff a whole plantation, if I\xe2\x80\x99d let her manage; but she wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t get the\r\ncheatery out of them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre there no honest ones?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now and then one, whom Nature makes so impracticably simple,\r\ntruthful and faithful, that the worst possible influence can\xe2\x80\x99t destroy\r\nit. But, you see, from the mother\xe2\x80\x99s breast the colored child feels and\r\nsees that there are none but underhand ways open to it. It can get\r\nalong no other way with its parents, its mistress, its young master and\r\nmissie play-fellows. Cunning and deception become necessary, inevitable\r\nhabits. It isn\xe2\x80\x99t fair to expect anything else of him. He ought not to\r\nbe punished for it. As to honesty, the slave is kept in that dependent,\r\nsemi-childish state, that there is no making him realize the rights of\r\nproperty, or feel that his master\xe2\x80\x99s goods are not his own, if he can\r\nget them. For my part, I don\xe2\x80\x99t see how they _can_ be honest. Such a\r\nfellow as Tom, here, is,\xe2\x80\x94is a moral miracle!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what becomes of their souls?\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat isn\xe2\x80\x99t my affair, as I know of,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare; \xe2\x80\x9cI am only\r\ndealing in facts of the present life. The fact is, that the whole race\r\nare pretty generally understood to be turned over to the devil, for our\r\nbenefit, in this world, however it may turn out in another!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is perfectly horrible!\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia; \xe2\x80\x9cyou ought to be\r\nashamed of yourselves!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know as I am. We are in pretty good company, for all that,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid St. Clare, \xe2\x80\x9cas people in the broad road generally are. Look at the\r\nhigh and the low, all the world over, and it\xe2\x80\x99s the same story,\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nlower class used up, body, soul and spirit, for the good of the upper.\r\nIt is so in England; it is so everywhere; and yet all Christendom\r\nstands aghast, with virtuous indignation, because we do the thing in a\r\nlittle different shape from what they do it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt isn\xe2\x80\x99t so in Vermont.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, well, in New England, and in the free States, you have the better\r\nof us, I grant. But there\xe2\x80\x99s the bell; so, Cousin, let us for a while\r\nlay aside our sectional prejudices, and come out to dinner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs Miss Ophelia was in the kitchen in the latter part of the afternoon,\r\nsome of the sable children called out, \xe2\x80\x9cLa, sakes! thar\xe2\x80\x99s Prue a\r\ncoming, grunting along like she allers does.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA tall, bony colored woman now entered the kitchen, bearing on her head\r\na basket of rusks and hot rolls.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHo, Prue! you\xe2\x80\x99ve come,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dinah.\r\n\r\nPrue had a peculiar scowling expression of countenance, and a sullen,\r\ngrumbling voice. I wish\xe2\x80\x99t I \xe2\x80\x99s dead!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy do you wish you were dead?\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d be out o\xe2\x80\x99 my misery,\xe2\x80\x9d said the woman, gruffly, without taking her\r\neyes from the floor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat need you getting drunk, then, and cutting up, Prue?\xe2\x80\x9d said a\r\nspruce quadroon chambermaid, dangling, as she spoke, a pair of coral\r\near-drops.\r\n\r\nThe woman looked at her with a sour surly glance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMaybe you\xe2\x80\x99ll come to it, one of these yer days. I\xe2\x80\x99d be glad to see\r\nyou, I would; then you\xe2\x80\x99ll be glad of a drop, like me, to forget your\r\nmisery.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, Prue,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dinah, \xe2\x80\x9clet\xe2\x80\x99s look at your rusks. Here\xe2\x80\x99s Missis will\r\npay for them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia took out a couple of dozen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThar\xe2\x80\x99s some tickets in that ar old cracked jug on the top shelf,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nDinah. \xe2\x80\x9cYou, Jake, climb up and get it down.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTickets,\xe2\x80\x94what are they for?\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe buy tickets of her Mas\xe2\x80\x99r, and she gives us bread for \xe2\x80\x99em.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd they counts my money and tickets, when I gets home, to see if I \xe2\x80\x99s\r\ngot the change; and if I han\xe2\x80\x99t, they half kills me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd serves you right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jane, the pert chambermaid, \xe2\x80\x9cif you will\r\ntake their money to get drunk on. That\xe2\x80\x99s what she does, Missis.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd that\xe2\x80\x99s what I _will_ do,\xe2\x80\x94I can\xe2\x80\x99t live no other ways,\xe2\x80\x94drink and\r\nforget my misery.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are very wicked and very foolish,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, \xe2\x80\x9cto steal\r\nyour master\xe2\x80\x99s money to make yourself a brute with.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s mighty likely, Missis; but I will do it,\xe2\x80\x94yes, I will. O Lord! I\r\nwish I \xe2\x80\x99s dead, I do,\xe2\x80\x94I wish I \xe2\x80\x99s dead, and out of my misery!\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\nslowly and stiffly the old creature rose, and got her basket on her\r\nhead again; but before she went out, she looked at the quadroon girl,\r\nwho still stood playing with her ear-drops.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYe think ye\xe2\x80\x99re mighty fine with them ar, a frolickin\xe2\x80\x99 and a tossin\xe2\x80\x99\r\nyour head, and a lookin\xe2\x80\x99 down on everybody.
