Who ever said I did defend it?\xe2\x80\x9d said St.\r\nClare.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course, you defend it,\xe2\x80\x94you all do,\xe2\x80\x94all you Southerners. What do you\r\nhave slaves for, if you don\xe2\x80\x99t?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you such a sweet innocent as to suppose nobody in this world ever\r\ndoes what they don\xe2\x80\x99t think is right? Don\xe2\x80\x99t you, or didn\xe2\x80\x99t you ever, do\r\nanything that you did not think quite right?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I do, I repent of it, I hope,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, rattling her\r\nneedles with energy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo do I,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, peeling his orange; \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m repenting of it all\r\nthe time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you keep on doing it for?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDidn\xe2\x80\x99t you ever keep on doing wrong, after you\xe2\x80\x99d repented, my good\r\ncousin?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, only when I\xe2\x80\x99ve been very much tempted,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I\xe2\x80\x99m very much tempted,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare; \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s just my\r\ndifficulty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I always resolve I won\xe2\x80\x99t and I try to break off.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I have been resolving I won\xe2\x80\x99t, off and on, these ten years,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid St. Clare; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I haven\xe2\x80\x99t, some how, got clear. Have you got clear\r\nof all your sins, cousin?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCousin Augustine,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, seriously, and laying down her\r\nknitting-work, \xe2\x80\x9cI suppose I deserve that you should reprove my\r\nshort-comings. I know all you say is true enough; nobody else feels\r\nthem more than I do; but it does seem to me, after all, there is some\r\ndifference between me and you. It seems to me I would cut off my right\r\nhand sooner than keep on, from day to day, doing what I thought was\r\nwrong. But, then, my conduct is so inconsistent with my profession, I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t wonder you reprove me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, now, cousin,\xe2\x80\x9d said Augustine, sitting down on the floor, and laying\r\nhis head back in her lap, \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t take on so awfully serious! You know\r\nwhat a good-for-nothing, saucy boy I always was. I love to poke you\r\nup,\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s all,\xe2\x80\x94just to see you get earnest. I do think you are\r\ndesperately, distressingly good; it tires me to death to think of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut this is a serious subject, my boy, Auguste,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia,\r\nlaying her hand on his forehead.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDismally so,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cand I\xe2\x80\x94well, I never want to talk seriously in\r\nhot weather. What with mosquitos and all, a fellow can\xe2\x80\x99t get himself up\r\nto any very sublime moral flights; and I believe,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare,\r\nsuddenly rousing himself up, \xe2\x80\x9cthere\xe2\x80\x99s a theory, now! I understand now\r\nwhy northern nations are always more virtuous than southern ones,\xe2\x80\x94I see\r\ninto that whole subject.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Augustine, you are a sad rattle-brain!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAm I? Well, so I am, I suppose; but for once I will be serious, now;\r\nbut you must hand me that basket of oranges;\xe2\x80\x94you see, you\xe2\x80\x99ll have to\r\n\xe2\x80\x98stay me with flagons and comfort me with apples,\xe2\x80\x99 if I\xe2\x80\x99m going to make\r\nthis effort. Now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Augustine, drawing the basket up, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll begin:\r\nWhen, in the course of human events, it becomes necessary for a fellow\r\nto hold two or three dozen of his fellow-worms in captivity, a decent\r\nregard to the opinions of society requires\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t see that you are growing more serious,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait,\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99m coming on,\xe2\x80\x94you\xe2\x80\x99ll hear. The short of the matter is, cousin,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid he, his handsome face suddenly settling into an earnest and\r\nserious expression, \xe2\x80\x9con this abstract question of slavery there can, as\r\nI think, be but one opinion. Planters, who have money to make by\r\nit,\xe2\x80\x94clergymen, who have planters to please,\xe2\x80\x94politicians, who want to\r\nrule by it,\xe2\x80\x94may warp and bend language and ethics to a degree that\r\nshall astonish the world at their ingenuity; they can press nature and\r\nthe Bible, and nobody knows what else, into the service; but, after\r\nall, neither they nor the world believe in it one particle the more. It\r\ncomes from the devil, that\xe2\x80\x99s the short of it;\xe2\x80\x94and, to my mind, it\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\npretty respectable specimen of what he can do in his own line.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia stopped her knitting, and looked surprised, and St. Clare,\r\napparently enjoying her astonishment, went on.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou seem to wonder; but if you will get me fairly at it, I\xe2\x80\x99ll make a\r\nclean breast of it. This cursed business, accursed of God and man, what\r\nis it? Strip it of all its ornament, run it down to the root and\r\nnucleus of the whole, and what is it? Why, because my brother Quashy is\r\nignorant and weak, and I am intelligent and strong,\xe2\x80\x94because I know how,\r\nand _can_ do it,\xe2\x80\x94therefore, I may steal all he has, keep it, and give\r\nhim only such and so much as suits my fancy. Whatever is too hard, too\r\ndirty, too disagreeable, for me, I may set Quashy to doing. Because I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t like work, Quashy shall work. Because the sun burns me, Quashy\r\nshall stay in the sun. Quashy shall earn the money, and I will spend\r\nit. Quashy shall lie down in every puddle, that I may walk over\r\ndry-shod. Quashy shall do my will, and not his, all the days of his\r\nmortal life, and have such chance of getting to heaven, at last, as I\r\nfind convenient. This I take to be about what slavery _is_. I defy\r\nanybody on earth to read our slave-code, as it stands in our law-books,\r\nand make anything else of it. Talk of the _abuses_ of slavery! Humbug!\r\nThe _thing itself_ is the essence of all abuse! And the only reason why\r\nthe land don\xe2\x80\x99t sink under it, like Sodom and Gomorrah, is because it is\r\n_used_ in a way infinitely better than it is. For pity\xe2\x80\x99s sake, for\r\nshame\xe2\x80\x99s sake, because we are men born of women, and not savage beasts,\r\nmany of us do not, and dare not,\xe2\x80\x94we would _scorn_ to use the full power\r\nwhich our savage laws put into our hands. And he who goes the furthest,\r\nand does the worst, only uses within limits the power that the law\r\ngives him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSt. Clare had started up, and, as his manner was when excited, was\r\nwalking, with hurried steps, up and down the floor. His fine face,\r\nclassic as that of a Greek statue, seemed actually to burn with the\r\nfervor of his feelings. His large blue eyes flashed, and he gestured\r\nwith an unconscious eagerness. Miss Ophelia had never seen him in this\r\nmood before, and she sat perfectly silent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI declare to you,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, suddenly stopping before his cousin \xe2\x80\x9c(It\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nno sort of use to talk or to feel on this subject), but I declare to\r\nyou, there have been times when I have thought, if the whole country\r\nwould sink, and hide all this injustice and misery from the light, I\r\nwould willingly sink with it. When I have been travelling up and down\r\non our boats, or about on my collecting tours, and reflected that every\r\nbrutal, disgusting, mean, low-lived fellow I met, was allowed by our\r\nlaws to become absolute despot of as many men, women and children, as\r\nhe could cheat, steal, or gamble money enough to buy,\xe2\x80\x94when I have seen\r\nsuch men in actual ownership of helpless children, of young girls and\r\nwomen,\xe2\x80\x94I have been ready to curse my country, to curse the human race!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAugustine! Augustine!\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sure you\xe2\x80\x99ve said\r\nenough. I never, in my life, heard anything like this, even at the\r\nNorth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt the North!\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, with a sudden change of expression, and\r\nresuming something of his habitual careless tone. \xe2\x80\x9cPooh! your northern\r\nfolks are cold-blooded; you are cool in everything! You can\xe2\x80\x99t begin to\r\ncurse up hill and down as we can, when we get fairly at it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, but the question is,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, yes, to be sure, the _question is_,\xe2\x80\x94and a deuce of a question it\r\nis! How came _you_ in this state of sin and misery? Well, I shall\r\nanswer in the good old words you used to teach me, Sundays. I came so\r\nby ordinary generation. My servants were my father\xe2\x80\x99s, and, what is\r\nmore, my mother\xe2\x80\x99s; and now they are mine, they and their increase,\r\nwhich bids fair to be a pretty considerable item. My father, you know,\r\ncame first from New England; and he was just such another man as your\r\nfather,\xe2\x80\x94a regular old Roman,\xe2\x80\x94upright, energetic, noble-minded, with an\r\niron will. Your father settled down in New England, to rule over rocks\r\nand stones, and to force an existence out of Nature; and mine settled\r\nin Louisiana, to rule over men and women, and force existence out of\r\nthem. My mother,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, getting up and walking to a picture\r\nat the end of the room, and gazing upward with a face fervent with\r\nveneration, \xe2\x80\x9c_she was divine!_ Don\xe2\x80\x99t look at me so!\xe2\x80\x94you know what I\r\nmean! She probably was of mortal birth; but, as far as ever I could\r\nobserve, there was no trace of any human weakness or error about her;\r\nand everybody that lives to remember her, whether bond or free,\r\nservant, acquaintance, relation, all say the same. Why, cousin, that\r\nmother has been all that has stood between me and utter unbelief for\r\nyears. She was a direct embodiment and personification of the New\r\nTestament,\xe2\x80\x94a living fact, to be accounted for, and to be accounted for\r\nin no other way than by its truth. O, mother! mother!\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare,\r\nclasping his hands, in a sort of transport; and then suddenly checking\r\nhimself, he came back, and seating himself on an ottoman, he went on:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy brother and I were twins; and they say, you know, that twins ought\r\nto resemble each other; but we were in all points a contrast. He had\r\nblack, fiery eyes, coal-black hair, a strong, fine Roman profile, and a\r\nrich brown complexion. I had blue eyes, golden hair, a Greek outline,\r\nand fair complexion. He was active and observing, I dreamy and\r\ninactive. He was generous to his friends and equals, but proud,\r\ndominant, overbearing, to inferiors, and utterly unmerciful to whatever\r\nset itself up against him. Truthful we both were; he from pride and\r\ncourage, I from a sort of abstract ideality. We loved each other about\r\nas boys generally do,\xe2\x80\x94off and on, and in general;\xe2\x80\x94he was my father\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npet, and I my mother\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere was a morbid sensitiveness and acuteness of feeling in me on all\r\npossible subjects, of which he and my father had no kind of\r\nunderstanding, and with which they could have no possible sympathy. But\r\nmother did; and so, when I had quarreled with Alfred, and father looked\r\nsternly on me, I used to go off to mother\xe2\x80\x99s room, and sit by her. I\r\nremember just how she used to look, with her pale cheeks, her deep,\r\nsoft, serious eyes, her white dress,\xe2\x80\x94she always wore white; and I used\r\nto think of her whenever I read in Revelations about the saints that\r\nwere arrayed in fine linen, clean and white. She had a great deal of\r\ngenius of one sort and another, particularly in music; and she used to\r\nsit at her organ, playing fine old majestic music of the Catholic\r\nchurch, and singing with a voice more like an angel than a mortal\r\nwoman; and I would lay my head down on her lap, and cry, and dream, and\r\nfeel,\xe2\x80\x94oh, immeasurably!\xe2\x80\x94things that I had no language to say!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn those days, this matter of slavery had never been canvassed as it\r\nhas now; nobody dreamed of any harm in it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy father was a born aristocrat. I think, in some preexistent state,\r\nhe must have been in the higher circles of spirits, and brought all his\r\nold court pride along with him; for it was ingrain, bred in the bone,\r\nthough he was originally of poor and not in any way of noble family. My\r\nbrother was begotten in his image.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, an aristocrat, you know, the world over, has no human sympathies,\r\nbeyond a certain line in society. In England the line is in one place,\r\nin Burmah in another, and in America in another; but the aristocrat of\r\nall these countries never goes over it. What would be hardship and\r\ndistress and injustice in his own class, is a cool matter of course in\r\nanother one. My father\xe2\x80\x99s dividing line was that of color. _Among his\r\nequals_, never was a man more just and generous; but he considered the\r\nnegro, through all possible gradations of color, as an intermediate\r\nlink between man and animals, and graded all his ideas of justice or\r\ngenerosity on this hypothesis. I suppose, to be sure, if anybody had\r\nasked him, plump and fair, whether they had human immortal souls, he\r\nmight have hemmed and hawed, and said yes. But my father was not a man\r\nmuch troubled with spiritualism; religious sentiment he had none,\r\nbeyond a veneration for God, as decidedly the head of the upper\r\nclasses.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my father worked some five hundred negroes; he was an\r\ninflexible, driving, punctilious business man; everything was to move\r\nby system,\xe2\x80\x94to be sustained with unfailing accuracy and precision. Now,\r\nif you take into account that all this was to be worked out by a set of\r\nlazy, twaddling, shiftless laborers, who had grown up, all their lives,\r\nin the absence of every possible motive to learn how to do anything but\r\n\xe2\x80\x98shirk,\xe2\x80\x99 as you Vermonters say, and you\xe2\x80\x99ll see that there might\r\nnaturally be, on his plantation, a great many things that looked\r\nhorrible and distressing to a sensitive child, like me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBesides all, he had an overseer,\xe2\x80\x94great, tall, slab-sided, two-fisted\r\nrenegade son of Vermont\xe2\x80\x94(begging your pardon),\xe2\x80\x94who had gone through a\r\nregular apprenticeship in hardness and brutality and taken his degree\r\nto be admitted to practice. My mother never could endure him, nor I;\r\nbut he obtained an entire ascendency over my father; and this man was\r\nthe absolute despot of the estate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was a little fellow then, but I had the same love that I have now\r\nfor all kinds of human things,\xe2\x80\x94a kind of passion for the study of\r\nhumanity, come in what shape it would. I was found in the cabins and\r\namong the field-hands a great deal, and, of course, was a great\r\nfavorite; and all sorts of complaints and grievances were breathed in\r\nmy ear; and I told them to mother, and we, between us, formed a sort of\r\ncommittee for a redress of grievances. We hindered and repressed a\r\ngreat deal of cruelty, and congratulated ourselves on doing a vast deal\r\nof good, till, as often happens, my zeal overacted. Stubbs complained\r\nto my father that he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t manage the hands, and must resign his\r\nposition. Father was a fond, indulgent husband, but a man that never\r\nflinched from anything that he thought necessary; and so he put down\r\nhis foot, like a rock, between us and the field-hands. He told my\r\nmother, in language perfectly respectful and deferential, but quite\r\nexplicit, that over the house-servants she should be entire mistress,\r\nbut that with the field-hands he could allow no interference. He\r\nrevered and respected her above all living beings; but he would have\r\nsaid it all the same to the virgin Mary herself, if she had come in the\r\nway of his system.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI used sometimes to hear my mother reasoning cases with\r\nhim,\xe2\x80\x94endeavoring to excite his sympathies. He would listen to the most\r\npathetic appeals with the most discouraging politeness and equanimity.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It all resolves itself into this,\xe2\x80\x99 he would say; \xe2\x80\x98must I part with\r\nStubbs, or keep him? Stubbs is the soul of punctuality, honesty, and\r\nefficiency,\xe2\x80\x94a thorough business hand, and as humane as the general run.\r\nWe can\xe2\x80\x99t have perfection; and if I keep him, I must sustain his\r\nadministration as a _whole_, even if there are, now and then, things\r\nthat are exceptionable. All government includes some necessary\r\nhardness. General rules will bear hard on particular cases.\xe2\x80\x99 This last\r\nmaxim my father seemed to consider a settler in most alleged cases of\r\ncruelty. After he had said _that_, he commonly drew up his feet on the\r\nsofa, like a man that has disposed of a business, and betook himself to\r\na nap, or the newspaper, as the case might be.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe fact is my father showed the exact sort of talent for a statesman.\r\nHe could have divided Poland as easily as an orange, or trod on Ireland\r\nas quietly and systematically as any man living. At last my mother gave\r\nup, in despair. It never will be known, till the last account, what\r\nnoble and sensitive natures like hers have felt, cast, utterly\r\nhelpless, into what seems to them an abyss of injustice and cruelty,\r\nand which seems so to nobody about them. It has been an age of long\r\nsorrow of such natures, in such a hell-begotten sort of world as ours.\r\nWhat remained for her, but to train her children in her own views and\r\nsentiments? Well, after all you say about training, children will grow\r\nup substantially what they _are_ by nature, and only that. From the\r\ncradle, Alfred was an aristocrat; and as he grew up, instinctively, all\r\nhis sympathies and all his reasonings were in that line, and all\r\nmother\xe2\x80\x99s exhortations went to the winds. As to me, they sunk deep into\r\nme. She never contradicted, in form, anything my father said, or seemed\r\ndirectly to differ from him; but she impressed, burnt into my very\r\nsoul, with all the force of her deep, earnest nature, an idea of the\r\ndignity and worth of the meanest human soul. I have looked in her face\r\nwith solemn awe, when she would point up to the stars in the evening,\r\nand say to me, \xe2\x80\x99See there, Auguste! the poorest, meanest soul on our\r\nplace will be living, when all these stars are gone forever,\xe2\x80\x94will live\r\nas long as God lives!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe had some fine old paintings; one, in particular, of Jesus healing\r\na blind man. They were very fine, and used to impress me strongly. \xe2\x80\x98See\r\nthere, Auguste,\xe2\x80\x99 she would say; \xe2\x80\x98the blind man was a beggar, poor and\r\nloathsome; therefore, he would not heal him _afar off!_ He called him\r\nto him, and put _his hands on him!_ Remember this, my boy.\xe2\x80\x99 If I had\r\nlived to grow up under her care, she might have stimulated me to I know\r\nnot what of enthusiasm. I might have been a saint, reformer,\r\nmartyr,\xe2\x80\x94but, alas! alas! I went from her when I was only thirteen, and\r\nI never saw her again!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSt. Clare rested his head on his hands, and did not speak for some\r\nminutes. After a while, he looked up, and went on:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat poor, mean trash this whole business of human virtue is! A mere\r\nmatter, for the most part, of latitude and longitude, and geographical\r\nposition, acting with natural temperament. The greater part is nothing\r\nbut an accident! Your father, for example, settles in Vermont, in a\r\ntown where all are, in fact, free and equal; becomes a regular church\r\nmember and deacon, and in due time joins an Abolition society, and\r\nthinks us all little better than heathens. Yet he is, for all the\r\nworld, in constitution and habit, a duplicate of my father. I can see\r\nit leaking out in fifty different ways,\xe2\x80\x94just the same strong,\r\noverbearing, dominant spirit. You know very well how impossible it is\r\nto persuade some of the folks in your village that Squire Sinclair does\r\nnot feel above them. The fact is, though he has fallen on democratic\r\ntimes, and embraced a democratic theory, he is to the heart an\r\naristocrat, as much as my father, who ruled over five or six hundred\r\nslaves.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia felt rather disposed to cavil at this picture, and was\r\nlaying down her knitting to begin, but St. Clare stopped her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, I know every word you are going to say. I do not say they _were_\r\nalike, in fact. One fell into a condition where everything acted\r\nagainst the natural tendency, and the other where everything acted for\r\nit; and so one turned out a pretty wilful, stout, overbearing old\r\ndemocrat, and the other a wilful, stout old despot. If both had owned\r\nplantations in Louisiana, they would have been as like as two old\r\nbullets cast in the same mould.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat an undutiful boy you are!\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t mean them any disrespect,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare. \xe2\x80\x9cYou know reverence\r\nis not my forte. But, to go back to my history:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen father died, he left the whole property to us twin boys, to be\r\ndivided as we should agree. There does not breathe on God\xe2\x80\x99s earth a\r\nnobler-souled, more generous fellow, than Alfred, in all that concerns\r\nhis equals; and we got on admirably with this property question,\r\nwithout a single unbrotherly word or feeling. We undertook to work the\r\nplantation together; and Alfred, whose outward life and capabilities\r\nhad double the strength of mine, became an enthusiastic planter, and a\r\nwonderfully successful one.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut two years\xe2\x80\x99 trial satisfied me that I could not be a partner in\r\nthat matter. To have a great gang of seven hundred, whom I could not\r\nknow personally, or feel any individual interest in, bought and driven,\r\nhoused, fed, worked like so many horned cattle, strained up to military\r\nprecision,\xe2\x80\x94the question of how little of life\xe2\x80\x99s commonest enjoyments\r\nwould keep them in working order being a constantly recurring\r\nproblem,\xe2\x80\x94the necessity of drivers and overseers,\xe2\x80\x94the ever-necessary\r\nwhip, first, last, and only argument,\xe2\x80\x94the whole thing was insufferably\r\ndisgusting and loathsome to me; and when I thought of my mother\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nestimate of one poor human soul, it became even frightful!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s all nonsense to talk to me about slaves _enjoying_ all this! To\r\nthis day, I have no patience with the unutterable trash that some of\r\nyour patronizing Northerners have made up, as in their zeal to\r\napologize for our sins. We all know better. Tell me that any man living\r\nwants to work all his days, from day-dawn till dark, under the constant\r\neye of a master, without the power of putting forth one irresponsible\r\nvolition, on the same dreary, monotonous, unchanging toil, and all for\r\ntwo pairs of pantaloons and a pair of shoes a year, with enough food\r\nand shelter to keep him in working order! Any man who thinks that human\r\nbeings can, as a general thing, be made about as comfortable that way\r\nas any other, I wish he might try it. I\xe2\x80\x99d buy the dog, and work him,\r\nwith a clear conscience!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI always have supposed,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you, all of you,\r\napproved of these things, and thought them _right_\xe2\x80\x94according to\r\nScripture.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHumbug! We are not quite reduced to that yet. Alfred who is as\r\ndetermined a despot as ever walked, does not pretend to this kind of\r\ndefence;\xe2\x80\x94no, he stands, high and haughty, on that good old respectable\r\nground, _the right of the strongest_; and he says, and I think quite\r\nsensibly, that the American planter is \xe2\x80\x98only doing, in another form,\r\nwhat the English aristocracy and capitalists are doing by the lower\r\nclasses;\xe2\x80\x99 that is, I take it, _appropriating_ them, body and bone, soul\r\nand spirit, to their use and convenience. He defends both,\xe2\x80\x94and I think,\r\nat least, _consistently_. He says that there can be no high\r\ncivilization without enslavement of the masses, either nominal or real.\r\nThere must, he says, be a lower class, given up to physical toil and\r\nconfined to an animal nature; and a higher one thereby acquires leisure\r\nand wealth for a more expanded intelligence and improvement, and\r\nbecomes the directing soul of the lower. So he reasons, because, as I\r\nsaid, he is born an aristocrat;\xe2\x80\x94so I don\xe2\x80\x99t believe, because I was born\r\na democrat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow in the world can the two things be compared?\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe English laborer is not sold, traded, parted from his family,\r\nwhipped.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is as much at the will of his employer as if he were sold to him.\r\nThe slave-owner can whip his refractory slave to death,\xe2\x80\x94the capitalist\r\ncan starve him to death. As to family security, it is hard to say which\r\nis the worst,\xe2\x80\x94to have one\xe2\x80\x99s children sold, or see them starve to death\r\nat home.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut it\xe2\x80\x99s no kind of apology for slavery, to prove that it isn\xe2\x80\x99t worse\r\nthan some other bad thing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t give it for one,\xe2\x80\x94nay, I\xe2\x80\x99ll say, besides, that ours is the\r\nmore bold and palpable infringement of human rights; actually buying a\r\nman up, like a horse,\xe2\x80\x94looking at his teeth, cracking his joints, and\r\ntrying his paces and then paying down for him,\xe2\x80\x94having speculators,\r\nbreeders, traders, and brokers in human bodies and souls,\xe2\x80\x94sets the\r\nthing before the eyes of the civilized world in a more tangible form,\r\nthough the thing done be, after all, in its nature, the same; that is,\r\nappropriating one set of human beings to the use and improvement of\r\nanother without any regard to their own.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never thought of the matter in this light,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I\xe2\x80\x99ve travelled in England some, and I\xe2\x80\x99ve looked over a good many\r\ndocuments as to the state of their lower classes; and I really think\r\nthere is no denying Alfred, when he says that his slaves are better off\r\nthan a large class of the population of England. You see, you must not\r\ninfer, from what I have told you, that Alfred is what is called a hard\r\nmaster; for he isn\xe2\x80\x99t. He is despotic, and unmerciful to\r\ninsubordination; he would shoot a fellow down with as little remorse as\r\nhe would shoot a buck, if he opposed him. But, in general, he takes a\r\nsort of pride in having his slaves comfortably fed and accommodated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen I was with him, I insisted that he should do something for their\r\ninstruction; and, to please me, he did get a chaplain, and used to have\r\nthem catechized Sunday, though, I believe, in his heart, that he\r\nthought it would do about as much good to set a chaplain over his dogs\r\nand horses. And the fact is, that a mind stupefied and animalized by\r\nevery bad influence from the hour of birth, spending the whole of every\r\nweek-day in unreflecting toil, cannot be done much with by a few hours\r\non Sunday. The teachers of Sunday-schools among the manufacturing\r\npopulation of England, and among plantation-hands in our country, could\r\nperhaps testify to the same result, _there and here_. Yet some striking\r\nexceptions there are among us, from the fact that the negro is\r\nnaturally more impressible to religious sentiment than the white.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, \xe2\x80\x9chow came you to give up your plantation\r\nlife?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, we jogged on together some time, till Alfred saw plainly that I\r\nwas no planter. He thought it absurd, after he had reformed, and\r\naltered, and improved everywhere, to suit my notions, that I still\r\nremained unsatisfied. The fact was, it was, after all, the THING that I\r\nhated\xe2\x80\x94the using these men and women, the perpetuation of all this\r\nignorance, brutality and vice,\xe2\x80\x94just to make money for me!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBesides, I was always interfering in the details. Being myself one of\r\nthe laziest of mortals, I had altogether too much fellow-feeling for\r\nthe lazy; and when poor, shiftless dogs put stones at the bottom of\r\ntheir cotton-baskets to make them weigh heavier, or filled their sacks\r\nwith dirt, with cotton at the top, it seemed so exactly like what I\r\nshould do if I were they, I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t and wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have them flogged for\r\nit. Well, of course, there was an end of plantation discipline; and Alf\r\nand I came to about the same point that I and my respected father did,\r\nyears before. So he told me that I was a womanish sentimentalist, and\r\nwould never do for business life; and advised me to take the bank-stock\r\nand the New Orleans family mansion, and go to writing poetry, and let\r\nhim manage the plantation. So we parted, and I came here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut why didn\xe2\x80\x99t you free your slaves?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t up to that. To hold them as tools for money-making, I\r\ncould not;\xe2\x80\x94have them to help spend money, you know, didn\xe2\x80\x99t look quite\r\nso ugly to me. Some of them were old house-servants, to whom I was much\r\nattached; and the younger ones were children to the old. All were well\r\nsatisfied to be as they were.\xe2\x80\x9d He paused, and walked reflectively up\r\nand down the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere was,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, \xe2\x80\x9ca time in my life when I had plans and\r\nhopes of doing something in this world, more than to float and drift. I\r\nhad vague, indistinct yearnings to be a sort of emancipator,\xe2\x80\x94to free my\r\nnative land from this spot and stain. All young men have had such\r\nfever-fits, I suppose, some time,\xe2\x80\x94but then\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy didn\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia;\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cyou ought not to put your hand to\r\nthe plough, and look back.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, well, things didn\xe2\x80\x99t go with me as I expected, and I got the despair\r\nof living that Solomon did. I suppose it was a necessary incident to\r\nwisdom in us both; but, some how or other, instead of being actor and\r\nregenerator in society, I became a piece of driftwood, and have been\r\nfloating and eddying about, ever since. Alfred scolds me, every time we\r\nmeet; and he has the better of me, I grant,\xe2\x80\x94for he really does\r\nsomething; his life is a logical result of his opinions and mine is a\r\ncontemptible _non sequitur_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear cousin, can you be satisfied with such a way of spending your\r\nprobation?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSatisfied! Was I not just telling you I despised it? But, then, to\r\ncome back to this point,\xe2\x80\x94we were on this liberation business. I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nthink my feelings about slavery are peculiar. I find many men who, in\r\ntheir hearts, think of it just as I do. The land groans under it; and,\r\nbad as it is for the slave, it is worse, if anything, for the master.\r\nIt takes no spectacles to see that a great class of vicious,\r\nimprovident, degraded people, among us, are an evil to us, as well as\r\nto themselves. The capitalist and aristocrat of England cannot feel\r\nthat as we do, because they do not mingle with the class they degrade\r\nas we do. They are in our homes; they are the associates of our\r\nchildren, and they form their minds faster than we can; for they are a\r\nrace that children always will cling to and assimilate with. If Eva,\r\nnow, was not more angel than ordinary, she would be ruined. We might as\r\nwell allow the small-pox to run among them, and think our children\r\nwould not take it, as to let them be uninstructed and vicious, and\r\nthink our children will not be affected by that. Yet our laws\r\npositively and utterly forbid any efficient general educational system,\r\nand they do it wisely, too; for, just begin and thoroughly educate one\r\ngeneration, and the whole thing would be blown sky high. If we did not\r\ngive them liberty, they would take it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what do you think will be the end of this?\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know. One thing is certain,\xe2\x80\x94that there is a mustering among\r\nthe masses, the world over; and there is a _dies ir\xc3\xa6_ coming on, sooner\r\nor later. The same thing is working in Europe, in England, and in this\r\ncountry. My mother used to tell me of a millennium that was coming,\r\nwhen Christ should reign, and all men should be free and happy. And she\r\ntaught me, when I was a boy, to pray, \xe2\x80\x99thy kingdom come.\xe2\x80\x99 Sometimes I\r\nthink all this sighing, and groaning, and stirring among the dry bones\r\nforetells what she used to tell me was coming. But who may abide the\r\nday of His appearing?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAugustine, sometimes I think you are not far from the kingdom,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nMiss Ophelia, laying down her knitting, and looking anxiously at her\r\ncousin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you for your good opinion, but it\xe2\x80\x99s up and down with me,\xe2\x80\x94up to\r\nheaven\xe2\x80\x99s gate in theory, down in earth\xe2\x80\x99s dust in practice. But there\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nthe teabell,\xe2\x80\x94do let\xe2\x80\x99s go,\xe2\x80\x94and don\xe2\x80\x99t say, now, I haven\xe2\x80\x99t had one\r\ndownright serious talk, for once in my life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt table, Marie alluded to the incident of Prue. \xe2\x80\x9cI suppose you\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nthink, cousin,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cthat we are all barbarians.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think that\xe2\x80\x99s a barbarous thing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nthink you are all barbarians.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie, \xe2\x80\x9cI know it\xe2\x80\x99s impossible to get along with some\r\nof these creatures. They are so bad they ought not to live. I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nfeel a particle of sympathy for such cases. If they\xe2\x80\x99d only behave\r\nthemselves, it would not happen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, mamma,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva, \xe2\x80\x9cthe poor creature was unhappy; that\xe2\x80\x99s what\r\nmade her drink.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, fiddlestick! as if that were any excuse! I\xe2\x80\x99m unhappy, very often. I\r\npresume,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, pensively, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I\xe2\x80\x99ve had greater trials than ever\r\nshe had. It\xe2\x80\x99s just because they are so bad. There\xe2\x80\x99s some of them that\r\nyou cannot break in by any kind of severity. I remember father had a\r\nman that was so lazy he would run away just to get rid of work, and lie\r\nround in the swamps, stealing and doing all sorts of horrid things.\r\nThat man was caught and whipped, time and again, and it never did him\r\nany good; and the last time he crawled off, though he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t but just\r\ngo, and died in the swamp. There was no sort of reason for it, for\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s hands were always treated kindly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI broke a fellow in, once,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, \xe2\x80\x9cthat all the overseers\r\nand masters had tried their hands on in vain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou!\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie; \xe2\x80\x9cwell, I\xe2\x80\x99d be glad to know when _you_ ever did\r\nanything of the sort.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, he was a powerful, gigantic fellow,\xe2\x80\x94a native-born African; and\r\nhe appeared to have the rude instinct of freedom in him to an uncommon\r\ndegree. He was a regular African lion. They called him Scipio. Nobody\r\ncould do anything with him; and he was sold round from overseer to\r\noverseer, till at last Alfred bought him, because he thought he could\r\nmanage him. Well, one day he knocked down the overseer, and was fairly\r\noff into the swamps. I was on a visit to Alf\xe2\x80\x99s plantation, for it was\r\nafter we had dissolved partnership. Alfred was greatly exasperated; but\r\nI told him that it was his own fault, and laid him any wager that I\r\ncould break the man; and finally it was agreed that, if I caught him, I\r\nshould have him to experiment on. So they mustered out a party of some\r\nsix or seven, with guns and dogs, for the hunt. People, you know, can\r\nget up as much enthusiasm in hunting a man as a deer, if it is only\r\ncustomary; in fact, I got a little excited myself, though I had only\r\nput in as a sort of mediator, in case he was caught.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, the dogs bayed and howled, and we rode and scampered, and\r\nfinally we started him. He ran and bounded like a buck, and kept us\r\nwell in the rear for some time; but at last he got caught in an\r\nimpenetrable thicket of cane; then he turned to bay, and I tell you he\r\nfought the dogs right gallantly. He dashed them to right and left, and\r\nactually killed three of them with only his naked fists, when a shot\r\nfrom a gun brought him down, and he fell, wounded and bleeding, almost\r\nat my feet. The poor fellow looked up at me with manhood and despair\r\nboth in his eye. I kept back the dogs and the party, as they came\r\npressing up, and claimed him as my prisoner. It was all I could do to\r\nkeep them from shooting him, in the flush of success; but I persisted\r\nin my bargain, and Alfred sold him to me. Well, I took him in hand, and\r\nin one fortnight I had him tamed down as submissive and tractable as\r\nheart could desire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat in the world did you do to him?\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, it was quite a simple process. I took him to my own room, had a\r\ngood bed made for him, dressed his wounds, and tended him myself, until\r\nhe got fairly on his feet again. And, in process of time, I had free\r\npapers made out for him, and told him he might go where he liked.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd did he go?\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo. The foolish fellow tore the paper in two, and absolutely refused\r\nto leave me. I never had a braver, better fellow,\xe2\x80\x94trusty and true as\r\nsteel. He embraced Christianity afterwards, and became as gentle as a\r\nchild. He used to oversee my place on the lake, and did it capitally,\r\ntoo. I lost him the first cholera season. In fact, he laid down his\r\nlife for me. For I was sick, almost to death; and when, through the\r\npanic, everybody else fled, Scipio worked for me like a giant, and\r\nactually brought me back into life again. But, poor fellow! he was\r\ntaken, right after, and there was no saving him. I never felt anybody\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nloss more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEva had come gradually nearer and nearer to her father, as he told the\r\nstory,\xe2\x80\x94her small lips apart, her eyes wide and earnest with absorbing\r\ninterest.\r\n\r\nAs he finished, she suddenly threw her arms around his neck, burst into\r\ntears, and sobbed convulsively.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEva, dear child! what is the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, as the child\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsmall frame trembled and shook with the violence of her feelings. \xe2\x80\x9cThis\r\nchild,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, \xe2\x80\x9cought not to hear any of this kind of thing,\xe2\x80\x94she\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nnervous.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, papa, I\xe2\x80\x99m not nervous,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva, controlling herself, suddenly,\r\nwith a strength of resolution singular in such a child. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not\r\nnervous, but these things _sink into my heart_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean, Eva?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t tell you, papa, I think a great many thoughts. Perhaps some\r\nday I shall tell you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, think away, dear,\xe2\x80\x94only don\xe2\x80\x99t cry and worry your papa,\xe2\x80\x9d said St.\r\nClare, \xe2\x80\x9cLook here,\xe2\x80\x94see what a beautiful peach I have got for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEva took it and smiled, though there was still a nervous twiching about\r\nthe corners of her mouth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, look at the gold-fish,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, taking her hand and\r\nstepping on to the verandah. A few moments, and merry laughs were heard\r\nthrough the silken curtains, as Eva and St. Clare were pelting each\r\nother with roses, and chasing each other among the alleys of the court.\r\n\r\n\r\nThere is danger that our humble friend Tom be neglected amid the\r\nadventures of the higher born; but, if our readers will accompany us up\r\nto a little loft over the stable, they may, perhaps, learn a little of\r\nhis affairs. It was a decent room, containing a bed, a chair, and a\r\nsmall, rough stand, where lay Tom\xe2\x80\x99s Bible and hymn-book; and where he\r\nsits, at present, with his slate before him, intent on something that\r\nseems to cost him a great deal of anxious thought.\r\n\r\nThe fact was, that Tom\xe2\x80\x99s home-yearnings had become so strong that he\r\nhad begged a sheet of writing-paper of Eva, and, mustering up all his\r\nsmall stock of literary attainment acquired by Mas\xe2\x80\x99r George\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ninstructions, he conceived the bold idea of writing a letter; and he\r\nwas busy now, on his slate, getting out his first draft. Tom was in a\r\ngood deal of trouble, for the forms of some of the letters he had\r\nforgotten entirely; and of what he did remember, he did not know\r\nexactly which to use. And while he was working, and breathing very\r\nhard, in his earnestness, Eva alighted, like a bird, on the round of\r\nhis chair behind him, and peeped over his shoulder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Uncle Tom! what funny things you _are_ making, there!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m trying to write to my poor old woman, Miss Eva, and my little\r\nchil\xe2\x80\x99en,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, drawing the back of his hand over his eyes; \xe2\x80\x9cbut,\r\nsome how, I\xe2\x80\x99m feard I shan\xe2\x80\x99t make it out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish I could help you, Tom! I\xe2\x80\x99ve learnt to write some. Last year I\r\ncould make all the letters, but I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid I\xe2\x80\x99ve forgotten.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo Eva put her golden head close to his, and the two commenced a grave\r\nand anxious discussion, each one equally earnest, and about equally\r\nignorant; and, with a deal of consulting and advising over every word,\r\nthe composition began, as they both felt very sanguine, to look quite\r\nlike writing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Uncle Tom, it really begins to look beautiful,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva, gazing\r\ndelightedly on it. \xe2\x80\x9cHow pleased your wife\xe2\x80\x99ll be, and the poor little\r\nchildren! O, it\xe2\x80\x99s a shame you ever had to go away from them! I mean to\r\nask papa to let you go back, some time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMissis said that she would send down money for me, as soon as they\r\ncould get it together,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m \xe2\x80\x99spectin, she will. Young Mas\xe2\x80\x99r\r\nGeorge, he said he\xe2\x80\x99d come for me; and he gave me this yer dollar as a\r\nsign;\xe2\x80\x9d and Tom drew from under his clothes the precious dollar.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, he\xe2\x80\x99ll certainly come, then!\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m so glad!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I wanted to send a letter, you know, to let \xe2\x80\x99em know whar I was,\r\nand tell poor Chloe that I was well off,\xe2\x80\x94cause she felt so drefful,\r\npoor soul!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say Tom!\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare\xe2\x80\x99s voice, coming in the door at this moment.\r\n\r\nTom and Eva both started.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s here?\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, coming up and looking at the slate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, it\xe2\x80\x99s Tom\xe2\x80\x99s letter. I\xe2\x80\x99m helping him to write it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva; \xe2\x80\x9cisn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nit nice?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t discourage either of you,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I rather\r\nthink, Tom, you\xe2\x80\x99d better get me to write your letter for you. I\xe2\x80\x99ll do\r\nit, when I come home from my ride.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s very important he should write,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva, \xe2\x80\x9cbecause his mistress\r\nis going to send down money to redeem him, you know, papa; he told me\r\nthey told him so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSt. Clare thought, in his heart, that this was probably only one of\r\nthose things which good-natured owners say to their servants, to\r\nalleviate their horror of being sold, without any intention of\r\nfulfilling the expectation thus excited. But he did not make any\r\naudible comment upon it,\xe2\x80\x94only ordered Tom to get the horses out for a\r\nride.\r\n\r\nTom\xe2\x80\x99s letter was written in due form for him that evening, and safely\r\nlodged in the post-office.\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia still persevered in her labors in the housekeeping line.\r\nIt was universally agreed, among all the household, from Dinah down to\r\nthe youngest urchin, that Miss Ophelia was decidedly \xe2\x80\x9ccuris,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94a term by\r\nwhich a southern servant implies that his or her betters don\xe2\x80\x99t exactly\r\nsuit them.\r\n\r\nThe higher circle in the family\xe2\x80\x94to wit, Adolph, Jane and Rosa\xe2\x80\x94agreed\r\nthat she was no lady; ladies never keep working about as she did,\xe2\x80\x94that\r\nshe had no _air_ at all; and they were surprised that she should be any\r\nrelation of the St. Clares. Even Marie declared that it was absolutely\r\nfatiguing to see Cousin Ophelia always so busy. And, in fact, Miss\r\nOphelia\xe2\x80\x99s industry was so incessant as to lay some foundation for the\r\ncomplaint. She sewed and stitched away, from daylight till dark, with\r\nthe energy of one who is pressed on by some immediate urgency; and\r\nthen, when the light faded, and the work was folded away, with one turn\r\nout came the ever-ready knitting-work, and there she was again, going\r\non as briskly as ever. It really was a labor to see her.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XX\r\nTopsy\r\n\r\n\r\nOne morning, while Miss Ophelia was busy in some of her domestic cares,\r\nSt. Clare\xe2\x80\x99s voice was heard, calling her at the foot of the stairs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome down here, Cousin, I\xe2\x80\x99ve something to show you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, coming down, with her sewing in her\r\nhand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve made a purchase for your department,\xe2\x80\x94see here,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare;\r\nand, with the word, he pulled along a little negro girl, about eight or\r\nnine years of age.\r\n\r\nShe was one of the blackest of her race; and her round shining eyes,\r\nglittering as glass beads, moved with quick and restless glances over\r\neverything in the room. Her mouth, half open with astonishment at the\r\nwonders of the new Mas\xe2\x80\x99r\xe2\x80\x99s parlor, displayed a white and brilliant set\r\nof teeth. Her woolly hair was braided in sundry little tails, which\r\nstuck out in every direction. The expression of her face was an odd\r\nmixture of shrewdness and cunning, over which was oddly drawn, like a\r\nkind of veil, an expression of the most doleful gravity and solemnity.\r\nShe was dressed in a single filthy, ragged garment, made of bagging;\r\nand stood with her hands demurely folded before her. Altogether, there\r\nwas something odd and goblin-like about her appearance,\xe2\x80\x94something, as\r\nMiss Ophelia afterwards said, \xe2\x80\x9cso heathenish,\xe2\x80\x9d as to inspire that good\r\nlady with utter dismay; and turning to St. Clare, she said,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAugustine, what in the world have you brought that thing here for?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor you to educate, to be sure, and train in the way she should go. I\r\nthought she was rather a funny specimen in the Jim Crow line. Here,\r\nTopsy,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, giving a whistle, as a man would to call the\r\nattention of a dog, \xe2\x80\x9cgive us a song, now, and show us some of your\r\ndancing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe black, glassy eyes glittered with a kind of wicked drollery, and\r\nthe thing struck up, in a clear shrill voice, an odd negro melody, to\r\nwhich she kept time with her hands and feet, spinning round, clapping\r\nher hands, knocking her knees together, in a wild, fantastic sort of\r\ntime, and producing in her throat all those odd guttural sounds which\r\ndistinguish the native music of her race; and finally, turning a\r\nsummerset or two, and giving a prolonged closing note, as odd and\r\nunearthly as that of a steam-whistle, she came suddenly down on the\r\ncarpet, and stood with her hands folded, and a most sanctimonious\r\nexpression of meekness and solemnity over her face, only broken by the\r\ncunning glances which she shot askance from the corners of her eyes.\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia stood silent, perfectly paralyzed with amazement. St.\r\nClare, like a mischievous fellow as he was, appeared to enjoy her\r\nastonishment; and, addressing the child again, said,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTopsy, this is your new mistress. I\xe2\x80\x99m going to give you up to her; see\r\nnow that you behave yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r,\xe2\x80\x9d said Topsy, with sanctimonious gravity, her wicked eyes\r\ntwinkling as she spoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re going to be good, Topsy, you understand,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO yes, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r,\xe2\x80\x9d said Topsy, with another twinkle, her hands still\r\ndevoutly folded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, Augustine, what upon earth is this for?\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia. \xe2\x80\x9cYour\r\nhouse is so full of these little plagues, now, that a body can\xe2\x80\x99t set\r\ndown their foot without treading on \xe2\x80\x99em. I get up in the morning, and\r\nfind one asleep behind the door, and see one black head poking out from\r\nunder the table, one lying on the door-mat,\xe2\x80\x94and they are mopping and\r\nmowing and grinning between all the railings, and tumbling over the\r\nkitchen floor! What on earth did you want to bring this one for?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor you to educate\xe2\x80\x94didn\xe2\x80\x99t I tell you? You\xe2\x80\x99re always preaching about\r\neducating. I thought I would make you a present of a fresh-caught\r\nspecimen, and let you try your hand on her, and bring her up in the way\r\nshe should go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_I_ don\xe2\x80\x99t want her, I am sure;\xe2\x80\x94I have more to do with \xe2\x80\x99em now than I\r\nwant to.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s you Christians, all over!\xe2\x80\x94you\xe2\x80\x99ll get up a society, and get some\r\npoor missionary to spend all his days among just such heathen. But let\r\nme see one of you that would take one into your house with you, and\r\ntake the labor of their conversion on yourselves! No; when it comes to\r\nthat, they are dirty and disagreeable, and it\xe2\x80\x99s too much care, and so\r\non.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAugustine, you know I didn\xe2\x80\x99t think of it in that light,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss\r\nOphelia, evidently softening. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, it might be a real missionary\r\nwork,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, looking rather more favorably on the child.\r\n\r\nSt. Clare had touched the right string. Miss Ophelia\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nconscientiousness was ever on the alert. \xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d she added, \xe2\x80\x9cI really\r\ndidn\xe2\x80\x99t see the need of buying this one;\xe2\x80\x94there are enough now, in your\r\nhouse, to take all my time and skill.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, Cousin,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, drawing her aside, \xe2\x80\x9cI ought to\r\nbeg your pardon for my good-for-nothing speeches. You are so good,\r\nafter all, that there\xe2\x80\x99s no sense in them. Why, the fact is, this\r\nconcern belonged to a couple of drunken creatures that keep a low\r\nrestaurant that I have to pass by every day, and I was tired of hearing\r\nher screaming, and them beating and swearing at her. She looked bright\r\nand funny, too, as if something might be made of her;\xe2\x80\x94so I bought her,\r\nand I\xe2\x80\x99ll give her to you. Try, now, and give her a good orthodox New\r\nEngland bringing up, and see what it\xe2\x80\x99ll make of her. You know I haven\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nany gift that way; but I\xe2\x80\x99d like you to try.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I\xe2\x80\x99ll do what I can,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia; and she approached her\r\nnew subject very much as a person might be supposed to approach a black\r\nspider, supposing them to have benevolent designs toward it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s dreadfully dirty, and half naked,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, take her down stairs, and make some of them clean and clothe her\r\nup.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia carried her to the kitchen regions.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t see what Mas\xe2\x80\x99r St. Clare wants of \xe2\x80\x99nother nigger!\xe2\x80\x9d said Dinah,\r\nsurveying the new arrival with no friendly air. \xe2\x80\x9cWon\xe2\x80\x99t have her around\r\nunder _my_ feet, _I_ know!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPah!\xe2\x80\x9d said Rosa and Jane, with supreme disgust; \xe2\x80\x9clet her keep out of\r\nour way! What in the world Mas\xe2\x80\x99r wanted another of these low niggers\r\nfor, I can\xe2\x80\x99t see!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou go long! No more nigger dan you be, Miss Rosa,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dinah, who\r\nfelt this last remark a reflection on herself. \xe2\x80\x9cYou seem to tink\r\nyourself white folks. You an\xe2\x80\x99t nerry one, black _nor_ white, I\xe2\x80\x99d like\r\nto be one or turrer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia saw that there was nobody in the camp that would undertake\r\nto oversee the cleansing and dressing of the new arrival; and so she\r\nwas forced to do it herself, with some very ungracious and reluctant\r\nassistance from Jane.\r\n\r\nIt is not for ears polite to hear the particulars of the first toilet\r\nof a neglected, abused child. In fact, in this world, multitudes must\r\nlive and die in a state that it would be too great a shock to the\r\nnerves of their fellow-mortals even to hear described. Miss Ophelia had\r\na good, strong, practical deal of resolution; and she went through all\r\nthe disgusting details with heroic thoroughness, though, it must be\r\nconfessed, with no very gracious air,\xe2\x80\x94for endurance was the utmost to\r\nwhich her principles could bring her. When she saw, on the back and\r\nshoulders of the child, great welts and calloused spots, ineffaceable\r\nmarks of the system under which she had grown up thus far, her heart\r\nbecame pitiful within her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee there!\xe2\x80\x9d said Jane, pointing to the marks, \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t that show she\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\nlimb? We\xe2\x80\x99ll have fine works with her, I reckon. I hate these nigger\r\nyoung uns! so disgusting! I wonder that Mas\xe2\x80\x99r would buy her!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe \xe2\x80\x9cyoung un\xe2\x80\x9d alluded to heard all these comments with the subdued and\r\ndoleful air which seemed habitual to her, only scanning, with a keen\r\nand furtive glance of her flickering eyes, the ornaments which Jane\r\nwore in her ears. When arrayed at last in a suit of decent and whole\r\nclothing, her hair cropped short to her head, Miss Ophelia, with some\r\nsatisfaction, said she looked more Christian-like than she did, and in\r\nher own mind began to mature some plans for her instruction.\r\n\r\nSitting down before her, she began to question her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow old are you, Topsy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDun no, Missis,\xe2\x80\x9d said the image, with a grin that showed all her\r\nteeth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t know how old you are? Didn\xe2\x80\x99t anybody ever tell you? Who was your\r\nmother?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever had none!\xe2\x80\x9d said the child, with another grin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever had any mother? What do you mean? Where were you born?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever was born!\xe2\x80\x9d persisted Topsy, with another grin, that looked so\r\ngoblin-like, that, if Miss Ophelia had been at all nervous, she might\r\nhave fancied that she had got hold of some sooty gnome from the land of\r\nDiablerie; but Miss Ophelia was not nervous, but plain and\r\nbusiness-like, and she said, with some sternness,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou mustn\xe2\x80\x99t answer me in that way, child; I\xe2\x80\x99m not playing with you.\r\nTell me where you were born, and who your father and mother were.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever was born,\xe2\x80\x9d reiterated the creature, more emphatically; \xe2\x80\x9cnever\r\nhad no father nor mother, nor nothin\xe2\x80\x99. I was raised by a speculator,\r\nwith lots of others. Old Aunt Sue used to take car on us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe child was evidently sincere, and Jane, breaking into a short laugh,\r\nsaid,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLaws, Missis, there\xe2\x80\x99s heaps of \xe2\x80\x99em. Speculators buys \xe2\x80\x99em up cheap,\r\nwhen they\xe2\x80\x99s little, and gets \xe2\x80\x99em raised for market.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow long have you lived with your master and mistress?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDun no, Missis.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it a year, or more, or less?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDun no, Missis.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLaws, Missis, those low negroes,\xe2\x80\x94they can\xe2\x80\x99t tell; they don\xe2\x80\x99t know\r\nanything about time,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jane; \xe2\x80\x9cthey don\xe2\x80\x99t know what a year is; they\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t know their own ages.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you ever heard anything about God, Topsy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe child looked bewildered, but grinned as usual.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know who made you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNobody, as I knows on,\xe2\x80\x9d said the child, with a short laugh.\r\n\r\nThe idea appeared to amuse her considerably; for her eyes twinkled, and\r\nshe added,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI spect I grow\xe2\x80\x99d. Don\xe2\x80\x99t think nobody never made me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know how to sew?\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, who thought she would turn\r\nher inquiries to something more tangible.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Missis.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat can you do?\xe2\x80\x94what did you do for your master and mistress?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFetch water, and wash dishes, and rub knives, and wait on folks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWere they good to you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpect they was,\xe2\x80\x9d said the child, scanning Miss Ophelia cunningly.\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia rose from this encouraging colloquy; St. Clare was leaning\r\nover the back of her chair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou find virgin soil there, Cousin; put in your own ideas,\xe2\x80\x94you won\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nfind many to pull up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia\xe2\x80\x99s ideas of education, like all her other ideas, were very\r\nset and definite; and of the kind that prevailed in New England a\r\ncentury ago, and which are still preserved in some very retired and\r\nunsophisticated parts, where there are no railroads. As nearly as could\r\nbe expressed, they could be comprised in very few words: to teach them\r\nto mind when they were spoken to; to teach them the catechism, sewing,\r\nand reading; and to whip them if they told lies. And though, of course,\r\nin the flood of light that is now poured on education, these are left\r\nfar away in the rear, yet it is an undisputed fact that our\r\ngrandmothers raised some tolerably fair men and women under this\r\nregime, as many of us can remember and testify. At all events, Miss\r\nOphelia knew of nothing else to do; and, therefore, applied her mind to\r\nher heathen with the best diligence she could command.\r\n\r\nThe child was announced and considered in the family as Miss Ophelia\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ngirl; and, as she was looked upon with no gracious eye in the kitchen,\r\nMiss Ophelia resolved to confine her sphere of operation and\r\ninstruction chiefly to her own chamber. With a self-sacrifice which\r\nsome of our readers will appreciate, she resolved, instead of\r\ncomfortably making her own bed, sweeping and dusting her own\r\nchamber,\xe2\x80\x94which she had hitherto done, in utter scorn of all offers of\r\nhelp from the chambermaid of the establishment,\xe2\x80\x94to condemn herself to\r\nthe martyrdom of instructing Topsy to perform these operations,\xe2\x80\x94ah, woe\r\nthe day! Did any of our readers ever do the same, they will appreciate\r\nthe amount of her self-sacrifice.\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia began with Topsy by taking her into her chamber, the first\r\nmorning, and solemnly commencing a course of instruction in the art and\r\nmystery of bed-making.\r\n\r\nBehold, then, Topsy, washed and shorn of all the little braided tails\r\nwherein her heart had delighted, arrayed in a clean gown, with\r\nwell-starched apron, standing reverently before Miss Ophelia, with an\r\nexpression of solemnity well befitting a funeral.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, Topsy, I\xe2\x80\x99m going to show you just how my bed is to be made. I am\r\nvery particular about my bed. You must learn exactly how to do it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d says Topsy, with a deep sigh, and a face of woful\r\nearnestness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, Topsy, look here;\xe2\x80\x94this is the hem of the sheet,\xe2\x80\x94this is the right\r\nside of the sheet, and this is the wrong;\xe2\x80\x94will you remember?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d says Topsy, with another sigh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now, the under sheet you must bring over the bolster,\xe2\x80\x94so\xe2\x80\x94and\r\ntuck it clear down under the mattress nice and smooth,\xe2\x80\x94so,\xe2\x80\x94do you see?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d said Topsy, with profound attention.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut the upper sheet,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, \xe2\x80\x9cmust be brought down in this\r\nway, and tucked under firm and smooth at the foot,\xe2\x80\x94so,\xe2\x80\x94the narrow hem\r\nat the foot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d said Topsy, as before;\xe2\x80\x94but we will add, what Miss Ophelia\r\ndid not see, that, during the time when the good lady\xe2\x80\x99s back was turned\r\nin the zeal of her manipulations, the young disciple had contrived to\r\nsnatch a pair of gloves and a ribbon, which she had adroitly slipped\r\ninto her sleeves, and stood with her hands dutifully folded, as before.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, Topsy, let\xe2\x80\x99s see _you_ do this,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, pulling off\r\nthe clothes, and seating herself.\r\n\r\nTopsy, with great gravity and adroitness, went through the exercise\r\ncompletely to Miss Ophelia\xe2\x80\x99s satisfaction; smoothing the sheets,\r\npatting out every wrinkle, and exhibiting, through the whole process, a\r\ngravity and seriousness with which her instructress was greatly\r\nedified. By an unlucky slip, however, a fluttering fragment of the\r\nribbon hung out of one of her sleeves, just as she was finishing, and\r\ncaught Miss Ophelia\xe2\x80\x99s attention. Instantly, she pounced upon it.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s this? I took Miss Eva\xe2\x80\x99s red thing she wars on her neck.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou did, you naughty child!\xe2\x80\x94Well, what else?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI took Rosa\xe2\x80\x99s yer-rings,\xe2\x80\x94them red ones.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo bring them to me this minute, both of \xe2\x80\x99em.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLaws, Missis! I would,\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99d let her catch it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no Rosa,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva, with an air of command, which the child could\r\nassume at times; \xe2\x80\x9cyou mustn\xe2\x80\x99t talk so, Rosa. She can\r\nspeak, for all the world, just like her papa,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, as she passed\r\nout of the room.\r\n\r\nEva stood looking at Topsy.\r\n\r\nThere stood the two children representatives of the two extremes of\r\nsociety. The fair, high-bred child, with her golden head, her deep\r\neyes, her spiritual, noble brow, and prince-like movements; and her\r\nblack, keen, subtle, cringing, yet acute neighbor. They stood the\r\nrepresentatives of their races. The Saxon, born of ages of cultivation,\r\ncommand, education, physical and moral eminence; the Afric, born of\r\nages of oppression, submission, ignorance, toil and vice!\r\n\r\nSomething, perhaps, of such thoughts struggled through Eva\xe2\x80\x99s mind. But\r\na child\xe2\x80\x99s thoughts are rather dim, undefined instincts; and in Eva\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nnoble nature many such were yearning and working, for which she had no\r\npower of utterance. When Miss Ophelia expatiated on Topsy\xe2\x80\x99s naughty,\r\nwicked conduct, the child looked perplexed and sorrowful, but said,\r\nsweetly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor Topsy, why need you steal? You\xe2\x80\x99re going to be taken good care of\r\nnow. No! the ear that has never heard anything but abuse is strangely\r\nincredulous of anything so heavenly as kindness; and Topsy only thought\r\nEva\xe2\x80\x99s speech something funny and inexplicable,\xe2\x80\x94she did not believe it.\r\n\r\nBut what was to be done with Topsy? Miss Ophelia found the case a\r\npuzzler; her rules for bringing up didn\xe2\x80\x99t seem to apply. She thought\r\nshe would take time to think of it; and, by the way of gaining time,\r\nand in hopes of some indefinite moral virtues supposed to be inherent\r\nin dark closets, Miss Ophelia shut Topsy up in one till she had\r\narranged her ideas further on the subject.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t see,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia to St. Clare, \xe2\x80\x9chow I\xe2\x80\x99m going to manage\r\nthat child, without whipping her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, whip her, then, to your heart\xe2\x80\x99s content; I\xe2\x80\x99ll give you full\r\npower to do what you like.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cChildren always have to be whipped,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia; \xe2\x80\x9cI never heard\r\nof bringing them up without.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, well, certainly,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare; \xe2\x80\x9cdo as you think best. Only I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nmake one suggestion: I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen this child whipped with a poker, knocked\r\ndown with the shovel or tongs, whichever came handiest, &c.; and,\r\nseeing that she is used to that style of operation, I think your\r\nwhippings will have to be pretty energetic, to make much impression.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is to be done with her, then?\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have started a serious question,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare; \xe2\x80\x9cI wish you\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nanswer it. What is to be done with a human being that can be governed\r\nonly by the lash,\xe2\x80\x94_that_ fails,\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s a very common state of things down\r\nhere!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sure I don\xe2\x80\x99t know; I never saw such a child as this.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuch children are very common among us, and such men and women, too.\r\nHow are they to be governed?\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sure it\xe2\x80\x99s more than I can say,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOr I either,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare. \xe2\x80\x9cThe horrid cruelties and outrages that\r\nonce and a while find their way into the papers,\xe2\x80\x94such cases as Prue\xe2\x80\x99s,\r\nfor example,\xe2\x80\x94what do they come from? In many cases, it is a gradual\r\nhardening process on both sides,\xe2\x80\x94the owner growing more and more cruel,\r\nas the servant more and more callous. Whipping and abuse are like\r\nlaudanum; you have to double the dose as the sensibilities decline. I\r\nsaw this very early when I became an owner; and I resolved never to\r\nbegin, because I did not know when I should stop,\xe2\x80\x94and I resolved, at\r\nleast, to protect my own moral nature. The consequence is, that my\r\nservants act like spoiled children; but I think that better than for us\r\nboth to be brutalized together. You have talked a great deal about our\r\nresponsibilities in educating, Cousin. I really wanted you to _try_\r\nwith one child, who is a specimen of thousands among us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is your system makes such children,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know it; but they are _made_,\xe2\x80\x94they exist,\xe2\x80\x94and what _is_ to be done\r\nwith them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I can\xe2\x80\x99t say I thank you for the experiment. But, then, as it\r\nappears to be a duty, I shall persevere and try, and do the best I\r\ncan,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia; and Miss Ophelia, after this, did labor, with\r\na commendable degree of zeal and energy, on her new subject. She\r\ninstituted regular hours and employments for her, and undertook to\r\nteach her to read and sew.\r\n\r\nIn the former art, the child was quick enough. She learned her letters\r\nas if by magic, and was very soon able to read plain reading; but the\r\nsewing was a more difficult matter. The creature was as lithe as a cat,\r\nand as active as a monkey, and the confinement of sewing was her\r\nabomination; so she broke her needles, threw them slyly out of the\r\nwindow, or down in chinks of the walls; she tangled, broke, and dirtied\r\nher thread, or, with a sly movement, would throw a spool away\r\naltogether. Her motions were almost as quick as those of a practised\r\nconjurer, and her command of her face quite as great; and though Miss\r\nOphelia could not help feeling that so many accidents could not\r\npossibly happen in succession, yet she could not, without a\r\nwatchfulness which would leave her no time for anything else, detect\r\nher.\r\n\r\nTopsy was soon a noted character in the establishment. Her talent for\r\nevery species of drollery, grimace, and mimicry,\xe2\x80\x94for dancing, tumbling,\r\nclimbing, singing, whistling, imitating every sound that hit her\r\nfancy,\xe2\x80\x94seemed inexhaustible. In her play-hours, she invariably had\r\nevery child in the establishment at her heels, open-mouthed with\r\nadmiration and wonder,\xe2\x80\x94not excepting Miss Eva, who appeared to be\r\nfascinated by her wild diablerie, as a dove is sometimes charmed by a\r\nglittering serpent. Miss Ophelia was uneasy that Eva should fancy\r\nTopsy\xe2\x80\x99s society so much, and implored St. Clare to forbid it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoh! let the child alone,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare. \xe2\x80\x9cTopsy will do her good.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut so depraved a child,\xe2\x80\x94are you not afraid she will teach her some\r\nmischief?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe can\xe2\x80\x99t teach her mischief; she might teach it to some children, but\r\nevil rolls off Eva\xe2\x80\x99s mind like dew off a cabbage-leaf,\xe2\x80\x94not a drop sinks\r\nin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t be too sure,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia. \xe2\x80\x9cI know I\xe2\x80\x99d never let a child\r\nof mine play with Topsy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, your children needn\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, \xe2\x80\x9cbut mine may; if Eva\r\ncould have been spoiled, it would have been done years ago.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTopsy was at first despised and contemned by the upper servants. They\r\nsoon found reason to alter their opinion. It was very soon discovered\r\nthat whoever cast an indignity on Topsy was sure to meet with some\r\ninconvenient accident shortly after;\xe2\x80\x94either a pair of ear-rings or some\r\ncherished trinket would be missing, or an article of dress would be\r\nsuddenly found utterly ruined, or the person would stumble accidently\r\ninto a pail of hot water, or a libation of dirty slop would\r\nunaccountably deluge them from above when in full gala dress;-and on\r\nall these occasions, when investigation was made, there was nobody\r\nfound to stand sponsor for the indignity. Topsy was cited, and had up\r\nbefore all the domestic judicatories, time and again; but always\r\nsustained her examinations with most edifying innocence and gravity of\r\nappearance. Nobody in the world ever doubted who did the things; but\r\nnot a scrap of any direct evidence could be found to establish the\r\nsuppositions, and Miss Ophelia was too just to feel at liberty to\r\nproceed to any length without it.\r\n\r\nThe mischiefs done were always so nicely timed, also, as further to\r\nshelter the aggressor. Thus, the times for revenge on Rosa and Jane,\r\nthe two chamber maids, were always chosen in those seasons when (as not\r\nunfrequently happened) they were in disgrace with their mistress, when\r\nany complaint from them would of course meet with no sympathy. In\r\nshort, Topsy soon made the household understand the propriety of\r\nletting her alone; and she was let alone, accordingly.\r\n\r\nTopsy was smart and energetic in all manual operations, learning\r\neverything that was taught her with surprising quickness. With a few\r\nlessons, she had learned to do the proprieties of Miss Ophelia\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nchamber in a way with which even that particular lady could find no\r\nfault. Mortal hands could not lay spread smoother, adjust pillows more\r\naccurately, sweep and dust and arrange more perfectly, than Topsy, when\r\nshe chose,\xe2\x80\x94but she didn\xe2\x80\x99t very often choose. If Miss Ophelia, after\r\nthree or four days of careful patient supervision, was so sanguine as\r\nto suppose that Topsy had at last fallen into her way, could do without\r\nover-looking, and so go off and busy herself about something else,\r\nTopsy would hold a perfect carnival of confusion, for some one or two\r\nhours. Instead of making the bed, she would amuse herself with pulling\r\noff the pillowcases, butting her woolly head among the pillows, till it\r\nwould sometimes be grotesquely ornamented with feathers sticking out in\r\nvarious directions; she would climb the posts, and hang head downward\r\nfrom the tops; flourish the sheets and spreads all over the apartment;\r\ndress the bolster up in Miss Ophelia\xe2\x80\x99s night-clothes, and enact various\r\nperformances with that,\xe2\x80\x94singing and whistling, and making grimaces at\r\nherself in the looking-glass; in short, as Miss Ophelia phrased it,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9craising Cain\xe2\x80\x9d generally.\r\n\r\nOn one occasion, Miss Ophelia found Topsy with her very best scarlet\r\nIndia Canton crape shawl wound round her head for a turban, going on\r\nwith her rehearsals before the glass in great style,\xe2\x80\x94Miss Ophelia\r\nhaving, with carelessness most unheard-of in her, left the key for once\r\nin her drawer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTopsy!\xe2\x80\x9d she would say, when at the end of all patience, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat does\r\nmake you act so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDunno, Missis,\xe2\x80\x94I spects cause I \xe2\x80\x99s so wicked!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know anything what I shall do with you, Topsy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLaw, Missis, you must whip me; my old Missis allers whipped me. I an\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nused to workin\xe2\x80\x99 unless I gets whipped.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, Topsy, I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to whip you. You can do well, if you\xe2\x80\x99ve a\r\nmind to; what is the reason you won\xe2\x80\x99t?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLaws, Missis, I \xe2\x80\x99s used to whippin\xe2\x80\x99; I spects it\xe2\x80\x99s good for me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia tried the recipe, and Topsy invariably made a terrible\r\ncommotion, screaming, groaning and imploring, though half an hour\r\nafterwards, when roosted on some projection of the balcony, and\r\nsurrounded by a flock of admiring \xe2\x80\x9cyoung uns,\xe2\x80\x9d she would express the\r\nutmost contempt of the whole affair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLaw, Miss Feely whip!\xe2\x80\x94wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t kill a skeeter, her whippins. Oughter\r\nsee how old Mas\xe2\x80\x99r made the flesh fly; old Mas\xe2\x80\x99r know\xe2\x80\x99d how!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTopsy always made great capital of her own sins and enormities,\r\nevidently considering them as something peculiarly distinguishing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLaw, you niggers,\xe2\x80\x9d she would say to some of her auditors, \xe2\x80\x9cdoes you\r\nknow you \xe2\x80\x99s all sinners? Well, you is\xe2\x80\x94everybody is. White folks is\r\nsinners too,\xe2\x80\x94Miss Feely says so; but I spects niggers is the biggest\r\nones; but lor! ye an\xe2\x80\x99t any on ye up to me. I \xe2\x80\x99s so awful wicked there\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t nobody do nothin\xe2\x80\x99 with me. I used to keep old Missis a swarin\xe2\x80\x99 at\r\nme half de time. I spects I \xe2\x80\x99s the wickedest critter in the world;\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\nTopsy would cut a summerset, and come up brisk and shining on to a\r\nhigher perch, and evidently plume herself on the distinction.\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia busied herself very earnestly on Sundays, teaching Topsy\r\nthe catechism. Topsy had an uncommon verbal memory, and committed with\r\na fluency that greatly encouraged her instructress.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat good do you expect it is going to do her?\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, it always has done children good. It\xe2\x80\x99s what children always have\r\nto learn, you know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnderstand it or not,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, children never understand it at the time; but, after they are grown\r\nup, it\xe2\x80\x99ll come to them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMine hasn\xe2\x80\x99t come to me yet,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, \xe2\x80\x9cthough I\xe2\x80\x99ll bear\r\ntestimony that you put it into me pretty thoroughly when I was a boy.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, you were always good at learning, Augustine.
