I used to have great\r\nhopes of you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, haven\xe2\x80\x99t you now?\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish you were as good as you were when you were a boy, Augustine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo do I, that\xe2\x80\x99s a fact, Cousin,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, go ahead and\r\ncatechize Topsy; may be you\xe2\x80\x99ll make out something yet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTopsy, who had stood like a black statue during this discussion, with\r\nhands decently folded, now, at a signal from Miss Ophelia, went on:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOur first parents, being left to the freedom of their own will, fell\r\nfrom the state wherein they were created.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTopsy\xe2\x80\x99s eyes twinkled, and she looked inquiringly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it, Topsy?\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlease, Missis, was dat ar state Kintuck?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat state, Topsy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDat state dey fell out of. I used to hear Mas\xe2\x80\x99r tell how we came down\r\nfrom Kintuck.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSt. Clare laughed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll have to give her a meaning, or she\xe2\x80\x99ll make one,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere seems to be a theory of emigration suggested there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO! Augustine, be still,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia; \xe2\x80\x9chow can I do anything, if\r\nyou will be laughing?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I won\xe2\x80\x99t disturb the exercises again, on my honor;\xe2\x80\x9d and St. Clare\r\ntook his paper into the parlor, and sat down, till Topsy had finished\r\nher recitations. They were all very well, only that now and then she\r\nwould oddly transpose some important words, and persist in the mistake,\r\nin spite of every effort to the contrary; and St. Clare, after all his\r\npromises of goodness, took a wicked pleasure in these mistakes, calling\r\nTopsy to him whenever he had a mind to amuse himself, and getting her\r\nto repeat the offending passages, in spite of Miss Ophelia\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nremonstrances.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do you think I can do anything with the child, if you will go on\r\nso, Augustine?\xe2\x80\x9d she would say.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, it is too bad,\xe2\x80\x94I won\xe2\x80\x99t again; but I do like to hear the droll\r\nlittle image stumble over those big words!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you confirm her in the wrong way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the odds? One word is as good as another to her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou wanted me to bring her up right; and you ought to remember she is\r\na reasonable creature, and be careful of your influence over her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, dismal! so I ought; but, as Topsy herself says, \xe2\x80\x99I \xe2\x80\x99s so wicked!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn very much this way Topsy\xe2\x80\x99s training proceeded, for a year or\r\ntwo,\xe2\x80\x94Miss Ophelia worrying herself, from day to day, with her, as a\r\nkind of chronic plague, to whose inflictions she became, in time, as\r\naccustomed, as persons sometimes do to the neuralgia or sick headache.\r\n\r\nSt. Clare took the same kind of amusement in the child that a man might\r\nin the tricks of a parrot or a pointer. Topsy, whenever her sins\r\nbrought her into disgrace in other quarters, always took refuge behind\r\nhis chair; and St. Clare, in one way or other, would make peace for\r\nher. From him she got many a stray picayune, which she laid out in nuts\r\nand candies, and distributed, with careless generosity, to all the\r\nchildren in the family; for Topsy, to do her justice, was good-natured\r\nand liberal, and only spiteful in self-defence. She is fairly\r\nintroduced into our _corps de ballet_, and will figure, from time to\r\ntime, in her turn, with other performers.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXI\r\nKentuck\r\n\r\n\r\nOur readers may not be unwilling to glance back, for a brief interval,\r\nat Uncle Tom\xe2\x80\x99s Cabin, on the Kentucky farm, and see what has been\r\ntranspiring among those whom he had left behind.\r\n\r\nIt was late in the summer afternoon, and the doors and windows of the\r\nlarge parlor all stood open, to invite any stray breeze, that might\r\nfeel in a good humor, to enter. Mr. Shelby sat in a large hall opening\r\ninto the room, and running through the whole length of the house, to a\r\nbalcony on either end. Leisurely tipped back on one chair, with his\r\nheels in another, he was enjoying his after-dinner cigar. Mrs. Shelby\r\nsat in the door, busy about some fine sewing; she seemed like one who\r\nhad something on her mind, which she was seeking an opportunity to\r\nintroduce.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cthat Chloe has had a letter from Tom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! has she? Tom \xe2\x80\x99s got some friend there, it seems. How is the old\r\nboy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe has been bought by a very fine family, I should think,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs.\r\nShelby,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cis kindly treated, and has not much to do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! well, I\xe2\x80\x99m glad of it,\xe2\x80\x94very glad,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Shelby, heartily. \xe2\x80\x9cTom,\r\nI suppose, will get reconciled to a Southern residence;\xe2\x80\x94hardly want to\r\ncome up here again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the contrary he inquires very anxiously,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Shelby, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen\r\nthe money for his redemption is to be raised.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sure _I_ don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Shelby. \xe2\x80\x9cOnce get business running\r\nwrong, there does seem to be no end to it. It\xe2\x80\x99s like jumping from one\r\nbog to another, all through a swamp; borrow of one to pay another, and\r\nthen borrow of another to pay one,\xe2\x80\x94and these confounded notes falling\r\ndue before a man has time to smoke a cigar and turn round,\xe2\x80\x94dunning\r\nletters and dunning messages,\xe2\x80\x94all scamper and hurry-scurry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt does seem to me, my dear, that something might be done to\r\nstraighten matters. Suppose we sell off all the horses, and sell one of\r\nyour farms, and pay up square?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, ridiculous, Emily! You are the finest woman in Kentucky; but still\r\nyou haven\xe2\x80\x99t sense to know that you don\xe2\x80\x99t understand business;\xe2\x80\x94women\r\nnever do, and never can.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, at least,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Shelby, \xe2\x80\x9ccould not you give me some little\r\ninsight into yours; a list of all your debts, at least, and of all that\r\nis owed to you, and let me try and see if I can\xe2\x80\x99t help you to\r\neconomize.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, bother! don\xe2\x80\x99t plague me, Emily!\xe2\x80\x94I can\xe2\x80\x99t tell exactly. I know\r\nsomewhere about what things are likely to be; but there\xe2\x80\x99s no trimming\r\nand squaring my affairs, as Chloe trims crust off her pies. You don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nknow anything about business, I tell you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd Mr. Shelby, not knowing any other way of enforcing his ideas,\r\nraised his voice,\xe2\x80\x94a mode of arguing very convenient and convincing,\r\nwhen a gentleman is discussing matters of business with his wife.\r\n\r\nMrs. Shelby ceased talking, with something of a sigh. The fact was,\r\nthat though her husband had stated she was a woman, she had a clear,\r\nenergetic, practical mind, and a force of character every way superior\r\nto that of her husband; so that it would not have been so very absurd a\r\nsupposition, to have allowed her capable of managing, as Mr. Shelby\r\nsupposed. Her heart was set on performing her promise to Tom and Aunt\r\nChloe, and she sighed as discouragements thickened around her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you think we might in some way contrive to raise that money?\r\nPoor Aunt Chloe! her heart is so set on it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sorry, if it is. I think I was premature in promising. I\xe2\x80\x99m not\r\nsure, now, but it\xe2\x80\x99s the best way to tell Chloe, and let her make up her\r\nmind to it. Tom\xe2\x80\x99ll have another wife, in a year or two; and she had\r\nbetter take up with somebody else.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Shelby, I have taught my people that their marriages are as sacred\r\nas ours. I never could think of giving Chloe such advice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a pity, wife, that you have burdened them with a morality above\r\ntheir condition and prospects. I always thought so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s only the morality of the Bible, Mr. Shelby.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, well, Emily, I don\xe2\x80\x99t pretend to interfere with your religious\r\nnotions; only they seem extremely unfitted for people in that\r\ncondition.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are, indeed,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Shelby, \xe2\x80\x9cand that is why, from my soul, I\r\nhate the whole thing. I tell you, my dear, _I_ cannot absolve myself\r\nfrom the promises I make to these helpless creatures. If I can get the\r\nmoney no other way I will take music-scholars;\xe2\x80\x94I could get enough, I\r\nknow, and earn the money myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t degrade yourself that way, Emily? I never could consent\r\nto it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDegrade! would it degrade me as much as to break my faith with the\r\nhelpless? No, indeed!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you are always heroic and transcendental,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Shelby, \xe2\x80\x9cbut\r\nI think you had better think before you undertake such a piece of\r\nQuixotism.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHere the conversation was interrupted by the appearance of Aunt Chloe,\r\nat the end of the verandah.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you please, Missis,\xe2\x80\x9d said she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Chloe, what is it?\xe2\x80\x9d said her mistress, rising, and going to the\r\nend of the balcony.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf Missis would come and look at dis yer lot o\xe2\x80\x99 poetry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nChloe had a particular fancy for calling poultry poetry,\xe2\x80\x94an application\r\nof language in which she always persisted, notwithstanding frequent\r\ncorrections and advisings from the young members of the family.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLa sakes!\xe2\x80\x9d she would say, \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t see; one jis good as turry,\xe2\x80\x94poetry\r\nsuthin good, any how;\xe2\x80\x9d and so poetry Chloe continued to call it.\r\n\r\nMrs. Shelby smiled as she saw a prostrate lot of chickens and ducks,\r\nover which Chloe stood, with a very grave face of consideration.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m a thinkin whether Missis would be a havin a chicken pie o\xe2\x80\x99 dese\r\nyer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally, Aunt Chloe, I don\xe2\x80\x99t much care;\xe2\x80\x94serve them any way you like.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nChloe stood handling them over abstractedly; it was quite evident that\r\nthe chickens were not what she was thinking of. At last, with the short\r\nlaugh with which her tribe often introduce a doubtful proposal, she\r\nsaid,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLaws me, Missis! what should Mas\xe2\x80\x99r and Missis be a troublin\r\ntheirselves \xe2\x80\x99bout de money, and not a usin what\xe2\x80\x99s right in der hands?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nand Chloe laughed again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t understand you, Chloe,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Shelby, nothing doubting,\r\nfrom her knowledge of Chloe\xe2\x80\x99s manner, that she had heard every word of\r\nthe conversation that had passed between her and her husband.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, laws me, Missis!\xe2\x80\x9d said Chloe, laughing again, \xe2\x80\x9cother folks hires\r\nout der niggers and makes money on \xe2\x80\x99em! Don\xe2\x80\x99t keep sich a tribe eatin\r\n\xe2\x80\x99em out of house and home.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Chloe, who do you propose that we should hire out?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLaws! I an\xe2\x80\x99t a proposin nothin; only Sam he said der was one of dese\r\nyer _perfectioners_, dey calls \xe2\x80\x99em, in Louisville, said he wanted a\r\ngood hand at cake and pastry; and said he\xe2\x80\x99d give four dollars a week to\r\none, he did.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Chloe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, laws, I \xe2\x80\x99s a thinkin, Missis, it\xe2\x80\x99s time Sally was put along to\r\nbe doin\xe2\x80\x99 something. Sally \xe2\x80\x99s been under my care, now, dis some time,\r\nand she does most as well as me, considerin; and if Missis would only\r\nlet me go, I would help fetch up de money. I an\xe2\x80\x99t afraid to put my\r\ncake, nor pies nother, \xe2\x80\x99long side no _perfectioner\xe2\x80\x99s_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cConfectioner\xe2\x80\x99s, Chloe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLaw sakes, Missis! \xe2\x80\x99tan\xe2\x80\x99t no odds;\xe2\x80\x94words is so curis, can\xe2\x80\x99t never get\r\n\xe2\x80\x99em right!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, Chloe, do you want to leave your children?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLaws, Missis! de boys is big enough to do day\xe2\x80\x99s works; dey does well\r\nenough; and Sally, she\xe2\x80\x99ll take de baby,\xe2\x80\x94she\xe2\x80\x99s such a peart young un,\r\nshe won\xe2\x80\x99t take no lookin arter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLouisville is a good way off.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLaw sakes! who\xe2\x80\x99s afeard?\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s down river, somer near my old man,\r\nperhaps?\xe2\x80\x9d said Chloe, speaking the last in the tone of a question, and\r\nlooking at Mrs. Shelby.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Chloe; it\xe2\x80\x99s many a hundred miles off,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Shelby.\r\n\r\nChloe\xe2\x80\x99s countenance fell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind; your going there shall bring you nearer, Chloe. Yes, you\r\nmay go; and your wages shall every cent of them be laid aside for your\r\nhusband\xe2\x80\x99s redemption.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs when a bright sunbeam turns a dark cloud to silver, so Chloe\xe2\x80\x99s dark\r\nface brightened immediately,\xe2\x80\x94it really shone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLaws! if Missis isn\xe2\x80\x99t too good! I was thinking of dat ar very thing;\r\ncause I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t need no clothes, nor shoes, nor nothin,\xe2\x80\x94I could save\r\nevery cent. How many weeks is der in a year, Missis?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFifty-two,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Shelby.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLaws! now, dere is? and four dollars for each on em. Why, how much \xe2\x80\x99d\r\ndat ar be?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwo hundred and eight dollars,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Shelby.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy-e!\xe2\x80\x9d said Chloe, with an accent of surprise and delight; \xe2\x80\x9cand how\r\nlong would it take me to work it out, Missis?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSome four or five years, Chloe; but, then, you needn\xe2\x80\x99t do it all,\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nshall add something to it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t hear to Missis\xe2\x80\x99 givin lessons nor nothin. Mas\xe2\x80\x99r\xe2\x80\x99s quite\r\nright in dat ar;\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98t wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t do, no ways. I hope none our family ever\r\nbe brought to dat ar, while I \xe2\x80\x99s got hands.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t fear, Chloe; I\xe2\x80\x99ll take care of the honor of the family,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nMrs. Shelby, smiling. \xe2\x80\x9cBut when do you expect to go?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I want spectin nothin; only Sam, he\xe2\x80\x99s a gwine to de river with\r\nsome colts, and he said I could go \xe2\x80\x99long with him; so I jes put my\r\nthings together. If Missis was willin, I\xe2\x80\x99d go with Sam tomorrow\r\nmorning, if Missis would write my pass, and write me a commendation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Chloe, I\xe2\x80\x99ll attend to it, if Mr. Shelby has no objections. I\r\nmust speak to him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Shelby went up stairs, and Aunt Chloe, delighted, went out to her\r\ncabin, to make her preparation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLaw sakes, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r George! ye didn\xe2\x80\x99t know I \xe2\x80\x99s a gwine to Louisville\r\ntomorrow!\xe2\x80\x9d she said to George, as entering her cabin, he found her busy\r\nin sorting over her baby\xe2\x80\x99s clothes. \xe2\x80\x9cI thought I\xe2\x80\x99d jis look over sis\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nthings, and get \xe2\x80\x99em straightened up. But I\xe2\x80\x99m gwine, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r George,\xe2\x80\x94gwine\r\nto have four dollars a week; and Missis is gwine to lay it all up, to\r\nbuy back my old man agin!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhew!\xe2\x80\x9d said George, \xe2\x80\x9chere\xe2\x80\x99s a stroke of business, to be sure! How are\r\nyou going?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTomorrow, wid Sam. And now, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r George, I knows you\xe2\x80\x99ll jis sit down\r\nand write to my old man, and tell him all about it,\xe2\x80\x94won\xe2\x80\x99t ye?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be sure,\xe2\x80\x9d said George; \xe2\x80\x9cUncle Tom\xe2\x80\x99ll be right glad to hear from us.\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll go right in the house, for paper and ink; and then, you know, Aunt\r\nChloe, I can tell about the new colts and all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSartin, sartin, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r George; you go \xe2\x80\x99long, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll get ye up a bit\r\no\xe2\x80\x99 chicken, or some sich; ye won\xe2\x80\x99t have many more suppers wid yer poor\r\nold aunty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXII\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Grass Withereth\xe2\x80\x94the Flower Fadeth\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nLife passes, with us all, a day at a time; so it passed with our friend\r\nTom, till two years were gone. Though parted from all his soul held\r\ndear, and though often yearning for what lay beyond, still was he never\r\npositively and consciously miserable; for, so well is the harp of human\r\nfeeling strung, that nothing but a crash that breaks every string can\r\nwholly mar its harmony; and, on looking back to seasons which in review\r\nappear to us as those of deprivation and trial, we can remember that\r\neach hour, as it glided, brought its diversions and alleviations, so\r\nthat, though not happy wholly, we were not, either, wholly miserable.\r\n\r\nTom read, in his only literary cabinet, of one who had \xe2\x80\x9clearned in\r\nwhatsoever state he was, therewith to be content.\xe2\x80\x9d It seemed to him\r\ngood and reasonable doctrine, and accorded well with the settled and\r\nthoughtful habit which he had acquired from the reading of that same\r\nbook.\r\n\r\nHis letter homeward, as we related in the last chapter, was in due time\r\nanswered by Master George, in a good, round, school-boy hand, that Tom\r\nsaid might be read \xe2\x80\x9cmost acrost the room.\xe2\x80\x9d It contained various\r\nrefreshing items of home intelligence, with which our reader is fully\r\nacquainted: stated how Aunt Chloe had been hired out to a confectioner\r\nin Louisville, where her skill in the pastry line was gaining wonderful\r\nsums of money, all of which, Tom was informed, was to be laid up to go\r\nto make up the sum of his redemption money; Mose and Pete were\r\nthriving, and the baby was trotting all about the house, under the care\r\nof Sally and the family generally.\r\n\r\nTom\xe2\x80\x99s cabin was shut up for the present; but George expatiated\r\nbrilliantly on ornaments and additions to be made to it when Tom came\r\nback.\r\n\r\nThe rest of this letter gave a list of George\xe2\x80\x99s school studies, each\r\none headed by a flourishing capital; and also told the names of four\r\nnew colts that appeared on the premises since Tom left; and stated, in\r\nthe same connection, that father and mother were well. The style of the\r\nletter was decidedly concise and terse; but Tom thought it the most\r\nwonderful specimen of composition that had appeared in modern times. He\r\nwas never tired of looking at it, and even held a council with Eva on\r\nthe expediency of getting it framed, to hang up in his room. Nothing\r\nbut the difficulty of arranging it so that both sides of the page would\r\nshow at once stood in the way of this undertaking.\r\n\r\nThe friendship between Tom and Eva had grown with the child\xe2\x80\x99s growth.\r\nIt would be hard to say what place she held in the soft, impressible\r\nheart of her faithful attendant. He loved her as something frail and\r\nearthly, yet almost worshipped her as something heavenly and divine. He\r\ngazed on her as the Italian sailor gazes on his image of the child\r\nJesus,\xe2\x80\x94with a mixture of reverence and tenderness; and to humor her\r\ngraceful fancies, and meet those thousand simple wants which invest\r\nchildhood like a many-colored rainbow, was Tom\xe2\x80\x99s chief delight. In the\r\nmarket, at morning, his eyes were always on the flower-stalls for rare\r\nbouquets for her, and the choicest peach or orange was slipped into his\r\npocket to give to her when he came back; and the sight that pleased him\r\nmost was her sunny head looking out the gate for his distant approach,\r\nand her childish questions,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Uncle Tom, what have you got for me\r\ntoday?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNor was Eva less zealous in kind offices, in return. Though a child,\r\nshe was a beautiful reader;\xe2\x80\x94a fine musical ear, a quick poetic fancy,\r\nand an instinctive sympathy with what\xe2\x80\x99s grand and noble, made her such\r\na reader of the Bible as Tom had never before heard. At first, she read\r\nto please her humble friend; but soon her own earnest nature threw out\r\nits tendrils, and wound itself around the majestic book; and Eva loved\r\nit, because it woke in her strange yearnings, and strong, dim emotions,\r\nsuch as impassioned, imaginative children love to feel.\r\n\r\nThe parts that pleased her most were the Revelations and the\r\nProphecies,\xe2\x80\x94parts whose dim and wondrous imagery, and fervent language,\r\nimpressed her the more, that she questioned vainly of their\r\nmeaning;\xe2\x80\x94and she and her simple friend, the old child and the young\r\none, felt just alike about it. All that they knew was, that they spoke\r\nof a glory to be revealed,\xe2\x80\x94a wondrous something yet to come, wherein\r\ntheir soul rejoiced, yet knew not why; and though it be not so in the\r\nphysical, yet in moral science that which cannot be understood is not\r\nalways profitless. For the soul awakes, a trembling stranger, between\r\ntwo dim eternities,\xe2\x80\x94the eternal past, the eternal future. The light\r\nshines only on a small space around her; therefore, she needs must\r\nyearn towards the unknown; and the voices and shadowy movings which\r\ncome to her from out the cloudy pillar of inspiration have each one\r\nechoes and answers in her own expecting nature. Its mystic imagery are\r\nso many talismans and gems inscribed with unknown hieroglyphics; she\r\nfolds them in her bosom, and expects to read them when she passes\r\nbeyond the veil.\r\n\r\n\r\n[Illustration: LITTLE EVA READING THE BIBLE TO UNCLE TOM IN THE ARBOR.]\r\n\r\n\r\nAt this time in our story, the whole St. Clare establishment is, for\r\nthe time being, removed to their villa on Lake Pontchartrain. The heats\r\nof summer had driven all who were able to leave the sultry and\r\nunhealthy city, to seek the shores of the lake, and its cool\r\nsea-breezes.\r\n\r\nSt. Clare\xe2\x80\x99s villa was an East Indian cottage, surrounded by light\r\nverandahs of bamboo-work, and opening on all sides into gardens and\r\npleasure-grounds. The common sitting-room opened on to a large garden,\r\nfragrant with every picturesque plant and flower of the tropics, where\r\nwinding paths ran down to the very shores of the lake, whose silvery\r\nsheet of water lay there, rising and falling in the sunbeams,\xe2\x80\x94a picture\r\nnever for an hour the same, yet every hour more beautiful.\r\n\r\nIt is now one of those intensely golden sunsets which kindles the whole\r\nhorizon into one blaze of glory, and makes the water another sky. The\r\nlake lay in rosy or golden streaks, save where white-winged vessels\r\nglided hither and thither, like so many spirits, and little golden\r\nstars twinkled through the glow, and looked down at themselves as they\r\ntrembled in the water.\r\n\r\nTom and Eva were seated on a little mossy seat, in an arbor, at the\r\nfoot of the garden. It was Sunday evening, and Eva\xe2\x80\x99s Bible lay open on\r\nher knee. She read,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I saw a sea of glass, mingled with fire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTom,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva, suddenly stopping, and pointing to the lake, \xe2\x80\x9cthere \xe2\x80\x99t\r\nis.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, Miss Eva?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you see,\xe2\x80\x94there?\xe2\x80\x9d said the child, pointing to the glassy water,\r\nwhich, as it rose and fell, reflected the golden glow of the sky.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s a \xe2\x80\x99sea of glass, mingled with fire.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue enough, Miss Eva,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom; and Tom sang\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, had I the wings of the morning,\r\n    I\xe2\x80\x99d fly away to Canaan\xe2\x80\x99s shore;\r\nBright angels should convey me home,\r\n    To the new Jerusalem.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere do you suppose new Jerusalem is, Uncle Tom?\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, up in the clouds, Miss Eva.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I think I see it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva. \xe2\x80\x9cLook in those clouds!\xe2\x80\x94they look\r\nlike great gates of pearl; and you can see beyond them\xe2\x80\x94far, far\r\noff\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s all gold. Tom, sing about \xe2\x80\x99spirits bright.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom sung the words of a well-known Methodist hymn,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see a band of spirits bright,\r\n    That taste the glories there;\r\nThey all are robed in spotless white,\r\n    And conquering palms they bear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUncle Tom, I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen _them_,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva.\r\n\r\nTom had no doubt of it at all; it did not surprise him in the least. If\r\nEva had told him she had been to heaven, he would have thought it\r\nentirely probable.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey come to me sometimes in my sleep, those spirits;\xe2\x80\x9d and Eva\xe2\x80\x99s eyes\r\ngrew dreamy, and she hummed, in a low voice,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are all robed in spotless white,\r\n    And conquering palms they bear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUncle Tom,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m going there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere, Miss Eva?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe child rose, and pointed her little hand to the sky; the glow of\r\nevening lit her golden hair and flushed cheek with a kind of unearthly\r\nradiance, and her eyes were bent earnestly on the skies.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m going _there_,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cto the spirits bright, Tom; _I\xe2\x80\x99m going,\r\nbefore long_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe faithful old heart felt a sudden thrust; and Tom thought how often\r\nhe had noticed, within six months, that Eva\xe2\x80\x99s little hands had grown\r\nthinner, and her skin more transparent, and her breath shorter; and\r\nhow, when she ran or played in the garden, as she once could for hours,\r\nshe became soon so tired and languid. He had heard Miss Ophelia speak\r\noften of a cough, that all her medicaments could not cure; and even now\r\nthat fervent cheek and little hand were burning with hectic fever; and\r\nyet the thought that Eva\xe2\x80\x99s words suggested had never come to him till\r\nnow.\r\n\r\nHas there ever been a child like Eva? Yes, there have been; but their\r\nnames are always on grave-stones, and their sweet smiles, their\r\nheavenly eyes, their singular words and ways, are among the buried\r\ntreasures of yearning hearts. In how many families do you hear the\r\nlegend that all the goodness and graces of the living are nothing to\r\nthe peculiar charms of one who _is not_. It is as if heaven had an\r\nespecial band of angels, whose office it was to sojourn for a season\r\nhere, and endear to them the wayward human heart, that they might bear\r\nit upward with them in their homeward flight. When you see that deep,\r\nspiritual light in the eye,\xe2\x80\x94when the little soul reveals itself in\r\nwords sweeter and wiser than the ordinary words of children,\xe2\x80\x94hope not\r\nto retain that child; for the seal of heaven is on it, and the light of\r\nimmortality looks out from its eyes.\r\n\r\nEven so, beloved Eva! fair star of thy dwelling! Thou art passing away;\r\nbut they that love thee dearest know it not.\r\n\r\nThe colloquy between Tom and Eva was interrupted by a hasty call from\r\nMiss Ophelia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEva\xe2\x80\x94Eva!\xe2\x80\x94why, child, the dew is falling; you mustn\xe2\x80\x99t be out there!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEva and Tom hastened in.\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia was old, and skilled in the tactics of nursing. She was\r\nfrom New England, and knew well the first guileful footsteps of that\r\nsoft, insidious disease, which sweeps away so many of the fairest and\r\nloveliest, and, before one fibre of life seems broken, seals them\r\nirrevocably for death.\r\n\r\nShe had noted the slight, dry cough, the daily brightening cheek; nor\r\ncould the lustre of the eye, and the airy buoyancy born of fever,\r\ndeceive her.\r\n\r\nShe tried to communicate her fears to St. Clare; but he threw back her\r\nsuggestions with a restless petulance, unlike his usual careless\r\ngood-humor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t be croaking, Cousin,\xe2\x80\x94I hate it!\xe2\x80\x9d he would say; \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t you see\r\nthat the child is only growing. Children always lose strength when they\r\ngrow fast.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut she has that cough!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO! nonsense of that cough!\xe2\x80\x94it is not anything. She has taken a little\r\ncold, perhaps.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, that was just the way Eliza Jane was taken, and Ellen and Maria\r\nSanders.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO! stop these hobgoblin\xe2\x80\x99 nurse legends. You old hands got so wise,\r\nthat a child cannot cough, or sneeze, but you see desperation and ruin\r\nat hand. Only take care of the child, keep her from the night air, and\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t let her play too hard, and she\xe2\x80\x99ll do well enough.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo St. Clare said; but he grew nervous and restless. He watched Eva\r\nfeverishly day by day, as might be told by the frequency with which he\r\nrepeated over that \xe2\x80\x9cthe child was quite well\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94that there wasn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nanything in that cough,\xe2\x80\x94it was only some little stomach affection, such\r\nas children often had. But he kept by her more than before, took her\r\noftener to ride with him, brought home every few days some receipt or\r\nstrengthening mixture,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cnot,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cthat the child _needed_ it, but\r\nthen it would not do her any harm.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIf it must be told, the thing that struck a deeper pang to his heart\r\nthan anything else was the daily increasing maturity of the child\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmind and feelings. While still retaining all a child\xe2\x80\x99s fanciful graces,\r\nyet she often dropped, unconsciously, words of such a reach of thought,\r\nand strange unworldly wisdom, that they seemed to be an inspiration. At\r\nsuch times, St. Clare would feel a sudden thrill, and clasp her in his\r\narms, as if that fond clasp could save her; and his heart rose up with\r\nwild determination to keep her, never to let her go.\r\n\r\nThe child\xe2\x80\x99s whole heart and soul seemed absorbed in works of love and\r\nkindness. Impulsively generous she had always been; but there was a\r\ntouching and womanly thoughtfulness about her now, that every one\r\nnoticed. She still loved to play with Topsy, and the various colored\r\nchildren; but she now seemed rather a spectator than an actor of their\r\nplays, and she would sit for half an hour at a time, laughing at the\r\nodd tricks of Topsy,\xe2\x80\x94and then a shadow would seem to pass across her\r\nface, her eyes grew misty, and her thoughts were afar.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMamma,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, suddenly, to her mother, one day, \xe2\x80\x9cwhy don\xe2\x80\x99t we\r\nteach our servants to read?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a question child! People never do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy don\xe2\x80\x99t they?\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause it is no use for them to read. It don\xe2\x80\x99t help them to work any\r\nbetter, and they are not made for anything else.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut they ought to read the Bible, mamma, to learn God\xe2\x80\x99s will.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO! they can get that read to them all _they_ need.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt seems to me, mamma, the Bible is for every one to read themselves.\r\nThey need it a great many times when there is nobody to read it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEva, you are an odd child,\xe2\x80\x9d said her mother.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Ophelia has taught Topsy to read,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Eva.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and you see how much good it does. Topsy is the worst creature I\r\never saw!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere\xe2\x80\x99s poor Mammy!\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva. \xe2\x80\x9cShe does love the Bible so much, and\r\nwishes so she could read! And what will she do when I can\xe2\x80\x99t read to\r\nher?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMarie was busy, turning over the contents of a drawer, as she answered,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, of course, by and by, Eva, you will have other things to think\r\nof besides reading the Bible round to servants. Not but that is very\r\nproper; I\xe2\x80\x99ve done it myself, when I had health. But when you come to be\r\ndressing and going into company, you won\xe2\x80\x99t have time. See here!\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nadded, \xe2\x80\x9cthese jewels I\xe2\x80\x99m going to give you when you come out. I wore\r\nthem to my first ball. I can tell you, Eva, I made a sensation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEva took the jewel-case, and lifted from it a diamond necklace. Her\r\nlarge, thoughtful eyes rested on them, but it was plain her thoughts\r\nwere elsewhere.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow sober you look child!\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre these worth a great deal of money, mamma?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be sure, they are. Father sent to France for them. They are worth a\r\nsmall fortune.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish I had them,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva, \xe2\x80\x9cto do what I pleased with!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat would you do with them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d sell them, and buy a place in the free states, and take all our\r\npeople there, and hire teachers, to teach them to read and write.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEva was cut short by her mother\xe2\x80\x99s laughing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSet up a boarding-school! Wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t you teach them to play on the\r\npiano, and paint on velvet?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d teach them to read their own Bible, and write their own letters,\r\nand read letters that are written to them,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva, steadily. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nknow, mamma, it does come very hard on them that they can\xe2\x80\x99t do these\r\nthings. Tom feels it\xe2\x80\x94Mammy does,\xe2\x80\x94a great many of them do. I think it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwrong.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come, Eva; you are only a child! You don\xe2\x80\x99t know anything about\r\nthese things,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie; \xe2\x80\x9cbesides, your talking makes my head ache.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMarie always had a headache on hand for any conversation that did not\r\nexactly suit her.\r\n\r\nEva stole away; but after that, she assiduously gave Mammy reading\r\nlessons.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXIII\r\nHenrique\r\n\r\n\r\nAbout this time, St. Clare\xe2\x80\x99s brother Alfred, with his eldest son, a boy\r\nof twelve, spent a day or two with the family at the lake.\r\n\r\nNo sight could be more singular and beautiful than that of these twin\r\nbrothers. Nature, instead of instituting resemblances between them, had\r\nmade them opposites on every point; yet a mysterious tie seemed to\r\nunite them in a closer friendship than ordinary.\r\n\r\nThey used to saunter, arm in arm, up and down the alleys and walks of\r\nthe garden. Augustine, with his blue eyes and golden hair, his\r\nethereally flexible form and vivacious features; and Alfred, dark-eyed,\r\nwith haughty Roman profile, firmly-knit limbs, and decided bearing.\r\nThey were always abusing each other\xe2\x80\x99s opinions and practices, and yet\r\nnever a whit the less absorbed in each other\xe2\x80\x99s society; in fact, the\r\nvery contrariety seemed to unite them, like the attraction between\r\nopposite poles of the magnet.\r\n\r\nHenrique, the eldest son of Alfred, was a noble, dark-eyed, princely\r\nboy, full of vivacity and spirit; and, from the first moment of\r\nintroduction, seemed to be perfectly fascinated by the spirituelle\r\ngraces of his cousin Evangeline.\r\n\r\nEva had a little pet pony, of a snowy whiteness. It was easy as a\r\ncradle, and as gentle as its little mistress; and this pony was now\r\nbrought up to the back verandah by Tom, while a little mulatto boy of\r\nabout thirteen led along a small black Arabian, which had just been\r\nimported, at a great expense, for Henrique.\r\n\r\nHenrique had a boy\xe2\x80\x99s pride in his new possession; and, as he advanced\r\nand took the reins out of the hands of his little groom, he looked\r\ncarefully over him, and his brow darkened.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s this, Dodo, you little lazy dog! you haven\xe2\x80\x99t rubbed my horse\r\ndown, this morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dodo, submissively; \xe2\x80\x9che got that dust on his own\r\nself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou rascal, shut your mouth!\xe2\x80\x9d said Henrique, violently raising his\r\nriding-whip. \xe2\x80\x9cHow dare you speak?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe boy was a handsome, bright-eyed mulatto, of just Henrique\xe2\x80\x99s size,\r\nand his curling hair hung round a high, bold forehead. He had white\r\nblood in his veins, as could be seen by the quick flush in his cheek,\r\nand the sparkle of his eye, as he eagerly tried to speak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMas\xe2\x80\x99r Henrique!\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d he began.\r\n\r\nHenrique struck him across the face with his riding-whip, and, seizing\r\none of his arms, forced him on to his knees, and beat him till he was\r\nout of breath.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, you impudent dog! Now will you learn not to answer back when I\r\nspeak to you? Take the horse back, and clean him properly. I\xe2\x80\x99ll teach\r\nyou your place!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYoung Mas\xe2\x80\x99r,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, \xe2\x80\x9cI specs what he was gwine to say was, that\r\nthe horse would roll when he was bringing him up from the stable; he\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nso full of spirits,\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s the way he got that dirt on him; I looked to\r\nhis cleaning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou hold your tongue till you\xe2\x80\x99re asked to speak!\xe2\x80\x9d said Henrique,\r\nturning on his heel, and walking up the steps to speak to Eva, who\r\nstood in her riding-dress.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear Cousin, I\xe2\x80\x99m sorry this stupid fellow has kept you waiting,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nsaid. \xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s sit down here, on this seat till they come. What\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\nmatter, Cousin?\xe2\x80\x94you look sober.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow could you be so cruel and wicked to poor Dodo?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Eva.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCruel,\xe2\x80\x94wicked!\xe2\x80\x9d said the boy, with unaffected surprise. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you\r\nmean, dear Eva?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want you to call me dear Eva, when you do so,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear Cousin, you don\xe2\x80\x99t know Dodo; it\xe2\x80\x99s the only way to manage him,\r\nhe\xe2\x80\x99s so full of lies and excuses. The only way is to put him down at\r\nonce,\xe2\x80\x94not let him open his mouth; that\xe2\x80\x99s the way papa manages.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut Uncle Tom said it was an accident, and he never tells what isn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ntrue.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s an uncommon old nigger, then!\xe2\x80\x9d said Henrique. \xe2\x80\x9cDodo will lie as\r\nfast as he can speak.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou frighten him into deceiving, if you treat him so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, Eva, you\xe2\x80\x99ve really taken such a fancy to Dodo, that I shall be\r\njealous.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you beat him,\xe2\x80\x94and he didn\xe2\x80\x99t deserve it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, well, it may go for some time when he does, and don\xe2\x80\x99t get it. A few\r\ncuts never come amiss with Dodo,\xe2\x80\x94he\xe2\x80\x99s a regular spirit, I can tell you;\r\nbut I won\xe2\x80\x99t beat him again before you, if it troubles you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEva was not satisfied, but found it in vain to try to make her handsome\r\ncousin understand her feelings.\r\n\r\nDodo soon appeared, with the horses.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Dodo, you\xe2\x80\x99ve done pretty well, this time,\xe2\x80\x9d said his young\r\nmaster, with a more gracious air. \xe2\x80\x9cCome, now, and hold Miss Eva\xe2\x80\x99s horse\r\nwhile I put her on to the saddle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDodo came and stood by Eva\xe2\x80\x99s pony. His face was troubled; his eyes\r\nlooked as if he had been crying.\r\n\r\nHenrique, who valued himself on his gentlemanly adroitness in all\r\nmatters of gallantry, soon had his fair cousin in the saddle, and,\r\ngathering the reins, placed them in her hands.\r\n\r\nBut Eva bent to the other side of the horse, where Dodo was standing,\r\nand said, as he relinquished the reins,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s a good boy, Dodo;\xe2\x80\x94thank\r\nyou!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDodo looked up in amazement into the sweet young face; the blood rushed\r\nto his cheeks, and the tears to his eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere, Dodo,\xe2\x80\x9d said his master, imperiously.\r\n\r\nDodo sprang and held the horse, while his master mounted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s a picayune for you to buy candy with, Dodo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Henrique;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cgo get some.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd Henrique cantered down the walk after Eva. Dodo stood looking after\r\nthe two children. One had given him money; and one had given him what\r\nhe wanted far more,\xe2\x80\x94a kind word, kindly spoken. Dodo had been only a\r\nfew months away from his mother. His master had bought him at a slave\r\nwarehouse, for his handsome face, to be a match to the handsome pony;\r\nand he was now getting his breaking in, at the hands of his young\r\nmaster.\r\n\r\nThe scene of the beating had been witnessed by the two brothers St.\r\nClare, from another part of the garden.\r\n\r\nAugustine\xe2\x80\x99s cheek flushed; but he only observed, with his usual\r\nsarcastic carelessness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI suppose that\xe2\x80\x99s what we may call republican education, Alfred?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHenrique is a devil of a fellow, when his blood\xe2\x80\x99s up,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alfred,\r\ncarelessly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI suppose you consider this an instructive practice for him,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nAugustine, drily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI couldn\xe2\x80\x99t help it, if I didn\xe2\x80\x99t. Henrique is a regular little\r\ntempest;\xe2\x80\x94his mother and I have given him up, long ago. But, then, that\r\nDodo is a perfect sprite,\xe2\x80\x94no amount of whipping can hurt him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd this by way of teaching Henrique the first verse of a republican\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncatechism, \xe2\x80\x99All men are born free and equal!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoh!\xe2\x80\x9d said Alfred; \xe2\x80\x9cone of Tom Jefferson\xe2\x80\x99s pieces of French sentiment\r\nand humbug. It\xe2\x80\x99s perfectly ridiculous to have that going the rounds\r\namong us, to this day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think it is,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, significantly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alfred, \xe2\x80\x9cwe can see plainly enough that all men are\r\n_not_ born free, nor born equal; they are born anything else. For my\r\npart, I think half this republican talk sheer humbug. It is the\r\neducated, the intelligent, the wealthy, the refined, who ought to have\r\nequal rights and not the canaille.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you can keep the canaille of that opinion,\xe2\x80\x9d said Augustine. \xe2\x80\x9cThey\r\ntook _their_ turn once, in France.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course, they must be _kept down_, consistently, steadily, as I\r\n_should_,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alfred, setting his foot hard down as if he were\r\nstanding on somebody.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt makes a terrible slip when they get up,\xe2\x80\x9d said Augustine,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cin St.\r\nDomingo, for instance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoh!\xe2\x80\x9d said Alfred, \xe2\x80\x9cwe\xe2\x80\x99ll take care of that, in this country. We must\r\nset our face against all this educating, elevating talk, that is\r\ngetting about now; the lower class must not be educated.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is past praying for,\xe2\x80\x9d said Augustine; \xe2\x80\x9ceducated they will be, and\r\nwe have only to say how. Our system is educating them in barbarism and\r\nbrutality. We are breaking all humanizing ties, and making them brute\r\nbeasts; and, if they get the upper hand, such we shall find them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey shall never get the upper hand!\xe2\x80\x9d said Alfred.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s right,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare; \xe2\x80\x9cput on the steam, fasten down the\r\nescape-valve, and sit on it, and see where you\xe2\x80\x99ll land.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alfred, \xe2\x80\x9cwe _will_ see. I\xe2\x80\x99m not afraid to sit on the\r\nescape-valve, as long as the boilers are strong, and the machinery\r\nworks well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe nobles in Louis XVI.\xe2\x80\x98s time thought just so; and Austria and Pius\r\nIX. think so now; and, some pleasant morning, you may all be caught up\r\nto meet each other in the air, _when the boilers burst_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Dies declarabit_,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alfred, laughing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI tell you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Augustine, \xe2\x80\x9cif there is anything that is revealed\r\nwith the strength of a divine law in our times, it is that the masses\r\nare to rise, and the under class become the upper one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s one of your red republican humbugs, Augustine! Why didn\xe2\x80\x99t you\r\never take to the stump;\xe2\x80\x94you\xe2\x80\x99d make a famous stump orator! Well, I hope\r\nI shall be dead before this millennium of your greasy masses comes on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGreasy or not greasy, they will govern _you_, when their time comes,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Augustine; \xe2\x80\x9cand they will be just such rulers as you make them.\r\nThe French noblesse chose to have the people \xe2\x80\x99_sans culottes_,\xe2\x80\x99 and\r\nthey had \xe2\x80\x99_sans culotte_\xe2\x80\x99 governors to their hearts\xe2\x80\x99 content. The\r\npeople of Hayti\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, come, Augustine! as if we hadn\xe2\x80\x99t had enough of that abominable,\r\ncontemptible Hayti![1] The Haytiens were not Anglo Saxons; if they had\r\nbeen there would have been another story. The Anglo Saxon is the\r\ndominant race of the world, and _is to be so_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n [1] In August 1791, as a consequence of the French Revolution, the\r\n black slaves and mulattoes on Haiti rose in revolt against the whites,\r\n and in the period of turmoil that followed enormous cruelties were\r\n practised by both sides. The \xe2\x80\x9cEmperor\xe2\x80\x9d Dessalines, come to power in\r\n 1804, massacred all the whites on the island. Haitian bloodshed became\r\n an argument to show the barbarous nature of the Negro, a doctrine\r\n Wendell Phillips sought to combat in his celebrated lecture on\r\n Toussaint L\xe2\x80\x99Ouverture.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, there is a pretty fair infusion of Anglo Saxon blood among our\r\nslaves, now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Augustine. \xe2\x80\x9cThere are plenty among them who have\r\nonly enough of the African to give a sort of tropical warmth and fervor\r\nto our calculating firmness and foresight. If ever the San Domingo hour\r\ncomes, Anglo Saxon blood will lead on the day. Sons of white fathers,\r\nwith all our haughty feelings burning in their veins, will not always\r\nbe bought and sold and traded. They will rise, and raise with them\r\ntheir mother\xe2\x80\x99s race.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStuff!\xe2\x80\x94nonsense!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Augustine, \xe2\x80\x9cthere goes an old saying to this effect, \xe2\x80\x99As\r\nit was in the days of Noah so shall it be;\xe2\x80\x94they ate, they drank, they\r\nplanted, they builded, and knew not till the flood came and took\r\nthem.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the whole, Augustine, I think your talents might do for a circuit\r\nrider,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alfred, laughing. \xe2\x80\x9cNever you fear for us; possession is\r\nour nine points. We\xe2\x80\x99ve got the power. This subject race,\xe2\x80\x9d said he,\r\nstamping firmly, \xe2\x80\x9cis down and shall _stay_ down! We have energy enough\r\nto manage our own powder.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSons trained like your Henrique will be grand guardians of your\r\npowder-magazines,\xe2\x80\x9d said Augustine,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cso cool and self-possessed! The\r\nproverb says, \xe2\x80\x99They that cannot govern themselves cannot govern\r\nothers.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is a trouble there\xe2\x80\x9d said Alfred, thoughtfully; \xe2\x80\x9cthere\xe2\x80\x99s no doubt\r\nthat our system is a difficult one to train children under. It gives\r\ntoo free scope to the passions, altogether, which, in our climate, are\r\nhot enough. I find trouble with Henrique. The boy is generous and\r\nwarm-hearted, but a perfect fire-cracker when excited. I believe I\r\nshall send him North for his education, where obedience is more\r\nfashionable, and where he will associate more with equals, and less\r\nwith dependents.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSince training children is the staple work of the human race,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nAugustine, \xe2\x80\x9cI should think it something of a consideration that our\r\nsystem does not work well there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt does not for some things,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alfred; \xe2\x80\x9cfor others, again, it\r\ndoes. It makes boys manly and courageous; and the very vices of an\r\nabject race tend to strengthen in them the opposite virtues. I think\r\nHenrique, now, has a keener sense of the beauty of truth, from seeing\r\nlying and deception the universal badge of slavery.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA Christian-like view of the subject, certainly!\xe2\x80\x9d said Augustine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s true, Christian-like or not; and is about as Christian-like as\r\nmost other things in the world,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alfred.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat may be,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, there\xe2\x80\x99s no use in talking, Augustine. I believe we\xe2\x80\x99ve been round\r\nand round this old track five hundred times, more or less. What do you\r\nsay to a game of backgammon?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe two brothers ran up the verandah steps, and were soon seated at a\r\nlight bamboo stand, with the backgammon-board between them. As they\r\nwere setting their men, Alfred said,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI tell you, Augustine, if I thought as you do, I should do something.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI dare say you would,\xe2\x80\x94you are one of the doing sort,\xe2\x80\x94but what?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, elevate your own servants, for a specimen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alfred, with a\r\nhalf-scornful smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou might as well set Mount \xc3\x86tna on them flat, and tell them to stand\r\nup under it, as tell me to elevate my servants under all the\r\nsuperincumbent mass of society upon them. One man can do nothing,\r\nagainst the whole action of a community. Education, to do anything,\r\nmust be a state education; or there must be enough agreed in it to make\r\na current.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou take the first throw,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alfred; and the brothers were soon\r\nlost in the game, and heard no more till the scraping of horses\xe2\x80\x99 feet\r\nwas heard under the verandah.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere come the children,\xe2\x80\x9d said Augustine, rising. \xe2\x80\x9cLook here, Alf! Did\r\nyou ever see anything so beautiful?\xe2\x80\x9d And, in truth, it _was_ a\r\nbeautiful sight. Henrique, with his bold brow, and dark, glossy curls,\r\nand glowing cheek, was laughing gayly as he bent towards his fair\r\ncousin, as they came on. She was dressed in a blue riding dress, with a\r\ncap of the same color. Exercise had given a brilliant hue to her\r\ncheeks, and heightened the effect of her singularly transparent skin,\r\nand golden hair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood heavens! what perfectly dazzling beauty!\xe2\x80\x9d said Alfred. \xe2\x80\x9cI tell\r\nyou, Auguste, won\xe2\x80\x99t she make some hearts ache, one of these days?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe will, too truly,\xe2\x80\x94God knows I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid so!\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, in a\r\ntone of sudden bitterness, as he hurried down to take her off her\r\nhorse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEva darling! you\xe2\x80\x99re not much tired?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, as he clasped her in his\r\narms.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, papa,\xe2\x80\x9d said the child; but her short, hard breathing alarmed her\r\nfather.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow could you ride so fast, dear?\xe2\x80\x94you know it\xe2\x80\x99s bad for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI felt so well, papa, and liked it so much, I forgot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSt. Clare carried her in his arms into the parlor, and laid her on the\r\nsofa.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHenrique, you must be careful of Eva,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cyou mustn\xe2\x80\x99t ride fast\r\nwith her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll take her under my care,\xe2\x80\x9d said Henrique, seating himself by the\r\nsofa, and taking Eva\xe2\x80\x99s hand.\r\n\r\nEva soon found herself much better. Her father and uncle resumed their\r\ngame, and the children were left together.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know, Eva, I\xe2\x80\x99m sorry papa is only going to stay two days here,\r\nand then I shan\xe2\x80\x99t see you again for ever so long! If I stay with you,\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99d try to be good, and not be cross to Dodo, and so on. I don\xe2\x80\x99t mean\r\nto treat Dodo ill; but, you know, I\xe2\x80\x99ve got such a quick temper. I\xe2\x80\x99m not\r\nreally bad to him, though. I give him a picayune, now and then; and you\r\nsee he dresses well. I think, on the whole, Dodo \xe2\x80\x99s pretty well off.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould you think you were well off, if there were not one creature in\r\nthe world near you to love you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI?\xe2\x80\x94Well, of course not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you have taken Dodo away from all the friends he ever had, and now\r\nhe has not a creature to love him;\xe2\x80\x94nobody can be good that way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I can\xe2\x80\x99t help it, as I know of. I can\xe2\x80\x99t get his mother and I\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t love him myself, nor anybody else, as I know of.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy can\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Love_ Dodo! Why, Eva, you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have me! I may _like_ him well\r\nenough; but you don\xe2\x80\x99t _love_ your servants.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do, indeed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow odd!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t the Bible say we must love everybody?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, the Bible! To be sure, it says a great many such things; but, then,\r\nnobody ever thinks of doing them,\xe2\x80\x94you know, Eva, nobody does.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEva did not speak; her eyes were fixed and thoughtful for a few\r\nmoments.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt any rate,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cdear Cousin, do love poor Dodo, and be kind\r\nto him, for my sake!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI could love anything, for your sake, dear Cousin; for I really think\r\nyou are the loveliest creature that I ever saw!\xe2\x80\x9d And Henrique spoke\r\nwith an earnestness that flushed his handsome face. Eva received it\r\nwith perfect simplicity, without even a change of feature; merely\r\nsaying, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m glad you feel so, dear Henrique! I hope you will\r\nremember.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe dinner-bell put an end to the interview.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXIV\r\nForeshadowings\r\n\r\n\r\nTwo days after this, Alfred St. Clare and Augustine parted; and Eva,\r\nwho had been stimulated, by the society of her young cousin, to\r\nexertions beyond her strength, began to fail rapidly. St. Clare was at\r\nlast willing to call in medical advice,\xe2\x80\x94a thing from which he had\r\nalways shrunk, because it was the admission of an unwelcome truth.\r\n\r\nBut, for a day or two, Eva was so unwell as to be confined to the\r\nhouse; and the doctor was called.\r\n\r\nMarie St. Clare had taken no notice of the child\xe2\x80\x99s gradually decaying\r\nhealth and strength, because she was completely absorbed in studying\r\nout two or three new forms of disease to which she believed she herself\r\nwas a victim. It was the first principle of Marie\xe2\x80\x99s belief that nobody\r\never was or could be so great a sufferer as _herself_; and, therefore,\r\nshe always repelled quite indignantly any suggestion that any one\r\naround her could be sick. She was always sure, in such a case, that it\r\nwas nothing but laziness, or want of energy; and that, if they had had\r\nthe suffering _she_ had, they would soon know the difference.\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia had several times tried to awaken her maternal fears about\r\nEva; but to no avail.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t see as anything ails the child,\xe2\x80\x9d she would say; \xe2\x80\x9cshe runs\r\nabout, and plays.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut she has a cough.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCough! you don\xe2\x80\x99t need to tell _me_ about a cough. I\xe2\x80\x99ve always been\r\nsubject to a cough, all my days. When I was of Eva\xe2\x80\x99s age, they thought\r\nI was in a consumption. Night after night, Mammy used to sit up with\r\nme. O! Eva\xe2\x80\x99s cough is not anything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut she gets weak, and is short-breathed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLaw! I\xe2\x80\x99ve had that, years and years; it\xe2\x80\x99s only a nervous affection.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut she sweats so, nights!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I have, these ten years. Very often, night after night, my\r\nclothes will be wringing wet. There won\xe2\x80\x99t be a dry thread in my\r\nnight-clothes and the sheets will be so that Mammy has to hang them up\r\nto dry! Eva doesn\xe2\x80\x99t sweat anything like that!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia shut her mouth for a season. But, now that Eva was fairly\r\nand visibly prostrated, and a doctor called, Marie, all on a sudden,\r\ntook a new turn.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe knew it,\xe2\x80\x9d she said; \xe2\x80\x9cshe always felt it, that she was destined to\r\nbe the most miserable of mothers. Here she was, with her wretched\r\nhealth, and her only darling child going down to the grave before her\r\neyes;\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and Marie routed up Mammy nights, and rumpussed and scolded,\r\nwith more energy than ever, all day, on the strength of this new\r\nmisery.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Marie, don\xe2\x80\x99t talk so!\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare. \xe2\x80\x9cYou ought not to give\r\nup the case so, at once.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have not a mother\xe2\x80\x99s feelings, St. Clare! You never could\r\nunderstand me!\xe2\x80\x94you don\xe2\x80\x99t now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut don\xe2\x80\x99t talk so, as if it were a gone case!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t take it as indifferently as you can, St. Clare. If _you_ don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nfeel when your only child is in this alarming state, I do. It\xe2\x80\x99s a blow\r\ntoo much for me, with all I was bearing before.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s true,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, \xe2\x80\x9cthat Eva is very delicate, _that_ I\r\nalways knew; and that she has grown so rapidly as to exhaust her\r\nstrength; and that her situation is critical. But just now she is only\r\nprostrated by the heat of the weather, and by the excitement of her\r\ncousin\xe2\x80\x99s visit, and the exertions she made. The physician says there is\r\nroom for hope.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, of course, if you can look on the bright side, pray do; it\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\nmercy if people haven\xe2\x80\x99t sensitive feelings, in this world. I am sure I\r\nwish I didn\xe2\x80\x99t feel as I do; it only makes me completely wretched! I\r\nwish I _could_ be as easy as the rest of you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd the \xe2\x80\x9crest of them\xe2\x80\x9d had good reason to breathe the same prayer, for\r\nMarie paraded her new misery as the reason and apology for all sorts of\r\ninflictions on every one about her. Every word that was spoken by\r\nanybody, everything that was done or was not done everywhere, was only\r\na new proof that she was surrounded by hard-hearted, insensible beings,\r\nwho were unmindful of her peculiar sorrows. Poor Eva heard some of\r\nthese speeches; and nearly cried her little eyes out, in pity for her\r\nmamma, and in sorrow that she should make her so much distress.\r\n\r\nIn a week or two, there was a great improvement of symptoms,\xe2\x80\x94one of\r\nthose deceitful lulls, by which her inexorable disease so often\r\nbeguiles the anxious heart, even on the verge of the grave. Eva\xe2\x80\x99s step\r\nwas again in the garden,\xe2\x80\x94in the balconies; she played and laughed\r\nagain,\xe2\x80\x94and her father, in a transport, declared that they should soon\r\nhave her as hearty as anybody. Miss Ophelia and the physician alone\r\nfelt no encouragement from this illusive truce. There was one other\r\nheart, too, that felt the same certainty, and that was the little heart\r\nof Eva. What is it that sometimes speaks in the soul so calmly, so\r\nclearly, that its earthly time is short? Is it the secret instinct of\r\ndecaying nature, or the soul\xe2\x80\x99s impulsive throb, as immortality draws\r\non? Be it what it may, it rested in the heart of Eva, a calm, sweet,\r\nprophetic certainty that Heaven was near; calm as the light of sunset,\r\nsweet as the bright stillness of autumn, there her little heart\r\nreposed, only troubled by sorrow for those who loved her so dearly.\r\n\r\nFor the child, though nursed so tenderly, and though life was unfolding\r\nbefore her with every brightness that love and wealth could give, had\r\nno regret for herself in dying.\r\n\r\nIn that book which she and her simple old friend had read so much\r\ntogether, she had seen and taken to her young heart the image of one\r\nwho loved the little child; and, as she gazed and mused, He had ceased\r\nto be an image and a picture of the distant past, and come to be a\r\nliving, all-surrounding reality. His love enfolded her childish heart\r\nwith more than mortal tenderness; and it was to Him, she said, she was\r\ngoing, and to his home.\r\n\r\nBut her heart yearned with sad tenderness for all that she was to leave\r\nbehind. Her father most,\xe2\x80\x94for Eva, though she never distinctly thought\r\nso, had an instinctive perception that she was more in his heart than\r\nany other. She loved her mother because she was so loving a creature,\r\nand all the selfishness that she had seen in her only saddened and\r\nperplexed her; for she had a child\xe2\x80\x99s implicit trust that her mother\r\ncould not do wrong. There was something about her that Eva never could\r\nmake out; and she always smoothed it over with thinking that, after\r\nall, it was mamma, and she loved her very dearly indeed.\r\n\r\nShe felt, too, for those fond, faithful servants, to whom she was as\r\ndaylight and sunshine. Children do not usually generalize; but Eva was\r\nan uncommonly mature child, and the things that she had witnessed of\r\nthe evils of the system under which they were living had fallen, one by\r\none, into the depths of her thoughtful, pondering heart. She had vague\r\nlongings to do something for them,\xe2\x80\x94to bless and save not only them, but\r\nall in their condition,\xe2\x80\x94longings that contrasted sadly with the\r\nfeebleness of her little frame.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUncle Tom,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, one day, when she was reading to her friend, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\ncan understand why Jesus _wanted_ to die for us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, Miss Eva?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause I\xe2\x80\x99ve felt so, too.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it Miss Eva?\xe2\x80\x94I don\xe2\x80\x99t understand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t tell you; but, when I saw those poor creatures on the boat,\r\nyou know, when you came up and I,\xe2\x80\x94some had lost their mothers, and some\r\ntheir husbands, and some mothers cried for their little children\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nwhen I heard about poor Prue,\xe2\x80\x94oh, wasn\xe2\x80\x99t that dreadful!\xe2\x80\x94and a great\r\nmany other times, I\xe2\x80\x99ve felt that I would be glad to die, if my dying\r\ncould stop all this misery. _I would_ die for them, Tom, if I could,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid the child, earnestly, laying her little thin hand on his.\r\n\r\nTom looked at the child with awe; and when she, hearing her father\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nvoice, glided away, he wiped his eyes many times, as he looked after\r\nher.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s jest no use tryin\xe2\x80\x99 to keep Miss Eva here,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to Mammy, whom\r\nhe met a moment after. \xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s got the Lord\xe2\x80\x99s mark in her forehead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, yes, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mammy, raising her hands; \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve allers said so.\r\nShe wasn\xe2\x80\x99t never like a child that\xe2\x80\x99s to live\xe2\x80\x94there was allers something\r\ndeep in her eyes. I\xe2\x80\x99ve told Missis so, many the time; it\xe2\x80\x99s a comin\xe2\x80\x99\r\ntrue,\xe2\x80\x94we all sees it,\xe2\x80\x94dear, little, blessed lamb!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEva came tripping up the verandah steps to her father. It was late in\r\nthe afternoon, and the rays of the sun formed a kind of glory behind\r\nher, as she came forward in her white dress, with her golden hair and\r\nglowing cheeks, her eyes unnaturally bright with the slow fever that\r\nburned in her veins.\r\n\r\nSt. Clare had called her to show a statuette that he had been buying\r\nfor her; but her appearance, as she came on, impressed him suddenly and\r\npainfully. There is a kind of beauty so intense, yet so fragile, that\r\nwe cannot bear to look at it. Her father folded her suddenly in his\r\narms, and almost forgot what he was going to tell her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEva, dear, you are better now-a-days,\xe2\x80\x94are you not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPapa,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva, with sudden firmness \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve had things I wanted to say\r\nto you, a great while. I want to say them now, before I get weaker.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSt. Clare trembled as Eva seated herself in his lap. She laid her head\r\non his bosom, and said,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s all no use, papa, to keep it to myself any longer. The time is\r\ncoming that I am going to leave you. I am going, and never to come\r\nback!\xe2\x80\x9d and Eva sobbed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, now, my dear little Eva!\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, trembling as he spoke,\r\nbut speaking cheerfully, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99ve got nervous and low-spirited; you\r\nmustn\xe2\x80\x99t indulge such gloomy thoughts. See here, I\xe2\x80\x99ve bought a statuette\r\nfor you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, papa,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva, putting it gently away, \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t deceive\r\nyourself!\xe2\x80\x94I am _not_ any better, I know it perfectly well,\xe2\x80\x94and I am\r\ngoing, before long. I am not nervous,\xe2\x80\x94I am not low-spirited. If it were\r\nnot for you, papa, and my friends, I should be perfectly happy. I want\r\nto go,\xe2\x80\x94I long to go!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, dear child, what has made your poor little heart so sad? You have\r\nhad everything, to make you happy, that could be given you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI had rather be in heaven; though, only for my friends\xe2\x80\x99 sake, I would\r\nbe willing to live. There are a great many things here that make me\r\nsad, that seem dreadful to me; I had rather be there; but I don\xe2\x80\x99t want\r\nto leave you,\xe2\x80\x94it almost breaks my heart!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat makes you sad, and seems dreadful, Eva?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, things that are done, and done all the time. I feel sad for our\r\npoor people; they love me dearly, and they are all good and kind to me.\r\nI wish, papa, they were all _free_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, Eva, child, don\xe2\x80\x99t you think they are well enough off now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, but, papa, if anything should happen to you, what would become of\r\nthem? There are very few men like you, papa. Uncle Alfred isn\xe2\x80\x99t like\r\nyou, and mamma isn\xe2\x80\x99t; and then, think of poor old Prue\xe2\x80\x99s owners! What\r\nhorrid things people do, and can do!\xe2\x80\x9d and Eva shuddered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear child, you are too sensitive. I\xe2\x80\x99m sorry I ever let you hear\r\nsuch stories.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, that\xe2\x80\x99s what troubles me, papa. You want me to live so happy, and\r\nnever to have any pain,\xe2\x80\x94never suffer anything,\xe2\x80\x94not even hear a sad\r\nstory, when other poor creatures have nothing but pain and sorrow, all\r\ntheir lives;\xe2\x80\x94it seems selfish. I ought to know such things, I ought to\r\nfeel about them! Such things always sunk into my heart; they went down\r\ndeep; I\xe2\x80\x99ve thought and thought about them. Papa, isn\xe2\x80\x99t there any way to\r\nhave all slaves made free?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s a difficult question, dearest. There\xe2\x80\x99s no doubt that this way\r\nis a very bad one; a great many people think so; I do myself; I heartily\r\nwish that there were not a slave in the land; but, then, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know\r\nwhat is to be done about it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPapa, you are such a good man, and so noble, and kind, and you always\r\nhave a way of saying things that is so pleasant, couldn\xe2\x80\x99t you go all\r\nround and try to persuade people to do right about this? When I am\r\ndead, papa, then you will think of me, and do it for my sake. I would\r\ndo it, if I could.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen you are dead, Eva,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, passionately. \xe2\x80\x9cO, child,\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t talk to me so! You are all I have on earth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor old Prue\xe2\x80\x99s child was all that she had,\xe2\x80\x94and yet she had to hear it\r\ncrying, and she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t help it! Papa, these poor creatures love their\r\nchildren as much as you do me. O! do something for them! There\xe2\x80\x99s poor\r\nMammy loves her children; I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen her cry when she talked about them.\r\nAnd Tom loves his children; and it\xe2\x80\x99s dreadful, papa, that such things\r\nare happening, all the time!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, there, darling,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, soothingly; \xe2\x80\x9conly don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ndistress yourself, don\xe2\x80\x99t talk of dying, and I will do anything you\r\nwish.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd promise me, dear father, that Tom shall have his freedom as soon\r\nas\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94she stopped, and said, in a hesitating tone\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI am gone!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, dear, I will do anything in the world,\xe2\x80\x94anything you could ask me\r\nto.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear papa,\xe2\x80\x9d said the child, laying her burning cheek against his, \xe2\x80\x9chow\r\nI wish we could go together!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere, dearest?\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo our Saviour\xe2\x80\x99s home; it\xe2\x80\x99s so sweet and peaceful there\xe2\x80\x94it is all so\r\nloving there!\xe2\x80\x9d The child spoke unconsciously, as of a place where she\r\nhad often been. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you want to go, papa?\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\nSt. Clare drew her closer to him, but was silent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will come to me,\xe2\x80\x9d said the child, speaking in a voice of calm\r\ncertainty which she often used unconsciously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall come after you. I shall not forget you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe shadows of the solemn evening closed round them deeper and deeper,\r\nas St. Clare sat silently holding the little frail form to his bosom.\r\nHe saw no more the deep eyes, but the voice came over him as a spirit\r\nvoice, and, as in a sort of judgment vision, his whole past life rose\r\nin a moment before his eyes: his mother\xe2\x80\x99s prayers and hymns; his own\r\nearly yearnings and aspirings for good; and, between them and this\r\nhour, years of worldliness and scepticism, and what man calls\r\nrespectable living. We can think _much_, very much, in a moment. St.\r\nClare saw and felt many things, but spoke nothing; and, as it grew\r\ndarker, he took his child to her bed-room; and, when she was prepared\r\nfor rest; he sent away the attendants, and rocked her in his arms, and\r\nsung to her till she was asleep.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXV\r\nThe Little Evangelist\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was Sunday afternoon. St. Clare was stretched on a bamboo lounge in\r\nthe verandah, solacing himself with a cigar. Marie lay reclined on a\r\nsofa, opposite the window opening on the verandah, closely secluded,\r\nunder an awning of transparent gauze, from the outrages of the\r\nmosquitos, and languidly holding in her hand an elegantly bound\r\nprayer-book. She was holding it because it was Sunday, and she imagined\r\nshe had been reading it,\xe2\x80\x94though, in fact, she had been only taking a\r\nsuccession of short naps, with it open in her hand.\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia, who, after some rummaging, had hunted up a small\r\nMethodist meeting within riding distance, had gone out, with Tom as\r\ndriver, to attend it; and Eva had accompanied them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say, Augustine,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie after dozing a while, \xe2\x80\x9cI must send to\r\nthe city after my old Doctor Posey; I\xe2\x80\x99m sure I\xe2\x80\x99ve got the complaint of\r\nthe heart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell; why need you send for him? This doctor that attends Eva seems\r\nskilful.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would not trust him in a critical case,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie; \xe2\x80\x9cand I think I\r\nmay say mine is becoming so! I\xe2\x80\x99ve been thinking of it, these two or\r\nthree nights past; I have such distressing pains, and such strange\r\nfeelings.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Marie, you are blue; I don\xe2\x80\x99t believe it\xe2\x80\x99s heart complaint.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI dare say _you_ don\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie; \xe2\x80\x9cI was prepared to expect _that_.\r\nYou can be alarmed enough, if Eva coughs, or has the least thing the\r\nmatter with her; but you never think of me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf it\xe2\x80\x99s particularly agreeable to you to have heart disease, why, I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\ntry and maintain you have it,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare; \xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t know it was.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I only hope you won\xe2\x80\x99t be sorry for this, when it\xe2\x80\x99s too late!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Marie; \xe2\x80\x9cbut, believe it or not, my distress about Eva, and the\r\nexertions I have made with that dear child, have developed what I have\r\nlong suspected.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhat the _exertions_ were which Marie referred to, it would have been\r\ndifficult to state. St. Clare quietly made this commentary to himself,\r\nand went on smoking, like a hard-hearted wretch of a man as he was,\r\ntill a carriage drove up before the verandah, and Eva and Miss Ophelia\r\nalighted.\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia marched straight to her own chamber, to put away her\r\nbonnet and shawl, as was always her manner, before she spoke a word on\r\nany subject; while Eva came, at St. Clare\xe2\x80\x99s call, and was sitting on\r\nhis knee, giving him an account of the services they had heard.\r\n\r\nThey soon heard loud exclamations from Miss Ophelia\xe2\x80\x99s room, which, like\r\nthe one in which they were sitting, opened on to the verandah and\r\nviolent reproof addressed to somebody.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat new witchcraft has Tops been brewing?\xe2\x80\x9d asked St. Clare. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\r\ncommotion is of her raising, I\xe2\x80\x99ll be bound!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd, in a moment after, Miss Ophelia, in high indignation, came\r\ndragging the culprit along.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome out here, now!\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cI _will_ tell your master!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the case now?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Augustine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe case is, that I cannot be plagued with this child, any longer!\r\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s past all bearing; flesh and blood cannot endure it! Here, I locked\r\nher up, and gave her a hymn to study; and what does she do, but spy out\r\nwhere I put my key, and has gone to my bureau, and got a\r\nbonnet-trimming, and cut it all to pieces to make dolls\xe2\x80\x99 jackets! I\r\nnever saw anything like it, in my life!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI told you, Cousin,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you\xe2\x80\x99d find out that these\r\ncreatures can\xe2\x80\x99t be brought up without severity. If I had _my_ way,\r\nnow,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, looking reproachfully at St. Clare, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d send that\r\nchild out, and have her thoroughly whipped; I\xe2\x80\x99d have her whipped till\r\nshe couldn\xe2\x80\x99t stand!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t doubt it,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare. \xe2\x80\x9cTell me of the lovely rule of\r\nwoman!
