I never saw above a dozen women that wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t half kill a horse,\r\nor a servant, either, if they had their own way with them!\xe2\x80\x94let alone a\r\nman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is no use in this shilly-shally way of yours, St. Clare!\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nMarie. \xe2\x80\x9cCousin is a woman of sense, and she sees it now, as plain as I\r\ndo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia had just the capability of indignation that belongs to the\r\nthorough-paced housekeeper, and this had been pretty actively roused by\r\nthe artifice and wastefulness of the child; in fact, many of my lady\r\nreaders must own that they should have felt just so in her\r\ncircumstances; but Marie\xe2\x80\x99s words went beyond her, and she felt less\r\nheat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have the child treated so, for the world,\xe2\x80\x9d she said; \xe2\x80\x9cbut,\r\nI am sure, Augustine, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what to do. I\xe2\x80\x99ve taught and taught;\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ve talked till I\xe2\x80\x99m tired; I\xe2\x80\x99ve whipped her; I\xe2\x80\x99ve punished her in\r\nevery way I can think of, and she\xe2\x80\x99s just what she was at first.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome here, Tops, you monkey!\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, calling the child up to\r\nhim.\r\n\r\nTopsy came up; her round, hard eyes glittering and blinking with a\r\nmixture of apprehensiveness and their usual odd drollery.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat makes you behave so?\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, who could not help being\r\namused with the child\xe2\x80\x99s expression.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpects it\xe2\x80\x99s my wicked heart,\xe2\x80\x9d said Topsy, demurely; \xe2\x80\x9cMiss Feely says\r\nso.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you see how much Miss Ophelia has done for you? She says she has\r\ndone everything she can think of.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLor, yes, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r! old Missis used to say so, too. She whipped me a heap\r\nharder, and used to pull my har, and knock my head agin the door; but\r\nit didn\xe2\x80\x99t do me no good! I spects, if they \xe2\x80\x99s to pull every spire o\xe2\x80\x99\r\nhar out o\xe2\x80\x99 my head, it wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t do no good, neither,\xe2\x80\x94I \xe2\x80\x99s so wicked!\r\nLaws! I \xe2\x80\x99s nothin but a nigger, no ways!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I shall have to give her up,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia; \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t have\r\nthat trouble any longer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I\xe2\x80\x99d just like to ask one question,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, if your Gospel is not strong enough to save one heathen child,\r\nthat you can have at home here, all to yourself, what\xe2\x80\x99s the use of\r\nsending one or two poor missionaries off with it among thousands of\r\njust such? I suppose this child is about a fair sample of what\r\nthousands of your heathen are.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia did not make an immediate answer; and Eva, who had stood a\r\nsilent spectator of the scene thus far, made a silent sign to Topsy to\r\nfollow her. There was a little glass-room at the corner of the\r\nverandah, which St. Clare used as a sort of reading-room; and Eva and\r\nTopsy disappeared into this place.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s Eva going about, now?\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare; \xe2\x80\x9cI mean to see.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd, advancing on tiptoe, he lifted up a curtain that covered the\r\nglass-door, and looked in. In a moment, laying his finger on his lips,\r\nhe made a silent gesture to Miss Ophelia to come and look. There sat\r\nthe two children on the floor, with their side faces towards them.\r\nTopsy, with her usual air of careless drollery and unconcern; but,\r\nopposite to her, Eva, her whole face fervent with feeling, and tears in\r\nher large eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat does make you so bad, Topsy? Why won\xe2\x80\x99t you try and be good? Don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nyou love _anybody_, Topsy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDonno nothing \xe2\x80\x99bout love; I loves candy and sich, that\xe2\x80\x99s all,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nTopsy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you love your father and mother?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever had none, ye know. I telled ye that, Miss Eva.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, I know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva, sadly; \xe2\x80\x9cbut hadn\xe2\x80\x99t you any brother, or sister,\r\nor aunt, or\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, none on \xe2\x80\x99em,\xe2\x80\x94never had nothing nor nobody.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, Topsy, if you\xe2\x80\x99d only try to be good, you might\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCouldn\xe2\x80\x99t never be nothin\xe2\x80\x99 but a nigger, if I was ever so good,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nTopsy. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I could be skinned, and come white, I\xe2\x80\x99d try then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut people can love you, if you are black, Topsy. Miss Ophelia would\r\nlove you, if you were good.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTopsy gave the short, blunt laugh that was her common mode of\r\nexpressing incredulity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you think so?\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; she can\xe2\x80\x99t bar me, \xe2\x80\x99cause I\xe2\x80\x99m a nigger!\xe2\x80\x94she\xe2\x80\x99d \xe2\x80\x99s soon have a toad\r\ntouch her! There can\xe2\x80\x99t nobody love niggers, and niggers can\xe2\x80\x99t do\r\nnothin\xe2\x80\x99! _I_ don\xe2\x80\x99t care,\xe2\x80\x9d said Topsy, beginning to whistle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Topsy, poor child, _I_ love you!\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva, with a sudden burst of\r\nfeeling, and laying her little thin, white hand on Topsy\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder; \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nlove you, because you haven\xe2\x80\x99t had any father, or mother, or\r\nfriends;\xe2\x80\x94because you\xe2\x80\x99ve been a poor, abused child! I love you, and I\r\nwant you to be good. I am very unwell, Topsy, and I think I shan\xe2\x80\x99t live\r\na great while; and it really grieves me, to have you be so naughty. I\r\nwish you would try to be good, for my sake;\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s only a little while I\r\nshall be with you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe round, keen eyes of the black child were overcast with\r\ntears;\xe2\x80\x94large, bright drops rolled heavily down, one by one, and fell on\r\nthe little white hand. Yes, in that moment, a ray of real belief, a ray\r\nof heavenly love, had penetrated the darkness of her heathen soul! She\r\nlaid her head down between her knees, and wept and sobbed,\xe2\x80\x94while the\r\nbeautiful child, bending over her, looked like the picture of some\r\nbright angel stooping to reclaim a sinner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor Topsy!\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva, \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t you know that Jesus loves all alike? He\r\nis just as willing to love you, as me. He loves you just as I do,\xe2\x80\x94only\r\nmore, because he is better. He will help you to be good; and you can go\r\nto Heaven at last, and be an angel forever, just as much as if you were\r\nwhite. Only think of it, Topsy!\xe2\x80\x94_you_ can be one of those spirits\r\nbright, Uncle Tom sings about.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, dear Miss Eva, dear Miss Eva!\xe2\x80\x9d said the child; \xe2\x80\x9cI will try, I will\r\ntry; I never did care nothin\xe2\x80\x99 about it before.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSt. Clare, at this instant, dropped the curtain. \xe2\x80\x9cIt puts me in mind of\r\nmother,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to Miss Ophelia. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is true what she told me; if we\r\nwant to give sight to the blind, we must be willing to do as Christ\r\ndid,\xe2\x80\x94call them to us, and _put our hands on them_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve always had a prejudice against negroes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99s a fact, I never could bear to have that child touch me; but, I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t think she knew it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrust any child to find that out,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare; \xe2\x80\x9cthere\xe2\x80\x99s no keeping\r\nit from them. But I believe that all the trying in the world to benefit\r\na child, and all the substantial favors you can do them, will never\r\nexcite one emotion of gratitude, while that feeling of repugnance\r\nremains in the heart;\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s a queer kind of a fact,\xe2\x80\x94but so it is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know how I can help it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia; \xe2\x80\x9cthey _are_\r\ndisagreeable to me,\xe2\x80\x94this child in particular,\xe2\x80\x94how can I help feeling\r\nso?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEva does, it seems.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, she\xe2\x80\x99s so loving! After all, though, she\xe2\x80\x99s no more than\r\nChrist-like,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia; \xe2\x80\x9cI wish I were like her. She might\r\nteach me a lesson.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be the first time a little child had been used to instruct\r\nan old disciple, if it _were_ so,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXVI\r\nDeath\r\n\r\n\r\nWeep not for those whom the veil of the tomb,\r\nIn life\xe2\x80\x99s early morning, hath hid from our eyes.[1]\r\n\r\n\r\n [1] \xe2\x80\x9cWeep Not for Those,\xe2\x80\x9d a poem by Thomas Moore (1779-1852).\r\n\r\n\r\nEva\xe2\x80\x99s bed-room was a spacious apartment, which, like all the other\r\nrooms in the house, opened on to the broad verandah. The room\r\ncommunicated, on one side, with her father and mother\xe2\x80\x99s apartment; on\r\nthe other, with that appropriated to Miss Ophelia. St. Clare had\r\ngratified his own eye and taste, in furnishing this room in a style\r\nthat had a peculiar keeping with the character of her for whom it was\r\nintended. The windows were hung with curtains of rose-colored and white\r\nmuslin, the floor was spread with a matting which had been ordered in\r\nParis, to a pattern of his own device, having round it a border of\r\nrose-buds and leaves, and a centre-piece with full-flown roses. The\r\nbedstead, chairs, and lounges, were of bamboo, wrought in peculiarly\r\ngraceful and fanciful patterns. Over the head of the bed was an\r\nalabaster bracket, on which a beautiful sculptured angel stood, with\r\ndrooping wings, holding out a crown of myrtle-leaves. From this\r\ndepended, over the bed, light curtains of rose-colored gauze, striped\r\nwith silver, supplying that protection from mosquitos which is an\r\nindispensable addition to all sleeping accommodation in that climate.\r\nThe graceful bamboo lounges were amply supplied with cushions of\r\nrose-colored damask, while over them, depending from the hands of\r\nsculptured figures, were gauze curtains similar to those of the bed. A\r\nlight, fanciful bamboo table stood in the middle of the room, where a\r\nParian vase, wrought in the shape of a white lily, with its buds,\r\nstood, ever filled with flowers. On this table lay Eva\xe2\x80\x99s books and\r\nlittle trinkets, with an elegantly wrought alabaster writing-stand,\r\nwhich her father had supplied to her when he saw her trying to improve\r\nherself in writing. There was a fireplace in the room, and on the\r\nmarble mantle above stood a beautifully wrought statuette of Jesus\r\nreceiving little children, and on either side marble vases, for which\r\nit was Tom\xe2\x80\x99s pride and delight to offer bouquets every morning. Two or\r\nthree exquisite paintings of children, in various attitudes,\r\nembellished the wall. In short, the eye could turn nowhere without\r\nmeeting images of childhood, of beauty, and of peace. Those little eyes\r\nnever opened, in the morning light, without falling on something which\r\nsuggested to the heart soothing and beautiful thoughts.\r\n\r\nThe deceitful strength which had buoyed Eva up for a little while was\r\nfast passing away; seldom and more seldom her light footstep was heard\r\nin the verandah, and oftener and oftener she was found reclined on a\r\nlittle lounge by the open window, her large, deep eyes fixed on the\r\nrising and falling waters of the lake.\r\n\r\nIt was towards the middle of the afternoon, as she was so\r\nreclining,\xe2\x80\x94her Bible half open, her little transparent fingers lying\r\nlistlessly between the leaves,\xe2\x80\x94suddenly she heard her mother\xe2\x80\x99s voice,\r\nin sharp tones, in the verandah.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat now, you baggage!\xe2\x80\x94what new piece of mischief! You\xe2\x80\x99ve been picking\r\nthe flowers, hey?\xe2\x80\x9d and Eva heard the sound of a smart slap.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLaw, Missis! they \xe2\x80\x99s for Miss Eva,\xe2\x80\x9d she heard a voice say, which she\r\nknew belonged to Topsy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Eva! A pretty excuse!\xe2\x80\x94you suppose she wants _your_ flowers, you\r\ngood-for-nothing nigger! Get along off with you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn a moment, Eva was off from her lounge, and in the verandah.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, don\xe2\x80\x99t, mother! I should like the flowers; do give them to me; I\r\nwant them!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, Eva, your room is full now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t have too many,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva. \xe2\x80\x9cTopsy, do bring them here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTopsy, who had stood sullenly, holding down her head, now came up and\r\noffered her flowers. She did it with a look of hesitation and\r\nbashfulness, quite unlike the eldrich boldness and brightness which was\r\nusual with her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a beautiful bouquet!\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva, looking at it.\r\n\r\nIt was rather a singular one,\xe2\x80\x94a brilliant scarlet geranium, and one\r\nsingle white japonica, with its glossy leaves. It was tied up with an\r\nevident eye to the contrast of color, and the arrangement of every leaf\r\nhad carefully been studied.\r\n\r\nTopsy looked pleased, as Eva said,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cTopsy, you arrange flowers very\r\nprettily. Here,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cis this vase I haven\xe2\x80\x99t any flowers for. She knows she\r\nmustn\xe2\x80\x99t pick flowers,\xe2\x80\x94so she does it; that\xe2\x80\x99s all there is to it. But,\r\nif you fancy to have her pluck them, so be it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMamma, I think Topsy is different from what she used to be; she\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ntrying to be a good girl.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99ll have to try a good while before _she_ gets to be good,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nMarie, with a careless laugh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you know, mamma, poor Topsy! everything has always been against\r\nher.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot since she\xe2\x80\x99s been here, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure. Isn\xe2\x80\x99t Jesus her\r\nSaviour?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, that may be. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nto be done; we ought to be thankful for our own advantages.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hardly can be,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m so sorry to think of poor folks that\r\nhaven\xe2\x80\x99t any.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s odd enough,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie;\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sure my religion makes me\r\nthankful for my advantages.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMamma,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva, \xe2\x80\x9cI want to have some of my hair cut off,\xe2\x80\x94a good deal\r\nof it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat for?\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMamma, I want to give some away to my friends, while I am able to give\r\nit to them myself. Won\xe2\x80\x99t you ask aunty to come and cut it for me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMarie raised her voice, and called Miss Ophelia, from the other room.\r\n\r\nThe child half rose from her pillow as she came in, and, shaking down\r\nher long golden-brown curls, said, rather playfully, \xe2\x80\x9cCome aunty, shear\r\nthe sheep!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s that?\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, who just then entered with some fruit he\r\nhad been out to get for her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPapa, I just want aunty to cut off some of my hair;\xe2\x80\x94there\xe2\x80\x99s too much\r\nof it, and it makes my head hot. Besides, I want to give some of it\r\naway.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia came, with her scissors.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake care,\xe2\x80\x94don\xe2\x80\x99t spoil the looks of it!\xe2\x80\x9d said her father; \xe2\x80\x9ccut\r\nunderneath, where it won\xe2\x80\x99t show. Eva\xe2\x80\x99s curls are my pride.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, papa!\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva, sadly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and I want them kept handsome against the time I take you up to\r\nyour uncle\xe2\x80\x99s plantation, to see Cousin Henrique,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, in a\r\ngay tone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall never go there, papa;\xe2\x80\x94I am going to a better country. Don\xe2\x80\x99t you see, papa, that I get weaker, every day?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy do you insist that I shall believe such a cruel thing, Eva?\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nher father.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly because it is _true_, papa: and, if you will believe it now,\r\nperhaps you will get to feel about it as I do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSt. Clare closed his lips, and stood gloomily eying the long, beautiful\r\ncurls, which, as they were separated from the child\xe2\x80\x99s head, were laid,\r\none by one, in her lap. She raised them up, looked earnestly at them,\r\ntwined them around her thin fingers, and looked from time to time,\r\nanxiously at her father.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s just what I\xe2\x80\x99ve been foreboding!\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie; \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s just what has\r\nbeen preying on my health, from day to day, bringing me downward to the\r\ngrave, though nobody regards it. I have seen this, long. St. Clare, you\r\nwill see, after a while, that I was right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich will afford you great consolation, no doubt!\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, in\r\na dry, bitter tone.\r\n\r\nMarie lay back on a lounge, and covered her face with her cambric\r\nhandkerchief.\r\n\r\nEva\xe2\x80\x99s clear blue eye looked earnestly from one to the other. It was the\r\ncalm, comprehending gaze of a soul half loosed from its earthly bonds;\r\nit was evident she saw, felt, and appreciated, the difference between\r\nthe two.\r\n\r\nShe beckoned with her hand to her father. He came and sat down by her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPapa, my strength fades away every day, and I know I must go. There\r\nare some things I want to say and do,\xe2\x80\x94that I ought to do; and you are\r\nso unwilling to have me speak a word on this subject. But it must come;\r\nthere\xe2\x80\x99s no putting it off. Do be willing I should speak now!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy child, I _am_ willing!\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, covering his eyes with one\r\nhand, and holding up Eva\xe2\x80\x99s hand with the other.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, I want to see all our people together. I have some things I\r\n_must_ say to them,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Well_,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, in a tone of dry endurance.\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia despatched a messenger, and soon the whole of the servants\r\nwere convened in the room.\r\n\r\nEva lay back on her pillows; her hair hanging loosely about her face,\r\nher crimson cheeks contrasting painfully with the intense whiteness of\r\nher complexion and the thin contour of her limbs and features, and her\r\nlarge, soul-like eyes fixed earnestly on every one.\r\n\r\nThe servants were struck with a sudden emotion. The spiritual face, the\r\nlong locks of hair cut off and lying by her, her father\xe2\x80\x99s averted face,\r\nand Marie\xe2\x80\x99s sobs, struck at once upon the feelings of a sensitive and\r\nimpressible race; and, as they came in, they looked one on another,\r\nsighed, and shook their heads. There was a deep silence, like that of a\r\nfuneral.\r\n\r\nEva raised herself, and looked long and earnestly round at every one.\r\nAll looked sad and apprehensive. Many of the women hid their faces in\r\ntheir aprons.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI sent for you all, my dear friends,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva, \xe2\x80\x9cbecause I love you. I\r\nlove you all; and I have something to say to you, which I want you\r\nalways to remember. . . . I am going to leave you. In a few more weeks\r\nyou will see me no more\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHere the child was interrupted by bursts of groans, sobs, and\r\nlamentations, which broke from all present, and in which her slender\r\nvoice was lost entirely. She waited a moment, and then, speaking in a\r\ntone that checked the sobs of all, she said,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you love me, you must not interrupt me so. Listen to what I say. I\r\nwant to speak to you about your souls. . . . Many of you, I am afraid,\r\nare very careless. You are thinking only about this world. I want you\r\nto remember that there is a beautiful world, where Jesus is. I am going\r\nthere, and you can go there. It is for you, as much as me. But, if you\r\nwant to go there, you must not live idle, careless, thoughtless lives.\r\nYou must be Christians. You must remember that each one of you can\r\nbecome angels, and be angels forever. . . . If you want to be\r\nChristians, Jesus will help you. You must pray to him; you must read\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe child checked herself, looked piteously at them, and said,\r\nsorrowfully,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO dear! you _can\xe2\x80\x99t_ read\xe2\x80\x94poor souls!\xe2\x80\x9d and she hid her face in the\r\npillow and sobbed, while many a smothered sob from those she was\r\naddressing, who were kneeling on the floor, aroused her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, raising her face and smiling brightly through\r\nher tears, \xe2\x80\x9cI have prayed for you; and I know Jesus will help you, even\r\nif you can\xe2\x80\x99t read. Try all to do the best you can; pray every day; ask\r\nHim to help you, and get the Bible read to you whenever you can; and I\r\nthink I shall see you all in heaven.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAmen,\xe2\x80\x9d was the murmured response from the lips of Tom and Mammy, and\r\nsome of the elder ones, who belonged to the Methodist church. The\r\nyounger and more thoughtless ones, for the time completely overcome,\r\nwere sobbing, with their heads bowed upon their knees.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva, \xe2\x80\x9cyou all love me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; oh, yes! indeed we do! Lord bless her!\xe2\x80\x9d was the involuntary\r\nanswer of all.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I know you do! There isn\xe2\x80\x99t one of you that hasn\xe2\x80\x99t always been\r\nvery kind to me; and I want to give you something that, when you look\r\nat, you shall always remember me, I\xe2\x80\x99m going to give all of you a curl\r\nof my hair; and, when you look at it, think that I loved you and am\r\ngone to heaven, and that I want to see you all there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt is impossible to describe the scene, as, with tears and sobs, they\r\ngathered round the little creature, and took from her hands what seemed\r\nto them a last mark of her love. They fell on their knees; they sobbed,\r\nand prayed, and kissed the hem of her garment; and the elder ones\r\npoured forth words of endearment, mingled in prayers and blessings,\r\nafter the manner of their susceptible race.\r\n\r\nAs each one took their gift, Miss Ophelia, who was apprehensive for the\r\neffect of all this excitement on her little patient, signed to each one\r\nto pass out of the apartment.\r\n\r\nAt last, all were gone but Tom and Mammy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere, Uncle Tom,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva, \xe2\x80\x9cis a beautiful one for you. O, I am so\r\nhappy, Uncle Tom, to think I shall see you in heaven,\xe2\x80\x94for I\xe2\x80\x99m sure I\r\nshall; and Mammy,\xe2\x80\x94dear, good, kind Mammy!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, fondly throwing\r\nher arms round her old nurse,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI know you\xe2\x80\x99ll be there, too.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Miss Eva, don\xe2\x80\x99t see how I can live without ye, no how!\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nfaithful creature. \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Pears like it\xe2\x80\x99s just taking everything off the\r\nplace to oncet!\xe2\x80\x9d and Mammy gave way to a passion of grief.\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia pushed her and Tom gently from the apartment, and thought\r\nthey were all gone; but, as she turned, Topsy was standing there.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere did you start up from?\xe2\x80\x9d she said, suddenly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was here,\xe2\x80\x9d said Topsy, wiping the tears from her eyes. \xe2\x80\x9cO, Miss Eva,\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ve been a bad girl; but won\xe2\x80\x99t you give _me_ one, too?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, poor Topsy! to be sure, I will. There\xe2\x80\x94every time you look at\r\nthat, think that I love you, and wanted you to be a good girl!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Miss Eva, I _is_ tryin!\xe2\x80\x9d said Topsy, earnestly; \xe2\x80\x9cbut, Lor, it\xe2\x80\x99s so\r\nhard to be good! \xe2\x80\x99Pears like I an\xe2\x80\x99t used to it, no ways!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJesus knows it, Topsy; he is sorry for you; he will help you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTopsy, with her eyes hid in her apron, was silently passed from the\r\napartment by Miss Ophelia; but, as she went, she hid the precious curl\r\nin her bosom.\r\n\r\nAll being gone, Miss Ophelia shut the door. That worthy lady had wiped\r\naway many tears of her own, during the scene; but concern for the\r\nconsequence of such an excitement to her young charge was uppermost in\r\nher mind.\r\n\r\nSt. Clare had been sitting, during the whole time, with his hand\r\nshading his eyes, in the same attitude.\r\n\r\nWhen they were all gone, he sat so still.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPapa!\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva, gently, laying her hand on his.\r\n\r\nHe gave a sudden start and shiver; but made no answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear papa!\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_I cannot_,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, rising, \xe2\x80\x9cI _cannot_ have it so! The\r\nAlmighty hath dealt _very bitterly_ with me!\xe2\x80\x9d and St. Clare pronounced\r\nthese words with a bitter emphasis, indeed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAugustine! has not God a right to do what he will with his own?\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nMiss Ophelia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps so; but that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t make it any easier to bear,\xe2\x80\x9d said he,\r\nwith a dry, hard, tearless manner, as he turned away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPapa, you break my heart!\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva, rising and throwing herself into\r\nhis arms; \xe2\x80\x9cyou must not feel so!\xe2\x80\x9d and the child sobbed and wept with a\r\nviolence which alarmed them all, and turned her father\xe2\x80\x99s thoughts at\r\nonce to another channel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, Eva,\xe2\x80\x94there, dearest! I will be resigned; I was wicked to speak as I did.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEva soon lay like a wearied dove in her father\xe2\x80\x99s arms; and he, bending\r\nover her, soothed her by every tender word he could think of.\r\n\r\nMarie rose and threw herself out of the apartment into her own, when\r\nshe fell into violent hysterics.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou didn\xe2\x80\x99t give me a curl, Eva,\xe2\x80\x9d said her father, smiling sadly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are all yours, papa,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, smiling\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cyours and mamma\xe2\x80\x99s; and\r\nyou must give dear aunty as many as she wants. I only gave them to our\r\npoor people myself, because you know, papa, they might be forgotten\r\nwhen I am gone, and because I hoped it might help them remember. . . .\r\nYou are a Christian, are you not, papa?\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva, doubtfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy do you ask me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know. You are so good, I don\xe2\x80\x99t see how you can help it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is being a Christian, Eva?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLoving Christ most of all,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you, Eva?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly I do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou never saw him,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat makes no difference,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eva. \xe2\x80\x9cI believe him, and in a few days\r\nI shall _see_ him;\xe2\x80\x9d and the young face grew fervent, radiant with joy.\r\n\r\nSt. Clare said no more. It was a feeling which he had seen before in\r\nhis mother; but no chord within vibrated to it.\r\n\r\nEva, after this, declined rapidly; there was no more any doubt of the\r\nevent; the fondest hope could not be blinded. Her beautiful room was\r\navowedly a sick room; and Miss Ophelia day and night performed the\r\nduties of a nurse,\xe2\x80\x94and never did her friends appreciate her value more\r\nthan in that capacity. With so well-trained a hand and eye, such\r\nperfect adroitness and practice in every art which could promote\r\nneatness and comfort, and keep out of sight every disagreeable incident\r\nof sickness,\xe2\x80\x94with such a perfect sense of time, such a clear,\r\nuntroubled head, such exact accuracy in remembering every prescription\r\nand direction of the doctors,\xe2\x80\x94she was everything to him. They who had\r\nshrugged their shoulders at her little peculiarities and setnesses, so\r\nunlike the careless freedom of southern manners, acknowledged that now\r\nshe was the exact person that was wanted.\r\n\r\nUncle Tom was much in Eva\xe2\x80\x99s room. The child suffered much from nervous\r\nrestlessness, and it was a relief to her to be carried; and it was\r\nTom\xe2\x80\x99s greatest delight to carry her little frail form in his arms,\r\nresting on a pillow, now up and down her room, now out into the\r\nverandah; and when the fresh sea-breezes blew from the lake,\xe2\x80\x94and the\r\nchild felt freshest in the morning,\xe2\x80\x94he would sometimes walk with her\r\nunder the orange-trees in the garden, or, sitting down in some of their\r\nold seats, sing to her their favorite old hymns.\r\n\r\nHer father often did the same thing; but his frame was slighter, and\r\nwhen he was weary, Eva would say to him,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, papa, let Tom take me. Poor fellow! it pleases him; and you know\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99s all he can do now, and he wants to do something!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo do I, Eva!\xe2\x80\x9d said her father.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, papa, you can do everything, and are everything to me. You read\r\nto me,\xe2\x80\x94you sit up nights,\xe2\x80\x94and Tom has only this one thing, and his\r\nsinging; and I know, too, he does it easier than you can. He carries me\r\nso strong!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe desire to do something was not confined to Tom. Every servant in\r\nthe establishment showed the same feeling, and in their way did what\r\nthey could.\r\n\r\nPoor Mammy\xe2\x80\x99s heart yearned towards her darling; but she found no\r\nopportunity, night or day, as Marie declared that the state of her mind\r\nwas such, it was impossible for her to rest; and, of course, it was\r\nagainst her principles to let any one else rest. Twenty times in a\r\nnight, Mammy would be roused to rub her feet, to bathe her head, to\r\nfind her pocket-handkerchief, to see what the noise was in Eva\xe2\x80\x99s room,\r\nto let down a curtain because it was too light, or to put it up because\r\nit was too dark; and, in the daytime, when she longed to have some\r\nshare in the nursing of her pet, Marie seemed unusually ingenious in\r\nkeeping her busy anywhere and everywhere all over the house, or about\r\nher own person; so that stolen interviews and momentary glimpses were\r\nall she could obtain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI feel it my duty to be particularly careful of myself, now,\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nwould say, \xe2\x80\x9cfeeble as I am, and with the whole care and nursing of that\r\ndear child upon me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, \xe2\x80\x9cI thought our cousin relieved you\r\nof that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou talk like a man, St. Clare,\xe2\x80\x94just as if a mother _could_ be\r\nrelieved of the care of a child in that state; but, then, it\xe2\x80\x99s all\r\nalike,\xe2\x80\x94no one ever knows what I feel! I can\xe2\x80\x99t throw things off, as you\r\ndo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSt. Clare smiled. You must excuse him, he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t help it,\xe2\x80\x94for St.\r\nClare could smile yet. For so bright and placid was the farewell voyage\r\nof the little spirit,\xe2\x80\x94by such sweet and fragrant breezes was the small\r\nbark borne towards the heavenly shores,\xe2\x80\x94that it was impossible to\r\nrealize that it was death that was approaching. The child felt no\r\npain,\xe2\x80\x94only a tranquil, soft weakness, daily and almost insensibly\r\nincreasing; and she was so beautiful, so loving, so trustful, so happy,\r\nthat one could not resist the soothing influence of that air of\r\ninnocence and peace which seemed to breathe around her. St. Clare found\r\na strange calm coming over him. It was not hope,\xe2\x80\x94that was impossible;\r\nit was not resignation; it was only a calm resting in the present,\r\nwhich seemed so beautiful that he wished to think of no future. It was\r\nlike that hush of spirit which we feel amid the bright, mild woods of\r\nautumn, when the bright hectic flush is on the trees, and the last\r\nlingering flowers by the brook; and we joy in it all the more, because\r\nwe know that soon it will all pass away.\r\n\r\nThe friend who knew most of Eva\xe2\x80\x99s own imaginings and foreshadowings was\r\nher faithful bearer, Tom. To him she said what she would not disturb\r\nher father by saying. To him she imparted those mysterious intimations\r\nwhich the soul feels, as the cords begin to unbind, ere it leaves its\r\nclay forever.\r\n\r\nTom, at last, would not sleep in his room, but lay all night in the\r\nouter verandah, ready to rouse at every call.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUncle Tom, what alive have you taken to sleeping anywhere and\r\neverywhere, like a dog, for?\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia. \xe2\x80\x9cI thought you was one\r\nof the orderly sort, that liked to lie in bed in a Christian way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do, Miss Feely,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, mysteriously. \xe2\x80\x9cI do, but now\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, what now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe mustn\xe2\x80\x99t speak loud; Mas\xe2\x80\x99r St. Clare won\xe2\x80\x99t hear on \xe2\x80\x99t; but Miss\r\nFeely, you know there must be somebody watchin\xe2\x80\x99 for the bridegroom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean, Tom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know it says in Scripture, \xe2\x80\x98At midnight there was a great cry\r\nmade. Behold, the bridegroom cometh.\xe2\x80\x99 That\xe2\x80\x99s what I\xe2\x80\x99m spectin now,\r\nevery night, Miss Feely,\xe2\x80\x94and I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t sleep out o\xe2\x80\x99 hearin, no ways.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, Uncle Tom, what makes you think so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Eva, she talks to me. The Lord, he sends his messenger in the\r\nsoul. I must be thar, Miss Feely; for when that ar blessed child goes\r\ninto the kingdom, they\xe2\x80\x99ll open the door so wide, we\xe2\x80\x99ll all get a look\r\nin at the glory, Miss Feely.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUncle Tom, did Miss Eva say she felt more unwell than usual tonight?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; but she telled me, this morning, she was coming nearer,\xe2\x80\x94thar\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nthem that tells it to the child, Miss Feely. It\xe2\x80\x99s the angels,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98it\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\ntrumpet sound afore the break o\xe2\x80\x99 day,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, quoting from a\r\nfavorite hymn.\r\n\r\nThis dialogue passed between Miss Ophelia and Tom, between ten and\r\neleven, one evening, after her arrangements had all been made for the\r\nnight, when, on going to bolt her outer door, she found Tom stretched\r\nalong by it, in the outer verandah.\r\n\r\nShe was not nervous or impressible; but the solemn, heart-felt manner\r\nstruck her. Eva had been unusually bright and cheerful, that afternoon,\r\nand had sat raised in her bed, and looked over all her little trinkets\r\nand precious things, and designated the friends to whom she would have\r\nthem given; and her manner was more animated, and her voice more\r\nnatural, than they had known it for weeks. Her father had been in, in\r\nthe evening, and had said that Eva appeared more like her former self\r\nthan ever she had done since her sickness; and when he kissed her for\r\nthe night, he said to Miss Ophelia,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cCousin, we may keep her with us,\r\nafter all; she is certainly better;\xe2\x80\x9d and he had retired with a lighter\r\nheart in his bosom than he had had there for weeks.\r\n\r\nBut at midnight,\xe2\x80\x94strange, mystic hour!\xe2\x80\x94when the veil between the frail\r\npresent and the eternal future grows thin,\xe2\x80\x94then came the messenger!\r\n\r\nThere was a sound in that chamber, first of one who stepped quickly. It\r\nwas Miss Ophelia, who had resolved to sit up all night with her little\r\ncharge, and who, at the turn of the night, had discerned what\r\nexperienced nurses significantly call \xe2\x80\x9ca change.\xe2\x80\x9d The outer door was\r\nquickly opened, and Tom, who was watching outside, was on the alert, in\r\na moment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo for the doctor, Tom! lose not a moment,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia; and,\r\nstepping across the room, she rapped at St. Clare\xe2\x80\x99s door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCousin,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cI wish you would come.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThose words fell on his heart like clods upon a coffin. Why did they?\r\nHe was up and in the room in an instant, and bending over Eva, who\r\nstill slept.\r\n\r\nWhat was it he saw that made his heart stand still? Why was no word\r\nspoken between the two? Thou canst say, who hast seen that same\r\nexpression on the face dearest to thee;\xe2\x80\x94that look indescribable,\r\nhopeless, unmistakable, that says to thee that thy beloved is no longer\r\nthine.\r\n\r\nOn the face of the child, however, there was no ghastly imprint,\xe2\x80\x94only a\r\nhigh and almost sublime expression,\xe2\x80\x94the overshadowing presence of\r\nspiritual natures, the dawning of immortal life in that childish soul.\r\n\r\nThey stood there so still, gazing upon her, that even the ticking of\r\nthe watch seemed too loud. In a few moments, Tom returned, with the\r\ndoctor. He entered, gave one look, and stood silent as the rest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen did this change take place?\xe2\x80\x9d said he, in a low whisper, to Miss\r\nOphelia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbout the turn of the night,\xe2\x80\x9d was the reply.\r\n\r\nMarie, roused by the entrance of the doctor, appeared, hurriedly, from\r\nthe next room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAugustine! Cousin!\xe2\x80\x94O!\xe2\x80\x94what!\xe2\x80\x9d she hurriedly began.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHush!\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, hoarsely; _\xe2\x80\x9cshe is dying!\xe2\x80\x9d_\r\n\r\nMammy heard the words, and flew to awaken the servants. The house was\r\nsoon roused,\xe2\x80\x94lights were seen, footsteps heard, anxious faces thronged\r\nthe verandah, and looked tearfully through the glass doors; but St.\r\nClare heard and said nothing,\xe2\x80\x94he saw only _that look_ on the face of\r\nthe little sleeper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, if she would only wake, and speak once more!\xe2\x80\x9d he said; and,\r\nstooping over her, he spoke in her ear,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cEva, darling!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe large blue eyes unclosed\xe2\x80\x94a smile passed over her face;\xe2\x80\x94she tried to\r\nraise her head, and to speak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know me, Eva?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear papa,\xe2\x80\x9d said the child, with a last effort, throwing her arms\r\nabout his neck. In a moment they dropped again; and, as St. Clare\r\nraised his head, he saw a spasm of mortal agony pass over the face,\xe2\x80\x94she\r\nstruggled for breath, and threw up her little hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, God, this is dreadful!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, turning away in agony, and\r\nwringing Tom\xe2\x80\x99s hand, scarce conscious what he was doing. \xe2\x80\x9cO, Tom, my\r\nboy, it is killing me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom had his master\xe2\x80\x99s hands between his own; and, with tears streaming\r\ndown his dark cheeks, looked up for help where he had always been used\r\nto look.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPray that this may be cut short!\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthis wrings my\r\nheart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, bless the Lord! it\xe2\x80\x99s over,\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s over, dear Master!\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom; \xe2\x80\x9clook\r\nat her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe child lay panting on her pillows, as one exhausted,\xe2\x80\x94the large clear\r\neyes rolled up and fixed. Ah, what said those eyes, that spoke so much\r\nof heaven! Earth was past,\xe2\x80\x94and earthly pain; but so solemn, so\r\nmysterious, was the triumphant brightness of that face, that it checked\r\neven the sobs of sorrow. They pressed around her, in breathless\r\nstillness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEva,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, gently.\r\n\r\nShe did not hear.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Eva, tell us what you see! What is it?\xe2\x80\x9d said her father.\r\n\r\nA bright, a glorious smile passed over her face, and she said,\r\nbrokenly,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cO! love,\xe2\x80\x94joy,\xe2\x80\x94peace!\xe2\x80\x9d gave one sigh and passed from death\r\nunto life!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFarewell, beloved child! the bright, eternal doors have closed after\r\nthee; we shall see thy sweet face no more. O, woe for them who watched\r\nthy entrance into heaven, when they shall wake and find only the cold\r\ngray sky of daily life, and thou gone forever!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXVII\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis Is the Last of Earth\xe2\x80\x9d[1]\r\n\r\n\r\n [1] \xe2\x80\x9cThis is the last of Earth! I am content,\xe2\x80\x9d last words of John\r\n Quincy Adams, uttered February 21, 1848.\r\n\r\n\r\nThe statuettes and pictures in Eva\xe2\x80\x99s room were shrouded in white\r\nnapkins, and only hushed breathings and muffled footfalls were heard\r\nthere, and the light stole in solemnly through windows partially\r\ndarkened by closed blinds.\r\n\r\nThe bed was draped in white; and there, beneath the drooping\r\nangel-figure, lay a little sleeping form,\xe2\x80\x94sleeping never to waken!\r\n\r\nThere she lay, robed in one of the simple white dresses she had been\r\nwont to wear when living; the rose-colored light through the curtains\r\ncast over the icy coldness of death a warm glow. The heavy eyelashes\r\ndrooped softly on the pure cheek; the head was turned a little to one\r\nside, as if in natural sleep, but there was diffused over every\r\nlineament of the face that high celestial expression, that mingling of\r\nrapture and repose, which showed it was no earthly or temporary sleep,\r\nbut the long, sacred rest which \xe2\x80\x9cHe giveth to his beloved.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere is no death to such as thou, dear Eva! neither darkness nor\r\nshadow of death; only such a bright fading as when the morning star\r\nfades in the golden dawn. Thine is the victory without the battle,\xe2\x80\x94the\r\ncrown without the conflict.\r\n\r\nSo did St. Clare think, as, with folded arms, he stood there gazing.\r\nAh! who shall say what he did think? for, from the hour that voices had\r\nsaid, in the dying chamber, \xe2\x80\x9cshe is gone,\xe2\x80\x9d it had been all a dreary\r\nmist, a heavy \xe2\x80\x9cdimness of anguish.\xe2\x80\x9d He had heard voices around him; he\r\nhad had questions asked, and answered them; they had asked him when he\r\nwould have the funeral, and where they should lay her; and he had\r\nanswered, impatiently, that he cared not.\r\n\r\nAdolph and Rosa had arranged the chamber; volatile, fickle and\r\nchildish, as they generally were, they were soft-hearted and full of\r\nfeeling; and, while Miss Ophelia presided over the general details of\r\norder and neatness, it was their hands that added those soft, poetic\r\ntouches to the arrangements, that took from the death-room the grim and\r\nghastly air which too often marks a New England funeral.\r\n\r\nThere were still flowers on the shelves,\xe2\x80\x94all white, delicate and\r\nfragrant, with graceful, drooping leaves. Eva\xe2\x80\x99s little table, covered\r\nwith white, bore on it her favorite vase, with a single white moss\r\nrose-bud in it. The folds of the drapery, the fall of the curtains, had\r\nbeen arranged and rearranged, by Adolph and Rosa, with that nicety of\r\neye which characterizes their race. Even now, while St. Clare stood\r\nthere thinking, little Rosa tripped softly into the chamber with a\r\nbasket of white flowers. She stepped back when she saw St. Clare, and\r\nstopped respectfully; but, seeing that he did not observe her, she came\r\nforward to place them around the dead. St. Clare saw her as in a dream,\r\nwhile she placed in the small hands a fair cape jessamine, and, with\r\nadmirable taste, disposed other flowers around the couch.\r\n\r\nThe door opened again, and Topsy, her eyes swelled with crying,\r\nappeared, holding something under her apron. Rosa made a quick\r\nforbidding gesture; but she took a step into the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must go out,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rosa, in a sharp, positive whisper; \xe2\x80\x9c_you_\r\nhaven\xe2\x80\x99t any business here!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, do let me! I brought a flower,\xe2\x80\x94such a pretty one!\xe2\x80\x9d said Topsy,\r\nholding up a half-blown tea rose-bud. \xe2\x80\x9cDo let me put just one there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGet along!\xe2\x80\x9d said Rosa, more decidedly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet her stay!\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, suddenly stamping his foot. \xe2\x80\x9cShe shall\r\ncome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nRosa suddenly retreated, and Topsy came forward and laid her offering\r\nat the feet of the corpse; then suddenly, with a wild and bitter cry,\r\nshe threw herself on the floor alongside the bed, and wept, and moaned\r\naloud.\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia hastened into the room, and tried to raise and silence\r\nher; but in vain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Miss Eva! oh, Miss Eva! I wish I \xe2\x80\x99s dead, too,\xe2\x80\x94I do!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was a piercing wildness in the cry; the blood flushed into St.\r\nClare\xe2\x80\x99s white, marble-like face, and the first tears he had shed since\r\nEva died stood in his eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGet up, child,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, in a softened voice; \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t cry so.\r\nMiss Eva is gone to heaven; she is an angel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I can\xe2\x80\x99t see her!\xe2\x80\x9d said Topsy. \xe2\x80\x9cI never shall see her!\xe2\x80\x9d and she\r\nsobbed again.\r\n\r\nThey all stood a moment in silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_She_ said she _loved_ me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Topsy,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cshe did! O, dear! oh, dear!\r\nthere an\xe2\x80\x99t _nobody_ left now,\xe2\x80\x94there an\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s true enough\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare; \xe2\x80\x9cbut do,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to Miss Ophelia,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9csee if you can\xe2\x80\x99t comfort the poor creature.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI jist wish I hadn\xe2\x80\x99t never been born,\xe2\x80\x9d said Topsy. \xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t want to\r\nbe born, no ways; and I don\xe2\x80\x99t see no use on \xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia raised her gently, but firmly, and took her from the room;\r\nbut, as she did so, some tears fell from her eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTopsy, you poor child,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, as she led her into her room, \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ngive up! _I_ can love you, though I am not like that dear little child.\r\nI hope I\xe2\x80\x99ve learnt something of the love of Christ from her. I can love\r\nyou; I do, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll try to help you to grow up a good Christian girl.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia\xe2\x80\x99s voice was more than her words, and more than that were\r\nthe honest tears that fell down her face. From that hour, she acquired\r\nan influence over the mind of the destitute child that she never lost.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, my Eva, whose little hour on earth did so much of good,\xe2\x80\x9d thought\r\nSt. Clare, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat account have I to give for my long years?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere were, for a while, soft whisperings and footfalls in the chamber,\r\nas one after another stole in, to look at the dead; and then came the\r\nlittle coffin; and then there was a funeral, and carriages drove to the\r\ndoor, and strangers came and were seated; and there were white scarfs\r\nand ribbons, and crape bands, and mourners dressed in black crape; and\r\nthere were words read from the Bible, and prayers offered; and St.\r\nClare lived, and walked, and moved, as one who has shed every tear;\xe2\x80\x94to\r\nthe last he saw only one thing, that golden head in the coffin; but\r\nthen he saw the cloth spread over it, the lid of the coffin closed; and\r\nhe walked, when he was put beside the others, down to a little place at\r\nthe bottom of the garden, and there, by the mossy seat where she and\r\nTom had talked, and sung, and read so often, was the little grave. St.\r\nClare stood beside it,\xe2\x80\x94looked vacantly down; he saw them lower the\r\nlittle coffin; he heard, dimly, the solemn words, \xe2\x80\x9cI am the\r\nresurrection and the Life; he that believeth in me, though he were\r\ndead, yet shall he live;\xe2\x80\x9d and, as the earth was cast in and filled up\r\nthe little grave, he could not realize that it was his Eva that they\r\nwere hiding from his sight.\r\n\r\nNor was it!\xe2\x80\x94not Eva, but only the frail seed of that bright, immortal\r\nform with which she shall yet come forth, in the day of the Lord Jesus!\r\n\r\nAnd then all were gone, and the mourners went back to the place which\r\nshould know her no more; and Marie\xe2\x80\x99s room was darkened, and she lay on\r\nthe bed, sobbing and moaning in uncontrollable grief, and calling every\r\nmoment for the attentions of all her servants. Of course, they had no\r\ntime to cry,\xe2\x80\x94why should they? the grief was _her_ grief, and she was\r\nfully convinced that nobody on earth did, could, or would feel it as\r\nshe did.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSt. Clare did not shed a tear,\xe2\x80\x9d she said; \xe2\x80\x9che didn\xe2\x80\x99t sympathize with\r\nher; it was perfectly wonderful to think how hard-hearted and unfeeling\r\nhe was, when he must know how she suffered.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo much are people the slave of their eye and ear, that many of the\r\nservants really thought that Missis was the principal sufferer in the\r\ncase, especially as Marie began to have hysterical spasms, and sent for\r\nthe doctor, and at last declared herself dying; and, in the running and\r\nscampering, and bringing up hot bottles, and heating of flannels, and\r\nchafing, and fussing, that ensued, there was quite a diversion.\r\n\r\nTom, however, had a feeling at his own heart, that drew him to his\r\nmaster. He followed him wherever he walked, wistfully and sadly; and\r\nwhen he saw him sitting, so pale and quiet, in Eva\xe2\x80\x99s room, holding\r\nbefore his eyes her little open Bible, though seeing no letter or word\r\nof what was in it, there was more sorrow to Tom in that still, fixed,\r\ntearless eye, than in all Marie\xe2\x80\x99s moans and lamentations.\r\n\r\nIn a few days the St. Clare family were back again in the city;\r\nAugustine, with the restlessness of grief, longing for another scene,\r\nto change the current of his thoughts. So they left the house and\r\ngarden, with its little grave, and came back to New Orleans; and St.\r\nClare walked the streets busily, and strove to fill up the chasm in his\r\nheart with hurry and bustle, and change of place; and people who saw\r\nhim in the street, or met him at the cafe, knew of his loss only by the\r\nweed on his hat; for there he was, smiling and talking, and reading the\r\nnewspaper, and speculating on politics, and attending to business\r\nmatters; and who could see that all this smiling outside was but a\r\nhollowed shell over a heart that was a dark and silent sepulchre?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. St. Clare is a singular man,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie to Miss Ophelia, in a\r\ncomplaining tone. \xe2\x80\x9cI used to think, if there was anything in the world\r\nhe did love, it was our dear little Eva; but he seems to be forgetting\r\nher very easily. I cannot ever get him to talk about her. I really did\r\nthink he would show more feeling!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStill waters run deepest, they used to tell me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia,\r\noracularly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, I don\xe2\x80\x99t believe in such things; it\xe2\x80\x99s all talk. If people have\r\nfeeling, they will show it,\xe2\x80\x94they can\xe2\x80\x99t help it; but, then, it\xe2\x80\x99s a great\r\nmisfortune to have feeling. I\xe2\x80\x99d rather have been made like St. Clare.\r\nMy feelings prey upon me so!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSure, Missis, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r St. Clare is gettin\xe2\x80\x99 thin as a shader. They say,\r\nhe don\xe2\x80\x99t never eat nothin\xe2\x80\x99,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mammy. \xe2\x80\x9cI know he don\xe2\x80\x99t forget Miss\r\nEva; I know there couldn\xe2\x80\x99t nobody,\xe2\x80\x94dear, little, blessed cretur!\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nadded, wiping her eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, at all events, he has no consideration for me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie; \xe2\x80\x9che\r\nhasn\xe2\x80\x99t spoken one word of sympathy, and he must know how much more a\r\nmother feels than any man can.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe heart knoweth its own bitterness,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, gravely.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s just what I think. I know just what I feel,\xe2\x80\x94nobody else seems\r\nto. Eva used to, but she is gone!\xe2\x80\x9d and Marie lay back on her lounge,\r\nand began to sob disconsolately.\r\n\r\nMarie was one of those unfortunately constituted mortals, in whose eyes\r\nwhatever is lost and gone assumes a value which it never had in\r\npossession. Whatever she had, she seemed to survey only to pick flaws\r\nin it; but, once fairly away, there was no end to her valuation of it.\r\n\r\nWhile this conversation was taking place in the parlor another was\r\ngoing on in St. Clare\xe2\x80\x99s library.\r\n\r\nTom, who was always uneasily following his master about, had seen him\r\ngo to his library, some hours before; and, after vainly waiting for him\r\nto come out, determined, at last, to make an errand in. He entered\r\nsoftly. St. Clare lay on his lounge, at the further end of the room. He\r\nwas lying on his face, with Eva\xe2\x80\x99s Bible open before him, at a little\r\ndistance. Tom walked up, and stood by the sofa. He hesitated; and,\r\nwhile he was hesitating, St. Clare suddenly raised himself up. The\r\nhonest face, so full of grief, and with such an imploring expression of\r\naffection and sympathy, struck his master. He laid his hand on Tom\xe2\x80\x99s,\r\nand bowed down his forehead on it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Tom, my boy, the whole world is as empty as an egg-shell.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know it, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r,\xe2\x80\x94I know it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom; \xe2\x80\x9cbut, oh, if Mas\xe2\x80\x99r could only\r\nlook up,\xe2\x80\x94up where our dear Miss Eva is,\xe2\x80\x94up to the dear Lord Jesus!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, Tom! I do look up; but the trouble is, I don\xe2\x80\x99t see anything, when\r\nI do, I wish I could.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom sighed heavily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt seems to be given to children, and poor, honest fellows, like you,\r\nto see what we can\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare. \xe2\x80\x9cHow comes it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou has \xe2\x80\x99hid from the wise and prudent, and revealed unto babes,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nmurmured Tom; \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98even so, Father, for so it seemed good in thy sight.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTom, I don\xe2\x80\x99t believe,\xe2\x80\x94I can\xe2\x80\x99t believe,\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99ve got the habit of\r\ndoubting,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare. \xe2\x80\x9cI want to believe this Bible,\xe2\x80\x94and I can\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear Mas\xe2\x80\x99r, pray to the good Lord,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Lord, I believe; help thou my\r\nunbelief.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho knows anything about anything?\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, his eyes wandering\r\ndreamily, and speaking to himself. \xe2\x80\x9cWas all that beautiful love and\r\nfaith only one of the ever-shifting phases of human feeling, having\r\nnothing real to rest on, passing away with the little breath? And is\r\nthere no more Eva,\xe2\x80\x94no heaven,\xe2\x80\x94no Christ,\xe2\x80\x94nothing?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, dear Mas\xe2\x80\x99r, there is! I know it; I\xe2\x80\x99m sure of it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, falling\r\non his knees. \xe2\x80\x9cDo, do, dear Mas\xe2\x80\x99r, believe it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do you know there\xe2\x80\x99s any Christ, Tom! You never saw the Lord.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFelt Him in my soul, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r,\xe2\x80\x94feel Him now! O, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r, when I was sold\r\naway from my old woman and the children, I was jest a\xe2\x80\x99most broke up. I\r\nfelt as if there warn\xe2\x80\x99t nothin\xe2\x80\x99 left; and then the good Lord, he stood\r\nby me, and he says, \xe2\x80\x98Fear not, Tom;\xe2\x80\x99 and he brings light and joy in a\r\npoor feller\xe2\x80\x99s soul,\xe2\x80\x94makes all peace; and I \xe2\x80\x99s so happy, and loves\r\neverybody, and feels willin\xe2\x80\x99 jest to be the Lord\xe2\x80\x99s, and have the Lord\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwill done, and be put jest where the Lord wants to put me. I know it\r\ncouldn\xe2\x80\x99t come from me, cause I \xe2\x80\x99s a poor, complainin\xe2\x80\x99 cretur; it comes\r\nfrom the Lord; and I know He\xe2\x80\x99s willin\xe2\x80\x99 to do for Mas\xe2\x80\x99r.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom spoke with fast-running tears and choking voice. St. Clare leaned\r\nhis head on his shoulder, and wrung the hard, faithful, black hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTom, you love me,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI \xe2\x80\x99s willin\xe2\x80\x99 to lay down my life, this blessed day, to see Mas\xe2\x80\x99r a\r\nChristian.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor, foolish boy!\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, half-raising himself. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not\r\nworth the love of one good, honest heart, like yours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r, dere\xe2\x80\x99s more than me loves you,\xe2\x80\x94the blessed Lord Jesus loves\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do you know that Tom?\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFeels it in my soul. O, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r! \xe2\x80\x99the love of Christ, that passeth\r\nknowledge.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSingular!\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, turning away, \xe2\x80\x9cthat the story of a man that\r\nlived and died eighteen hundred years ago can affect people so yet. But\r\nhe was no man,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, suddenly. \xe2\x80\x9cNo man ever had such long and\r\nliving power! O, that I could believe what my mother taught me, and\r\npray as I did when I was a boy!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf Mas\xe2\x80\x99r pleases,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, \xe2\x80\x9cMiss Eva used to read this so\r\nbeautifully. I wish Mas\xe2\x80\x99r\xe2\x80\x99d be so good as read it. Don\xe2\x80\x99t get no\r\nreadin\xe2\x80\x99, hardly, now Miss Eva\xe2\x80\x99s gone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe chapter was the eleventh of John,\xe2\x80\x94the touching account of the\r\nraising of Lazarus, St. Clare read it aloud, often pausing to wrestle\r\ndown feelings which were roused by the pathos of the story. Tom knelt\r\nbefore him, with clasped hands, and with an absorbed expression of\r\nlove, trust, adoration, on his quiet face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTom,\xe2\x80\x9d said his Master, \xe2\x80\x9cthis is all _real_ to you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can jest fairly _see_ it Mas\xe2\x80\x99r,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish I had your eyes, Tom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish, to the dear Lord, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r had!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, Tom, you know that I have a great deal more knowledge than you;\r\nwhat if I should tell you that I don\xe2\x80\x99t believe this Bible?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r!\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, holding up his hands, with a deprecating gesture.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWouldn\xe2\x80\x99t it shake your faith some, Tom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot a grain,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, Tom, you must know I know the most.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r, haven\xe2\x80\x99t you jest read how he hides from the wise and\r\nprudent, and reveals unto babes? But Mas\xe2\x80\x99r wasn\xe2\x80\x99t in earnest, for\r\nsartin, now?\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, anxiously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Tom, I was not. I don\xe2\x80\x99t disbelieve, and I think there is reason to\r\nbelieve; and still I don\xe2\x80\x99t. It\xe2\x80\x99s a troublesome bad habit I\xe2\x80\x99ve got,\r\nTom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf Mas\xe2\x80\x99r would only pray!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do you know I don\xe2\x80\x99t, Tom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes Mas\xe2\x80\x99r?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would, Tom, if there was anybody there when I pray; but it\xe2\x80\x99s all\r\nspeaking unto nothing, when I do. But come, Tom, you pray now, and show\r\nme how.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom\xe2\x80\x99s heart was full; he poured it out in prayer, like waters that have\r\nbeen long suppressed. One thing was plain enough; Tom thought there was\r\nsomebody to hear, whether there were or not. In fact, St. Clare felt\r\nhimself borne, on the tide of his faith and feeling, almost to the\r\ngates of that heaven he seemed so vividly to conceive. It seemed to\r\nbring him nearer to Eva.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, my boy,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, when Tom rose. \xe2\x80\x9cI like to hear\r\nyou, Tom; but go, now, and leave me alone; some other time, I\xe2\x80\x99ll talk\r\nmore.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom silently left the room.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXVIII\r\nReunion\r\n\r\n\r\nWeek after week glided away in the St. Clare mansion, and the waves of\r\nlife settled back to their usual flow, where that little bark had gone\r\ndown. For how imperiously, how coolly, in disregard of all one\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfeeling, does the hard, cold, uninteresting course of daily realities\r\nmove on! Still must we eat, and drink, and sleep, and wake again,\xe2\x80\x94still\r\nbargain, buy, sell, ask and answer questions,\xe2\x80\x94pursue, in short, a\r\nthousand shadows, though all interest in them be over; the cold\r\nmechanical habit of living remaining, after all vital interest in it\r\nhas fled.\r\n\r\nAll the interests and hopes of St. Clare\xe2\x80\x99s life had unconsciously wound\r\nthemselves around this child. It was for Eva that he had managed his\r\nproperty; it was for Eva that he had planned the disposal of his time;\r\nand, to do this and that for Eva,\xe2\x80\x94to buy, improve, alter, and arrange,\r\nor dispose something for her,\xe2\x80\x94had been so long his habit, that now she\r\nwas gone, there seemed nothing to be thought of, and nothing to be\r\ndone.\r\n\r\nTrue, there was another life,\xe2\x80\x94a life which, once believed in, stands as\r\na solemn, significant figure before the otherwise unmeaning ciphers of\r\ntime, changing them to orders of mysterious, untold value. St. Clare\r\nknew this well; and often, in many a weary hour, he heard that slender,\r\nchildish voice calling him to the skies, and saw that little hand\r\npointing to him the way of life; but a heavy lethargy of sorrow lay on\r\nhim,\xe2\x80\x94he could not arise. He had one of those natures which could better\r\nand more clearly conceive of religious things from its own perceptions\r\nand instincts, than many a matter-of-fact and practical Christian. The\r\ngift to appreciate and the sense to feel the finer shades and relations\r\nof moral things, often seems an attribute of those whose whole life\r\nshows a careless disregard of them. Hence Moore, Byron, Goethe, often\r\nspeak words more wisely descriptive of the true religious sentiment,\r\nthan another man, whose whole life is governed by it. In such minds,\r\ndisregard of religion is a more fearful treason,\xe2\x80\x94a more deadly sin.\r\n\r\nSt. Clare had never pretended to govern himself by any religious\r\nobligation; and a certain fineness of nature gave him such an\r\ninstinctive view of the extent of the requirements of Christianity,\r\nthat he shrank, by anticipation, from what he felt would be the\r\nexactions of his own conscience, if he once did resolve to assume them.\r\nFor, so inconsistent is human nature, especially in the ideal, that not\r\nto undertake a thing at all seems better than to undertake and come\r\nshort.\r\n\r\nStill St. Clare was, in many respects, another man. He read his little\r\nEva\xe2\x80\x99s Bible seriously and honestly; he thought more soberly and\r\npractically of his relations to his servants,\xe2\x80\x94enough to make him\r\nextremely dissatisfied with both his past and present course; and one\r\nthing he did, soon after his return to New Orleans, and that was to\r\ncommence the legal steps necessary to Tom\xe2\x80\x99s emancipation, which was to\r\nbe perfected as soon as he could get through the necessary formalities.\r\nMeantime, he attached himself to Tom more and more, every day. In all\r\nthe wide world, there was nothing that seemed to remind him so much of\r\nEva; and he would insist on keeping him constantly about him, and,\r\nfastidious and unapproachable as he was with regard to his deeper\r\nfeelings, he almost thought aloud to Tom. Nor would any one have\r\nwondered at it, who had seen the expression of affection and devotion\r\nwith which Tom continually followed his young master.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Tom,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, the day after he had commenced the legal\r\nformalities for his enfranchisement, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m going to make a free man of\r\nyou;\xe2\x80\x94so have your trunk packed, and get ready to set out for Kentuck.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe sudden light of joy that shone in Tom\xe2\x80\x99s face as he raised his hands\r\nto heaven, his emphatic \xe2\x80\x9cBless the Lord!\xe2\x80\x9d rather discomposed St. Clare;\r\nhe did not like it that Tom should be so ready to leave him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou haven\xe2\x80\x99t had such very bad times here, that you need be in such a\r\nrapture, Tom,\xe2\x80\x9d he said drily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r! \xe2\x80\x99tan\xe2\x80\x99t that,\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s bein\xe2\x80\x99 a _freeman!_ that\xe2\x80\x99s what I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\njoyin\xe2\x80\x99 for.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, Tom, don\xe2\x80\x99t you think, for your own part, you\xe2\x80\x99ve been better off\r\nthan to be free?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_No, indeed_, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r St. Clare,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, with a flash of energy. \xe2\x80\x9cNo,\r\nindeed!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, Tom, you couldn\xe2\x80\x99t possibly have earned, by your work, such\r\nclothes and such living as I have given you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKnows all that, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r St. Clare; Mas\xe2\x80\x99r\xe2\x80\x99s been too good; but, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r,\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99d rather have poor clothes, poor house, poor everything, and have \xe2\x80\x99em\r\n_mine_, than have the best, and have \xe2\x80\x99em any man\xe2\x80\x99s else,\xe2\x80\x94I had _so_,\r\nMas\xe2\x80\x99r; I think it\xe2\x80\x99s natur, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI suppose so, Tom, and you\xe2\x80\x99ll be going off and leaving me, in a month\r\nor so,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, rather discontentedly. \xe2\x80\x9cThough why you shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t, no\r\nmortal knows,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, in a gayer tone; and, getting up, he began to\r\nwalk the floor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot while Mas\xe2\x80\x99r is in trouble,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll stay with Mas\xe2\x80\x99r as\r\nlong as he wants me,\xe2\x80\x94so as I can be any use.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot while I\xe2\x80\x99m in trouble, Tom?\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, looking sadly out of\r\nthe window. . . . \xe2\x80\x9cAnd when will _my_ trouble be over?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen Mas\xe2\x80\x99r St. Clare\xe2\x80\x99s a Christian,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you really mean to stay by till that day comes?\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare,\r\nhalf smiling, as he turned from the window, and laid his hand on Tom\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nshoulder. \xe2\x80\x9cAh, Tom, you soft, silly boy! I won\xe2\x80\x99t keep you till that\r\nday. Go home to your wife and children, and give my love to all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI \xe2\x80\x99s faith to believe that day will come,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, earnestly, and\r\nwith tears in his eyes; \xe2\x80\x9cthe Lord has a work for Mas\xe2\x80\x99r.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA work, hey?\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, \xe2\x80\x9cwell, now, Tom, give me your views on\r\nwhat sort of a work it is;\xe2\x80\x94let\xe2\x80\x99s hear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, even a poor fellow like me has a work from the Lord; and Mas\xe2\x80\x99r\r\nSt. Clare, that has larnin, and riches, and friends,\xe2\x80\x94how much he might\r\ndo for the Lord!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTom, you seem to think the Lord needs a great deal done for him,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nSt. Clare, smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe does for the Lord when we does for his critturs,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood theology, Tom; better than Dr. B. preaches, I dare swear,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nSt. Clare.\r\n\r\nThe conversation was here interrupted by the announcement of some\r\nvisitors.\r\n\r\nMarie St. Clare felt the loss of Eva as deeply as she could feel\r\nanything; and, as she was a woman that had a great faculty of making\r\neverybody unhappy when she was, her immediate attendants had still\r\nstronger reason to regret the loss of their young mistress, whose\r\nwinning ways and gentle intercessions had so often been a shield to\r\nthem from the tyrannical and selfish exactions of her mother. Poor old\r\nMammy, in particular, whose heart, severed from all natural domestic\r\nties, had consoled itself with this one beautiful being, was almost\r\nheart-broken. She cried day and night, and was, from excess of sorrow,\r\nless skilful and alert in her ministrations of her mistress than usual,\r\nwhich drew down a constant storm of invectives on her defenceless head.\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia felt the loss; but, in her good and honest heart, it bore\r\nfruit unto everlasting life. She was more softened, more gentle; and,\r\nthough equally assiduous in every duty, it was with a chastened and\r\nquiet air, as one who communed with her own heart not in vain. She was\r\nmore diligent in teaching Topsy,\xe2\x80\x94taught her mainly from the Bible,\xe2\x80\x94did\r\nnot any longer shrink from her touch, or manifest an ill-repressed\r\ndisgust, because she felt none. She viewed her now through the softened\r\nmedium that Eva\xe2\x80\x99s hand had first held before her eyes, and saw in her\r\nonly an immortal creature, whom God had sent to be led by her to glory\r\nand virtue. Topsy did not become at once a saint; but the life and\r\ndeath of Eva did work a marked change in her. The callous indifference\r\nwas gone; there was now sensibility, hope, desire, and the striving for\r\ngood,\xe2\x80\x94a strife irregular, interrupted, suspended oft, but yet renewed\r\nagain.\r\n\r\nOne day, when Topsy had been sent for by Miss Ophelia, she came,\r\nhastily thrusting something into her bosom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you doing there, you limb? You\xe2\x80\x99ve been stealing something,\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll be bound,\xe2\x80\x9d said the imperious little Rosa, who had been sent to\r\ncall her, seizing her, at the same time, roughly by the arm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou go \xe2\x80\x99long, Miss Rosa!\xe2\x80\x9d said Topsy, pulling from her; \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98tan\xe2\x80\x99t none\r\no\xe2\x80\x99 your business!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNone o\xe2\x80\x99 your sa\xe2\x80\x99ce!\xe2\x80\x9d said Rosa, \xe2\x80\x9cI saw you hiding something,\xe2\x80\x94I know\r\nyer tricks,\xe2\x80\x9d and Rosa seized her arm, and tried to force her hand into\r\nher bosom, while Topsy, enraged, kicked and fought valiantly for what\r\nshe considered her rights. The clamor and confusion of the battle drew\r\nMiss Ophelia and St. Clare both to the spot.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s been stealing!\xe2\x80\x9d said Rosa.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI han\xe2\x80\x99t, neither!\xe2\x80\x9d vociferated Topsy, sobbing with passion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive me that, whatever it is!\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, firmly.\r\n\r\nTopsy hesitated; but, on a second order, pulled out of her bosom a\r\nlittle parcel done up in the foot of one of her own old stockings.\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia turned it out. There was a small book, which had been\r\ngiven to Topsy by Eva, containing a single verse of Scripture, arranged\r\nfor every day in the year, and in a paper the curl of hair that she had\r\ngiven her on that memorable day when she had taken her last farewell.\r\n\r\nSt. Clare was a good deal affected at the sight of it; the little book\r\nhad been rolled in a long strip of black crape, torn from the funeral\r\nweeds.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat did you wrap _this_ round the book for?\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, holding\r\nup the crape.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCause,\xe2\x80\x94cause,\xe2\x80\x94cause \xe2\x80\x99t was Miss Eva. O, don\xe2\x80\x99t take \xe2\x80\x99em away, please!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nshe said; and, sitting flat down on the floor, and putting her apron\r\nover her head, she began to sob vehemently.\r\n\r\nIt was a curious mixture of the pathetic and the ludicrous,\xe2\x80\x94the little\r\nold stockings,\xe2\x80\x94black crape,\xe2\x80\x94text-book,\xe2\x80\x94fair, soft curl,\xe2\x80\x94and Topsy\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nutter distress.\r\n\r\nSt. Clare smiled; but there were tears in his eyes, as he said,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come,\xe2\x80\x94don\xe2\x80\x99t cry; you shall have them!\xe2\x80\x9d and, putting them\r\ntogether, he threw them into her lap, and drew Miss Ophelia with him\r\ninto the parlor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI really think you can make something of that concern,\xe2\x80\x9d he said,\r\npointing with his thumb backward over his shoulder. \xe2\x80\x9cAny mind that is\r\ncapable of a _real sorrow_ is capable of good. You must try and do\r\nsomething with her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe child has improved greatly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia. \xe2\x80\x9cI have great\r\nhopes of her; but, Augustine,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, laying her hand on his arm,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cone thing I want to ask; whose is this child to be?\xe2\x80\x94yours or mine?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, I gave her to you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Augustine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut not legally;\xe2\x80\x94I want her to be mine legally,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhew! cousin,\xe2\x80\x9d said Augustine. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat will the Abolition Society think?\r\nThey\xe2\x80\x99ll have a day of fasting appointed for this backsliding, if you\r\nbecome a slaveholder!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, nonsense! I want her mine, that I may have a right to take her to\r\nthe free States, and give her her liberty, that all I am trying to do\r\nbe not undone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, cousin, what an awful \xe2\x80\x99doing evil that good may come\xe2\x80\x99! I can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nencourage it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want you to joke, but to reason,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is\r\nno use in my trying to make this child a Christian child, unless I save\r\nher from all the chances and reverses of slavery; and, if you really\r\nare willing I should have her, I want you to give me a deed of gift, or\r\nsome legal paper.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, well,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, \xe2\x80\x9cI will;\xe2\x80\x9d and he sat down, and unfolded a\r\nnewspaper to read.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I want it done now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s your hurry?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause now is the only time there ever is to do a thing in,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nMiss Ophelia. \xe2\x80\x9cCome, now, here\xe2\x80\x99s paper, pen, and ink; just write a\r\npaper.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSt. Clare, like most men of his class of mind, cordially hated the\r\npresent tense of action, generally; and, therefore, he was considerably\r\nannoyed by Miss Ophelia\xe2\x80\x99s downrightness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, what\xe2\x80\x99s the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cCan\xe2\x80\x99t you take my word? One would\r\nthink you had taken lessons of the Jews, coming at a fellow so!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want to make sure of it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia. \xe2\x80\x9cYou may die, or fail,\r\nand then Topsy be hustled off to auction, spite of all I can do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally, you are quite provident. Well, seeing I\xe2\x80\x99m in the hands of a\r\nYankee, there is nothing for it but to concede;\xe2\x80\x9d and St. Clare rapidly\r\nwrote off a deed of gift, which, as he was well versed in the forms of\r\nlaw, he could easily do, and signed his name to it in sprawling\r\ncapitals, concluding by a tremendous flourish.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, isn\xe2\x80\x99t that black and white, now, Miss Vermont?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, as he\r\nhanded it to her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood boy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, smiling. \xe2\x80\x9cBut must it not be witnessed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, bother!\xe2\x80\x94yes. Here,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, opening the door into Marie\xe2\x80\x99s\r\napartment, \xe2\x80\x9cMarie, Cousin wants your autograph; just put your name down\r\nhere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s this?\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie, as she ran over the paper. \xe2\x80\x9cRidiculous! I\r\nthought Cousin was too pious for such horrid things,\xe2\x80\x9d she added, as she\r\ncarelessly wrote her name; \xe2\x80\x9cbut, if she has a fancy for that article, I\r\nam sure she\xe2\x80\x99s welcome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, now, she\xe2\x80\x99s yours, body and soul,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, handing the\r\npaper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo more mine now than she was before,\xe2\x80\x9d Miss Ophelia. \xe2\x80\x9cNobody but God\r\nhas a right to give her to me;
