but I can protect her now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, she\xe2\x80\x99s yours by a fiction of law, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, as he\r\nturned back into the parlor, and sat down to his paper.\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia, who seldom sat much in Marie\xe2\x80\x99s company, followed him into\r\nthe parlor, having first carefully laid away the paper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAugustine,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, suddenly, as she sat knitting, \xe2\x80\x9chave you ever\r\nmade any provision for your servants, in case of your death?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, as he read on.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen all your indulgence to them may prove a great cruelty, by and\r\nby.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSt. Clare had often thought the same thing himself; but he answered,\r\nnegligently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I mean to make a provision, by and by.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen?\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, one of these days.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat if you should die first?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCousin, what\xe2\x80\x99s the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, laying down his paper and\r\nlooking at her. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you think I show symptoms of yellow fever or\r\ncholera, that you are making post mortem arrangements with such zeal?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98In the midst of life we are in death,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia.\r\n\r\nSt. Clare rose up, and laying the paper down, carelessly, walked to the\r\ndoor that stood open on the verandah, to put an end to a conversation\r\nthat was not agreeable to him. Mechanically, he repeated the last word\r\nagain,\xe2\x80\x94_\xe2\x80\x9cDeath!\xe2\x80\x9d_\xe2\x80\x94and, as he leaned against the railings, and watched\r\nthe sparkling water as it rose and fell in the fountain; and, as in a\r\ndim and dizzy haze, saw flowers and trees and vases of the courts, he\r\nrepeated, again the mystic word so common in every mouth, yet of such\r\nfearful power,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cDEATH!\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cStrange that there should be such a word,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nsaid, \xe2\x80\x9cand such a thing, and we ever forget it; that one should be\r\nliving, warm and beautiful, full of hopes, desires and wants, one day,\r\nand the next be gone, utterly gone, and forever!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was a warm, golden evening; and, as he walked to the other end of\r\nthe verandah, he saw Tom busily intent on his Bible, pointing, as he\r\ndid so, with his finger to each successive word, and whispering them to\r\nhimself with an earnest air.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWant me to read to you, Tom?\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, seating himself\r\ncarelessly by him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf Mas\xe2\x80\x99r pleases,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, gratefully, \xe2\x80\x9cMas\xe2\x80\x99r makes it so much\r\nplainer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSt. Clare took the book and glanced at the place, and began reading one\r\nof the passages which Tom had designated by the heavy marks around it.\r\nIt ran as follows:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen the Son of man shall come in his glory, and all his holy angels\r\nwith him, then shall he sit upon the throne of his glory: and before\r\nhim shall be gathered all nations; and he shall separate them one from\r\nanother, as a shepherd divideth his sheep from the goats.\xe2\x80\x9d St. Clare\r\nread on in an animated voice, till he came to the last of the verses.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen shall the king say unto him on his left hand, Depart from me, ye\r\ncursed, into everlasting fire: for I was an hungered, and ye gave me no\r\nmeat: I was thirsty, and ye gave me no drink: I was a stranger, and ye\r\ntook me not in: naked, and ye clothed me not: I was sick, and in\r\nprison, and ye visited me not. Then shall they answer unto Him, Lord\r\nwhen saw we thee an hungered, or athirst, or a stranger, or naked, or\r\nsick, or in prison, and did not minister unto thee? Then shall he say\r\nunto them, Inasmuch as ye did it not to one of the least of these my\r\nbrethren, ye did it not to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSt. Clare seemed struck with this last passage, for he read it\r\ntwice,\xe2\x80\x94the second time slowly, and as if he were revolving the words in\r\nhis mind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTom,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cthese folks that get such hard measure seem to have\r\nbeen doing just what I have,\xe2\x80\x94living good, easy, respectable lives; and\r\nnot troubling themselves to inquire how many of their brethren were\r\nhungry or athirst, or sick, or in prison.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom did not answer.\r\n\r\nSt. Clare rose up and walked thoughtfully up and down the verandah,\r\nseeming to forget everything in his own thoughts; so absorbed was he,\r\nthat Tom had to remind him twice that the teabell had rung, before he\r\ncould get his attention.\r\n\r\nSt. Clare was absent and thoughtful, all tea-time. After tea, he and\r\nMarie and Miss Ophelia took possession of the parlor almost in silence.\r\n\r\nMarie disposed herself on a lounge, under a silken mosquito curtain,\r\nand was soon sound asleep. Miss Ophelia silently busied herself with\r\nher knitting. St. Clare sat down to the piano, and began playing a soft\r\nand melancholy movement with the \xc3\x86olian accompaniment. He seemed in a\r\ndeep reverie, and to be soliloquizing to himself by music. After a\r\nlittle, he opened one of the drawers, took out an old music-book whose\r\nleaves were yellow with age, and began turning it over.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to Miss Ophelia, \xe2\x80\x9cthis was one of my mother\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbooks,\xe2\x80\x94and here is her handwriting,\xe2\x80\x94come and look at it. She copied and\r\narranged this from Mozart\xe2\x80\x99s Requiem.\xe2\x80\x9d Miss Ophelia came accordingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was something she used to sing often,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare. \xe2\x80\x9cI think I\r\ncan hear her now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe struck a few majestic chords, and began singing that grand old Latin\r\npiece, the \xe2\x80\x9cDies Ir\xc3\xa6.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom, who was listening in the outer verandah, was drawn by the sound to\r\nthe very door, where he stood earnestly. He did not understand the\r\nwords, of course; but the music and manner of singing appeared to\r\naffect him strongly, especially when St. Clare sang the more pathetic\r\nparts. Tom would have sympathized more heartily, if he had known the\r\nmeaning of the beautiful words:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRecordare Jesu pie\r\nQuod sum causa tu\xc3\xa6r vi\xc3\xa6\r\nNe me perdas, illa die\r\nQu\xc3\xa6rens me sedisti lassus\r\nRedemisti crucem passus\r\nTantus labor non sit cassus.\xe2\x80\x9d[1]\r\n\r\n\r\n [1] These lines have been thus rather inadequately translated:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThink, O Jesus, for what reason\r\nThou endured\xe2\x80\x99st earth\xe2\x80\x99s spite and treason,\r\nNor me lose, in that dread season;\r\nSeeking me, thy worn feet hasted,\r\nOn the cross thy soul death tasted,\r\nLet not all these toils be wasted.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n[Mrs. Stowe\xe2\x80\x99s note.]\r\n\r\n\r\nSt. Clare threw a deep and pathetic expression into the words; for the\r\nshadowy veil of years seemed drawn away, and he seemed to hear his\r\nmother\xe2\x80\x99s voice leading his. Voice and instrument seemed both living,\r\nand threw out with vivid sympathy those strains which the ethereal\r\nMozart first conceived as his own dying requiem.\r\n\r\nWhen St. Clare had done singing, he sat leaning his head upon his hand\r\na few moments, and then began walking up and down the floor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a sublime conception is that of a last judgment!\xe2\x80\x9d said he,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9ca\r\nrighting of all the wrongs of ages!\xe2\x80\x94a solving of all moral problems, by\r\nan unanswerable wisdom! It is, indeed, a wonderful image.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a fearful one to us,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt ought to be to me, I suppose,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare stopping,\r\nthoughtfully. \xe2\x80\x9cI was reading to Tom, this afternoon, that chapter in\r\nMatthew that gives an account of it, and I have been quite struck with\r\nit. One should have expected some terrible enormities charged to those\r\nwho are excluded from Heaven, as the reason; but no,\xe2\x80\x94they are condemned\r\nfor _not_ doing positive good, as if that included every possible\r\nharm.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, \xe2\x80\x9cit is impossible for a person who does\r\nno good not to do harm.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, speaking abstractedly, but with deep\r\nfeeling, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat shall be said of one whose own heart, whose education,\r\nand the wants of society, have called in vain to some noble purpose;\r\nwho has floated on, a dreamy, neutral spectator of the struggles,\r\nagonies, and wrongs of man, when he should have been a worker?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should say,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, \xe2\x80\x9cthat he ought to repent, and begin\r\nnow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlways practical and to the point!\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, his face breaking\r\nout into a smile. \xe2\x80\x9cYou never leave me any time for general reflections,\r\nCousin; you always bring me short up against the actual present; you\r\nhave a kind of eternal _now_, always in your mind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Now_ is all the time I have anything to do with,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear little Eva,\xe2\x80\x94poor child!\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, \xe2\x80\x9cshe had set her little\r\nsimple soul on a good work for me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was the first time since Eva\xe2\x80\x99s death that he had ever said as many\r\nwords as these to her, and he spoke now evidently repressing very\r\nstrong feeling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy view of Christianity is such,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I think no man can\r\nconsistently profess it without throwing the whole weight of his being\r\nagainst this monstrous system of injustice that lies at the foundation\r\nof all our society; and, if need be, sacrificing himself in the battle.\r\nThat is, I mean that _I_ could not be a Christian otherwise, though I\r\nhave certainly had intercourse with a great many enlightened and\r\nChristian people who did no such thing; and I confess that the apathy\r\nof religious people on this subject, their want of perception of wrongs\r\nthat filled me with horror, have engendered in me more scepticism than\r\nany other thing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you knew all this,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, \xe2\x80\x9cwhy didn\xe2\x80\x99t you do it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, because I have had only that kind of benevolence which consists in\r\nlying on a sofa, and cursing the church and clergy for not being\r\nmartyrs and confessors. One can see, you know, very easily, how others\r\nought to be martyrs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, are you going to do differently now?\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod only knows the future,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare. \xe2\x80\x9cI am braver than I was,\r\nbecause I have lost all; and he who has nothing to lose can afford all\r\nrisks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what are you going to do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy duty, I hope, to the poor and lowly, as fast as I find it out,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid St. Clare, \xe2\x80\x9cbeginning with my own servants, for whom I have yet\r\ndone nothing; and, perhaps, at some future day, it may appear that I\r\ncan do something for a whole class; something to save my country from\r\nthe disgrace of that false position in which she now stands before all\r\ncivilized nations.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you suppose it possible that a nation ever will voluntarily\r\nemancipate?\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare. \xe2\x80\x9cThis is a day of great deeds. Heroism\r\nand disinterestedness are rising up, here and there, in the earth. The\r\nHungarian nobles set free millions of serfs, at an immense pecuniary\r\nloss; and, perhaps, among us may be found generous spirits, who do not\r\nestimate honor and justice by dollars and cents.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hardly think so,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, suppose we should rise up tomorrow and emancipate, who would\r\neducate these millions, and teach them how to use their freedom? They\r\nnever would rise to do much among us. The fact is, we are too lazy and\r\nunpractical, ourselves, ever to give them much of an idea of that\r\nindustry and energy which is necessary to form them into men. They will\r\nhave to go north, where labor is the fashion,\xe2\x80\x94the universal custom; and\r\ntell me, now, is there enough Christian philanthropy, among your\r\nnorthern states, to bear with the process of their education and\r\nelevation? You send thousands of dollars to foreign missions; but could\r\nyou endure to have the heathen sent into your towns and villages, and\r\ngive your time, and thoughts, and money, to raise them to the Christian\r\nstandard? That\xe2\x80\x99s what I want to know. If we emancipate, are you willing\r\nto educate? How many families, in your town, would take a negro man and\r\nwoman, teach them, bear with them, and seek to make them Christians?\r\nHow many merchants would take Adolph, if I wanted to make him a clerk;\r\nor mechanics, if I wanted him taught a trade? If I wanted to put Jane\r\nand Rosa to a school, how many schools are there in the northern states\r\nthat would take them in? how many families that would board them? and\r\nyet they are as white as many a woman, north or south. You see, Cousin,\r\nI want justice done us. We are in a bad position. We are the more\r\n_obvious_ oppressors of the negro; but the unchristian prejudice of the\r\nnorth is an oppressor almost equally severe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Cousin, I know it is so,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI know it was so\r\nwith me, till I saw that it was my duty to overcome it; but, I trust I\r\nhave overcome it; and I know there are many good people at the north,\r\nwho in this matter need only to be _taught_ what their duty is, to do\r\nit. It would certainly be a greater self-denial to receive heathen\r\namong us, than to send missionaries to them; but I think we would do\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_You_ would, I know,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d like to see anything you\r\nwouldn\xe2\x80\x99t do, if you thought it your duty!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I\xe2\x80\x99m not uncommonly good,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia. \xe2\x80\x9cOthers would, if\r\nthey saw things as I do. I intend to take Topsy home, when I go. I\r\nsuppose our folks will wonder, at first; but I think they will be\r\nbrought to see as I do. Besides, I know there are many people at the\r\nnorth who do exactly what you said.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but they are a minority; and, if we should begin to emancipate to\r\nany extent, we should soon hear from you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia did not reply. There was a pause of some moments; and St.\r\nClare\xe2\x80\x99s countenance was overcast by a sad, dreamy expression.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know what makes me think of my mother so much, tonight,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nsaid. \xe2\x80\x9cI have a strange kind of feeling, as if she were near me. I keep\r\nthinking of things she used to say. Strange, what brings these past\r\nthings so vividly back to us, sometimes!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSt. Clare walked up and down the room for some minutes more, and then\r\nsaid,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe I\xe2\x80\x99ll go down street, a few moments, and hear the news,\r\ntonight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe took his hat, and passed out.\r\n\r\nTom followed him to the passage, out of the court, and asked if he\r\nshould attend him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, my boy,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare. \xe2\x80\x9cI shall be back in an hour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom sat down in the verandah. It was a beautiful moonlight evening, and\r\nhe sat watching the rising and falling spray of the fountain, and\r\nlistening to its murmur. Tom thought of his home, and that he should\r\nsoon be a free man, and able to return to it at will. He thought how he\r\nshould work to buy his wife and boys. He felt the muscles of his brawny\r\narms with a sort of joy, as he thought they would soon belong to\r\nhimself, and how much they could do to work out the freedom of his\r\nfamily. Then he thought of his noble young master, and, ever second to\r\nthat, came the habitual prayer that he had always offered for him; and\r\nthen his thoughts passed on to the beautiful Eva, whom he now thought\r\nof among the angels; and he thought till he almost fancied that that\r\nbright face and golden hair were looking upon him, out of the spray of\r\nthe fountain. And, so musing, he fell asleep, and dreamed he saw her\r\ncoming bounding towards him, just as she used to come, with a wreath of\r\njessamine in her hair, her cheeks bright, and her eyes radiant with\r\ndelight; but, as he looked, she seemed to rise from the ground; her\r\ncheeks wore a paler hue,\xe2\x80\x94her eyes had a deep, divine radiance, a golden\r\nhalo seemed around her head,\xe2\x80\x94and she vanished from his sight; and Tom\r\nwas awakened by a loud knocking, and a sound of many voices at the\r\ngate.\r\n\r\nHe hastened to undo it; and, with smothered voices and heavy tread,\r\ncame several men, bringing a body, wrapped in a cloak, and lying on a\r\nshutter. The light of the lamp fell full on the face; and Tom gave a\r\nwild cry of amazement and despair, that rung through all the galleries,\r\nas the men advanced, with their burden, to the open parlor door, where\r\nMiss Ophelia still sat knitting.\r\n\r\nSt. Clare had turned into a cafe, to look over an evening paper. As he\r\nwas reading, an affray arose between two gentlemen in the room, who\r\nwere both partially intoxicated. St. Clare and one or two others made\r\nan effort to separate them, and St. Clare received a fatal stab in the\r\nside with a bowie-knife, which he was attempting to wrest from one of\r\nthem.\r\n\r\nThe house was full of cries and lamentations, shrieks and screams,\r\nservants frantically tearing their hair, throwing themselves on the\r\nground, or running distractedly about, lamenting. Tom and Miss Ophelia\r\nalone seemed to have any presence of mind; for Marie was in strong\r\nhysteric convulsions. At Miss Ophelia\xe2\x80\x99s direction, one of the lounges\r\nin the parlor was hastily prepared, and the bleeding form laid upon it.\r\nSt. Clare had fainted, through pain and loss of blood; but, as Miss\r\nOphelia applied restoratives, he revived, opened his eyes, looked\r\nfixedly on them, looked earnestly around the room, his eyes travelling\r\nwistfully over every object, and finally they rested on his mother\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npicture.\r\n\r\nThe physician now arrived, and made his examination. It was evident,\r\nfrom the expression of his face, that there was no hope; but he applied\r\nhimself to dressing the wound, and he and Miss Ophelia and Tom\r\nproceeded composedly with this work, amid the lamentations and sobs and\r\ncries of the affrighted servants, who had clustered about the doors and\r\nwindows of the verandah.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said the physician, \xe2\x80\x9cwe must turn all these creatures out; all\r\ndepends on his being kept quiet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSt. Clare opened his eyes, and looked fixedly on the distressed beings,\r\nwhom Miss Ophelia and the doctor were trying to urge from the\r\napartment. \xe2\x80\x9cPoor creatures!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, and an expression of bitter\r\nself-reproach passed over his face. Adolph absolutely refused to go.\r\nTerror had deprived him of all presence of mind; he threw himself along\r\nthe floor, and nothing could persuade him to rise. The rest yielded to\r\nMiss Ophelia\xe2\x80\x99s urgent representations, that their master\xe2\x80\x99s safety\r\ndepended on their stillness and obedience.\r\n\r\nSt. Clare could say but little; he lay with his eyes shut, but it was\r\nevident that he wrestled with bitter thoughts. After a while, he laid\r\nhis hand on Tom\xe2\x80\x99s, who was kneeling beside him, and said, \xe2\x80\x9cTom! poor\r\nfellow!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r?\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, earnestly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am dying!\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, pressing his hand; \xe2\x80\x9cpray!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you would like a clergyman\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d said the physician.\r\n\r\nSt. Clare hastily shook his head, and said again to Tom, more\r\nearnestly, \xe2\x80\x9cPray!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd Tom did pray, with all his mind and strength, for the soul that was\r\npassing,\xe2\x80\x94the soul that seemed looking so steadily and mournfully from\r\nthose large, melancholy blue eyes. It was literally prayer offered with\r\nstrong crying and tears.\r\n\r\nWhen Tom ceased to speak, St. Clare reached out and took his hand,\r\nlooking earnestly at him, but saying nothing. He closed his eyes, but\r\nstill retained his hold; for, in the gates of eternity, the black hand\r\nand the white hold each other with an equal clasp. He murmured softly\r\nto himself, at broken intervals,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRecordare Jesu pie\xe2\x80\x94\r\n*  *  *  *\r\nNe me perdas\xe2\x80\x94illa die\r\nQu\xc3\xa6rens me\xe2\x80\x94sedisti lassus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was evident that the words he had been singing that evening were\r\npassing through his mind,\xe2\x80\x94words of entreaty addressed to Infinite Pity.\r\nHis lips moved at intervals, as parts of the hymn fell brokenly from\r\nthem.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis mind is wandering,\xe2\x80\x9d said the doctor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo! it is coming HOME, at last!\xe2\x80\x9d said St. Clare, energetically; \xe2\x80\x9cat\r\nlast! at last!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe effort of speaking exhausted him. The sinking paleness of death\r\nfell on him; but with it there fell, as if shed from the wings of some\r\npitying spirit, a beautiful expression of peace, like that of a wearied\r\nchild who sleeps.\r\n\r\nSo he lay for a few moments. They saw that the mighty hand was on him.\r\nJust before the spirit parted, he opened his eyes, with a sudden light,\r\nas of joy and recognition, and said _\xe2\x80\x9cMother!\xe2\x80\x9d_ and then he was gone!\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXIX\r\nThe Unprotected\r\n\r\n\r\nWe hear often of the distress of the negro servants, on the loss of a\r\nkind master; and with good reason, for no creature on God\xe2\x80\x99s earth is\r\nleft more utterly unprotected and desolate than the slave in these\r\ncircumstances.\r\n\r\nThe child who has lost a father has still the protection of friends,\r\nand of the law; he is something, and can do something,\xe2\x80\x94has acknowledged\r\nrights and position; the slave has none. The law regards him, in every\r\nrespect, as devoid of rights as a bale of merchandise. The only\r\npossible acknowledgment of any of the longings and wants of a human and\r\nimmortal creature, which are given to him, comes to him through the\r\nsovereign and irresponsible will of his master; and when that master is\r\nstricken down, nothing remains.\r\n\r\nThe number of those men who know how to use wholly irresponsible power\r\nhumanely and generously is small. Everybody knows this, and the slave\r\nknows it best of all; so that he feels that there are ten chances of\r\nhis finding an abusive and tyrannical master, to one of his finding a\r\nconsiderate and kind one. Therefore is it that the wail over a kind\r\nmaster is loud and long, as well it may be.\r\n\r\nWhen St. Clare breathed his last, terror and consternation took hold of\r\nall his household. He had been stricken down so in a moment, in the\r\nflower and strength of his youth! Every room and gallery of the house\r\nresounded with sobs and shrieks of despair.\r\n\r\nMarie, whose nervous system had been enervated by a constant course of\r\nself-indulgence, had nothing to support the terror of the shock, and,\r\nat the time her husband breathed his last, was passing from one\r\nfainting fit to another; and he to whom she had been joined in the\r\nmysterious tie of marriage passed from her forever, without the\r\npossibility of even a parting word.\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia, with characteristic strength and self-control, had\r\nremained with her kinsman to the last,\xe2\x80\x94all eye, all ear, all attention;\r\ndoing everything of the little that could be done, and joining with her\r\nwhole soul in the tender and impassioned prayers which the poor slave\r\nhad poured forth for the soul of his dying master.\r\n\r\nWhen they were arranging him for his last rest, they found upon his\r\nbosom a small, plain miniature case, opening with a spring. It was the\r\nminiature of a noble and beautiful female face; and on the reverse,\r\nunder a crystal, a lock of dark hair. They laid them back on the\r\nlifeless breast,\xe2\x80\x94dust to dust,\xe2\x80\x94poor mournful relics of early dreams,\r\nwhich once made that cold heart beat so warmly!\r\n\r\nTom\xe2\x80\x99s whole soul was filled with thoughts of eternity; and while he\r\nministered around the lifeless clay, he did not once think that the\r\nsudden stroke had left him in hopeless slavery. He felt at peace about\r\nhis master; for in that hour, when he had poured forth his prayer into\r\nthe bosom of his Father, he had found an answer of quietness and\r\nassurance springing up within himself. In the depths of his own\r\naffectionate nature, he felt able to perceive something of the fulness\r\nof Divine love; for an old oracle hath thus written,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cHe that dwelleth\r\nin love dwelleth in God, and God in him.\xe2\x80\x9d Tom hoped and trusted, and\r\nwas at peace.\r\n\r\nBut the funeral passed, with all its pageant of black crape, and\r\nprayers, and solemn faces; and back rolled the cool, muddy waves of\r\nevery-day life; and up came the everlasting hard inquiry of \xe2\x80\x9cWhat is to\r\nbe done next?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt rose to the mind of Marie, as, dressed in loose morning-robes, and\r\nsurrounded by anxious servants, she sat up in a great easy-chair, and\r\ninspected samples of crape and bombazine. It rose to Miss Ophelia, who\r\nbegan to turn her thoughts towards her northern home. It rose, in\r\nsilent terrors, to the minds of the servants, who well knew the\r\nunfeeling, tyrannical character of the mistress in whose hands they\r\nwere left. All knew, very well, that the indulgences which had been\r\naccorded to them were not from their mistress, but from their master;\r\nand that, now he was gone, there would be no screen between them and\r\nevery tyrannous infliction which a temper soured by affliction might\r\ndevise.\r\n\r\nIt was about a fortnight after the funeral, that Miss Ophelia, busied\r\none day in her apartment, heard a gentle tap at the door. She opened\r\nit, and there stood Rosa, the pretty young quadroon, whom we have\r\nbefore often noticed, her hair in disorder, and her eyes swelled with\r\ncrying.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Miss Feeley,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, falling on her knees, and catching the\r\nskirt of her dress, \xe2\x80\x9c_do, do go_ to Miss Marie for me! do plead for me!\r\nShe\xe2\x80\x99s goin\xe2\x80\x99 to send me out to be whipped\xe2\x80\x94look there!\xe2\x80\x9d And she handed to\r\nMiss Ophelia a paper.\r\n\r\nIt was an order, written in Marie\xe2\x80\x99s delicate Italian hand, to the\r\nmaster of a whipping-establishment to give the bearer fifteen lashes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat have you been doing?\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know, Miss Feely, I\xe2\x80\x99ve got such a bad temper; it\xe2\x80\x99s very bad of me.\r\nI was trying on Miss Marie\xe2\x80\x99s dress, and she slapped my face; and I\r\nspoke out before I thought, and was saucy; and she said that she\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nbring me down, and have me know, once for all, that I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t going to\r\nbe so topping as I had been; and she wrote this, and says I shall carry\r\nit. I\xe2\x80\x99d rather she\xe2\x80\x99d kill me, right out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia stood considering, with the paper in her hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see, Miss Feely,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rosa, \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t mind the whipping so much,\r\nif Miss Marie or you was to do it; but, to be sent to a _man!_ and such\r\na horrid man,\xe2\x80\x94the shame of it, Miss Feely!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia well knew that it was the universal custom to send women\r\nand young girls to whipping-houses, to the hands of the lowest of\r\nmen,\xe2\x80\x94men vile enough to make this their profession,\xe2\x80\x94there to be\r\nsubjected to brutal exposure and shameful correction. She had _known_\r\nit before; but hitherto she had never realized it, till she saw the\r\nslender form of Rosa almost convulsed with distress. All the honest\r\nblood of womanhood, the strong New England blood of liberty, flushed to\r\nher cheeks, and throbbed bitterly in her indignant heart; but, with\r\nhabitual prudence and self-control, she mastered herself, and, crushing\r\nthe paper firmly in her hand, she merely said to Rosa,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSit down, child, while I go to your mistress.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShameful! monstrous! outrageous!\xe2\x80\x9d she said to herself, as she was\r\ncrossing the parlor.\r\n\r\nShe found Marie sitting up in her easy-chair, with Mammy standing by\r\nher, combing her hair; Jane sat on the ground before her, busy in\r\nchafing her feet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do you find yourself, today?\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia.\r\n\r\nA deep sigh, and a closing of the eyes, was the only reply, for a\r\nmoment; and then Marie answered, \xe2\x80\x9cO, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know, Cousin; I suppose\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99m as well as I ever shall be!\xe2\x80\x9d and Marie wiped her eyes with a\r\ncambric handkerchief, bordered with an inch deep of black.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI came,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, with a short, dry cough, such as commonly\r\nintroduces a difficult subject,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI came to speak with you about poor\r\nRosa.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMarie\xe2\x80\x99s eyes were open wide enough now, and a flush rose to her sallow\r\ncheeks, as she answered, sharply,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, what about her?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is very sorry for her fault.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is, is she? She\xe2\x80\x99ll be sorrier, before I\xe2\x80\x99ve done with her! I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nendured that child\xe2\x80\x99s impudence long enough; and now I\xe2\x80\x99ll bring her\r\ndown,\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99ll make her lie in the dust!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut could not you punish her some other way,\xe2\x80\x94some way that would be\r\nless shameful?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mean to shame her; that\xe2\x80\x99s just what I want. She has all her life\r\npresumed on her delicacy, and her good looks, and her lady-like airs,\r\ntill she forgets who she is;\xe2\x80\x94and I\xe2\x80\x99ll give her one lesson that will\r\nbring her down, I fancy!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, Cousin, consider that, if you destroy delicacy and a sense of\r\nshame in a young girl, you deprave her very fast.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDelicacy!\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie, with a scornful laugh,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9ca fine word for such as\r\nshe! I\xe2\x80\x99ll teach her, with all her airs, that she\xe2\x80\x99s no better than the\r\nraggedest black wench that walks the streets! She\xe2\x80\x99ll take no more airs\r\nwith me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will answer to God for such cruelty!\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, with\r\nenergy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCruelty,\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99d like to know what the cruelty is! I wrote orders for only\r\nfifteen lashes, and told him to put them on lightly. I\xe2\x80\x99m sure there\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nno cruelty there!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo cruelty!\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sure any girl might rather be\r\nkilled outright!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt might seem so to anybody with your feeling; but all these creatures\r\nget used to it; it\xe2\x80\x99s the only way they can be kept in order. Once let\r\nthem feel that they are to take any airs about delicacy, and all that,\r\nand they\xe2\x80\x99ll run all over you, just as my servants always have. I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nbegun now to bring them under; and I\xe2\x80\x99ll have them all to know that I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nsend one out to be whipped, as soon as another, if they don\xe2\x80\x99t mind\r\nthemselves!\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie, looking around her decidedly.\r\n\r\nJane hung her head and cowered at this, for she felt as if it was\r\nparticularly directed to her. Miss Ophelia sat for a moment, as if she\r\nhad swallowed some explosive mixture, and were ready to burst. Then,\r\nrecollecting the utter uselessness of contention with such a nature,\r\nshe shut her lips resolutely, gathered herself up, and walked out of\r\nthe room.\r\n\r\nIt was hard to go back and tell Rosa that she could do nothing for her;\r\nand, shortly after, one of the man-servants came to say that her\r\nmistress had ordered him to take Rosa with him to the whipping-house,\r\nwhither she was hurried, in spite of her tears and entreaties.\r\n\r\nA few days after, Tom was standing musing by the balconies, when he was\r\njoined by Adolph, who, since the death of his master, had been entirely\r\ncrest-fallen and disconsolate. Adolph knew that he had always been an\r\nobject of dislike to Marie; but while his master lived he had paid but\r\nlittle attention to it. Now that he was gone, he had moved about in\r\ndaily dread and trembling, not knowing what might befall him next.\r\nMarie had held several consultations with her lawyer; after\r\ncommunicating with St. Clare\xe2\x80\x99s brother, it was determined to sell the\r\nplace, and all the servants, except her own personal property, and\r\nthese she intended to take with her, and go back to her father\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nplantation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo ye know, Tom, that we\xe2\x80\x99ve all got to be sold?\xe2\x80\x9d said Adolph.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow did you hear that?\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hid myself behind the curtains when Missis was talking with the\r\nlawyer. In a few days we shall be sent off to auction, Tom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Lord\xe2\x80\x99s will be done!\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, folding his arms and sighing\r\nheavily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll never get another such a master,\xe2\x80\x9d said Adolph, apprehensively;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbut I\xe2\x80\x99d rather be sold than take my chance under Missis.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom turned away; his heart was full. The hope of liberty, the thought\r\nof distant wife and children, rose up before his patient soul, as to\r\nthe mariner shipwrecked almost in port rises the vision of the\r\nchurch-spire and loving roofs of his native village, seen over the top\r\nof some black wave only for one last farewell. He drew his arms tightly\r\nover his bosom, and choked back the bitter tears, and tried to pray.\r\nThe poor old soul had such a singular, unaccountable prejudice in favor\r\nof liberty, that it was a hard wrench for him; and the more he said,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThy will be done,\xe2\x80\x9d the worse he felt.\r\n\r\nHe sought Miss Ophelia, who, ever since Eva\xe2\x80\x99s death, had treated him\r\nwith marked and respectful kindness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Feely,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cMas\xe2\x80\x99r St. Clare promised me my freedom. He told\r\nme that he had begun to take it out for me; and now, perhaps, if Miss\r\nFeely would be good enough to speak bout it to Missis, she would feel\r\nlike goin\xe2\x80\x99 on with it, was it as Mas\xe2\x80\x99r St. Clare\xe2\x80\x99s wish.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll speak for you, Tom, and do my best,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia; \xe2\x80\x9cbut, if\r\nit depends on Mrs. St. Clare, I can\xe2\x80\x99t hope much for you;\xe2\x80\x94nevertheless,\r\nI will try.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis incident occurred a few days after that of Rosa, while Miss\r\nOphelia was busied in preparations to return north.\r\n\r\nSeriously reflecting within herself, she considered that perhaps she\r\nhad shown too hasty a warmth of language in her former interview with\r\nMarie; and she resolved that she would now endeavor to moderate her\r\nzeal, and to be as conciliatory as possible. So the good soul gathered\r\nherself up, and, taking her knitting, resolved to go into Marie\xe2\x80\x99s room,\r\nbe as agreeable as possible, and negotiate Tom\xe2\x80\x99s case with all the\r\ndiplomatic skill of which she was mistress.\r\n\r\nShe found Marie reclining at length upon a lounge, supporting herself\r\non one elbow by pillows, while Jane, who had been out shopping, was\r\ndisplaying before her certain samples of thin black stuffs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat will do,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie, selecting one; \xe2\x80\x9conly I\xe2\x80\x99m not sure about its\r\nbeing properly mourning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLaws, Missis,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jane, volubly, \xe2\x80\x9cMrs. General Derbennon wore just\r\nthis very thing, after the General died, last summer; it makes up\r\nlovely!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you think?\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie to Miss Ophelia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a matter of custom, I suppose,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia. \xe2\x80\x9cYou can judge\r\nabout it better than I.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe fact is,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I haven\xe2\x80\x99t a dress in the world that I\r\ncan wear; and, as I am going to break up the establishment, and go off,\r\nnext week, I must decide upon something.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you going so soon?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. St. Clare\xe2\x80\x99s brother has written, and he and the lawyer think that\r\nthe servants and furniture had better be put up at auction, and the\r\nplace left with our lawyer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s one thing I wanted to speak with you about,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss\r\nOphelia. \xe2\x80\x9cAugustine promised Tom his liberty, and began the legal forms\r\nnecessary to it. I hope you will use your influence to have it\r\nperfected.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed, I shall do no such thing!\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie, sharply. \xe2\x80\x9cTom is one of\r\nthe most valuable servants on the place,\xe2\x80\x94it couldn\xe2\x80\x99t be afforded, any\r\nway. Besides, what does he want of liberty? He\xe2\x80\x99s a great deal better\r\noff as he is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut he does desire it, very earnestly, and his master promised it,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Miss Ophelia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI dare say he does want it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie; \xe2\x80\x9cthey all want it, just\r\nbecause they are a discontented set,\xe2\x80\x94always wanting what they haven\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ngot. Now, I\xe2\x80\x99m principled against emancipating, in any case. Keep a\r\nnegro under the care of a master, and he does well enough, and is\r\nrespectable; but set them free, and they get lazy, and won\xe2\x80\x99t work, and\r\ntake to drinking, and go all down to be mean, worthless fellows, I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nseen it tried, hundreds of times. It\xe2\x80\x99s no favor to set them free.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut Tom is so steady, industrious, and pious.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, you needn\xe2\x80\x99t tell me! I\xe2\x80\x99ve see a hundred like him. He\xe2\x80\x99ll do very\r\nwell, as long as he\xe2\x80\x99s taken care of,\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, then, consider,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen you set him up for\r\nsale, the chances of his getting a bad master.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, that\xe2\x80\x99s all humbug!\xe2\x80\x9d said Marie; \xe2\x80\x9cit isn\xe2\x80\x99t one time in a hundred\r\nthat a good fellow gets a bad master; most masters are good, for all\r\nthe talk that is made. I\xe2\x80\x99ve lived and grown up here, in the South, and\r\nI never yet was acquainted with a master that didn\xe2\x80\x99t treat his servants\r\nwell,\xe2\x80\x94quite as well as is worth while. I don\xe2\x80\x99t feel any fears on that\r\nhead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ophelia, energetically, \xe2\x80\x9cI know it was one of the\r\nlast wishes of your husband that Tom should have his liberty; it was\r\none of the promises that he made to dear little Eva on her death-bed,\r\nand I should not think you would feel at liberty to disregard it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMarie had her face covered with her handkerchief at this appeal, and\r\nbegan sobbing and using her smelling-bottle, with great vehemence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEverybody goes against me!\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cEverybody is so inconsiderate!\r\nI shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have expected that _you_ would bring up all these\r\nremembrances of my troubles to me,\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s so inconsiderate! But nobody\r\never does consider,\xe2\x80\x94my trials are so peculiar! It\xe2\x80\x99s so hard, that when\r\nI had only one daughter, she should have been taken!\xe2\x80\x94and when I had a\r\nhusband that just exactly suited me,\xe2\x80\x94and I\xe2\x80\x99m so hard to be suited!\xe2\x80\x94he\r\nshould be taken! And you seem to have so little feeling for me, and\r\nkeep bringing it up to me so carelessly,\xe2\x80\x94when you know how it overcomes\r\nme! I suppose you mean well; but it is very inconsiderate,\xe2\x80\x94very!\xe2\x80\x9d And\r\nMarie sobbed, and gasped for breath, and called Mammy to open the\r\nwindow, and to bring her the camphor-bottle, and to bathe her head, and\r\nunhook her dress. And, in the general confusion that ensued, Miss\r\nOphelia made her escape to her apartment.\r\n\r\nShe saw, at once, that it would do no good to say anything more; for\r\nMarie had an indefinite capacity for hysteric fits; and, after this,\r\nwhenever her husband\xe2\x80\x99s or Eva\xe2\x80\x99s wishes with regard to the servants were\r\nalluded to, she always found it convenient to set one in operation.\r\nMiss Ophelia, therefore, did the next best thing she could for Tom,\xe2\x80\x94she\r\nwrote a letter to Mrs. Shelby for him, stating his troubles, and urging\r\nthem to send to his relief.\r\n\r\nThe next day, Tom and Adolph, and some half a dozen other servants,\r\nwere marched down to a slave-warehouse, to await the convenience of the\r\ntrader, who was going to make up a lot for auction.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXX\r\nThe Slave Warehouse\r\n\r\n\r\nA slave warehouse! Perhaps some of my readers conjure up horrible\r\nvisions of such a place. They fancy some foul, obscure den, some\r\nhorrible _Tartarus \xe2\x80\x9cinformis, ingens, cui lumen ademptum.\xe2\x80\x9d_ But no,\r\ninnocent friend; in these days men have learned the art of sinning\r\nexpertly and genteelly, so as not to shock the eyes and senses of\r\nrespectable society. Human property is high in the market; and is,\r\ntherefore, well fed, well cleaned, tended, and looked after, that it\r\nmay come to sale sleek, and strong, and shining. A slave-warehouse in\r\nNew Orleans is a house externally not much unlike many others, kept\r\nwith neatness; and where every day you may see arranged, under a sort\r\nof shed along the outside, rows of men and women, who stand there as a\r\nsign of the property sold within.\r\n\r\nThen you shall be courteously entreated to call and examine, and shall\r\nfind an abundance of husbands, wives, brothers, sisters, fathers,\r\nmothers, and young children, to be \xe2\x80\x9csold separately, or in lots to suit\r\nthe convenience of the purchaser;\xe2\x80\x9d and that soul immortal, once bought\r\nwith blood and anguish by the Son of God, when the earth shook, and the\r\nrocks rent, and the graves were opened, can be sold, leased, mortgaged,\r\nexchanged for groceries or dry goods, to suit the phases of trade, or\r\nthe fancy of the purchaser.\r\n\r\nIt was a day or two after the conversation between Marie and Miss\r\nOphelia, that Tom, Adolph, and about half a dozen others of the St.\r\nClare estate, were turned over to the loving kindness of Mr. Skeggs,\r\nthe keeper of a depot on \xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94 street, to await the auction, next day.\r\n\r\nTom had with him quite a sizable trunk full of clothing, as had most\r\nothers of them. They were ushered, for the night, into a long room,\r\nwhere many other men, of all ages, sizes, and shades of complexion,\r\nwere assembled, and from which roars of laughter and unthinking\r\nmerriment were proceeding.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, ha! that\xe2\x80\x99s right. Go it, boys,\xe2\x80\x94go it!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Skeggs, the\r\nkeeper. \xe2\x80\x9cMy people are always so merry! Sambo, I see!\xe2\x80\x9d he said,\r\nspeaking approvingly to a burly negro who was performing tricks of low\r\nbuffoonery, which occasioned the shouts which Tom had heard.\r\n\r\nAs might be imagined, Tom was in no humor to join these proceedings;\r\nand, therefore, setting his trunk as far as possible from the noisy\r\ngroup, he sat down on it, and leaned his face against the wall.\r\n\r\nThe dealers in the human article make scrupulous and systematic efforts\r\nto promote noisy mirth among them, as a means of drowning reflection,\r\nand rendering them insensible to their condition. The whole object of\r\nthe training to which the negro is put, from the time he is sold in the\r\nnorthern market till he arrives south, is systematically directed\r\ntowards making him callous, unthinking, and brutal. The slave-dealer\r\ncollects his gang in Virginia or Kentucky, and drives them to some\r\nconvenient, healthy place,\xe2\x80\x94often a watering place,\xe2\x80\x94to be fattened. Here\r\nthey are fed full daily; and, because some incline to pine, a fiddle is\r\nkept commonly going among them, and they are made to dance daily; and\r\nhe who refuses to be merry\xe2\x80\x94in whose soul thoughts of wife, or child, or\r\nhome, are too strong for him to be gay\xe2\x80\x94is marked as sullen and\r\ndangerous, and subjected to all the evils which the ill will of an\r\nutterly irresponsible and hardened man can inflict upon him. Briskness,\r\nalertness, and cheerfulness of appearance, especially before observers,\r\nare constantly enforced upon them, both by the hope of thereby getting\r\na good master, and the fear of all that the driver may bring upon them\r\nif they prove unsalable.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat dat ar nigger doin here?\xe2\x80\x9d said Sambo, coming up to Tom, after Mr.\r\nSkeggs had left the room. Sambo was a full black, of great size, very\r\nlively, voluble, and full of trick and grimace.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat you doin here?\xe2\x80\x9d said Sambo, coming up to Tom, and poking him\r\nfacetiously in the side. \xe2\x80\x9cMeditatin\xe2\x80\x99, eh?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am to be sold at the auction tomorrow!\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, quietly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSold at auction,\xe2\x80\x94haw! haw! boys, an\xe2\x80\x99t this yer fun? I wish\xe2\x80\x99t I was\r\ngwine that ar way!\xe2\x80\x94tell ye, wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t I make em laugh? But how is\r\nit,\xe2\x80\x94dis yer whole lot gwine tomorrow?\xe2\x80\x9d said Sambo, laying his hand\r\nfreely on Adolph\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlease to let me alone!\xe2\x80\x9d said Adolph, fiercely, straightening himself\r\nup, with extreme disgust.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLaw, now, boys! dis yer\xe2\x80\x99s one o\xe2\x80\x99 yer white niggers,\xe2\x80\x94kind o\xe2\x80\x99 cream\r\ncolor, ye know, scented!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, coming up to Adolph and snuffing. \xe2\x80\x9cO\r\nLor! he\xe2\x80\x99d do for a tobaccer-shop; they could keep him to scent snuff!\r\nLor, he\xe2\x80\x99d keep a whole shope agwine,\xe2\x80\x94he would!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say, keep off, can\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d said Adolph, enraged.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLor, now, how touchy we is,\xe2\x80\x94we white niggers! Look at us now!\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\nSambo gave a ludicrous imitation of Adolph\xe2\x80\x99s manner; \xe2\x80\x9chere\xe2\x80\x99s de airs\r\nand graces. We\xe2\x80\x99s been in a good family, I specs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Adolph; \xe2\x80\x9cI had a master that could have bought you all for\r\nold truck!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLaws, now, only think,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sambo, \xe2\x80\x9cthe gentlemens that we is!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI belonged to the St. Clare family,\xe2\x80\x9d said Adolph, proudly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLor, you did! Be hanged if they ar\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99t lucky to get shet of ye. Spects\r\nthey\xe2\x80\x99s gwine to trade ye off with a lot o\xe2\x80\x99 cracked tea-pots and sich\r\nlike!\xe2\x80\x9d said Sambo, with a provoking grin.\r\n\r\nAdolph, enraged at this taunt, flew furiously at his adversary,\r\nswearing and striking on every side of him. The rest laughed and\r\nshouted, and the uproar brought the keeper to the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat now, boys? Order,\xe2\x80\x94order!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, coming in and flourishing a\r\nlarge whip.\r\n\r\nAll fled in different directions, except Sambo, who, presuming on the\r\nfavor which the keeper had to him as a licensed wag, stood his ground,\r\nducking his head with a facetious grin, whenever the master made a dive\r\nat him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLor, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r, \xe2\x80\x99tan\xe2\x80\x99t us,\xe2\x80\x94we \xe2\x80\x99s reglar stiddy,\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s these yer new hands;\r\nthey \xe2\x80\x99s real aggravatin\xe2\x80\x99,\xe2\x80\x94kinder pickin\xe2\x80\x99 at us, all time!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe keeper, at this, turned upon Tom and Adolph, and distributing a few\r\nkicks and cuffs without much inquiry, and leaving general orders for\r\nall to be good boys and go to sleep, left the apartment.\r\n\r\nWhile this scene was going on in the men\xe2\x80\x99s sleeping-room, the reader\r\nmay be curious to take a peep at the corresponding apartment allotted\r\nto the women. Stretched out in various attitudes over the floor, he may\r\nsee numberless sleeping forms of every shade of complexion, from the\r\npurest ebony to white, and of all years, from childhood to old age,\r\nlying now asleep. Here is a fine bright girl, of ten years, whose\r\nmother was sold out yesterday, and who tonight cried herself to sleep\r\nwhen nobody was looking at her. Here, a worn old negress, whose thin\r\narms and callous fingers tell of hard toil, waiting to be sold\r\ntomorrow, as a cast-off article, for what can be got for her; and some\r\nforty or fifty others, with heads variously enveloped in blankets or\r\narticles of clothing, lie stretched around them. But, in a corner,\r\nsitting apart from the rest, are two females of a more interesting\r\nappearance than common. One of these is a respectably-dressed mulatto\r\nwoman between forty and fifty, with soft eyes and a gentle and pleasing\r\nphysiognomy. She has on her head a high-raised turban, made of a gay\r\nred Madras handkerchief, of the first quality, her dress is neatly\r\nfitted, and of good material, showing that she has been provided for\r\nwith a careful hand. By her side, and nestling closely to her, is a\r\nyoung girl of fifteen,\xe2\x80\x94her daughter. She is a quadroon, as may be seen\r\nfrom her fairer complexion, though her likeness to her mother is quite\r\ndiscernible. She has the same soft, dark eye, with longer lashes, and\r\nher curling hair is of a luxuriant brown. She also is dressed with\r\ngreat neatness, and her white, delicate hands betray very little\r\nacquaintance with servile toil. These two are to be sold tomorrow, in\r\nthe same lot with the St. Clare servants; and the gentleman to whom\r\nthey belong, and to whom the money for their sale is to be transmitted,\r\nis a member of a Christian church in New York, who will receive the\r\nmoney, and go thereafter to the sacrament of his Lord and theirs, and\r\nthink no more of it.\r\n\r\nThese two, whom we shall call Susan and Emmeline, had been the personal\r\nattendants of an amiable and pious lady of New Orleans, by whom they\r\nhad been carefully and piously instructed and trained. They had been\r\ntaught to read and write, diligently instructed in the truths of\r\nreligion, and their lot had been as happy an one as in their condition\r\nit was possible to be. But the only son of their protectress had the\r\nmanagement of her property; and, by carelessness and extravagance\r\ninvolved it to a large amount, and at last failed. One of the largest\r\ncreditors was the respectable firm of B. & Co., in New York. B. & Co.\r\nwrote to their lawyer in New Orleans, who attached the real estate\r\n(these two articles and a lot of plantation hands formed the most\r\nvaluable part of it), and wrote word to that effect to New York.\r\nBrother B., being, as we have said, a Christian man, and a resident in\r\na free State, felt some uneasiness on the subject. He didn\xe2\x80\x99t like\r\ntrading in slaves and souls of men,\xe2\x80\x94of course, he didn\xe2\x80\x99t; but, then,\r\nthere were thirty thousand dollars in the case, and that was rather too\r\nmuch money to be lost for a principle; and so, after much considering,\r\nand asking advice from those that he knew would advise to suit him,\r\nBrother B. wrote to his lawyer to dispose of the business in the way\r\nthat seemed to him the most suitable, and remit the proceeds.\r\n\r\nThe day after the letter arrived in New Orleans, Susan and Emmeline\r\nwere attached, and sent to the depot to await a general auction on the\r\nfollowing morning; and as they glimmer faintly upon us in the moonlight\r\nwhich steals through the grated window, we may listen to their\r\nconversation. Both are weeping, but each quietly, that the other may\r\nnot hear.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMother, just lay your head on my lap, and see if you can\xe2\x80\x99t sleep a\r\nlittle,\xe2\x80\x9d says the girl, trying to appear calm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI haven\xe2\x80\x99t any heart to sleep, Em; I can\xe2\x80\x99t; it\xe2\x80\x99s the last night we may\r\nbe together!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, mother, don\xe2\x80\x99t say so! perhaps we shall get sold together,\xe2\x80\x94who\r\nknows?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf \xe2\x80\x99t was anybody\xe2\x80\x99s else case, I should say so, too, Em,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nwoman; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I\xe2\x80\x99m so feard of losin\xe2\x80\x99 you that I don\xe2\x80\x99t see anything but\r\nthe danger.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, mother, the man said we were both likely, and would sell well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSusan remembered the man\xe2\x80\x99s looks and words. With a deadly sickness at\r\nher heart, she remembered how he had looked at Emmeline\xe2\x80\x99s hands, and\r\nlifted up her curly hair, and pronounced her a first-rate article.\r\nSusan had been trained as a Christian, brought up in the daily reading\r\nof the Bible, and had the same horror of her child\xe2\x80\x99s being sold to a\r\nlife of shame that any other Christian mother might have; but she had\r\nno hope,\xe2\x80\x94no protection.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMother, I think we might do first rate, if you could get a place as\r\ncook, and I as chambermaid or seamstress, in some family. I dare say we\r\nshall. Let\xe2\x80\x99s both look as bright and lively as we can, and tell all we\r\ncan do, and perhaps we shall,\xe2\x80\x9d said Emmeline.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want you to brush your hair all back straight, tomorrow,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nSusan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat for, mother? I don\xe2\x80\x99t look near so well, that way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but you\xe2\x80\x99ll sell better so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t see why!\xe2\x80\x9d said the child.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRespectable families would be more apt to buy you, if they saw you\r\nlooked plain and decent, as if you wasn\xe2\x80\x99t trying to look handsome. I\r\nknow their ways better \xe2\x80\x99n you do,\xe2\x80\x9d said Susan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, mother, then I will.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd, Emmeline, if we shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t ever see each other again, after\r\ntomorrow,\xe2\x80\x94if I\xe2\x80\x99m sold way up on a plantation somewhere, and you\r\nsomewhere else,\xe2\x80\x94always remember how you\xe2\x80\x99ve been brought up, and all\r\nMissis has told you; take your Bible with you, and your hymn-book; and\r\nif you\xe2\x80\x99re faithful to the Lord, he\xe2\x80\x99ll be faithful to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo speaks the poor soul, in sore discouragement; for she knows that\r\ntomorrow any man, however vile and brutal, however godless and\r\nmerciless, if he only has money to pay for her, may become owner of her\r\ndaughter, body and soul; and then, how is the child to be faithful? She\r\nthinks of all this, as she holds her daughter in her arms, and wishes\r\nthat she were not handsome and attractive. It seems almost an\r\naggravation to her to remember how purely and piously, how much above\r\nthe ordinary lot, she has been brought up. But she has no resort but to\r\n_pray_; and many such prayers to God have gone up from those same trim,\r\nneatly-arranged, respectable slave-prisons,\xe2\x80\x94prayers which God has not\r\nforgotten, as a coming day shall show; for it is written, \xe2\x80\x9cWho causeth\r\none of these little ones to offend, it were better for him that a\r\nmillstone were hanged about his neck, and that he were drowned in the\r\ndepths of the sea.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe soft, earnest, quiet moonbeam looks in fixedly, marking the bars of\r\nthe grated windows on the prostrate, sleeping forms. The mother and\r\ndaughter are singing together a wild and melancholy dirge, common as a\r\nfuneral hymn among the slaves:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, where is weeping Mary?\r\nO, where is weeping Mary?\r\n          \xe2\x80\x99Rived in the goodly land.\r\nShe is dead and gone to Heaven;\r\nShe is dead and gone to Heaven;\r\n          \xe2\x80\x99Rived in the goodly land.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nThese words, sung by voices of a peculiar and melancholy sweetness, in\r\nan air which seemed like the sighing of earthy despair after heavenly\r\nhope, floated through the dark prison rooms with a pathetic cadence, as\r\nverse after verse was breathed out:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, where are Paul and Silas?\r\nO, where are Paul and Silas?\r\n          Gone to the goodly land.\r\nThey are dead and gone to Heaven;\r\nThey are dead and gone to Heaven;\r\n          \xe2\x80\x99Rived in the goodly land.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nSing on poor souls! The night is short, and the morning will part you\r\nforever!\r\n\r\nBut now it is morning, and everybody is astir; and the worthy Mr.\r\nSkeggs is busy and bright, for a lot of goods is to be fitted out for\r\nauction. There is a brisk lookout on the toilet; injunctions passed\r\naround to every one to put on their best face and be spry; and now all\r\nare arranged in a circle for a last review, before they are marched up\r\nto the Bourse.\r\n\r\nMr. Skeggs, with his palmetto on and his cigar in his mouth, walks\r\naround to put farewell touches on his wares.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow\xe2\x80\x99s this?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, stepping in front of Susan and Emmeline.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere\xe2\x80\x99s your curls, gal?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe girl looked timidly at her mother, who, with the smooth adroitness\r\ncommon among her class, answers,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was telling her, last night, to put up her hair smooth and neat, and\r\nnot havin\xe2\x80\x99 it flying about in curls; looks more respectable so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBother!\xe2\x80\x9d said the man, peremptorily, turning to the girl; \xe2\x80\x9cyou go\r\nright along, and curl yourself real smart!\xe2\x80\x9d He added, giving a crack to\r\na rattan he held in his hand, \xe2\x80\x9cAnd be back in quick time, too!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou go and help her,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, to the mother. \xe2\x80\x9cThem curls may make a\r\nhundred dollars difference in the sale of her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nBeneath a splendid dome were men of all nations, moving to and fro,\r\nover the marble pave. On every side of the circular area were little\r\ntribunes, or stations, for the use of speakers and auctioneers. Two of\r\nthese, on opposite sides of the area, were now occupied by brilliant\r\nand talented gentlemen, enthusiastically forcing up, in English and\r\nFrench commingled, the bids of connoisseurs in their various wares. A\r\nthird one, on the other side, still unoccupied, was surrounded by a\r\ngroup, waiting the moment of sale to begin. And here we may recognize\r\nthe St. Clare servants,\xe2\x80\x94Tom, Adolph, and others; and there, too, Susan\r\nand Emmeline, awaiting their turn with anxious and dejected faces.\r\nVarious spectators, intending to purchase, or not intending, examining,\r\nand commenting on their various points and faces with the same freedom\r\nthat a set of jockeys discuss the merits of a horse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHulloa, Alf! what brings you here?\xe2\x80\x9d said a young exquisite, slapping\r\nthe shoulder of a sprucely-dressed young man, who was examining Adolph\r\nthrough an eye-glass.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell! I was wanting a valet, and I heard that St. Clare\xe2\x80\x99s lot was\r\ngoing. I thought I\xe2\x80\x99d just look at his\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCatch me ever buying any of St. Clare\xe2\x80\x99s people! Spoilt niggers, every\r\none. Impudent as the devil!\xe2\x80\x9d said the other.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever fear that!\xe2\x80\x9d said the first. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I get \xe2\x80\x99em, I\xe2\x80\x99ll soon have their\r\nairs out of them; they\xe2\x80\x99ll soon find that they\xe2\x80\x99ve another kind of master\r\nto deal with than Monsieur St. Clare. \xe2\x80\x99Pon my word, I\xe2\x80\x99ll buy that\r\nfellow. I like the shape of him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll find it\xe2\x80\x99ll take all you\xe2\x80\x99ve got to keep him. He\xe2\x80\x99s deucedly\r\nextravagant!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but my lord will find that he _can\xe2\x80\x99t_ be extravagant with _me_.\r\nJust let him be sent to the calaboose a few times, and thoroughly\r\ndressed down! I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you if it don\xe2\x80\x99t bring him to a sense of his\r\nways! O, I\xe2\x80\x99ll reform him, up hill and down,\xe2\x80\x94you\xe2\x80\x99ll see. I buy him,\r\nthat\xe2\x80\x99s flat!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom had been standing wistfully examining the multitude of faces\r\nthronging around him, for one whom he would wish to call master. And if\r\nyou should ever be under the necessity, sir, of selecting, out of two\r\nhundred men, one who was to become your absolute owner and disposer,\r\nyou would, perhaps, realize, just as Tom did, how few there were that\r\nyou would feel at all comfortable in being made over to. Tom saw\r\nabundance of men,\xe2\x80\x94great, burly, gruff men; little, chirping, dried men;\r\nlong-favored, lank, hard men; and every variety of stubbed-looking,\r\ncommonplace men, who pick up their fellow-men as one picks up chips,\r\nputting them into the fire or a basket with equal unconcern, according\r\nto their convenience; but he saw no St. Clare.\r\n\r\nA little before the sale commenced, a short, broad, muscular man, in a\r\nchecked shirt considerably open at the bosom, and pantaloons much the\r\nworse for dirt and wear, elbowed his way through the crowd, like one\r\nwho is going actively into a business; and, coming up to the group,\r\nbegan to examine them systematically. From the moment that Tom saw him\r\napproaching, he felt an immediate and revolting horror at him, that\r\nincreased as he came near. He was evidently, though short, of gigantic\r\nstrength. His round, bullet head, large, light-gray eyes, with their\r\nshaggy, sandy eyebrows, and stiff, wiry, sun-burned hair, were rather\r\nunprepossessing items, it is to be confessed; his large, coarse mouth\r\nwas distended with tobacco, the juice of which, from time to time, he\r\nejected from him with great decision and explosive force; his hands\r\nwere immensely large, hairy, sun-burned, freckled, and very dirty, and\r\ngarnished with long nails, in a very foul condition. This man proceeded\r\nto a very free personal examination of the lot. He seized Tom by the\r\njaw, and pulled open his mouth to inspect his teeth; made him strip up\r\nhis sleeve, to show his muscle; turned him round, made him jump and\r\nspring, to show his paces.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere was you raised?\xe2\x80\x9d he added, briefly, to these investigations.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn Kintuck, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, looking about, as if for deliverance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat have you done?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHad care of Mas\xe2\x80\x99r\xe2\x80\x99s farm,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLikely story!\xe2\x80\x9d said the other, shortly, as he passed on. He paused a\r\nmoment before Dolph; then spitting a discharge of tobacco-juice on his\r\nwell-blacked boots, and giving a contemptuous umph, he walked on. Again\r\nhe stopped before Susan and Emmeline. He put out his heavy, dirty hand,\r\nand drew the girl towards him; passed it over her neck and bust, felt\r\nher arms, looked at her teeth, and then pushed her back against her\r\nmother, whose patient face showed the suffering she had been going\r\nthrough at every motion of the hideous stranger.\r\n\r\nThe girl was frightened, and began to cry.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStop that, you minx!\xe2\x80\x9d said the salesman; \xe2\x80\x9cno whimpering here,\xe2\x80\x94the sale\r\nis going to begin.\xe2\x80\x9d And accordingly the sale begun.\r\n\r\nAdolph was knocked off, at a good sum, to the young gentlemen who had\r\npreviously stated his intention of buying him; and the other servants\r\nof the St. Clare lot went to various bidders.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, up with you, boy! d\xe2\x80\x99ye hear?\xe2\x80\x9d said the auctioneer to Tom.\r\n\r\nTom stepped upon the block, gave a few anxious looks round; all seemed\r\nmingled in a common, indistinct noise,\xe2\x80\x94the clatter of the salesman\r\ncrying off his qualifications in French and English, the quick fire of\r\nFrench and English bids; and almost in a moment came the final thump of\r\nthe hammer, and the clear ring on the last syllable of the word\r\n_\xe2\x80\x9cdollars,\xe2\x80\x9d_ as the auctioneer announced his price, and Tom was made\r\nover.\xe2\x80\x94He had a master!\r\n\r\nHe was pushed from the block;\xe2\x80\x94the short, bullet-headed man seizing him\r\nroughly by the shoulder, pushed him to one side, saying, in a harsh\r\nvoice, \xe2\x80\x9cStand there, _you!_\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom hardly realized anything; but still the bidding went on,\xe2\x80\x94ratting,\r\nclattering, now French, now English. Down goes the hammer again,\xe2\x80\x94Susan\r\nis sold! She goes down from the block, stops, looks wistfully back,\xe2\x80\x94her\r\ndaughter stretches her hands towards her. She looks with agony in the\r\nface of the man who has bought her,\xe2\x80\x94a respectable middle-aged man, of\r\nbenevolent countenance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r, please do buy my daughter!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d like to, but I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid I can\xe2\x80\x99t afford it!\xe2\x80\x9d said the gentleman,\r\nlooking, with painful interest, as the young girl mounted the block,\r\nand looked around her with a frightened and timid glance.\r\n\r\nThe blood flushes painfully in her otherwise colorless cheek, her eye\r\nhas a feverish fire, and her mother groans to see that she looks more\r\nbeautiful than she ever saw her before. The auctioneer sees his\r\nadvantage, and expatiates volubly in mingled French and English, and\r\nbids rise in rapid succession.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll do anything in reason,\xe2\x80\x9d said the benevolent-looking gentleman,\r\npressing in and joining with the bids. In a few moments they have run\r\nbeyond his purse. He is silent; the auctioneer grows warmer; but bids\r\ngradually drop off. It lies now between an aristocratic old citizen and\r\nour bullet-headed acquaintance. The citizen bids for a few turns,\r\ncontemptuously measuring his opponent; but the bullet-head has the\r\nadvantage over him, both in obstinacy and concealed length of purse,\r\nand the controversy lasts but a moment; the hammer falls,\xe2\x80\x94he has got\r\nthe girl, body and soul, unless God help her!\r\n\r\nHer master is Mr. Legree, who owns a cotton plantation on the Red\r\nRiver. She is pushed along into the same lot with Tom and two other\r\nmen, and goes off, weeping as she goes.\r\n\r\nThe benevolent gentleman is sorry; but, then, the thing happens every\r\nday! One sees girls and mothers crying, at these sales, _always!_ it\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t be helped, &c.; and he walks off, with his acquisition, in\r\nanother direction.\r\n\r\nTwo days after, the lawyer of the Christian firm of B. & Co., New York,\r\nsend on their money to them. On the reverse of that draft, so obtained,\r\nlet them write these words of the great Paymaster, to whom they shall\r\nmake up their account in a future day: _\xe2\x80\x9cWhen he maketh inquisition for\r\nblood, he forgetteth not the cry of the humble!\xe2\x80\x9d_\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXI\r\nThe Middle Passage\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou art of purer eyes than to behold evil, and canst not look upon\r\niniquity: wherefore lookest thou upon them that deal treacherously, and\r\nholdest thy tongue when the wicked devoureth the man that is more\r\nrighteous than he?\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94HAB. 1: 13.\r\n\r\n\r\nOn the lower part of a small, mean boat, on the Red River, Tom\r\nsat,\xe2\x80\x94chains on his wrists, chains on his feet, and a weight heavier\r\nthan chains lay on his heart. All had faded from his sky,\xe2\x80\x94moon and\r\nstar; all had passed by him, as the trees and banks were now passing,\r\nto return no more. Kentucky home, with wife and children, and indulgent\r\nowners; St. Clare home, with all its refinements and splendors; the\r\ngolden head of Eva, with its saint-like eyes; the proud, gay, handsome,\r\nseemingly careless, yet ever-kind St. Clare; hours of ease and\r\nindulgent leisure,\xe2\x80\x94all gone! and in place thereof, _what_ remains?\r\n\r\nIt is one of the bitterest apportionments of a lot of slavery, that the\r\nnegro, sympathetic and assimilative, after acquiring, in a refined\r\nfamily, the tastes and feelings which form the atmosphere of such a\r\nplace, is not the less liable to become the bond-slave of the coarsest\r\nand most brutal,\xe2\x80\x94just as a chair or table, which once decorated the\r\nsuperb saloon, comes, at last, battered and defaced, to the barroom of\r\nsome filthy tavern, or some low haunt of vulgar debauchery. The great\r\ndifference is, that the table and chair cannot feel, and the _man_ can;\r\nfor even a legal enactment that he shall be \xe2\x80\x9ctaken, reputed, adjudged\r\nin law, to be a chattel personal,\xe2\x80\x9d cannot blot out his soul, with its\r\nown private little world of memories, hopes, loves, fears, and desires.\r\n\r\nMr. Simon Legree, Tom\xe2\x80\x99s master, had purchased slaves at one place and\r\nanother, in New Orleans, to the number of eight, and driven them,\r\nhandcuffed, in couples of two and two, down to the good steamer Pirate,\r\nwhich lay at the levee, ready for a trip up the Red River.\r\n\r\nHaving got them fairly on board, and the boat being off, he came round,\r\nwith that air of efficiency which ever characterized him, to take a\r\nreview of them. Stopping opposite to Tom, who had been attired for sale\r\nin his best broadcloth suit, with well-starched linen and shining\r\nboots, he briefly expressed himself as follows:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStand up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom stood up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake off that stock!\xe2\x80\x9d and, as Tom, encumbered by his fetters,\r\nproceeded to do it, he assisted him, by pulling it, with no gentle\r\nhand, from his neck, and putting it in his pocket.\r\n\r\nLegree now turned to Tom\xe2\x80\x99s trunk, which, previous to this, he had been\r\nransacking, and, taking from it a pair of old pantaloons and\r\ndilapidated coat, which Tom had been wont to put on about his\r\nstable-work, he said, liberating Tom\xe2\x80\x99s hands from the handcuffs, and\r\npointing to a recess in among the boxes,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou go there, and put these on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom obeyed, and in a few moments returned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake off your boots,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Legree.\r\n\r\nTom did so.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere,\xe2\x80\x9d said the former, throwing him a pair of coarse, stout shoes,\r\nsuch as were common among the slaves, \xe2\x80\x9cput these on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn Tom\xe2\x80\x99s hurried exchange, he had not forgotten to transfer his\r\ncherished Bible to his pocket. It was well he did so; for Mr. Legree,\r\nhaving refitted Tom\xe2\x80\x99s handcuffs, proceeded deliberately to investigate\r\nthe contents of his pockets. He drew out a silk handkerchief, and put\r\nit into his own pocket. Several little trifles, which Tom had\r\ntreasured, chiefly because they had amused Eva, he looked upon with a\r\ncontemptuous grunt, and tossed them over his shoulder into the river.\r\n\r\nTom\xe2\x80\x99s Methodist hymn-book, which, in his hurry, he had forgotten, he\r\nnow held up and turned over.\r\n\r\nHumph! pious, to be sure. So, what\xe2\x80\x99s yer name,\xe2\x80\x94you belong to the\r\nchurch, eh?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, firmly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I\xe2\x80\x99ll soon have _that_ out of you. I have none o\xe2\x80\x99 yer bawling,\r\npraying, singing niggers on my place; so remember. Now, mind yourself,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nhe said, with a stamp and a fierce glance of his gray eye, directed at\r\nTom, \xe2\x80\x9c_I\xe2\x80\x99m_ your church now! You understand,\xe2\x80\x94you\xe2\x80\x99ve got to be as _I_\r\nsay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSomething within the silent black man answered _No!_ and, as if\r\nrepeated by an invisible voice, came the words of an old prophetic\r\nscroll, as Eva had often read them to him,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cFear not! for I have\r\nredeemed thee. I have called thee by name. Thou art MINE!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut Simon Legree heard no voice. That voice is one he never shall hear.\r\nHe only glared for a moment on the downcast face of Tom, and walked\r\noff. He took Tom\xe2\x80\x99s trunk, which contained a very neat and abundant\r\nwardrobe, to the forecastle, where it was soon surrounded by various\r\nhands of the boat. With much laughing, at the expense of niggers who\r\ntried to be gentlemen, the articles very readily were sold to one and\r\nanother, and the empty trunk finally put up at auction. It was a good\r\njoke, they all thought, especially to see how Tom looked after his\r\nthings, as they were going this way and that; and then the auction of\r\nthe trunk, that was funnier than all, and occasioned abundant\r\nwitticisms.\r\n\r\nThis little affair being over, Simon sauntered up again to his\r\nproperty.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, Tom, I\xe2\x80\x99ve relieved you of any extra baggage, you see. Take mighty\r\ngood care of them clothes. It\xe2\x80\x99ll be long enough \xe2\x80\x99fore you get more. I\r\ngo in for making niggers careful; one suit has to do for one year, on\r\nmy place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSimon next walked up to the place where Emmeline was sitting, chained\r\nto another woman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, chucking her under the chin, \xe2\x80\x9ckeep up your\r\nspirits.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe involuntary look of horror, fright and aversion, with which the\r\ngirl regarded him, did not escape his eye. He frowned fiercely.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNone o\xe2\x80\x99 your shines, gal! you\xe2\x80\x99s got to keep a pleasant face, when I\r\nspeak to ye,\xe2\x80\x94d\xe2\x80\x99ye hear? And you, you old yellow poco moonshine!\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nsaid, giving a shove to the mulatto woman to whom Emmeline was chained,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t you carry that sort of face! You\xe2\x80\x99s got to look chipper, I tell\r\nye!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say, all on ye,\xe2\x80\x9d he said retreating a pace or two back, \xe2\x80\x9clook at\r\nme,\xe2\x80\x94look at me,\xe2\x80\x94look me right in the eye,\xe2\x80\x94_straight_, now!\xe2\x80\x9d said he,\r\nstamping his foot at every pause.\r\n\r\nAs by a fascination, every eye was now directed to the glaring\r\ngreenish-gray eye of Simon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, doubling his great, heavy fist into something\r\nresembling a blacksmith\xe2\x80\x99s hammer, \xe2\x80\x9cd\xe2\x80\x99ye see this fist? Heft it!\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nsaid, bringing it down on Tom\xe2\x80\x99s hand. \xe2\x80\x9cLook at these yer bones! Well, I\r\ntell ye this yer fist has got as hard as iron _knocking down niggers_.\r\nI never see the nigger, yet, I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t bring down with one crack,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid he, bringing his fist down so near to the face of Tom that he\r\nwinked and drew back. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t keep none o\xe2\x80\x99 yer cussed overseers; I\r\ndoes my own overseeing; and I tell you things _is_ seen to. You\xe2\x80\x99s every\r\none on ye got to toe the mark, I tell ye; quick,\xe2\x80\x94straight,\xe2\x80\x94the moment I\r\nspeak. That\xe2\x80\x99s the way to keep in with me. Ye won\xe2\x80\x99t find no soft spot in\r\nme, nowhere. So, now, mind yerselves; for I don\xe2\x80\x99t show no mercy!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe women involuntarily drew in their breath, and the whole gang sat\r\nwith downcast, dejected faces. Meanwhile, Simon turned on his heel, and\r\nmarched up to the bar of the boat for a dram.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s the way I begin with my niggers,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, to a gentlemanly\r\nman, who had stood by him during his speech. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s my system to begin\r\nstrong,\xe2\x80\x94just let \xe2\x80\x99em know what to expect.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed!\xe2\x80\x9d said the stranger, looking upon him with the curiosity of a\r\nnaturalist studying some out-of-the-way specimen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, indeed. I\xe2\x80\x99m none o\xe2\x80\x99 yer gentlemen planters, with lily fingers, to\r\nslop round and be cheated by some old cuss of an overseer! Just feel of\r\nmy knuckles, now; look at my fist. Tell ye, sir, the flesh on \xe2\x80\x99t has\r\ncome jest like a stone, practising on nigger\xe2\x80\x94feel on it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe stranger applied his fingers to the implement in question, and\r\nsimply said,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x99T is hard enough; and, I suppose,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, \xe2\x80\x9cpractice has made your\r\nheart just like it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, yes, I may say so,\xe2\x80\x9d said Simon, with a hearty laugh. \xe2\x80\x9cI reckon\r\nthere\xe2\x80\x99s as little soft in me as in any one going. Tell you, nobody\r\ncomes it over me! Niggers never gets round me, neither with squalling\r\nnor soft soap,\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s a fact.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have a fine lot there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReal,\xe2\x80\x9d said Simon. \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s that Tom, they telled me he was suthin\xe2\x80\x99\r\nuncommon.
