I paid a little high for him, tendin\xe2\x80\x99 him for a driver and a\r\nmanaging chap; only get the notions out that he\xe2\x80\x99s larnt by bein\xe2\x80\x99\r\ntreated as niggers never ought to be, he\xe2\x80\x99ll do prime! The yellow woman\r\nI got took in on. I rayther think she\xe2\x80\x99s sickly, but I shall put her\r\nthrough for what she\xe2\x80\x99s worth; she may last a year or two. I don\xe2\x80\x99t go\r\nfor savin\xe2\x80\x99 niggers. Use up, and buy more, \xe2\x80\x99s my way;-makes you less\r\ntrouble, and I\xe2\x80\x99m quite sure it comes cheaper in the end;\xe2\x80\x9d and Simon\r\nsipped his glass.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how long do they generally last?\xe2\x80\x9d said the stranger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, donno; \xe2\x80\x99cordin\xe2\x80\x99 as their constitution is. Stout fellers last six\r\nor seven years; trashy ones gets worked up in two or three. I used to,\r\nwhen I fust begun, have considerable trouble fussin\xe2\x80\x99 with \xe2\x80\x99em and\r\ntrying to make \xe2\x80\x99em hold out,\xe2\x80\x94doctorin\xe2\x80\x99 on \xe2\x80\x99em up when they\xe2\x80\x99s sick, and\r\ngivin\xe2\x80\x99 on \xe2\x80\x99em clothes and blankets, and what not, tryin\xe2\x80\x99 to keep \xe2\x80\x99em\r\nall sort o\xe2\x80\x99 decent and comfortable. Law, \xe2\x80\x99t wasn\xe2\x80\x99t no sort o\xe2\x80\x99 use; I\r\nlost money on \xe2\x80\x99em, and \xe2\x80\x99t was heaps o\xe2\x80\x99 trouble. Now, you see, I just\r\nput \xe2\x80\x99em straight through, sick or well. When one nigger\xe2\x80\x99s dead, I buy\r\nanother; and I find it comes cheaper and easier, every way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe stranger turned away, and seated himself beside a gentleman, who\r\nhad been listening to the conversation with repressed uneasiness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must not take that fellow to be any specimen of Southern\r\nplanters,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should hope not,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young gentleman, with emphasis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is a mean, low, brutal fellow!\xe2\x80\x9d said the other.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet your laws allow him to hold any number of human beings subject\r\nto his absolute will, without even a shadow of protection; and, low as\r\nhe is, you cannot say that there are not many such.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said the other, \xe2\x80\x9cthere are also many considerate and humane men\r\namong planters.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGranted,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man; \xe2\x80\x9cbut, in my opinion, it is you\r\nconsiderate, humane men, that are responsible for all the brutality and\r\noutrage wrought by these wretches; because, if it were not for your\r\nsanction and influence, the whole system could not keep foothold for an\r\nhour. If there were no planters except such as that one,\xe2\x80\x9d said he,\r\npointing with his finger to Legree, who stood with his back to them,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthe whole thing would go down like a millstone. It is your\r\nrespectability and humanity that licenses and protects his brutality.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou certainly have a high opinion of my good nature,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nplanter, smiling, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I advise you not to talk quite so loud, as there\r\nare people on board the boat who might not be quite so tolerant to\r\nopinion as I am. You had better wait till I get up to my plantation,\r\nand there you may abuse us all, quite at your leisure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe young gentleman colored and smiled, and the two were soon busy in a\r\ngame of backgammon. Meanwhile, another conversation was going on in the\r\nlower part of the boat, between Emmeline and the mulatto woman with\r\nwhom she was confined. As was natural, they were exchanging with each\r\nother some particulars of their history.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho did you belong to?\xe2\x80\x9d said Emmeline.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my Mas\xe2\x80\x99r was Mr. Ellis,\xe2\x80\x94lived on Levee-street. P\xe2\x80\x99raps you\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nseen the house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas he good to you?\xe2\x80\x9d said Emmeline.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMostly, till he tuk sick. He\xe2\x80\x99s lain sick, off and on, more than six\r\nmonths, and been orful oneasy. \xe2\x80\x99Pears like he warnt willin\xe2\x80\x99 to have\r\nnobody rest, day or night; and got so curous, there couldn\xe2\x80\x99t nobody\r\nsuit him. \xe2\x80\x99Pears like he just grew crosser, every day; kep me up nights\r\ntill I got farly beat out, and couldn\xe2\x80\x99t keep awake no longer; and cause\r\nI got to sleep, one night, Lors, he talk so orful to me, and he tell me\r\nhe\xe2\x80\x99d sell me to just the hardest master he could find; and he\xe2\x80\x99d\r\npromised me my freedom, too, when he died.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHad you any friends?\xe2\x80\x9d said Emmeline.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, my husband,\xe2\x80\x94he\xe2\x80\x99s a blacksmith. Mas\xe2\x80\x99r gen\xe2\x80\x99ly hired him out. They\r\ntook me off so quick, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t even have time to see him; and I\xe2\x80\x99s got\r\nfour children. O, dear me!\xe2\x80\x9d said the woman, covering her face with her\r\nhands.\r\n\r\nIt is a natural impulse, in every one, when they hear a tale of\r\ndistress, to think of something to say by way of consolation. Emmeline\r\nwanted to say something, but she could not think of anything to say.\r\nWhat was there to be said? As by a common consent, they both avoided,\r\nwith fear and dread, all mention of the horrible man who was now their\r\nmaster.\r\n\r\nTrue, there is religious trust for even the darkest hour. The mulatto\r\nwoman was a member of the Methodist church, and had an unenlightened\r\nbut very sincere spirit of piety. Emmeline had been educated much more\r\nintelligently,\xe2\x80\x94taught to read and write, and diligently instructed in\r\nthe Bible, by the care of a faithful and pious mistress; yet, would it\r\nnot try the faith of the firmest Christian, to find themselves\r\nabandoned, apparently, of God, in the grasp of ruthless violence? How\r\nmuch more must it shake the faith of Christ\xe2\x80\x99s poor little ones, weak in\r\nknowledge and tender in years!\r\n\r\nThe boat moved on,\xe2\x80\x94freighted with its weight of sorrow,\xe2\x80\x94up the red,\r\nmuddy, turbid current, through the abrupt tortuous windings of the Red\r\nriver; and sad eyes gazed wearily on the steep red-clay banks, as they\r\nglided by in dreary sameness. At last the boat stopped at a small town,\r\nand Legree, with his party, disembarked.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXII\r\nDark Places\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe dark places of the earth are full of the habitations of\r\ncruelty.\xe2\x80\x9d[1]\r\n\r\n\r\n [1] Ps. 74:20.\r\n\r\n\r\nTrailing wearily behind a rude wagon, and over a ruder road, Tom and\r\nhis associates faced onward.\r\n\r\nIn the wagon was seated Simon Legree and the two women, still fettered\r\ntogether, were stowed away with some baggage in the back part of it,\r\nand the whole company were seeking Legree\xe2\x80\x99s plantation, which lay a\r\ngood distance off.\r\n\r\nIt was a wild, forsaken road, now winding through dreary pine barrens,\r\nwhere the wind whispered mournfully, and now over log causeways,\r\nthrough long cypress swamps, the doleful trees rising out of the slimy,\r\nspongy ground, hung with long wreaths of funeral black moss, while ever\r\nand anon the loathsome form of the mocassin snake might be seen sliding\r\namong broken stumps and shattered branches that lay here and there,\r\nrotting in the water.\r\n\r\nIt is disconsolate enough, this riding, to the stranger, who, with\r\nwell-filled pocket and well-appointed horse, threads the lonely way on\r\nsome errand of business; but wilder, drearier, to the man enthralled,\r\nwhom every weary step bears further from all that man loves and prays\r\nfor.\r\n\r\nSo one should have thought, that witnessed the sunken and dejected\r\nexpression on those dark faces; the wistful, patient weariness with\r\nwhich those sad eyes rested on object after object that passed them in\r\ntheir sad journey.\r\n\r\nSimon rode on, however, apparently well pleased, occasionally pulling\r\naway at a flask of spirit, which he kept in his pocket.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say, _you!_\xe2\x80\x9d he said, as he turned back and caught a glance at the\r\ndispirited faces behind him. \xe2\x80\x9cStrike up a song, boys,\xe2\x80\x94come!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe men looked at each other, and the \xe2\x80\x9c_come_\xe2\x80\x9d was repeated, with a\r\nsmart crack of the whip which the driver carried in his hands. Tom\r\nbegan a Methodist hymn.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJerusalem, my happy home,\r\n    Name ever dear to me!\r\nWhen shall my sorrows have an end,\r\n    Thy joys when shall\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9c[2]\r\n\r\n\r\n [2] _Jerusalem, my happy home_,\xe2\x80\x9d anonymous hymn dating from the latter\r\n part of the sixteenth century, sung to the tune of \xe2\x80\x9cSt. Stephen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n Words derive from St. Augustine\xe2\x80\x99s _Meditations_.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShut up, you black cuss!\xe2\x80\x9d roared Legree; \xe2\x80\x9cdid ye think I wanted any o\xe2\x80\x99\r\nyer infernal old Methodism? I say, tune up, now, something real\r\nrowdy,\xe2\x80\x94quick!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOne of the other men struck up one of those unmeaning songs, common\r\namong the slaves.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMas\xe2\x80\x99r see\xe2\x80\x99d me cotch a coon,\r\n    High boys, high!\r\nHe laughed to split,\xe2\x80\x94d\xe2\x80\x99ye see the moon,\r\n    Ho! ho! ho! boys, ho!\r\nHo! yo! hi\xe2\x80\x94e! _oh!\xe2\x80\x9d_\r\n\r\n\r\nThe singer appeared to make up the song to his own pleasure, generally\r\nhitting on rhyme, without much attempt at reason; and the party took up\r\nthe chorus, at intervals,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHo! ho! ho! boys, ho!\r\nHigh\xe2\x80\x94e\xe2\x80\x94oh! high\xe2\x80\x94e\xe2\x80\x94oh!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was sung very boisterouly, and with a forced attempt at merriment;\r\nbut no wail of despair, no words of impassioned prayer, could have had\r\nsuch a depth of woe in them as the wild notes of the chorus. As if the\r\npoor, dumb heart, threatened,\xe2\x80\x94prisoned,\xe2\x80\x94took refuge in that\r\ninarticulate sanctuary of music, and found there a language in which to\r\nbreathe its prayer to God! There was a prayer in it, which Simon could\r\nnot hear. He only heard the boys singing noisily, and was well pleased;\r\nhe was making them \xe2\x80\x9ckeep up their spirits.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my little dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, turning to Emmeline, and laying his\r\nhand on her shoulder, \xe2\x80\x9cwe\xe2\x80\x99re almost home!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen Legree scolded and stormed, Emmeline was terrified; but when he\r\nlaid his hand on her, and spoke as he now did, she felt as if she had\r\nrather he would strike her. The expression of his eyes made her soul\r\nsick, and her flesh creep. Involuntarily she clung closer to the\r\nmulatto woman by her side, as if she were her mother.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou didn\xe2\x80\x99t ever wear ear-rings,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, taking hold of her small ear\r\nwith his coarse fingers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r!\xe2\x80\x9d said Emmeline, trembling and looking down.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I\xe2\x80\x99ll give you a pair, when we get home, if you\xe2\x80\x99re a good girl.\r\nYou needn\xe2\x80\x99t be so frightened; I don\xe2\x80\x99t mean to make you work very hard.\r\nYou\xe2\x80\x99ll have fine times with me, and live like a lady,\xe2\x80\x94only be a good\r\ngirl.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLegree had been drinking to that degree that he was inclining to be\r\nvery gracious; and it was about this time that the enclosures of the\r\nplantation rose to view. The estate had formerly belonged to a\r\ngentleman of opulence and taste, who had bestowed some considerable\r\nattention to the adornment of his grounds. Having died insolvent, it\r\nhad been purchased, at a bargain, by Legree, who used it, as he did\r\neverything else, merely as an implement for money-making. The place had\r\nthat ragged, forlorn appearance, which is always produced by the\r\nevidence that the care of the former owner has been left to go to utter\r\ndecay.\r\n\r\nWhat was once a smooth-shaven lawn before the house, dotted here and\r\nthere with ornamental shrubs, was now covered with frowsy tangled\r\ngrass, with horseposts set up, here and there, in it, where the turf\r\nwas stamped away, and the ground littered with broken pails, cobs of\r\ncorn, and other slovenly remains. Here and there, a mildewed jessamine\r\nor honeysuckle hung raggedly from some ornamental support, which had\r\nbeen pushed to one side by being used as a horse-post. What once was a\r\nlarge garden was now all grown over with weeds, through which, here and\r\nthere, some solitary exotic reared its forsaken head. What had been a\r\nconservatory had now no window-shades, and on the mouldering shelves\r\nstood some dry, forsaken flower-pots, with sticks in them, whose dried\r\nleaves showed they had once been plants.\r\n\r\nThe wagon rolled up a weedy gravel walk, under a noble avenue of China\r\ntrees, whose graceful forms and ever-springing foliage seemed to be the\r\nonly things there that neglect could not daunt or alter,\xe2\x80\x94like noble\r\nspirits, so deeply rooted in goodness, as to flourish and grow stronger\r\namid discouragement and decay.\r\n\r\nThe house had been large and handsome. It was built in a manner common\r\nat the South; a wide verandah of two stories running round every part\r\nof the house, into which every outer door opened, the lower tier being\r\nsupported by brick pillars.\r\n\r\nBut the place looked desolate and uncomfortable; some windows stopped\r\nup with boards, some with shattered panes, and shutters hanging by a\r\nsingle hinge,\xe2\x80\x94all telling of coarse neglect and discomfort.\r\n\r\nBits of board, straw, old decayed barrels and boxes, garnished the\r\nground in all directions; and three or four ferocious-looking dogs,\r\nroused by the sound of the wagon-wheels, came tearing out, and were\r\nwith difficulty restrained from laying hold of Tom and his companions,\r\nby the effort of the ragged servants who came after them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYe see what ye\xe2\x80\x99d get!\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, caressing the dogs with grim\r\nsatisfaction, and turning to Tom and his companions. \xe2\x80\x9cYe see what ye\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nget, if ye try to run off. These yer dogs has been raised to track\r\nniggers; and they\xe2\x80\x99d jest as soon chaw one on ye up as eat their supper.\r\nSo, mind yerself! How now, Sambo!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, to a ragged fellow, without\r\nany brim to his hat, who was officious in his attentions. \xe2\x80\x9cHow have\r\nthings been going?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFust rate, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuimbo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree to another, who was making zealous demonstrations\r\nto attract his attention, \xe2\x80\x9cye minded what I telled ye?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGuess I did, didn\xe2\x80\x99t I?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThese two colored men were the two principal hands on the plantation.\r\nLegree had trained them in savageness and brutality as systematically\r\nas he had his bull-dogs; and, by long practice in hardness and cruelty,\r\nbrought their whole nature to about the same range of capacities. It is\r\na common remark, and one that is thought to militate strongly against\r\nthe character of the race, that the negro overseer is always more\r\ntyrannical and cruel than the white one. This is simply saying that the\r\nnegro mind has been more crushed and debased than the white. It is no\r\nmore true of this race than of every oppressed race, the world over.\r\nThe slave is always a tyrant, if he can get a chance to be one.\r\n\r\nLegree, like some potentates we read of in history, governed his\r\nplantation by a sort of resolution of forces. Sambo and Quimbo\r\ncordially hated each other; the plantation hands, one and all,\r\ncordially hated them; and, by playing off one against another, he was\r\npretty sure, through one or the other of the three parties, to get\r\ninformed of whatever was on foot in the place.\r\n\r\nNobody can live entirely without social intercourse; and Legree\r\nencouraged his two black satellites to a kind of coarse familiarity\r\nwith him,\xe2\x80\x94a familiarity, however, at any moment liable to get one or\r\nthe other of them into trouble; for, on the slightest provocation, one\r\nof them always stood ready, at a nod, to be a minister of his vengeance\r\non the other.\r\n\r\nAs they stood there now by Legree, they seemed an apt illustration of\r\nthe fact that brutal men are lower even than animals. Their coarse,\r\ndark, heavy features; their great eyes, rolling enviously on each\r\nother; their barbarous, guttural, half-brute intonation; their\r\ndilapidated garments fluttering in the wind,\xe2\x80\x94were all in admirable\r\nkeeping with the vile and unwholesome character of everything about the\r\nplace.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere, you Sambo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, \xe2\x80\x9ctake these yer boys down to the\r\nquarters; and here\xe2\x80\x99s a gal I\xe2\x80\x99ve got for _you_,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, as he\r\nseparated the mulatto woman from Emmeline, and pushed her towards\r\nhim;\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI promised to bring you one, you know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe woman gave a start, and drawing back, said, suddenly,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r! I left my old man in New Orleans.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat of that, you\xe2\x80\x94; won\xe2\x80\x99t you want one here? None o\xe2\x80\x99 your words,\xe2\x80\x94go\r\nlong!\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, raising his whip.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, mistress,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to Emmeline, \xe2\x80\x9cyou go in here with me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA dark, wild face was seen, for a moment, to glance at the window of\r\nthe house; and, as Legree opened the door, a female voice said\r\nsomething, in a quick, imperative tone. Tom, who was looking, with\r\nanxious interest, after Emmeline, as she went in, noticed this, and\r\nheard Legree answer, angrily, \xe2\x80\x9cYou may hold your tongue! I\xe2\x80\x99ll do as I\r\nplease, for all you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom heard no more; for he was soon following Sambo to the quarters. The\r\nquarters was a little sort of street of rude shanties, in a row, in a\r\npart of the plantation, far off from the house. They had a forlorn,\r\nbrutal, forsaken air. Tom\xe2\x80\x99s heart sunk when he saw them. He had been\r\ncomforting himself with the thought of a cottage, rude, indeed, but one\r\nwhich he might make neat and quiet, and where he might have a shelf for\r\nhis Bible, and a place to be alone out of his laboring hours. He looked\r\ninto several; they were mere rude shells, destitute of any species of\r\nfurniture, except a heap of straw, foul with dirt, spread confusedly\r\nover the floor, which was merely the bare ground, trodden hard by the\r\ntramping of innumerable feet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich of these will be mine?\xe2\x80\x9d said he, to Sambo, submissively.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDunno; ken turn in here, I spose,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sambo; \xe2\x80\x9cspects thar\xe2\x80\x99s room for\r\nanother thar; thar\xe2\x80\x99s a pretty smart heap o\xe2\x80\x99 niggers to each on \xe2\x80\x99em,\r\nnow; sure, I dunno what I \xe2\x80\x99s to do with more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was late in the evening when the weary occupants of the shanties\r\ncame flocking home,\xe2\x80\x94men and women, in soiled and tattered garments,\r\nsurly and uncomfortable, and in no mood to look pleasantly on\r\nnew-comers. The small village was alive with no inviting sounds;\r\nhoarse, guttural voices contending at the hand-mills where their morsel\r\nof hard corn was yet to be ground into meal, to fit it for the cake\r\nthat was to constitute their only supper. From the earliest dawn of the\r\nday, they had been in the fields, pressed to work under the driving\r\nlash of the overseers; for it was now in the very heat and hurry of the\r\nseason, and no means was left untried to press every one up to the top\r\nof their capabilities. \xe2\x80\x9cTrue,\xe2\x80\x9d says the negligent lounger; \xe2\x80\x9cpicking\r\ncotton isn\xe2\x80\x99t hard work.\xe2\x80\x9d Isn\xe2\x80\x99t it? And it isn\xe2\x80\x99t much inconvenience,\r\neither, to have one drop of water fall on your head; yet the worst\r\ntorture of the inquisition is produced by drop after drop, drop after\r\ndrop, falling moment after moment, with monotonous succession, on the\r\nsame spot; and work, in itself not hard, becomes so, by being pressed,\r\nhour after hour, with unvarying, unrelenting sameness, with not even\r\nthe consciousness of free-will to take from its tediousness. Tom looked\r\nin vain among the gang, as they poured along, for companionable faces.\r\nHe saw only sullen, scowling, imbruted men, and feeble, discouraged\r\nwomen, or women that were not women,\xe2\x80\x94the strong pushing away the\r\nweak,\xe2\x80\x94the gross, unrestricted animal selfishness of human beings, of\r\nwhom nothing good was expected and desired; and who, treated in every\r\nway like brutes, had sunk as nearly to their level as it was possible\r\nfor human beings to do. To a late hour in the night the sound of the\r\ngrinding was protracted; for the mills were few in number compared with\r\nthe grinders, and the weary and feeble ones were driven back by the\r\nstrong, and came on last in their turn.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHo yo!\xe2\x80\x9d said Sambo, coming to the mulatto woman, and throwing down a\r\nbag of corn before her; \xe2\x80\x9cwhat a cuss yo name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLucy,\xe2\x80\x9d said the woman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWal, Lucy, yo my woman now. Yo grind dis yer corn, and get _my_ supper\r\nbaked, ye har?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI an\xe2\x80\x99t your woman, and I won\xe2\x80\x99t be!\xe2\x80\x9d said the woman, with the sharp,\r\nsudden courage of despair; \xe2\x80\x9cyou go long!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll kick yo, then!\xe2\x80\x9d said Sambo, raising his foot threateningly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYe may kill me, if ye choose,\xe2\x80\x94the sooner the better! Wish\xe2\x80\x99t I was\r\ndead!\xe2\x80\x9d said she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say, Sambo, you go to spilin\xe2\x80\x99 the hands, I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell Mas\xe2\x80\x99r o\xe2\x80\x99 you,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Quimbo, who was busy at the mill, from which he had viciously\r\ndriven two or three tired women, who were waiting to grind their corn.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd, I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell him ye won\xe2\x80\x99t let the women come to the mills, yo old\r\nnigger!\xe2\x80\x9d said Sambo. \xe2\x80\x9cYo jes keep to yo own row.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom was hungry with his day\xe2\x80\x99s journey, and almost faint for want of\r\nfood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThar, yo!\xe2\x80\x9d said Quimbo, throwing down a coarse bag, which contained a\r\npeck of corn; \xe2\x80\x9cthar, nigger, grab, take car on \xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x94yo won\xe2\x80\x99t get no\r\nmore, _dis_ yer week.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom waited till a late hour, to get a place at the mills; and then,\r\nmoved by the utter weariness of two women, whom he saw trying to grind\r\ntheir corn there, he ground for them, put together the decaying brands\r\nof the fire, where many had baked cakes before them, and then went\r\nabout getting his own supper. It was a new kind of work there,\xe2\x80\x94a deed\r\nof charity, small as it was; but it woke an answering touch in their\r\nhearts,\xe2\x80\x94an expression of womanly kindness came over their hard faces;\r\nthey mixed his cake for him, and tended its baking; and Tom sat down by\r\nthe light of the fire, and drew out his Bible,\xe2\x80\x94for he had need for\r\ncomfort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s that?\xe2\x80\x9d said one of the woman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA Bible,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood Lord! han\xe2\x80\x99t seen un since I was in Kentuck.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas you raised in Kentuck?\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, with interest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and well raised, too; never \xe2\x80\x99spected to come to dis yer!\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nthe woman, sighing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s dat ar book, any way?\xe2\x80\x9d said the other woman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, the Bible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLaws a me! what\xe2\x80\x99s dat?\xe2\x80\x9d said the woman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo tell! you never hearn on \xe2\x80\x99t?\xe2\x80\x9d said the other woman. \xe2\x80\x9cI used to har\r\nMissis a readin\xe2\x80\x99 on \xe2\x80\x99t, sometimes, in Kentuck; but, laws o\xe2\x80\x99 me! we\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t har nothin\xe2\x80\x99 here but crackin\xe2\x80\x99 and swarin\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRead a piece, anyways!\xe2\x80\x9d said the first woman, curiously, seeing Tom\r\nattentively poring over it.\r\n\r\nTom read,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cCome unto Me, all ye that labor and are heavy laden, and I\r\nwill give you rest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThem\xe2\x80\x99s good words, enough,\xe2\x80\x9d said the woman; \xe2\x80\x9cwho says \xe2\x80\x99em?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Lord,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI jest wish I know\xe2\x80\x99d whar to find Him,\xe2\x80\x9d said the woman. \xe2\x80\x9cI would go;\r\n\xe2\x80\x99pears like I never should get rested again. My flesh is fairly sore,\r\nand I tremble all over, every day, and Sambo\xe2\x80\x99s allers a jawin\xe2\x80\x99 at me,\r\n\xe2\x80\x99cause I doesn\xe2\x80\x99t pick faster; and nights it\xe2\x80\x99s most midnight \xe2\x80\x99fore I can\r\nget my supper; and den \xe2\x80\x99pears like I don\xe2\x80\x99t turn over and shut my eyes,\r\n\xe2\x80\x99fore I hear de horn blow to get up, and at it agin in de mornin\xe2\x80\x99. If I\r\nknew whar de Lor was, I\xe2\x80\x99d tell him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s here, he\xe2\x80\x99s everywhere,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLor, you an\xe2\x80\x99t gwine to make me believe dat ar! I know de Lord an\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nhere,\xe2\x80\x9d said the woman; \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98tan\xe2\x80\x99t no use talking, though. I\xe2\x80\x99s jest gwine\r\nto camp down, and sleep while I ken.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe women went off to their cabins, and Tom sat alone, by the\r\nsmouldering fire, that flickered up redly in his face.\r\n\r\nThe silver, fair-browed moon rose in the purple sky, and looked down,\r\ncalm and silent, as God looks on the scene of misery and\r\noppression,\xe2\x80\x94looked calmly on the lone black man, as he sat, with his\r\narms folded, and his Bible on his knee.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs God HERE?\xe2\x80\x9d Ah, how is it possible for the untaught heart to keep\r\nits faith, unswerving, in the face of dire misrule, and palpable,\r\nunrebuked injustice? In that simple heart waged a fierce conflict; the\r\ncrushing sense of wrong, the foreshadowing, of a whole life of future\r\nmisery, the wreck of all past hopes, mournfully tossing in the soul\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsight, like dead corpses of wife, and child, and friend, rising from\r\nthe dark wave, and surging in the face of the half-drowned mariner! Ah,\r\nwas it easy _here_ to believe and hold fast the great password of\r\nChristian faith, that \xe2\x80\x9cGod IS, and is the REWARDER of them that\r\ndiligently seek Him\xe2\x80\x9d?\r\n\r\nTom rose, disconsolate, and stumbled into the cabin that had been\r\nallotted to him. The floor was already strewn with weary sleepers, and\r\nthe foul air of the place almost repelled him; but the heavy night-dews\r\nwere chill, and his limbs weary, and, wrapping about him a tattered\r\nblanket, which formed his only bed-clothing, he stretched himself in\r\nthe straw and fell asleep.\r\n\r\nIn dreams, a gentle voice came over his ear; he was sitting on the\r\nmossy seat in the garden by Lake Pontchartrain, and Eva, with her\r\nserious eyes bent downward, was reading to him from the Bible; and he\r\nheard her read.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen thou passest through the waters, I will be with thee, and the\r\nrivers they shall not overflow thee; when thou walkest through the\r\nfire, thou shalt not be burned, neither shall the flame kindle upon\r\nthee; for I am the Lord thy God, the Holy One of Israel, thy Saviour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGradually the words seemed to melt and fade, as in a divine music; the\r\nchild raised her deep eyes, and fixed them lovingly on him, and rays of\r\nwarmth and comfort seemed to go from them to his heart; and, as if\r\nwafted on the music, she seemed to rise on shining wings, from which\r\nflakes and spangles of gold fell off like stars, and she was gone.\r\n\r\nTom woke. Was it a dream? Let it pass for one. But who shall say that\r\nthat sweet young spirit, which in life so yearned to comfort and\r\nconsole the distressed, was forbidden of God to assume this ministry\r\nafter death?\r\n\r\nIt is a beautiful belief,\r\n    That ever round our head\r\nAre hovering, on angel wings,\r\n    The spirits of the dead.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXIII\r\nCassy\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd behold, the tears of such as were oppressed, and they had no\r\ncomforter; and on the side of their oppressors there was power, but\r\nthey had no comforter.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94ECCL. 4:1\r\n\r\n\r\nIt took but a short time to familiarize Tom with all that was to be\r\nhoped or feared in his new way of life. He was an expert and efficient\r\nworkman in whatever he undertook; and was, both from habit and\r\nprinciple, prompt and faithful. Quiet and peaceable in his disposition,\r\nhe hoped, by unremitting diligence, to avert from himself at least a\r\nportion of the evils of his condition. He saw enough of abuse and\r\nmisery to make him sick and weary; but he determined to toil on, with\r\nreligious patience, committing himself to Him that judgeth righteously,\r\nnot without hope that some way of escape might yet be opened to him.\r\n\r\nLegree took a silent note of Tom\xe2\x80\x99s availability. He rated him as a\r\nfirst-class hand; and yet he felt a secret dislike to him,\xe2\x80\x94the native\r\nantipathy of bad to good. He saw, plainly, that when, as was often the\r\ncase, his violence and brutality fell on the helpless, Tom took notice\r\nof it; for, so subtle is the atmosphere of opinion, that it will make\r\nitself felt, without words; and the opinion even of a slave may annoy a\r\nmaster. Tom in various ways manifested a tenderness of feeling, a\r\ncommiseration for his fellow-sufferers, strange and new to them, which\r\nwas watched with a jealous eye by Legree. He had purchased Tom with a\r\nview of eventually making him a sort of overseer, with whom he might,\r\nat times, intrust his affairs, in short absences; and, in his view, the\r\nfirst, second, and third requisite for that place, was _hardness_.\r\nLegree made up his mind, that, as Tom was not hard to his hand, he\r\nwould harden him forthwith; and some few weeks after Tom had been on\r\nthe place, he determined to commence the process.\r\n\r\nOne morning, when the hands were mustered for the field, Tom noticed,\r\nwith surprise, a new comer among them, whose appearance excited his\r\nattention. It was a woman, tall and slenderly formed, with remarkably\r\ndelicate hands and feet, and dressed in neat and respectable garments.\r\nBy the appearance of her face, she might have been between thirty-five\r\nand forty; and it was a face that, once seen, could never be\r\nforgotten,\xe2\x80\x94one of those that, at a glance, seem to convey to us an idea\r\nof a wild, painful, and romantic history. Her forehead was high, and\r\nher eyebrows marked with beautiful clearness. Her straight, well-formed\r\nnose, her finely-cut mouth, and the graceful contour of her head and\r\nneck, showed that she must once have been beautiful; but her face was\r\ndeeply wrinkled with lines of pain, and of proud and bitter endurance.\r\nHer complexion was sallow and unhealthy, her cheeks thin, her features\r\nsharp, and her whole form emaciated. But her eye was the most\r\nremarkable feature,\xe2\x80\x94so large, so heavily black, overshadowed by long\r\nlashes of equal darkness, and so wildly, mournfully despairing. There\r\nwas a fierce pride and defiance in every line of her face, in every\r\ncurve of the flexible lip, in every motion of her body; but in her eye\r\nwas a deep, settled night of anguish,\xe2\x80\x94an expression so hopeless and\r\nunchanging as to contrast fearfully with the scorn and pride expressed\r\nby her whole demeanor.\r\n\r\nWhere she came from, or who she was, Tom did not know. The first he did\r\nknow, she was walking by his side, erect and proud, in the dim gray of\r\nthe dawn. To the gang, however, she was known; for there was much\r\nlooking and turning of heads, and a smothered yet apparent exultation\r\namong the miserable, ragged, half-starved creatures by whom she was\r\nsurrounded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGot to come to it, at last,\xe2\x80\x94glad of it!\xe2\x80\x9d said one.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe! he! he!\xe2\x80\x9d said another; \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99ll know how good it is, Misse!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll see her work!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWonder if she\xe2\x80\x99ll get a cutting up, at night, like the rest of us!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d be glad to see her down for a flogging, I\xe2\x80\x99ll bound!\xe2\x80\x9d said another.\r\n\r\nThe woman took no notice of these taunts, but walked on, with the same\r\nexpression of angry scorn, as if she heard nothing. Tom had always\r\nlived among refined, and cultivated people, and he felt intuitively,\r\nfrom her air and bearing, that she belonged to that class; but how or\r\nwhy she could be fallen to those degrading circumstances, he could not\r\ntell. The women neither looked at him nor spoke to him, though, all the\r\nway to the field, she kept close at his side.\r\n\r\nTom was soon busy at his work; but, as the woman was at no great\r\ndistance from him, he often glanced an eye to her, at her work. He saw,\r\nat a glance, that a native adroitness and handiness made the task to\r\nher an easier one than it proved to many. She picked very fast and very\r\nclean, and with an air of scorn, as if she despised both the work and\r\nthe disgrace and humiliation of the circumstances in which she was\r\nplaced.\r\n\r\nIn the course of the day, Tom was working near the mulatto woman who\r\nhad been bought in the same lot with himself. She was evidently in a\r\ncondition of great suffering, and Tom often heard her praying, as she\r\nwavered and trembled, and seemed about to fall down. Tom silently as he\r\ncame near to her, transferred several handfuls of cotton from his own\r\nsack to hers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, don\xe2\x80\x99t, don\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x9d said the woman, looking surprised; \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99ll get you\r\ninto trouble.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJust then Sambo came up. He seemed to have a special spite against this\r\nwoman; and, flourishing his whip, said, in brutal, guttural tones,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat dis yer, Luce,\xe2\x80\x94foolin\xe2\x80\x99 a\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d and, with the word, kicking the woman\r\nwith his heavy cowhide shoe, he struck Tom across the face with his\r\nwhip.\r\n\r\nTom silently resumed his task; but the woman, before at the last point\r\nof exhaustion, fainted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll bring her to!\xe2\x80\x9d said the driver, with a brutal grin. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll give\r\nher something better than camphire!\xe2\x80\x9d and, taking a pin from his\r\ncoat-sleeve, he buried it to the head in her flesh. The woman groaned,\r\nand half rose. \xe2\x80\x9cGet up, you beast, and work, will yer, or I\xe2\x80\x99ll show yer\r\na trick more!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe woman seemed stimulated, for a few moments, to an unnatural\r\nstrength, and worked with desperate eagerness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee that you keep to dat ar,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man, \xe2\x80\x9cor yer\xe2\x80\x99ll wish yer\xe2\x80\x99s dead\r\ntonight, I reckin!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat I do now!\xe2\x80\x9d Tom heard her say; and again he heard her say, \xe2\x80\x9cO,\r\nLord, how long! O, Lord, why don\xe2\x80\x99t you help us?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt the risk of all that he might suffer, Tom came forward again, and\r\nput all the cotton in his sack into the woman\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, you mustn\xe2\x80\x99t! you donno what they\xe2\x80\x99ll do to ye!\xe2\x80\x9d said the woman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can bar it!\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, \xe2\x80\x9cbetter \xe2\x80\x99n you;\xe2\x80\x9d and he was at his place\r\nagain. It passed in a moment.\r\n\r\nSuddenly, the stranger woman whom we have described, and who had, in\r\nthe course of her work, come near enough to hear Tom\xe2\x80\x99s last words,\r\nraised her heavy black eyes, and fixed them, for a second, on him;\r\nthen, taking a quantity of cotton from her basket, she placed it in\r\nhis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know nothing about this place,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cor you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have\r\ndone that. When you\xe2\x80\x99ve been here a month, you\xe2\x80\x99ll be done helping\r\nanybody; you\xe2\x80\x99ll find it hard enough to take care of your own skin!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Lord forbid, Missis!\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, using instinctively to his field\r\ncompanion the respectful form proper to the high bred with whom he had\r\nlived.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Lord never visits these parts,\xe2\x80\x9d said the woman, bitterly, as she\r\nwent nimbly forward with her work; and again the scornful smile curled\r\nher lips.\r\n\r\nBut the action of the woman had been seen by the driver, across the\r\nfield; and, flourishing his whip, he came up to her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! what!\xe2\x80\x9d he said to the woman, with an air of triumph, \xe2\x80\x9cYou a\r\nfoolin\xe2\x80\x99? Go along! yer under me now,\xe2\x80\x94mind yourself, or yer\xe2\x80\x99ll cotch\r\nit!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA glance like sheet-lightning suddenly flashed from those black eyes;\r\nand, facing about, with quivering lip and dilated nostrils, she drew\r\nherself up, and fixed a glance, blazing with rage and scorn, on the\r\ndriver.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDog!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9ctouch _me_, if you dare! I\xe2\x80\x99ve power enough, yet, to\r\nhave you torn by the dogs, burnt alive, cut to inches! I\xe2\x80\x99ve only to say\r\nthe word!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat de devil you here for, den?\xe2\x80\x9d said the man, evidently cowed, and\r\nsullenly retreating a step or two. \xe2\x80\x9cDidn\xe2\x80\x99t mean no harm, Misse Cassy!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKeep your distance, then!\xe2\x80\x9d said the woman. And, in truth, the man\r\nseemed greatly inclined to attend to something at the other end of the\r\nfield, and started off in quick time.\r\n\r\nThe woman suddenly turned to her work, and labored with a despatch that\r\nwas perfectly astonishing to Tom. She seemed to work by magic. Before\r\nthe day was through, her basket was filled, crowded down, and piled,\r\nand she had several times put largely into Tom\xe2\x80\x99s. Long after dusk, the\r\nwhole weary train, with their baskets on their heads, defiled up to the\r\nbuilding appropriated to the storing and weighing the cotton. Legree\r\nwas there, busily conversing with the two drivers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDat ar Tom\xe2\x80\x99s gwine to make a powerful deal o\xe2\x80\x99 trouble; kept a puttin\xe2\x80\x99\r\ninto Lucy\xe2\x80\x99s basket.\xe2\x80\x94One o\xe2\x80\x99 these yer dat will get all der niggers to\r\nfeelin\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x99bused, if Masir don\xe2\x80\x99t watch him!\xe2\x80\x9d said Sambo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHey-dey! The black cuss!\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99ll have to get a breakin\xe2\x80\x99\r\nin, won\xe2\x80\x99t he, boys?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBoth negroes grinned a horrid grin, at this intimation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, ay! Let Mas\xe2\x80\x99r Legree alone, for breakin\xe2\x80\x99 in! De debil heself\r\ncouldn\xe2\x80\x99t beat Mas\xe2\x80\x99r at dat!\xe2\x80\x9d said Quimbo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWal, boys, the best way is to give him the flogging to do, till he\r\ngets over his notions. Break him in!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLord, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r\xe2\x80\x99ll have hard work to get dat out o\xe2\x80\x99 him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99ll have to come out of him, though!\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, as he rolled his\r\ntobacco in his mouth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, dar\xe2\x80\x99s Lucy,\xe2\x80\x94de aggravatinest, ugliest wench on de place!\xe2\x80\x9d pursued\r\nSambo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake care, Sam; I shall begin to think what\xe2\x80\x99s the reason for your\r\nspite agin Lucy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r knows she sot herself up agin Mas\xe2\x80\x99r, and wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have me,\r\nwhen he telled her to.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d a flogged her into \xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, spitting, \xe2\x80\x9conly there\xe2\x80\x99s such\r\na press o\xe2\x80\x99 work, it don\xe2\x80\x99t seem wuth a while to upset her jist now.\r\nShe\xe2\x80\x99s slender; but these yer slender gals will bear half killin\xe2\x80\x99 to get\r\ntheir own way!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWal, Lucy was real aggravatin\xe2\x80\x99 and lazy, sulkin\xe2\x80\x99 round; wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t do\r\nnothin,\xe2\x80\x94and Tom he stuck up for her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe did, eh! Wal, then, Tom shall have the pleasure of flogging her.\r\nIt\xe2\x80\x99ll be a good practice for him, and he won\xe2\x80\x99t put it on to the gal\r\nlike you devils, neither.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHo, ho! haw! haw! haw!\xe2\x80\x9d laughed both the sooty wretches; and the\r\ndiabolical sounds seemed, in truth, a not unapt expression of the\r\nfiendish character which Legree gave them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWal, but, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r, Tom and Misse Cassy, and dey among \xe2\x80\x99em, filled Lucy\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbasket. I ruther guess der weight \xe2\x80\x99s in it, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_I do the weighing!_\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, emphatically.\r\n\r\nBoth the drivers again laughed their diabolical laugh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo!\xe2\x80\x9d he added, \xe2\x80\x9cMisse Cassy did her day\xe2\x80\x99s work.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe picks like de debil and all his angels!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s got \xe2\x80\x99em all in her, I believe!\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree; and, growling a\r\nbrutal oath, he proceeded to the weighing-room.\r\n\r\n\r\nSlowly the weary, dispirited creatures, wound their way into the room,\r\nand, with crouching reluctance, presented their baskets to be weighed.\r\n\r\nLegree noted on a slate, on the side of which was pasted a list of\r\nnames, the amount.\r\n\r\nTom\xe2\x80\x99s basket was weighed and approved; and he looked, with an anxious\r\nglance, for the success of the woman he had befriended.\r\n\r\nTottering with weakness, she came forward, and delivered her basket. It\r\nwas of full weight, as Legree well perceived; but, affecting anger, he\r\nsaid,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, you lazy beast! short again! stand aside, you\xe2\x80\x99ll catch it,\r\npretty soon!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe woman gave a groan of utter despair, and sat down on a board.\r\n\r\nThe person who had been called Misse Cassy now came forward, and, with\r\na haughty, negligent air, delivered her basket. As she delivered it,\r\nLegree looked in her eyes with a sneering yet inquiring glance.\r\n\r\nShe fixed her black eyes steadily on him, her lips moved slightly, and\r\nshe said something in French. What it was, no one knew; but Legree\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nface became perfectly demoniacal in its expression, as she spoke; he\r\nhalf raised his hand, as if to strike,\xe2\x80\x94a gesture which she regarded\r\nwith fierce disdain, as she turned and walked away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, \xe2\x80\x9ccome here, you Tom. You see, I telled ye I\r\ndidn\xe2\x80\x99t buy ye jest for the common work; I mean to promote ye, and make\r\na driver of ye; and tonight ye may jest as well begin to get yer hand\r\nin. Now, ye jest take this yer gal and flog her; ye\xe2\x80\x99ve seen enough on\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nto know how.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg Mas\xe2\x80\x99r\xe2\x80\x99s pardon,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom; \xe2\x80\x9chopes Mas\xe2\x80\x99r won\xe2\x80\x99t set me at that.\r\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s what I an\xe2\x80\x99t used to,\xe2\x80\x94never did,\xe2\x80\x94and can\xe2\x80\x99t do, no way possible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYe\xe2\x80\x99ll larn a pretty smart chance of things ye never did know, before\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ve done with ye!\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, taking up a cowhide, and striking Tom\r\na heavy blow cross the cheek, and following up the infliction by a\r\nshower of blows.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, as he stopped to rest; \xe2\x80\x9cnow, will ye tell me ye can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ndo it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, putting up his hand, to wipe the blood, that\r\ntrickled down his face. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m willin\xe2\x80\x99 to work, night and day, and work\r\nwhile there\xe2\x80\x99s life and breath in me; but this yer thing I can\xe2\x80\x99t feel it\r\nright to do;\xe2\x80\x94and, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r, I _never_ shall do it,\xe2\x80\x94_never_!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom had a remarkably smooth, soft voice, and a habitually respectful\r\nmanner, that had given Legree an idea that he would be cowardly, and\r\neasily subdued. When he spoke these last words, a thrill of amazement\r\nwent through every one; the poor woman clasped her hands, and said, \xe2\x80\x9cO\r\nLord!\xe2\x80\x9d and every one involuntarily looked at each other and drew in\r\ntheir breath, as if to prepare for the storm that was about to burst.\r\n\r\nLegree looked stupefied and confounded; but at last burst forth,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cWhat!\r\nye blasted black beast! tell _me_ ye don\xe2\x80\x99t think it _right_ to do what\r\nI tell ye! What have any of you cussed cattle to do with thinking\r\nwhat\xe2\x80\x99s right? I\xe2\x80\x99ll put a stop to it! Why, what do ye think ye are? May\r\nbe ye think ye\xe2\x80\x99r a gentleman master, Tom, to be a telling your master\r\nwhat\xe2\x80\x99s right, and what ain\xe2\x80\x99t! So you pretend it\xe2\x80\x99s wrong to flog the\r\ngal!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think so, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom; \xe2\x80\x9cthe poor crittur\xe2\x80\x99s sick and feeble; \xe2\x80\x99t\r\nwould be downright cruel, and it\xe2\x80\x99s what I never will do, nor begin to.\r\nMas\xe2\x80\x99r, if you mean to kill me, kill me; but, as to my raising my hand\r\nagin any one here, I never shall,\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99ll die first!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom spoke in a mild voice, but with a decision that could not be\r\nmistaken. Legree shook with anger; his greenish eyes glared fiercely,\r\nand his very whiskers seemed to curl with passion; but, like some\r\nferocious beast, that plays with its victim before he devours it, he\r\nkept back his strong impulse to proceed to immediate violence, and\r\nbroke out into bitter raillery.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, here\xe2\x80\x99s a pious dog, at last, let down among us sinners!\xe2\x80\x94a saint,\r\na gentleman, and no less, to talk to us sinners about our sins!\r\nPowerful holy critter, he must be! Here, you rascal, you make believe\r\nto be so pious,\xe2\x80\x94didn\xe2\x80\x99t you never hear, out of yer Bible, \xe2\x80\x99Servants,\r\nobey yer masters\xe2\x80\x99? An\xe2\x80\x99t I yer master? Didn\xe2\x80\x99t I pay down twelve hundred\r\ndollars, cash, for all there is inside yer old cussed black shell? An\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nyer mine, now, body and soul?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, giving Tom a violent kick with\r\nhis heavy boot; \xe2\x80\x9ctell me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn the very depth of physical suffering, bowed by brutal oppression,\r\nthis question shot a gleam of joy and triumph through Tom\xe2\x80\x99s soul. He\r\nsuddenly stretched himself up, and, looking earnestly to heaven, while\r\nthe tears and blood that flowed down his face mingled, he exclaimed,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo! no! no! my soul an\xe2\x80\x99t yours, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r! The poor woman screamed with apprehension, and\r\nall rose, as by a general impulse, while they dragged him unresisting\r\nfrom the place.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXIV\r\nThe Quadroon\xe2\x80\x99s Story\r\n\r\n\r\nAnd behold the tears of such as are oppressed; and on the side of their\r\noppressors there was power. Wherefore I praised the dead that are\r\nalready dead more than the living that are yet alive.\xe2\x80\x94ECCL. 4:1.\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was late at night, and Tom lay groaning and bleeding alone, in an\r\nold forsaken room of the gin-house, among pieces of broken machinery,\r\npiles of damaged cotton, and other rubbish which had there accumulated.\r\n\r\nThe night was damp and close, and the thick air swarmed with myriads of\r\nmosquitos, which increased the restless torture of his wounds; whilst a\r\nburning thirst\xe2\x80\x94a torture beyond all others\xe2\x80\x94filled up the uttermost\r\nmeasure of physical anguish.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, good Lord! _Do_ look down,\xe2\x80\x94give me the victory!\xe2\x80\x94give me the victory\r\nover all!\xe2\x80\x9d prayed poor Tom, in his anguish.\r\n\r\nA footstep entered the room, behind him, and the light of a lantern\r\nflashed on his eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho\xe2\x80\x99s there? Another and\r\nanother cup were drained, with feverish eagerness.\r\n\r\n\r\n[Illustration: CASSY MINISTERING TO UNCLE TOM AFTER HIS WHIPPING.]\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDrink all ye want,\xe2\x80\x9d she said; \xe2\x80\x9cI knew how it would be. I\xe2\x80\x99m a miserable slave, like yourself,\xe2\x80\x94a lower\r\none than you can ever be!\xe2\x80\x9d said she, bitterly; \xe2\x80\x9cbut now,\xe2\x80\x9d said she,\r\ngoing to the door, and dragging in a small pallaise, over which she had\r\nspread linen cloths wet with cold water, \xe2\x80\x9ctry, my poor fellow, to roll\r\nyourself on to this.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nStiff with wounds and bruises, Tom was a long time in accomplishing\r\nthis movement; but, when done, he felt a sensible relief from the\r\ncooling application to his wounds.\r\n\r\nThe woman, whom long practice with the victims of brutality had made\r\nfamiliar with many healing arts, went on to make many applications to\r\nTom\xe2\x80\x99s wounds, by means of which he was soon somewhat relieved.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said the woman, when she had raised his head on a roll of\r\ndamaged cotton, which served for a pillow, \xe2\x80\x9cthere\xe2\x80\x99s the best I can do\r\nfor you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom thanked her; and the woman, sitting down on the floor, drew up her\r\nknees, and embracing them with her arms, looked fixedly before her,\r\nwith a bitter and painful expression of countenance. Her bonnet fell\r\nback, and long wavy streams of black hair fell around her singular and\r\nmelancholy-face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s no use, my poor fellow!\xe2\x80\x9d she broke out, at last, \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s of no use,\r\nthis you\xe2\x80\x99ve been trying to do. Well, I was brought up in luxury; the first I remember is, playing\r\nabout, when I was a child, in splendid parlors,\xe2\x80\x94when I was kept dressed\r\nup like a doll, and company and visitors used to praise me. There was a\r\ngarden opening from the saloon windows; and there I used to play\r\nhide-and-go-seek, under the orange-trees, with my brothers and sisters.\r\nI went to a convent, and there I learned music, French and embroidery,\r\nand what not; and when I was fourteen, I came out to my father\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfuneral. He died very suddenly, and when the property came to be\r\nsettled, they found that there was scarcely enough to cover the debts;\r\nand when the creditors took an inventory of the property, I was set\r\ndown in it. My mother was a slave woman, and my father had always meant\r\nto set me free; but he had not done it, and so I was set down in the\r\nlist. I\xe2\x80\x99d always known who I was, but never thought much about it.\r\nNobody ever expects that a strong, healthy man is going to die. My\r\nfather was a well man only four hours before he died;\xe2\x80\x94it was one of the\r\nfirst cholera cases in New Orleans. The day after the funeral, my\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s wife took her children, and went up to her father\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nplantation. I thought they treated me strangely, but didn\xe2\x80\x99t know. There\r\nwas a young lawyer who they left to settle the business; and he came\r\nevery day, and was about the house, and spoke very politely to me. He\r\nbrought with him, one day, a young man, whom I thought the handsomest I\r\nhad ever seen. I shall never forget that evening. I walked with him in\r\nthe garden. I was lonesome and full of sorrow, and he was so kind and\r\ngentle to me; and he told me that he had seen me before I went to the\r\nconvent, and that he had loved me a great while, and that he would be\r\nmy friend and protector;\xe2\x80\x94in short, though he didn\xe2\x80\x99t tell me, he had\r\npaid two thousand dollars for me, and I was his property,\xe2\x80\x94I became his\r\nwillingly, for I loved him. Loved!\xe2\x80\x9d said the woman, stopping. \xe2\x80\x9cO, how I\r\n_did_ love that man! How I love him now,\xe2\x80\x94and always shall, while I\r\nbreathe! He was so beautiful, so high, so noble! He put me into a\r\nbeautiful house, with servants, horses, and carriages, and furniture,\r\nand dresses. Everything that money could buy, he gave me; but I didn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nset any value on all that,\xe2\x80\x94I only cared for him. I loved him better\r\nthan my God and my own soul, and, if I tried, I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t do any other\r\nway from what he wanted me to.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wanted only one thing\xe2\x80\x94I did want him to _marry_ me. But he convinced me\r\nthat it would be impossible; and he told me that, if we were only\r\nfaithful to each other, it was marriage before God. If that is true,\r\nwasn\xe2\x80\x99t I that man\xe2\x80\x99s wife? Wasn\xe2\x80\x99t I faithful? For seven years, didn\xe2\x80\x99t I\r\nstudy every look and motion, and only live and breathe to please him?\r\nHe had the yellow fever, and for twenty days and nights I watched with\r\nhim. I alone,\xe2\x80\x94and gave him all his medicine, and did everything for\r\nhim; and then he called me his good angel, and said I\xe2\x80\x99d saved his life.\r\nWe had two beautiful children. The first was a boy, and we called him\r\nHenry. He was the image of his father,\xe2\x80\x94he had such beautiful eyes, such\r\na forehead, and his hair hung all in curls around it; and he had all\r\nhis father\xe2\x80\x99s spirit, and his talent, too. He used to love to\r\nhave me dress them up, and take them and me about in an open carriage,\r\nand hear the remarks that people would make on us; and he used to fill\r\nmy ears constantly with the fine things that were said in praise of me\r\nand the children. O, those were happy days! I thought I was as happy as\r\nany one could be; but then there came evil times. He had a cousin come\r\nto New Orleans, who was his particular friend,\xe2\x80\x94he thought all the world\r\nof him;\xe2\x80\x94but, from the first time I saw him, I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t tell why, I\r\ndreaded him; for I felt sure he was going to bring misery on us. He never told me, but I saw it,\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nknew it, day after day,\xe2\x80\x94I felt my heart breaking, but I could not say a\r\nword! At this, the wretch offered to buy me and the children of Henry,\r\nto clear off his gambling debts, which stood in the way of his marrying\r\nas he wished;\xe2\x80\x94and _he sold us_. He told me, one day, that he had\r\nbusiness in the country, and should be gone two or three weeks. He\r\nspoke kinder than usual, and said he should come back; but it didn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ndeceive me. I knew that the time had come; I was just like one turned\r\ninto stone; I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t speak, nor shed a tear. He kissed me and kissed\r\nthe children, a good many times, and went out. I saw him get on his\r\nhorse, and I watched him till he was quite out of sight; and then I\r\nfell down, and fainted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen _he_ came, the cursed wretch! he came to take possession. He told\r\nme that he had bought me and my children; and showed me the papers. I\r\ncursed him before God, and told him I\xe2\x80\x99d die sooner than live with him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Just as you please,\xe2\x80\x99 said he; \xe2\x80\x98but, if you don\xe2\x80\x99t behave reasonably,\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll sell both the children, where you shall never see them again.\xe2\x80\x99 He\r\ntold me that he always had meant to have me, from the first time he saw\r\nme; and that he had drawn Henry on, and got him in debt, on purpose to\r\nmake him willing to sell me. That he got him in love with another\r\nwoman; and that I might know, after all that, that he should not give\r\nup for a few airs and tears, and things of that sort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI gave up, for my hands were tied. He had my children;\xe2\x80\x94whenever I\r\nresisted his will anywhere, he would talk about selling them, and he\r\nmade me as submissive as he desired. O, what a life it was! to live\r\nwith my heart breaking, every day,\xe2\x80\x94to keep on, on, on, loving, when it\r\nwas only misery; and to be bound, body and soul, to one I hated. I used\r\nto love to read to Henry, to play to him, to waltz with him, and sing\r\nto him; but everything I did for this one was a perfect drag,\xe2\x80\x94yet I was\r\nafraid to refuse anything. He was very imperious, and harsh to the\r\nchildren. Elise was a timid little thing; but Henry was bold and\r\nhigh-spirited, like his father, and he had never been brought under, in\r\nthe least, by any one. He was always finding fault, and quarrelling\r\nwith him; and I used to live in daily fear and dread. I tried to make\r\nthe child respectful;\xe2\x80\x94I tried to keep them apart, for I held on to\r\nthose children like death; but it did no good. _He sold both those\r\nchildren_. He took me to ride, one day, and when I came home, they were\r\nnowhere to be found! He told me he had sold them; he showed me the\r\nmoney, the price of their blood. Then it seemed as if all good forsook\r\nme. I raved and cursed,\xe2\x80\x94cursed God and man; and, for a while, I\r\nbelieve, he really was afraid of me. But he didn\xe2\x80\x99t give up so. He told\r\nme that my children were sold, but whether I ever saw their faces\r\nagain, depended on him; and that, if I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t quiet, they should smart\r\nfor it. Well, you can do anything with a woman, when you\xe2\x80\x99ve got her\r\nchildren. He made me submit; he made me be peaceable; he flattered me\r\nwith hopes that, perhaps, he would buy them back; and so things went\r\non, a week or two. One day, I was out walking, and passed by the\r\ncalaboose; I saw a crowd about the gate, and heard a child\xe2\x80\x99s voice,\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nsuddenly my Henry broke away from two or three men who were holding\r\nhim, and ran, screaming, and caught my dress. They came up to him,\r\nswearing dreadfully; and one man, whose face I shall never forget, told\r\nhim that he wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t get away so; that he was going with him into the\r\ncalaboose, and he\xe2\x80\x99d get a lesson there he\xe2\x80\x99d never forget. I tried to\r\nbeg and plead,\xe2\x80\x94they only laughed; the poor boy screamed and looked into\r\nmy face, and held on to me, until, in tearing him off, they tore the\r\nskirt of my dress half away; and they carried him in, screaming\r\n\xe2\x80\x99Mother! mother! mother!\xe2\x80\x99 There was one man stood there seemed to pity\r\nme. I offered him all the money I had, if he\xe2\x80\x99d only interfere. He shook\r\nhis head, and said that the boy had been impudent and disobedient, ever\r\nsince he bought him; that he was going to break him in, once for all. I\r\nturned and ran; and every step of the way, I thought that I heard him\r\nscream. I got into the house; ran, all out of breath, to the parlor,\r\nwhere I found Butler. I told him, and begged him to go and interfere.\r\nHe only laughed, and told me the boy had got his deserts. He\xe2\x80\x99d got to\r\nbe broken in,\xe2\x80\x94the sooner the better; \xe2\x80\x99what did I expect?\xe2\x80\x99 he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt seemed to me something in my head snapped, at that moment. I felt\r\ndizzy and furious. I remember seeing a great sharp bowie-knife on the\r\ntable; I remember something about catching it, and flying upon him; and\r\nthen all grew dark, and I didn\xe2\x80\x99t know any more,\xe2\x80\x94not for days and days.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen I came to myself, I was in a nice room,\xe2\x80\x94but not mine. An old\r\nblack woman tended me; and a doctor came to see me, and there was a\r\ngreat deal of care taken of me. After a while, I found that he had gone\r\naway, and left me at this house to be sold; and that\xe2\x80\x99s why they took\r\nsuch pains with me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t mean to get well, and hoped I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t; but, in spite of me\r\nthe fever went off and I grew healthy, and finally got up. Then, they\r\nmade me dress up, every day; and gentlemen used to come in and stand\r\nand smoke their cigars, and look at me, and ask questions, and debate\r\nmy price. I was so gloomy and silent, that none of them wanted me. They\r\nthreatened to whip me, if I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t gayer, and didn\xe2\x80\x99t take some pains to\r\nmake myself agreeable. At length, one day, came a gentleman named\r\nStuart. He seemed to have some feeling for me; he saw that something\r\ndreadful was on my heart, and he came to see me alone, a great many\r\ntimes, and finally persuaded me to tell him. He bought me, at last, and\r\npromised to do all he could to find and buy back my children. He went\r\nto the hotel where my Henry was; they told him he had been sold to a\r\nplanter up on Pearl River; that was the last that I ever heard. Then he\r\nfound where my daughter was; an old woman was keeping her. He offered\r\nan immense sum for her, but they would not sell her. Butler found out\r\nthat it was for me he wanted her; and he sent me word that I should\r\nnever have her. Captain Stuart was very kind to me; he had a splendid\r\nplantation, and took me to it. In the course of a year, I had a son\r\nborn. O, that child!\xe2\x80\x94how I loved it! How just like my poor Henry the\r\nlittle thing looked! But I had made up my mind,\xe2\x80\x94yes, I had. I would\r\nnever again let a child live to grow up! I took the little fellow in my\r\narms, when he was two weeks old, and kissed him, and cried over him;\r\nand then I gave him laudanum, and held him close to my bosom, while he\r\nslept to death. How I mourned and cried over it! and who ever dreamed\r\nthat it was anything but a mistake, that had made me give it the\r\nlaudanum? but it\xe2\x80\x99s one of the few things that I\xe2\x80\x99m glad of, now. I am\r\nnot sorry, to this day; he, at least, is out of pain. What better than\r\ndeath could I give him, poor child! After a while, the cholera came,\r\nand Captain Stuart died; everybody died that wanted to live,\xe2\x80\x94and I,\xe2\x80\x94I,\r\nthough I went down to death\xe2\x80\x99s door,\xe2\x80\x94_I lived!_ Then I was sold, and\r\npassed from hand to hand, till I grew faded and wrinkled, and I had a\r\nfever; and then this wretch bought me, and brought me here,\xe2\x80\x94and here I\r\nam!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe woman stopped. She had hurried on through her story, with a wild,\r\npassionate utterance; sometimes seeming to address it to Tom, and\r\nsometimes speaking as in a soliloquy. So vehement and overpowering was\r\nthe force with which she spoke, that, for a season, Tom was beguiled\r\neven from the pain of his wounds, and, raising himself on one elbow,\r\nwatched her as she paced restlessly up and down, her long black hair\r\nswaying heavily about her, as she moved.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou tell me,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, after a pause, \xe2\x80\x9cthat there is a God,\xe2\x80\x94a God\r\nthat looks down and sees all these things. May be it\xe2\x80\x99s so. The sisters\r\nin the convent used to tell me of a day of judgment, when everything is\r\ncoming to light;\xe2\x80\x94won\xe2\x80\x99t there be vengeance, then!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey think it\xe2\x80\x99s nothing, what we suffer,\xe2\x80\x94nothing, what our children\r\nsuffer! It\xe2\x80\x99s all a small matter; yet I\xe2\x80\x99ve walked the streets when it\r\nseemed as if I had misery enough in my one heart to sink the city. I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nwished the houses would fall on me, or the stones sink under me. Yes!\r\nand, in the judgment day, I will stand up before God, a witness against\r\nthose that have ruined me and my children, body and soul!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen I was a girl, I thought I was religious; I used to love God and\r\nprayer. Now, I\xe2\x80\x99m a lost soul, pursued by devils that torment me day and\r\nnight; they keep pushing me on and on\xe2\x80\x94and I\xe2\x80\x99ll do it, too, some of\r\nthese days!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, clenching her hand, while an insane light\r\nglanced in her heavy black eyes. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll send him where he belongs,\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nshort way, too,\xe2\x80\x94one of these nights, if they burn me alive for it!\xe2\x80\x9d A\r\nwild, long laugh rang through the deserted room, and ended in a\r\nhysteric sob; she threw herself on the floor, in convulsive sobbing and\r\nstruggles.\r\n\r\nIn a few moments, the frenzy fit seemed to pass off; she rose slowly,\r\nand seemed to collect herself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan I do anything more for you, my poor fellow?\xe2\x80\x9d she said, approaching\r\nwhere Tom lay; \xe2\x80\x9cshall I give you some more water?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was a graceful and compassionate sweetness in her voice and\r\nmanner, as she said this, that formed a strange contrast with the\r\nformer wildness.\r\n\r\nTom drank the water, and looked earnestly and pitifully into her face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Missis, I wish you\xe2\x80\x99d go to him that can give you living waters!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo to him! Where is he? Who is he?\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHim that you read of to me,\xe2\x80\x94the Lord.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI used to see the picture of him, over the altar, when I was a girl,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Cassy, her dark eyes fixing themselves in an expression of\r\nmournful reverie; \xe2\x80\x9cbut, _he isn\xe2\x80\x99t here!_ there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing here, but sin\r\nand long, long, long despair! O!\xe2\x80\x9d She laid her hand on her breast and\r\ndrew in her breath, as if to lift a heavy weight.\r\n\r\nTom looked as if he would speak again; but she cut him short, with a\r\ndecided gesture.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t talk, my poor fellow. Try to sleep, if you can.\xe2\x80\x9d And, placing\r\nwater in his reach, and making whatever little arrangements for his\r\ncomforts she could, Cassy left the shed.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXV\r\nThe Tokens\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd slight, withal, may be the things that bring\r\nBack on the heart the weight which it would fling\r\nAside forever; it may be a sound,\r\nA flower, the wind, the ocean, which shall wound,\xe2\x80\x94\r\nStriking the electric chain wherewith we\xe2\x80\x99re darkly bound.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n_Childe Harold\xe2\x80\x99s Pilgrimage, Can_. 4.\r\n\r\n\r\nThe sitting-room of Legree\xe2\x80\x99s establishment was a large, long room, with\r\na wide, ample fireplace. It had once been hung with a showy and\r\nexpensive paper, which now hung mouldering, torn and discolored, from\r\nthe damp walls. The place had that peculiar sickening, unwholesome\r\nsmell, compounded of mingled damp, dirt and decay, which one often\r\nnotices in close old houses. The wall-paper was defaced, in spots, by\r\nslops of beer and wine; or garnished with chalk memorandums, and long\r\nsums footed up, as if somebody had been practising arithmetic there. In\r\nthe fireplace stood a brazier full of burning charcoal; for, though the\r\nweather was not cold, the evenings always seemed damp and chilly in\r\nthat great room; and Legree, moreover, wanted a place to light his\r\ncigars, and heat his water for punch. The ruddy glare of the charcoal\r\ndisplayed the confused and unpromising aspect of the room,\xe2\x80\x94saddles,\r\nbridles, several sorts of harness, riding-whips, overcoats, and various\r\narticles of clothing, scattered up and down the room in confused\r\nvariety; and the dogs, of whom we have before spoken, had encamped\r\nthemselves among them, to suit their own taste and convenience.\r\n\r\nLegree was just mixing himself a tumbler of punch, pouring his hot\r\nwater from a cracked and broken-nosed pitcher, grumbling, as he did so,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlague on that Sambo, to kick up this yer row between me and the new\r\nhands! The fellow won\xe2\x80\x99t be fit to work for a week, now,\xe2\x80\x94right in the\r\npress of the season!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, just like you,\xe2\x80\x9d said a voice, behind his chair. It was the woman\r\nCassy, who had stolen upon his soliloquy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHah! you she-devil! you\xe2\x80\x99ve come back, have you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I have,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, coolly; \xe2\x80\x9ccome to have my own way, too!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou lie, you jade! I\xe2\x80\x99ll be up to my word. Either behave yourself, or\r\nstay down to the quarters, and fare and work with the rest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d rather, ten thousand times,\xe2\x80\x9d said the woman, \xe2\x80\x9clive in the dirtiest\r\nhole at the quarters, than be under your hoof!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you _are_ under my hoof, for all that,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, turning upon her,\r\nwith a savage grin; \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s one comfort. So, sit down here on my knee,\r\nmy dear, and hear to reason,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, laying hold on her wrist.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSimon Legree, take care!\xe2\x80\x9d said the woman, with a sharp flash of her\r\neye, a glance so wild and insane in its light as to be almost\r\nappalling. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re afraid of me, Simon,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, deliberately; \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99ve reason to be! But be careful, for I\xe2\x80\x99ve got the devil in me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe last words she whispered in a hissing tone, close to his ear.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGet out! I believe, to my soul, you have!\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, pushing her\r\nfrom him, and looking uncomfortably at her. \xe2\x80\x9cAfter all, Cassy,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nsaid, \xe2\x80\x9cwhy can\xe2\x80\x99t you be friends with me, as you used to?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUsed to!\xe2\x80\x9d said she, bitterly. She stopped short,\xe2\x80\x94a word of choking\r\nfeelings, rising in her heart, kept her silent.\r\n\r\nCassy had always kept over Legree the kind of influence that a strong,\r\nimpassioned woman can ever keep over the most brutal man; but, of late,\r\nshe had grown more and more irritable and restless, under the hideous\r\nyoke of her servitude, and her irritability, at times, broke out into\r\nraving insanity; and this liability made her a sort of object of dread\r\nto Legree, who had that superstitious horror of insane persons which is\r\ncommon to coarse and uninstructed minds. When Legree brought Emmeline\r\nto the house, all the smouldering embers of womanly feeling flashed up\r\nin the worn heart of Cassy, and she took part with the girl; and a\r\nfierce quarrel ensued between her and Legree. Legree, in a fury, swore\r\nshe should be put to field service, if she would not be peaceable.\r\nCassy, with proud scorn, declared she _would_ go to the field. And she\r\nworked there one day, as we have described, to show how perfectly she\r\nscorned the threat.\r\n\r\nLegree was secretly uneasy, all day; for Cassy had an influence over\r\nhim from which he could not free himself. When she presented her basket\r\nat the scales, he had hoped for some concession, and addressed her in a\r\nsort of half conciliatory, half scornful tone; and she had answered\r\nwith the bitterest contempt.\r\n\r\nThe outrageous treatment of poor Tom had roused her still more; and she\r\nhad followed Legree to the house, with no particular intention, but to\r\nupbraid him for his brutality.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish, Cassy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99d behave yourself decently.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_You_ talk about behaving decently! And what have you been doing?\xe2\x80\x94you,\r\nwho haven\xe2\x80\x99t even sense enough to keep from spoiling one of your best\r\nhands, right in the most pressing season, just for your devilish\r\ntemper!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was a fool, it\xe2\x80\x99s a fact, to let any such brangle come up,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nLegree; \xe2\x80\x9cbut, when the boy set up his will, he had to be broke in.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI reckon you won\xe2\x80\x99t break _him_ in!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWon\xe2\x80\x99t I?\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, rising, passionately. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d like to know if I\r\nwon\xe2\x80\x99t? He\xe2\x80\x99ll be the first nigger that ever came it round me! I\xe2\x80\x99ll break\r\nevery bone in his body, but he _shall_ give up!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJust then the door opened, and Sambo entered. He came forward, bowing,\r\nand holding out something in a paper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s that, you dog?\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a witch thing, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA what?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSomething that niggers gets from witches. Keeps \xe2\x80\x99em from feelin\xe2\x80\x99 when\r\nthey \xe2\x80\x99s flogged. He had it tied round his neck, with a black string.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLegree, like most godless and cruel men, was superstitious. He took the\r\npaper, and opened it uneasily.\r\n\r\nThere dropped out of it a silver dollar, and a long, shining curl of\r\nfair hair,\xe2\x80\x94hair which, like a living thing, twined itself round\r\nLegree\xe2\x80\x99s fingers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDamnation!\xe2\x80\x9d he screamed, in sudden passion, stamping on the floor, and\r\npulling furiously at the hair, as if it burned him. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere did this\r\ncome from? Take it off!\xe2\x80\x94burn it up!\xe2\x80\x94burn it up!\xe2\x80\x9d he screamed, tearing\r\nit off, and throwing it into the charcoal. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat did you bring it to me\r\nfor?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSambo stood, with his heavy mouth wide open, and aghast with wonder;\r\nand Cassy, who was preparing to leave the apartment, stopped, and\r\nlooked at him in perfect amazement.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you bring me any more of your devilish things!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, shaking\r\nhis fist at Sambo, who retreated hastily towards the door; and, picking\r\nup the silver dollar, he sent it smashing through the window-pane, out\r\ninto the darkness.\r\n\r\nSambo was glad to make his escape. When he was gone, Legree seemed a\r\nlittle ashamed of his fit of alarm. He sat doggedly down in his chair,\r\nand began sullenly sipping his tumbler of punch.\r\n\r\nCassy prepared herself for going out, unobserved by him; and slipped\r\naway to minister to poor Tom, as we have already related.\r\n\r\nAnd what was the matter with Legree? and what was there in a simple\r\ncurl of fair hair to appall that brutal man, familiar with every form\r\nof cruelty? To answer this, we must carry the reader backward in his\r\nhistory. Hard and reprobate as the godless man seemed now, there had\r\nbeen a time when he had been rocked on the bosom of a mother,\xe2\x80\x94cradled\r\nwith prayers and pious hymns,\xe2\x80\x94his now seared brow bedewed with the\r\nwaters of holy baptism. In early childhood, a fair-haired woman had led\r\nhim, at the sound of Sabbath bell, to worship and to pray. Far in New\r\nEngland that mother had trained her only son, with long, unwearied\r\nlove, and patient prayers. Born of a hard-tempered sire, on whom that\r\ngentle woman had wasted a world of unvalued love, Legree had followed\r\nin the steps of his father. Boisterous, unruly, and tyrannical, he\r\ndespised all her counsel, and would none of her reproof; and, at an\r\nearly age, broke from her, to seek his fortunes at sea. He never came\r\nhome but once, after; and then, his mother, with the yearning of a\r\nheart that must love something, and has nothing else to love, clung to\r\nhim, and sought, with passionate prayers and entreaties, to win him\r\nfrom a life of sin, to his soul\xe2\x80\x99s eternal good.\r\n\r\nThat was Legree\xe2\x80\x99s day of grace; then good angels called him; then he\r\nwas almost persuaded, and mercy held him by the hand. His heart inly\r\nrelented,\xe2\x80\x94there was a conflict,\xe2\x80\x94but sin got the victory, and he set all\r\nthe force of his rough nature against the conviction of his conscience.\r\nHe drank and swore,\xe2\x80\x94was wilder and more brutal than ever. And, one\r\nnight, when his mother, in the last agony of her despair, knelt at his\r\nfeet, he spurned her from him,\xe2\x80\x94threw her senseless on the floor, and,\r\nwith brutal curses, fled to his ship. The next Legree heard of his\r\nmother was, when, one night, as he was carousing among drunken\r\ncompanions, a letter was put into his hand. He opened it, and a lock of\r\nlong, curling hair fell from it, and twined about his fingers. The\r\nletter told him his mother was dead, and that, dying, she blest and\r\nforgave him.\r\n\r\nThere is a dread, unhallowed necromancy of evil, that turns things\r\nsweetest and holiest to phantoms of horror and affright. That pale,\r\nloving mother,\xe2\x80\x94her dying prayers, her forgiving love,\xe2\x80\x94wrought in that\r\ndemoniac heart of sin only as a damning sentence, bringing with it a\r\nfearful looking for of judgment and fiery indignation. Legree burned\r\nthe hair, and burned the letter; and when he saw them hissing and\r\ncrackling in the flame, inly shuddered as he thought of everlasting\r\nfires. He tried to drink, and revel, and swear away the memory; but\r\noften, in the deep night, whose solemn stillness arraigns the bad soul\r\nin forced communion with herself, he had seen that pale mother rising\r\nby his bedside, and felt the soft twining of that hair around his\r\nfingers, till the cold sweat would roll down his face, and he would\r\nspring from his bed in horror. Ye who have wondered to hear, in the\r\nsame evangel, that God is love, and that God is a consuming fire, see\r\nye not how, to the soul resolved in evil, perfect love is the most\r\nfearful torture, the seal and sentence of the direst despair?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBlast it!\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree to himself, as he sipped his liquor; \xe2\x80\x9cwhere did\r\nhe get that? If it didn\xe2\x80\x99t look just like\xe2\x80\x94whoo! I thought I\xe2\x80\x99d forgot\r\nthat. Curse me, if I think there\xe2\x80\x99s any such thing as forgetting\r\nanything, any how,\xe2\x80\x94hang it! I\xe2\x80\x99m lonesome! I mean to call Em. She hates\r\nme\xe2\x80\x94the monkey!
