I don\xe2\x80\x99t care,\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99ll _make_ her come!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLegree stepped out into a large entry, which went up stairs, by what\r\nhad formerly been a superb winding staircase; but the passage-way was\r\ndirty and dreary, encumbered with boxes and unsightly litter. The\r\nstairs, uncarpeted, seemed winding up, in the gloom, to nobody knew\r\nwhere! The pale moonlight streamed through a shattered fanlight over\r\nthe door; the air was unwholesome and chilly, like that of a vault.\r\n\r\nLegree stopped at the foot of the stairs, and heard a voice singing. It\r\nseemed strange and ghostlike in that dreary old house, perhaps because\r\nof the already tremulous state of his nerves. Hark! what is it?\r\n\r\nA wild, pathetic voice, chants a hymn common among the slaves:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO there\xe2\x80\x99ll be mourning, mourning, mourning,\r\nO there\xe2\x80\x99ll be mourning, at the judgment-seat of Christ!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBlast the girl!\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll choke her.\xe2\x80\x94Em! Em!\xe2\x80\x9d he called,\r\nharshly; but only a mocking echo from the walls answered him. The sweet\r\nvoice still sung on:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cParents and children there shall part!\r\nParents and children there shall part!\r\n    Shall part to meet no more!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nAnd clear and loud swelled through the empty halls the refrain,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO there\xe2\x80\x99ll be mourning, mourning, mourning,\r\nO there\xe2\x80\x99ll be mourning, at the judgment-seat of Christ!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nLegree stopped. He would have been ashamed to tell of it, but large\r\ndrops of sweat stood on his forehead, his heart beat heavy and thick\r\nwith fear; he even thought he saw something white rising and glimmering\r\nin the gloom before him, and shuddered to think what if the form of his\r\ndead mother should suddenly appear to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know one thing,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to himself, as he stumbled back in the\r\nsitting-room, and sat down; \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll let that fellow alone, after this!\r\nWhat did I want of his cussed paper? I b\xe2\x80\x99lieve I am bewitched, sure\r\nenough! I\xe2\x80\x99ve been shivering and sweating, ever since! Where did he get\r\nthat hair? It couldn\xe2\x80\x99t have been _that!_ I burnt _that_ up, I know I\r\ndid! It would be a joke, if hair could rise from the dead!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAh, Legree! that golden tress _was_ charmed; each hair had in it a\r\nspell of terror and remorse for thee, and was used by a mightier power\r\nto bind thy cruel hands from inflicting uttermost evil on the helpless!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say,\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, stamping and whistling to the dogs, \xe2\x80\x9cwake up,\r\nsome of you, and keep me company!\xe2\x80\x9d but the dogs only opened one eye at\r\nhim, sleepily, and closed it again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll have Sambo and Quimbo up here, to sing and dance one of their\r\nhell dances, and keep off these horrid notions,\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree; and,\r\nputting on his hat, he went on to the verandah, and blew a horn, with\r\nwhich he commonly summoned his two sable drivers.\r\n\r\nLegree was often wont, when in a gracious humor, to get these two\r\nworthies into his sitting-room, and, after warming them up with\r\nwhiskey, amuse himself by setting them to singing, dancing or fighting,\r\nas the humor took him.\r\n\r\nIt was between one and two o\xe2\x80\x99clock at night, as Cassy was returning\r\nfrom her ministrations to poor Tom, that she heard the sound of wild\r\nshrieking, whooping, halloing, and singing, from the sitting-room,\r\nmingled with the barking of dogs, and other symptoms of general uproar.\r\n\r\nShe came up on the verandah steps, and looked in. Legree and both the\r\ndrivers, in a state of furious intoxication, were singing, whooping,\r\nupsetting chairs, and making all manner of ludicrous and horrid\r\ngrimaces at each other.\r\n\r\nShe rested her small, slender hand on the window-blind, and looked\r\nfixedly at them;\xe2\x80\x94there was a world of anguish, scorn, and fierce\r\nbitterness, in her black eyes, as she did so. \xe2\x80\x9cWould it be a sin to rid\r\nthe world of such a wretch?\xe2\x80\x9d she said to herself.\r\n\r\nShe turned hurriedly away, and, passing round to a back door, glided up\r\nstairs, and tapped at Emmeline\xe2\x80\x99s door.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXVI\r\nEmmeline and Cassy\r\n\r\n\r\nCassy entered the room, and found Emmeline sitting, pale with fear, in\r\nthe furthest corner of it. As she came in, the girl started up\r\nnervously; but, on seeing who it was, rushed forward, and catching her\r\narm, said, \xe2\x80\x9cO Cassy, is it you? I\xe2\x80\x99m so glad you\xe2\x80\x99ve come! I was afraid\r\nit was\xe2\x80\x94. O, you don\xe2\x80\x99t know what a horrid noise there has been, down\r\nstairs, all this evening!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI ought to know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy, dryly. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve heard it often enough.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO Cassy! do tell me,\xe2\x80\x94couldn\xe2\x80\x99t we get away from this place? I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ncare where,\xe2\x80\x94into the swamp among the snakes,\xe2\x80\x94anywhere! _Couldn\xe2\x80\x99t_ we\r\nget _somewhere_ away from here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNowhere, but into our graves,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you ever try?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve seen enough of trying and what comes of it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d be willing to live in the swamps, and gnaw the bark from trees. I\r\nan\xe2\x80\x99t afraid of snakes! I\xe2\x80\x99d rather have one near me than him,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nEmmeline, eagerly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere have been a good many here of your opinion,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy; \xe2\x80\x9cbut\r\nyou couldn\xe2\x80\x99t stay in the swamps,\xe2\x80\x94you\xe2\x80\x99d be tracked by the dogs, and\r\nbrought back, and then\xe2\x80\x94then\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat would he do?\xe2\x80\x9d said the girl, looking, with breathless interest,\r\ninto her face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat _wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t_ he do, you\xe2\x80\x99d better ask,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s learned\r\nhis trade well, among the pirates in the West Indies. You wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nsleep much, if I should tell you things I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen,\xe2\x80\x94things that he tells\r\nof, sometimes, for good jokes. I\xe2\x80\x99ve heard screams here that I haven\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nbeen able to get out of my head for weeks and weeks. There\xe2\x80\x99s a place\r\nway out down by the quarters, where you can see a black, blasted tree,\r\nand the ground all covered with black ashes. Ask anyone what was done\r\nthere, and see if they will dare to tell you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO! what do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI won\xe2\x80\x99t tell you. I hate to think of it. And I tell you, the Lord only\r\nknows what we may see tomorrow, if that poor fellow holds out as he\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbegun.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHorrid!\xe2\x80\x9d said Emmeline, every drop of blood receding from her cheeks.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Cassy, do tell me what I shall do!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat I\xe2\x80\x99ve done. Do the best you can,\xe2\x80\x94do what you must,\xe2\x80\x94and make it up\r\nin hating and cursing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe wanted to make me drink some of his hateful brandy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Emmeline;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cand I hate it so\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99d better drink,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy. \xe2\x80\x9cI hated it, too; and now I can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nlive without it. One must have something;\xe2\x80\x94things don\xe2\x80\x99t look so\r\ndreadful, when you take that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMother used to tell me never to touch any such thing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Emmeline.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Mother_ told you!\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy, with a thrilling and bitter emphasis\r\non the word mother. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat use is it for mothers to say anything? You\r\nare all to be bought and paid for, and your souls belong to whoever\r\ngets you. That\xe2\x80\x99s the way it goes. I say, _drink_ brandy; drink all you\r\ncan, and it\xe2\x80\x99ll make things come easier.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Cassy! do pity me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPity you!\xe2\x80\x94don\xe2\x80\x99t I? Haven\xe2\x80\x99t I a daughter,\xe2\x80\x94Lord knows where she is, and\r\nwhose she is, now,\xe2\x80\x94going the way her mother went, before her, I\r\nsuppose, and that her children must go, after her! There\xe2\x80\x99s no end to\r\nthe curse\xe2\x80\x94forever!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish I\xe2\x80\x99d never been born!\xe2\x80\x9d said Emmeline, wringing her hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s an old wish with me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve got used to wishing\r\nthat. I\xe2\x80\x99d die, if I dared to,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, looking out into the darkness,\r\nwith that still, fixed despair which was the habitual expression of her\r\nface when at rest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt would be wicked to kill one\xe2\x80\x99s self,\xe2\x80\x9d said Emmeline.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know why,\xe2\x80\x94no wickeder than things we live and do, day after\r\nday. But the sisters told me things, when I was in the convent, that\r\nmake me afraid to die. If it would only be the end of us, why, then\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEmmeline turned away, and hid her face in her hands.\r\n\r\nWhile this conversation was passing in the chamber, Legree, overcome\r\nwith his carouse, had sunk to sleep in the room below. Legree was not\r\nan habitual drunkard. His coarse, strong nature craved, and could\r\nendure, a continual stimulation, that would have utterly wrecked and\r\ncrazed a finer one. But a deep, underlying spirit of cautiousness\r\nprevented his often yielding to appetite in such measure as to lose\r\ncontrol of himself.\r\n\r\nThis night, however, in his feverish efforts to banish from his mind\r\nthose fearful elements of woe and remorse which woke within him, he had\r\nindulged more than common; so that, when he had discharged his sable\r\nattendants, he fell heavily on a settle in the room, and was sound\r\nasleep.\r\n\r\nO! how dares the bad soul to enter the shadowy world of sleep?\xe2\x80\x94that\r\nland whose dim outlines lie so fearfully near to the mystic scene of\r\nretribution! Legree dreamed. In his heavy and feverish sleep, a veiled\r\nform stood beside him, and laid a cold, soft hand upon him. He thought\r\nhe knew who it was; and shuddered, with creeping horror, though the\r\nface was veiled. Then he thought he felt _that hair_ twining round his\r\nfingers; and then, that it slid smoothly round his neck, and tightened\r\nand tightened, and he could not draw his breath; and then he thought\r\nvoices _whispered_ to him,\xe2\x80\x94whispers that chilled him with horror. Then\r\nit seemed to him he was on the edge of a frightful abyss, holding on\r\nand struggling in mortal fear, while dark hands stretched up, and were\r\npulling him over; and Cassy came behind him laughing, and pushed him.\r\nAnd then rose up that solemn veiled figure, and drew aside the veil. It\r\nwas his mother; and she turned away from him, and he fell down, down,\r\ndown, amid a confused noise of shrieks, and groans, and shouts of demon\r\nlaughter,\xe2\x80\x94and Legree awoke.\r\n\r\nCalmly the rosy hue of dawn was stealing into the room. The morning\r\nstar stood, with its solemn, holy eye of light, looking down on the man\r\nof sin, from out the brightening sky. O, with what freshness, what\r\nsolemnity and beauty, is each new day born; as if to say to insensate\r\nman, \xe2\x80\x9cBehold! thou hast one more chance! _Strive_ for immortal glory!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nThere is no speech nor language where this voice is not heard; but the\r\nbold, bad man heard it not. He woke with an oath and a curse. What to\r\nhim was the gold and purple, the daily miracle of morning! What to him\r\nthe sanctity of the star which the Son of God has hallowed as his own\r\nemblem? Brute-like, he saw without perceiving; and, stumbling forward,\r\npoured out a tumbler of brandy, and drank half of it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve had a h\xe2\x80\x94l of a night!\xe2\x80\x9d he said to Cassy, who just then entered\r\nfrom an opposite door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll get plenty of the same sort, by and by,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, dryly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean, you minx?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll find out, one of these days,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Cassy, in the same tone.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow Simon, I\xe2\x80\x99ve one piece of advice to give you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe devil, you have!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy advice is,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy, steadily, as she began adjusting some\r\nthings about the room, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you let Tom alone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat business is \xe2\x80\x99t of yours?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat? To be sure, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what it should be. If you want to pay\r\ntwelve hundred for a fellow, and use him right up in the press of the\r\nseason, just to serve your own spite, it\xe2\x80\x99s no business of mine, I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\ndone what I could for him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have? What business have you meddling in my matters?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNone, to be sure. I\xe2\x80\x99ve saved you some thousands of dollars, at\r\ndifferent times, by taking care of your hands,\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s all the thanks I\r\nget. If your crop comes shorter into market than any of theirs, you\r\nwon\xe2\x80\x99t lose your bet, I suppose? Tompkins won\xe2\x80\x99t lord it over you, I\r\nsuppose,\xe2\x80\x94and you\xe2\x80\x99ll pay down your money like a lady, won\xe2\x80\x99t you? I think\r\nI see you doing it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLegree, like many other planters, had but one form of ambition,\xe2\x80\x94to have\r\nin the heaviest crop of the season,\xe2\x80\x94and he had several bets on this\r\nvery present season pending in the next town. Cassy, therefore, with\r\nwoman\xe2\x80\x99s tact, touched the only string that could be made to vibrate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I\xe2\x80\x99ll let him off at what he\xe2\x80\x99s got,\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree; \xe2\x80\x9cbut he shall\r\nbeg my pardon, and promise better fashions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat he won\xe2\x80\x99t do,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWon\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x94eh?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, he won\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d like to know _why_, Mistress,\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, in the extreme of\r\nscorn.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause he\xe2\x80\x99s done right, and he knows it, and won\xe2\x80\x99t say he\xe2\x80\x99s done\r\nwrong.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho a cuss cares what he knows? The nigger shall say what I please,\r\nor\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOr, you\xe2\x80\x99ll lose your bet on the cotton crop, by keeping him out of the\r\nfield, just at this very press.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut he _will_ give up,\xe2\x80\x94course, he will; don\xe2\x80\x99t I know what niggers is?\r\nHe\xe2\x80\x99ll beg like a dog, this morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe won\xe2\x80\x99t, Simon; you don\xe2\x80\x99t know this kind. You may kill him by\r\ninches,\xe2\x80\x94you won\xe2\x80\x99t get the first word of confession out of him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll see,\xe2\x80\x94where is he?\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, going out.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the waste-room of the gin-house,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy.\r\n\r\nLegree, though he talked so stoutly to Cassy, still sallied forth from\r\nthe house with a degree of misgiving which was not common with him. His\r\ndreams of the past night, mingled with Cassy\xe2\x80\x99s prudential suggestions,\r\nconsiderably affected his mind. He resolved that nobody should be\r\nwitness of his encounter with Tom; and determined, if he could not\r\nsubdue him by bullying, to defer his vengeance, to be wreaked in a more\r\nconvenient season.\r\n\r\nThe solemn light of dawn\xe2\x80\x94the angelic glory of the morning-star\xe2\x80\x94had\r\nlooked in through the rude window of the shed where Tom was lying; and,\r\nas if descending on that star-beam, came the solemn words, \xe2\x80\x9cI am the\r\nroot and offspring of David, and the bright and morning star.\xe2\x80\x9d The\r\nmysterious warnings and intimations of Cassy, so far from discouraging\r\nhis soul, in the end had roused it as with a heavenly call. He did not\r\nknow but that the day of his death was dawning in the sky; and his\r\nheart throbbed with solemn throes of joy and desire, as he thought that\r\nthe wondrous _all_, of which he had often pondered,\xe2\x80\x94the great white\r\nthrone, with its ever radiant rainbow; the white-robed multitude, with\r\nvoices as many waters; the crowns, the palms, the harps,\xe2\x80\x94might all\r\nbreak upon his vision before that sun should set again. And, therefore,\r\nwithout shuddering or trembling, he heard the voice of his persecutor,\r\nas he drew near.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my boy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, with a contemptuous kick, \xe2\x80\x9chow do you find\r\nyourself? Didn\xe2\x80\x99t I tell yer I could larn yer a thing or two? How do yer\r\nlike it\xe2\x80\x94eh? How did yer whaling agree with yer, Tom? An\xe2\x80\x99t quite so\r\ncrank as ye was last night. Ye couldn\xe2\x80\x99t treat a poor sinner, now, to a\r\nbit of sermon, could ye,\xe2\x80\x94eh?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom answered nothing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGet up, you beast!\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, kicking him again.\r\n\r\nThis was a difficult matter for one so bruised and faint; and, as Tom\r\nmade efforts to do so, Legree laughed brutally.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat makes ye so spry, this morning, Tom? Cotched cold, may be, last\r\nnight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom by this time had gained his feet, and was confronting his master\r\nwith a steady, unmoved front.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe devil, you can!\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, looking him over. \xe2\x80\x9cI believe you\r\nhaven\xe2\x80\x99t got enough yet. Now, Tom, get right down on yer knees and beg\r\nmy pardon, for yer shines last night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom did not move.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDown, you dog!\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, striking him with his riding-whip.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMas\xe2\x80\x99r Legree,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t do it. I did only what I thought was\r\nright. I shall do just so again, if ever the time comes. I never will\r\ndo a cruel thing, come what may.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but ye don\xe2\x80\x99t know what may come, Master Tom. Ye think what you\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\ngot is something. I tell you \xe2\x80\x99tan\xe2\x80\x99t anything,\xe2\x80\x94nothing \xe2\x80\x99t all. How would\r\nye like to be tied to a tree, and have a slow fire lit up around\r\nye;\xe2\x80\x94wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t that be pleasant,\xe2\x80\x94eh, Tom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMas\xe2\x80\x99r,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, \xe2\x80\x9cI know ye can do dreadful things; but,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he\r\nstretched himself upward and clasped his hands,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cbut, after ye\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nkilled the body, there an\xe2\x80\x99t no more ye can do. And O, there\xe2\x80\x99s all\r\nETERNITY to come, after that!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nETERNITY,\xe2\x80\x94the word thrilled through the black man\xe2\x80\x99s soul with light and\r\npower, as he spoke; it thrilled through the sinner\xe2\x80\x99s soul, too, like\r\nthe bite of a scorpion. Legree gnashed on him with his teeth, but rage\r\nkept him silent; and Tom, like a man disenthralled, spoke, in a clear\r\nand cheerful voice,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMas\xe2\x80\x99r Legree, as ye bought me, I\xe2\x80\x99ll be a true and faithful servant to\r\nye. I\xe2\x80\x99ll give ye all the work of my hands, all my time, all my\r\nstrength; but my soul I won\xe2\x80\x99t give up to mortal man. I will hold on to\r\nthe Lord, and put his commands before all,\xe2\x80\x94die or live; you may be sure\r\non \xe2\x80\x99t. Mas\xe2\x80\x99r Legree, I ain\xe2\x80\x99t a grain afeard to die. I\xe2\x80\x99d as soon die as\r\nnot. Ye may whip me, starve me, burn me,\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99ll only send me sooner\r\nwhere I want to go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll make ye give out, though, \xe2\x80\x99fore I\xe2\x80\x99ve done!\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, in a\r\nrage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall have _help_,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom; \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99ll never do it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho the devil\xe2\x80\x99s going to help you?\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, scornfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Lord Almighty,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cD\xe2\x80\x94n you!\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, as with one blow of his fist he felled Tom to\r\nthe earth.\r\n\r\nA cold soft hand fell on Legree\xe2\x80\x99s at this moment. He turned,\xe2\x80\x94it was\r\nCassy\xe2\x80\x99s; but the cold soft touch recalled his dream of the night\r\nbefore, and, flashing through the chambers of his brain, came all the\r\nfearful images of the night-watches, with a portion of the horror that\r\naccompanied them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you be a fool?\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy, in French. \xe2\x80\x9cLet him go! Let me alone\r\nto get him fit to be in the field again. Isn\xe2\x80\x99t it just as I told you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey say the alligator, the rhinoceros, though enclosed in bullet-proof\r\nmail, have each a spot where they are vulnerable; and fierce, reckless,\r\nunbelieving reprobates, have commonly this point in superstitious\r\ndread.\r\n\r\nLegree turned away, determined to let the point go for the time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, have it your own way,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, doggedly, to Cassy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHark, ye!\xe2\x80\x9d he said to Tom; \xe2\x80\x9cI won\xe2\x80\x99t deal with ye now, because the\r\nbusiness is pressing, and I want all my hands; but I _never_ forget.\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll score it against ye, and sometime I\xe2\x80\x99ll have my pay out o\xe2\x80\x99 yer old\r\nblack hide,\xe2\x80\x94mind ye!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLegree turned, and went out.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere you go,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy, looking darkly after him; \xe2\x80\x9cyour reckoning\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nto come, yet!\xe2\x80\x94My poor fellow, how are you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Lord God hath sent his angel, and shut the lion\xe2\x80\x99s mouth, for this\r\ntime,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor this time, to be sure,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy; \xe2\x80\x9cbut now you\xe2\x80\x99ve got his ill\r\nwill upon you, to follow you day in, day out, hanging like a dog on\r\nyour throat,\xe2\x80\x94sucking your blood, bleeding away your life, drop by drop.\r\nI know the man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXVII\r\nLiberty\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo matter with what solemnities he may have been devoted upon the\r\naltar of slavery, the moment he touches the sacred soil of Britain, the\r\naltar and the God sink together in the dust, and he stands redeemed,\r\nregenerated, and disenthralled, by the irresistible genius of universal\r\nemancipation.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_Curran_.[1]\r\n\r\n\r\n [1] John Philpot Curran (1750-1817), Irish orator and judge who worked\r\n for Catholic emancipation.\r\n\r\n\r\nA while we must leave Tom in the hands of his persecutors, while we\r\nturn to pursue the fortunes of George and his wife, whom we left in\r\nfriendly hands, in a farmhouse on the road-side.\r\n\r\nTom Loker we left groaning and touzling in a most immaculately clean\r\nQuaker bed, under the motherly supervision of Aunt Dorcas, who found\r\nhim to the full as tractable a patient as a sick bison.\r\n\r\nImagine a tall, dignified, spiritual woman, whose clear muslin cap\r\nshades waves of silvery hair, parted on a broad, clear forehead, which\r\noverarches thoughtful gray eyes. A snowy handkerchief of lisse crape is\r\nfolded neatly across her bosom; her glossy brown silk dress rustles\r\npeacefully, as she glides up and down the chamber.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe devil!\xe2\x80\x9d says Tom Loker, giving a great throw to the bedclothes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must request thee, Thomas, not to use such language,\xe2\x80\x9d says Aunt\r\nDorcas, as she quietly rearranged the bed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I won\xe2\x80\x99t, granny, if I can help it,\xe2\x80\x9d says Tom; \xe2\x80\x9cbut it is enough\r\nto make a fellow swear,\xe2\x80\x94so cursedly hot!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDorcas removed a comforter from the bed, straightened the clothes\r\nagain, and tucked them in till Tom looked something like a chrysalis;\r\nremarking, as she did so,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish, friend, thee would leave off cursing and swearing, and think\r\nupon thy ways.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat the devil,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, \xe2\x80\x9cshould I think of _them_ for? Last thing\r\never _I_ want to think of\xe2\x80\x94hang it all!\xe2\x80\x9d And Tom flounced over,\r\nuntucking and disarranging everything, in a manner frightful to behold.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat fellow and gal are here, I s\xe2\x80\x99pose,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, sullenly, after a\r\npause.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are so,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dorcas.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99d better be off up to the lake,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom; \xe2\x80\x9cthe quicker the\r\nbetter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cProbably they will do so,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aunt Dorcas, knitting peacefully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd hark ye,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom; \xe2\x80\x9cwe\xe2\x80\x99ve got correspondents in Sandusky, that\r\nwatch the boats for us. I don\xe2\x80\x99t care if I tell, now. I hope they _will_\r\nget away, just to spite Marks,\xe2\x80\x94the cursed puppy!\xe2\x80\x94d\xe2\x80\x94n him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThomas!\xe2\x80\x9d said Dorcas.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI tell you, granny, if you bottle a fellow up too tight, I shall\r\nsplit,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom. \xe2\x80\x9cBut about the gal,\xe2\x80\x94tell \xe2\x80\x99em to dress her up some\r\nway, so\xe2\x80\x99s to alter her. Her description\xe2\x80\x99s out in Sandusky.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe will attend to that matter,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dorcas, with characteristic\r\ncomposure.\r\n\r\nAs we at this place take leave of Tom Loker, we may as well say, that,\r\nhaving lain three weeks at the Quaker dwelling, sick with a rheumatic\r\nfever, which set in, in company with his other afflictions, Tom arose\r\nfrom his bed a somewhat sadder and wiser man; and, in place of\r\nslave-catching, betook himself to life in one of the new settlements,\r\nwhere his talents developed themselves more happily in trapping bears,\r\nwolves, and other inhabitants of the forest, in which he made himself\r\nquite a name in the land. Tom always spoke reverently of the Quakers.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNice people,\xe2\x80\x9d he would say; \xe2\x80\x9cwanted to convert me, but couldn\xe2\x80\x99t come\r\nit, exactly. But, tell ye what, stranger, they do fix up a sick fellow\r\nfirst rate,\xe2\x80\x94no mistake. Make jist the tallest kind o\xe2\x80\x99 broth and\r\nknicknacks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs Tom had informed them that their party would be looked for in\r\nSandusky, it was thought prudent to divide them. Jim, with his old\r\nmother, was forwarded separately; and a night or two after, George and\r\nEliza, with their child, were driven privately into Sandusky, and\r\nlodged beneath a hospital roof, preparatory to taking their last\r\npassage on the lake.\r\n\r\nTheir night was now far spent, and the morning star of liberty rose\r\nfair before them!\xe2\x80\x94electric word! What is it? Is there anything more in\r\nit than a name\xe2\x80\x94a rhetorical flourish? Why, men and women of America,\r\ndoes your heart\xe2\x80\x99s blood thrill at that word, for which your fathers\r\nbled, and your braver mothers were willing that their noblest and best\r\nshould die?\r\n\r\nIs there anything in it glorious and dear for a nation, that is not\r\nalso glorious and dear for a man? What is freedom to a nation, but\r\nfreedom to the individuals in it? What is freedom to that young man,\r\nwho sits there, with his arms folded over his broad chest, the tint of\r\nAfrican blood in his cheek, its dark fires in his eyes,\xe2\x80\x94what is freedom\r\nto George Harris? To your fathers, freedom was the right of a nation to\r\nbe a nation. To him, it is the right of a man to be a man, and not a\r\nbrute; the right to call the wife of his bosom his wife, and to protect\r\nher from lawless violence; the right to protect and educate his child;\r\nthe right to have a home of his own, a religion of his own, a character\r\nof his own, unsubject to the will of another. All these thoughts were\r\nrolling and seething in George\xe2\x80\x99s breast, as he was pensively leaning\r\nhis head on his hand, watching his wife, as she was adapting to her\r\nslender and pretty form the articles of man\xe2\x80\x99s attire, in which it was\r\ndeemed safest she should make her escape.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow for it,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, as she stood before the glass, and shook down\r\nher silky abundance of black curly hair. \xe2\x80\x9cI say, George, it\xe2\x80\x99s almost a\r\npity, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, as she held up some of it, playfully,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cpity\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99s all got to come off?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGeorge smiled sadly, and made no answer.\r\n\r\nEliza turned to the glass, and the scissors glittered as one long lock\r\nafter another was detached from her head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, now, that\xe2\x80\x99ll do,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, taking up a hair-brush; \xe2\x80\x9cnow for a\r\nfew fancy touches.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, an\xe2\x80\x99t I a pretty young fellow?\xe2\x80\x9d she said, turning around to her\r\nhusband, laughing and blushing at the same time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou always will be pretty, do what you will,\xe2\x80\x9d said George.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat does make you so sober?\xe2\x80\x9d said Eliza, kneeling on one knee, and\r\nlaying her hand on his. \xe2\x80\x9cWe are only within twenty-four hours of\r\nCanada, they say. Only a day and a night on the lake, and then\xe2\x80\x94oh,\r\nthen!\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Eliza!\xe2\x80\x9d said George, drawing her towards him; \xe2\x80\x9cthat is it! Now my\r\nfate is all narrowing down to a point. To come so near, to be almost in\r\nsight, and then lose all. I should never live under it, Eliza.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t fear,\xe2\x80\x9d said his wife, hopefully. \xe2\x80\x9cThe good Lord would not have\r\nbrought us so far, if he didn\xe2\x80\x99t mean to carry us through. I seem to\r\nfeel him with us, George.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are a blessed woman, Eliza!\xe2\x80\x9d said George, clasping her with a\r\nconvulsive grasp. \xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x94oh, tell me! can this great mercy be for us?\r\nWill these years and years of misery come to an end?\xe2\x80\x94shall we be free?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am sure of it, George,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eliza, looking upward, while tears of\r\nhope and enthusiasm shone on her long, dark lashes. \xe2\x80\x9cI feel it in me,\r\nthat God is going to bring us out of bondage, this very day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will believe you, Eliza,\xe2\x80\x9d said George, rising suddenly up, \xe2\x80\x9cI will\r\nbelieve,\xe2\x80\x94come let\xe2\x80\x99s be off. Well, indeed,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, holding her off at\r\narm\xe2\x80\x99s length, and looking admiringly at her, \xe2\x80\x9cyou _are_ a pretty little\r\nfellow. That crop of little, short curls, is quite becoming. Put on\r\nyour cap. So\xe2\x80\x94a little to one side. I never saw you look quite so\r\npretty. But, it\xe2\x80\x99s almost time for the carriage;\xe2\x80\x94I wonder if Mrs. Smyth\r\nhas got Harry rigged?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe door opened, and a respectable, middle-aged woman entered, leading\r\nlittle Harry, dressed in girl\xe2\x80\x99s clothes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a pretty girl he makes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eliza, turning him round. \xe2\x80\x9cWe call\r\nhim Harriet, you see;\xe2\x80\x94don\xe2\x80\x99t the name come nicely?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe child stood gravely regarding his mother in her new and strange\r\nattire, observing a profound silence, and occasionally drawing deep\r\nsighs, and peeping at her from under his dark curls.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes Harry know mamma?\xe2\x80\x9d said Eliza, stretching her hands toward him.\r\n\r\nThe child clung shyly to the woman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome Eliza, why do you try to coax him, when you know that he has got\r\nto be kept away from you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know it\xe2\x80\x99s foolish,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eliza; \xe2\x80\x9cyet, I can\xe2\x80\x99t bear to have him turn\r\naway from me. But come,\xe2\x80\x94where\xe2\x80\x99s my cloak? Here,\xe2\x80\x94how is it men put on\r\ncloaks, George?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must wear it so,\xe2\x80\x9d said her husband, throwing it over his\r\nshoulders.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eliza, imitating the motion,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cand I must stamp, and\r\ntake long steps, and try to look saucy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t exert yourself,\xe2\x80\x9d said George. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is, now and then, a modest\r\nyoung man; and I think it would be easier for you to act that\r\ncharacter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd these gloves! mercy upon us!\xe2\x80\x9d said Eliza; \xe2\x80\x9cwhy, my hands are lost\r\nin them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI advise you to keep them on pretty strictly,\xe2\x80\x9d said George. \xe2\x80\x9cYour\r\nslender paw might bring us all out. Now, Mrs. Smyth, you are to go\r\nunder our charge, and be our aunty,\xe2\x80\x94you mind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve heard,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Smyth, \xe2\x80\x9cthat there have been men down, warning\r\nall the packet captains against a man and woman, with a little boy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey have!\xe2\x80\x9d said George. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, if we see any such people, we can tell\r\nthem.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA hack now drove to the door, and the friendly family who had received\r\nthe fugitives crowded around them with farewell greetings.\r\n\r\nThe disguises the party had assumed were in accordance with the hints\r\nof Tom Loker. Mrs. Smyth, a respectable woman from the settlement in\r\nCanada, whither they were fleeing, being fortunately about crossing the\r\nlake to return thither, had consented to appear as the aunt of little\r\nHarry; and, in order to attach him to her, he had been allowed to\r\nremain, the two last days, under her sole charge; and an extra amount\r\nof petting, jointed to an indefinite amount of seed-cakes and candy,\r\nhad cemented a very close attachment on the part of the young\r\ngentleman.\r\n\r\nThe hack drove to the wharf. The two young men, as they appeared,\r\nwalked up the plank into the boat, Eliza gallantly giving her arm to\r\nMrs. Smyth, and George attending to their baggage.\r\n\r\nGeorge was standing at the captain\xe2\x80\x99s office, settling for his party,\r\nwhen he overheard two men talking by his side.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve watched every one that came on board,\xe2\x80\x9d said one, \xe2\x80\x9cand I know\r\nthey\xe2\x80\x99re not on this boat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe voice was that of the clerk of the boat. The speaker whom he\r\naddressed was our sometime friend Marks, who, with that valuable\r\nperseverance which characterized him, had come on to Sandusky, seeking\r\nwhom he might devour.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou would scarcely know the woman from a white one,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marks. \xe2\x80\x9cThe\r\nman is a very light mulatto; he has a brand in one of his hands.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe hand with which George was taking the tickets and change trembled a\r\nlittle; but he turned coolly around, fixed an unconcerned glance on the\r\nface of the speaker, and walked leisurely toward another part of the\r\nboat, where Eliza stood waiting for him.\r\n\r\nMrs. Smyth, with little Harry, sought the seclusion of the ladies\xe2\x80\x99\r\ncabin, where the dark beauty of the supposed little girl drew many\r\nflattering comments from the passengers.\r\n\r\nGeorge had the satisfaction, as the bell rang out its farewell peal, to\r\nsee Marks walk down the plank to the shore; and drew a long sigh of\r\nrelief, when the boat had put a returnless distance between them.\r\n\r\nIt was a superb day. The blue waves of Lake Erie danced, rippling and\r\nsparkling, in the sun-light. A fresh breeze blew from the shore, and\r\nthe lordly boat ploughed her way right gallantly onward.\r\n\r\nO, what an untold world there is in one human heart! Who thought, as\r\nGeorge walked calmly up and down the deck of the steamer, with his shy\r\ncompanion at his side, of all that was burning in his bosom? The mighty\r\ngood that seemed approaching seemed too good, too fair, even to be a\r\nreality; and he felt a jealous dread, every moment of the day, that\r\nsomething would rise to snatch it from him.\r\n\r\nBut the boat swept on. Hours fleeted, and, at last, clear and full rose\r\nthe blessed English shores; shores charmed by a mighty spell,\xe2\x80\x94with one\r\ntouch to dissolve every incantation of slavery, no matter in what\r\nlanguage pronounced, or by what national power confirmed.\r\n\r\n\r\n[Illustration: THE FUGITIVES ARE SAVE IN A FREE LAND.]\r\n\r\n\r\nGeorge and his wife stood arm in arm, as the boat neared the small town\r\nof Amherstberg, in Canada. His breath grew thick and short; a mist\r\ngathered before his eyes; he silently pressed the little hand that lay\r\ntrembling on his arm. The bell rang; the boat stopped. Scarcely seeing\r\nwhat he did, he looked out his baggage, and gathered his little party.\r\nThe little company were landed on the shore. They stood still till the\r\nboat had cleared; and then, with tears and embracings, the husband and\r\nwife, with their wondering child in their arms, knelt down and lifted\r\nup their hearts to God!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x99T was something like the burst from death to life;\r\n    From the grave\xe2\x80\x99s cerements to the robes of heaven;\r\nFrom sin\xe2\x80\x99s dominion, and from passion\xe2\x80\x99s strife,\r\n    To the pure freedom of a soul forgiven;\r\n    Where all the bonds of death and hell are riven,\r\nAnd mortal puts on immortality,\r\nWhen Mercy\xe2\x80\x99s hand hath turned the golden key,\r\nAnd Mercy\xe2\x80\x99s voice hath said, _Rejoice, thy soul is free.\xe2\x80\x9d_\r\n\r\n\r\nThe little party were soon guided, by Mrs. Smyth, to the hospitable\r\nabode of a good missionary, whom Christian charity has placed here as a\r\nshepherd to the outcast and wandering, who are constantly finding an\r\nasylum on this shore.\r\n\r\nWho can speak the blessedness of that first day of freedom? Is not the\r\n_sense_ of liberty a higher and a finer one than any of the five? To\r\nmove, speak and breathe,\xe2\x80\x94go out and come in unwatched, and free from\r\ndanger! Who can speak the blessings of that rest which comes down on\r\nthe free man\xe2\x80\x99s pillow, under laws which insure to him the rights that\r\nGod has given to man? How fair and precious to that mother was that\r\nsleeping child\xe2\x80\x99s face, endeared by the memory of a thousand dangers!\r\nHow impossible was it to sleep, in the exuberant possession of such\r\nblessedness! And yet, these two had not one acre of ground,\xe2\x80\x94not a roof\r\nthat they could call their own,\xe2\x80\x94they had spent their all, to the last\r\ndollar. They had nothing more than the birds of the air, or the flowers\r\nof the field,\xe2\x80\x94yet they could not sleep for joy. \xe2\x80\x9cO, ye who take freedom\r\nfrom man, with what words shall ye answer it to God?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXVIII\r\nThe Victory\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks be unto God, who giveth us the victory.\xe2\x80\x9d[1]\r\n\r\n\r\n [1] I Cor. 15:57.\r\n\r\n\r\nHave not many of us, in the weary way of life, felt, in some hours, how\r\nfar easier it were to die than to live?\r\n\r\nThe martyr, when faced even by a death of bodily anguish and horror,\r\nfinds in the very terror of his doom a strong stimulant and tonic.\r\nThere is a vivid excitement, a thrill and fervor, which may carry\r\nthrough any crisis of suffering that is the birth-hour of eternal glory\r\nand rest.\r\n\r\nBut to live,\xe2\x80\x94to wear on, day after day, of mean, bitter, low, harassing\r\nservitude, every nerve dampened and depressed, every power of feeling\r\ngradually smothered,\xe2\x80\x94this long and wasting heart-martyrdom, this slow,\r\ndaily bleeding away of the inward life, drop by drop, hour after\r\nhour,\xe2\x80\x94this is the true searching test of what there may be in man or\r\nwoman.\r\n\r\nWhen Tom stood face to face with his persecutor, and heard his threats,\r\nand thought in his very soul that his hour was come, his heart swelled\r\nbravely in him, and he thought he could bear torture and fire, bear\r\nanything, with the vision of Jesus and heaven but just a step beyond;\r\nbut, when he was gone, and the present excitement passed off, came back\r\nthe pain of his bruised and weary limbs,\xe2\x80\x94came back the sense of his\r\nutterly degraded, hopeless, forlorn estate; and the day passed wearily\r\nenough.\r\n\r\nLong before his wounds were healed, Legree insisted that he should be\r\nput to the regular field-work; and then came day after day of pain and\r\nweariness, aggravated by every kind of injustice and indignity that the\r\nill-will of a mean and malicious mind could devise. Whoever, in _our_\r\ncircumstances, has made trial of pain, even with all the alleviations\r\nwhich, for us, usually attend it, must know the irritation that comes\r\nwith it. Tom no longer wondered at the habitual surliness of his\r\nassociates; nay, he found the placid, sunny temper, which had been the\r\nhabitude of his life, broken in on, and sorely strained, by the inroads\r\nof the same thing. He had flattered himself on leisure to read his\r\nBible; but there was no such thing as leisure there. In the height of\r\nthe season, Legree did not hesitate to press all his hands through,\r\nSundays and week-days alike. Why shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t he?\xe2\x80\x94he made more cotton by\r\nit, and gained his wager; and if it wore out a few more hands, he could\r\nbuy better ones. At first, Tom used to read a verse or two of his\r\nBible, by the flicker of the fire, after he had returned from his daily\r\ntoil; but, after the cruel treatment he received, he used to come home\r\nso exhausted, that his head swam and his eyes failed when he tried to\r\nread; and he was fain to stretch himself down, with the others, in\r\nutter exhaustion.\r\n\r\nIs it strange that the religious peace and trust, which had upborne him\r\nhitherto, should give way to tossings of soul and despondent darkness?\r\nThe gloomiest problem of this mysterious life was constantly before his\r\neyes,\xe2\x80\x94souls crushed and ruined, evil triumphant, and God silent. It was\r\nweeks and months that Tom wrestled, in his own soul, in darkness and\r\nsorrow. He thought of Miss Ophelia\xe2\x80\x99s letter to his Kentucky friends,\r\nand would pray earnestly that God would send him deliverance. And then\r\nhe would watch, day after day, in the vague hope of seeing somebody\r\nsent to redeem him; and, when nobody came, he would crush back to his\r\nsoul bitter thoughts,\xe2\x80\x94that it was vain to serve God, that God had\r\nforgotten him. He sometimes saw Cassy; and sometimes, when summoned to\r\nthe house, caught a glimpse of the dejected form of Emmeline, but held\r\nvery little communion with either; in fact, there was no time for him\r\nto commune with anybody.\r\n\r\nOne evening, he was sitting, in utter dejection and prostration, by a\r\nfew decaying brands, where his coarse supper was baking. He put a few\r\nbits of brushwood on the fire, and strove to raise the light, and then\r\ndrew his worn Bible from his pocket. There were all the marked\r\npassages, which had thrilled his soul so often,\xe2\x80\x94words of patriarchs and\r\nseers, poets and sages, who from early time had spoken courage to\r\nman,\xe2\x80\x94voices from the great cloud of witnesses who ever surround us in\r\nthe race of life. Had the word lost its power, or could the failing eye\r\nand weary sense no longer answer to the touch of that mighty\r\ninspiration? Heavily sighing, he put it in his pocket. A coarse laugh\r\nroused him; he looked up,\xe2\x80\x94Legree was standing opposite to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, old boy,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cyou find your religion don\xe2\x80\x99t work, it seems!\r\nI thought I should get that through your wool, at last!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe cruel taunt was more than hunger and cold and nakedness. Tom was\r\nsilent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou were a fool,\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree; \xe2\x80\x9cfor I meant to do well by you, when I\r\nbought you. You might have been better off than Sambo, or Quimbo\r\neither, and had easy times; and, instead of getting cut up and\r\nthrashed, every day or two, ye might have had liberty to lord it round,\r\nand cut up the other niggers; and ye might have had, now and then, a\r\ngood warming of whiskey punch. Come, Tom, don\xe2\x80\x99t you think you\xe2\x80\x99d better\r\nbe reasonable?\xe2\x80\x94heave that ar old pack of trash in the fire, and join my\r\nchurch!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Lord forbid!\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, fervently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see the Lord an\xe2\x80\x99t going to help you; if he had been, he wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nhave let _me_ get you! This yer religion is all a mess of lying\r\ntrumpery, Tom. I know all about it. Ye\xe2\x80\x99d better hold to me; I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nsomebody, and can do something!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom; \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll hold on. The Lord may help me, or not\r\nhelp; but I\xe2\x80\x99ll hold to him, and believe him to the last!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe more fool you!\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, spitting scornfully at him, and\r\nspurning him with his foot. \xe2\x80\x9cNever mind; I\xe2\x80\x99ll chase you down, yet, and\r\nbring you under,\xe2\x80\x94you\xe2\x80\x99ll see!\xe2\x80\x9d and Legree turned away.\r\n\r\nWhen a heavy weight presses the soul to the lowest level at which\r\nendurance is possible, there is an instant and desperate effort of\r\nevery physical and moral nerve to throw off the weight; and hence the\r\nheaviest anguish often precedes a return tide of joy and courage. So\r\nwas it now with Tom. The atheistic taunts of his cruel master sunk his\r\nbefore dejected soul to the lowest ebb; and, though the hand of faith\r\nstill held to the eternal rock, it was a numb, despairing grasp. Tom\r\nsat, like one stunned, at the fire. Suddenly everything around him\r\nseemed to fade, and a vision rose before him of one crowned with\r\nthorns, buffeted and bleeding. Tom gazed, in awe and wonder, at the\r\nmajestic patience of the face; the deep, pathetic eyes thrilled him to\r\nhis inmost heart; his soul woke, as, with floods of emotion, he\r\nstretched out his hands and fell upon his knees,\xe2\x80\x94when, gradually, the\r\nvision changed: the sharp thorns became rays of glory; and, in splendor\r\ninconceivable, he saw that same face bending compassionately towards\r\nhim, and a voice said, \xe2\x80\x9cHe that overcometh shall sit down with me on my\r\nthrone, even as I also overcome, and am set down with my Father on his\r\nthrone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHow long Tom lay there, he knew not. When he came to himself, the fire\r\nwas gone out, his clothes were wet with the chill and drenching dews;\r\nbut the dread soul-crisis was past, and, in the joy that filled him, he\r\nno longer felt hunger, cold, degradation, disappointment, wretchedness.\r\nFrom his deepest soul, he that hour loosed and parted from every hope\r\nin life that now is, and offered his own will an unquestioning\r\nsacrifice to the Infinite. Tom looked up to the silent, ever-living\r\nstars,\xe2\x80\x94types of the angelic hosts who ever look down on man; and the\r\nsolitude of the night rung with the triumphant words of a hymn, which\r\nhe had sung often in happier days, but never with such feeling as now:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe earth shall be dissolved like snow,\r\n    The sun shall cease to shine;\r\nBut God, who called me here below,\r\n    Shall be forever mine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd when this mortal life shall fail,\r\n    And flesh and sense shall cease,\r\nI shall possess within the veil\r\n    A life of joy and peace.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen we\xe2\x80\x99ve been there ten thousand years,\r\n    Bright shining like the sun,\r\nWe\xe2\x80\x99ve no less days to sing God\xe2\x80\x99s praise\r\n    Than when we first begun.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nThose who have been familiar with the religious histories of the slave\r\npopulation know that relations like what we have narrated are very\r\ncommon among them. We have heard some from their own lips, of a very\r\ntouching and affecting character. The psychologist tells us of a state,\r\nin which the affections and images of the mind become so dominant and\r\noverpowering, that they press into their service the outward imagining.\r\nWho shall measure what an all-pervading Spirit may do with these\r\ncapabilities of our mortality, or the ways in which He may encourage\r\nthe desponding souls of the desolate? If the poor forgotten slave\r\nbelieves that Jesus hath appeared and spoken to him, who shall\r\ncontradict him? Did He not say that his mission, in all ages, was to\r\nbind up the broken-hearted, and set at liberty them that are bruised?\r\n\r\nWhen the dim gray of dawn woke the slumberers to go forth to the field,\r\nthere was among those tattered and shivering wretches one who walked\r\nwith an exultant tread; for firmer than the ground he trod on was his\r\nstrong faith in Almighty, eternal love. Ah, Legree, try all your forces\r\nnow! Utmost agony, woe, degradation, want, and loss of all things,\r\nshall only hasten on the process by which he shall be made a king and a\r\npriest unto God!\r\n\r\nFrom this time, an inviolable sphere of peace encompassed the lowly\r\nheart of the oppressed one,\xe2\x80\x94an ever-present Saviour hallowed it as a\r\ntemple. Past now the bleeding of earthly regrets; past its fluctuations\r\nof hope, and fear, and desire; the human will, bent, and bleeding, and\r\nstruggling long, was now entirely merged in the Divine. So short now\r\nseemed the remaining voyage of life,\xe2\x80\x94so near, so vivid, seemed eternal\r\nblessedness,\xe2\x80\x94that life\xe2\x80\x99s uttermost woes fell from him unharming.\r\n\r\nAll noticed the change in his appearance. Cheerfulness and alertness\r\nseemed to return to him, and a quietness which no insult or injury\r\ncould ruffle seemed to possess him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat the devil\xe2\x80\x99s got into Tom?\xe2\x80\x9d Legree said to Sambo. \xe2\x80\x9cA while ago he\r\nwas all down in the mouth, and now he\xe2\x80\x99s peart as a cricket.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDunno, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r; gwine to run off, mebbe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLike to see him try that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, with a savage grin, \xe2\x80\x9cwouldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nwe, Sambo?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGuess we would! Haw! haw! ho!\xe2\x80\x9d said the sooty gnome, laughing\r\nobsequiously. \xe2\x80\x9cLord, de fun! To see him stickin\xe2\x80\x99 in de mud,\xe2\x80\x94chasin\xe2\x80\x99 and\r\ntarin\xe2\x80\x99 through de bushes, dogs a holdin\xe2\x80\x99 on to him! Lord, I laughed fit\r\nto split, dat ar time we cotched Molly. I thought they\xe2\x80\x99d a had her all\r\nstripped up afore I could get \xe2\x80\x99em off. She car\xe2\x80\x99s de marks o\xe2\x80\x99 dat ar\r\nspree yet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI reckon she will, to her grave,\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree. \xe2\x80\x9cBut now, Sambo, you\r\nlook sharp. If the nigger\xe2\x80\x99s got anything of this sort going, trip him\r\nup.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMas\xe2\x80\x99r, let me lone for dat,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sambo, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll tree de coon. Ho, ho,\r\nho!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis was spoken as Legree was getting on his horse, to go to the\r\nneighboring town. That night, as he was returning, he thought he would\r\nturn his horse and ride round the quarters, and see if all was safe.\r\n\r\nIt was a superb moonlight night, and the shadows of the graceful China\r\ntrees lay minutely pencilled on the turf below, and there was that\r\ntransparent stillness in the air which it seems almost unholy to\r\ndisturb. Legree was a little distance from the quarters, when he heard\r\nthe voice of some one singing. It was not a usual sound there, and he\r\npaused to listen. A musical tenor voice sang,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen I can read my title clear\r\n    To mansions in the skies,\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll bid farewell to every fear,\r\n    And wipe my weeping eyes\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShould earth against my soul engage,\r\n    And hellish darts be hurled,\r\nThen I can smile at Satan\xe2\x80\x99s rage,\r\n    And face a frowning world.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet cares like a wild deluge come,\r\n    And storms of sorrow fall,\r\nMay I but safely reach my home,\r\n    My God, my Heaven, my All.\xe2\x80\x9d[2]\r\n\r\n\r\n [2] \xe2\x80\x9cOn My Journey Home,\xe2\x80\x9d hymn by Isaac Watts, found in many of the\r\n southern country songbooks of the ante bellum period.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo ho!\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree to himself, \xe2\x80\x9che thinks so, does he? How I hate\r\nthese cursed Methodist hymns! Here, you nigger,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, coming\r\nsuddenly out upon Tom, and raising his riding-whip, \xe2\x80\x9chow dare you be\r\ngettin\xe2\x80\x99 up this yer row, when you ought to be in bed? Shut yer old\r\nblack gash, and get along in with you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, with ready cheerfulness, as he rose to go in.\r\n\r\nLegree was provoked beyond measure by Tom\xe2\x80\x99s evident happiness; and\r\nriding up to him, belabored him over his head and shoulders.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, you dog,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9csee if you\xe2\x80\x99ll feel so comfortable, after\r\nthat!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut the blows fell now only on the outer man, and not, as before, on\r\nthe heart. Tom stood perfectly submissive; and yet Legree could not\r\nhide from himself that his power over his bond thrall was somehow gone.\r\nAnd, as Tom disappeared in his cabin, and he wheeled his horse suddenly\r\nround, there passed through his mind one of those vivid flashes that\r\noften send the lightning of conscience across the dark and wicked soul.\r\nHe understood full well that it was GOD who was standing between him\r\nand his victim, and he blasphemed him. That submissive and silent man,\r\nwhom taunts, nor threats, nor stripes, nor cruelties, could disturb,\r\nroused a voice within him, such as of old his Master roused in the\r\ndemoniac soul, saying, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat have we to do with thee, thou Jesus of\r\nNazareth?\xe2\x80\x94art thou come to torment us before the time?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom\xe2\x80\x99s whole soul overflowed with compassion and sympathy for the poor\r\nwretches by whom he was surrounded. To him it seemed as if his\r\nlife-sorrows were now over, and as if, out of that strange treasury of\r\npeace and joy, with which he had been endowed from above, he longed to\r\npour out something for the relief of their woes. It is true,\r\nopportunities were scanty; but, on the way to the fields, and back\r\nagain, and during the hours of labor, chances fell in his way of\r\nextending a helping-hand to the weary, the disheartened and\r\ndiscouraged. The poor, worn-down, brutalized creatures, at first, could\r\nscarce comprehend this; but, when it was continued week after week, and\r\nmonth after month, it began to awaken long-silent chords in their\r\nbenumbed hearts. Gradually and imperceptibly the strange, silent,\r\npatient man, who was ready to bear every one\xe2\x80\x99s burden, and sought help\r\nfrom none,\xe2\x80\x94who stood aside for all, and came last, and took least, yet\r\nwas foremost to share his little all with any who needed,\xe2\x80\x94the man who,\r\nin cold nights, would give up his tattered blanket to add to the\r\ncomfort of some woman who shivered with sickness, and who filled the\r\nbaskets of the weaker ones in the field, at the terrible risk of coming\r\nshort in his own measure,\xe2\x80\x94and who, though pursued with unrelenting\r\ncruelty by their common tyrant, never joined in uttering a word of\r\nreviling or cursing,\xe2\x80\x94this man, at last, began to have a strange power\r\nover them; and, when the more pressing season was past, and they were\r\nallowed again their Sundays for their own use, many would gather\r\ntogether to hear from him of Jesus. They would gladly have met to hear,\r\nand pray, and sing, in some place, together; but Legree would not\r\npermit it, and more than once broke up such attempts, with oaths and\r\nbrutal execrations,\xe2\x80\x94so that the blessed news had to circulate from\r\nindividual to individual. Yet who can speak the simple joy with which\r\nsome of those poor outcasts, to whom life was a joyless journey to a\r\ndark unknown, heard of a compassionate Redeemer and a heavenly home? It\r\nis the statement of missionaries, that, of all races of the earth, none\r\nhave received the Gospel with such eager docility as the African. The\r\nprinciple of reliance and unquestioning faith, which is its foundation,\r\nis more a native element in this race than any other; and it has often\r\nbeen found among them, that a stray seed of truth, borne on some breeze\r\nof accident into hearts the most ignorant, has sprung up into fruit,\r\nwhose abundance has shamed that of higher and more skilful culture.\r\n\r\nThe poor mulatto woman, whose simple faith had been well-nigh crushed\r\nand overwhelmed, by the avalanche of cruelty and wrong which had fallen\r\nupon her, felt her soul raised up by the hymns and passages of Holy\r\nWrit, which this lowly missionary breathed into her ear in intervals,\r\nas they were going to and returning from work; and even the half-crazed\r\nand wandering mind of Cassy was soothed and calmed by his simple and\r\nunobtrusive influences.\r\n\r\nStung to madness and despair by the crushing agonies of a life, Cassy\r\nhad often resolved in her soul an hour of retribution, when her hand\r\nshould avenge on her oppressor all the injustice and cruelty to which\r\nshe had been witness, or which _she_ had in her own person suffered.\r\n\r\nOne night, after all in Tom\xe2\x80\x99s cabin were sunk in sleep, he was suddenly\r\naroused by seeing her face at the hole between the logs, that served\r\nfor a window. She made a silent gesture for him to come out.\r\n\r\nTom came out the door. It was between one and two o\xe2\x80\x99clock at\r\nnight,\xe2\x80\x94broad, calm, still moonlight. Tom remarked, as the light of the\r\nmoon fell upon Cassy\xe2\x80\x99s large, black eyes, that there was a wild and\r\npeculiar glare in them, unlike their wonted fixed despair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome here, Father Tom,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, laying her small hand on his wrist,\r\nand drawing him forward with a force as if the hand were of steel;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9ccome here,\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99ve news for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, Misse Cassy?\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, anxiously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTom, wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t you like your liberty?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall have it, Misse, in God\xe2\x80\x99s time,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom. \xe2\x80\x9cAy, but you may\r\nhave it tonight,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy, with a flash of sudden energy. \xe2\x80\x9cCome on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom hesitated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome!\xe2\x80\x9d said she, in a whisper, fixing her black eyes on him. \xe2\x80\x9cCome\r\nalong! He\xe2\x80\x99s asleep\xe2\x80\x94sound. I put enough into his brandy to keep him so.\r\nI wish I\xe2\x80\x99d had more,\xe2\x80\x94I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have wanted you. But come, the back\r\ndoor is unlocked; there\xe2\x80\x99s an axe there, I put it there,\xe2\x80\x94his room door\r\nis open; I\xe2\x80\x99ll show you the way. I\xe2\x80\x99d a done it myself, only my arms are\r\nso weak. Come along!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot for ten thousand worlds, Misse!\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, firmly, stopping and\r\nholding her back, as she was pressing forward.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut think of all these poor creatures,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy. \xe2\x80\x9cWe might set them\r\nall free, and go somewhere in the swamps, and find an island, and live\r\nby ourselves; I\xe2\x80\x99ve heard of its being done. Any life is better than\r\nthis.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, firmly. \xe2\x80\x9cNo! good never comes of wickedness. I\xe2\x80\x99d sooner\r\nchop my right hand off!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen _I_ shall do it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy, turning.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Misse Cassy!\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, throwing himself before her, \xe2\x80\x9cfor the dear\r\nLord\xe2\x80\x99s sake that died for ye, don\xe2\x80\x99t sell your precious soul to the\r\ndevil, that way! Nothing but evil will come of it. The Lord hasn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ncalled us to wrath. We must suffer, and wait his time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait!\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy. \xe2\x80\x9cHaven\xe2\x80\x99t I waited?\xe2\x80\x94waited till my head is dizzy and\r\nmy heart sick? What has he made me suffer? What has he made hundreds of\r\npoor creatures suffer? Isn\xe2\x80\x99t he wringing the life-blood out of you? I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\ncalled on; they call me! His time\xe2\x80\x99s come, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll have his heart\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nblood!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, no!\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, holding her small hands, which were clenched\r\nwith spasmodic violence. \xe2\x80\x9cNo, ye poor, lost soul, that ye mustn\xe2\x80\x99t do.\r\nThe dear, blessed Lord never shed no blood but his own, and that he\r\npoured out for us when we was enemies. Lord, help us to follow his\r\nsteps, and love our enemies.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLove!\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy, with a fierce glare; \xe2\x80\x9clove _such_ enemies! It isn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nin flesh and blood.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Misse, it isn\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, looking up; \xe2\x80\x9cbut _He_ gives it to us,\r\nand that\xe2\x80\x99s the victory. When we can love and pray over all and through\r\nall, the battle\xe2\x80\x99s past, and the victory\xe2\x80\x99s come,\xe2\x80\x94glory be to God!\xe2\x80\x9d And,\r\nwith streaming eyes and choking voice, the black man looked up to\r\nheaven.\r\n\r\nAnd this, oh Africa! latest called of nations,\xe2\x80\x94called to the crown of\r\nthorns, the scourge, the bloody sweat, the cross of agony,\xe2\x80\x94this is to\r\nbe _thy_ victory; by this shalt thou reign with Christ when his kingdom\r\nshall come on earth.\r\n\r\nThe deep fervor of Tom\xe2\x80\x99s feelings, the softness of his voice, his\r\ntears, fell like dew on the wild, unsettled spirit of the poor woman. A\r\nsoftness gathered over the lurid fires of her eye; she looked down, and\r\nTom could feel the relaxing muscles of her hands, as she said,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDidn\xe2\x80\x99t I tell you that evil spirits followed me? O! Father Tom, I\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t pray,\xe2\x80\x94I wish I could. I never have prayed since my children were\r\nsold! What you say must be right, I know it must; but when I try to\r\npray, I can only hate and curse. I can\xe2\x80\x99t pray!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor soul!\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, compassionately. \xe2\x80\x9cSatan desires to have ye, and\r\nsift ye as wheat. I pray the Lord for ye. O! Misse Cassy, turn to the\r\ndear Lord Jesus. He came to bind up the broken-hearted, and comfort all\r\nthat mourn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCassy stood silent, while large, heavy tears dropped from her downcast\r\neyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMisse Cassy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, in a hesitating tone, after surveying her in\r\nsilence, \xe2\x80\x9cif ye only could get away from here,\xe2\x80\x94if the thing was\r\npossible,\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99d \xe2\x80\x99vise ye and Emmeline to do it; that is, if ye could go\r\nwithout blood-guiltiness,\xe2\x80\x94not otherwise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould you try it with us, Father Tom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom; \xe2\x80\x9ctime was when I would; but the Lord\xe2\x80\x99s given me a work\r\namong these yer poor souls, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll stay with \xe2\x80\x99em and bear my cross\r\nwith \xe2\x80\x99em till the end. It\xe2\x80\x99s different with you; it\xe2\x80\x99s a snare to\r\nyou,\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s more\xe2\x80\x99n you can stand,\xe2\x80\x94and you\xe2\x80\x99d better go, if you can.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know no way but through the grave,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy. \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s no beast or\r\nbird but can find a home some where; even the snakes and the alligators\r\nhave their places to lie down and be quiet; but there\xe2\x80\x99s no place for\r\nus. Down in the darkest swamps, their dogs will hunt us out, and find\r\nus. Everybody and everything is against us; even the very beasts side\r\nagainst us,\xe2\x80\x94and where shall we go?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom stood silent; at length he said,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHim that saved Daniel in the den of lions,\xe2\x80\x94that saved the children in\r\nthe fiery furnace,\xe2\x80\x94Him that walked on the sea, and bade the winds be\r\nstill,\xe2\x80\x94He\xe2\x80\x99s alive yet; and I\xe2\x80\x99ve faith to believe he can deliver you.\r\nTry it, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll pray, with all my might, for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBy what strange law of mind is it that an idea long overlooked, and\r\ntrodden under foot as a useless stone, suddenly sparkles out in new\r\nlight, as a discovered diamond?\r\n\r\nCassy had often revolved, for hours, all possible or probable schemes\r\nof escape, and dismissed them all, as hopeless and impracticable; but\r\nat this moment there flashed through her mind a plan, so simple and\r\nfeasible in all its details, as to awaken an instant hope.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFather Tom, I\xe2\x80\x99ll try it!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, suddenly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAmen!\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom; \xe2\x80\x9cthe Lord help ye!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXIX\r\nThe Stratagem\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe way of the wicked is as darkness; he knoweth not at what he\r\nstumbleth.\xe2\x80\x9d[1]\r\n\r\n\r\n [1] Prov. 4:19.\r\n\r\n\r\nThe garret of the house that Legree occupied, like most other garrets,\r\nwas a great, desolate space, dusty, hung with cobwebs, and littered\r\nwith cast-off lumber. The opulent family that had inhabited the house\r\nin the days of its splendor had imported a great deal of splendid\r\nfurniture, some of which they had taken away with them, while some\r\nremained standing desolate in mouldering, unoccupied rooms, or stored\r\naway in this place. One or two immense packing-boxes, in which this\r\nfurniture was brought, stood against the sides of the garret. There was\r\na small window there, which let in, through its dingy, dusty panes, a\r\nscanty, uncertain light on the tall, high-backed chairs and dusty\r\ntables, that had once seen better days. Altogether, it was a weird and\r\nghostly place; but, ghostly as it was, it wanted not in legends among\r\nthe superstitious negroes, to increase its terrors. Some few years\r\nbefore, a negro woman, who had incurred Legree\xe2\x80\x99s displeasure, was\r\nconfined there for several weeks. What passed there, we do not say; the\r\nnegroes used to whisper darkly to each other; but it was known that the\r\nbody of the unfortunate creature was one day taken down from there, and\r\nburied; and, after that, it was said that oaths and cursings, and the\r\nsound of violent blows, used to ring through that old garret, and\r\nmingled with wailings and groans of despair. Once, when Legree chanced\r\nto overhear something of this kind, he flew into a violent passion, and\r\nswore that the next one that told stories about that garret should have\r\nan opportunity of knowing what was there, for he would chain them up\r\nthere for a week. This hint was enough to repress talking, though, of\r\ncourse, it did not disturb the credit of the story in the least.\r\n\r\nGradually, the staircase that led to the garret, and even the\r\npassage-way to the staircase, were avoided by every one in the house,\r\nfrom every one fearing to speak of it, and the legend was gradually\r\nfalling into desuetude. It had suddenly occurred to Cassy to make use\r\nof the superstitious excitability, which was so great in Legree, for\r\nthe purpose of her liberation, and that of her fellow-sufferer.\r\n\r\nThe sleeping-room of Cassy was directly under the garret. One day,\r\nwithout consulting Legree, she suddenly took it upon her, with some\r\nconsiderable ostentation, to change all the furniture and appurtenances\r\nof the room to one at some considerable distance. The under-servants,\r\nwho were called on to effect this movement, were running and bustling\r\nabout with great zeal and confusion, when Legree returned from a ride.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHallo! you Cass!\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat\xe2\x80\x99s in the wind now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing; only I choose to have another room,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy, doggedly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what for, pray?\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI choose to,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe devil you do! and what for?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d like to get some sleep, now and then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSleep! well, what hinders your sleeping?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI could tell, I suppose, if you want to hear,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy, dryly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak out, you minx!\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO! nothing. I suppose it wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t disturb _you!_ Only groans, and\r\npeople scuffing, and rolling round on the garret floor, half the night,\r\nfrom twelve to morning!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeople up garret!\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, uneasily, but forcing a laugh; \xe2\x80\x9cwho\r\nare they, Cassy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCassy raised her sharp, black eyes, and looked in the face of Legree,\r\nwith an expression that went through his bones, as she said, \xe2\x80\x9cTo be\r\nsure, Simon, who are they? I\xe2\x80\x99d like to have _you_ tell me. You don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nknow, I suppose!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith an oath, Legree struck at her with his riding-whip; but she glided\r\nto one side, and passed through the door, and looking back, said, \xe2\x80\x9cIf\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99ll sleep in that room, you\xe2\x80\x99ll know all about it. Perhaps you\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nbetter try it!\xe2\x80\x9d and then immediately she shut and locked the door.\r\n\r\nLegree blustered and swore, and threatened to break down the door; but\r\napparently thought better of it, and walked uneasily into the\r\nsitting-room. Cassy perceived that her shaft had struck home; and, from\r\nthat hour, with the most exquisite address, she never ceased to\r\ncontinue the train of influences she had begun.\r\n\r\nIn a knot-hole of the garret, that had opened, she had inserted the\r\nneck of an old bottle, in such a manner that when there was the least\r\nwind, most doleful and lugubrious wailing sounds proceeded from it,\r\nwhich, in a high wind, increased to a perfect shriek, such as to\r\ncredulous and superstitious ears might easily seem to be that of horror\r\nand despair.\r\n\r\nThese sounds were, from time to time, heard by the servants, and\r\nrevived in full force the memory of the old ghost legend. A\r\nsuperstitious creeping horror seemed to fill the house; and though no\r\none dared to breathe it to Legree, he found himself encompassed by it,\r\nas by an atmosphere.\r\n\r\nNo one is so thoroughly superstitious as the godless man. The Christian\r\nis composed by the belief of a wise, all-ruling Father, whose presence\r\nfills the void unknown with light and order; but to the man who has\r\ndethroned God, the spirit-land is, indeed, in the words of the Hebrew\r\npoet, \xe2\x80\x9ca land of darkness and the shadow of death,\xe2\x80\x9d without any order,\r\nwhere the light is as darkness. Life and death to him are haunted\r\ngrounds, filled with goblin forms of vague and shadowy dread.\r\n\r\nLegree had had the slumbering moral elements in him roused by his\r\nencounters with Tom,\xe2\x80\x94roused, only to be resisted by the determinate\r\nforce of evil; but still there was a thrill and commotion of the dark,\r\ninner world, produced by every word, or prayer, or hymn, that reacted\r\nin superstitious dread.\r\n\r\nThe influence of Cassy over him was of a strange and singular kind. He\r\nwas her owner, her tyrant and tormentor. She was, as he knew, wholly,\r\nand without any possibility of help or redress, in his hands; and yet\r\nso it is, that the most brutal man cannot live in constant association\r\nwith a strong female influence, and not be greatly controlled by it.\r\nWhen he first bought her, she was, as she said, a woman delicately\r\nbred; and then he crushed her, without scruple, beneath the foot of his\r\nbrutality. But, as time, and debasing influences, and despair, hardened\r\nwomanhood within her, and waked the fires of fiercer passions, she had\r\nbecome in a measure his mistress, and he alternately tyrannized over\r\nand dreaded her.\r\n\r\nThis influence had become more harassing and decided, since partial\r\ninsanity had given a strange, weird, unsettled cast to all her words\r\nand language.\r\n\r\nA night or two after this, Legree was sitting in the old sitting-room,\r\nby the side of a flickering wood fire, that threw uncertain glances\r\nround the room. It was a stormy, windy night, such as raises whole\r\nsquadrons of nondescript noises in rickety old houses. Windows were\r\nrattling, shutters flapping, and wind carousing, rumbling, and tumbling\r\ndown the chimney, and, every once in a while, puffing out smoke and\r\nashes, as if a legion of spirits were coming after them. Legree had\r\nbeen casting up accounts and reading newspapers for some hours, while\r\nCassy sat in the corner; sullenly looking into the fire. Legree laid\r\ndown his paper, and seeing an old book lying on the table, which he had\r\nnoticed Cassy reading, the first part of the evening, took it up, and\r\nbegan to turn it over. It was one of those collections of stories of\r\nbloody murders, ghostly legends, and supernatural visitations, which,\r\ncoarsely got up and illustrated, have a strange fascination for one who\r\nonce begins to read them.\r\n\r\nLegree poohed and pished, but read, turning page after page, till,\r\nfinally, after reading some way, he threw down the book, with an oath.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t believe in ghosts, do you, Cass?\xe2\x80\x9d said he, taking the tongs\r\nand settling the fire. \xe2\x80\x9cI thought you\xe2\x80\x99d more sense than to let noises\r\nscare _you_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo matter what I believe,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy, sullenly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFellows used to try to frighten me with their yarns at sea,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nLegree. \xe2\x80\x9cNever come it round me that way. I\xe2\x80\x99m too tough for any such\r\ntrash, tell ye.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCassy sat looking intensely at him in the shadow of the corner. There\r\nwas that strange light in her eyes that always impressed Legree with\r\nuneasiness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThem noises was nothing but rats and the wind,\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree. \xe2\x80\x9cRats\r\nwill make a devil of a noise. I used to hear \xe2\x80\x99em sometimes down in the\r\nhold of the ship; and wind,\xe2\x80\x94Lord\xe2\x80\x99s sake! ye can make anything out o\xe2\x80\x99\r\nwind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCassy knew Legree was uneasy under her eyes, and, therefore, she made\r\nno answer, but sat fixing them on him, with that strange, unearthly\r\nexpression, as before.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, speak out, woman,\xe2\x80\x94don\xe2\x80\x99t you think so?\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan rats walk down stairs, and come walking through the entry, and\r\nopen a door when you\xe2\x80\x99ve locked it and set a chair against it?\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nCassy; \xe2\x80\x9cand come walk, walk, walking right up to your bed, and put out\r\ntheir hand, so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCassy kept her glittering eyes fixed on Legree, as she spoke, and he\r\nstared at her like a man in the nightmare, till, when she finished by\r\nlaying her hand, icy cold, on his, he sprung back, with an oath.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWoman! what do you mean? Nobody did?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, no,\xe2\x80\x94of course not,\xe2\x80\x94did I say they did?\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy, with a smile of\r\nchilling derision.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut\xe2\x80\x94did\xe2\x80\x94have you really seen?\xe2\x80\x94Come, Cass, what is it, now,\xe2\x80\x94speak out!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou may sleep there, yourself,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy, \xe2\x80\x9cif you want to know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid it come from the garret, Cassy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_It_,\xe2\x80\x94what?\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, what you told of\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t tell you anything,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy, with dogged sullenness.\r\n\r\nLegree walked up and down the room, uneasily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll have this yer thing examined. I\xe2\x80\x99ll look into it, this very night.\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll take my pistols\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy; \xe2\x80\x9csleep in that room. I\xe2\x80\x99d like to see you doing it.\r\nFire your pistols,\xe2\x80\x94do!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLegree stamped his foot, and swore violently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t swear,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy; \xe2\x80\x9cnobody knows who may be hearing you. Hark!\r\nWhat was that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, starting.\r\n\r\nA heavy old Dutch clock, that stood in the corner of the room, began,\r\nand slowly struck twelve.\r\n\r\nFor some reason or other, Legree neither spoke nor moved; a vague\r\nhorror fell on him; while Cassy, with a keen, sneering glitter in her\r\neyes, stood looking at him, counting the strokes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwelve o\xe2\x80\x99clock; well _now_ we\xe2\x80\x99ll see,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, turning, and opening\r\nthe door into the passage-way, and standing as if listening.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHark! What\xe2\x80\x99s that?\xe2\x80\x9d said she, raising her finger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s only the wind,\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you hear how cursedly it\r\nblows?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSimon, come here,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy, in a whisper, laying her hand on his,\r\nand leading him to the foot of the stairs: \xe2\x80\x9cdo you know what _that_ is?\r\nHark!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA wild shriek came pealing down the stairway.
