It came from the garret.\r\nLegree\xe2\x80\x99s knees knocked together; his face grew white with fear.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHadn\xe2\x80\x99t you better get your pistols?\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy, with a sneer that\r\nfroze Legree\xe2\x80\x99s blood. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s time this thing was looked into, you know.\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99d like to have you go up now; _they\xe2\x80\x99re at it_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI won\xe2\x80\x99t go!\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, with an oath.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy not? There an\xe2\x80\x99t any such thing as ghosts, you know! Come!\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\nCassy flitted up the winding stairway, laughing, and looking back after\r\nhim. \xe2\x80\x9cCome on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe you _are_ the devil!\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree. \xe2\x80\x9cCome back you hag,\xe2\x80\x94come\r\nback, Cass! You shan\xe2\x80\x99t go!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut Cassy laughed wildly, and fled on. He heard her open the entry\r\ndoors that led to the garret. A wild gust of wind swept down,\r\nextinguishing the candle he held in his hand, and with it the fearful,\r\nunearthly screams; they seemed to be shrieked in his very ear.\r\n\r\nLegree fled frantically into the parlor, whither, in a few moments, he\r\nwas followed by Cassy, pale, calm, cold as an avenging spirit, and with\r\nthat same fearful light in her eye.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope you are satisfied,\xe2\x80\x9d said she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBlast you, Cass!\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat for?\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy. \xe2\x80\x9cI only went up and shut the doors. _What\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\nmatter with that garret_, Simon, do you suppose?\xe2\x80\x9d said she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNone of your business!\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, it an\xe2\x80\x99t? Well,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy, \xe2\x80\x9cat any rate, I\xe2\x80\x99m glad _I_ don\xe2\x80\x99t sleep\r\nunder it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnticipating the rising of the wind, that very evening, Cassy had been\r\nup and opened the garret window. Of course, the moment the doors were\r\nopened, the wind had drafted down, and extinguished the light.\r\n\r\nThis may serve as a specimen of the game that Cassy played with Legree,\r\nuntil he would sooner have put his head into a lion\xe2\x80\x99s mouth than to\r\nhave explored that garret. Meanwhile, in the night, when everybody else\r\nwas asleep, Cassy slowly and carefully accumulated there a stock of\r\nprovisions sufficient to afford subsistence for some time; she\r\ntransferred, article by article, a greater part of her own and\r\nEmmeline\xe2\x80\x99s wardrobe. All things being arranged, they only waited a\r\nfitting opportunity to put their plan in execution.\r\n\r\nBy cajoling Legree, and taking advantage of a good-natured interval,\r\nCassy had got him to take her with him to the neighboring town, which\r\nwas situated directly on the Red River. With a memory sharpened to\r\nalmost preternatural clearness, she remarked every turn in the road,\r\nand formed a mental estimate of the time to be occupied in traversing\r\nit.\r\n\r\nAt the time when all was matured for action, our readers may, perhaps,\r\nlike to look behind the scenes, and see the final _coup d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\xa9tat_.\r\n\r\nIt was now near evening, Legree had been absent, on a ride to a\r\nneighboring farm. For many days Cassy had been unusually gracious and\r\naccommodating in her humors; and Legree and she had been, apparently,\r\non the best of terms. At present, we may behold her and Emmeline in the\r\nroom of the latter, busy in sorting and arranging two small bundles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, these will be large enough,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy. \xe2\x80\x9cNow put on your\r\nbonnet, and let\xe2\x80\x99s start; it\xe2\x80\x99s just about the right time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, they can see us yet,\xe2\x80\x9d said Emmeline.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mean they shall,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy, coolly. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you know that they must\r\nhave their chase after us, at any rate? The way of the thing is to be\r\njust this:\xe2\x80\x94We will steal out of the back door, and run down by the\r\nquarters. Sambo or Quimbo will be sure to see us. They will give chase,\r\nand we will get into the swamp; then, they can\xe2\x80\x99t follow us any further\r\ntill they go up and give the alarm, and turn out the dogs, and so on;\r\nand, while they are blundering round, and tumbling over each other, as\r\nthey always do, you and I will slip along to the creek, that runs back\r\nof the house, and wade along in it, till we get opposite the back door.\r\nThat will put the dogs all at fault; for scent won\xe2\x80\x99t lie in the water.\r\nEvery one will run out of the house to look after us, and then we\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nwhip in at the back door, and up into the garret, where I\xe2\x80\x99ve got a nice\r\nbed made up in one of the great boxes. We must stay in that garret a\r\ngood while, for, I tell you, he will raise heaven and earth after us.\r\nHe\xe2\x80\x99ll muster some of those old overseers on the other plantations, and\r\nhave a great hunt; and they\xe2\x80\x99ll go over every inch of ground in that\r\nswamp. He makes it his boast that nobody ever got away from him. So let\r\nhim hunt at his leisure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCassy, how well you have planned it!\xe2\x80\x9d said Emmeline. \xe2\x80\x9cWho ever would\r\nhave thought of it, but you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was neither pleasure nor exultation in Cassy\xe2\x80\x99s eyes,\xe2\x80\x94only a\r\ndespairing firmness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, reaching her hand to Emmeline.\r\n\r\nThe two fugitives glided noiselessly from the house, and flitted,\r\nthrough the gathering shadows of evening, along by the quarters. The\r\ncrescent moon, set like a silver signet in the western sky, delayed a\r\nlittle the approach of night. As Cassy expected, when quite near the\r\nverge of the swamps that encircled the plantation, they heard a voice\r\ncalling to them to stop. It was not Sambo, however, but Legree, who was\r\npursuing them with violent execrations. At the sound, the feebler\r\nspirit of Emmeline gave way; and, laying hold of Cassy\xe2\x80\x99s arm, she said,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Cassy, I\xe2\x80\x99m going to faint!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you do, I\xe2\x80\x99ll kill you!\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy, drawing a small, glittering\r\nstiletto, and flashing it before the eyes of the girl.\r\n\r\nThe diversion accomplished the purpose. Emmeline did not faint, and\r\nsucceeded in plunging, with Cassy, into a part of the labyrinth of\r\nswamp, so deep and dark that it was perfectly hopeless for Legree to\r\nthink of following them, without assistance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, chuckling brutally; \xe2\x80\x9cat any rate, they\xe2\x80\x99ve got\r\nthemselves into a trap now\xe2\x80\x94the baggage! They\xe2\x80\x99re safe enough. They shall\r\nsweat for it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHulloa, there! Sambo! Quimbo! All hands!\xe2\x80\x9d called Legree, coming to the\r\nquarters, when the men and women were just returning from work.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s two runaways in the swamps. I\xe2\x80\x99ll give five dollars to any\r\nnigger as catches \xe2\x80\x99em. Turn out the dogs! Turn out Tiger, and Fury, and\r\nthe rest!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe sensation produced by this news was immediate. Many of the men\r\nsprang forward, officiously, to offer their services, either from the\r\nhope of the reward, or from that cringing subserviency which is one of\r\nthe most baleful effects of slavery. Some ran one way, and some\r\nanother. Some were for getting flambeaux of pine-knots. Some were\r\nuncoupling the dogs, whose hoarse, savage bay added not a little to the\r\nanimation of the scene.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMas\xe2\x80\x99r, shall we shoot \xe2\x80\x99em, if can\xe2\x80\x99t cotch \xe2\x80\x99em?\xe2\x80\x9d said Sambo, to whom\r\nhis master brought out a rifle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou may fire on Cass, if you like; it\xe2\x80\x99s time she was gone to the\r\ndevil, where she belongs; but the gal, not,\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd now,\r\nboys, be spry and smart. Five dollars for him that gets \xe2\x80\x99em; and a\r\nglass of spirits to every one of you, anyhow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe whole band, with the glare of blazing torches, and whoop, and\r\nshout, and savage yell, of man and beast, proceeded down to the swamp,\r\nfollowed, at some distance, by every servant in the house. The\r\nestablishment was, of a consequence, wholly deserted, when Cassy and\r\nEmmeline glided into it the back way. The whooping and shouts of their\r\npursuers were still filling the air; and, looking from the sitting-room\r\nwindows, Cassy and Emmeline could see the troop, with their flambeaux,\r\njust dispersing themselves along the edge of the swamp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee there!\xe2\x80\x9d said Emmeline, pointing to Cassy; \xe2\x80\x9cthe hunt is begun! Look\r\nhow those lights dance about! Hark! the dogs! Don\xe2\x80\x99t you hear? If we\r\nwere only _there_, our chances wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be worth a picayune. O, for\r\npity\xe2\x80\x99s sake, do let\xe2\x80\x99s hide ourselves. Quick!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s no occasion for hurry,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy, coolly; \xe2\x80\x9cthey are all out\r\nafter the hunt,\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s the amusement of the evening! We\xe2\x80\x99ll go up\r\nstairs, by and by. Meanwhile,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, deliberately taking a key from\r\nthe pocket of a coat that Legree had thrown down in his hurry,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cmeanwhile I shall take something to pay our passage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe unlocked the desk, took from it a roll of bills, which she counted\r\nover rapidly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, don\xe2\x80\x99t let\xe2\x80\x99s do that!\xe2\x80\x9d said Emmeline.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy; \xe2\x80\x9cwhy not? Would you have us starve in the swamps,\r\nor have that that will pay our way to the free states. Money will do\r\nanything, girl.\xe2\x80\x9d And, as she spoke, she put the money in her bosom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt would be stealing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Emmeline, in a distressed whisper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStealing!\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy, with a scornful laugh. \xe2\x80\x9cThey who steal body and\r\nsoul needn\xe2\x80\x99t talk to us. Every one of these bills is stolen,\xe2\x80\x94stolen\r\nfrom poor, starving, sweating creatures, who must go to the devil at\r\nlast, for his profit. Let _him_ talk about stealing! But come, we may\r\nas well go up garret; I\xe2\x80\x99ve got a stock of candles there, and some books\r\nto pass away the time. You may be pretty sure they won\xe2\x80\x99t come _there_\r\nto inquire after us. If they do, I\xe2\x80\x99ll play ghost for them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen Emmeline reached the garret, she found an immense box, in which\r\nsome heavy pieces of furniture had once been brought, turned on its\r\nside, so that the opening faced the wall, or rather the eaves. Cassy\r\nlit a small lamp, and creeping round under the eaves, they established\r\nthemselves in it. It was spread with a couple of small mattresses and\r\nsome pillows; a box near by was plentifully stored with candles,\r\nprovisions, and all the clothing necessary to their journey, which\r\nCassy had arranged into bundles of an astonishingly small compass.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy, as she fixed the lamp into a small hook, which she\r\nhad driven into the side of the box for that purpose; \xe2\x80\x9cthis is to be\r\nour home for the present. How do you like it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you sure they won\xe2\x80\x99t come and search the garret?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d like to see Simon Legree doing that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy. \xe2\x80\x9cNo, indeed; he\r\nwill be too glad to keep away. As to the servants, they would any of\r\nthem stand and be shot, sooner than show their faces here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSomewhat reassured, Emmeline settled herself back on her pillow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat did you mean, Cassy, by saying you would kill me?\xe2\x80\x9d she said,\r\nsimply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI meant to stop your fainting,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy, \xe2\x80\x9cand I did do it. And now\r\nI tell you, Emmeline, you must make up your mind _not_ to faint, let\r\nwhat will come; there\xe2\x80\x99s no sort of need of it. If I had not stopped\r\nyou, that wretch might have had his hands on you now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEmmeline shuddered.\r\n\r\nThe two remained some time in silence. Cassy busied herself with a\r\nFrench book; Emmeline, overcome with the exhaustion, fell into a doze,\r\nand slept some time. She was awakened by loud shouts and outcries, the\r\ntramp of horses\xe2\x80\x99 feet, and the baying of dogs. She started up, with a\r\nfaint shriek.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly the hunt coming back,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy, coolly; \xe2\x80\x9cnever fear. Look out\r\nof this knot-hole. Don\xe2\x80\x99t you see \xe2\x80\x99em all down there? Simon has to give\r\nup, for this night. Look, how muddy his horse is, flouncing about in\r\nthe swamp; the dogs, too, look rather crestfallen. Ah, my good sir,\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99ll have to try the race again and again,\xe2\x80\x94the game isn\xe2\x80\x99t there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, don\xe2\x80\x99t speak a word!\xe2\x80\x9d said Emmeline; \xe2\x80\x9cwhat if they should hear you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf they do hear anything, it will make them very particular to keep\r\naway,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy. \xe2\x80\x9cNo danger; we may make any noise we please, and it\r\nwill only add to the effect.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt length the stillness of midnight settled down over the house.\r\nLegree, cursing his ill luck, and vowing dire vengeance on the morrow,\r\nwent to bed.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XL\r\nThe Martyr\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDeem not the just by Heaven forgot!\r\n    Though life its common gifts deny,\xe2\x80\x94\r\nThough, with a crushed and bleeding heart,\r\n    And spurned of man, he goes to die!\r\nFor God hath marked each sorrowing day,\r\n    And numbered every bitter tear,\r\nAnd heaven\xe2\x80\x99s long years of bliss shall pay\r\n    For all his children suffer here.\xe2\x80\x9d BRYANT.[1]\r\n\r\n\r\n [1] This poem does not appear in the collected works of William Cullen\r\n Bryant, nor in the collected poems of his brother, John Howard Bryant.\r\n It was probably copied from a newspaper or magazine.\r\n\r\n\r\nThe longest way must have its close,\xe2\x80\x94the gloomiest night will wear on\r\nto a morning. An eternal, inexorable lapse of moments is ever hurrying\r\nthe day of the evil to an eternal night, and the night of the just to\r\nan eternal day. We have walked with our humble friend thus far in the\r\nvalley of slavery; first through flowery fields of ease and indulgence,\r\nthen through heart-breaking separations from all that man holds dear.\r\nAgain, we have waited with him in a sunny island, where generous hands\r\nconcealed his chains with flowers; and, lastly, we have followed him\r\nwhen the last ray of earthly hope went out in night, and seen how, in\r\nthe blackness of earthly darkness, the firmament of the unseen has\r\nblazed with stars of new and significant lustre.\r\n\r\nThe morning-star now stands over the tops of the mountains, and gales\r\nand breezes, not of earth, show that the gates of day are unclosing.\r\n\r\nThe escape of Cassy and Emmeline irritated the before surly temper of\r\nLegree to the last degree; and his fury, as was to be expected, fell\r\nupon the defenceless head of Tom. When he hurriedly announced the\r\ntidings among his hands, there was a sudden light in Tom\xe2\x80\x99s eye, a\r\nsudden upraising of his hands, that did not escape him. He saw that he\r\ndid not join the muster of the pursuers. He thought of forcing him to\r\ndo it; but, having had, of old, experience of his inflexibility when\r\ncommanded to take part in any deed of inhumanity, he would not, in his\r\nhurry, stop to enter into any conflict with him.\r\n\r\nTom, therefore, remained behind, with a few who had learned of him to\r\npray, and offered up prayers for the escape of the fugitives.\r\n\r\nWhen Legree returned, baffled and disappointed, all the long-working\r\nhatred of his soul towards his slave began to gather in a deadly and\r\ndesperate form. Had not this man braved him,\xe2\x80\x94steadily, powerfully,\r\nresistlessly,\xe2\x80\x94ever since he bought him? Was there not a spirit in him\r\nwhich, silent as it was, burned on him like the fires of perdition?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI _hate_ him!\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, that night, as he sat up in his bed; \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\n_hate_ him! And isn\xe2\x80\x99t he MINE? Can\xe2\x80\x99t I do what I like with him? Who\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nto hinder, I wonder?\xe2\x80\x9d And Legree clenched his fist, and shook it, as if\r\nhe had something in his hands that he could rend in pieces.\r\n\r\nBut, then, Tom was a faithful, valuable servant; and, although Legree\r\nhated him the more for that, yet the consideration was still somewhat\r\nof a restraint to him.\r\n\r\nThe next morning, he determined to say nothing, as yet; to assemble a\r\nparty, from some neighboring plantations, with dogs and guns; to\r\nsurround the swamp, and go about the hunt systematically. If it\r\nsucceeded, well and good; if not, he would summon Tom before him,\r\nand\xe2\x80\x94his teeth clenched and his blood boiled\xe2\x80\x94_then_ he would break the\r\nfellow down, or\xe2\x80\x94there was a dire inward whisper, to which his soul\r\nassented.\r\n\r\nYe say that the _interest_ of the master is a sufficient safeguard for\r\nthe slave. In the fury of man\xe2\x80\x99s mad will, he will wittingly, and with\r\nopen eye, sell his own soul to the devil to gain his ends; and will he\r\nbe more careful of his neighbor\xe2\x80\x99s body?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy, the next day, from the garret, as she reconnoitred\r\nthrough the knot-hole, \xe2\x80\x9cthe hunt\xe2\x80\x99s going to begin again, today!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThree or four mounted horsemen were curvetting about, on the space in\r\nfront of the house; and one or two leashes of strange dogs were\r\nstruggling with the negroes who held them, baying and barking at each\r\nother.\r\n\r\nThe men are, two of them, overseers of plantations in the vicinity; and\r\nothers were some of Legree\xe2\x80\x99s associates at the tavern-bar of a\r\nneighboring city, who had come for the interest of the sport. A more\r\nhard-favored set, perhaps, could not be imagined. Legree was serving\r\nbrandy, profusely, round among them, as also among the negroes, who had\r\nbeen detailed from the various plantations for this service; for it was\r\nan object to make every service of this kind, among the negroes, as\r\nmuch of a holiday as possible.\r\n\r\nCassy placed her ear at the knot-hole; and, as the morning air blew\r\ndirectly towards the house, she could overhear a good deal of the\r\nconversation. A grave sneer overcast the dark, severe gravity of her\r\nface, as she listened, and heard them divide out the ground, discuss\r\nthe rival merits of the dogs, give orders about firing, and the\r\ntreatment of each, in case of capture.\r\n\r\nCassy drew back; and, clasping her hands, looked upward, and said, \xe2\x80\x9cO,\r\ngreat Almighty God! we are _all_ sinners; but what have _we_ done, more\r\nthan all the rest of the world, that we should be treated so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was a terrible earnestness in her face and voice, as she spoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t for _you_, child,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, looking at Emmeline, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d\r\n_go_ out to them; and I\xe2\x80\x99d thank any one of them that _would_ shoot me\r\ndown; for what use will freedom be to me? Can it give me back my\r\nchildren, or make me what I used to be?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEmmeline, in her child-like simplicity, was half afraid of the dark\r\nmoods of Cassy. She looked perplexed, but made no answer. She only took\r\nher hand, with a gentle, caressing movement.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy, trying to draw it away; \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99ll get me to loving\r\nyou; and I never mean to love anything, again!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor Cassy!\xe2\x80\x9d said Emmeline, \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t feel so! If the Lord gives us\r\nliberty, perhaps he\xe2\x80\x99ll give you back your daughter; at any rate, I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nbe like a daughter to you. I know I\xe2\x80\x99ll never see my poor old mother\r\nagain! I shall love you, Cassy, whether you love me or not!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe gentle, child-like spirit conquered. Cassy sat down by her, put her\r\narm round her neck, stroked her soft, brown hair; and Emmeline then\r\nwondered at the beauty of her magnificent eyes, now soft with tears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Em!\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve hungered for my children, and thirsted for\r\nthem, and my eyes fail with longing for them! Here! here!\xe2\x80\x9d she said,\r\nstriking her breast, \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s all desolate, all empty! If God would give\r\nme back my children, then I could pray.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must trust him, Cassy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Emmeline; \xe2\x80\x9che is our Father!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis wrath is upon us,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy; \xe2\x80\x9che has turned away in anger.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Cassy! He will be good to us! Let us hope in Him,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nEmmeline,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI always have had hope.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nThe hunt was long, animated, and thorough, but unsuccessful; and, with\r\ngrave, ironic exultation, Cassy looked down on Legree, as, weary and\r\ndispirited, he alighted from his horse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, Quimbo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, as he stretched himself down in the\r\nsitting-room, \xe2\x80\x9cyou jest go and walk that Tom up here, right away! The\r\nold cuss is at the bottom of this yer whole matter; and I\xe2\x80\x99ll have it\r\nout of his old black hide, or I\xe2\x80\x99ll know the reason why!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSambo and Quimbo, both, though hating each other, were joined in one\r\nmind by a no less cordial hatred of Tom. Legree had told them, at\r\nfirst, that he had bought him for a general overseer, in his absence;\r\nand this had begun an ill will, on their part, which had increased, in\r\ntheir debased and servile natures, as they saw him becoming obnoxious\r\nto their master\xe2\x80\x99s displeasure. Quimbo, therefore, departed, with a\r\nwill, to execute his orders.\r\n\r\nTom heard the message with a forewarning heart; for he knew all the\r\nplan of the fugitives\xe2\x80\x99 escape, and the place of their present\r\nconcealment;\xe2\x80\x94he knew the deadly character of the man he had to deal\r\nwith, and his despotic power. But he felt strong in God to meet death,\r\nrather than betray the helpless.\r\n\r\nHe sat his basket down by the row, and, looking up, said, \xe2\x80\x9cInto thy\r\nhands I commend my spirit! Thou hast redeemed me, oh Lord God of\r\ntruth!\xe2\x80\x9d and then quietly yielded himself to the rough, brutal grasp\r\nwith which Quimbo seized him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, ay!\xe2\x80\x9d said the giant, as he dragged him along; \xe2\x80\x9cye\xe2\x80\x99ll cotch it,\r\nnow! I\xe2\x80\x99ll boun\xe2\x80\x99 Mas\xe2\x80\x99r\xe2\x80\x99s back \xe2\x80\x99s up _high!_ No sneaking out, now! Tell\r\nye, ye\xe2\x80\x99ll get it, and no mistake! See how ye\xe2\x80\x99ll look, now, helpin\xe2\x80\x99\r\nMas\xe2\x80\x99r\xe2\x80\x99s niggers to run away! See what ye\xe2\x80\x99ll get!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe savage words none of them reached that ear!\xe2\x80\x94a higher voice there\r\nwas saying, \xe2\x80\x9cFear not them that kill the body, and, after that, have no\r\nmore that they can do.\xe2\x80\x9d Nerve and bone of that poor man\xe2\x80\x99s body vibrated\r\nto those words, as if touched by the finger of God; and he felt the\r\nstrength of a thousand souls in one. As he passed along, the trees and\r\nbushes, the huts of his servitude, the whole scene of his degradation,\r\nseemed to whirl by him as the landscape by the rushing ear. His soul\r\nthrobbed,\xe2\x80\x94his home was in sight,\xe2\x80\x94and the hour of release seemed at\r\nhand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Tom!\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, walking up, and seizing him grimly by the\r\ncollar of his coat, and speaking through his teeth, in a paroxysm of\r\ndetermined rage, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you know I\xe2\x80\x99ve made up my mind to KILL YOU?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s very likely, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, calmly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI _have_,\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, with a grim, terrible calmness,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_done\xe2\x80\x94just\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x94thing_, Tom, unless you\xe2\x80\x99ll tell me what you know about\r\nthese yer gals!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom stood silent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cD\xe2\x80\x99ye hear?\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, stamping, with a roar like that of an\r\nincensed lion. \xe2\x80\x9cSpeak!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_I han\xe2\x80\x99t got nothing to tell, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r_,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, with a slow, firm,\r\ndeliberate utterance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you dare to tell me, ye old black Christian, ye don\xe2\x80\x99t _know_?\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nLegree.\r\n\r\nTom was silent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak!\xe2\x80\x9d thundered Legree, striking him furiously. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you know\r\nanything?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r; but I can\xe2\x80\x99t tell anything. _I can die!_\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLegree drew in a long breath; and, suppressing his rage, took Tom by\r\nthe arm, and, approaching his face almost to his, said, in a terrible\r\nvoice, \xe2\x80\x9cHark \xe2\x80\x99e, Tom!\xe2\x80\x94ye think, \xe2\x80\x99cause I\xe2\x80\x99ve let you off before, I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nmean what I say; but, this time, _I\xe2\x80\x99ve made up my mind_, and counted\r\nthe cost. You\xe2\x80\x99ve always stood it out again\xe2\x80\x99 me: now, _I\xe2\x80\x99ll conquer ye,\r\nor kill ye!_\xe2\x80\x94one or t\xe2\x80\x99 other. I\xe2\x80\x99ll count every drop of blood there is\r\nin you, and take \xe2\x80\x99em, one by one, till ye give up!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom looked up to his master, and answered, \xe2\x80\x9cMas\xe2\x80\x99r, if you was sick, or\r\nin trouble, or dying, and I could save ye, I\xe2\x80\x99d _give_ ye my heart\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nblood; and, if taking every drop of blood in this poor old body would\r\nsave your precious soul, I\xe2\x80\x99d give \xe2\x80\x99em freely, as the Lord gave his for\r\nme. O, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r! don\xe2\x80\x99t bring this great sin on your soul! It will hurt you\r\nmore than \xe2\x80\x99t will me! Do the worst you can, my troubles\xe2\x80\x99ll be over\r\nsoon; but, if ye don\xe2\x80\x99t repent, yours won\xe2\x80\x99t _never_ end!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLike a strange snatch of heavenly music, heard in the lull of a\r\ntempest, this burst of feeling made a moment\xe2\x80\x99s blank pause. Legree\r\nstood aghast, and looked at Tom; and there was such a silence, that the\r\ntick of the old clock could be heard, measuring, with silent touch, the\r\nlast moments of mercy and probation to that hardened heart.\r\n\r\nIt was but a moment. There was one hesitating pause,\xe2\x80\x94one irresolute,\r\nrelenting thrill,\xe2\x80\x94and the spirit of evil came back, with seven-fold\r\nvehemence; and Legree, foaming with rage, smote his victim to the\r\nground.\r\n\r\n\r\nScenes of blood and cruelty are shocking to our ear and heart. What man\r\nhas nerve to do, man has not nerve to hear. What brother-man and\r\nbrother-Christian must suffer, cannot be told us, even in our secret\r\nchamber, it so harrows the soul! And yet, oh my country! these things\r\nare done under the shadow of thy laws! O, Christ! thy church sees them,\r\nalmost in silence!\r\n\r\nBut, of old, there was One whose suffering changed an instrument of\r\ntorture, degradation and shame, into a symbol of glory, honor, and\r\nimmortal life; and, where His spirit is, neither degrading stripes, nor\r\nblood, nor insults, can make the Christian\xe2\x80\x99s last struggle less than\r\nglorious.\r\n\r\nWas he alone, that long night, whose brave, loving spirit was bearing\r\nup, in that old shed, against buffeting and brutal stripes?\r\n\r\nNay! There stood by him ONE,\xe2\x80\x94seen by him alone,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9clike unto the Son of\r\nGod.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe tempter stood by him, too,\xe2\x80\x94blinded by furious, despotic will,\xe2\x80\x94every\r\nmoment pressing him to shun that agony by the betrayal of the innocent.\r\nBut the brave, true heart was firm on the Eternal Rock. Like his\r\nMaster, he knew that, if he saved others, himself he could not save;\r\nnor could utmost extremity wring from him words, save of prayers and\r\nholy trust.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s most gone, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sambo, touched, in spite of himself, by\r\nthe patience of his victim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPay away, till he gives up! Give it to him!\xe2\x80\x94give it to him!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted\r\nLegree. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll take every drop of blood he has, unless he confesses!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTom opened his eyes, and looked upon his master. \xe2\x80\x9cYe poor miserable\r\ncritter!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cthere ain\xe2\x80\x99t no more ye can do! I forgive ye, with\r\nall my soul!\xe2\x80\x9d and he fainted entirely away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI b\xe2\x80\x99lieve, my soul, he\xe2\x80\x99s done for, finally,\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, stepping\r\nforward, to look at him. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, he is! Well, his mouth\xe2\x80\x99s shut up, at\r\nlast,\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s one comfort!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nYes, Legree; but who shall shut up that voice in thy soul? that soul,\r\npast repentance, past prayer, past hope, in whom the fire that never\r\nshall be quenched is already burning!\r\n\r\nYet Tom was not quite gone. His wondrous words and pious prayers had\r\nstruck upon the hearts of the imbruted blacks, who had been the\r\ninstruments of cruelty upon him; and, the instant Legree withdrew, they\r\ntook him down, and, in their ignorance, sought to call him back to\r\nlife,\xe2\x80\x94as if _that_ were any favor to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSartin, we \xe2\x80\x99s been doin\xe2\x80\x99 a drefful wicked thing!\xe2\x80\x9d said Sambo; \xe2\x80\x9chopes\r\nMas\xe2\x80\x99r\xe2\x80\x99ll have to \xe2\x80\x99count for it, and not we.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey washed his wounds,\xe2\x80\x94they provided a rude bed, of some refuse\r\ncotton, for him to lie down on; and one of them, stealing up to the\r\nhouse, begged a drink of brandy of Legree, pretending that he was\r\ntired, and wanted it for himself. He brought it back, and poured it\r\ndown Tom\xe2\x80\x99s throat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Tom!\xe2\x80\x9d said Quimbo, \xe2\x80\x9cwe\xe2\x80\x99s been awful wicked to ye!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI forgive ye, with all my heart!\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, faintly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Tom! do tell us who is _Jesus_, anyhow?\xe2\x80\x9d said Sambo;\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cJesus, that\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbeen a standin\xe2\x80\x99 by you so, all this night!\xe2\x80\x94Who is he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe word roused the failing, fainting spirit. He poured forth a few\r\nenergetic sentences of that wondrous One,\xe2\x80\x94his life, his death, his\r\neverlasting presence, and power to save.\r\n\r\nThey wept,\xe2\x80\x94both the two savage men.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy didn\xe2\x80\x99t I never hear this before?\xe2\x80\x9d said Sambo; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I do believe!\xe2\x80\x94I\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t help it! Lord Jesus, have mercy on us!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor critters!\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d be willing to bar all I have, if it\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nonly bring ye to Christ! O, Lord! give me these two more souls, I\r\npray!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThat prayer was answered!\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XLI\r\nThe Young Master\r\n\r\n\r\nTwo days after, a young man drove a light wagon up through the avenue\r\nof China trees, and, throwing the reins hastily on the horse\xe2\x80\x99s neck,\r\nsprang out and inquired for the owner of the place.\r\n\r\nIt was George Shelby; and, to show how he came to be there, we must go\r\nback in our story.\r\n\r\nThe letter of Miss Ophelia to Mrs. Shelby had, by some unfortunate\r\naccident, been detained, for a month or two, at some remote\r\npost-office, before it reached its destination; and, of course, before\r\nit was received, Tom was already lost to view among the distant swamps\r\nof the Red River.\r\n\r\nMrs. Shelby read the intelligence with the deepest concern; but any\r\nimmediate action upon it was an impossibility. She was then in\r\nattendance on the sick-bed of her husband, who lay delirious in the\r\ncrisis of a fever. Master George Shelby, who, in the interval, had\r\nchanged from a boy to a tall young man, was her constant and faithful\r\nassistant, and her only reliance in superintending his father\xe2\x80\x99s\r\naffairs. Miss Ophelia had taken the precaution to send them the name of\r\nthe lawyer who did business for the St. Clares; and the most that, in\r\nthe emergency, could be done, was to address a letter of inquiry to\r\nhim. The sudden death of Mr. Shelby, a few days after, brought, of\r\ncourse, an absorbing pressure of other interests, for a season.\r\n\r\nMr. Shelby showed his confidence in his wife\xe2\x80\x99s ability, by appointing\r\nher sole executrix upon his estates; and thus immediately a large and\r\ncomplicated amount of business was brought upon her hands.\r\n\r\nMrs. Shelby, with characteristic energy, applied herself to the work of\r\nstraightening the entangled web of affairs; and she and George were for\r\nsome time occupied with collecting and examining accounts, selling\r\nproperty and settling debts; for Mrs. Shelby was determined that\r\neverything should be brought into tangible and recognizable shape, let\r\nthe consequences to her prove what they might. In the mean time, they\r\nreceived a letter from the lawyer to whom Miss Ophelia had referred\r\nthem, saying that he knew nothing of the matter; that the man was sold\r\nat a public auction, and that, beyond receiving the money, he knew\r\nnothing of the affair.\r\n\r\nNeither George nor Mrs. Shelby could be easy at this result; and,\r\naccordingly, some six months after, the latter, having business for his\r\nmother, down the river, resolved to visit New Orleans, in person, and\r\npush his inquiries, in hopes of discovering Tom\xe2\x80\x99s whereabouts, and\r\nrestoring him.\r\n\r\nAfter some months of unsuccessful search, by the merest accident,\r\nGeorge fell in with a man, in New Orleans, who happened to be possessed\r\nof the desired information; and with his money in his pocket, our hero\r\ntook steamboat for Red River, resolving to find out and re-purchase his\r\nold friend.\r\n\r\nHe was soon introduced into the house, where he found Legree in the\r\nsitting-room.\r\n\r\nLegree received the stranger with a kind of surly hospitality,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI understand,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you bought, in New Orleans, a\r\nboy, named Tom. He used to be on my father\xe2\x80\x99s place, and I came to see\r\nif I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t buy him back.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLegree\xe2\x80\x99s brow grew dark, and he broke out, passionately: \xe2\x80\x9cYes, I did\r\nbuy such a fellow,\xe2\x80\x94and a h\xe2\x80\x94l of a bargain I had of it, too! The most\r\nrebellious, saucy, impudent dog! Set up my niggers to run away; got off\r\ntwo gals, worth eight hundred or a thousand apiece. He owned to that,\r\nand, when I bid him tell me where they was, he up and said he knew, but\r\nhe wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t tell; and stood to it, though I gave him the cussedest\r\nflogging I ever gave nigger yet. I b\xe2\x80\x99lieve he\xe2\x80\x99s trying to die; but I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t know as he\xe2\x80\x99ll make it out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is he?\xe2\x80\x9d said George, impetuously. \xe2\x80\x9cLet me see him.\xe2\x80\x9d The cheeks\r\nof the young man were crimson, and his eyes flashed fire; but he\r\nprudently said nothing, as yet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s in dat ar shed,\xe2\x80\x9d said a little fellow, who stood holding George\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhorse.\r\n\r\nLegree kicked the boy, and swore at him; but George, without saying\r\nanother word, turned and strode to the spot.\r\n\r\nTom had been lying two days since the fatal night, not suffering, for\r\nevery nerve of suffering was blunted and destroyed. He lay, for the\r\nmost part, in a quiet stupor; for the laws of a powerful and well-knit\r\nframe would not at once release the imprisoned spirit. By stealth,\r\nthere had been there, in the darkness of the night, poor desolated\r\ncreatures, who stole from their scanty hours\xe2\x80\x99 rest, that they might\r\nrepay to him some of those ministrations of love in which he had always\r\nbeen so abundant. Truly, those poor disciples had little to give,\xe2\x80\x94only\r\nthe cup of cold water; but it was given with full hearts.\r\n\r\nTears had fallen on that honest, insensible face,\xe2\x80\x94tears of late\r\nrepentance in the poor, ignorant heathen, whom his dying love and\r\npatience had awakened to repentance, and bitter prayers, breathed over\r\nhim to a late-found Saviour, of whom they scarce knew more than the\r\nname, but whom the yearning ignorant heart of man never implores in\r\nvain.\r\n\r\nCassy, who had glided out of her place of concealment, and, by\r\noverhearing, learned the sacrifice that had been made for her and\r\nEmmeline, had been there, the night before, defying the danger of\r\ndetection; and, moved by the last few words which the affectionate soul\r\nhad yet strength to breathe, the long winter of despair, the ice of\r\nyears, had given way, and the dark, despairing woman had wept and\r\nprayed.\r\n\r\nWhen George entered the shed, he felt his head giddy and his heart\r\nsick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it possible,\xe2\x80\x94is it possible?\xe2\x80\x9d said he, kneeling down by him. \xe2\x80\x9cUncle\r\nTom, my poor, poor old friend!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSomething in the voice penetrated to the ear of the dying. He moved his\r\nhead gently, smiled, and said,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJesus can make a dying-bed\r\nFeel soft as down pillows are.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nTears which did honor to his manly heart fell from the young man\xe2\x80\x99s\r\neyes, as he bent over his poor friend.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, dear Uncle Tom! do wake,\xe2\x80\x94do speak once more! Look up! Here\xe2\x80\x99s Mas\xe2\x80\x99r\r\nGeorge,\xe2\x80\x94your own little Mas\xe2\x80\x99r George. Don\xe2\x80\x99t you know me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMas\xe2\x80\x99r George!\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, opening his eyes, and speaking in a feeble\r\nvoice; \xe2\x80\x9cMas\xe2\x80\x99r George!\xe2\x80\x9d He looked bewildered.\r\n\r\nSlowly the idea seemed to fill his soul; and the vacant eye became\r\nfixed and brightened, the whole face lighted up, the hard hands\r\nclasped, and tears ran down the cheeks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBless the Lord! it is,\xe2\x80\x94it is,\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s all I wanted! They haven\xe2\x80\x99t forgot\r\nme. It warms my soul; it does my heart good! Now I shall die content!\r\nBless the Lord, on my soul!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou shan\xe2\x80\x99t die! you _mustn\xe2\x80\x99t_ die, nor think of it! I\xe2\x80\x99ve come to buy\r\nyou, and take you home,\xe2\x80\x9d said George, with impetuous vehemence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r George, ye\xe2\x80\x99re too late. The Lord\xe2\x80\x99s bought me, and is going to\r\ntake me home,\xe2\x80\x94and I long to go. Heaven is better than Kintuck.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, don\xe2\x80\x99t die! It\xe2\x80\x99ll kill me!\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99ll break my heart to think what you\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nsuffered,\xe2\x80\x94and lying in this old shed, here! Poor, poor fellow!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t call me poor fellow!\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, solemnly, \xe2\x80\x9cI _have_ been poor\r\nfellow; but that\xe2\x80\x99s all past and gone, now. I\xe2\x80\x99m right in the door, going\r\ninto glory! O, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r George! _Heaven has come!_ I\xe2\x80\x99ve got the\r\nvictory!\xe2\x80\x94the Lord Jesus has given it to me! Glory be to His name!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGeorge was awe-struck at the force, the vehemence, the power, with\r\nwhich these broken sentences were uttered. He sat gazing in silence.\r\n\r\nTom grasped his hand, and continued,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cYe mustn\xe2\x80\x99t, now, tell Chloe, poor\r\nsoul! how ye found me;\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98t would be so drefful to her. Only tell her ye\r\nfound me going into glory; and that I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t stay for no one. And\r\ntell her the Lord\xe2\x80\x99s stood by me everywhere and al\xe2\x80\x99ays, and made\r\neverything light and easy. And oh, the poor chil\xe2\x80\x99en, and the baby;\xe2\x80\x94my\r\nold heart\xe2\x80\x99s been most broke for \xe2\x80\x99em, time and agin! Tell \xe2\x80\x99em all to\r\nfollow me\xe2\x80\x94follow me! Give my love to Mas\xe2\x80\x99r, and dear good Missis, and\r\neverybody in the place! Ye don\xe2\x80\x99t know! \xe2\x80\x99Pears like I loves \xe2\x80\x99em all! I\r\nloves every creature everywhar!\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s nothing _but_ love! O, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r\r\nGeorge! what a thing \xe2\x80\x99t is to be a Christian!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this moment, Legree sauntered up to the door of the shed, looked in,\r\nwith a dogged air of affected carelessness, and turned away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe old Satan!\xe2\x80\x9d said George, in his indignation. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a comfort to\r\nthink the devil will pay _him_ for this, some of these days!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, don\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x94oh, ye mustn\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x9d said Tom, grasping his hand; \xe2\x80\x9che\xe2\x80\x99s a poor\r\nmis\xe2\x80\x99able critter! it\xe2\x80\x99s awful to think on \xe2\x80\x99t! Oh, if he only could\r\nrepent, the Lord would forgive him now; but I\xe2\x80\x99m \xe2\x80\x99feared he never will!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope he won\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x9d said George; \xe2\x80\x9cI never want to see _him_ in heaven!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHush, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r George!\xe2\x80\x94it worries me! Don\xe2\x80\x99t feel so! He an\xe2\x80\x99t done me no\r\nreal harm,\xe2\x80\x94only opened the gate of the kingdom for me; that\xe2\x80\x99s all!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this moment, the sudden flush of strength which the joy of meeting\r\nhis young master had infused into the dying man gave way. A sudden\r\nsinking fell upon him; he closed his eyes; and that mysterious and\r\nsublime change passed over his face, that told the approach of other\r\nworlds.\r\n\r\nHe began to draw his breath with long, deep inspirations; and his broad\r\nchest rose and fell, heavily. The expression of his face was that of a\r\nconqueror.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho,\xe2\x80\x94who,\xe2\x80\x94who shall separate us from the love of Christ?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, in\r\na voice that contended with mortal weakness; and, with a smile, he fell\r\nasleep.\r\n\r\nGeorge sat fixed with solemn awe. It seemed to him that the place was\r\nholy; and, as he closed the lifeless eyes, and rose up from the dead,\r\nonly one thought possessed him,\xe2\x80\x94that expressed by his simple old\r\nfriend,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a thing it is to be a Christian!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe turned: Legree was standing, sullenly, behind him.\r\n\r\nSomething in that dying scene had checked the natural fierceness of\r\nyouthful passion. The presence of the man was simply loathsome to\r\nGeorge; and he felt only an impulse to get away from him, with as few\r\nwords as possible.\r\n\r\nFixing his keen dark eyes on Legree, he simply said, pointing to the\r\ndead, \xe2\x80\x9cYou have got all you ever can of him. What shall I pay you for\r\nthe body? I will take it away, and bury it decently.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t sell dead niggers,\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, doggedly. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are welcome to\r\nbury him where and when you like.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBoys,\xe2\x80\x9d said George, in an authoritative tone, to two or three negroes,\r\nwho were looking at the body, \xe2\x80\x9chelp me lift him up, and carry him to my\r\nwagon; and get me a spade.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOne of them ran for a spade; the other two assisted George to carry the\r\nbody to the wagon.\r\n\r\nGeorge neither spoke to nor looked at Legree, who did not countermand\r\nhis orders, but stood, whistling, with an air of forced unconcern. He\r\nsulkily followed them to where the wagon stood at the door.\r\n\r\nGeorge spread his cloak in the wagon, and had the body carefully\r\ndisposed of in it,\xe2\x80\x94moving the seat, so as to give it room. Then he\r\nturned, fixed his eyes on Legree, and said, with forced composure,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have not, as yet, said to you what I think of this most atrocious\r\naffair;\xe2\x80\x94this is not the time and place. But, sir, this innocent blood\r\nshall have justice. I will proclaim this murder. I will go to the very\r\nfirst magistrate, and expose you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo!\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree, snapping his fingers, scornfully. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d like to see\r\nyou doing it. Where you going to get witnesses?\xe2\x80\x94how you going to prove\r\nit?\xe2\x80\x94Come, now!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGeorge saw, at once, the force of this defiance. There was not a white\r\nperson on the place; and, in all southern courts, the testimony of\r\ncolored blood is nothing. He felt, at that moment, as if he could have\r\nrent the heavens with his heart\xe2\x80\x99s indignant cry for justice; but in\r\nvain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAfter all, what a fuss, for a dead nigger!\xe2\x80\x9d said Legree.\r\n\r\nThe word was as a spark to a powder magazine. Prudence was never a\r\ncardinal virtue of the Kentucky boy. George turned, and, with one\r\nindignant blow, knocked Legree flat upon his face; and, as he stood\r\nover him, blazing with wrath and defiance, he would have formed no bad\r\npersonification of his great namesake triumphing over the dragon.\r\n\r\nSome men, however, are decidedly bettered by being knocked down. If a\r\nman lays them fairly flat in the dust, they seem immediately to\r\nconceive a respect for him; and Legree was one of this sort. As he\r\nrose, therefore, and brushed the dust from his clothes, he eyed the\r\nslowly-retreating wagon with some evident consideration; nor did he\r\nopen his mouth till it was out of sight.\r\n\r\nBeyond the boundaries of the plantation, George had noticed a dry,\r\nsandy knoll, shaded by a few trees; there they made the grave.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall we take off the cloak, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r?\xe2\x80\x9d said the negroes, when the grave\r\nwas ready.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no,\xe2\x80\x94bury it with him! It\xe2\x80\x99s all I can give you, now, poor Tom, and\r\nyou shall have it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey laid him in; and the men shovelled away, silently. They banked it\r\nup, and laid green turf over it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou may go, boys,\xe2\x80\x9d said George, slipping a quarter into the hand of\r\neach. They lingered about, however.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf young Mas\xe2\x80\x99r would please buy us\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d said one.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99d serve him so faithful!\xe2\x80\x9d said the other.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHard times here, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r!\xe2\x80\x9d said the first. \xe2\x80\x9cDo, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r, buy us, please!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x94I can\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x9d said George, with difficulty, motioning them off;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s impossible!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe poor fellows looked dejected, and walked off in silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWitness, eternal God!\xe2\x80\x9d said George, kneeling on the grave of his poor\r\nfriend; \xe2\x80\x9coh, witness, that, from this hour, I will do _what one man\r\ncan_ to drive out this curse of slavery from my land!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere is no monument to mark the last resting-place of our friend. He\r\nneeds none! His Lord knows where he lies, and will raise him up,\r\nimmortal, to appear with him when he shall appear in his glory.\r\n\r\nPity him not! Such a life and death is not for pity! Not in the riches\r\nof omnipotence is the chief glory of God; but in self-denying,\r\nsuffering love! And blessed are the men whom he calls to fellowship\r\nwith him, bearing their cross after him with patience. Of such it is\r\nwritten, \xe2\x80\x9cBlessed are they that mourn, for they shall be comforted.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XLII\r\nAn Authentic Ghost Story\r\n\r\n\r\nFor some remarkable reason, ghostly legends were uncommonly rife, about\r\nthis time, among the servants on Legree\xe2\x80\x99s place.\r\n\r\nIt was whisperingly asserted that footsteps, in the dead of night, had\r\nbeen heard descending the garret stairs, and patrolling the house. In\r\nvain the doors of the upper entry had been locked; the ghost either\r\ncarried a duplicate key in its pocket, or availed itself of a ghost\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nimmemorial privilege of coming through the keyhole, and promenaded as\r\nbefore, with a freedom that was alarming.\r\n\r\nAuthorities were somewhat divided, as to the outward form of the\r\nspirit, owing to a custom quite prevalent among negroes,\xe2\x80\x94and, for aught\r\nwe know, among whites, too,\xe2\x80\x94of invariably shutting the eyes, and\r\ncovering up heads under blankets, petticoats, or whatever else might\r\ncome in use for a shelter, on these occasions. Of course, as everybody\r\nknows, when the bodily eyes are thus out of the lists, the spiritual\r\neyes are uncommonly vivacious and perspicuous; and, therefore, there\r\nwere abundance of full-length portraits of the ghost, abundantly sworn\r\nand testified to, which, as is often the case with portraits, agreed\r\nwith each other in no particular, except the common family peculiarity\r\nof the ghost tribe,\xe2\x80\x94the wearing of a _white sheet_. The poor souls were\r\nnot versed in ancient history, and did not know that Shakspeare had\r\nauthenticated this costume, by telling how\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe _sheeted_ dead\r\nDid squeak and gibber in the streets of Rome.\xe2\x80\x9d[1]\r\n\r\n\r\n [1] _Hamlet_, Act I, scene 1, lines 115-116\r\n\r\n\r\nAnd, therefore, their all hitting upon this is a striking fact in\r\npneumatology, which we recommend to the attention of spiritual media\r\ngenerally.\r\n\r\nBe it as it may, we have private reasons for knowing that a tall figure\r\nin a white sheet did walk, at the most approved ghostly hours, around\r\nthe Legree premises,\xe2\x80\x94pass out the doors, glide about the\r\nhouse,\xe2\x80\x94disappear at intervals, and, reappearing, pass up the silent\r\nstairway, into that fatal garret; and that, in the morning, the entry\r\ndoors were all found shut and locked as firm as ever.\r\n\r\nLegree could not help overhearing this whispering; and it was all the\r\nmore exciting to him, from the pains that were taken to conceal it from\r\nhim. He drank more brandy than usual; held up his head briskly, and\r\nswore louder than ever in the daytime; but he had bad dreams, and the\r\nvisions of his head on his bed were anything but agreeable. The night\r\nafter Tom\xe2\x80\x99s body had been carried away, he rode to the next town for a\r\ncarouse, and had a high one. Got home late and tired; locked his door,\r\ntook out the key, and went to bed.\r\n\r\nAfter all, let a man take what pains he may to hush it down, a human\r\nsoul is an awful ghostly, unquiet possession, for a bad man to have.\r\nWho knows the metes and bounds of it? Who knows all its awful\r\nperhapses,\xe2\x80\x94those shudderings and tremblings, which it can no more live\r\ndown than it can outlive its own eternity! What a fool is he who locks\r\nhis door to keep out spirits, who has in his own bosom a spirit he\r\ndares not meet alone,\xe2\x80\x94whose voice, smothered far down, and piled over\r\nwith mountains of earthliness, is yet like the forewarning trumpet of\r\ndoom!\r\n\r\nBut Legree locked his door and set a chair against it; he set a\r\nnight-lamp at the head of his bed; and put his pistols there. He\r\nexamined the catches and fastenings of the windows, and then swore he\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cdidn\xe2\x80\x99t care for the devil and all his angels,\xe2\x80\x9d and went to sleep.\r\n\r\nWell, he slept, for he was tired,\xe2\x80\x94slept soundly. But, finally, there\r\ncame over his sleep a shadow, a horror, an apprehension of something\r\ndreadful hanging over him. It was his mother\xe2\x80\x99s shroud, he thought; but\r\nCassy had it, holding it up, and showing it to him. He heard a confused\r\nnoise of screams and groanings; and, with it all, he knew he was\r\nasleep, and he struggled to wake himself. He was half awake. He was\r\nsure something was coming into his room. He knew the door was opening,\r\nbut he could not stir hand or foot. At last he turned, with a start;\r\nthe door _was_ open, and he saw a hand putting out his light.\r\n\r\nIt was a cloudy, misty moonlight, and there he saw it!\xe2\x80\x94something white,\r\ngliding in! He heard the still rustle of its ghostly garments. It stood\r\nstill by his bed;\xe2\x80\x94a cold hand touched his; a voice said, three times,\r\nin a low, fearful whisper, \xe2\x80\x9cCome! come! come!\xe2\x80\x9d And, while he lay\r\nsweating with terror, he knew not when or how, the thing was gone. He\r\nsprang out of bed, and pulled at the door. It was shut and locked, and\r\nthe man fell down in a swoon.\r\n\r\nAfter this, Legree became a harder drinker than ever before. He no\r\nlonger drank cautiously, prudently, but imprudently and recklessly.\r\n\r\nThere were reports around the country, soon after that he was sick and\r\ndying. Excess had brought on that frightful disease that seems to throw\r\nthe lurid shadows of a coming retribution back into the present life.\r\nNone could bear the horrors of that sick room, when he raved and\r\nscreamed, and spoke of sights which almost stopped the blood of those\r\nwho heard him; and, at his dying bed, stood a stern, white, inexorable\r\nfigure, saying, \xe2\x80\x9cCome! come! come!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBy a singular coincidence, on the very night that this vision appeared\r\nto Legree, the house-door was found open in the morning, and some of\r\nthe negroes had seen two white figures gliding down the avenue towards\r\nthe high-road.\r\n\r\nIt was near sunrise when Cassy and Emmeline paused, for a moment, in a\r\nlittle knot of trees near the town.\r\n\r\nCassy was dressed after the manner of the Creole Spanish ladies,\xe2\x80\x94wholly\r\nin black. A small black bonnet on her head, covered by a veil thick\r\nwith embroidery, concealed her face. It had been agreed that, in their\r\nescape, she was to personate the character of a Creole lady, and\r\nEmmeline that of her servant.\r\n\r\nBrought up, from early life, in connection with the highest society,\r\nthe language, movements and air of Cassy, were all in agreement with\r\nthis idea; and she had still enough remaining with her, of a once\r\nsplendid wardrobe, and sets of jewels, to enable her to personate the\r\nthing to advantage.\r\n\r\nShe stopped in the outskirts of the town, where she had noticed trunks\r\nfor sale, and purchased a handsome one. This she requested the man to\r\nsend along with her. And, accordingly, thus escorted by a boy wheeling\r\nher trunk, and Emmeline behind her, carrying her carpet-bag and sundry\r\nbundles, she made her appearance at the small tavern, like a lady of\r\nconsideration.\r\n\r\nThe first person that struck her, after her arrival, was George Shelby,\r\nwho was staying there, awaiting the next boat.\r\n\r\nCassy had remarked the young man from her loophole in the garret, and\r\nseen him bear away the body of Tom, and observed with secret\r\nexultation, his rencontre with Legree. Subsequently she had gathered,\r\nfrom the conversations she had overheard among the negroes, as she\r\nglided about in her ghostly disguise, after nightfall, who he was, and\r\nin what relation he stood to Tom. She, therefore, felt an immediate\r\naccession of confidence, when she found that he was, like herself,\r\nawaiting the next boat.\r\n\r\nCassy\xe2\x80\x99s air and manner, address, and evident command of money,\r\nprevented any rising disposition to suspicion in the hotel. People\r\nnever inquire too closely into those who are fair on the main point, of\r\npaying well,\xe2\x80\x94a thing which Cassy had foreseen when she provided herself\r\nwith money.\r\n\r\nIn the edge of the evening, a boat was heard coming along, and George\r\nShelby handed Cassy aboard, with the politeness which comes naturally\r\nto every Kentuckian, and exerted himself to provide her with a good\r\nstate-room.\r\n\r\nCassy kept her room and bed, on pretext of illness, during the whole\r\ntime they were on Red River; and was waited on, with obsequious\r\ndevotion, by her attendant.\r\n\r\nWhen they arrived at the Mississippi river, George, having learned that\r\nthe course of the strange lady was upward, like his own, proposed to\r\ntake a state-room for her on the same boat with himself,\xe2\x80\x94good-naturedly\r\ncompassionating her feeble health, and desirous to do what he could to\r\nassist her.\r\n\r\nBehold, therefore, the whole party safely transferred to the good\r\nsteamer Cincinnati, and sweeping up the river under a powerful head of\r\nsteam.\r\n\r\nCassy\xe2\x80\x99s health was much better. She sat upon the guards, came to the\r\ntable, and was remarked upon in the boat as a lady that must have been\r\nvery handsome.\r\n\r\nFrom the moment that George got the first glimpse of her face, he was\r\ntroubled with one of those fleeting and indefinite likenesses, which\r\nalmost every body can remember, and has been, at times, perplexed with.\r\nHe could not keep himself from looking at her, and watching her\r\nperpetually. At table, or sitting at her state-room door, still she\r\nwould encounter the young man\xe2\x80\x99s eyes fixed on her, and politely\r\nwithdrawn, when she showed, by her countenance, that she was sensible\r\nto the observation.\r\n\r\nCassy became uneasy. She began to think that he suspected something;\r\nand finally resolved to throw herself entirely on his generosity, and\r\nintrusted him with her whole history.\r\n\r\nGeorge was heartily disposed to sympathize with any one who had escaped\r\nfrom Legree\xe2\x80\x99s plantation,\xe2\x80\x94a place that he could not remember or speak\r\nof with patience,\xe2\x80\x94and, with the courageous disregard of consequences\r\nwhich is characteristic of his age and state, he assured her that he\r\nwould do all in his power to protect and bring them through.\r\n\r\nThe next state-room to Cassy\xe2\x80\x99s was occupied by a French lady, named De\r\nThoux, who was accompanied by a fine little daughter, a child of some\r\ntwelve summers.\r\n\r\nThis lady, having gathered, from George\xe2\x80\x99s conversation, that he was\r\nfrom Kentucky, seemed evidently disposed to cultivate his acquaintance;\r\nin which design she was seconded by the graces of her little girl, who\r\nwas about as pretty a plaything as ever diverted the weariness of a\r\nfortnight\xe2\x80\x99s trip on a steamboat.\r\n\r\nGeorge\xe2\x80\x99s chair was often placed at her state-room door; and Cassy, as\r\nshe sat upon the guards, could hear their conversation.\r\n\r\nMadame de Thoux was very minute in her inquiries as to Kentucky, where\r\nshe said she had resided in a former period of her life. George\r\ndiscovered, to his surprise, that her former residence must have been\r\nin his own vicinity; and her inquiries showed a knowledge of people and\r\nthings in his vicinity, that was perfectly surprising to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Thoux to him, one day, \xe2\x80\x9cof any man, in\r\nyour neighborhood, of the name of Harris?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is an old fellow, of that name, lives not far from my father\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nplace,\xe2\x80\x9d said George. \xe2\x80\x9cWe never have had much intercourse with him,\r\nthough.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is a large slave-owner, I believe,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Thoux, with a\r\nmanner which seemed to betray more interest than she was exactly\r\nwilling to show.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is,\xe2\x80\x9d said George, looking rather surprised at her manner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you ever know of his having\xe2\x80\x94perhaps, you may have heard of his\r\nhaving a mulatto boy, named George?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, certainly,\xe2\x80\x94George Harris,\xe2\x80\x94I know him well; he married a servant of\r\nmy mother\xe2\x80\x99s, but has escaped, now, to Canada.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe has?\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Thoux, quickly. \xe2\x80\x9cThank God!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGeorge looked a surprised inquiry, but said nothing.\r\n\r\nMadame de Thoux leaned her head on her hand, and burst into tears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is my brother,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame!\xe2\x80\x9d said George, with a strong accent of surprise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Thoux, lifting her head, proudly, and wiping her\r\ntears, \xe2\x80\x9cMr. Shelby, George Harris is my brother!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am perfectly astonished,\xe2\x80\x9d said George, pushing back his chair a pace\r\nor two, and looking at Madame de Thoux.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was sold to the South when he was a boy,\xe2\x80\x9d said she. \xe2\x80\x9cI was bought by\r\na good and generous man. He took me with him to the West Indies, set me\r\nfree, and married me. It is but lately that he died; and I was going up\r\nto Kentucky, to see if I could find and redeem my brother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI heard him speak of a sister Emily, that was sold South,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nGeorge.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, indeed! I am the one,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Thoux;\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9ctell me what sort\r\nof a\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA very fine young man,\xe2\x80\x9d said George, \xe2\x80\x9cnotwithstanding the curse of\r\nslavery that lay on him. He sustained a first rate character, both for\r\nintelligence and principle. I know, you see,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cbecause he\r\nmarried in our family.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat sort of a girl?\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Thoux, eagerly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA treasure,\xe2\x80\x9d said George; \xe2\x80\x9ca beautiful, intelligent, amiable girl.\r\nVery pious. My mother had brought her up, and trained her as carefully,\r\nalmost, as a daughter. She could read and write, embroider and sew,\r\nbeautifully; and was a beautiful singer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas she born in your house?\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Thoux.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo. Father bought her once, in one of his trips to New Orleans, and\r\nbrought her up as a present to mother. She was about eight or nine\r\nyears old, then. Father would never tell mother what he gave for her;\r\nbut, the other day, in looking over his old papers, we came across the\r\nbill of sale. He paid an extravagant sum for her, to be sure. I\r\nsuppose, on account of her extraordinary beauty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGeorge sat with his back to Cassy, and did not see the absorbed\r\nexpression of her countenance, as he was giving these details.\r\n\r\nAt this point in the story, she touched his arm, and, with a face\r\nperfectly white with interest, said, \xe2\x80\x9cDo you know the names of the\r\npeople he bought her of?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA man of the name of Simmons, I think, was the principal in the\r\ntransaction. At least, I think that was the name on the bill of sale.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, my God!\xe2\x80\x9d said Cassy, and fell insensible on the floor of the cabin.\r\n\r\nGeorge was wide awake now, and so was Madame de Thoux. Though neither\r\nof them could conjecture what was the cause of Cassy\xe2\x80\x99s fainting, still\r\nthey made all the tumult which is proper in such cases;\xe2\x80\x94George\r\nupsetting a wash-pitcher, and breaking two tumblers, in the warmth of\r\nhis humanity; and various ladies in the cabin, hearing that somebody\r\nhad fainted, crowded the state-room door, and kept out all the air they\r\npossibly could, so that, on the whole, everything was done that could\r\nbe expected.\r\n\r\nPoor Cassy! when she recovered, turned her face to the wall, and wept\r\nand sobbed like a child,\xe2\x80\x94perhaps, mother, you can tell what she was\r\nthinking of! Perhaps you cannot,\xe2\x80\x94but she felt as sure, in that hour,\r\nthat God had had mercy on her, and that she should see her daughter,\xe2\x80\x94as\r\nshe did, months afterwards,\xe2\x80\x94when\xe2\x80\x94but we anticipate.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XLIII\r\nResults\r\n\r\n\r\nThe rest of our story is soon told. George Shelby, interested, as any\r\nother young man might be, by the romance of the incident, no less than\r\nby feelings of humanity, was at the pains to send to Cassy the bill of\r\nsale of Eliza; whose date and name all corresponded with her own\r\nknowledge of facts, and felt no doubt upon her mind as to the identity\r\nof her child. It remained now only for her to trace out the path of the\r\nfugitives.\r\n\r\nMadame de Thoux and she, thus drawn together by the singular\r\ncoincidence of their fortunes, proceeded immediately to Canada, and\r\nbegan a tour of inquiry among the stations, where the numerous\r\nfugitives from slavery are located. At Amherstberg they found the\r\nmissionary with whom George and Eliza had taken shelter, on their first\r\narrival in Canada; and through him were enabled to trace the family to\r\nMontreal.\r\n\r\nGeorge and Eliza had now been five years free. George had found\r\nconstant occupation in the shop of a worthy machinist, where he had\r\nbeen earning a competent support for his family, which, in the mean\r\ntime, had been increased by the addition of another daughter.\r\n\r\nLittle Harry\xe2\x80\x94a fine bright boy\xe2\x80\x94had been put to a good school, and was\r\nmaking rapid proficiency in knowledge.\r\n\r\nThe worthy pastor of the station, in Amherstberg, where George had\r\nfirst landed, was so much interested in the statements of Madame de\r\nThoux and Cassy, that he yielded to the solicitations of the former, to\r\naccompany them to Montreal, in their search,\xe2\x80\x94she bearing all the\r\nexpense of the expedition.\r\n\r\nThe scene now changes to a small, neat tenement, in the outskirts of\r\nMontreal; the time, evening. A cheerful fire blazes on the hearth; a\r\ntea-table, covered with a snowy cloth, stands prepared for the evening\r\nmeal. In one corner of the room was a table covered with a green cloth,\r\nwhere was an open writing-desk, pens, paper, and over it a shelf of\r\nwell-selected books.\r\n\r\nThis was George\xe2\x80\x99s study. The same zeal for self-improvement, which led\r\nhim to steal the much coveted arts of reading and writing, amid all the\r\ntoil and discouragements of his early life, still led him to devote all\r\nhis leisure time to self-cultivation.\r\n\r\nAt this present time, he is seated at the table, making notes from a\r\nvolume of the family library he has been reading.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, George,\xe2\x80\x9d says Eliza, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99ve been gone all day. Do put down that\r\nbook, and let\xe2\x80\x99s talk, while I\xe2\x80\x99m getting tea,\xe2\x80\x94do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd little Eliza seconds the effort, by toddling up to her father, and\r\ntrying to pull the book out of his hand, and install herself on his\r\nknee as a substitute.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, you little witch!\xe2\x80\x9d says George, yielding, as, in such\r\ncircumstances, man always must.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s right,\xe2\x80\x9d says Eliza, as she begins to cut a loaf of bread. A\r\nlittle older she looks; her form a little fuller; her air more matronly\r\nthan of yore; but evidently contented and happy as woman need be.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHarry, my boy, how did you come on in that sum, today?\xe2\x80\x9d says George,\r\nas he laid his hand on his son\xe2\x80\x99s head.\r\n\r\nHarry has lost his long curls; but he can never lose those eyes and\r\neyelashes, and that fine, bold brow, that flushes with triumph, as he\r\nanswers, \xe2\x80\x9cI did it, every bit of it, _myself_, father; and _nobody_\r\nhelped me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s right,\xe2\x80\x9d says his father; \xe2\x80\x9cdepend on yourself, my son. You have\r\na better chance than ever your poor father had.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this moment, there is a rap at the door; and Eliza goes and opens\r\nit. The delighted\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cWhy! this you?\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94calls up her husband; and the good\r\npastor of Amherstberg is welcomed. There are two more women with him,\r\nand Eliza asks them to sit down.\r\n\r\nNow, if the truth must be told, the honest pastor had arranged a little\r\nprogramme, according to which this affair was to develop itself; and,\r\non the way up, all had very cautiously and prudently exhorted each\r\nother not to let things out, except according to previous arrangement.\r\n\r\nWhat was the good man\xe2\x80\x99s consternation, therefore, just as he had\r\nmotioned to the ladies to be seated, and was taking out his\r\npocket-handkerchief to wipe his mouth, so as to proceed to his\r\nintroductory speech in good order, when Madame de Thoux upset the whole\r\nplan, by throwing her arms around George\xe2\x80\x99s neck, and letting all out at\r\nonce, by saying, \xe2\x80\x9cO, George! don\xe2\x80\x99t you know me? I\xe2\x80\x99m your sister Emily.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCassy had seated herself more composedly, and would have carried on her\r\npart very well, had not little Eliza suddenly appeared before her in\r\nexact shape and form, every outline and curl, just as her daughter was\r\nwhen she saw her last. The little thing peered up in her face; and\r\nCassy caught her up in her arms, pressed her to her bosom, saying,\r\nwhat, at the moment she really believed, \xe2\x80\x9cDarling, I\xe2\x80\x99m your mother!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn fact, it was a troublesome matter to do up exactly in proper order;\r\nbut the good pastor, at last, succeeded in getting everybody quiet, and\r\ndelivering the speech with which he had intended to open the exercises;\r\nand in which, at last, he succeeded so well, that his whole audience\r\nwere sobbing about him in a manner that ought to satisfy any orator,\r\nancient or modern.\r\n\r\nThey knelt together, and the good man prayed,\xe2\x80\x94for there are some\r\nfeelings so agitated and tumultuous, that they can find rest only by\r\nbeing poured into the bosom of Almighty love,\xe2\x80\x94and then, rising up, the\r\nnew-found family embraced each other, with a holy trust in Him, who\r\nfrom such peril and dangers, and by such unknown ways, had brought them\r\ntogether.\r\n\r\nThe note-book of a missionary, among the Canadian fugitives, contains\r\ntruth stranger than fiction. How can it be otherwise, when a system\r\nprevails which whirls families and scatters their members, as the wind\r\nwhirls and scatters the leaves of autumn? These shores of refuge, like\r\nthe eternal shore, often unite again, in glad communion, hearts that\r\nfor long years have mourned each other as lost. And affecting beyond\r\nexpression is the earnestness with which every new arrival among them\r\nis met, if, perchance, it may bring tidings of mother, sister, child or\r\nwife, still lost to view in the shadows of slavery.\r\n\r\nDeeds of heroism are wrought here more than those of romance, when\r\ndefying torture, and braving death itself, the fugitive voluntarily\r\nthreads his way back to the terrors and perils of that dark land, that\r\nhe may bring out his sister, or mother, or wife.\r\n\r\nOne young man, of whom a missionary has told us, twice re-captured, and\r\nsuffering shameful stripes for his heroism, had escaped again; and, in\r\na letter which we heard read, tells his friends that he is going back a\r\nthird time, that he may, at last, bring away his sister. My good sir,\r\nis this man a hero, or a criminal? Would not you do as much for your\r\nsister? And can you blame him?\r\n\r\nBut, to return to our friends, whom we left wiping their eyes, and\r\nrecovering themselves from too great and sudden a joy. They are now\r\nseated around the social board, and are getting decidedly\r\ncompanionable; only that Cassy, who keeps little Eliza on her lap,\r\noccasionally squeezes the little thing, in a manner that rather\r\nastonishes her, and obstinately refuses to have her mouth stuffed with\r\ncake to the extent the little one desires,\xe2\x80\x94alleging, what the child\r\nrather wonders at, that she has got something better than cake, and\r\ndoesn\xe2\x80\x99t want it.\r\n\r\nAnd, indeed, in two or three days, such a change has passed over Cassy,\r\nthat our readers would scarcely know her. The despairing, haggard\r\nexpression of her face had given way to one of gentle trust. She seemed\r\nto sink, at once, into the bosom of the family, and take the little\r\nones into her heart, as something for which it long had waited. Indeed,\r\nher love seemed to flow more naturally to the little Eliza than to her\r\nown daughter; for she was the exact image and body of the child whom\r\nshe had lost. The little one was a flowery bond between mother and\r\ndaughter, through whom grew up acquaintanceship and affection. Eliza\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsteady, consistent piety, regulated by the constant reading of the\r\nsacred word, made her a proper guide for the shattered and wearied mind\r\nof her mother. Cassy yielded at once, and with her whole soul, to every\r\ngood influence, and became a devout and tender Christian.\r\n\r\nAfter a day or two, Madame de Thoux told her brother more particularly\r\nof her affairs. The death of her husband had left her an ample fortune,\r\nwhich she generously offered to share with the family. When she asked\r\nGeorge what way she could best apply it for him, he answered, \xe2\x80\x9cGive me\r\nan education, Emily; that has always been my heart\xe2\x80\x99s desire. Then, I\r\ncan do all the rest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOn mature deliberation, it was decided that the whole family should go,\r\nfor some years, to France; whither they sailed, carrying Emmeline with\r\nthem.\r\n\r\nThe good looks of the latter won the affection of the first mate of the\r\nvessel; and, shortly after entering the port, she became his wife.\r\n\r\nGeorge remained four years at a French university, and, applying\r\nhimself with an unintermitted zeal, obtained a very thorough education.\r\n\r\nPolitical troubles in France, at last, led the family again to seek an\r\nasylum in this country.\r\n\r\nGeorge\xe2\x80\x99s feelings and views, as an educated man, may be best expressed\r\nin a letter to one of his friends.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI feel somewhat at a loss, as to my future course. True, as you have\r\nsaid to me, I might mingle in the circles of the whites, in this\r\ncountry, my shade of color is so slight, and that of my wife and family\r\nscarce perceptible. Well, perhaps, on sufferance, I might. But, to tell\r\nyou the truth, I have no wish to.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy sympathies are not for my father\xe2\x80\x99s race, but for my mother\xe2\x80\x99s. To\r\nhim I was no more than a fine dog or horse: to my poor heart-broken\r\nmother I was a _child_; and, though I never saw her, after the cruel\r\nsale that separated us, till she died, yet I _know_ she always loved me\r\ndearly. I know it by my own heart. When I think of all she suffered, of\r\nmy own early sufferings, of the distresses and struggles of my heroic\r\nwife, of my sister, sold in the New Orleans slave-market,\xe2\x80\x94though I hope\r\nto have no unchristian sentiments, yet I may be excused for saying, I\r\nhave no wish to pass for an American, or to identify myself with them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is with the oppressed, enslaved African race that I cast in my lot;\r\nand, if I wished anything, I would wish myself two shades darker,\r\nrather than one lighter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe desire and yearning of my soul is for an African _nationality_. I\r\nwant a people that shall have a tangible, separate existence of its\r\nown; and where am I to look for it? Not in Hayti; for in Hayti they had\r\nnothing to start with. A stream cannot rise above its fountain. The\r\nrace that formed the character of the Haytiens was a worn-out,\r\neffeminate one; and, of course, the subject race will be centuries in\r\nrising to anything.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere, then, shall I look? On the shores of Africa I see a republic,\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nrepublic formed of picked men, who, by energy and self-educating force,\r\nhave, in many cases, individually, raised themselves above a condition\r\nof slavery. Having gone through a preparatory stage of feebleness, this\r\nrepublic has, at last, become an acknowledged nation on the face of the\r\nearth,\xe2\x80\x94acknowledged by both France and England. There it is my wish to\r\ngo, and find myself a people.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am aware, now, that I shall have you all against me; but, before you\r\nstrike, hear me. During my stay in France, I have followed up, with\r\nintense interest, the history of my people in America. I have noted the\r\nstruggle between abolitionist and colonizationist, and have received\r\nsome impressions, as a distant spectator, which could never have\r\noccurred to me as a participator.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI grant that this Liberia may have subserved all sorts of purposes, by\r\nbeing played off, in the hands of our oppressors, against us. Doubtless\r\nthe scheme may have been used, in unjustifiable ways, as a means of\r\nretarding our emancipation. But the question to me is, Is there not a\r\nGod above all man\xe2\x80\x99s schemes? May He not have over-ruled their designs,\r\nand founded for us a nation by them?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn these days, a nation is born in a day. A nation starts, now, with\r\nall the great problems of republican life and civilization wrought out\r\nto its hand;\xe2\x80\x94it has not to discover, but only to apply. Let us, then,\r\nall take hold together, with all our might, and see what we can do with\r\nthis new enterprise, and the whole splendid continent of Africa opens\r\nbefore us and our children. _Our nation_ shall roll the tide of\r\ncivilization and Christianity along its shores, and plant there mighty\r\nrepublics, that, growing with the rapidity of tropical vegetation,\r\nshall be for all coming ages.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you say that I am deserting my enslaved brethren? I think not. If I\r\nforget them one hour, one moment of my life, so may God forget me! But,\r\nwhat can I do for them, here? Can I break their chains? No, not as an\r\nindividual; but, let me go and form part of a nation, which shall have\r\na voice in the councils of nations, and then we can speak.
