A nation has\r\na right to argue, remonstrate, implore, and present the cause of its\r\nrace,\xe2\x80\x94which an individual has not.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf Europe ever becomes a grand council of free nations,\xe2\x80\x94as I trust in\r\nGod it will,\xe2\x80\x94if, there, serfdom, and all unjust and oppressive social\r\ninequalities, are done away; and if they, as France and England have\r\ndone, acknowledge our position,\xe2\x80\x94then, in the great congress of nations,\r\nwe will make our appeal, and present the cause of our enslaved and\r\nsuffering race; and it cannot be that free, enlightened America will\r\nnot then desire to wipe from her escutcheon that bar sinister which\r\ndisgraces her among nations, and is as truly a curse to her as to the\r\nenslaved.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, you will tell me, our race have equal rights to mingle in the\r\nAmerican republic as the Irishman, the German, the Swede. Granted, they\r\nhave. We _ought_ to be free to meet and mingle,\xe2\x80\x94to rise by our\r\nindividual worth, without any consideration of caste or color; and they\r\nwho deny us this right are false to their own professed principles of\r\nhuman equality. We ought, in particular, to be allowed _here_. We have\r\n_more_ than the rights of common men;\xe2\x80\x94we have the claim of an injured\r\nrace for reparation. But, then, _I do not want it_; I want a country, a\r\nnation, of my own. I think that the African race has peculiarities, yet\r\nto be unfolded in the light of civilization and Christianity, which, if\r\nnot the same with those of the Anglo-Saxon, may prove to be, morally,\r\nof even a higher type.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the Anglo-Saxon race has been intrusted the destinies of the world,\r\nduring its pioneer period of struggle and conflict. To that mission its\r\nstern, inflexible, energetic elements, were well adapted; but, as a\r\nChristian, I look for another era to arise. On its borders I trust we\r\nstand; and the throes that now convulse the nations are, to my hope,\r\nbut the birth-pangs of an hour of universal peace and brotherhood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI trust that the development of Africa is to be essentially a\r\nChristian one. If not a dominant and commanding race, they are, at\r\nleast, an affectionate, magnanimous, and forgiving one. Having been\r\ncalled in the furnace of injustice and oppression, they have need to\r\nbind closer to their hearts that sublime doctrine of love and\r\nforgiveness, through which alone they are to conquer, which it is to be\r\ntheir mission to spread over the continent of Africa.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn myself, I confess, I am feeble for this,\xe2\x80\x94full half the blood in my\r\nveins is the hot and hasty Saxon; but I have an eloquent preacher of\r\nthe Gospel ever by my side, in the person of my beautiful wife. When I\r\nwander, her gentler spirit ever restores me, and keeps before my eyes\r\nthe Christian calling and mission of our race. As a Christian patriot,\r\nas a teacher of Christianity, I go to _my country_,\xe2\x80\x94my chosen, my\r\nglorious Africa!\xe2\x80\x94and to her, in my heart, I sometimes apply those\r\nsplendid words of prophecy: \xe2\x80\x99Whereas thou hast been forsaken and hated,\r\nso that no man went through thee; _I_ will make thee an eternal\r\nexcellence, a joy of many generations!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will call me an enthusiast: you will tell me that I have not well\r\nconsidered what I am undertaking. But I have considered, and counted\r\nthe cost. I go to _Liberia_, not as an Elysium of romance, but as to _a\r\nfield of work_. I expect to work with both hands,\xe2\x80\x94to work _hard_; to\r\nwork against all sorts of difficulties and discouragements; and to work\r\ntill I die. This is what I go for; and in this I am quite sure I shall\r\nnot be disappointed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhatever you may think of my determination, do not divorce me from\r\nyour confidence; and think that, in whatever I do, I act with a heart\r\nwholly given to my people.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGEORGE HARRIS.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nGeorge, with his wife, children, sister and mother, embarked for\r\nAfrica, some few weeks after. If we are not mistaken, the world will\r\nyet hear from him there.\r\n\r\nOf our other characters we have nothing very particular to write,\r\nexcept a word relating to Miss Ophelia and Topsy, and a farewell\r\nchapter, which we shall dedicate to George Shelby.\r\n\r\nMiss Ophelia took Topsy home to Vermont with her, much to the surprise\r\nof the grave deliberative body whom a New Englander recognizes under\r\nthe term \xe2\x80\x9c_Our folks_.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cOur folks,\xe2\x80\x9d at first, thought it an odd and\r\nunnecessary addition to their well-trained domestic establishment; but,\r\nso thoroughly efficient was Miss Ophelia in her conscientious endeavor\r\nto do her duty by her _ilhve_, that the child rapidly grew in grace and\r\nin favor with the family and neighborhood. At the age of womanhood, she\r\nwas, by her own request, baptized, and became a member of the Christian\r\nchurch in the place; and showed so much intelligence, activity and\r\nzeal, and desire to do good in the world, that she was at last\r\nrecommended, and approved as a missionary to one of the stations in\r\nAfrica; and we have heard that the same activity and ingenuity which,\r\nwhen a child, made her so multiform and restless in her developments,\r\nis now employed, in a safer and wholesomer manner, in teaching the\r\nchildren of her own country.\r\n\r\nP.S.\xe2\x80\x94It will be a satisfaction to some mother, also, to state, that\r\nsome inquiries, which were set on foot by Madame de Thoux, have\r\nresulted recently in the discovery of Cassy\xe2\x80\x99s son. Being a young man of\r\nenergy, he had escaped, some years before his mother, and been received\r\nand educated by friends of the oppressed in the north. He will soon\r\nfollow his family to Africa.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XLIV\r\nThe Liberator\r\n\r\n\r\nGeorge Shelby had written to his mother merely a line, stating the day\r\nthat she might expect him home. Of the death scene of his old friend he\r\nhad not the heart to write. He had tried several times, and only\r\nsucceeded in half choking himself; and invariably finished by tearing\r\nup the paper, wiping his eyes, and rushing somewhere to get quiet.\r\n\r\nThere was a pleased bustle all through the Shelby mansion, that day, in\r\nexpectation of the arrival of young Mas\xe2\x80\x99r George.\r\n\r\nMrs. Shelby was seated in her comfortable parlor, where a cheerful\r\nhickory fire was dispelling the chill of the late autumn evening. A\r\nsupper-table, glittering with plate and cut glass, was set out, on\r\nwhose arrangements our former friend, old Chloe, was presiding.\r\n\r\nArrayed in a new calico dress, with clean, white apron, and high,\r\nwell-starched turban, her black polished face glowing with\r\nsatisfaction, she lingered, with needless punctiliousness, around the\r\narrangements of the table, merely as an excuse for talking a little to\r\nher mistress.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLaws, now! won\xe2\x80\x99t it look natural to him?\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cThar,\xe2\x80\x94I set his\r\nplate just whar he likes it round by the fire. Mas\xe2\x80\x99r George allers\r\nwants de warm seat. O, go way!\xe2\x80\x94why didn\xe2\x80\x99t Sally get out de _best_\r\ntea-pot,\xe2\x80\x94de little new one, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r George got for Missis, Christmas?\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll have it out! And Missis has heard from Mas\xe2\x80\x99r George?\xe2\x80\x9d she said,\r\ninquiringly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Chloe; but only a line, just to say he would be home tonight, if\r\nhe could,\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDidn\xe2\x80\x99t say nothin\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x99bout my old man, s\xe2\x80\x99pose?\xe2\x80\x9d said Chloe, still\r\nfidgeting with the tea-cups.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, he didn\xe2\x80\x99t. He did not speak of anything, Chloe. He said he would\r\ntell all, when he got home.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJes like Mas\xe2\x80\x99r George,\xe2\x80\x94he\xe2\x80\x99s allers so ferce for tellin\xe2\x80\x99 everything\r\nhisself. I allers minded dat ar in Mas\xe2\x80\x99r George. Don\xe2\x80\x99t see, for my\r\npart, how white people gen\xe2\x80\x99lly can bar to hev to write things much as\r\nthey do, writin\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x99s such slow, oneasy kind o\xe2\x80\x99 work.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Shelby smiled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m a thinkin\xe2\x80\x99 my old man won\xe2\x80\x99t know de boys and de baby. Lor\xe2\x80\x99! she\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nde biggest gal, now,\xe2\x80\x94good she is, too, and peart, Polly is. She\xe2\x80\x99s out\r\nto the house, now, watchin\xe2\x80\x99 de hoe-cake. I \xe2\x80\x99s got jist de very pattern\r\nmy old man liked so much, a bakin\xe2\x80\x99. Jist sich as I gin him the mornin\xe2\x80\x99\r\nhe was took off. Lord bless us! how I felt, dat ar morning!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Shelby sighed, and felt a heavy weight on her heart, at this\r\nallusion. She had felt uneasy, ever since she received her son\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nletter, lest something should prove to be hidden behind the veil of\r\nsilence which he had drawn.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMissis has got dem bills?\xe2\x80\x9d said Chloe, anxiously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Chloe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Cause I wants to show my old man dem very bills de _perfectioner_\r\ngave me. \xe2\x80\x98And,\xe2\x80\x99 say he, \xe2\x80\x98Chloe, I wish you\xe2\x80\x99d stay longer.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98Thank you,\r\nMas\xe2\x80\x99r,\xe2\x80\x99 says I, \xe2\x80\x98I would, only my old man\xe2\x80\x99s coming home, and\r\nMissis,\xe2\x80\x94she can\xe2\x80\x99t do without me no longer.\xe2\x80\x99 There\xe2\x80\x99s jist what I telled\r\nhim. Berry nice man, dat Mas\xe2\x80\x99r Jones was.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nChloe had pertinaciously insisted that the very bills in which her\r\nwages had been paid should be preserved, to show her husband, in\r\nmemorial of her capability. And Mrs. Shelby had readily consented to\r\nhumor her in the request.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe won\xe2\x80\x99t know Polly,\xe2\x80\x94my old man won\xe2\x80\x99t. Laws, it\xe2\x80\x99s five year since they\r\ntuck him! She was a baby den,\xe2\x80\x94couldn\xe2\x80\x99t but jist stand. Remember how\r\ntickled he used to be, cause she would keep a fallin\xe2\x80\x99 over, when she\r\nsot out to walk. Laws a me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe rattling of wheels now was heard.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMas\xe2\x80\x99r George!\xe2\x80\x9d said Aunt Chloe, starting to the window.\r\n\r\nMrs. Shelby ran to the entry door, and was folded in the arms of her\r\nson. Aunt Chloe stood anxiously straining her eyes out into the\r\ndarkness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, _poor_ Aunt Chloe!\xe2\x80\x9d said George, stopping compassionately, and\r\ntaking her hard, black hand between both his; \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d have given all my\r\nfortune to have brought him with me, but he\xe2\x80\x99s gone to a better\r\ncountry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was a passionate exclamation from Mrs. Shelby, but Aunt Chloe\r\nsaid nothing.\r\n\r\nThe party entered the supper-room. The money, of which Chloe was so\r\nproud, was still lying on the table.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThar,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, gathering it up, and holding it, with a trembling\r\nhand, to her mistress, \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t never want to see nor hear on \xe2\x80\x99t again.\r\nJist as I knew \xe2\x80\x99t would be,\xe2\x80\x94sold, and murdered on dem ar\xe2\x80\x99 old\r\nplantations!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nChloe turned, and was walking proudly out of the room. Mrs. Shelby\r\nfollowed her softly, and took one of her hands, drew her down into a\r\nchair, and sat down by her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy poor, good Chloe!\xe2\x80\x9d said she.\r\n\r\nChloe leaned her head on her mistress\xe2\x80\x99 shoulder, and sobbed out, \xe2\x80\x9cO\r\nMissis! \xe2\x80\x99scuse me, my heart\xe2\x80\x99s broke,\xe2\x80\x94dat\xe2\x80\x99s all!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know it is,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Shelby, as her tears fell fast; \xe2\x80\x9cand _I_\r\ncannot heal it, but Jesus can. He healeth the broken hearted, and\r\nbindeth up their wounds.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was a silence for some time, and all wept together. At last,\r\nGeorge, sitting down beside the mourner, took her hand, and, with\r\nsimple pathos, repeated the triumphant scene of her husband\xe2\x80\x99s death,\r\nand his last messages of love.\r\n\r\nAbout a month after this, one morning, all the servants of the Shelby\r\nestate were convened together in the great hall that ran through the\r\nhouse, to hear a few words from their young master.\r\n\r\nTo the surprise of all, he appeared among them with a bundle of papers\r\nin his hand, containing a certificate of freedom to every one on the\r\nplace, which he read successively, and presented, amid the sobs and\r\ntears and shouts of all present.\r\n\r\nMany, however, pressed around him, earnestly begging him not to send\r\nthem away; and, with anxious faces, tendering back their free papers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe don\xe2\x80\x99t want to be no freer than we are. We\xe2\x80\x99s allers had all we\r\nwanted. We don\xe2\x80\x99t want to leave de ole place, and Mas\xe2\x80\x99r and Missis, and\r\nde rest!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy good friends,\xe2\x80\x9d said George, as soon as he could get a silence,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthere\xe2\x80\x99ll be no need for you to leave me. The place wants as many hands\r\nto work it as it did before. We need the same about the house that we\r\ndid before. But, you are now free men and free women. I shall pay you\r\nwages for your work, such as we shall agree on. The advantage is, that\r\nin case of my getting in debt, or dying,\xe2\x80\x94things that might happen,\xe2\x80\x94you\r\ncannot now be taken up and sold. I expect to carry on the estate, and\r\nto teach you what, perhaps, it will take you some time to learn,\xe2\x80\x94how to\r\nuse the rights I give you as free men and women. I expect you to be\r\ngood, and willing to learn; and I trust in God that I shall be\r\nfaithful, and willing to teach. And now, my friends, look up, and thank\r\nGod for the blessing of freedom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAn aged, partriarchal negro, who had grown gray and blind on the\r\nestate, now rose, and, lifting his trembling hand said, \xe2\x80\x9cLet us give\r\nthanks unto the Lord!\xe2\x80\x9d As all kneeled by one consent, a more touching\r\nand hearty _Te Deum_ never ascended to heaven, though borne on the peal\r\nof organ, bell and cannon, than came from that honest old heart.\r\n\r\nOn rising, another struck up a Methodist hymn, of which the burden was,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe year of Jubilee is come,\xe2\x80\x94\r\nReturn, ye ransomed sinners, home.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne thing more,\xe2\x80\x9d said George, as he stopped the congratulations of the\r\nthrong; \xe2\x80\x9cyou all remember our good old Uncle Tom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGeorge here gave a short narration of the scene of his death, and of\r\nhis loving farewell to all on the place, and added,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was on his grave, my friends, that I resolved, before God, that I\r\nwould never own another slave, while it was possible to free him; that\r\nnobody, through me, should ever run the risk of being parted from home\r\nand friends, and dying on a lonely plantation, as he died. So, when you\r\nrejoice in your freedom, think that you owe it to that good old soul,\r\nand pay it back in kindness to his wife and children. Think of your\r\nfreedom, every time you see UNCLE TOM\xe2\x80\x99S CABIN; and let it be a memorial\r\nto put you all in mind to follow in his steps, and be honest and\r\nfaithful and Christian as he was.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XLV\r\nConcluding Remarks\r\n\r\n\r\nThe writer has often been inquired of, by correspondents from different\r\nparts of the country, whether this narrative is a true one; and to\r\nthese inquiries she will give one general answer.\r\n\r\nThe separate incidents that compose the narrative are, to a very great\r\nextent, authentic, occurring, many of them, either under her own\r\nobservation, or that of her personal friends. She or her friends have\r\nobserved characters the counterpart of almost all that are here\r\nintroduced; and many of the sayings are word for word as heard herself,\r\nor reported to her.\r\n\r\nThe personal appearance of Eliza, the character ascribed to her, are\r\nsketches drawn from life. The incorruptible fidelity, piety and\r\nhonesty, of Uncle Tom, had more than one development, to her personal\r\nknowledge. Some of the most deeply tragic and romantic, some of the\r\nmost terrible incidents, have also their parallels in reality. The\r\nincident of the mother\xe2\x80\x99s crossing the Ohio river on the ice is a\r\nwell-known fact. The story of \xe2\x80\x9cold Prue,\xe2\x80\x9d in the second volume, was an\r\nincident that fell under the personal observation of a brother of the\r\nwriter, then collecting-clerk to a large mercantile house, in New\r\nOrleans. From the same source was derived the character of the planter\r\nLegree. Of him her brother thus wrote, speaking of visiting his\r\nplantation, on a collecting tour; \xe2\x80\x9cHe actually made me feel of his\r\nfist, which was like a blacksmith\xe2\x80\x99s hammer, or a nodule of iron,\r\ntelling me that it was \xe2\x80\x98calloused with knocking down niggers.\xe2\x80\x99 When I\r\nleft the plantation, I drew a long breath, and felt as if I had escaped\r\nfrom an ogre\xe2\x80\x99s den.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThat the tragical fate of Tom, also, has too many times had its\r\nparallel, there are living witnesses, all over our land, to testify.\r\nLet it be remembered that in all southern states it is a principle of\r\njurisprudence that no person of colored lineage can testify in a suit\r\nagainst a white, and it will be easy to see that such a case may occur,\r\nwherever there is a man whose passions outweigh his interests, and a\r\nslave who has manhood or principle enough to resist his will. There is,\r\nactually, nothing to protect the slave\xe2\x80\x99s life, but the _character_ of\r\nthe master. Facts too shocking to be contemplated occasionally force\r\ntheir way to the public ear, and the comment that one often hears made\r\non them is more shocking than the thing itself. It is said, \xe2\x80\x9cVery\r\nlikely such cases may now and then occur, but they are no sample of\r\ngeneral practice.\xe2\x80\x9d If the laws of New England were so arranged that a\r\nmaster could _now and then_ torture an apprentice to death, would it be\r\nreceived with equal composure? Would it be said, \xe2\x80\x9cThese cases are rare,\r\nand no samples of general practice\xe2\x80\x9d? This injustice is an _inherent_\r\none in the slave system,\xe2\x80\x94it cannot exist without it.\r\n\r\nThe public and shameless sale of beautiful mulatto and quadroon girls\r\nhas acquired a notoriety, from the incidents following the capture of\r\nthe Pearl. We extract the following from the speech of Hon. Horace\r\nMann, one of the legal counsel for the defendants in that case. He\r\nsays: \xe2\x80\x9cIn that company of seventy-six persons, who attempted, in 1848,\r\nto escape from the District of Columbia in the schooner Pearl, and\r\nwhose officers I assisted in defending, there were several young and\r\nhealthy girls, who had those peculiar attractions of form and feature\r\nwhich connoisseurs prize so highly. Elizabeth Russel was one of them.\r\nShe immediately fell into the slave-trader\xe2\x80\x99s fangs, and was doomed for\r\nthe New Orleans market. The hearts of those that saw her were touched\r\nwith pity for her fate. They offered eighteen hundred dollars to redeem\r\nher; and some there were who offered to give, that would not have much\r\nleft after the gift; but the fiend of a slave-trader was inexorable.\r\nShe was despatched to New Orleans; but, when about half way there, God\r\nhad mercy on her, and smote her with death. There were two girls named\r\nEdmundson in the same company. When about to be sent to the same\r\nmarket, an older sister went to the shambles, to plead with the wretch\r\nwho owned them, for the love of God, to spare his victims. He bantered\r\nher, telling what fine dresses and fine furniture they would have.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 she said, \xe2\x80\x98that may do very well in this life, but what will\r\nbecome of them in the next?\xe2\x80\x99 They too were sent to New Orleans; but\r\nwere afterwards redeemed, at an enormous ransom, and brought back.\xe2\x80\x9d Is\r\nit not plain, from this, that the histories of Emmeline and Cassy may\r\nhave many counterparts?\r\n\r\nJustice, too, obliges the author to state that the fairness of mind and\r\ngenerosity attributed to St. Clare are not without a parallel, as the\r\nfollowing anecdote will show. A few years since, a young southern\r\ngentleman was in Cincinnati, with a favorite servant, who had been his\r\npersonal attendant from a boy. The young man took advantage of this\r\nopportunity to secure his own freedom, and fled to the protection of a\r\nQuaker, who was quite noted in affairs of this kind. The owner was\r\nexceedingly indignant. He had always treated the slave with such\r\nindulgence, and his confidence in his affection was such, that he\r\nbelieved he must have been practised upon to induce him to revolt from\r\nhim. He visited the Quaker, in high anger; but, being possessed of\r\nuncommon candor and fairness, was soon quieted by his arguments and\r\nrepresentations. It was a side of the subject which he never had\r\nheard,\xe2\x80\x94never had thought on; and he immediately told the Quaker that,\r\nif his slave would, to his own face, say that it was his desire to be\r\nfree, he would liberate him. An interview was forthwith procured, and\r\nNathan was asked by his young master whether he had ever had any reason\r\nto complain of his treatment, in any respect.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Mas\xe2\x80\x99r,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nathan; \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99ve always been good to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, why do you want to leave me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMas\xe2\x80\x99r may die, and then who get me?\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99d rather be a free man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAfter some deliberation, the young master replied, \xe2\x80\x9cNathan, in your\r\nplace, I think I should feel very much so, myself. You are free.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe immediately made him out free papers; deposited a sum of money in\r\nthe hands of the Quaker, to be judiciously used in assisting him to\r\nstart in life, and left a very sensible and kind letter of advice to\r\nthe young man. That letter was for some time in the writer\xe2\x80\x99s hands.\r\n\r\nThe author hopes she has done justice to that nobility, generosity, and\r\nhumanity, which in many cases characterize individuals at the South.\r\nSuch instances save us from utter despair of our kind. But, she asks\r\nany person, who knows the world, are such characters _common_,\r\nanywhere?\r\n\r\nFor many years of her life, the author avoided all reading upon or\r\nallusion to the subject of slavery, considering it as too painful to be\r\ninquired into, and one which advancing light and civilization would\r\ncertainly live down. But, since the legislative act of 1850, when she\r\nheard, with perfect surprise and consternation, Christian and humane\r\npeople actually recommending the remanding escaped fugitives into\r\nslavery, as a duty binding on good citizens,\xe2\x80\x94when she heard, on all\r\nhands, from kind, compassionate and estimable people, in the free\r\nstates of the North, deliberations and discussions as to what Christian\r\nduty could be on this head,\xe2\x80\x94she could only think, These men and\r\nChristians cannot know what slavery is; if they did, such a question\r\ncould never be open for discussion. And from this arose a desire to\r\nexhibit it in a _living dramatic reality_. She has endeavored to show\r\nit fairly, in its best and its worst phases. In its _best_ aspect, she\r\nhas, perhaps, been successful; but, oh! who shall say what yet remains\r\nuntold in that valley and shadow of death, that lies the other side?\r\n\r\nTo you, generous, noble-minded men and women, of the South,\xe2\x80\x94you, whose\r\nvirtue, and magnanimity and purity of character, are the greater for\r\nthe severer trial it has encountered,\xe2\x80\x94to you is her appeal. Have you\r\nnot, in your own secret souls, in your own private conversings, felt\r\nthat there are woes and evils, in this accursed system, far beyond what\r\nare here shadowed, or can be shadowed? Can it be otherwise? Is _man_\r\never a creature to be trusted with wholly irresponsible power? And does\r\nnot the slave system, by denying the slave all legal right of\r\ntestimony, make every individual owner an irresponsible despot? Can\r\nanybody fail to make the inference what the practical result will be?\r\nIf there is, as we admit, a public sentiment among you, men of honor,\r\njustice and humanity, is there not also another kind of public\r\nsentiment among the ruffian, the brutal and debased? And cannot the\r\nruffian, the brutal, the debased, by slave law, own just as many slaves\r\nas the best and purest? Are the honorable, the just, the high-minded\r\nand compassionate, the majority anywhere in this world?\r\n\r\nThe slave-trade is now, by American law, considered as piracy. But a\r\nslave-trade, as systematic as ever was carried on on the coast of\r\nAfrica, is an inevitable attendant and result of American slavery. And\r\nits heart-break and its horrors, can they be told?\r\n\r\nThe writer has given only a faint shadow, a dim picture, of the anguish\r\nand despair that are, at this very moment, riving thousands of hearts,\r\nshattering thousands of families, and driving a helpless and sensitive\r\nrace to frenzy and despair. There are those living who know the mothers\r\nwhom this accursed traffic has driven to the murder of their children;\r\nand themselves seeking in death a shelter from woes more dreaded than\r\ndeath. Nothing of tragedy can be written, can be spoken, can be\r\nconceived, that equals the frightful reality of scenes daily and hourly\r\nacting on our shores, beneath the shadow of American law, and the\r\nshadow of the cross of Christ.\r\n\r\nAnd now, men and women of America, is this a thing to be trifled with,\r\napologized for, and passed over in silence? Farmers of Massachusetts,\r\nof New Hampshire, of Vermont, of Connecticut, who read this book by the\r\nblaze of your winter-evening fire,\xe2\x80\x94strong-hearted, generous sailors and\r\nship-owners of Maine,\xe2\x80\x94is this a thing for you to countenance and\r\nencourage? Brave and generous men of New York, farmers of rich and\r\njoyous Ohio, and ye of the wide prairie states,\xe2\x80\x94answer, is this a thing\r\nfor you to protect and countenance? And you, mothers of America,\xe2\x80\x94you\r\nwho have learned, by the cradles of your own children, to love and feel\r\nfor all mankind,\xe2\x80\x94by the sacred love you bear your child; by your joy in\r\nhis beautiful, spotless infancy; by the motherly pity and tenderness\r\nwith which you guide his growing years; by the anxieties of his\r\neducation; by the prayers you breathe for his soul\xe2\x80\x99s eternal good;\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nbeseech you, pity the mother who has all your affections, and not one\r\nlegal right to protect, guide, or educate, the child of her bosom! By\r\nthe sick hour of your child; by those dying eyes, which you can never\r\nforget; by those last cries, that wrung your heart when you could\r\nneither help nor save; by the desolation of that empty cradle, that\r\nsilent nursery,\xe2\x80\x94I beseech you, pity those mothers that are constantly\r\nmade childless by the American slave-trade! And say, mothers of\r\nAmerica, is this a thing to be defended, sympathized with, passed over\r\nin silence?\r\n\r\nDo you say that the people of the free state have nothing to do with\r\nit, and can do nothing? Would to God this were true! But it is not\r\ntrue. The people of the free states have defended, encouraged, and\r\nparticipated; and are more guilty for it, before God, than the South,\r\nin that they have not the apology of education or custom.\r\n\r\nIf the mothers of the free states had all felt as they should, in times\r\npast, the sons of the free states would not have been the holders, and,\r\nproverbially, the hardest masters of slaves; the sons of the free\r\nstates would not have connived at the extension of slavery, in our\r\nnational body; the sons of the free states would not, as they do, trade\r\nthe souls and bodies of men as an equivalent to money, in their\r\nmercantile dealings. There are multitudes of slaves temporarily owned,\r\nand sold again, by merchants in northern cities; and shall the whole\r\nguilt or obloquy of slavery fall only on the South?\r\n\r\nNorthern men, northern mothers, northern Christians, have something\r\nmore to do than denounce their brethren at the South; they have to look\r\nto the evil among themselves.\r\n\r\nBut, what can any individual do? Of that, every individual can judge.\r\nThere is one thing that every individual can do,\xe2\x80\x94they can see to it\r\nthat _they feel right_. An atmosphere of sympathetic influence\r\nencircles every human being; and the man or woman who _feels_ strongly,\r\nhealthily and justly, on the great interests of humanity, is a constant\r\nbenefactor to the human race. See, then, to your sympathies in this\r\nmatter! Are they in harmony with the sympathies of Christ? or are they\r\nswayed and perverted by the sophistries of worldly policy?\r\n\r\nChristian men and women of the North! still further,\xe2\x80\x94you have another\r\npower; you can _pray!_ Do you believe in prayer? or has it become an\r\nindistinct apostolic tradition? You pray for the heathen abroad; pray\r\nalso for the heathen at home. And pray for those distressed Christians\r\nwhose whole chance of religious improvement is an accident of trade and\r\nsale; from whom any adherence to the morals of Christianity is, in many\r\ncases, an impossibility, unless they have given them, from above, the\r\ncourage and grace of martyrdom.\r\n\r\nBut, still more. On the shores of our free states are emerging the\r\npoor, shattered, broken remnants of families,\xe2\x80\x94men and women, escaped,\r\nby miraculous providences from the surges of slavery,\xe2\x80\x94feeble in\r\nknowledge, and, in many cases, infirm in moral constitution, from a\r\nsystem which confounds and confuses every principle of Christianity and\r\nmorality. They come to seek a refuge among you; they come to seek\r\neducation, knowledge, Christianity.\r\n\r\nWhat do you owe to these poor unfortunates, oh Christians? Does not\r\nevery American Christian owe to the African race some effort at\r\nreparation for the wrongs that the American nation has brought upon\r\nthem? Shall the doors of churches and school-houses be shut upon them?\r\nShall states arise and shake them out? Shall the church of Christ hear\r\nin silence the taunt that is thrown at them, and shrink away from the\r\nhelpless hand that they stretch out; and, by her silence, encourage the\r\ncruelty that would chase them from our borders? If it must be so, it\r\nwill be a mournful spectacle. If it must be so, the country will have\r\nreason to tremble, when it remembers that the fate of nations is in the\r\nhands of One who is very pitiful, and of tender compassion.\r\n\r\nDo you say, \xe2\x80\x9cWe don\xe2\x80\x99t want them here; let them go to Africa\xe2\x80\x9d?\r\n\r\nThat the providence of God has provided a refuge in Africa, is, indeed,\r\na great and noticeable fact; but that is no reason why the church of\r\nChrist should throw off that responsibility to this outcast race which\r\nher profession demands of her.\r\n\r\nTo fill up Liberia with an ignorant, inexperienced, half-barbarized\r\nrace, just escaped from the chains of slavery, would be only to\r\nprolong, for ages, the period of struggle and conflict which attends\r\nthe inception of new enterprises. Let the church of the north receive\r\nthese poor sufferers in the spirit of Christ; receive them to the\r\neducating advantages of Christian republican society and schools, until\r\nthey have attained to somewhat of a moral and intellectual maturity,\r\nand then assist them in their passage to those shores, where they may\r\nput in practice the lessons they have learned in America.\r\n\r\nThere is a body of men at the north, comparatively small, who have been\r\ndoing this; and, as the result, this country has already seen examples\r\nof men, formerly slaves, who have rapidly acquired property,\r\nreputation, and education. Talent has been developed, which,\r\nconsidering the circumstances, is certainly remarkable; and, for moral\r\ntraits of honesty, kindness, tenderness of feeling,\xe2\x80\x94for heroic efforts\r\nand self-denials, endured for the ransom of brethren and friends yet in\r\nslavery,\xe2\x80\x94they have been remarkable to a degree that, considering the\r\ninfluence under which they were born, is surprising.\r\n\r\nThe writer has lived, for many years, on the frontier-line of slave\r\nstates, and has had great opportunities of observation among those who\r\nformerly were slaves. They have been in her family as servants; and, in\r\ndefault of any other school to receive them, she has, in many cases,\r\nhad them instructed in a family school, with her own children. She has\r\nalso the testimony of missionaries, among the fugitives in Canada, in\r\ncoincidence with her own experience; and her deductions, with regard to\r\nthe capabilities of the race, are encouraging in the highest degree.\r\n\r\nThe first desire of the emancipated slave, generally, is for\r\n_education_. There is nothing that they are not willing to give or do\r\nto have their children instructed, and, so far as the writer has\r\nobserved herself, or taken the testimony of teachers among them, they\r\nare remarkably intelligent and quick to learn. The results of schools,\r\nfounded for them by benevolent individuals in Cincinnati, fully\r\nestablish this.\r\n\r\nThe author gives the following statement of facts, on the authority of\r\nProfessor C. E. Stowe, then of Lane Seminary, Ohio, with regard to\r\nemancipated slaves, now resident in Cincinnati; given to show the\r\ncapability of the race, even without any very particular assistance or\r\nencouragement.\r\n\r\nThe initial letters alone are given. They are all residents of\r\nCincinnati.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cB\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94. Furniture maker; twenty years in the city; worth ten thousand\r\ndollars, all his own earnings; a Baptist.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cC\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94. Full black; stolen from Africa; sold in New Orleans; been free\r\nfifteen years; paid for himself six hundred dollars; a farmer; owns\r\nseveral farms in Indiana; Presbyterian; probably worth fifteen or\r\ntwenty thousand dollars, all earned by himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cK\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94. Full black; dealer in real estate; worth thirty thousand dollars;\r\nabout forty years old; free six years; paid eighteen hundred dollars\r\nfor his family; member of the Baptist church; received a legacy from\r\nhis master, which he has taken good care of, and increased.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cG\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94. Full black; coal dealer; about thirty years old; worth eighteen\r\nthousand dollars; paid for himself twice, being once defrauded to the\r\namount of sixteen hundred dollars; made all his money by his own\r\nefforts\xe2\x80\x94much of it while a slave, hiring his time of his master, and\r\ndoing business for himself; a fine, gentlemanly fellow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cW\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94. Three-fourths black; barber and waiter; from Kentucky; nineteen\r\nyears free; paid for self and family over three thousand dollars;\r\ndeacon in the Baptist church.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cG. D\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94. Three-fourths black; white-washer; from Kentucky; nine years\r\nfree; paid fifteen hundred dollars for self and family; recently died,\r\naged sixty; worth six thousand dollars.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nProfessor Stowe says, \xe2\x80\x9cWith all these, except G\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94, I have been, for\r\nsome years, personally acquainted, and make my statements from my own\r\nknowledge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe writer well remembers an aged colored woman, who was employed as a\r\nwasherwoman in her father\xe2\x80\x99s family. The daughter of this woman married\r\na slave. She was a remarkably active and capable young woman, and, by\r\nher industry and thrift, and the most persevering self-denial, raised\r\nnine hundred dollars for her husband\xe2\x80\x99s freedom, which she paid, as she\r\nraised it, into the hands of his master. She yet wanted a hundred\r\ndollars of the price, when he died. She never recovered any of the\r\nmoney.\r\n\r\nThese are but few facts, among multitudes which might be adduced, to\r\nshow the self-denial, energy, patience, and honesty, which the slave\r\nhas exhibited in a state of freedom.\r\n\r\nAnd let it be remembered that these individuals have thus bravely\r\nsucceeded in conquering for themselves comparative wealth and social\r\nposition, in the face of every disadvantage and discouragement. The\r\ncolored man, by the law of Ohio, cannot be a voter, and, till within a\r\nfew years, was even denied the right of testimony in legal suits with\r\nthe white. Nor are these instances confined to the State of Ohio. In\r\nall states of the Union we see men, but yesterday burst from the\r\nshackles of slavery, who, by a self-educating force, which cannot be\r\ntoo much admired, have risen to highly respectable stations in society.\r\nPennington, among clergymen, Douglas and Ward, among editors, are well\r\nknown instances.\r\n\r\nIf this persecuted race, with every discouragement and disadvantage,\r\nhave done thus much, how much more they might do if the Christian\r\nchurch would act towards them in the spirit of her Lord!\r\n\r\nThis is an age of the world when nations are trembling and convulsed. A\r\nmighty influence is abroad, surging and heaving the world, as with an\r\nearthquake. And is America safe? Every nation that carries in its bosom\r\ngreat and unredressed injustice has in it the elements of this last\r\nconvulsion.\r\n\r\nFor what is this mighty influence thus rousing in all nations and\r\nlanguages those groanings that cannot be uttered, for man\xe2\x80\x99s freedom and\r\nequality?\r\n\r\nO, Church of Christ, read the signs of the times! Is not this power the\r\nspirit of Him whose kingdom is yet to come, and whose will to be done\r\non earth as it is in heaven?\r\n\r\nBut who may abide the day of his appearing? \xe2\x80\x9cfor that day shall burn as\r\nan oven: and he shall appear as a swift witness against those that\r\noppress the hireling in his wages, the widow and the fatherless, and\r\nthat _turn aside the stranger in his right_: and he shall break in\r\npieces the oppressor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAre not these dread words for a nation bearing in her bosom so mighty\r\nan injustice? Christians! every time that you pray that the kingdom of\r\nChrist may come, can you forget that prophecy associates, in dread\r\nfellowship, the _day of vengeance_ with the year of his redeemed?\r\n\r\nA day of grace is yet held out to us. Both North and South have been\r\nguilty before God; and the _Christian church_ has a heavy account to\r\nanswer. Not by combining together, to protect injustice and cruelty,\r\nand making a common capital of sin, is this Union to be saved,\xe2\x80\x94but by\r\nrepentance, justice and mercy; for, not surer is the eternal law by\r\nwhich the millstone sinks in the ocean, than that stronger law, by\r\nwhich injustice and cruelty shall bring on nations the wrath of\r\nAlmighty God!\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nEnd of the Project Gutenberg EBook of Uncle Tom\xe2\x80\x99s Cabin, by Harriet Beecher Stowe\r\n\r\n*** END OF THIS PROJECT GUTENBERG EBOOK UNCLE TOM\xe2\x80\x99S CABIN ***\r\n\r\n***** This file should be named 203-0.txt or 203-0.zip *****\r\nThis and all associated files of various formats will be found in:\r\n        http://www.gutenberg.org/2/0/203/\r\n\r\nProduced by Judith Boss, An Anonymous Volunteer and David Widger\r\n\r\nUpdated editions will replace the previous one--the old editions will\r\nbe renamed.\r\n\r\nCreating the works from print editions not protected by U.S. copyright\r\nlaw means that no one owns a United States copyright in these works,\r\nso the Foundation (and you!) can copy and distribute it in the United\r\nStates without permission and without paying copyright\r\nroyalties.
